site_title: GIC, global investors to take 4.4b euro majority stake in AccorInvest
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC, along with international investors, has agreed to acquire a 55% stake in AccorInvest, the property business arm of French hotel chain AccorHotels, for 4.4 billion euros. The sale includes luxury brands Raffles and Novotel, and budget brand Ibis, with operations in 27 countries and 30,000 employees. The deal is expected to be finalized in the second quarter this year, subject to regulatory approvals, and will provide GIC with exposure to AccorInvest's diversified portfolio.

site_title: Sentosa Cove penthouse sold at S$2.4m loss
summary: A two-level penthouse in Sentosa Cove was sold at Edmund Tie & Company's auction for S$3.25 million, or S$1,105 per square feet, resulting in a loss of about S$2.4 million, or 42%, from its original purchase price of S$5.64 million in 2011. This is the first mortgagee sale of a Sentosa Cove property in 2018, following a trend of four similar sales in the past two years, with prices ranging from 40-51% below their original values.

site_title: Astronomers detect signal of Universe's first stars
summary: Astronomers have detected a signal from the Universe's first stars, born 13.6 billion years ago, using a radio spectrometer in the Australian desert. The signal, detected after a decade-long quest, provides a window into the early Universe and may shed light on dark matter, an invisible substance making up 85% of the Universe's matter. The findings suggest the Universe was twice as cold as previously estimated, at -270°C, and may explain dark matter's existence through ordinary matter's interaction with it.

site_title: SGX among contenders said to be eyeing Tel Aviv Stock Exchange
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is among the contenders vying for a controlling stake in the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange (TASE), according to Israeli media reports. Over 10 foreign exchanges, including SGX, London, Toronto, and Hong Kong, have expressed interest in buying a 71.7% stake valued at around US$147 million. The TASE aims to strengthen its global competitive position and attract overseas investors through the strategic investment. This comes as the exchange has seen a slump in trading volumes and around 200 de-listings over the past decade.

site_title: US: Stocks fall again on rate worries, Dow loses 1.5%
summary: US stocks fell for the second consecutive session, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 1.5% to close at 25,028.37. The decline was driven by concerns over higher interest rates, sparked by Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's congressional testimony. Petroleum-linked shares tumbled following a bearish US oil inventory report, while other companies like Lowe's and TJX Companies reported mixed earnings. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also fell, with the Nasdaq losing 0.8%.

site_title: Carousell partners MoneySmart to bring personal finance to mobile app
summary: Carousell has partnered with MoneySmart to introduce a personal finance portal within its mobile app, allowing users to access credit card offers and apply for financial products directly within the app. The partnership aims to make personal finance more accessible and trustworthy for mobile-first customers. The finance category will expand to include recommendations for travel insurance and savings accounts within the year. The collaboration aims to provide users with hassle-free access to financial products and expert advice, helping them make informed decisions about their personal finance.

site_title: MindChamps eyes China market, aims to be leading preschool brand globally
summary: MindChamps PreSchool, Singapore's largest premium preschool provider, plans to expand into the China market by August 2018. The company aims to become a leading preschool brand globally, targeting other key markets such as the UK, Australia, and the US. MindChamps has entered a joint venture agreement with China First Capital Group to establish a China Preschool Fund, which will raise US$200 million. The company reported a 15% decline in net profit to S$4.6 million for FY2017, due to higher costs and expenses.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Help SMEs scale to compete globally, MPs urge
summary: Singaporean Members of Parliament (MPs) have urged the government to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) scale up and compete globally. MPs pointed out that local firms often receive subcontracted jobs in major projects, such as the rail system, while large foreign firms handle the main contracts. The MPs' call comes as the government prepares its 2018 budget, with a focus on supporting SMEs to improve their competitiveness in the global market.

site_title: Marshall Islands to issue own sovereign cryptocurrency
summary: The Marshall Islands will issue its own cryptocurrency, called SOV, which will be legal tender along with the US dollar. The country's parliament has approved the plan, and the SOV will be issued through an initial coin offering. The 24 million tokens are capped to prevent inflation, and the government plans to use part of the proceeds to finance the National Trust Fund. The new currency is based on the "Yakwe framework," which requires users to identify themselves on the blockchain, addressing the anonymity issue in traditional cryptocurrencies.

site_title: Here's what we learnt from the new Fed chief's first testimony
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell testified before the House Financial Services Committee, providing an upbeat economic assessment and hinting at a differing approach from his predecessor Janet Yellen. Markets reacted positively to his comments, but the article's main focus is on unrelated news from July 11, 2025, including China's slowing GDP growth, Chinese banks struggling with consumer lending, and Trump imposing tariffs on Canada.

images.alt_text: Mr Powell says his focus as Fed chief is on the economy and thus, near-term gyrations in the stock market are unlikely to faze him.

site_title: Asia: Markets see in March with another sell-off
summary: Asian markets experienced a sharp sell-off in March, driven by US interest rate hike fears and plunging oil prices. The sell-off, which began in February, was fueled by concerns over the strong US economy and Donald Trump's tax cuts leading to higher borrowing costs. Energy firms were particularly affected, with petroleum-linked stocks plummeting due to higher US shale production and a stronger dollar. The sell-off extended across Asia, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Singapore experiencing significant losses.

site_title: China approves US$5.3b plans for Beijing-Xiongan rail link
summary: China has approved plans to build a $5.3 billion rail link connecting Beijing with Xiongan in Hebei province, with a projected annual passenger capacity of 50 million. The 92.4km rail project will include five new stations and link to Beijing's new international airport.

site_title: Macau casino revenue growth falls short of expectations in February
summary: Macau's casino revenue grew 5.7% in February, falling short of expected 7-12% growth, but marking the 19th consecutive month of gains. Revenue reached 24.3 billion patacas ($4.02 billion), the third highest in the past 12 months. The number of visitors rose 6.5% during the national holiday week, while casino operators' fourth-quarter earnings exceeded analyst expectations. Macau's gross gaming revenue is expected to reach $60 billion by 2022, driven by increased tourism and infrastructure developments.

images.alt_text: Gambling revenue in the Chinese territory of Macau rose 5.7 per cent in February, less than analysts had expected for the big-spending holiday period but still the 19th month of consecutive gains in the world's largest gambling hub.

site_title: Innovation, digital economy key areas for Singapore's Asean chairmanship: Hng Kiang
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Lim Hng Kiang emphasized innovation and the digital economy as key areas for the country's Asean chairmanship in 2018. The country aims to deepen regional connectivity, strengthen Asean cohesion, and position the region for growth through initiatives like the AEC Blueprint 2025. Singapore seeks to leverage innovation to drive economic activity and growth, particularly in areas such as advanced chip packaging and sustainable aviation.

site_title: Gold steadies after sell-off linked to hawkish Fed, strong dollar
summary: Gold prices steadied on Wednesday after a 1% fall the previous day due to hawkish Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's comments that the US central bank would raise interest rates four times this year. The dollar surged to a five-week high, making gold costlier for investors using other currencies. Powell's upbeat assessment of the US economy lifted the dollar, which in turn affected gold prices.

images.alt_text: Gold prices steadied on Wednesday after the previous session's more than 1 per cent fall following comments by the Federal Reserve's new chairman that fueled views the US central bank would raise rates four times this year rather than three.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SGX, Vard, Yangzijiang, Venture Corp, UOB Kay Hian
summary: Singapore stocks to watch: SGX emerged as a contender for a controlling stake in Tel Aviv Stock Exchange, valued at around US$147 million. Vard Holdings reported a net loss of 131 million Norwegian kronor (S$22.1 million) in Q4, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding saw its net profit jump 12% to 678 million yuan (S$142 million). Venture Corporation's net profit more than doubled to S$143 million, and UOB Kay Hian posted an 85% increase in Q4 net profit to S$21.84 million.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close down on high yen ahead of US data
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on March 1, 2018, as investors locked in profits ahead of US data, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 1.56% to 21,724.47. The dollar's decline further damaged sentiment, following a weaker Wall Street performance. The broader Topix index also dropped 1.59%.

site_title: Oil prices fall on weak Asian industry data and rise in US crude stocks
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday due to weak Asian industry data and rising US crude stocks. US West Texas Intermediate crude dropped 31 cents to $62.70 a barrel, while Brent crude fell 40 cents to $66.23 a barrel. The decline in oil prices comes amid concerns of an economic slowdown and lower oil demand.

images.alt_text: Soaring US production has pressured oil prices at a time when Opec and Russia have reduced output to support prices. "Climbing US production continues to weigh on the market as traders fear that the Opec output cuts will be nullified by the rising US output," said William O'Loughlin, investment analyst at Australia's Rivkin Securities.

site_title: Clearbridge Health full-year loss widens almost 4 times to S$7.47m on fair value loss, non-recurring expenses
summary: Clearbridge Health Limited reported a widened net loss of S$7.47 million for fiscal 2017, almost four times the loss of S$1.95 million in the previous year, due to a fair value loss and non-recurring expenses. Revenue more than doubled to S$288,000, driven by its medical clinics and laboratory testing services businesses. The company has a cash and cash equivalent balance of S$27.74 million and expects to see cost savings after relocating one of its subsidiaries.

site_title: Singapore mobile operator Circles.Life unveils on-demand unlimited data plans
summary: Circles.Life, Singapore's first digital telco, unveiled three new services: Unlimited Data on Demand ($3/day), WhatsApp Passport (unlimited WhatsApp messages overseas for $1/day), and Unlimited Outgoing Calls ($16/month). These services aim to "give power back" to customers, offering flexibility and value. The company plans to expand to Indonesia by the second half of 2018, leveraging its innovative cloud-based infrastructure, Circles-X, to achieve rapid expansion at 5% of the cost.

images.alt_text: Circles.Life's Unlimited Data on Demand add-on requires a basic plan of $28 a month that comes with 6GB of mobile data.

site_title: TSH ceases proposed purchase of Brisbane properties, plans to buy alcohol businesses
summary: TSH Corporation, a Singapore-incorporated company, has ceased its proposed acquisition of four Brisbane properties due to inability to finalize a definitive agreement. Instead, the company has entered into a non-binding agreement with vendors to acquire several alcohol businesses, including pubs and bars, in a bid to meet listing requirements under the Catalist rules. The deal is subject to shareholder approval and Singapore Exchange Securities Trading approval, and TSH will seek a further extension of time to complete the acquisition.

site_title: New York regulator asks Deutsche, other banks about Kushner loans
summary: New York's state banking regulator has requested information from Deutsche Bank, Signature Bank, and New York Community Bank about their relationships with Jared Kushner, US President Donald Trump's son-in-law and White House senior adviser, and his family's real estate company. The requests include loans, lines of credit, and loan guarantees, and Kushner's representatives have declined to comment. The regulator's move comes amid concerns about potential conflicts of interest, following Kushner's resignation from Kushner Cos and sale of his stake to a family trust.

images.alt_text: New York's state banking regulator asked Deutsche Bank AG and two other lenders for information on their relationships with US President Donald Trump's son-in-law and White House senior adviser Jared Kushner and his family's real estate company, a person familiar with the matter told Reuters.

site_title: UK house prices dip unexpectedly in February: Nationwide
summary: UK house prices fell 0.3% month-on-month in February, according to Nationwide, contradicting the consensus of economists who expected a 0.2% increase. This represents a slowdown in annual growth, which rose 2.2% compared to 3.2% in January. The unexpected drop is attributed to a subdued consumer economy, marking a reversal from the previous month's 0.8% rise.

site_title: Car care giant Tyreplus opens first Singapore outlet
summary: Tyreplus, a global car care specialist, has opened its first outlet in Singapore at Wave 9, Woodlands Industrial Park. The 4,575 sq ft outlet will be one of two more set to open this year, aiming to provide services island-wide. This marks the company's expansion into the Singapore market, following its presence in 17 countries with over 2,000 stores.

images.alt_text: Personnel from Tyreplus, Michelin Group and Hock Tyre Group going through the safety check procedure at the Tyreplus outlet at Wave 9. The outlet offers a one-stop car maintenance and repair service, including the changing of tyres, batteries and oil as well as the servicing of air-conditioning and brakes.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.45 points to 1,852.75. Losers outnumbered gainers 213 to 70, and volume was 103.25 million lots worth RM32.78 million.

site_title: Picasso painting of muse, future lover fetches European record of £50m
summary: A Pablo Picasso portrait of his muse Marie-Therese Walter with future lover Dora Maar fetched £50 million (S$91.2 million) at a London sale, setting a European auction record. The 1937 oil on canvas painting, "Femme au Beret et a la Robe Quadrillee (Marie-Therese Walter)", was sold at Sotheby's, beating expectations of £36 million. The sale marked the first time the painting had emerged on the international art market, highlighting its importance as a museum-quality piece from a key era in Picasso's career.

site_title: Japan PM Abe climbs down on contentious labour reform after data flaws
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has abandoned a contentious labour law reform aimed at boosting productivity after admitting data flaws. The reform, part of "Abenomics," would have expanded a discretionary labour system, but Abe confirmed its deletion after the government revealed flawed data. The move is likely to disappoint businesses and investors, who had been expecting the reforms. Abe has asked the labour ministry to reassess the situation and debate the proposals again.

site_title: Business lending risks losing steam
summary: Singapore's business lending saw a 5.6% year-on-year growth in January, the slowest pace of expansion since January 2017, at S$387 billion. This is due to a moderation in business lending, particularly in the building and construction segment, which contracted by 1.4% to S$120 billion. Consumer loans, however, gained ground, expanding 5.2% to S$263 billion, driven by housing loans and share financing. Experts expect 2018 total bank loans growth to slow to around 4% due to a benign macroeconomic outlook.

site_title: Australia Q4 business investment in surprise dip, but firms raise spending plans
summary: Australian business investment unexpectedly decreased 0.2% in the December quarter to A$29.6 billion, missing forecasts. However, investment in equipment and plant rose 2.2%, indicating a positive sign for economic growth. Firms also increased spending plans for the year to June, exceeding forecasts. The Reserve Bank of Australia remains optimistic about investment, driven by booming public spending on infrastructure and stabilizing mining investment.

site_title: Pointy-eared mascots picked for Tokyo 2020
summary: Tokyo's 2020 Olympics and Paralympics mascots, featuring pointy-eared characters with chequered patterns, were unveiled in Tokyo. The blue mascot, chosen by schoolchildren, will represent the Olympics, while the pink cherry blossom-inspired mascot will represent the Paralympics. Over 2,000 designs were submitted, and the winning pair, created by Ryo Taniguchi, received over half of the total votes. The names of the mascots will be announced later this year, and discussions will begin on producing goods featuring the characters.

site_title: Swedes now at risk of losing access to cash in parts of country
summary: Swedish authorities are considering forcing banks and retailers to continue accepting cash, amid concerns that the country's cashless society may lead to a loss of access to notes and coins. Loomis AB, a cash-handling provider, is urging the authorities to take action to avoid this extreme scenario. The move comes as Sweden's reliance on digital payments continues to grow, and the country's cashless status has raised concerns about the potential impact on vulnerable populations and the economy.

site_title: Datapulse shareholders to cast votes at April 20 EGM
summary: Datapulse Technology's extraordinary general meeting (EGM) has been set for April 20. Shareholders will vote on a proposed change of board and possible diversification into a consumer and/or investment business. The meeting comes after a fresh requisition notice from Datapulse co-founder's daughter, Ng Bie Tjin, seeking to oust recently-appointed directors and replace them. The proposed diversification, known as Ordinary Resolution 9, would be subject to an independent review, but not put up for voting if a board reshuffle occurs.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Global trade cools China's factories amid CNY pause
summary: China's manufacturing purchasing managers index fell to 50.3 in February, the biggest slump in five years, indicating a cooling in global demand for Chinese factories. New export orders declined for the second month, while the services PMI also dropped. The decline is attributed to a pause in the Chinese yuan, which may be affecting global trade. The data suggests China's GDP growth is set to slow, putting pressure on policymakers to address the issue.

site_title: Pervasive innovation, not Singapore Budget 2018 goodies, can help firms thrive
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat highlighted the importance of pervasive innovation in firms' success. Pan United, a concrete supplier, leveraged innovation to develop a breakthrough product and become a market leader. Firms like Grab, a ride-hailing app, also successfully embedded data analytics into their culture, enabling strategic business decisions and driving growth. Education institutions, such as PSB Academy, can adopt edtech to promote lifelong learning and enhance graduate outcomes. Ultimately, businesses, not government agencies, should create jobs and drive productivity improvements by embracing pervasive innovation.

images.alt_text: Grab is just one of many firms that are reaping the dividends of deep capabilities such as self-service data analytics.

site_title: CapitaLand buys prime site for its first integrated project in Hanoi; sets up US$130m fund
summary: CapitaLand has acquired a prime site in Hanoi's Tay Ho district for its first integrated development, valued at approximately US$217 million. The mixed-use project will feature a 380-unit residence, 230,000 square feet of office space, and 208,000 sq ft of retail space. CapitaLand has set up a US$130 million fund, with a 50-50 stake, to focus on grade A commercial properties in Vietnam, aiming to expand its presence in the city and drive long-term growth.

site_title: Aluminum foil imports from China dumped, subsidised: US
summary: The US Commerce Department has imposed anti-dumping and countervailing duties on Chinese firms importing aluminum foil, citing unfair trade practices. The duties, ranging from 17.14% to 106.09%, will be in effect for five years. China has expressed "strong dissatisfaction" and will take necessary measures to protect its interests. This move comes amid mounting trade friction between the US and China, with US President Donald Trump set to decide on broader duties on steel and aluminum imports.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Golden Agri-Resources reported FY17 core net profit below expectations due to lower FFB production, accounting for 70% of forecasts. The group blames the 2015 El Nino drought and projects a strong recovery in 2018 with an 8-10% increase in FFB output.

site_title: Cryptocurrencies are for gamblers, not investors
summary: A professional economist argues that cryptocurrencies, such as Bitcoin, are not suitable for investment and are more about entertainment due to their volatile prices and lack of value. Unlike traditional currencies, cryptocurrencies do not satisfy the basic requirements of money and are not backed by a central authority. The economist suggests renaming them to "crypto cyber units" to minimize confusion and encourage investors to view them as a form of entertainment rather than a legitimate investment opportunity.

site_title: Top Trump aide Hope Hicks to resign
summary: Hope Hicks, a 29-year-old former model and PR operative, announced her resignation as a top aide to President Donald Trump, marking the latest departure from the embattled White House. Hicks, who was communications director, was known for her close relationship with the president's family and her efforts to defend his image. Her resignation comes after a string of departures from the White House, including other high-ranking officials.

site_title: Walmart raises to 21 minimum age to buy firearms, ammunition
summary: US retail giant Walmart announced it will raise the minimum age to buy firearms and ammunition to 21 years, following the deadly Florida school shooting. The retailer will also remove assault-style rifle items from its website and stop selling bump stocks and high-capacity magazines. This decision comes as the US gun industry faces a growing corporate backlash, with companies cutting ties with the National Rifle Association gun lobbyists. Dick's Sporting Goods also announced it will bar gun sales to anyone under 21 years old.

site_title: Maybank, CIMB post mixed quarterly results
summary: Malaysia's largest bank, Maybank, reported an 11% drop in Q4 net profit, while its competitor CIMB saw a 24% jump in earnings. Maybank attributed the decline to volatile markets, but maintained a record performance for 2017. CIMB aims to boost loan growth in its Thailand, Indonesia, and Singapore units, targeting mid single-digit growth in Indonesia and high single-digit growth in Thailand and Singapore. The banks' performances reflect the challenging 2018 market conditions.

site_title: MAS scraps S$50,000 issue limit for Singapore Savings Bonds
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has lifted the S$50,000 cap on the maximum amount an individual can hold of each issue of Singapore Savings Bonds (SSBs), effective immediately. This change aims to simplify the SSB programme, allowing investors to apply for a larger amount of a particular issue. The individual limit for total SSB holdings remains at S$100,000.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: South Korea: Financial markets closed on Thursday
summary: South Korea's financial markets were closed on Thursday for a public holiday, resuming trade on Friday, March 2. This news does not appear to be related to the provided articles, which focus on Singapore and Asia markets, as well as global economic and stock market updates.

site_title: Singapore will feel global flare-ups acutely: EIU
summary: Singapore's economy is vulnerable to global risks, including a slump in global trade, market crashes, and territorial disputes, according to the Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU). The city-state's trade-oriented economy makes it susceptible to a decline in global trade, with a trade-to-GDP ratio of around 400%. Despite this, Singapore's economy is expected to benefit from healthy global trade growth. However, risks such as cyber attacks, terrorism, and diplomatic pressure from major trading partners, particularly China, must be monitored. The government's strong finances and willingness to adapt to external shocks mitigate the risk of recession.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Ex-City Harvest Church leader Chew Eng Han begins jail term
summary: Former City Harvest Church leader Chew Eng Han began serving a three years and four months jail term for his role in misusing millions in church funds. He was initially scheduled to start his sentence in February but was arrested for trying to flee to Malaysia on a motorised boat. Five other church leaders, including founder-pastor Kong Hee, began serving their sentences in April last year. Chew was allowed to defer his sentence after Chinese New Year, but his case will be mentioned on March 29. Boatman Tan Poh Teck, 53, faces an amended charge and a fresh charge related to his alleged involvement in helping Chew flee.

site_title: InnoTek declares one S cent dividend as Q4 earnings fall 42% to S$2.8m
summary: InnoTek Limited, a precision metal components manufacturer, has declared a one-cent dividend for fiscal 2017, following a request by Gazelle Capital to declare a 7.5-cent dividend. The company reported a 42% decrease in Q4 net profit to S$2.8 million, with revenue increasing 1.3% to S$56.1 million. Full-year revenue and net profit fell 1% and 15% respectively, due to lower demand for office automation and consumer products.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on lingering rate hike fears
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on March 1, 2018, due to lingering fears of higher interest rates and a stronger yen. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.87% to 21,877.29, while the Topix index dropped 0.93% to 1,751.81. This follows similar falls on Wall Street, indicating a global market trend. The decline was attributed to concerns about interest rate hikes and their impact on the economy.

site_title: Rio Tinto and BHP drag Aussie shares lower; NZ snaps 6 session winning streak
summary: Australian shares fell 0.7% on Thursday, led by declines in Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton due to weakening commodity prices and concerns over rising US interest rates. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,973.3 points. The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates, which may add to uncertainty. Other key drops included commercial explosives maker Orica and struggling construction company Fletcher Building.

site_title: Facebook says finds no new evidence Russia interfered in Brexit referendum
summary: Facebook has found no new evidence that Russia interfered in the 2016 Brexit referendum. A recent investigation by the company, led by UK policy director Simon Milner, failed to identify any coordinated Russian-linked accounts or ads promoting the EU Referendum. This finding contrasts with Facebook's US investigation, which has resulted in indictments against Russian individuals and entities. The UK parliamentary committee has expressed concerns about social media's role in spreading fake news and is likely to make recommendations for new laws or regulations.

site_title: GST hike 'not an option that we have taken lightly': Heng Swee Keat
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that the upcoming Goods and Services Tax (GST) hike is necessary to maintain the country's long-term fiscal health, despite concerns from MPs. The GST will increase by two percentage points from 7% to 9% between 2021 and 2025, with revenue expected to rise by 0.7% of GDP or S$3 billion annually. The increase aims to cover rising healthcare, security, and social spending, and the government will assess economic conditions to determine the timing of the hike.

site_title: Sri Lankan businesses with disputes can look to Singapore for arbitration
summary: Sri Lanka's businesses can consider Singapore as a hub for arbitration due to its favorable environment, with minimal judicial interference and a robust framework for recognizing and enforcing foreign arbitral awards. The country's Arbitration Act of 1995 and the New York Convention have created a suitable framework, but challenges persist, including delays and lack of expertise. In contrast, Singapore has become a leading arbitration hub, supported by its legislative framework, world-class infrastructure, and the Singapore International Arbitration Centre (SIAC). The two countries recently signed a free-trade agreement, which includes the SIAC as a venue for investor-state disputes.

site_title: Euro falls as dollar gains after recent sell-off
summary: The euro fell to a six-week low against the dollar, reaching $1.2215, after a hawkish signal from the US Federal Reserve and slower eurozone inflation. The dollar rose 0.2% to 90.5, a three-week high, amid investor expectations of a stronger US economy and potential rate hikes. Eurozone inflation slowed to a 14-month low, reinforcing the European Central Bank's caution in removing stimulus. The euro could fall to $1.20, but may rise to $1.30 in the long term if the eurozone economy improves.

site_title: Australia amnesty takes 57,000 guns off the streets
summary: Australia's three-month gun amnesty collected 57,324 firearms, including 2,500 fully-automatic and semi-automatic weapons. The campaign, which ran from July to September 2017, aims to remove illegal guns from the streets and prevent them from falling into the hands of criminals. The move follows strict gun laws enacted in 1996 after a mass shooting, resulting in no mass shootings since. Law Enforcement Minister Angus Taylor said the campaign demonstrates what can be achieved when governments and the public work together to make communities safer.

site_title: Singapore shares enter afternoon session lower on Thursday; STI at 3,504.33, down 0.4% on day
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.4% in the afternoon session, with the Straits Times Index at 3,504.33, down 13.61 points. About 1.01 billion shares changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 233 to 120. Key stocks, including Thai Beverage, Golden Agri-Resources, and DBS, declined. The rally in Singapore stocks, which reached a 5-day high, may be affected by tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: MindChamps full-year profit down 15% as costs, expenses offset higher revenue
summary: MindChamps PreSchool reported a 15% decline in full-year net profit to S$4.6 million, due to higher cost of sales and operating expenses offsetting a 24% revenue rise. Revenue increased to S$22.8 million, driven by increased student enrollment and franchisee-owned-franchisee-operated centres. The group plans to expand in China, Myanmar, and Vietnam, with a joint venture agreement to establish a China Preschool Fund targeting a US$200 million initial tranche.

site_title: Alibaba sets up AI research centre in Singapore
summary: Alibaba has opened an artificial intelligence (AI) research institute in Singapore, in partnership with Nanyang Technological University (NTU), marking the Chinese e-commerce giant's first joint research centre outside mainland China. The institute aims to develop cutting-edge AI technologies in areas such as elderly care and urban transport. This move intensifies the battle to develop AI technology and highlights Singapore's growing importance in the field. The partnership is expected to foster innovation and research in AI.

site_title: New study finds 1 in 4 teens sexting; experts say it's normal
summary: A new study analyzing 39 previous studies with 110,000 participants found that nearly 1 in 4 teenagers (25%) reported receiving a sext, and 15% reported sending one. The study suggests that sexting may be an emerging component of teenage sexual behavior and development, but also notes that nonconsensual sexting is a concern. Experts emphasize the need for education and understanding around teenage sexting, rather than punitive measures, to address potential negative mental health effects.

site_title: Q4 GDP growth revised down to 2.5 %
summary: US economic growth slowed to 2.5% in the fourth quarter of 2017, revised down from the initial 2.6% estimate. The slowdown was due to a smaller inventory build than previously reported, and it followed a 3.2% growth pace in the third quarter. Consumer spending remained strong, growing at a 3.8% rate, but companies failed to meet this demand, leading to a surge in imports and a trade deficit. Economists expect the economy to rebound in the first half of the year, with growth estimates for the first quarter ranging from 1.8% to 2.2%.

site_title: HK warns potential home buyers to assess risks fully before jumping in
summary: Hong Kong's Financial Secretary Paul Chan warns potential home buyers to "carefully assess the risks" before entering the market due to expected pressure from rising interest rates and increased supply of flats. Despite record-breaking private home prices, Chan did not announce any immediate measures to curb the market. Analysts predict further 5-20% price increases in 2018, with the government expecting to fetch HK$121 billion from land premiums.

site_title: Singapore Feb market cap down 1.6% month-on-month to S$1.01 trillion
summary: Singapore's stock market experienced a 1.6% decline in February, with the benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) falling 0.8% to S$594.5 billion. Despite this, the market still saw gains from banks and manufacturers, driven by strong loan growth and industrial production. Notable performers included DBS, OCBC, and Venture Corp, while Telcos and offshore heavyweights suffered losses. Experts believe the market has sufficient valuation cushion to withstand potential rises in US bond yields, and a broad-based sell-off is unlikely.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: STI falls 0.6% on fears of faster rate hikes
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.6% to 3,517.94 points on February 28, 2018, amid fears of faster US rate hikes. Investors were cautious after Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's upbeat assessment of the US economy. Weak macro data from China, Japan, and India also contributed to the decline. Despite this, some analysts expect the Fed to hike rates, while others caution against an overreaction.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: GIC in 5.5b Mexican peso JV to develop and operate rental apartment buildings in Mexico
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has entered a 5.5 billion Mexican peso (S$387.8 million) joint venture to develop and operate rental apartment buildings in Mexico City and Guadalajara. GIC's partner, CCLA, will develop and operate mid-to-high-rise buildings with 250-400 rental units. The joint venture targets sustainable risk-adjusted returns and follows demographic trends similar to the US. This is part of GIC's investment strategy in Latin America, following the acquisition of a 55% stake in AccorHotel's property business arm for 4.4 billion euros.

site_title: Singapore Medical Group more than triples full-year profit to S$8.5m, proposes 1-for-20 rights issue
summary: Singapore Medical Group (SMG) reported a 250.8% jump in net profit to S$8.5 million for its 2017 financial year, driven by growth in healthcare and diagnostic segments. Revenue rose 63.5% to S$68 million. The company proposed a 1-for-20 renounceable non-underwritten rights issue to raise up to S$10.8 million, strengthening its balance sheet for high-growth initiatives. SMG remains poised to scale its pan-Asian specialist healthcare platform in key markets.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Active investment strategies pay off in volatile times
summary: Institutional investors are shifting towards active investment strategies in volatile markets, with 76% saying the current market favors active management. Despite this, passive funds absorbed $692 billion in assets last year, while active funds saw $45 billion in outflows. Investors are diversifying their portfolios with private equity, commodities, and properties, and are willing to pay higher fees for potential outperformance. The survey also found that institutional investors are increasingly focusing on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues and managing longevity risk.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Unwise to amend rules on land sales proceeds, net investment returns: Heng Swee Keat
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of Singapore's approach to land sales proceeds and national reserves, stating it strikes a balance between present needs and preserving resources for future generations. He argued that using 20% of land sale proceeds instead of 100% does not undermine the principle of asset conversion, and instead achieves a balance between supporting current and future generations. The government's net investment returns contribution (NIRC) framework is now the largest contributor to the annual Budget, and amending rules to increase spending would be "ill-disciplined and unwise".

site_title: No pot luck for Singapore investors
summary: Singapore investors are cautious about investing in cannabis-related stocks due to the country's harsh drug laws, which include the death penalty for trafficking and possession of more than 500g of cannabis. While companies like Cronos Group and Aurora Cannabis have gained significantly, investors should tread carefully as cannabis remains a controlled drug under international drug control conventions. The Misuse of Drugs Act prohibits the unauthorised importation, manufacture, cultivation, trafficking, possession, and consumption of controlled drugs, including cannabis.

site_title: Singapore LNG's 4th storage tank on track for completion
summary: Singapore's fourth LNG storage tank, with a capacity of 260,000 cu m, is on track for completion by mid-2018, Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran announced. The tank will be one of the world's largest, offering LNG traders more options and flexibility. SLNG, the Singapore LNG Corporation, plans to use its spare terminal capacity to grow its ancillary services business, which has seen 23 LNG vessel cool-downs and storage & reloads in 2017. This expansion supports Singapore's energy diversification strategy and future economic development in the energy sector.

site_title: Vard sinks deeper into the red with 131m kronor Q4 loss
summary: Vard Holdings Limited reported a Q4 net loss of 131 million Norwegian kronor (S$22.1 million), widening from a year-ago loss of 67 million kronor. Revenue increased 25.3% to 2.69 billion kronor due to higher activity levels at its yards in Romania and Vietnam. For the full year, revenue rose 9% to 8.6 billion kronor, but net loss widened to 233 million kronor. The company aims to sustain and build competitive positions in key markets while stabilizing workloads and undertaking cost reduction efforts.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding increased its equity stake in a Suzhou-registered investment vehicle, valued at 700 million yuan. The company reported a 12% jump in fourth quarter net profit to 677.82 million yuan. Meanwhile, Centurion Corporation posted a 27% fall in net profit to S$9.3 million, and China Everbright Water saw a 46.9% increase in full year earnings. UOB Kay Hian and SIIC Environment Holdings also reported significant increases in net profit.

site_title: KrisEnergy narrows FY17 loss to US$139.2m
summary: KrisEnergy, an upstream oil and gas group, reported a narrowed net loss of $139.2 million for FY17, down from $237.1 million in the previous year. A non-cash impairment of $120.7 million from the Block A Aceh gas project in Indonesia was the main factor. Despite a 21% drop in working interest production, the company maintained year-on-year revenues at $140.7 million due to a near 60% increase in average realised oil price. The company will focus on cost control and core Cambodian and Thai assets.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: US Supreme Court grapples with global access
summary: The US Supreme Court is grappling with a digital-age legal dilemma: whether the US government can use a warrant to force a US company, Microsoft, to turn over data stored in a server overseas. The case involves a drug dealer's e-mails housed in a Microsoft data centre in Ireland. The government argues that the warrant, issued under the Stored Communications Act, allows for the retrieval of data within US borders, while Microsoft claims the law does not reach beyond US borders. A bipartisan bill has been introduced to address the issue, but its fate is unclear.

site_title: Palm oil edges higher on weaker ringgit
summary: Malaysian palm oil futures edged up 0.2% in early trade on Wednesday, extending gains into a fourth session, driven by a weaker ringgit. The benchmark contract rose to 2,547 ringgit (S$858) a tonne, gaining 2.2% in February. A weaker ringgit makes palm oil cheaper for foreign buyers, supporting prices. Trading volumes were 16,131 lots at the midday break, with analysts attributing the gains to the weak ringgit and neutral market conditions.

site_title: CapitaLand buys prime site for its first integrated project in Hanoi; sets up US$130m fund
summary: CapitaLand acquires a prime site in Hanoi, Vietnam for its first integrated development, worth US$217 million. The 25-storey mixed-use project will include residences, office space, and retail areas. A US$130 million commercial fund has been set up, with a life span of eight years, to focus on grade A commercial properties in Vietnam. The fund will be equally held by CapitaLand and MEA Commercial Holdings. This investment aims to diversify and optimize CapitaLand's Vietnam portfolio, expanding its presence in Hanoi and reaffirming its commitment to Vietnam's urbanization journey.

site_title: Summers warns next US recession could outlast previous one
summary: Former US Treasury Secretary Larry Summers warns that the next US recession could last longer than the previous 18-month recession, citing the need for a delicate balance between stimulating the economy and controlling inflation. Summers believes that monetary and fiscal policies have already been "shot the cannons," suggesting a more prolonged recession ahead. This assessment comes as the economy enters its ninth year of expansion, with the Federal Reserve facing a challenging task in striking the right balance for growth and inflation.

site_title: Tap potential of older workers, say MPs
summary: Singaporean MPs suggest utilizing older workers' knowledge and experience in various roles, including in-house mentors or trainers, and re-training them for jobs in sectors like early childhood education. The government could support retired professionals and civil servants to share their skills voluntarily and provide re-training for older workers to become early childhood teaching assistants. MPs also expressed concerns about fair hiring and job opportunities for middle-aged to senior workers and proposed reviewing Central Provident Fund contribution rates for workers above 55.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Sea Ltd's group president Nick Nash to leave end 2018
summary: Sea Ltd's group president Nick Nash, 39, is set to leave the company at the end of 2018 to pursue a career in investment. Nash, who has served as group president since 2014, will continue to advise CEO Forrest Li on strategic priorities until his departure. Nash plans to set up his own private equity firm and has stepped down from the company's board. Despite wider losses, Sea reported higher revenues in its fourth quarter, with adjusted net loss of US$251.6 million. Nash's departure comes as Sea continues to invest in its e-commerce business, Shopee.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: Singapore stocks rise for a 5th consecutive day ahead of GDP data release. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) plan to deepen their collaboration on green and transition finance. Meanwhile, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Other notable news includes Helen Wong's retirement as OCBC CEO, Kerry Mok's 30.5% pay rise at Sats, and Tesla's formal entry into the Indian market.

site_title: Red ink continues to flow at Serrano as company undergoes debt restructuring
summary: Serrano, an interior design contractor, has undergone debt restructuring through its schemes of arrangement, approved by the court on February 23, 2018. The company reported a loss of S$8.93 million for FY2017, with revenue falling 96% to S$650,600 and cost of sales decreasing by S$97.1 million. Total liabilities rose 5% to S$122.5 million, and the company plans to revive its business, acquire Sinbor Company, and expand its product range. Trading in Serrano's shares will resume, pending the lodging of court orders.

site_title: Singapore looking at investor protection rules for cryptocurrencies
summary: Singapore's central bank is assessing whether additional regulations are needed to protect investors in cryptocurrencies. The city-state, aiming to be a hub for financial technology, currently regulates virtual currencies that pose specific risks. Deputy Managing Director Ong Chong Tee stated that the assessment aims to ensure investor protection. This move follows similar efforts in other countries, such as South Korea, which is considering ways to regulate cryptocurrency trading.

site_title: No risk of Russell Peters being Deported
summary: Stand-up comedian Russell Peters performed in Singapore, drawing big laughs with his self-deprecating humor despite gaining weight. He poked fun at racial and cultural stereotypes, but avoided politically sensitive topics, including Donald Trump. Peters' show, part of his Deported world tour, features new material and improv, with some jokes potentially being mean-spirited, but overall, the audience responded enthusiastically to his unique brand of humor.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: CDL's Q4 net profit falls 23% against 'very strong' 2016
summary: City Developments (CDL) reported a 23% fall in Q4 net profit to S$186.7 million, citing an exceptionally strong 2016 as the reason for the year-on-year comparison. The 2016 performance was boosted by several factors, including Hong Leong City Center, higher profit margin projects, and divestments. CDL's FY16 performance was also aided by the recapitalisation of a Profit Participation Securities (PPS) platform. The company attributed the Q4 decline to a weaker year in 2017.

site_title: Ho Bee's FY17 profit up 15% on back of China JV project
summary: Ho Bee Land's FY17 net profit rose 15% to S$249.26 million, driven by a 235% surge in associate profits from a Shanghai joint venture project. This project contributed S$99.3 million to the company's profits, significantly boosting its overall earnings. The success of the joint venture project is seen as a key factor in Ho Bee Land's strong financial performance for the year.

site_title: 'Booth babes' bow out as carmakers opt for less flesh in Geneva
summary: Carmakers at the Geneva car show are ditching "booth babes" in favor of more professional models, reflecting the #MeToo movement's impact on the industry. Toyota, Nissan, and Lexus have all announced plans to reduce or eliminate the use of attractive women to promote their vehicles. Instead, they will feature male and female models dressed in sportswear, a shift seen as a response to changing customer demographics and societal attitudes. The change is part of a broader trend in various industries, including sports and entertainment, to reevaluate the use of attractive women as promotional tools.

site_title: CDL's fund management platform targeting US$5b in assets by 2023
summary: City Developments (CDL) plans to build a fund management platform targeting $5 billion in assets by 2023, tapping into the $5 trillion US private capital market. The platform will diversify its client base, including institutional investors, and invest in core, core-plus, and opportunistic real estate assets. CDL aims to launch its first close-ended funds in the Asia-Pacific by 2019 and may consider an open-ended core fund in the future. The move is seen as a strategic expansion for the company, allowing it to play in both listed and unlisted spaces.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: Japan's MUFG targets US securitisation business to boost revenue, while PBOC adviser urges a 1.5 trillion yuan stimulus to counter US tariffs. Tesla expands robotaxi services in California and Arizona, and FedEx partners with Singapore startup QuikBot to deploy robots for deliveries. Meanwhile, a Singaporean entrepreneur makes a mandatory offer for the rest of a local bakery, and the US shoemaker's reliance on China remains despite 190% tariffs. The Asian stock market continues to rally despite new Trump threats, with Japan's elevator empire experiencing a 6,000% stock gain amid succession crisis concerns.

site_title: NIO hires 8 banks to work on US IPO: sources
summary: Chinese electric vehicle startup NIO has hired eight banks, including Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs, to work on a planned US stock market listing worth up to $2 billion. The IPO, set for the second half of the year, will finance NIO's expansion and investments in autonomous driving and battery technologies. NIO, founded by William Li in 2014, aims to become a dominant global producer of electric cars as China promotes electric vehicles to curb emissions and boost energy security. The IPO would be the biggest Chinese listing in America since Alibaba's 2014 listing.

site_title: Taiwan developer detained over deadly quake building collapse
summary: Taiwan developer Liu has been detained for negligent manslaughter over the collapse of a 12-storey building in Hualien during an earthquake on February 6, 2018. The building partially pancaked, killing 17 people, including 14 in the Yun Tsui building. Prosecutors allege Liu, who was not licensed to oversee construction projects, oversaw the building's construction despite lacking necessary engineering qualifications. Three others, including the building's architect and restaurant owners, have been questioned and released on bail.

site_title: Blockchain could replace banks and even lawyers
summary: Blockchain technology has the potential to replace banks and lawyers by providing a decentralized and transparent system for financial records. By distributing records among users, blockchain systems can increase trust and reliability, reducing the need for middlemen institutions. This technology can also save firms cost and effort, increase transparency and security, and enable organizations to work together without institutional trust. While challenges remain, blockchain has the potential to revolutionize commerce and supply chain management, providing transactional certainty, reducing costs, and increasing access to participants.

site_title: US Senate passes bill promoting ties with Taiwan
summary: The US Senate unanimously passed the Taiwan Travel Act, promoting ties with Taiwan and allowing high-level Taiwanese officials to visit the US. The bill, which now requires President Donald Trump's signature, aims to encourage visits and business between the US and Taiwan. This move is likely to infuriate China, which recognizes the Communist mainland rulers in Beijing as the sole government of "One China." The bill's passage follows previous actions by Trump, including approving a $1.3 billion arms sale to Taiwan, which have strained relations with China.

site_title: Seacrest, cleared of sexual harassment, to host E! Oscars
summary: Ryan Seacrest, host of E!'s Oscars coverage, has been cleared of sexual harassment allegations made by his former personal stylist, Suzie Hardy. NBCUniversal defended Seacrest, stating that an independent investigation found her claims to be unsubstantiated. Seacrest maintained his innocence and supported the movement to combat sexual harassment, but denied the allegations. The investigation involved dozens of interviews, including with Seacrest, Hardy, and other witnesses, and found no evidence to support the claims. Seacrest will continue to host the Oscars red carpet coverage.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip as earnings fail to dispel US rate worries
summary: European shares fell 0.7% on Wednesday due to concerns about US interest rate hikes, despite a batch of corporate results. Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's comments strengthened the odds of four interest rate hikes this year. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index dropped, with most bourses and sectors losing ground.

site_title: AstraZeneca spins off autoimmune drugs into new biotech company
summary: AstraZeneca is spinning off six experimental autoimmune drugs into a new US$250 million biotech company, focusing on severe autoimmune diseases. The spin-off is part of the company's efforts to prune non-core drug development work and focus on priority areas, particularly in cancer.

site_title: Amazon buys maker of smart home products
summary: Amazon has acquired Ring, a maker of smart home products, including Internet-connected doorbells and cameras, for around $1.1 billion. The deal propels Amazon deeper into the home security market. Ring's products allow homeowners to monitor visitors remotely and integrate with Amazon's Echo family of products, including the Echo Spot device. The acquisition suggests Amazon's plans to enter the home security market more seriously and potentially offer bundled services, including with its Prime membership.

site_title: Comcast seeks to outfox Murdoch with higher bid for Sky
summary: Comcast has made an informal all-cash offer of £12.50 per share for Sky, valuing the UK satellite TV group at £22 billion. This bid surpasses Rupert Murdoch's 21st Century Fox's offer of £11.4 billion, sending Sky's share price soaring nearly 21% on the London Stock Exchange. Comcast CEO Brian Roberts expressed confidence in securing necessary regulatory approvals, while Sky advised shareholders to wait for a formal bid. A bidding war is expected, with analysts predicting even higher offers from Comcast.

site_title: Hike in DC rates unlikely to derail en bloc fever soon
summary: The Singapore government has increased development charge (DC) rates for non-landed residential use by an average of 22.8% for the next six months. However, this rate hike is unlikely to derail the collective sale market, as it may only affect land bids and lower en bloc sellers' expectations. Analysts expect the market to remain stable, with most en bloc sales finding takers, as long as they are sensibly priced. The rate hike may also lead developers to lower their bids or accept lower profit margins.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: US economic policy: Security interests or nationalism first?
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration is considering imposing steel and aluminum tariffs on China, citing national security concerns. Despite initial internationalist leanings, Trump's protectionist instincts have been tempered by advisors. The move aims to protect the US technology sector from Chinese intellectual property theft and pressure to transfer technology. However, critics argue this could damage the US innovation base and stifle global competition. The decision has bipartisan support in Congress, with lawmakers considering legislation to widen the Committee on Foreign Investment in the US's oversight powers.

site_title: Tech mogul gets US$13b richer just by leaving New York for China
summary: Zhou Hongyi, 47, relocated his online security firm Qihoo 360 Technology Co to China, merging it into a shell company that soared 550% in value. The move boosted his net worth to $14.1 billion, making him China's 11th-richest person. The company delisted from the New York Stock Exchange in July 2016 and began trading in Shanghai, driven by China's richer tech valuations and the Communist Party's tightening cybersecurity sovereignty. The shares experienced a rocky first day, swinging between gains and losses.

images.alt_text: Mr Zhou relocated his online security firm to China and merged it into a shell company.

site_title: 3 in 4 SMEs say proposed GST hikes not an issue: DBS poll
summary: In a DBS Bank survey of 240 Singapore SMEs, 75% of respondents believe a proposed GST hike will have a moderate to no impact on their businesses. The majority plan to address business challenges with grants, and 82% favor extending the wage credit scheme. Despite concerns about internationalization, 8 in 10 SMEs feel more confident about accessing regional market opportunities with the right resources.

site_title: How to buy your home away from home
summary: A guide on buying a home abroad is set to be featured in a Weekend magazine issue, providing tips on what to look out for and where to buy. In other news, a 91-year-old chef in Singapore is celebrating Chap Goh Mei with a traditional lohei dish, and a new restaurant, Thevar 2.0, showcases mod-Indian cuisine. Additionally, companies such as CMC Markets and the Social Kitchen are promoting financial literacy and zero-waste living, respectively.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Thursday; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.6% lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index falling 22.77 points to 3,495.17. About 81 million shares worth S$144 million changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 124 to 28. The most actively traded stock was Thai Beverage, down S$0.835. Major banks DBS and OCBC Bank also saw declines, with DBS down S$0.15 and OCBC Bank down S$0.12.

site_title: Australia: Shares weaken, Rio Tinto drops 4.8%; NZ set to snap winning streak
summary: Australian shares weakened, with the S&P/ASX 200 index down 0.9% to 5,960.8, due to rising US interest rate expectations and a decline in Rio Tinto, which dropped 4.8% as it traded ex-dividend. The benchmark closed down 0.7% on Wednesday. US Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell's comments on interest rate hikes also influenced the market. Iron ore and copper prices fell, impacting energy stocks and iron ore miner Fortescue Metals. New Zealand's benchmark index was also on track to snap a six-day winning streak.

site_title: Airlines flag cost pressures as Changi Airport unveils new levy, fee hikes to help fund expansion
summary: Singapore's Changi Airport has introduced a new levy and fee hikes to help fund its expansion, including a S$10.80 airport development levy, a S$2.50 increase in passenger service and security fee, and a one-per-cent hike in landing, parking and aerobridge fees. Airlines, particularly budget carriers, are expected to feel the impact, with potential fare increases of 10-25% for short-haul flights. Premium and transit passengers are less likely to be affected. The fees will help fund the development of Terminal 5 and a third runway by 2020, as well as tunnel and system upgrades.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: HK unveils expansionary budget with push on innovative industries
summary: Hong Kong has unveiled an expansionary budget with tax cuts, relief measures, and capital spending aimed at boosting competitiveness, particularly in high-tech industries. The budget includes a startup fund, investments in fintech, biotechnology, and artificial intelligence, and allocates over HK$50 billion for strategic capital spending. The city expects an overall surplus of HK$138 billion for the 2017/18 financial year, with GDP growth projected at 3-4% for the year. The measures are seen as a step to address economic challenges, including a widening wealth gap and high property prices, but may face public skepticism.

site_title: Keppel set to land US$425m rig-building deal
summary: Keppel's offshore arm, Keppel Fels, has signed a letter of intent with Awilco Drilling Plc for the construction of a harsh-environment semi-submersible rig valued at US$425 million. The deal, if finalized, would be the first rig-building project awarded during the current offshore and marine downturn. Keppel Corp's order book is expected to reach S$4.4 billion, and the project's delivery is targeted for 2021. However, concerns have been raised over the rig-building margin, with some analysts noting that the yard price is tens of millions lower than previous quotes.

site_title: US pending home sales slide 4.7% in January
summary: US pending home sales declined 4.7% in January to their lowest level in over three years, according to the National Association of Realtors. This marks the second straight month of sales decline, following a stumble at the turn of the year. Low inventory and rising mortgage rates, which have reached a four-year high, are cited as contributing factors. Economists had forecast a 0.3% increase in pending sales. The decline is the latest sign of a weakening housing market, with sales of new and previously owned homes falling for the second straight month.

site_title: The making of Lehman Brothers II
summary: The US Treasury Department has released a report on the Orderly Liquidation Authority (OLA), a provision under the Dodd-Frank financial reform legislation aimed at preventing a financial system collapse like the 2008 Lehman Brothers failure. The report concludes that the OLA should remain in place, but masks a broader legislative agenda that could add unnecessary risk to the financial system. The proposed Economic Growth, Regulatory Relief, and Consumer Protection Act, supported by the Trump administration, would reduce scrutiny on banks with assets above $250 billion, potentially increasing the risk of systemic failures.

site_title: South Korea's Moon says Japan cannot declare wartime crimes 'over'
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae In stated that Japan cannot declare the issue of its former wartime sex slaves "over", repeating calls for Tokyo to apologize and confront wrongdoings. This controversy has marred relations between the two neighbors for decades, following a 2015 deal between Park Geun Hye's ousted predecessor and Japan that allowed the issue to be dropped in exchange for 1 billion yen. Moon's comments emphasize the need for Japan to acknowledge its wartime wrongdoings and provide compensation to the victims.

site_title: China global dream spurred Fiat takeover move before Daimler
summary: Li Shufu's Zhejiang Geely Holding Group held informal talks with Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) in 2017 about a potential takeover, before focusing on Daimler. The talks were dropped due to differing views on FCA's future valuation. Geely later invested 7.3 billion euros in Daimler, becoming its largest shareholder, amid concerns that traditional carmakers must adapt to changing technology to remain competitive. The move is part of Li's expansion efforts outside China, aiming to gain access to technology and forge partnerships in Europe.

site_title: Triyards yet to receive balance of US$5m short-term loan
summary: Triyards Holdings, a yard operating unit of Ezra Holdings, has yet to receive the remaining $3.8 million of a $5 million short-term loan from a Cayman Island-based fund vehicle. The loan's first tranche of $1.2 million was disbursed to settle outstanding salary payments. The loan's 180-day tenor carries a 4% annual interest rate. Triyards is due to announce its first quarter financial results but has requested more time. The loan was held back by technicalities and documentation, and the company must complete satisfactory due diligence within 180 days to conduct corporate restructuring.

site_title: EU, Japan seek to push through trade deal before Brexit
summary: The European Union and Japan are rushing to finalize a free trade agreement before the UK leaves the EU in March 2019. Japan's ambassador said the deal could be presented to the Japanese parliament later this year and ratified by the end of 2018, potentially allowing it to enter force before Brexit. EU Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmstrom suggested a summer signing, with EU negotiator Mauro Petriccione stating a "reasonable expectation" of an early 2019 entry into force, if the deal is ratified in time.

site_title: Noble auditors raise doubts on company as a going concern
summary: Noble Group reported a significant loss of US$4.94 billion for 2017, with its auditor flagging concerns over the group's ability to continue as a going concern. However, the company's board remains confident it can continue as a going concern until its restructuring plan is complete, which could be in a few weeks. The group is in talks with creditors and has made progress in its restructuring discussions. Despite some creditors expressing dissatisfaction with the terms, Noble's chairman believes the group can navigate the restructuring process and protect its trading business.

site_title: Europe follows FDA with plans to help early Alzheimer's drugs
summary: European regulators have introduced new guidance to encourage the testing of novel Alzheimer's drugs at the earliest stages of the disease. The European Medicines Agency plans to support pharmaceutical companies by allowing the use of biomarkers, such as protein build-up in the brain, and will also permit testing of new medicines before symptoms appear. This move follows the US FDA's efforts to help early Alzheimer's drug approvals, which have been hindered by a dismal track record of experimental treatments.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after GDP data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday after data showed the US economy grew slightly less than expected in the fourth quarter, weakening the case for faster interest rate hikes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 98.48 points, or 0.39%, to 25,508.51, while the S&P 500 gained 12.71 points, or 0.46%, to 2,756.99. The Nasdaq Composite added 41.00 points, or 0.56%, to 7,371.36, as investors took a cautious approach despite the data.

site_title: Malaysia: shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 15.26 points to 1,856.20 on Wednesday, closing lower. The FTSE index saw 2.95 billion shares traded at RM3.63 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 812-265, indicating a bearish market trend.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.6% lower
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.6% lower on Wednesday, losing 22.45 points to 3,517.94, as weak US market leads. The key market indicators showed 2.1 billion shares traded, with 293 counters down and 164 up.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Toyota to build new Auris car at UK plant, in Brexit boost for PM May
summary: Toyota will build the next generation of its Auris car at its UK plant in Burnaston, Derbyshire, in a Brexit boost for Prime Minister Theresa May. The Japanese carmaker will replace the current run of the model made there, confirming a previous Reuters report. The move is based on the assumption that ministers will secure a transitional Brexit deal to maintain current trading conditions until at least the end of 2020.

site_title: US Q4 GDP growth revised down to 2.5%
summary: US economic growth slowed to a 2.5% annual rate in the fourth quarter of 2017, down from the initially reported 2.6% pace. The decrease was largely due to a smaller inventory build, in line with economists' expectations. This marked a deceleration from the third quarter's 3.2% pace. The revised estimate was released by the Commerce Department, which also confirmed the strongest pace of consumer spending in three years.

site_title: SIAS to moderate Yuuzoo dialogue with shareholders
summary: YuuZoo Corp is inviting shareholders to a dialogue session on March 7, moderated by Securities Investors Association (Singapore) president and CEO David Gerald. The session follows queries from the Singapore Exchange and corporate governance expert Mak Yuen Teen regarding disclosures on the firm's financial performance. This move aims to address concerns and provide transparency.

site_title: YZJ Q4 net profit jumps 12 per cent
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's fourth quarter net profit jumped 12% to 677.92 million yuan, driven by higher turnover, other income, and lower finance expenses. Revenue rose 15% to 6.35 billion yuan, with shipbuilding revenue increasing 8.6% to 4.34 billion yuan. The company delivered six vessels in Q4, down from nine last year, but saw improved market conditions for the shipbuilding industry. Full-year net profit rose 67% to 2.93 billion yuan, and the company proposed a final dividend of 4.5 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: Venture Corp's Q4 profit jumps 165% on revenue surge, R&D boost
summary: Venture Corp reported a 164.5% surge in Q4 net profit to S$143 million, driven by a 27.1% increase in revenue to S$1.086 billion. The company's R&D revenue surged, partly due to achieved milestones in R&D projects. Net profit margin reached 13.2%, with a final dividend of S$0.60 per share, up 20% from the same period last year. The company's full-year net profit jumped 106.3% to S$372.8 million, beating estimates.

site_title: Top Malaysian lenders Maybank, CIMB post mixed quarterly results
summary: Malaysia's largest bank, Maybank, reported a 11% decline in quarterly profit, while competitor CIMB Group Holdings Bhd's earnings rose. Maybank's profit excluding one-off proceeds rose 22.4% due to a slight rise in net interest income. Group president Datuk Abdul Farid Alias warned of a challenging 2018 due to volatile markets. This contrasts with CIMB's earnings increase, which may suggest differing market conditions for the two banks.

site_title: India bids tearful farewell to Bollywood superstar Sridevi
summary: Bollywood superstar Sridevi Kapoor, 54, died from accidental drowning in a Dubai hotel bathtub. Thousands of fans and actors bid farewell to her in Mumbai, with a public service and state honors ceremony. Her body was cremated at a private Hindu ceremony after her husband performed the last rites. Tributes poured in from fans and fellow actors, including Prime Minister Narendra Modi, as Sridevi was remembered as one of the most influential Bollywood actresses of all time, with a career spanning over four decades.

site_title: Venture Corp net profit up 165% in Q4 on record revenue, R&D boost
summary: Venture Corp's net profit surged 164.5% to S$143 million in Q4 2017, driven by a 27.1% increase in revenue to S$1.086 billion. The company's R&D revenue rose significantly, partly due to milestones achieved in projects for customers. Net profit margin climbed to 13.2%, with full-year net profit more than doubling to S$372.8 million. Venture's revenue reached a record S$4 billion, and the company declared a final dividend of 60 Singapore cents.

site_title: US$1b painting 'only matter of time' as art prices surge
summary: The art market is experiencing a boom, with prices surging across the globe, driven by record-breaking sales and museum acquisition strategies. The sale of Leonardo da Vinci's "Salvator Mundi" for $450 million in November marked the beginning of a new era, with predictions of a US$1 billion painting sale in the near future. The market is expected to see significant growth, with Asia driving the boom, particularly China and the US. Artprice reports intense competition between China and the US, with museum acquisition strategies becoming a major driver of growth.

site_title: Tung Lok signs tenancy agreement to open Signatures restaurant at Eu Tong Sen St
summary: Tung Lok Restaurants has signed a tenancy agreement with Riverhub Pte Ltd to operate its Tung Lok Signatures restaurant at The Central mall in Singapore for a one-year term. The lease includes eight units and outdoor areas, totaling 6,426 square feet. The estimated rental fees are around S$573,000, representing 3.31% of Tung Lok's latest audited net tangible assets. This marks the group's latest expansion, following similar agreements with Tee Yih Jia Food Manufacturing and Orchard Central.

site_title: SBI flags 17.28m yuan unauthorised write-off
summary: SBI Offshore has flagged an unauthorized write-off of 17.28 million yuan in the books of its subsidiary, Jiangyin SBI offshore Equipment Co. The company's auditors, BDO LLP, discovered the discrepancy, which could lead to a potential tax exposure of 2.5 million yuan. SBI's board is seeking to reverse the write-off and has appointed an independent reviewer to investigate the matter. The company believes the accounts may not be materially misstated, but the write-off could lead to certain liabilities.

site_title: New independent director for Hong Leong Asia
summary: Hong Leong Asia announced the retirement of independent non-executive director Tan Huay Lim, who will step down at the April 2018 AGM. He will be replaced by Tan Chian Khong, a 61-year-old former Ernst & Young audit partner. Tan Chian Khong will take over as chairman of the audit and risk committee and as a member of the remuneration committee and share option scheme committee. This appointment is effective at the April AGM, marking a change in leadership for the company.

site_title: Spackman back in black in FY2017 with US$2.98m profit
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group reported a US$2.98 million profit for FY2017, reversing a US$2.43 million loss from the previous year. Revenue increased by 36% to US$20.55 million, driven by recognition of profit from "Master" film, VOD sales, and restaurant sales. The company's equipment leasing business also contributed to the profit. The turnaround was largely due to the recognition of profit from "Master" film and investment returns.

site_title: China factory expansion slows to 19-month low in February
summary: China's factory expansion slowed to a 19-month low in February, with the manufacturing purchasing managers index (PMI) falling to 50.3, below analyst expectations. This marked the third consecutive month of slowdown and the lowest reading since August 2016. The Lunar New Year holidays and reduced output, import, and export orders contributed to the decline. Economists warn of a cyclical downturn in the global electronic supply chain and a weakening of growth momentum in the manufacturing sector.

site_title: Straco Q4 profit dips slightly
summary: Straco Corporation reported a 1.2% drop in Q4 profit to S$6.07 million due to lower revenue from its Singapore Flyer operator. However, the group's top line was lifted by 5.8% to S$24.59 million from its three Chinese attractions. Overall, the company's profit before tax rose 4.4% to S$9.32 million for the quarter. For the year, profit attributable to shareholders increased 2.7% to S$47.73 million. The company's executive chairman expressed satisfaction with the overall performance, citing growth in visitor numbers and profitability at its Chinese attractions.

site_title: Venture Corp net profit up 165% in Q4 on record revenue
summary: VENTURE Corp reported a 165% net profit surge in Q4 to S$143 million, driven by record revenue of S$1.086 billion, a 27.1% increase from the same period last year. Full-year net profit rose 106.3% to S$372.8 million, beating estimates. The company declared a 60 Singapore cents final dividend, up from 50 cents last year. Venture shares rose 1.7% to S$27.56 before results were released, and the company remains confident of creating significant value for its partners.

site_title: Ho Bee posts 20.9% drop in Q4 profit, but full-year profit up 15%
summary: Ho Bee Land reported a 20.9% drop in Q4 net profit to S$102.44 million due to decreased revenue from development projects. However, full-year net profit rose 15% to S$249.26 million, driven by a surge in share of profits from associates. Group revenue declined 3.1% to S$41.17 million in Q4, while full-year revenue dropped 45% to S$164.7 million. The company plans to sell its Sentosa Cove projects to capitalize on improved market sentiment.

site_title: Noble Group reports 2017 loss of US$4.94b; auditor warns uncertainty over "going concern" status
summary: Noble Group reported a significant loss of US$4.94 billion for 2017, with its auditor warning of uncertainty over the company's "going concern" status due to material uncertainties, including significant debt and net deficiency. Despite this, Noble's board is confident it can continue as a going concern until restructuring is completed. The company's revenue tumbled 26% to US$6.43 billion, with volumes in metals and minerals declining due to contract endings and a focus on profitability.

site_title: YZJ forks out 700m yuan for equity in Suzhou-registered investment firm
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (YZJ) acquired a 25% equity stake in Suzhou-registered investment firm Jiangsu Sushang Joint Industry Investment Partnership for 700 million yuan (S$146 million). The acquisition is not expected to impact YZJ's earnings per share and net tangible assets. Sushang's core businesses include equity fund and convertible bond investments in various industries. The six-year operating term of Sushang does not anticipate significant financial implications for YZJ.

site_title: Global automotive care specialist opens in Singapore
summary: TYREPLUS, a global automotive care specialist with 2,000 stores in 17 countries, has opened its first outlet in Singapore at Wave 9 in Woodlands Industrial Park. The 4,575 sqft outlet offers a one-stop car maintenance and repair service, including tyre changing, battery and oil servicing, and air-conditioning and brake maintenance. The store will also provide a free complimentary safety check for all customers, with two more outlets planned to open in the West and Central regions of Singapore this year.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip as earnings fail to dispel Wall Street gloom
summary: European shares fell 0.4% on Wednesday, with most sectors down, as disappointing corporate results failed to lift the market.
