France's Biomerieux and German drugmaker Bayer were among the worst performers, while ITV in the UK dropped 7.5% due to a 5% decline in adjusted earnings. Despite some gains from Dialog Semiconductor, the negative trend on Wall Street continued, fueled by fears of faster-than-expected US interest rate hikes.

site_title: Aspen posts RM41.97m net profit in Q4
summary: Aspen (Group) Holdings reported a net profit of RM41.97 million in Q4 2017, up from RM1.46 million in the same quarter last year, driven by a significant increase in revenue. Gross profit nearly quadrupled to RM75.71 million. The company returned to profitability for the full year, with a net profit of RM85.41 million. Aspen's commercial development Vervea and residential project Vertu Resort have seen sales of 88.28% and 65.73%, respectively, with plans to launch four more projects in 2018-2019.

site_title: DC rates hiked 22.8% on average for non-landed residential use, 2.7% for commercial use
summary: Singapore's Development Charge (DC) rates have been increased by 22.8% on average for non-landed residential use and 2.7% for commercial use, effective March 1, 2018 to August 31, 2018. The hikes are attributed to record land prices and high-profile collective sales. DC rates remain unchanged for landed residential and industrial uses. The increases are expected to impact the collective sales market, with some developers potentially lowering their bids to maximize their gross floor area.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: UOB Kay Hian Q4 net profit jumps 85 per cent
summary: UOB Kay Hian posted an 85% increase in Q4 net profit to S$21.84 million, driven by a 16.2% rise in total revenue and a 21.4% increase in commission income. Full-year net profit rose 34.7% to S$76.25 million. The brokerage expects positive market sentiment in 2018 but flags inflationary pressures as a concern, which may lead to interest rate hikes and divert capital flows.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks suffer sharp losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.36% on Wednesday, following an Asia-wide sell-off due to concerns over rising US interest rates and weak Chinese factory data. The Hang Seng Index fell to 30,844.72, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.99% to 3,259.41. The Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.16% to 1,811.78, despite the overall market decline.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore bank lending decreased to S$651 billion in January, down from S$652 billion in December. The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore introduced new passenger fees at Changi Airport to fund the Changi East project. Noble Group's perpetual bond holders are uniting to oppose restructuring. The 1MDB chairman is confident the firm will repay its debts. Singapore and Japan now hold the world's most powerful passports, granting visa-free access to 180 destinations. The STI closed 0.6% lower due to weak US market leads.

site_title: China Aviation Oil Q4 profit dented on deferred tax assets
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) reported a 21.7% decline in Q4 2017 profit to US$14.03 million due to a near seven-fold increase in income tax expense. The increase was attributed to a decline in deferred tax assets and recognition of deferred tax liabilities. Revenue rose 23.96% to US$4.06 billion, driven by higher oil prices. The company's net asset value per share increased to 84.12 US cents, while earnings per share fell to 1.64 US cents. CAO's board proposed a dividend of 4.5 Singapore cents per share for FY2017.

site_title: Noble Group perpetual holders unite to oppose restructuring
summary: Holders of Noble Group Ltd's perpetual bonds, collectively holding over 25% of the bonds, have joined forces to oppose the company's US$3.5 billion restructuring plan, which would give equity investors 10% of shares in the new company. The group, led by Pinpoint Asset Management, has hired lawyers to negotiate a better deal or "exercise remedies" against Noble. Perpetual bondholders would receive a US$15 million payment in exchange for notes with a face value of US$400 million, seen as a raw deal given the current market value of perpetual bonds.

site_title: Hong Kong cash surplus hits record but critics hit out at budget
summary: Hong Kong reported a record surplus of $18 billion in its annual budget, largely due to a strong property market. The budget includes tax cuts for the middle class and welfare measures for the poor, but critics say it fails to address long-term poverty problems. The government plans to build 100,000 public housing flats, but no one-off cash handout was announced. The budget is expected to benefit nearly two million people, but demonstrators and social media users expressed discontent, calling for more support for ordinary people.

site_title: Global investors are rattled by India's new season of scandal
summary: India is facing a new wave of scandals that have rattled global investors, with several high-profile cases of alleged corporate fraud. Billionaire jeweler Nirav Modi has been accused of masterminding a $2 billion financial scam, while the Singh family has been accused of siphoning millions of dollars from a hospital company and a pen manufacturer has been accused of defrauding banks of $570 million. The government has launched wide-ranging probes into the allegations, but the culture of impunity and lack of regulation have raised concerns about the ability to hold perpetrators accountable.

site_title: China Everbright full year profit grows 46.9% to HK$513.4m
summary: China Everbright Water Limited posted a 46.9% increase in full-year earnings to HK$513.4 million, driven by revenue growth of 44% to HK$3.59 billion. The company's construction services, operation services, and finance income contributed to the increase. Net asset value per share rose to HK$2.99. CEO An Xuesong attributed the growth to the company's expansion efforts in the water industry, solidifying its market position and boosting market expansion.

site_title: Tokyo stocks down after Fed chief comments
summary: Tokyo stocks declined on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 1.44% to 22,068.24, and the Topix index down 1.23% to 1,768.24. The decline was attributed to worries over higher interest rates following Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell's congressional testimony. A stronger yen also weighed on investor sentiment, with banks and exporters losing ground. The dollar fetched 107.06 yen in Asian afternoon trade, down from 107.38 yen in New York.

site_title: Amazon should get an open goal from the Premier League
summary: The Premier League is struggling with low bids from broadcasters, with Sky and BT Group sealing deals for £4.4 billion for 160 matches over three years. To stimulate competition, the league should offer Amazon a cut-price deal to broadcast games through Prime Video, potentially increasing Prime subscriptions and bolstering revenue. A precedent exists with BT's user growth after securing broadcast rights in 2013, and offering Amazon a discount could lead to increased competition for larger packages in the future.

site_title: Thai growth improves but domestic demand not strong enough: minutes
summary: Thailand's economy showed improved growth due to external demand, but domestic demand remained insufficiently strong, according to the Bank of Thailand's policy meeting minutes. The central bank maintained its accommodative monetary policy stance to boost activity. Economic growth is forecasted at 3.9% for 2018, with public investment expected to be a key growth driver. The Bank of Thailand will review its projection on March 28. Most economists expect no policy change for the rest of 2018, while some predict rate increases in the second half of the year.

site_title: Waymo seeks to reassure potential riders with new self-driving video
summary: Waymo, an Alphabet Inc company, released a 360-degree video showcasing what it's like to ride in an autonomous vehicle. The video aims to reassure potential riders ahead of the company's launch of self-driving rides in Phoenix, Arizona. Waymo has driven over 8.05 million kilometers on public roads, more than doubling its miles since 2017. The company plans to offer self-driving rides with no human behind the wheel in Phoenix, marking its first foray into ride-hailing. Specialists believe self-driving cars used in fleets for ride-hailing services are economically viable.

site_title: China startup NIO hires eight banks for up to US$2b US IPO: sources
summary: Chinese electric vehicle startup NIO has hired eight banks, including Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs, to work on a planned US stock market listing worth up to $2 billion. The IPO is part of the firm's expansion and investments in autonomous driving and battery technologies. Founded by William Li in 2014, NIO aims to raise $1 billion to $2 billion in fresh capital.

site_title: Australian shares end lower as materials, financials weigh; NZ inches up
summary: Australian shares fell 0.7% to 6,016.0, tracking a US equities decline, while New Zealand shares rose 0.16% to 8,373.82. Materials stocks dropped 1.4% and financials fell 0.6% after Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's comments revived interest-rate hike fears. BHP Billiton and Westpac Banking Corp led the decline, while Wesfarmers and Woodside Petroleum provided limited support.

site_title: "Booth babes" banished as carmakers opt for less flesh in Geneva
summary: Carmakers at the Geneva auto show are ditching "booth babes" in favor of male and female models dressed in sportswear, a shift driven by the #MeToo movement and changing customer demographics. Industry leaders such as Toyota, Nissan, and Lexus are cutting back on using attractive women to sell cars, instead opting for product specialists. The move is seen as a potential sea change for the industry, with several European sports events also ditching hostesses in skimpy clothing.

site_title: New passenger, aeronautical fees at Changi Airport from July 1 to help fund Changi East project
summary: Changi Airport in Singapore will implement increased passenger and aeronautical fees from July 1 to help fund the construction of the mega Terminal 5 project and other expansion works. The airport development levy for departing passengers will increase to S$10.80, while the passenger service and security fee will rise by S$2.50 to S$30.40. The funds will also be used to upgrade and refurbish existing terminal infrastructure, with the Changi East project expected to cost "tens of billions of dollars" and be funded by the government and airport operator Changi Airport Group.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: 1MDB will be 'shut down' once debts are cleared: chairman
summary: Malaysia's 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) will be wound up once it clears all its debts, its chairman Tan Sri Dr Mohd Irwan Serigar Abdullah said. The firm, plagued by controversy and allegations of misappropriation of up to $4.5 billion, will repay debts through revenue from government mega projects, including the Tun Razak Exchange and East Coast Rail Link. The process is expected to take over 10 years, with 1MDB already paying off a $602.7 million debt to Abu Dhabi's IPIC.

site_title: How Hong Kong could scrap income tax and prosper: Gadfly
summary: Hong Kong, with a surplus of HK$138 billion in the 2017-18 fiscal year, may consider alternative revenue streams to mitigate future deficits. Unlike Singapore, which plans to increase its goods and services tax, Hong Kong could "live off assets" by investing its wealth, including land premiums and stamp duties, in riskier overseas assets. Sequestering half of the revenue could finance infrastructure spending, provide more risk-free investment options for wealthy citizens, and address population aging and healthcare needs. This approach could potentially reduce the need for income taxes in the future.

site_title: Jaya Holdings to delist from SGX on March 1
summary: Jaya Holdings to delist from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on March 1, marking the end of its presence on the exchange. The company, which previously owned an offshore fleet and shipyard, sold its businesses for $625 million in 2014 and acquired Heduru Moni in 2016. Following a failed reverse takeover agreement, Jaya Holdings will cease to be listed on the SGX.

site_title: Australia's Westpac says Big Four banks are not 'highly profitable'
summary: Australia's Westpac rejects claims that the country's four major banks, known as the Big Four, are highly profitable. Despite producing large profits, their return on equity has fallen over the past decade. Westpac's CFO, Peter King, stated that their profits do not stand out compared to other leading entities and are in line with global banking systems. The Big Four banks have faced criticism for their lending practices and are set to face scrutiny from a government-backed inquiry starting next month.

site_title: SIIC Environment Q4 profit grows 8.9% to 185.4m yuan
summary: SIIC Environment Holdings Limited reported an 8.9% increase in its fourth-quarter net profit to 185.4 million yuan, driven by a 13.4% rise in revenue to 1.29 billion yuan. The company's full-year net profit grew 17.7% to 535.7 million yuan. The executive chairman, Zhou Jun, attributed the results to strong fundamentals and sound business strategies, and announced plans to improve operational efficiency and explore new investment opportunities. The company is also awaiting shareholders' approval for a dual listing on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange.

site_title: GIC, international investors take majority stake in French property group AccorInvest for 4.4b euros
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC, along with international investors, has acquired a 55% stake in French property group AccorInvest for €4.4 billion. The sale marks a major move by AccorHotels, with the remaining 45% stake retained by the company. The deal is expected to be finalized in the second quarter of this year, subject to regulatory approvals. The acquisition aims to provide GIC with exposure to AccorInvest's diversified portfolio and attractive opportunities for value creation.

site_title: Pacific Radiance in voluntary trading suspension
summary: Pacific Radiance, an offshore marine operator, has voluntarily suspended trading of its shares due to a debt restructuring plan being rejected by noteholders. The plan, which would have converted debt into equity, was voted down, and the company will continue to pursue restructuring. Pacific Radiance, carrying over $500 million in debt, aims to operate in a sustainable manner and stay competitive. The company has made progress in discussions with creditors and investors, and will engage with broader stakeholder groups to complete the restructuring.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Singapore LNG's fourth storage tank on track to be completed by H1
summary: Singapore LNG's fourth storage tank is on track to be completed by the first half of 2018, according to Trade and Industry Minister S Iswaran. The 260,000 cubic meter tank will offer more options and flexibility for LNG traders. SLNG will soon call for proposals to utilize its spare capacity for ancillary services. The company handled 23 LNG vessel cool downs and storage reloads in 2017. The completion of the tank is expected to support the growth of SLNG's services.

site_title: Asian shares slide as weak China, Japan manufacturing data add to Fed worries
summary: Asian shares declined for the second day in a row, with the MSCI Asia-Pacific index falling over 1% due to weak Chinese and Japanese manufacturing data, reviving concerns about global growth amid US rate hike worries. Japan's industrial output plummeted, while China's services sector slowed, and growth in India's factory activity also slowed. The US Federal Reserve's Jerome Powell sparked anxiety with his upbeat view of the US economy, fueling fears of faster rate hikes and a subsequent tightening of global monetary policy.

site_title: Hong Kong exchange's FY profit rises 28%, meets estimates
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd (HKEX) reported a 28% increase in 2017 profit to HK$7.4 billion, meeting estimates. The rise was driven by a jump in fees from trading and stock listings as Chinese companies tapped Hong Kong for funding. Despite being the world's biggest equity capital-raising centre for four of the last 10 years, HKEX has struggled to attract hot tech stocks, falling behind New York.

site_title: Workplace automation in Singapore expected to double in next 3 years: poll
summary: Singapore is expected to see a significant increase in workplace automation over the next three years, with 29% of work done by firms in the country expected to be automated, up from 14% currently. Organizations aim to improve human performance and productivity through automation, but not replace humans. New job roles such as robot trainers and data scientists are emerging, and companies are expected to pay higher salaries for employees with digital-focused skills. The survey also highlights the need for efficient leadership and communication to drive change in the workplace.

site_title: Hong Kong attracts IPO of biotech firm backed by Bezos, Gates
summary: Grail Inc, a cancer detection firm backed by Bill Gates and Jeff Bezos, plans a Hong Kong initial public offering, aiming to raise up to $500 million. This move supports Hong Kong's efforts to attract biotech listings, with Shanghai Henlius Biotech also planning a listing under new listing rules. The company's investors include the personal venture fund of Amazon's founder and the billionaire philanthropist Gates.

site_title: US judge criticised by Trump rejects challenge to border wall
summary: US District Judge Gonzalo Curiel rejected a challenge to the planned US-Mexico border wall, citing the construction of border barriers as a separate issue from the constitutionality of the wall itself. The ruling came after a lawsuit from California and environmental groups argued that waivers to environmental regulations exceeded Congress's authority. The decision allows the wall's construction to proceed, despite concerns over its cost and potential environmental impact. President Trump hailed the ruling as a "big legal win."

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.43 points to 1,869.03. Losers outnumbered gainers 187 to 85, with 113.45 million lots traded worth RM53.16 million.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Wednesday; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore stocks opened flat on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 0.7% to 3,565.21. The move followed a decline on Wall Street, where the Dow Jones fell 1.2% and the S&P 500 dropped 1.3%. About 99.6 million shares changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 77 to 49.

site_title: Sea deepens Q4 loss to US$251.6m; group president Nick Nash to retire
summary: SEA Limited, a Singapore-based internet company, reported a net loss of US$251.6 million in its fourth quarter of 2017, more than four times the previous year's loss of US$62 million. Total adjusted revenue rose 72.8% to US$164.5 million, driven by higher revenues from its digital entertainment, e-commerce, and digital financial services segments. Group President Nick Nash will retire at the end of 2018, and the company has elected Tony Tianyu Hou as a director to replace him.

site_title: Weiye Q4 profit surges to 142.9m yuan on higher property development sales
summary: Weiye Holdings Limited reported a significant surge in its fourth-quarter profit, jumping about four times to 142.9 million yuan (S$29.8 million) from 35.2 million yuan in the previous year. Revenue also increased almost seven times to 1.03 billion yuan, while net asset value per share rose to 6.71 yuan. The company's full-year revenue more than doubled to 1.75 billion yuan, with net profit growing 77.8% to 116.2 million yuan.

site_title: Asia: Markets tumble with Wall St as Fed boss fans rate fears
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Wednesday as Federal Reserve boss Jerome Powell's upbeat assessment of the US economy fueled fears of a sharp rise in interest rates. Markets sank, with Hong Kong and Shanghai falling over 1%, while Tokyo and Sydney dropped 0.4%. The dollar surged against other currencies, and the yield on the 10-year US Treasury bond jumped. Investors bet on four rate hikes this year, rather than the previously expected three, citing the strong US economy and inflation concerns.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks wobble, won slides on Fed rate hike worries
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index wobbled, falling 0.35 points or 0.01% to 2,455.79. The won sharply fell against the US dollar, while bond yields rose due to Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's comments on faster-than-expected US rate hikes. Foreign and individual investor stock purchases prevented bigger losses, but the Kospi is down 0.5% this year and 1.61% in the past 30 days.

site_title: Singapore bank lending dips in January: MAS
summary: Bank lending in Singapore decreased in January, with loans totaling S$651 billion, a 0.2% drop from December. Weaker lending in the business segment, particularly in building loans and lending to financial institutions, contributed to the decline. However, lending to transport and storage firms increased 4% to S$23 billion, and consumer loans rose 0.4% to S$263 billion. Year-on-year, bank lending grew 5.4%, slightly weaker than the 5.6% growth in December.

site_title: Datapulse sets April 20 for EGM, but proposed diversification may not be up for shareholder vote
summary: Datapulse Technology has set an April 20 date for an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to consider proposed business diversification and a potential change in the board of directors. The company's co-founder's family has launched a bid to oust the current board, but the resolution on diversification will not be put to a shareholder vote if a change in the board is approved. Datapulse has been embroiled in a months-long dispute over its expansion into a new business, with the company's finance director seeking to halt the move and replace existing directors.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Deutsche Bank to pay US$240m to end Libor rigging lawsuit in US
summary: Deutsche Bank has agreed to pay US$240 million to settle private US antitrust litigation accusing it of conspiring to manipulate the Libor benchmark interest rate. This is the third bank to resolve claims, following Citigroup and Barclays. Deutsche Bank denied wrongdoing but settled to avoid litigation risks. The bank's settlement is part of a global trend, with banks paying roughly US$9 billion to settle Libor-rigging probes worldwide.

site_title: Gold slides 1% after Fed's Powell confirms gradual rate hikes
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell confirmed gradual interest rate hikes, pressuring gold prices, which fell 1% to $1,318.22 an ounce. The dollar strengthened, and stock prices fell, while traders boosted bets on a potential fourth rate hike this year. Analysts expect gold to move lower, with some predicting a drop under $1,300 an ounce by the end of the quarter.

images.alt_text: Gold prices were down 1 per cent Tuesday after the new US central bank chairman pledged to stick with gradual interest rate increases.

site_title: Japan factory output suffers first fall in 4 months
summary: Japan's factory output fell 6.6% in January for the first time in four months, according to industry ministry data. However, experts say industrial momentum remains strong, predicting a 9.0% surge in February. Despite this, the country still battles deflation fears, failing to achieve a 2.0% inflation rate target. The government and central bank aim for a "virtuous cycle" of an export-led recovery boosting jobs and household income.

images.alt_text: Japan's factory output fell in January for the first time in four months, official data showed Wednesday, but the government and experts said industrial momentum remained strong in the world's third-largest economy.

site_title: Trump son-in-law Kushner loses top security clearance
summary: US President Donald Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner has lost his top-level security clearance, casting doubt on his role as a powerbroker in the White House. The decision, made by Chief of Staff John Kelly, affects Kushner's ability to access sensitive information, particularly in his foreign policy portfolio, including the Israeli-Palestinian peace effort. Kushner's lawyer had not completed the clearance process, despite accessing the president's daily briefing, and his loss of clearance may impact his credibility in Middle East negotiations.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump's son-in-law and senior aide Jared Kushner has lost his top-level security clearance, sources familiar with the matter said Tuesday, a decision with potentially profound implications for the US administration.

site_title: China global dream spurred Fiat takeover move before Daimler
summary: Chinese billionaire Li Shufu's Zhejiang Geely Holding Group had informal talks with Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) in the middle of 2017 about a potential takeover before focusing on Daimler. Geely ultimately decided not to make a formal offer due to differing views on FCA's future valuations. Li later acquired a 7.3 billion-euro stake in Daimler, becoming the German company's largest shareholder. Geely's expansion outside China has enabled it to acquire assets across Europe, including Volvo Car and a sports-car maker, as Li seeks to forge partnerships and access technology in the face of changing technology.

images.alt_text: As it turns out, Daimler wasn't the only belle of the ball.

site_title: Doe-eyed superhero mascot picked for Tokyo 2020 Olympics
summary: Tokyo unveiled its 2020 Olympic mascot, a futuristic blue-checked, doe-eyed character with pointy ears and special powers, chosen by elementary school kids from a shortlist of three options. The mascot has a strong sense of justice and athleticism, and its magic power allows it to move anywhere instantly. The mascot's Paralympic counterpart, also chosen by schoolchildren, has a calming presence and powerful abilities. The selection aims to avoid a repeat of past mascot failures, which have generated significant revenue for Japan.

images.alt_text: Tokyo Wednesday unveiled its long-awaited mascot for the 2020 Olympic Games: a futuristic blue-checked, doe-eyed character with pointy ears and "special powers" that was picked by schoolchildren across mascot-mad Japan.

site_title: Amazon buys video doorbell startup Ring
summary: Amazon has acquired video doorbell startup Ring for more than a billion dollars, expanding its delivery arm's reach into people's homes. The deal comes as Amazon unveiled its smart lock and camera combination, "Amazon Key", which allows Prime members to track and secure package deliveries. This acquisition marks a new competitive front for Amazon, following Alphabet's expansion of Nest Labs' products. The move is expected to help Ring achieve its mission to reduce crime in neighborhoods with affordable home security tools.

images.alt_text: Amazon confirmed on Tuesday that it bought video doorbell startup Ring, in a move that could help the internet giant's delivery arm reach into people's homes.

site_title: US finds China aluminum foil imports dumped, subsidised
summary: The US Commerce Department has determined that Chinese aluminum foil imports are being sold at less than fair value and producers are receiving subsidies. As a result, antidumping and countervailing duties will be levied on several Chinese firms, with dumping margins ranging from 48.64% to 106.09% and anti-subsidy rates of 17.14% to 80.97%. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross stated that the administration is committed to fair and reciprocal trade, and will not allow American workers and businesses to be harmed by unfair imports.

images.alt_text: The US Commerce Department said on Tuesday it had made a final determination that imports of aluminum foil from China are being sold in the United States at less than their fair value and producers are benefiting from subsidies from Beijing.

site_title: CDL posts 23% drop in Q4 profit to S$186.7m
summary: CDL posted a 23% drop in Q4 profit to S$186.7m, down from S$243.8m a year ago. Revenue rose 14% to S$1.33 billion, driven by The Brownstone EC project. Earnings per share fell to 19.8 cents from 26.1 cents. CDL recommended a special final ordinary dividend of six cents per share and a total dividend of 18 cents per share for 2017.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on fresh Fed rates worries
summary: Hong Kong stocks dropped on Wednesday, following sharp losses on Wall Street due to renewed worries about a sharp increase in interest rates. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.74%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.85% and 0.79%, respectively. The decline follows the Federal Reserve head's comments that revived concerns about a rate hike.

site_title: Singapore shares enter Wednesday afternoon trade flat; STI down 0.02% on day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed flat on Wednesday, retreating 0.59 points, or 0.02%, to 3,539.8. About 1.14 billion shares worth S$967.2 million changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 228 to 139. Notable movers included Lion Gold, Genting Singapore, DBS, and Singtel, with Lion Gold and Genting Singapore being flat and down 1.68% respectively. The market awaits GDP data ahead of the weekend.

site_title: Sinjia Land unit's supplier withdraws application for wind up order
summary: A Singaporean subsidiary, Sinjia RTE Solutions, was served with a wind-up order application by Nutech Automation, a supplier, due to unpaid debts. The application, made on January 23, has been withdrawn and discontinued. Sinjia Land Limited, the parent company, saw its stock price drop to S$0.05 on February 27.

site_title: Advanced Holdings Q4 earnings plunge 85% to S$359,000
summary: Advanced Holdings announced a 85% decline in its net profit to S$359,000 for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2017. Revenue decreased by 14% to S$23.1 million, mainly due to the lack of contribution from a disposed subsidiary. Earnings per share dropped to 0.37 cents, compared to 2.25 cents in the previous year. The company has not proposed dividends for the current period.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower after Fed chief comments
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday following comments from Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell, who testified in the US Congress about potential interest rate hikes. The Nikkei 225 index slipped 0.42% and the Topix index fell 0.30%. The decline was attributed to concerns about higher interest rates, which have been a market worry since Powell's testimony.

site_title: Taiwan developer detained over deadly quake building collapse
summary: Taiwan's developer, Liu, has been detained for negligent manslaughter over the collapse of a 12-storey building in Hualien during an earthquake, resulting in 17 deaths. Liu allegedly lacked necessary engineering qualifications and supervised construction himself, leading to a significant reduction in the building's structural strength. He faces charges alongside three others, including the building's architect and two owners of a restaurant and hotel on the lower floors. The incident highlights Taiwan's ongoing struggles with building collapses during earthquakes, despite stricter building codes implemented after a 1999 quake that killed 2,400 people.

images.alt_text: The developer of a building in Taiwan that partially collapsed during an earthquake has been detained for negligent manslaughter with prosecutors saying the man was not licensed to oversee construction projects.

site_title: Broker's take: UOB Kay Hian maintains 'buy' on Keppel Corp on Awilco rig deal
summary: UOB Kay Hian maintained its 'buy' call on Keppel Corp, with a target price of S$9.30, following the company's announcement of a letter of intent with Awilco Drilling for the construction of a harsh environment semi-submersible drilling rig. The deal has the option to build up three units. Keppel Corp's shares were trading 0.7% lower at S$8.04 apiece as of 11:55am on Wednesday.

site_title: US outlook stronger since December: Federal Reserve Chair
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell stated the US economic outlook is strong and more robust since December's tax cuts. He mentioned considering factors for potential rate hikes three or four times this year, but will not "prejudge" the outcome. Powell's prepared testimony focused on gradual rate increases, as he appeared before lawmakers for the first time.

site_title: Oil prices dip before US crude inventory data
summary: Oil prices dropped on Tuesday, falling 1.4% to $66.63 a barrel, amid a stronger US dollar and expectations of rising US crude inventories. The dollar rose after Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell announced gradual interest rate increases, making oil more expensive for foreign buyers. Analysts forecast US crude inventories rose 2.7 million barrels last week, with the EIA releasing monthly data on crude supply on Wednesday, which may show substantial upward revisions to US oil output.

site_title: Farm groups urge Trump not to weaken US biofuel policy
summary: US farm groups urged President Donald Trump not to weaken the nation's biofuels policy, citing it as a critical engine for rural American jobs. The policy, the Renewable Fuel Standard, requires corn-based ethanol to be blended into petrol. Trump is set to meet with senators and cabinet members to discuss potential tweaks to the law, which oil refiners claim costs them a fortune.

site_title: Cityneon's full-year profit more than doubles on IP rights contributions
summary: Cityneon Holdings, a MAINBOARD-listed events and exhibitions firm, reported a full-year net profit of S$17.39 million, more than doubling from S$6.68 million last year. Revenue rose 20.7% to S$116.74 million, driven by a significant increase in revenue from its Intellectual Property Rights (IPR) business unit, which tripled to S$50.7 million. The company plans to expand its "design and build" services and explore new business development opportunities to enhance shareholder value.

site_title: EC supply crunch powers Punggol site to record price
summary: A record-breaking bid of S$583 psf ppr was placed for the Sumang Walk site in Punggol, surpassing the 2013 record of S$419 psf ppr for EC land. The top bid, from a joint venture between City Developments Ltd and TID, was 39% higher than the previous record. The site, which can accommodate up to 820 residential units, is expected to be developed into a landmark waterfront residence with desirable attributes, including proximity to the Waterway Point shopping mall and the upcoming Punggol Digital District.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Challenging the norms of trade arrangements in a climate of protectionism
summary: The article challenges the dominant ideal of free trade, citing its uneven impact on developed and developing countries. It highlights how protectionism has gained weight in older developed countries since the 2008 recession, influencing Brexit, Donald Trump's election, and nationalist movements. The article suggests that national attitudes towards free trade have historically depended on a country's developmental status, and that a rebalancing of trade arrangements may be necessary. This could involve reducing barriers to trade while allowing for measures to defend domestic production on economic or cultural grounds.

site_title: Savings from US tax cuts unleashing a bonanza of stock buybacks
summary: US companies are using the tax cuts to finance record-high share buybacks, with over $178 billion in planned purchases announced in the fourth quarter. While this may benefit shareholders, it may come at the expense of investments in hiring, research, and development, potentially worsening economic inequality. The benefits of the tax cuts, such as lower corporate rates and a permanent break on overseas profits, are largely being used for short-term gains, rather than long-term investments in the economy.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop on poor earnings, US sell-off; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares dropped 0.3% to 6,037.2, as a US sell-off and poor company results weighed on the market. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 19.7 points, with BHP down 1.5% due to declining commodity prices. Electronics retailer Harvey Norman Holdings plummeted 14.9% after its profit fell 19%. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index remained flat at 8,363.4.

site_title: Centurion Q4 profit down 27% to S$9.3m
summary: Centurion Corporation reported a 27% decline in net profit to S$9.3 million for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2017. Revenue fell 4% to S$33.6 million due to reduced contributions from Westlite Tuas in Singapore. Administrative expenses rose due to one-off fees related to a Hong Kong listing. The board recommended a final dividend of one cent per share and a special dividend of 0.5 cents per share, totaling 2.5 cents for the 2017 financial year.

site_title: 2017 was a good year; what's next?
summary: Private banks enjoyed record growth in assets under management (AUM), income, and profit in 2017, driven by booming markets in Asia. Key players in the sector, including UBS, Credit Suisse, and Citi, reported double-digit growth in AUM and revenue. Despite strong results, industry leaders emphasized the need for adaptation to changing regulatory environments, client preferences, and new competitors. In 2018, experts forecast continued growth, but with a focus on maintaining a balanced investment portfolio and navigating emerging market trends.

site_title: Infrastructure: the key to tackling climate change challenges
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article:

The impact of climate change is severe and intensifying, requiring urgent and multi-pronged global action. To address this challenge, infrastructure investment is crucial, with a need to invest around $100 trillion over the next 15 years. The focus should be on "green" infrastructure that minimizes future carbon emissions and helps economies and communities adapt to climate change impacts. Energy infrastructure, in particular, needs to be upgraded to reduce emissions and become more resilient to climate change. With increasing investment in renewable energy and energy efficiency, governments, private sectors, and institutions must work together to address this challenge.

site_title: Europe: FTSE little changed as Sky soars on Comcast bid
summary: The FTSE 100 index in Europe closed down 0.1% on Tuesday, with Sky soaring 20.5% following Comcast's surprise bid for the pay-TV group. Comcast's $184 billion offer may scupper plans for Rupert Murdoch's Fox to buy out Sky and sell it to Walt Disney. Persimmon's strong results, including a dividend payment increase, helped boost housebuilders. Provident Financial's shares surged 70.4% after it announced a £331 million rights issue. Market reaction to Jerome Powell's comments on "gradual" interest rate increases was muted.

site_title: Creating a sustainable legacy in Asia
summary: Asia's billionaires, with over 85% being first-generation business owners, are shifting their investment strategy to impact investing, led by visionary next-generation family members. The combined net worth of Asian billionaires grew by 30% in 2016, with 637 billionaires in Asia, surpassing the US. Succession planning is a top priority, with 48.4% of families in the Asia-Pacific region developing a plan, and 45% expected to transfer wealth in the next five years. This trend is driven by the emergence of multigenerational family engagements and the need to align family values with investment practices.

site_title: IndoAgri Q4 profit falls 65.4% on lower plantation contributions, lack of one-off gain
summary: Indofood Agri's fourth quarter net profit fell 65.4% to 76.94 billion rupiah due to lower plantation contributions and no one-off gain. Revenue decreased 15.7% to 3.59 trillion rupiah, while net asset value per share increased to 8,671 rupiah. The company attributed the decline to higher production costs, foreign currency fluctuations, and changes in fair values of biological assets. Despite this, the company recommended a first and final dividend for the full year.

site_title: US: Stocks stumble on revived worries over Federal Reserve
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday, reversing recent gains, after Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell's testimony revived worries about higher interest rates. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.2% to 25,410.03, while the S&P 500 fell 1.3% to 2,744.28. Powell's comments suggested the Fed may accelerate interest rate hikes, sparking concerns about inflation and rising borrowing costs. Other individual shares also declined, including Comcast and Disney, despite a strong report from Macy's department store chain.

site_title: Comcast seeks to outfox Murdoch with higher bid for Sky
summary: US cable giant Comcast has made a surprise bid to acquire pan-European satellite TV group Sky, outbidding Rupert Murdoch's 21st Century Fox with an offer of £12.50 per share, worth over £22 billion. The bid comes after the UK government provisionally ruled that Fox's offer was "not in the public interest". Comcast CEO Brian L. Roberts expressed confidence in receiving regulatory approvals and plans to maintain Sky News' existing brand and culture. The move could escalate into a bidding war, with analysts predicting higher offers from other companies, including Disney, which recently acquired 21st Century Fox.

site_title: HSBC tournament is ready for tee off, with no S'porean in the mix
summary: The HSBC Women's World Championship, set to tee off at Sentosa Golf Club, marks the first time in 11 years that no Singaporean golfer will participate. The event boasts 19 of the top-20 world-ranked golfers, including five current Major winners. Local players, despite previous national qualifier wins, have struggled to compete with the elite field. The tournament's organizers have instead opted to feature international golfers, including Thailand's 15-year-old star Atthaya Thitikul, who secured the coveted spot through a wire-to-wire victory.

site_title: OCBC celebrates Year of the Dog with SME customers
summary: OCBC Bank celebrated the Year of the Dog with over 1,000 SME customers from Singapore and the region at The Clifford Pier. The event was attended by OCBC Bank chairman Ooi Sang Kuang, group CEO Samuel Tsien, and head of global commercial banking Linus Goh.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018 GST hike: MPs voice concerns, suggest alternatives
summary: Singapore's Budget 2018 introduced a 2% increase in the Goods and Services Tax (GST) from 7% to 9% from 2021 to 2025. The move drew varied responses, with some MPs proposing alternative revenue sources, while the Workers' Party expressed concerns and inability to support the announcement. The ruling PAP MPs argued the current approach is more responsible, citing adequate warning for the hike.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Stocks to watch: Pacific Radiance, Centurion, CDL, Cityneon, Fragrance Group, UMS
summary: Stocks to watch on Wednesday include Pacific Radiance, which suspended trading after noteholders voted down a debt restructuring plan, and Centurion Corporation, which reported a 27% fall in net profit for the fourth quarter. City Developments Limited (CDL) also posted a 23% fall in net profit, while Cityneon Holdings' full-year net profit more than doubled. Fragrance Group's full-year net profit rose fivefold, and UMS Holdings reported a bumper year with strong semiconductor sales.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Q&M Dental Group reported a 16% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$23.9 million for FY2017. Aoxin Q&M Dental Group, deconsolidated from Q&M in 2017, saw a 46% year-on-year fall in net profit to S$1.06 million. Wheelock Properties reversed a net loss to a net profit of S$19.9 million in its fourth quarter. ESR-Reit aims to raise up to S$141.9 million through a preferential offering of new units, with the Reit's sponsor and Mitsui & Co committing to accept provisional allocations.

site_title: StanChart brings back dividend as profits jump
summary: Standard Chartered Plc restored its dividend after a two-year suspension, with a full-year dividend of 11 US cents per share. The bank's revenue rose 2.6% to US$14.4 billion and underlying pretax profit nearly tripled to US$3.01 billion. CEO Bill Winters cited "significant improvement in underlying profits" and a strong capital position as reasons for the dividend announcement. However, the return on equity remains below target, and the bank still faces challenges in establishing income growth momentum.

site_title: Electric vehicle fervour inspires another bleak petrol forecast
summary: The Boston Consulting Group predicts a potential 30-35% drop in US petrol consumption by 2035 due to growing electric vehicle adoption, which could lead to a third decrease in demand by 2035. This forecast aligns with other research suggesting a decline in oil consumption over the next two decades. However, not all experts agree, with some arguing that demand growth will remain strong, particularly in India, where petrol and diesel consumption is expected to double by 2030.

site_title: Regulatory shake-up in Japan seen as a game changer for the banking industry
summary: Japan's Financial Services Agency is considering a regulatory overhaul to bring emerging companies, such as fintech startups, under the same rules as traditional financial institutions. The goal is to increase competition and adaptability in the $10 trillion banking industry, allowing non-traditional companies to compete with established banks. The overhaul aims to shift from rules focused on entities to rules based on functions, and will cover four key areas: settlements, credit, investing, and risk transfer. The move could free up banks to enter new businesses and increase the competitiveness of the finance sector.

site_title: IHH back in the black in Q4 on absence of exceptional items
summary: IHH Healthcare Berhad reported a Q4 FY17 profit of RM101.26 million, reversing losses from a year ago due to exceptional items. Revenue rose 10% year-on-year to RM2.88 billion, driven by growth from existing operations and new hospital openings. The company recommended a full-year dividend of three sen per share and is poised for growth, with new hospitals expected to be game-changers.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Icy Europe, balmy North Pole: the world upside down
summary: A record-breaking Arctic high temperature has occurred at the North Pole, while Europe experiences a deep freeze, leaving scientists to question the role of global warming in altering winter weather patterns. Temperatures in the Arctic rose above freezing, with a 30°C temperature anomaly, while sea ice coverage in the Arctic Ocean reached its smallest area in over 50 years. This phenomenon is linked to climate change, which has warmed the Arctic region twice as fast as the global average. The connection between the "warm Arctic, cold continent" phenomenon and global warming remains speculative, but scientists attribute the recent weather pattern to "sudden stratospheric warming."

site_title: US core capital goods orders fall; goods trade deficit widens
summary: US core capital goods orders fell for a second consecutive month in January, down 0.2% from December, indicating a slowdown in business spending on equipment. The goods trade deficit widened to $74.4 billion, with exports falling and imports rising. Despite this, economists expect business spending on equipment to remain supported, driven by a US$1.5 trillion tax cut package and companies' plans to boost productivity.

site_title: Call in a tech SWAT team to fend off cyberattacks
summary: Ingram Micro Security Consulting and Services (IMSCS) is addressing the growing need for cybersecurity expertise in Singapore and the region. The company, which recently acquired local cybersecurity firm CNAV, offers consulting, implementation, operations, and risk assessment services to help enterprises protect their cybersecurity. IMSCS provides specialized services, including vulnerability assessment and penetration testing, configuration management and assurance service, and annual subscription packages. The company aims to provide regional services capabilities to its key vendors and customers, with plans to expand to emerging economies such as Indonesia, Vietnam, and Myanmar.

images.alt_text: Chantal Sajan

site_title: Trump aide Hicks declines to answer Russia hearing questions
summary: Hope Hicks, a top aide to President Donald Trump, appeared at a closed congressional hearing on Russian election meddling, but refused to answer many questions. Hicks stuck to pre-approved answers, similar to other Trump inner-circle advisors who have testified. This means she avoided discussing her work and White House contacts with Russia following the 2016 presidential election and inauguration. Democratic Congressman Mike Quigley stated that Hicks' refusal to answer questions was unusual, as other advisors have answered questions about their work. Hicks' testimony was limited to pre-approved questions.

site_title: 2018: Will the bears return in the Year of the Dog?
summary: Investors face a challenging year in 2018 due to late-cycle global equity markets. Key risks include a potential peak in geopolitical risk, central bank policies, and the economic cycle in the US. The market has overrated the impact of geopolitical events, and central banks are expected to slow their growth of balance sheets. The US economy is in its third-longest expansion, but European and Asian economies are in mid-cycle, supporting global growth. The forecast is for global growth in GDP to average over 3% for another year, with a moderate overweight equity view after the correction in Asian markets.

site_title: Noble's Q4 losses 'extremely shocking': Goldilocks
summary: Noble Group, a commodities trader, has issued a profit warning, expecting a fourth-quarter net loss of $1.7 billion to $1.9 billion and a full-year net loss of $4.8 billion to $5 billion. The company's major shareholder, Goldilocks Investment Company, describes the figures as "extremely shocking." The losses are attributed to non-cash net losses of $1.45 billion to $1.55 billion, with $0.9 billion to $1 billion of that attributed to changes in the discount rate used to value derivatives. The timing of the release raises questions about whether Noble's management is deliberately releasing losses to pressure stakeholders to approve a proposed restructuring plan.

site_title: Facebook can't avoid suit over biometric prints
summary: A US federal judge in San Francisco ruled that Facebook must face claims that its photo scanning technology violated users' privacy by gathering and storing biometric data without consent. The ruling lets a class action case proceed, potentially leading to new restrictions on Facebook's use of biometrics in the US. The Illinois residents who sued alleged that Facebook disregarded Illinois law, which requires user consent for biometric data collection. The case could lead to fines under a unique Illinois law, with potential fines ranging from $1,000 to $5,000 per image used without permission.

site_title: The China threat: Theory or reality?
summary: China's rapid growth and assertive behavior are causing alarm globally, with many countries viewing Beijing's increasing influence as a threat. Despite China's denials, countries like Japan, US, and Europe are taking steps to counter its growing power. A recent report by the Mercator Institute for China Studies warns of China's pervasive influence efforts in Europe and its challenge to liberal democracy. Meanwhile, Australia and New Zealand are proposing legislation to crack down on foreign interference in politics. China's increasing authoritarianism and lack of reciprocity in investments are fueling concerns about the "China threat."

site_title: US dollar steady as spotlight falls on Powell
summary: The US dollar steadied against major currencies ahead of Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell's Congressional testimony. Traders are cautious about the impact of his testimony on the currency's recovery from a three-year low. Powell's first public appearance since becoming chairman could determine the dollar's further recovery.

site_title: Olam focusing on digitalisation, posts Q4 profit of S$265m
summary: Olam International reported a Q4 net profit of S$265.1 million, more than double from the previous year, driven by one-off gains from divestments and lower depreciation. The company is focusing on digitalisation, incorporating sensors in almond plantations to improve water usage efficiencies by 22-23%. Olam also piloted digital procurement programs in Indonesia for cocoa and coffee. Revenue grew 18.5% to S$7.2 billion in Q4, and the company recommended a final dividend of 4 Singapore cents per share, the highest payout since 2014.

site_title: Size does not matter when it comes to charity
summary: Toluna, a small survey firm in Singapore, has been providing pro bono use of its services to the National Volunteer and Philanthropy Centre (NVPC) since 2016. The partnership has helped NVPC gain valuable insights into the mindset of Singaporeans and improve its marketing efforts. The quarterly surveys have led to significant increases in donations to charities through the Giving.sg platform, and NVPC has seen improved allocation of resources through Toluna's analysis of marketing channels. The partnership aims to continue providing actionable insights to support NVPC's mission.

site_title: Investing in European real estate: Opportunities and strategies
summary: The European real estate market is expected to deliver attractive rental and capital growth in the coming years, driven by a favourable macroeconomic outlook. The region's economic recovery has strengthened, with the eurozone experiencing its strongest growth in the last 10 years, and the European Central Bank unlikely to raise interest rates in 2018. A disequilibrium between supply and demand, combined with declining vacancy rates in rental markets, is expected to lead to higher rents and increased investment opportunities. Investors can consider a range of strategies, including core, core-plus, value-added, and opportunistic approaches, to tap into the European property market's value proposition.

site_title: Fragrance posts 505% increase in full-year net profit
summary: Fragrance Group reported a 505.3% increase in full-year net profit to S$48.55 million, driven by higher turnover, other operating income, and a joint venture. Earnings per share rose to 0.72 Singapore cents, up from 0.11 cents in FY16.

site_title: Managing urban waters in Africa: challenges ahead
summary: African countries face significant urban water management challenges due to rapid population growth and urbanization. Between 1960 and 2017, Africa's population increased by 1 billion, with urbanization rates rising from 10.3% to 40%. By 2050, Africa's population is projected to reach 2.52 billion and urbanization is expected to reach 53%. The current water crisis in Cape Town highlights the need for improved urban water services across the continent.

site_title: Steelmaker POSCO to buy lithium from Australian miner
summary: South Korean steelmaker POSCO has agreed to buy up to 240,000 tonnes of lithium concentrate per year from Australian miner Pilbara Minerals to supply electric vehicle battery producers. As part of the deal, POSCO's Australian unit will acquire a 4.75% stake in Pilbara for A$79.6 million. The partnership aims to support the growing demand for lithium in the electric vehicle industry.

site_title: GST hike aimed at helping Singapore remain competitive while staying inclusive: Tharman
summary: Singapore plans to increase its Goods and Services Tax (GST) from 7% to 9% to remain competitive while ensuring sustainable and inclusive growth. The hike, set to be implemented between 2021 and 2025, aims to balance competitiveness with healthcare affordability for an aging population. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the increase as part of Budget 2018, with Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasizing the need for fairness to all classes.

site_title: Tulip Garden, Windy Heights join en bloc wagon
summary: Two Singapore en bloc projects, Tulip Garden and Windy Heights, are set to launch collective sale tenders. Tulip Garden owners are seeking S$753 million, while Windy Heights has a reserve price of S$806 million. The sales are part of a surge in en bloc deals, with over S$3.1 billion in sales so far this year, and analysts expect the success rate to slow as developers become more choosy. The projects offer attractive land rates, with Tulip Garden's at S$1,486 psf ppr and Windy Heights' at S$1,288 psf ppr, making them comparable to recent successful deals in the area.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: CPFIS funds yield positive returns in Q4
summary: CPFIS funds in Singapore yielded positive returns in Q4 2017, with an average increase of 3.61% in unit trusts and 3.42% in investment-linked insurance products. Equities and mixed-asset funds outperformed, with returns of 4.68% and 3.00%, respectively. For the full year, CPFIS-included funds posted a 15.82% average return, with unit trusts rising 16.54% and ILPs climbing 15.40%. This positive performance comes as global markets experience volatility and inflation concerns spread.

site_title: Don't be shy, catch China's transformations
summary: China is undergoing significant transformations, including economic restructuring, financial sustainability, and capital flows, that will elevate its representation in global capital markets. China's economy is shifting from fixed investment growth to consumption and services, with exports growing at 7.8% and imports at 16.4%. The country has also made strides in financial sustainability, with corporate debt decreasing and interest rates rising, and is poised to grow at 6.5% in 2018. As China's benchmark climbs, investors should consider increasing their exposure to Chinese equities, which currently account for only 3.5% of MSCI World.

site_title: UIC helps UOL lift earnings 3 times to S$891m
summary: UOL Group's net profit jumped three times to S$891 million in the year ended Dec 31, driven by higher contributions from core business segments. The group's revenue rose 46% to S$2.1 billion, largely due to the consolidation of UIC. Despite securing several residential sites, UOL is concerned about aggressive land price escalation, particularly for collective sale sites. The company remains committed to replenishing its landbank and expects sustained growth in the economy and residential market.

site_title: Aston Martin posts first profit in eight years as it eyes IPO
summary: Aston Martin Holdings Ltd reported its first annual profit in eight years, with pretax profit reaching £87 million in 2017, up from a loss of £163 million in 2016. Strong sales of its latest sports car models, including the DB11 supercar, contributed to the turnaround. The company is considering an initial public offering, with a potential valuation of £5 billion, and expects earnings to improve again this year. CEO Andy Palmer's turnaround efforts are seen as a success, paving the way for a potential IPO.

site_title: Retailer Sam's Club partners Instacart to deliver groceries
summary: Sam's Club, a unit of Walmart, has partnered with Instacart to offer home delivery of groceries in select cities, including Austin and Dallas-Forth Worth in Texas, and St Louis. The service is available without a membership and is part of Sam's new CEO John Furner's strategic shift to turn around the underperforming business. This move comes as the grocery industry faces intense competition and disruption, with Amazon's acquisition of Whole Foods last year. Instacart, which handles shopping and delivery from 200 retailers, has raised $200 million in funding to compete with Amazon.

site_title: Cryptocurrencies - a technological disruption and a challenge for all
summary: Cryptocurrencies, a new form of electronic cash, have gained popularity due to investors' quest for financial return and technological advancements. However, they come with significant challenges, including high volatility, price manipulations, and technical issues. Despite these shortcomings, some investors view cryptocurrencies as an alternative to traditional currencies, particularly in emerging economies. Regulation is a key concern, with the lack of governance and oversight potentially leading to social and economic instability. The underlying distributed ledger technology, however, holds potential for commercial applications beyond cryptocurrency use.

site_title: NETS told to hire consultant following disruption
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has instructed NETS to hire a consultant to enhance controls and minimize disruptions caused by human errors, following a January 2018 EFTPOS service outage. The outage, which lasted about an hour, was caused by a human error during a planned system change. NETS has taken interim measures to tighten controls and mitigate consequences, and MAS will closely monitor the remediation process. No regulatory breaches were reported, and the MAS emphasized the importance of having alternative payment methods in place.

site_title: Heart disease kills more women than breast cancer
summary: Heart disease is the leading cause of death in women, accounting for one in four deaths, yet high cholesterol is often overlooked as a risk factor. According to a CDC report, nearly 35% of women aged 40-59 have high cholesterol, and women are less likely to take cholesterol-lowering medications than men. Experts emphasize that cholesterol is not the only risk factor, and lifestyle changes such as quitting smoking, exercise, and a healthy diet are more effective in reducing heart disease risk.

site_title: STI falls as traders eye key Fed testimony
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 15.46 points or 0.4% to 3,540.39, closing lower for the second half of the trading session ahead of US Fed Chairman Jerome Powell's testimony to Congress. Investors are cautious about Powell's potential signals on monetary policy tightening. The mixed regional bourse performance follows overnight gains on Wall Street, with China's Shanghai Composite down 1.13% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng slipping 0.7%.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Golden Agri falls into the red in Q4 with US$29m loss
summary: Golden Agri-Resources, the largest palm oil plantation firm in Indonesia, reported a net loss of US$29.1 million in the fourth quarter of 2017, compared to a net profit of US$46.3 million a year ago. The company attributed the loss to slower production, an impairment charge on an oilseeds plant, and higher foreign exchange losses. Revenue declined 10% to US$1.9 billion, and the group's full-year net profit plummeted 81.5% to US$74 million. Despite this, the company expects the industry's output to grow 8-9% this year, driven by increased demand in China and biodiesel exports.

site_title: Investors' dilemma
summary: Global equity markets are expected to remain volatile in 2018, despite positive investor sentiment, due to high valuations and the potential for monetary policy tightening. Economic growth is expected to continue, with inflation stabilizing and central banks gradually tightening monetary policy. Investors should consider buying hedges when they are cheap and diversifying their portfolios with alternative assets. Equities are expected to deliver better returns than fixed income in 2018, with markets outside the US showing more upside opportunities. Investors should be cautious of a US recession, but rising inflation is seen as a key driver of asset price growth.

site_title: Cash holdings don't suggest a market turn
summary: Cash holdings by fund managers do not signal an impending market turn, as they may invest during good times to maintain liquidity. Ample liquidity supply exists due to accommodative monetary policy, with G4 central banks' balance sheets not peaking until mid-2018. This liquidity has spread from financial sectors to real estate, asset classes, and the broader economy, indicating a stable financial environment.

site_title: UK astronaut hails 'groundbreaking' satellite
summary: UK astronaut Tim Peake hailed a "groundbreaking" satellite being built by Airbus as a symbol of British innovation in space. The Eutelsat Quantum satellite, set to launch in 2019, will be the first commercial satellite to be fully reconfigurable in orbit, allowing operators to change key elements in real-time. The satellite will provide unprecedented flexibility to space telecommunications, enabling adaptability to changing market conditions and regulatory constraints. The project is an example of international partnership, with the UK contributing to the ESA-led programme.

site_title: Cuscaden Road site up for tender under govt land sales programme
summary: A 5,722.5 sq m 99-year leasehold site in Singapore's Orchard Road district has been launched for sale under the government's Government Land Sales (GLS) programme. The site, zoned for residential use, faces Regent Singapore and has a maximum building height of 100 m. Expected to yield around 170 units, the site is highly sought after due to its central location and limited new supply of private non-landed residential units. The tender is expected to attract 10-18 bidders, with prices ranging from S$1,800 to S$2,300 per square foot per plot ratio.

site_title: SGX set to snag its first fintech listing through Ayondo's IPO
summary: Ayondo, a European social-trading broker, is set to become the first fintech company to list on the Catalist platform of the Singapore Exchange (SGX) through an initial public offering (IPO). The company, which has struggled with losses, is valued at close to S$140 million and could list as early as next month. The IPO will test Singapore investors' risk appetite for startups, but is seen as a boon for SGX, which aims to move into the new economy and attract more fintech listings.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Leave no one behind, MPs urge government
summary: Singapore's Budget 2018 highlighted the need to address manpower issues as the country seeks to transform its economy. MPs urged the government to consider adjustments to foreign manpower policies to support growth areas such as data analytics and cyber-security. They also emphasized the importance of aligning all segments of the population with industry transformation maps and raising the employment rate of older workers. To address these issues, MPs proposed setting up a tripartite committee to assess the effective retirement age and recommend measures to support older workers, as well as increasing youth involvement in small and medium-sized enterprises through internship opportunities.

site_title: Rise of women leaders in maritime
summary: The maritime industry in Asia is slowly becoming more gender-diverse, with efforts to advance women's roles yielding results. Despite challenges, women are increasingly joining the industry at the entry level in various roles and are making strides in higher management. Female veterans, such as Magdalene Chew, Xue Hua, Su Yin Anand, and Dorcas Teo, share their experiences and advice, emphasizing the importance of female role models, networking, and targeted education and training. They also highlight the need for companies and society to change their mindset and provide support for women who want to build careers in the maritime sector.

site_title: The rise of ESG investing in Asia
summary: Responsible investing has entered the mainstream in Asia, with government pension funds and sovereign wealth funds driving the growth of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) investments. Asia's ESG assets under management reached $500 billion, accounting for 2.2% of global ESG assets. Key countries like Japan, South Korea, and Hong Kong are leading the adoption of ESG principles, with mandates for sustainability reporting from stock exchanges. China has also stepped up its green finance efforts, with plans to have 20% of vehicles running on alternative fuel by 2025 and established five "green finance" pilot zones. The growing demand from next-gen investors for ESG strategies is expected to drive further growth in the region.

site_title: A long, dry wait for DeClout's third act
summary: DeClout, a holding company for next-generation technology firms, has seen a significant decline in shareholder value. Its shares trade at S$0.07, 72% lower than its IPO price of S$0.25 in 2012. Two years ago, DeClout had two big exits on its investments, but no subsequent "harvests" have materialized. The company's most recent IPO in July 2016 raised S$34.6 million, but its value has since plummeted. DeClout's performance raises concerns about the company's ability to deliver on its promise of successful exits.

site_title: American Airlines, Qantas re-seek US nod for JV
summary: American Airlines and Qantas are re-submitting their joint venture application to the US for coordination on prices and schedules, aiming to improve services and unlock consumer benefits of over $300 million annually. The airlines, which were previously rejected in 2016, hope the new administration's lighter regulatory approach will favor their application. A rejection could result in Qantas reducing its A380 service between Sydney and Dallas/Fort Worth, and American further reducing services between Los Angeles and Sydney.

site_title: Sold in 12 minutes: House found with skeletal remains went for S$2.23m
summary: A 1,720 sq ft abandoned terrace house in Singapore's Sembawang Hills Estate was sold at a frenzied auction for S$2.23 million in 12 minutes. The house, which had been in a dilapidated state for 10 years, was previously the residence of two sets of skeletal remains found in 2006. The Public Trustee's Office put the house up for auction after relatives' claims were dismissed, and it was won by a 70-year-old local contractor, Toh Yong Chuan, who plans to tear down the house and build a new one.

images.alt_text: Toh Yong Chuan

site_title: Alibaba delivery deal could be a tasty side dish
summary: Alibaba is reportedly planning to buy the remaining 75% of Chinese food delivery company Ele.me, valuing it at around $9.5 billion. The deal could enhance Alibaba's logistics and payments operations, supporting its expanding bricks-and-mortar portfolio and Alipay system. The business of food delivery is growing rapidly in China, with projected sales of nearly $50 billion in 2018, and Alibaba's move could help it compete with rival Meituan Dianping.

site_title: AIA group and S'pore division report firm growth for FY17
summary: AIA Singapore reported a 12% increase in operating profit after tax to US$504 million for FY2017, driven by growth in its high-quality in-force portfolio and new business. The company achieved a US$311 million value of new business and a 12% increase in annualised new premium. AIA Singapore attributed its success to its "disciplined approach" to product mix management and the growth of its digital sales and training tools. The AIA Group as a whole reported double-digit growth across its main financial metrics for FY2017.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: China urges regions to take responsibility after smog surge in Yangtze
summary: China's regional governments must take more responsibility for local pollution and stop blaming others for smog surges in the Yangtze and Pearl river delta regions. PM2.5 concentrations rose 20% in the Yangtze delta and 3.9% in the Pearl river delta in January, amid a nationwide crackdown in northern regions. China's Ministry of Environmental Protection urges local governments to improve air quality and is preparing to introduce tougher targets.

site_title: Alleged mastermind behind penny stock crash loses second bid for bail
summary: John Soh Chee Wen, alleged mastermind behind the 2013 penny stock crash, has lost a second bid for bail in a Singapore High Court hearing. Justice Hoo Sheau Peng ruled that Soh poses a flight risk and could tamper with witnesses, citing his past movements and lack of family ties in Singapore. Soh, 59, faces 188 criminal charges, including witness tampering, over his alleged involvement in manipulating penny stock prices, resulting in a market crash of over S$8 billion.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Apple shares on verge of record high after Buffett comments
summary: Warren Buffett expressed confidence in Apple, stating his company, Berkshire Hathaway, has increased its stake in the iPhone maker by 23% and plans to retain customers through its ecosystem. Apple shares rose 2% and are on the verge of a record high. The company is expected to launch its largest-ever iPhone, along with two other smartphones, later this year. Since its quarterly report, nine analysts have raised their price targets for Apple, with the median target increasing to $192.43, valuing the company at $989 billion.

site_title: South Korea keeps investors guessing on cryptocurrency regulation
summary: South Korea's government is uncertain about how to regulate cryptocurrency trading, with a senior official stating that sufficient consultations must come first. Minister Hong Nam-ki expressed the government's desire to foster transparency in the market, but a decision on whether to ban trading or regulate exchanges remains contentious. The country's opaque market has raised concerns about money laundering and other risks, with global policymakers warning investors to be cautious. South Korea's regulator has promised normalization, but the lack of clear regulation has led to a decline in bitcoin's value.

site_title: Apple plans biggest iPhone yet for 2018
summary: Apple plans to release three new iPhones in 2018, including the largest iPhone ever, which may have a 16.5 cm screen, larger than the Samsung Galaxy S9 Plus. The new phones will include an upgraded iPhone X, a less expensive model with X's key features, and a gold-coloured device for Asian markets. The release is expected this fall, following production tests with suppliers. This move aims to revive the screen-size wars and capitalize on a saturated market, where global smartphone sales were down 0.1% last year.

site_title: End of Nifty futures: Fighting protectionist pressures abroad
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has seen its Nifty futures franchise unravel due to India's decision to curb offshoring of Indian equity-linked derivatives to protect domestic market liquidity. India's National Stock Exchange (NSE) and other exchanges have cut off data feeds to foreign exchanges and ended licence agreements with immediate effect. This move affects SGX's Nifty-linked products, which accounted for 12% of its total derivatives volumes in the first half of 2018. India aims to increase domestic market share, but the decision is seen as protectionist and may harm SGX's interests.

site_title: Deal with ageing population well, or face a triple whammy
summary: Singapore's rapidly ageing population poses a triple whammy: a shrinking workforce, increased pressure on the government to raise taxes, and a loss of valuable manpower. To mitigate this, companies must support older workers in upgrading their skills to keep up with technological changes, rather than simply hiring younger workers. Industry Transformation Maps can help achieve this, with a focus on digitally aware and technologically competent mature workers. By doing so, Singapore can turn an ageing workforce into a strength, rather than a drag.

site_title: Growth strong but countries must prepare for change: IMF chief
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde stated the global economy is showing broad-based growth, with expected 3.9% growth in 2018 and 2019. However, she warned of heightened risks from trade disputes, monetary policy normalisation, and technological change. Lagarde cautioned policymakers to prepare for higher interest rates, financial stability concerns, and potential job losses. She emphasized the need for countries to adopt new growth models, invest in education, and adapt to technological changes to mitigate the impact on workers and economies.

site_title: US core capital goods orders fall for second straight month
summary: US core capital goods orders fell 0.2% in January for the second straight month, a decline of 0.6% in December. Shipments of core capital goods rose 0.1% after an upwardly revised 0.7% increase in December. The decline suggests a slowdown in business spending on equipment after robust growth in 2017, with economists attributing it to moderation in economic growth.

site_title: Overseas growth helps Scotiabank, BMO beat profit estimates
summary: Canadian lenders Scotiabank and Bank of Montreal reported better-than-expected quarterly earnings, driven by resilient domestic performances and overseas growth. Scotiabank's earnings per share rose 18% to C$1.86, while Bank of Montreal's earnings per share excluding one-off items fell 7% to C$2.12. The banks' international businesses saw significant growth, with Scotiabank's net income surging 16% to C$667 million. This beats analyst expectations and suggests a positive outlook for the Canadian banking sector.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: MP calls for employer CPF rate to stay constant with age
summary: Singapore MPs proposed several ideas to support workers during the Budget 2018 debate, including a universal CPF rate for older workers, mandatory annual wage supplement or 13th month bonus for low-wage workers, and stricter regulation of third-party platforms for freelancers. MPs also suggested making eldercare or family-care leave mandatory and increasing nurses' wages to address the gender pay gap. Additionally, they proposed regulatory changes to improve workplace safety and health, including a reporting regime for near-miss accidents.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Powell indicates he'll keep bolstering growth in public debut
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell is expected to paint an optimistic picture of the US economy, signaling continued growth and a balanced approach to interest rates. In his public debut, Powell emphasized the job market's strength and business investment, while pledging to maintain the policies of his predecessor, Janet Yellen. He aims to strike a balance between avoiding an overheated economy and allowing inflation to reach the 2% target. Powell faces scrutiny over potential interest rate hikes, with some investors expecting more increases than anticipated.

site_title: TT International gets nod to update term sheet; move will give it access to interim funding
summary: TT International, a distressed consumer electronics retailer, has reached an agreement with an unnamed investor to update a term sheet for S$125 million of proposed investment. The amendment allows for possible interim funding, critical for the firm to continue operations at the Big Box building.
