Many, such as Swiss curler Dominik Maerki and Polish speed skater Zbigniew Brodka, are resuming their pre-Olympic careers, with some finding it easier to cope with the pressures of competition after working in other professions. Others, like Norwegian curler Kristin Skaslien, have found perspective in their pre-Olympic jobs, with some even receiving financial support from their employers. Despite the glamour of the Olympics, many athletes struggle to make ends meet, with some resorting to crowdfunding to support their participation.

site_title: Euro rises as traders eye central bank speeches
summary: The euro rose 0.3% to US$1.2334 on Monday as the dollar declined amid falling US Treasury yields. The euro's rally is due to dollar weakness and expectations of the European Central Bank tightening monetary policy, but analysts warn of cautious trading ahead of central bank speeches and political developments in Germany and Italy. The dollar index eased 0.2% to 89.685, while investors are wary of taking big positions due to potential risks from the Italian and German elections.

site_title: CNMC's gold production poised to recover this year: CEO
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings, a Malaysian gold miner, reported a net profit of US$1.29 million for the fourth quarter of 2017, reversing a net loss of US$1.94 million in the same period last year. The company's revenue declined 6.2% due to lower gold production, but its bottom line was boosted by a reduction in management remuneration and employees' compensation. CNMC is poised to recover this year with the start of full-scale production at its carbon-in-leach plant and plans to monetize other minerals, including silver, lead, and zinc, at its Sokor project.

site_title: Pacific Radiance faces technical default after noteholders throw out debt resolutions
summary: Pacific Radiance's noteholders rejected two debt restructuring resolutions, leading to a technical default. The move follows a consent solicitation exercise on Friday. The firm's listed status may be impacted by the default, although the article does not provide further details on potential consequences.

site_title: 'Emperor' stocks soar in China
summary: China's ruling Communist Party proposed removing a constitutional clause limiting presidential service to two terms, paving the way for President Xi Jinping to stay in office indefinitely. This move led to a surge in "emperor" stocks, as speculators bet on Xi's prolonged rule. The proposal's passage sets pressure on policymakers to address slowing GDP growth and other economic concerns.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on tech gains
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Monday, driven by gains in technology stocks and expectations of continued monetary tightening under new Fed chair Jerome Powell. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.46%, the S&P 500 gained 0.44%, and the Nasdaq Composite added 0.5%.

site_title: Understanding nature of Vietnamese communism
summary: A recent case of Vietnamese individuals jailed for flying the flag of the former South Vietnam (RVN) regime highlights the country's complex history with communism. The RVN flag represents a dictatorship that received US aid to fight North Vietnam, yet neither the US nor RVN aimed to bring democracy. Many South Vietnamese joined the National Liberation Front to liberate the country due to corruption, coercion, and failure to meet economic aspirations. The re-education programme, initiated after reunification, aimed to convert loyalists into model citizens, but its effectiveness remains a concern. Vietnam's success as an economic power under communism has led to a lack of historical memory among the younger generation, who need to understand the complex nature of Vietnamese communism.

site_title: ComfortDelGro has to disrupt itself
summary: ComfortDelGro, Singapore's largest taxi operator, faces a disruption of its own after Uber's potential sale of its South-east Asian business to Grab. The company had partnered with Uber's private car rental subsidiary, Lion City Holdings, but the outcome of the sale and regulatory review will determine its next move. If rejected, ComfortDelGro must innovate, enhancing its mobile app and exploring new growth areas. Alternatively, if approved, it will partner with Grab, but in a less favorable position.

site_title: Boeing to have 51% stake in venture with Embraer: paper
summary: Boeing will have a 51% stake in a joint company with Embraer, a Brazilian aircraft maker, after negotiations with the Brazilian government. This comes after Boeing's initial plan to buy Embraer was rejected due to concerns over foreign control of the company's defense unit. The joint company will focus on commercial aviation, excluding Embraer's defense unit, and would create a market leader in the smaller passenger jet market, potentially increasing competition for the CSeries aircraft programme.

site_title: Bank of Japan likely to stay the course for stimulus programme
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda has no plans to reassess the central bank's stimulus program, which has failed to meet its 2% inflation target despite years of heavy money printing. Kuroda dismissed a proposal for a comprehensive review, citing the steady economy's recovery and the effectiveness of monetary easing. The BOJ will maintain its massive stimulus, with inflation still distant from its target, and policymakers are wary of ramping up stimulus due to dwindling policy options and rising costs of prolonged easing.

site_title: A world with no bank bonuses? It's not so bad
summary: A world without bank bonuses could have a positive impact, as it would eliminate the potential for job dissatisfaction, door-slamming, and excessive risk-taking. Banks that have voluntarily stopped paying bonuses, such as Handelsbanken, have seen successful results, with the bank's stock doubling in 10 years. Some argue that bonuses incentivize risk-taking, which led to the 2008 financial crisis, while others believe that short-term incentives can lead to worse performance. Implementing a system with fixed salaries and long-term incentives could help mitigate these issues and create a more stable financial environment.

site_title: The political consequences of slower economic growth
summary: The US economic report, released by President Donald Trump's administration, highlights the consequences of slower economic growth, which may erode social cohesion and exacerbate rising inequality. The report suggests that economic growth serves as a social glue, counteracting factors that drive people apart. A prolonged period of slow growth could lead to widespread frustration and potentially destabilize the social fabric. The report's findings coincide with concerns about the impact of economic inequality on US politics, sparking a debate about the role of economic growth in advanced democracies.

site_title: Geely shares surge as chairman builds stake in Daimler
summary: Li Shufu, chairman of Geely Automobile Holdings Ltd, has built a $9 billion stake in Daimler AG, making him the company's largest shareholder. This move aims to gain leverage in negotiations for technology cooperation, particularly in autonomous driving and electric vehicles. Geely's shares surged 7% on the news, while Daimler's edged 0.6% lower. The stake acquisition is seen as part of China's efforts to bolster its tech capabilities in the automotive market, despite a broader crackdown on outbound deals.

site_title: IMF chief urges Jakarta to boost growth to create jobs
summary: IMF managing director Christine Lagarde urged Indonesia to boost its growth rate to create jobs, praising the country's economic management and stronger policies. Indonesia's economy has struggled to exceed 5% growth, below China and India, and Lagarde discussed the importance of achieving higher potential growth to support job creation. The IMF recommended focusing on financing infrastructure with domestic revenue to avoid external debt. Lagarde's visit comes two decades after Indonesia's painful IMF bail-out.

site_title: Deutsche Bank kicks off asset management unit's IPO
summary: Deutsche Bank has announced its intention to sell shares in its asset management unit, DWS, through an initial public offering (IPO). The IPO, expected to take place in the earliest available window, will only sell existing shares held indirectly by Deutsche Bank. The unit aims to deliver shareholder value and achieve targets of net inflows of 3-5% of assets and an adjusted cost-to-income ratio of less than 65%. A successful IPO would mark an important achievement for Deutsche Bank CEO John Cryan, who proposed the IPO last year to bolster capital and give the business more independence.

site_title: Old tensions clash with grand ambition in new Indian city Amaravati
summary: India is building a new capital city, Amaravati, in the state of Andhra Pradesh, with a projected population of 3.5 million by 2050. The city, modeled after Singapore, aims to be a greenfield capital with eco-friendly features and modern infrastructure. However, critics argue that officials ignored protests from farmers who gave up land, and the ecological impact of building on farmland close to the Krishna River. The project has raised concerns about the displacement of marginalized communities and the loss of power for individuals to shape their own communities.

site_title: Dolce & Gabbana opens the gates of fashion heaven
summary: Dolce & Gabbana showcased its fall-winter 2018/19 collection in a Milan fashion week event, featuring church-influenced designs, opulent fabrics, and iconic traits. The show included drones carrying handbags, golden gates, and angels, with phrases like "Holy fashion pray for us" printed on clothes. The collection combined rich and bright elements, including black lace, veils, and Italy's southern traditions. The event was seen as a celebration of fashion heaven, marking a spectacular finale to Milan's fashion week.

site_title: Nokia phones look to the future, and to the past
summary: Nokia is expanding its phone lineup with a premium Android smartphone and a remake of its iconic 8110 "slider" phone, its first major releases since its comeback. The new devices are being developed by HMD Global, a company licensed by ex-Nokia executives. This marks a shift towards mid-priced and budget-friendly Android options, including a sub-$100 model.

site_title: Raffles Medical ups FY17 dividend; prepares to launch hospitals in China
summary: Raffles Medical Group raised its FY17 dividend payout, signaling confidence in its outlook, with a final dividend of 1.75 Singapore cents per share. The group's net profit edged up 0.8% year on year to S$70.78 million, driven by higher hospital services revenue. Raffles Medical prepares to launch a new 700-bed hospital in Chongqing in the fourth quarter of this year and a 400-bed hospital in Shanghai in 2019. The company plans to reinvest profits to grow future income and aims to break even on its Chongqing hospital in about three years.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Pakistan economic woes go from bad to worse before elections
summary: Pakistan's government is struggling to fix its economy five months before national polls, with the country's currency devalued and taxes raised to curb rising imports. The current account and trade deficits are at records, while foreign exchange reserves continue to fall. Experts predict a balance of payments crisis and potential IMF bailout, citing a widening current account deficit and declining foreign exchange reserves. The nation's economy is growing at 5.3% despite high import demand fueled by China's Belt and Road trade route.

site_title: China's January home prices rise even as top cities post decline
summary: China's new home prices rose 5% in January, driven by government efforts to support first-time buyers and upgraders. However, major cities, including tier one cities, saw early signs of softening, with prices declining in 11 cities year-on-year. The slowdown in growth rate is attributed to purchase restrictions and monetary policy tightening, which led to higher mortgage rates. Despite this, demand for housing remains resilient, with some cities experiencing price gains. The government aims to balance the risks of a slowdown in the sector with its growth target of 6.5% for 2018.

site_title: Major quake halts oil and gas operations in Papua New Guinea
summary: A 7.5 magnitude earthquake struck Papua New Guinea's Southern Highlands, causing landslides, damage to buildings, and halting oil and gas operations. The USGS reported the quake occurred 560km northwest of the capital Port Moresby at 3.45am local time. At least one company began evacuating non-essential personnel following the disaster.

site_title: Sunsea court filing dismissed, paving way for Keppel asset sale
summary: The Court of Appeal in Singapore has dismissed an application by Sunsea Yacht Club to block Keppel Corporation's planned divestment of a stake in a China marina project. The dismissal removes a roadblock to Keppel's planned sale, with costs awarded to Keppel's units. The decision allows Keppel to proceed with the sale, which could result in a gain of around S$290 million for the company.

site_title: Xi as China's long-haul leader: Beware the 'key-person' risk this creates
summary: China's President Xi Jinping is set to remain in power beyond 2023, potentially ruling for life, after the Communist Party repeals presidential term limits. This move simplifies the calculation of political risk in China, where companies associated with influential families have historically flourished. Investors are uncertain whether Xi's determination to stay in power is a risk-on or risk-off moment for the entire emerging markets asset class, which now accounts for a third of the MSCI Emerging Markets Index. The decision poses a significant test for investors and policymakers.

site_title: Want a new luxury watch? Trade in the one on your wrist
summary: The luxury watch industry is experiencing a surge in the secondhand market, with wealthy owners trading in their used timepieces for new or different styles. Swiss watchmakers are embracing the resale movement, seeking to lure shoppers back to stores. Brands such as Audemars Piguet, TAG Heuer, and Breitling are opening standalone stores to buy and sell secondhand watches, while others, like Richard Mille, are exploring the sale of preowned watches in the Americas. The preowned market is growing rapidly, with sales estimated to be around $5 billion annually, and is predicted to exceed the new market in the next five years.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ST Engineering appoints Russell Tham as president of new enterprises and ventures, injecting S$47 million into a new vehicle. Noble Group disposes assets for US$10.1 million, resulting in a US$6.8 million loss. BEST World International reports a 77.2% increase in net profit to S$21.8 million for the three months to Dec 31, 2017. SMI secures an exclusive deal to develop The Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf brand in Myanmar. Frasers Centrepoint Trust appoints Cheong Choong Kong as chairman of the board, abolishing the need for a separate lead independent director role.

site_title: Coding simplicity into learning
summary: Code Gakko, a Singapore-based coding education startup, aims to make coding accessible to primary school students through its customised platform, GakkoBlocks. Founded in 2016, the company has developed a teacher's dashboard and materials to ensure consistency in instruction. With a focus on scalability, Code Gakko plans to expand into 16 new countries by 2018. The startup has secured funding from an angel investor and aims to differentiate itself from other coding education businesses by providing standardised teaching materials. Revenue for 2017 was approximately $45,000, and the company expects to undergo further funding rounds to support its growth plans.

site_title: The key to reducing fraud in world trade
summary: Blockchain technology has the potential to reduce fraud in world trade by creating a secure, transparent, and decentralized platform for international trade finance. The current reliance on paper documents, such as bills of lading and warehouse receipts, leaves a significant information gap that can be exploited by fraudsters. Blockchain can tag key information, prevent duplicate or forged documents, and provide a single instance of truth, thereby reducing the risk of double financing and phantom trades. However, widespread adoption of blockchain technology will require acceptance across multiple stakeholders, including banks, suppliers, and customs authorities, and a clear regulatory framework.

site_title: Fiscal prudence with an eye on the future: Singapore Budget 2018
summary: The Singapore Budget 2018, titled "Together, a Better Future," achieved a bumper fiscal surplus of S$9.6 billion, the highest in three decades, equivalent to 2.1% of GDP. The government opted to use this surplus to fund major projects, such as the Rail Infrastructure Fund and ElderShield review, rather than distributing it to Singaporeans. The budget also included a 2% increase in Goods and Services Tax (GST) but delayed its implementation until 2021-2025, dependent on economic conditions. The government aims to maintain fiscal prudence while investing in infrastructure and social programs.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Analysts from BS Group Research and HB Research have reaffirmed their buy recommendations for Sembcorp Industries (SCI) and ST Engineering (STE) respectively. SCI is valued at S$4.40 due to its cyclical offshore and marine business, defensive utilities arm, and potential for long-term growth in the utilities sector. STE's 4Q17 earnings exceeded estimates, driven by strong aerospace performance and a lower-than-expected tax rate, with analysts predicting sustained growth driven by P2F conversions and Smart Nation initiatives.

site_title: VW's profitability may take a hit from electric vehicle shift
summary: Volkswagen's 2018 profitability may be impacted by investments in electric vehicles and new models, with a forecasted return on sales of 6.5-7.5% before special items. The company has set aside 25.8 billion euros to cover fines and costs related to the "Dieselgate" emissions scandal, with 20 billion already paid out. Despite record 2017 earnings, analysts were disappointed, and VW shares fell 0.8% after the results. The company expects 2018 revenue to exceed 231 billion euros, driven by sales of higher-margin models and increasing savings from modular platforms.

site_title: Economists take dim view of a range of Trump policies
summary: Economists overwhelmingly disagree with Trump's policies, foreseeing a growing budget deficit and negative impacts from immigration and trade actions. While tax cuts and deregulation are expected to boost growth in the short-term, economists predict long-term negative effects. A National Association for Business Economics survey found 61% believe the government should reduce the deficit, 93% expect the tax cuts to have a positive impact, but only 67% expect the same for 2027. Economists also diverge on infrastructure and climate policies, with 59% prioritizing climate change mitigation and 78% addressing income inequality.

site_title: Few phone makers will survive industry's brutal economics: Huawei consumer chief
summary: Huawei's consumer chief, Richard Yu, predicts the smartphone industry will consolidate as only a handful of firms can remain competitive due to heavy investments required to stay ahead. Companies with less than 10% market share are losing money, while those above 10% can break even. Huawei, the world's third-largest smartphone maker, is growing its business, with a 30% increase in the last year, and may become the second-largest or even the largest smartphone maker. The company will launch new devices, including a 5G-ready smartphone, and showcase innovative camera technology in its upcoming flagship P20 smartphone.

site_title: Acceptable political settlement is only long-term solution to Philippine unrest
summary: A long-term political settlement is necessary to address the underlying issues in the southern Philippines, where Marawi militants have attempted to establish a South-east Asian caliphate. The region's history of marginalization by the Spanish and US colonizers has led to alienation of the Muslim population from the Manila government. Despite efforts by the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF) to sign a peace deal, the region remains fertile ground for Islamic State recruits, and a federal system of government may be the only solution to prevent further bloodshed.

site_title: Banyan Tree to bid for rest of Laguna Resorts & Hotels
summary: Banyan Tree Holdings Limited announced plans to make a voluntary tender offer for the remaining shares it does not own in its subsidiary Laguna Resorts & Hotels Public Company Limited in Thailand. The offer price is 40 Thai baht per share, representing a 34% premium to the last traded price. The total purchase price is approximately 2.28 billion baht, and Banyan Tree has no plans to delist the Thai-listed unit. The acquisition will be made through its subsidiary Banyan Tree Resorts & Spas (Thailand) Company Limited.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Halcyon Agri explores Myanmar market, posts 84% plunge in Q4 earnings
summary: Halcyon Agri Corporation reported a 84% plunge in Q4 earnings to US$11.6 million, mainly due to a one-off US$90.3 million net bargain purchase in 2016. The company has discontinued operations for its processing business in Thailand and is exploring a non-control deal with the Myanmar government to gain market exposure. Halcyon Agri's revenue more than doubled to US$2 billion in FY 2017. The company plans to address its Thailand business and considers listing its global non-tyres segment to increase value.

site_title: Giant oil tankers from US to cut time, money and traders
summary: US oil tankers sailing from the Gulf Coast to Asia are set to reduce costs and waiting time for Asian buyers, with the ability to fill large tankers at discounted rates. The new option at the Louisiana Offshore Oil Port (LOOP) reduces the need for traders to manage tanker logistics, potentially cutting out their margin. According to Braemar ACM, loading oil into a VLCC at LOOP can cut costs by $300,000 per shipment and reduce the timeline from four days to one day. This shift may benefit Asian buyers and reduce traders' role as middlemen.

site_title: First Resources posts 41 per cent decrease in Q4 net profit
summary: First Resources, an oil palm-focused investment holding company, reported a 41.1% decrease in Q4 net profit to US$34.16 million, due to a 19% increase in cost of sales outweighing a 3.2% increase in revenue.

site_title: The Estoril at Holland Rd up for sale with S$220m guide price
summary: The Estoril condominium project, located at 95 & 97 Holland Road in Singapore, is up for collective sale with a guide price of S$220 million. The 84,600 sq ft freehold site has a plot ratio of 1.6 and a maximum allowable gross floor area of 148,896 sq ft. The site could be redeveloped into a 166-unit residential development. The sale price reflects a land price of about S$1,625 per sq ft per plot ratio, with no development charge payable. The public tender will close on April 3 at 3pm.

site_title: Bangladesh's Summit Power aims for Singapore listing by April
summary: Bangladesh's Summit Power International plans to list on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) by April, aiming to raise funds to invest in assets across Asia. As the country's economic growth rises and its population is expected to reach 185 million by 2030, Summit Power seeks to capitalize on South Asia's growing LNG demand. The company, which has a 13% share of Bangladesh's electricity generation market, plans to invest in LNG assets and power projects across Asia, with a multibillion-dollar pipeline of projects over the next five years.

site_title: GE to restate two years of earnings
summary: General Electric will restate its 2016 and 2017 earnings due to a new accounting standard that takes into account revenue from long-term contracts. This change will result in a 13-cent cut in reported earnings per share for 2016 and a 16-cent cut for 2017, according to the company's 10-K filing.

site_title: Big jump in R&D spending by Singapore precision engineering firms
summary: Singapore precision engineering firms have seen a significant increase in R&D spending, with a 50% rise in 2016 to S$313 million. This has led to a 20% year-on-year increase in research scientist and engineering jobs. Companies like Wavelength Opto-Electronic, which invested S$800,000 in R&D, have benefited from government initiatives such as the Technology for Enterprise Capability Upgrading (T-up) scheme and the Operation and Technology Roadmapping (OTR) initiative. The investments have led to improved efficiency and attracted multinational corporations, transforming the companies into systems providers.

site_title: Economists take dim view of a range of Trump policies in survey
summary: Economists in a National Association for Business Economics survey expressed a dim view of various Trump administration policies, foreseeing a growing budget deficit and unfavorable impacts from immigration and trade actions. Despite short-term positive effects from tax cuts and looser regulation, economists expect longer-term negative consequences. The survey shows a majority expect a 0.25-0.75% boost to economic growth this year from tax legislation, but a smaller majority see positive impacts from regulatory actions.

site_title: Aspial's profit surges 111%, expects to be profitable in 2018
summary: Aspial Corporation's full 2017 financial year results showed a 111.1% surge in net profit to S$2.3 million, driven by higher profit from its CityGate project, foreign exchange gains, and increased interest income from its secured lending business. However, revenue declined 21.9% to S$485.1 million. The company expects to be profitable in 2018, citing the positive outlook.

site_title: Huawei launches new laptop and tablet, latest flagship phone to be unveiled later
summary: Huawei unveiled its new laptop, the Matebook X Pro, and tablet, the MediaPad M5, ahead of the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona. The company's focus shifted to its flagship smartphone, the P20, to be launched on March 27 in Paris, potentially outpacing Samsung's new top-end phone launch later. The new devices feature long-lasting batteries and quicker charge times, as well as the world's first commercial 5G chipset capable of 2.3 gigabits per second download speeds. Huawei maintains its third-place position among smartphone manufacturers, with a 10.2% market share in 2017.

site_title: Green light for Singapore's third derivatives exchange
summary: Singapore's third derivatives exchange, Asia Pacific Exchange Pte Ltd (Apex), has received approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to operate a derivatives exchange and clearing house. Apex aims to launch trading in May, starting with a US dollar-denominated physically-delivered palm olein futures contract. The exchange, backed by Chinese conglomerates CEFC China Energy and Xinhu Group, aims to become Asia's price discovery center and a hub for risk management hedging in derivatives. Apex's CEO, Eugene Zhu, believes the shift in global trading will move to Asia, driven by the region's growing economies and population.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: UPS sues EU for 1.7b euros after botched veto of TNT bid
summary: UPS is suing the European Union for 1.7 billion euros after regulators wrongly vetoed its attempted takeover of TNT Express NV in 2013. The EU's General Court initially threw out the veto, but UPS is now seeking compensation for the lost opportunity. The company claims the veto prevented it from materializing benefits from the proposed transaction. This case highlights the EU's tough regulatory hurdles for big takeovers, with companies seeking to challenge the commission's powers and decisions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 1.42 points lower at 1,860.08 on Monday, with 513 losers outweighing 479 gainers. Volume reached 2.7 billion lots worth RM2.7 billion.

site_title: Framework agreement to build Myanmar airport expires: Yongnam
summary: A framework agreement to build Myanmar's Hanthawaddy International Airport has expired, putting the project's future in doubt. The agreement, held by a consortium including Yongnam Holdings, JGC Corporation, and Changi Airports International, had not been renewed due to unresolved issues. Yongnam will provide updates when new developments occur. The project's status remains uncertain, casting a shadow on the airport's construction timeline.

site_title: Germany 'watchful' of Chinese investment in Daimler
summary: Germany's Economy Minister Brigitte Zypries expressed concern over a 9.69% stake in Mercedes-Benz maker Daimler acquired by Chinese auto billionaire Li Shufu, worth around 7.2 billion euros. The investment may lead to scrutiny of Li's plans, particularly regarding Daimler's transition to electric and hybrid cars. Worker representatives also expressed caution, while German politicians view the investment in a broader context of Chinese influence on the European economy.

site_title: Bangkok Airways to invest in new routes, aircraft
summary: Bangkok Airways plans to invest in new routes, aircraft, and airport improvements as tourist arrivals to Thailand rise. The airline aims to expand its network in Asia and increase revenue by 10% this year. Bangkok Airways will receive two Airbus A319 aircraft, upgrade its airport at Samui, and build an aircraft repair center at Sukhothai airport, investing one billion baht. The airline expects a 6% rise in tourist numbers and a 7% increase in passenger numbers this year.

site_title: First Ship Lease Trust narrows Q4 loss to US$33.87m
summary: First Ship Lease Trust reported a Q4 loss of US$33.87 million, down 19.9% from the previous year, due to lower revenue from vessel charters. Income available for distribution was negative S$6.25 million, resulting in no distribution for unit holders. The full-year loss widened to S$73.89 million. The trust is seeking to extend an amortising loan facility by one year to allow for refinancing.

site_title: Pakistan economic woes go from bad to worse before elections
summary: Pakistan's economy is facing significant challenges five months before national polls, with the country's current account and trade deficits hitting records. The government has devalued its currency and raised taxes, but foreign exchange reserves continue to fall. Economists predict a balance of payments crisis and a potential bailout, with the next government likely to seek help from the International Monetary Fund. The nation's imports rose to a record last month, despite tax increases, and the economy is growing at 5.3% - the fastest pace in a decade.

site_title: Best World International posts 77.2% jump in Q4 profit to S$21.8 million
summary: Best World International reported a 77.2% jump in Q4 profit to S$21.8 million, driven by higher turnover and a tax credit. Revenue grew 19.8% to S$74.1 million, with the mainland Chinese market contributing nearly half of the quarter's revenue. The company expects growth momentum to continue in FY2018, with both top and bottom lines expected to improve.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: STI up 0.6% on receding Treasury yields
summary: The Singapore stock market rose 0.6% on Monday, led by gains in US stocks and upbeat data on manufacturing output. The Straits Times Index jumped 22.63 points to 3,555.85, with key Asian markets also edging higher. Investors are watching US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell's testimony to Congress this week, expecting signals on whether he will raise interest rates. Banking stocks led the gains, with DBS and UOB rising 0.1% and 1.4% respectively.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust appoints Cheong Choong Kong as new board chairman; reshuffles committees
summary: FRASERS Centrepoint Trust appointed Cheong Choong Kong as new chairman of the board, effective March 1, 2018, replacing Philip Eng Heng Nee. Dr. Cheong will also sit on the audit, nominating and remuneration committees. Non-executive director Ho Chai Seng was appointed chairman of the nominating and remuneration committee, following the retirement of Soh Kim Soon.

site_title: CSE Global shares surge 7.5% on moves by activist shareholder
summary: CSE Global shares rose 7.25% to S$0.37 after activist investor Quarz Capital Management called for "cash discipline" and higher dividends, urging the company to distribute S$18 million of its net cash position as a special dividend. Quarz also suggested that CSE commit to paying at least 80% of net income as dividend with a payout floor of S$12.5 million. The investor claims the company is "poorly-managed" and its leadership team has inadequate cost and operational discipline, citing a sharp fall in underlying net income and high executive compensation.

site_title: Singapore Myanmar Investco signs deal to develop The Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf brand in Myanmar
summary: Singapore Myanmar Investco (SMI) has secured an exclusive deal to develop The Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf (CBTL) brand in Myanmar, with the first outlet opening in the first quarter of 2018. SMI already operates two CBTL outlets at Yangon International Airport, which have performed well. The company aims to develop the brand into a solid business foundation in Myanmar, leveraging its local market knowledge and operational experience. This partnership is part of SMI's food and beverage portfolio, which includes Ippudo and Crystal Jade.

site_title: Rare snow storm disrupts flights, shuts schools in Rome
summary: A rare snow storm in Rome on February 26, 2018, disrupted flights, shut schools, and prompted Italian authorities to call in the army to clear streets. The storm turned the city's central square, Piazza Venezia, into a winter wonderland, with students skiing down the Oppian Hill near the Colosseum. The unusual weather brought a sense of joy and freedom to the city, with priests and seminarians engaging in snowball fights in St. Peter's Square. The storm's impact was significant, but the city's residents seemed to enjoy the rare and unique experience.

site_title: Boeing to have 51 per cent stake in venture with Embraer: paper
summary: Boeing has agreed to a 51% stake in a joint company with Embraer, a Brazilian aircraft maker, following Brazilian government demands. The partnership aims to create a new company focused on commercial aviation, excluding Embraer's defense unit. This move would give Boeing a controlling share and create stiffer competition for the CSeries aircraft program. The deal comes after Boeing's initial plan to buy Embraer was rejected due to concerns over foreign control of the defense unit.

site_title: Pawnbroker Maxi-Cash posts 17% profit rise for FY2017
summary: Maxi-Cash Financial Services reported a 17% profit rise for FY2017, driven by higher interest income from the pawnbroking business, increased sales from retail and trading of jewellery, and revenue from its secured lending business. Net profit rose to S$13.3 million, a 16.8% increase from the previous year, while revenue grew 15.4% to S$188.4 million. The company declared a final dividend of 0.7 Singapore cents and plans to invest in branding and review its retail network.

site_title: Record starting pay for grads, but fewer full-time jobs
summary: Singapore university graduates earned a record median monthly salary of S$3,400 in 2018, up from S$3,300 in 2016. However, the proportion of graduates in full-time permanent jobs fell to 78.4% from 79.9% in 2016. More graduates (2.4% vs 1.7% in 2016) moved into freelance work, while part-time or temporary jobs remained steady at around 8%. The survey of 11,628 graduates from three top universities showed varying employment rates and median pay.

site_title: Ed Sheeran named world's best-selling artist of 2017
summary: Ed Sheeran was named the world's best-selling artist of 2017 by the IFPI, beating previous winners like Taylor Swift, Adele, and Drake. His album "÷ (Divide)" was the best-selling of the year, and single "Shape of You" was the best-selling single. This marks Sheeran's fifth Global Recording Artist of the Year Award.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector rebounded 17.9% in January, driven by a 17.9% jump in electronics production. Apex received approval to launch Singapore's third derivatives exchange and clearing house. A condominium in Singapore is up for en bloc sale with a guide price of S$220 million. ST Engineering created a new management role to drive growth in new business areas. The Straits Times Index advanced 0.6% to finish at 3,555.85.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.6% higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 22.6 points or 0.6% to close at 3,555.85 on Monday, driven by gains from 263 counters. This marks the 5th consecutive day of gains. The market saw 1.7 billion shares worth S$1.3 billion traded, with gainers outnumbering losers 263-216.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: US new home sales drop for second straight month
summary: US new home sales declined for the second consecutive month in January, falling 7.8% to 593,000 units, the lowest level since August 2017. Sales dropped 33.3% in the Northeast and 14.2% in the South, while rising in the Midwest and West. The housing market is constrained by a severe shortage of affordable homes, pushing up prices and sidelining first-time buyers. Rising mortgage rates, now averaging 4.40%, could further limit buying power, especially if wage growth doesn't accelerate.

site_title: Singapore precision engineering R&D expenditure rises 50% to S$313m in FY2016
summary: Singapore's precision engineering R&D expenditure increased by 50% to S$313m in FY2016, according to the Department of Statistics. This represents a significant investment in research and development, with companies like Wavelength Opto-Electronic, a high-value lens manufacturer, leading the way. The Ministry of Trade and Industry encouraged companies to continue investing in R&D, citing strong contributions to GDP growth. Meanwhile, the number of research scientists and engineers in the precision engineering sector also saw a 20% year-on-year increase.

site_title: Court of Appeal dismisses Sunsea filing, paves way for Keppel's divestment
summary: The Court of Appeal in Hong Kong has dismissed Sunsea Yacht Club's application to block Keppel Corporation's planned divestment of a stake in a China marina project. The decision allows Keppel to proceed with the divestment, with costs awarded to Keppel Land China Ltd and Keppel China Marina Holdings Pte Ltd. The outcome clears the way for Keppel Land China to complete the divestment process.

site_title: Soilbuild swings into the red with loss of S$3.5m in Q4
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group reported a loss of S$3.5 million in the fourth quarter of 2017, primarily due to lower contributions from completed or nearing completion projects in Singapore. Revenue dropped 56.1% to S$39.26 million, compared to the same period last year. The loss was attributed to the group's transition from major project contributions, which are expected to continue in the coming years.

site_title: Electronics once again fires up January manufacturing output
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector started 2018 on a strong note, with output expanding 17.9% in January from a year earlier, beating economists' forecasts. Electronics registered a 32.4% year-on-year surge, driven by strong demand for electronic gadgets and semiconductor, infocomms, and consumer electronics. The sector's growth was broad, with precision engineering and medical technology segments also experiencing significant increases. Economists attribute the robust showing to a synchronised global recovery and expect the sector to continue growing, albeit at a slightly slower pace, with a forecasted 4.4% expansion this year.

site_title: Singapore Technologies Engineering injects S$47m into VC fund
summary: ST Engineering has injected S$47 million into its corporate venture fund, ST Engineering Ventures Fund (STEVF), which now has a total capital of S$54 million. The fund is designed to invest in promising technology start-ups. The move is expected to have no material impact on the company's financials. ST Engineering also appointed Russell Tham as president of new enterprises and ventures, effective March 19, 2018, to drive expansion through technology and innovation in non-core business areas.

site_title: Deutsche Bank kicks off asset management unit's public offering
summary: Deutsche Bank has formally announced its intention to sell shares in its asset management unit, DWS, in an initial public offering (IPO). The IPO will take place in the earliest available window, with the bank planning to sell existing shares held indirectly by Deutsche Bank. The offering aims to deliver shareholder value and support the bank's strategy. A successful IPO would mark an important achievement for CEO John Cryan and give the business more independence. Deutsche Bank expects to sell a 25% stake in DWS for approximately 2 billion euros.

site_title: Gold prices climb as US dollar dips; market eyes US policy outlook
summary: Gold prices rose 0.8% to $1,338.97 per ounce, buoyed by a weaker US dollar and dipping bond yields. US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell will testify on Tuesday, and investors are cautious ahead of his first congressional testimony. Despite inflation concerns, gold remains a "buy on dip" strategy due to its lack of interest-paying properties. Precious metals, including silver, palladium, and platinum, also saw gains.

site_title: Sinarmas Q4 profit surges 412.5%, issues special dividend
summary: Sinarmas Land reported a 412.5% surge in Q4 net profit to S$238.2 million, driven by a S$109.4 million gain from divestment of Orchard Towers. Earnings per share jumped to 5.6 Singapore cents from 1.09 cents in the previous year. The company also declared a special dividend of 0.7 Singapore cents, on top of the interim dividend paid earlier.

OCBC announced Helen Wong's retirement as CEO, with Tan Teck Long named her successor. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay increased by 30.5% to S$3.1 million. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a launch event, and Citigroup set a target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index by mid-2026.

site_title: ST Engineering creates new management role to drive growth in new business areas
summary: ST Engineering appoints Russell Tham as president of new enterprises and ventures, effective March 19, 2018. In this newly created role, Tham will drive growth in new business areas through technology and innovation, particularly in health and medical technology. He joins the group after 23 years with Applied Materials, where he held various management positions. The move aims to expand the group's business beyond its core sectors, signaling a commitment to growth and innovation.

site_title: Ericsson signs China Mobile for industrial internet trials
summary: Ericsson has signed a Memorandum of Understanding with China Mobile to conduct industrial internet trials, focusing on factory automation using the Internet of Things (IoT). The partnership aims to test and deploy IoT solutions for commercial use. Ericsson CEO Börje Ekholm stated that the company has several 5G network deployment contracts with network operators, including China Mobile, starting later in 2018.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rise to 3-week high amid signs of mainland inflows
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.7% to a three-week high on Monday, led by property and utility shares, amid signs of mainland investment. The Hang Seng index closed at 31,498.60 and the China Enterprises Index gained 0.8% to 12,834.06. This uptrend follows increased mainland investment, indicating a positive trend for Hong Kong's markets.

site_title: Despite state-level bans, plastic bags still suffocate India's cities
summary: India's efforts to ban plastic bags have been met with limited success despite state-level bans, with many shops and individuals continuing to use the bags. Half of India's states and union territories have introduced a ban, but enforcement is weak. Experts say that a ban on plastic bags will only be effective if the manufacture of polythene is stopped and cheaper alternatives are made available. The government is considering imposing fines on those who carry polythene bags and may also introduce a system for tracking progress. However, many critics argue that the government needs to take a more comprehensive approach to address the issue.

site_title: Scoot will fly to Nanchang and Pekanbaru
summary: Budget carrier Scoot has added Nanchang and Pekanbaru to its network, with flights to Nanchang scheduled to start July 2 and to Pekanbaru, previously SilkAir's route, also set to begin in the second half of this year.

site_title: With bread loaves and fish, Russia is a food export powerhouse
summary: Russia's food exports surged 25% to $19 billion in 2017, driven by wheat and frozen fish sales, with Egypt becoming the largest buyer of Russian food for the first time since 2012. The country aims to cut its agricultural import dependence after banning Western food imports. Higher wheat prices and attractive export prices contributed to the record-breaking sales, with Egypt purchasing $1.74 billion worth of Russian food and China importing $1.72 billion. Russia's food exports are expected to cap another record this season.

site_title: Giant oil tankers from US seen cutting time, money and traders
summary: US oil tankers are cutting costs and time for Asian refiners by exporting crude directly from the US Gulf Coast to China via the Louisiana Offshore Oil Port, or Loop. This reduces costs by $300,000 per barrel and timeline by four days compared to traditional methods. The new option allows Asian buyers to cut out traders' margins, potentially reducing their costs. However, Loop shipments are expected to average only 1-2 VLCCs per month, leaving room for traders to maintain their business.

site_title: Four dead after blast destroys shop and home in English city of Leicester
summary: A blast destroyed a convenience store and a home in Leicester, England, killing at least four people and injuring four others. The explosion, which occurred at 1900 GMT on Sunday, left a two-storey apartment and shop in rubble. No immediate link to terrorism was indicated, and investigators were working to determine the cause of the blast. Rescue efforts continued to locate any further casualties.

site_title: Booze, surveillance cameras, cars: China's top stocks under Xi
summary: China's top stocks since Xi Jinping became president in 2013 have seen significant growth, driven by companies catering to the growing middle class and the state's security apparatus. Distillers such as Kweichow Moutai Co and Wuliangye Yibin Co have more than tripled, while Inner Mongolia Yili Industrial Group Co and Jiangsu Hengrui Medicine Co have also seen substantial gains. Manufacturers like Hangzhou Hikvision Digital Technology Co and Guangzhou Automobile Group Co have benefited from Xi's focus on public security and infrastructure development, respectively.

site_title: PODCAST: Tips for first-time investors (Money Hacks, Ep 1)
summary: A new podcast series, "Money Hacks", offers tips for first-time investors, covering topics such as balancing savings for investment and diving into cryptocurrency. The podcast aims to provide general information for Singaporean investors and encourages listeners to share their scenarios and questions. Produced by Ernest Luis and Christopher Lim, the series is available on BT Podcasts and can be sent feedback to po.dcast@sph.com.sg. The podcast advises consulting a financial adviser before making investment decisions.

site_title: Few phone makers will survive industry's brutal economics: Huawei
summary: Huawei's CEO, Richard Yu, says the smartphone industry will consolidate as only a handful of firms can remain profitable due to heavy investments required to stay competitive. Companies with less than 10% market share are losing money, and most smaller Chinese vendors will disappear. Huawei, the world's third-largest smartphone maker, expects to grow its smartphone business by 30% and potentially become the second-largest or No.1 maker this year. The company unveiled new products, including 5G versions of a consumer network router and its own chipset, ahead of its flagship P20 smartphone launch next month.

site_title: Melrose gets US, Canada antitrust clearance for GKN deal
summary: Melrose, a turnaround specialist, has received US and Canadian antitrust clearance for its £7.4 billion bid to acquire British engineering firm GKN, despite GKN's rejection of the deal. The US clearance comes after Melrose secured approval from Canadian regulators. However, Melrose still needs to secure approval from the US Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) due to GKN's military supplier role, which could take longer to come by.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher after Wall Street gains
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 1.19% to 22,153.63, following big gains on Wall Street last week. Fears of accelerated US interest rate hikes eased, contributing to the calm market. Despite the yen's appreciation, shares remained in the high-price range.

site_title: Europe: Shares edge higher
summary: European shares rose slightly on Monday, driven by gains in mining and healthcare sectors. The pan-European STOXX benchmark index was up 0.75% at 384 points. Despite a 4.7% drop from Lloyd's of London underwriter Hiscox due to a 90% fall in full-year pretax profit, other companies such as Deutsche Bank rose 0.7% after announcing plans to float its asset management arm. The focus is shifting to monetary policy and politics, with ECB President Mario Draghi's speech and Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's first House testimony this week.

site_title: Bangladesh's Summit Group plans Singapore listing for power unit by April : Chairman
summary: Bangladesh's Summit Power International plans to list on the Singapore Exchange Ltd by April, marking the country's first company to list in the city-state. The electricity producer aims to raise funds to invest in assets across Asia, following Bangladesh's economic growth and increasing energy demand. Summit Power, which operates 15 power plants with a combined capacity of 1,200 megawatts, plans to invest in LNG assets and power projects across Asia, with a focus on meeting the country's growing energy needs.

site_title: Roche's sinking diabetes unit looks towards a monster for a boost
summary: Roche Holding is turning to its diabetes unit's new technology, acquired from Austrian startup mySugr, to boost sales after a decade of declining diabetes sales. The company sells the app's data on blood-sugar readings and workouts directly to US patients, and is marketing it to insurers as a way to tie prices of diabetes products to results. With nearly half a billion people worldwide having diabetes, Roche is betting on a digital turnaround, despite the market for traditional blood-sugar monitoring expected to grow only 1.1% a year.

site_title: Business council, innovation corridor to help Singapore firms enter Andhra Pradesh
summary: Singapore has established a business council and innovation corridor to facilitate entry for its firms into Andhra Pradesh, India's fastest-growing state. The Andhra Pradesh-Singapore Business Council will drive private sector partnerships in sectors such as smart infrastructure, agrifood, and logistics. A new innovation corridor will provide a platform for Singapore firms to pilot and scale up urban solutions in Amaravati, with the aim of expanding across India and abroad. The initiatives aim to promote economic collaboration and provide direct access for Singapore's innovative urban solutions to be implemented in Andhra Pradesh.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: The rise and fall and rise again of ageless Italian icon Berlusconi
summary: Berlusconi, 81, has defied odds with a series of comebacks, remaining a key figure in Italian politics despite scandals and convictions. As Italians vote on March 4, his coalition is set to be the largest bloc in the new legislature. Berlusconi's resilience is attributed to his "amazing capacity to take knocks and resist" in the spotlight, according to author Giovanni Orsina.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won rise, but cautious ahead of global events
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 0.25% on Monday, driven by foreign net sales limiting gains from US stock price increases. The won rose 0.52% against the dollar, while the MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index gained 0.69%. The KOSPI is down 0.6% so far this year, and foreign net sales were 151,922 million won worth of shares.

site_title: Apple moves to store iCloud keys in China, raising human rights fears
summary: Apple has agreed to store iCloud keys for Chinese users in a new Chinese data center, raising human rights concerns. The change allows Chinese authorities to access iCloud data without needing US courts, sparking fears of dissidents being tracked. Apple claims the keys will be specific to Chinese customers, but privacy lawyers say the move represents a downgrade in protections. The company has given Chinese users warnings and options to opt out, but human rights activists worry about the close relationship with a state-controlled entity and potential pressure from the Chinese Communist Party.

site_title: Major quake cuts communications, halts oil and gas operations in Papua New Guinea
summary: A 7.5 magnitude earthquake struck Papua New Guinea's Southern Highlands, causing landslides, damaging buildings, and halting oil and gas operations. The quake, which hit at 3:45am local time, resulted in at least 13 aftershocks and no confirmed casualties. ExxonMobil and Oil Search suspended operations, while the PNG government sent disaster assessment teams. Communications were severely disrupted, making it difficult to assess damage, and the Papua New Guinea Defence Force was mobilized to assist with the response.

site_title: Thai carrier Bangkok Airways to invest in new routes
summary: Bangkok Airways plans to invest in new routes, aircraft, and airport improvements as Thailand expects a 6% rise in tourist numbers this year. The airline will add two new routes, charter flights to China, and upgrade its airport at Samui. It expects to receive two Airbus A319 aircraft and invest 1 billion baht in an aircraft repair center and airport upgrades. Revenue is expected to grow 10% this year with a 7% increase in passenger numbers. The airline aims to expand its network to cover key destinations in Asia to facilitate passengers and codeshare partners.

site_title: Oil steady after hitting 3-week top as Saudi to keep output well below cap
summary: Oil prices stabilized at nearly three-week highs after Saudi Arabia reaffirmed its commitment to curbing shipments to support the Opec-led supply cut effort. US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 4 cents to $63.59 a barrel, while London Brent crude slipped 3 cents to $67.28 a barrel. The stabilization comes as oil prices had risen 3% last week, supported by Saudi Arabia's decision to keep output below the cap.

site_title: Mexico slaps billionaire's steel company with fine for stock manipulation
summary: Mexico's securities regulator has fined Industrias CH, a steel company owned by billionaire Rufino Gonzalez, 2.96 million pesos ($210,000) for making "prohibited trades" under a law banning simulated price or volume trades. The company's investor relations manager and subsidiary Simec were also fined. The fine is the largest of 19 fines given out since 2014 and is related to trades made in 2014 that artificially boosted the company's stock price and kept it on the country's main stock index. The regulator did not explain the basis for the fines, but experts say they set an important precedent in Mexico.

site_title: 'What we make of it': Labour's Corbyn to outline Brexit vision Monday
summary: Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn plans to outline a Brexit vision on Monday, calling for a "bespoke relationship" with the EU, maintaining tariff-free access and a floor under existing rights and protections. Corbyn's proposal aims to bridge Labour's divide on Brexit, with over 80 senior party figures urging him to keep Britain in the single market. The move could threaten Prime Minister Theresa May's government, which has repeatedly said Britain will not remain in an EU customs union.

images.alt_text: Opposition Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn will on Monday call for Britain to keep tariff-free access to the EU after Brexit, arguing that withdrawal from the bloc is "what we make of it", according to excerpts of his speech.

site_title: Singapore shares enter afternoon session higher on Monday; STI at 3,551.68 up 0.5 % on day
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.5% in the afternoon session on Monday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,551.68. About 946 million shares worth S$610 million changed hands, with Rowsley being the most actively traded stock. Other notable movers included Thai Beverage and Genting Singapore. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day rally in the market.

site_title: Broker's take: Genting Singapore's price rally to continue, says DBS
summary: DBS maintains its "buy" rating on Genting Singapore with a lower target price of S$1.49 due to expected positive newsflow, including a recovery in earnings and a bid for a Japanese casino. Despite a 45% surge since August, DBS believes the price rally can continue as Genting selectively extends credit to VIP customers, increasing earnings. However, the bank dropped its target price due to the Singapore government's plan to raise the GST rate to 9% between 2021 and 2025.

site_title: Crypto 'noobs' learn to cope with wild swings in digital coins
summary: A growing number of "crypto noobs" have entered the cryptocurrency market, with many investing with little understanding of how digital currencies work. These new investors, often referred to as "average Joes," have been drawn in by the promise of high returns during the recent rally. However, the market has experienced wild swings, with some investors experiencing significant losses. Experts cite parallels to the 1990s dot-com bubble, where retail investors jumped into stocks with little understanding, only to see their wealth evaporate. Many "noobs" remain optimistic, with some even predicting future gains, while others view their investments as a "fun side investment" or a "gamble."

images.alt_text: Bitcoin is the best-known virtual currency but there are now more than 1,500 to choose from, according to market data website CoinMarketCap, ranging from popular coins like ether and ripple to obscure coins like dentacoin, the one intended for dentists.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing output rebounds with 17.9% jump in January, thanks to electronics
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector rebounded in January with a 17.9% year-on-year increase, exceeding expectations, driven by a strong bounce back in electronics production. Electronics output expanded 32.4% and semiconductor segment grew 41.8%. Biomedical production also rebounded, with medical technology segment posting 22.8% growth. Other segments, such as chemicals, food, and beverages, also saw growth, while transport engineering sector saw the weakest year-on-year growth. The rebound follows the sector's biggest decline in two years in December.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

Singapore's manufacturing sector staged a strong comeback in January after output suffered its biggest decline in two years the previous month, with output rebounding by 17.9 per cent year-on-year, thanks to a bounce back in electronics production.

site_title: Swing time: Thais go dancing in the streets
summary: Hundreds of Thais gathered in the town of Nakhon Pathom for a swing dance street party, organized by the "Bangkok Swing" group. The event, which has become an annual tradition, saw over 300 enthusiasts, including foreigners, dancing to swing music. The party was held on a street near the ancient Phra Pathom Chedi Buddhist stupa. Participants dressed in vintage outfits and enjoyed the lively atmosphere, with many praising the event as a fun way to meet people and enjoy beautiful music. The event is expected to continue annually.

site_title: Apex to launch Singapore's 3rd derivatives exchange
summary: Apex Exchange, a subsidiary of Asia Pacific Exchange Pte, has received approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore to launch Singapore's third derivatives exchange. The exchange plans to start trading in the second quarter of 2018 with US dollar-denominated palm olein futures, followed by commodity and financial derivatives products. Apex aims to establish itself as an Asian centre for price benchmarks, with a vision to reference global market participants. The exchange will be Singapore's third, after the Singapore Exchange and Intercontinental Exchange.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: The Estoril at Holland Village up for en bloc sale with S$220m guide price
summary: The Estoril condominium in Singapore is up for collective sale with a guide price of S$220 million, reflecting a land price of about S$1,625 per sq ft per plot ratio. The site, zoned "residential" with a height control of up to 12 storeys, could be redeveloped into a residential development of 166 units. The public tender for The Estoril will close on April 3, 2018, with CBRE, the exclusive marketing agent, expecting a sale price of less than S$250 million, driven by the en bloc cycle shifting to prime districts.

images.alt_text: The site could potentially be redeveloped from its current 44 units into a residential development of 166 units.

site_title: Huawei launches new tablet in flagship phone hiatus
summary: Huawei launches new laptop and tablet, the Matebook X Pro and MediaPad M5, as it seeks to solidify its position among top electronic device manufacturers. The company will instead unveil its new flagship smartphone, the P20, in Paris on March 27, bypassing the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona where it typically makes major announcements. The new devices feature long-lasting batteries, quicker charge times, and the world's first commercial 5G chipset, which can reach speeds of 2.3 gigabits per second.

images.alt_text: The laptop, the Matebook X Pro, and the tablet, the MediaPad M5, were presented on the eve of the opening of the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona - the scene of previous major Huawei launches.

site_title: Icy blast from Siberia sweeps across Europe
summary: A wintry blast from Siberia, dubbed the "Beast from the East," has swept across Europe, claiming four lives and endangering homeless individuals. Freezing temperatures are forecast to continue, with some areas feeling as cold as minus 30C. The cold snap has caused travel disruptions, postponed sports events, and forced schools to close in several countries, including Italy, France, and Romania. Russia and Poland have also been affected, with temperatures expected to drop to minus 24C and minus 35C, respectively.

site_title: China's January home prices rise even as top cities register decline
summary: China's new home prices rose 5% in January, despite major cities experiencing early signs of decline, according to data from the National Bureau of Statistics. The growth was driven by provincial governments' efforts to support first-time buyers, while mortgage fraud remains a concern. Eleven major cities saw year-on-year price declines, and property sales slowed by over 10% in 15 cities. The data suggests the housing market is gradually slowing, but still resilient, ahead of the annual parliament meeting in March where economic targets for 2018 will be set.

site_title: China's yuan rises to 2-week high on stronger fix, corp US dollar sales
summary: China's yuan rose to a 2-week high against the US dollar, reaching 6.3160 per dollar, after the People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.3378 per dollar. The onshore yuan opened at 6.3367 and rose to 6.3180 by midday, with traders attributing the move to firmer official yuan rates, a pullback in US bond yields, and renewed corporate sales of the US dollar. The yuan is expected to remain range-bound between 6.31 to 6.35 per dollar.

images.alt_text: China's yuan rose against the dollar to the highest level in two weeks on Monday, underpinned by a firmer official yuan midpoint, pullback in US bond yields and renewed corporate sales of the greenback.

site_title: Sony pins hopes on 4K video to revive smartphone sales
summary: Sony unveiled its new Xperia XZ2 smartphone at Mobile World Congress, focusing on 4K high-definition video recording to differentiate itself from rivals. The device features Corning Gorilla Glass 5, a longer 18:9 ratio display, and can record video in 4K HDR, as well as upscale SDR video to near HDR quality. Despite technical innovations, Sony's sales have declined, with 4 million units sold in the quarter to end-December, down from 5.1 million a year ago. Analysts praise the device's competitive design but acknowledge the challenge of standing out in the market against top vendors like Apple and Samsung.

site_title: Craft vodka with tiny village roots to propel Altia's US dreams
summary: Finnish distiller Altia Oyj is betting on Koskenkorva, a handcrafted vodka with roots in a tiny village, to gain a share of the US vodka market. The company, seeking to expand, plans to finance its efforts via an initial public offering. CEO Pekka Tennila believes the craft vodka's local roots and story will attract US consumers shifting away from global giants like Smirnoff and Absolut.

site_title: Trade in your luxury watch like a BMW: It's a booming business
summary: Luxury watch seller Danny Govberg's Philadelphia-based company, Govberg Jewelers, is experiencing a boom in the secondhand market, with wealthy customers trading in their used Patek Philippe and Rolex watches for new or vintage styles. This shift is driven by Swiss watchmakers embracing the resale movement to attract shoppers back to stores. Industry analyst Reginald Brack notes that the preowned market is no longer seen as competition, but rather as a way to increase sales. The trend is a significant change in the industry's market landscape over the past two decades.

site_title: Hilfiger's fast-paced fashion, cars push Milan shows to the finish line
summary: US designer Tommy Hilfiger closed Milan Fashion Week with his "TommyNow Drive" collection, featuring fast cars and fast fashion. The show marked the brand's adoption of the "see now, buy now" strategy, with all collection items available online immediately after the runway show. A temporary shop was set up at the venue, offering customers the chance to purchase items straight away. This move aimed to democratize fashion and pioneer the see-now-buy-now movement.

site_title: Bitcoin bitterness starts to make messy divorces even worse
summary: UK lawyers are facing a new challenge in handling divorces involving cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin, which are volatile and difficult to value. The increasing popularity of Bitcoin has led to more separations involving the currency, complicating the division of assets. The lack of transparency and regulatory clarity surrounding virtual currencies is exacerbating the issue, making the already painful process of divorce even more messy.

site_title: Changi Airport's passenger traffic in January up 0.9%
summary: Changi Airport's passenger traffic in January saw a 0.9% increase to 5.3 million, with aircraft movements rising 2.8% to 32,490 landings and take-offs. Air cargo volumes grew 11% to 175,590 tonnes, with Japan experiencing the highest growth at 11%. Major city routes like Bangkok, Chennai, and London also saw strong traffic growth of at least 8%.

site_title: China faces rule by Xi for decades with repeal of term limits
summary: China's Communist Party has repealed presidential term limits, allowing Xi Jinping to rule beyond 2023. The move removes the only formal barrier to Xi's indefinite stay in power, following a similar path taken by Russian President Vladimir Putin. The decision signals Xi's consolidation of control over China, drawing comparisons to Putin's efforts to consolidate power in Russia. The change comes as Xi prepares to put his mark on the government, with a three-day conclave in Beijing where he will install favored candidates and reshape the government's structure.

site_title: Japanese firms in consortium to bring LNG to Australia's east coast
summary: A consortium led by Japanese firms JERA and Marubeni Corp plans to import liquefied natural gas (LNG) to Australia's east coast, aiming to supply industrial gas users and a potential new power plant. The project, expected to start in 2020, would meet up to three-quarters of New South Wales' gas needs. This is the second proposed LNG import terminal for Australia, which is seeking to fill a supply gap amid long-term LNG contracts to Japan, China, and South Korea.

site_title: Something borrowed: grooms and guests for hire in Vietnam
summary: A 27-year-old Vietnamese woman, Kha, staged a fake marriage with a man hired for $1,500 to avoid social stigma of becoming a single mother. The US$1,500 was paid by her baby's father, who is married to another woman. Kha's parents would have been shamed if she was pregnant without a husband, breaking traditional Vietnamese social norms. This highlights the societal pressure and consequences of non-traditional relationships in Vietnam, where single mothers are often stigmatized.

site_title: Dolce & Gabbana opens the gates of fashion heaven in Milan show
summary: Dolce & Gabbana's Milan fashion show was a spectacular event featuring drones, one of the last events of Milan's fashion week. The show, titled "Fashion Devotion," featured golden gates, angels, and clouds as a backdrop. The event started with the chiming of bells, the opening of golden gates, and drones carrying the brand's handbags down the catwalk. The show marked the designers' return to Milan fashion week after a brief hiatus. The event was a celebration of fashion and a return to the glamour of the fashion world.

site_title: Nokia phones look to the future, and to the past
summary: Nokia, the iconic phone brand, is making a comeback with new Android smartphones and a remake of its 1990s "slider" phone, the 8110. HMD Global, a company led by ex-Nokia executives, has sold around 30 million phones since entering the market last year, with a focus on mid-priced Androids and affordable options. The new Nokia 8 and 8110 models will be available in April and May, respectively, and are designed to compete with premium brands like Samsung and Huawei.

site_title: Cyber threats top concerns for UK investors, business leaders
summary: UK investors and business leaders cite cyber threats as the top concern, surpassing populism, trade protectionism, and over-regulation. A PricewaterhouseCoopers survey found investors prioritize cyber security, while CEOs focus on excessive regulation and skills shortages. Globally, cyber crime could cost businesses up to $8 trillion in damage over five years. Experts emphasize the need for investing in cyber security, digital skills, and training to regain investor confidence.

images.alt_text: Investors and chief executives say cyber attacks pose the greatest threat to businesses operating in the UK, outweighing other material risks including populism, trade protectionism and over-regulation, according to PricewaterhouseCoopers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Monday at 1,864.21, with gains outnumbering losses 337 to 220. Volume reached 780.22 million lots worth RM341.6 million.

site_title: Banyan Tree to make S$95.5m offer for rest of Laguna Resorts & Hotels Public Company
summary: Banyan Tree Holdings Limited is set to make an offer of approximately S$95.5 million to acquire the remaining shares of its Thai-listed subsidiary, Laguna Resorts & Hotels Public Company Limited. The voluntary tender offer is priced at 40 baht (29.75 SGD) per share, representing about 34.25% of the company. The acquisition will be made by Banyan Tree and its subsidiary, with no plans to delist LRH shares from the Stock Exchange of Thailand.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars tread water; eyes on Fed chief Powell's testimony
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars held steady on Monday as investors awaited Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's testimony for hints on US policy tightening. The Aussie dollar rose 0.3% to US$0.7867, while the New Zealand dollar remained near a two-week low at US$0.7318. The currencies have experienced wild fluctuations this month due to a bond rout and declining risk appetite, with the Aussie down 2.6% so far in February. Market expectations suggest three to four US rate hikes this year.

site_title: Raffles Medical says increase in FY17 dividend payout signals group's confidence
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 0.8% increase in net profit to S$70.8 million for FY17, driven by marginal growth in hospital services and investment holdings. Revenue rose 0.8% to S$477.6 million. The increase in dividend payout signals the group's confidence in its future performance.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: UK services businesses enjoy first profit rise in in 2 years: CBI
summary: UK services businesses reported the first profit rise in over two years, according to the Confederation of British Industry (CBI). The services sector's volumes grew at the fastest pace since August 2015, and profits increased. Despite high inflation, business volumes have grown, and hiring is on the up. However, investment plans have been muted due to uncertainty over the UK's future relationship with the EU.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend rally at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose at the open on Monday, extending last week's rally as concerns about rising US interest rates eased globally. The Hang Seng Index climbed 0.84%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 0.56% and 0.51%, respectively.

site_title: HRnet Q4 profit rises 23.2% to S$12.2m
summary: HRnetGroup's fourth-quarter net profit rose 23.2% to S$12.2 million, driven by strong growth in its flexible staffing business in Singapore. Revenue increased 9.5% to S$101.7 million, and the company proposed a final dividend of 2.3 cents per share. The net asset value per share rose to 30.9 Singapore cents, while shares traded 0.6% higher at S$0.79.

site_title: Debopama Sen to head Citi's treasury, trade solutions business for Singapore and Asean
summary: Citi has appointed Debopama Sen as the Singapore and Asean head for its treasury and trade solutions business, overseeing cash management and trade finance services for multinational corporations and financial institutions. Sen, who previously held the role of Citi's India cluster head for TTS, will report to Rajesh Mehta, Asia-Pacific head for TTS. The appointment aims to leverage pan-Asean and Asia-to-Asia trade flows, supporting global and multinational clients in the region.

images.alt_text: Citi on Monday announced the appointment of Debopama Sen as its Singapore and Asean head for its treasury and trade solutions business.

site_title: Tokyo stocks open higher after Wall Street gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by gains on Wall Street last week, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.98% to 22,106.32. Fears of accelerated US interest rate increases abating also contributed to the market's optimism. The broader Topix index rose 0.71% to 1,773.09.

site_title: Australia, NZ shares supported by Wall Street; QBE tumbles after annual loss
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% on Monday, supported by Wall Street's gains, as the Federal Reserve reaffirmed its plan for steady economic growth and rate hikes. The S&P/ASX 200 index hit its highest in three weeks, driven by gains from the 'Big 4' banks, energy stocks, and consumer companies. However, QBE Insurance tumbled 4.9% after reporting an annual loss and selling its Latin American business. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 0.3%.

site_title: Halcyon Agri's Q4 profit plummets 84% to US$11.6m
summary: Halcyon Agri Corporation reported a 84.4% decline in Q4 net profit to US$11.6 million, primarily due to the absence of a one-off US$90 million net bargain purchase in 2016. Revenue grew 16.9% to US$469.4 million, driven by higher rubber revenue per tonne and sales volumes. Earnings per share fell to 0.68 US cents, while net asset value per share increased to 52.53 US cents. The board proposed a total dividend distribution of two Singapore cents per share.

site_title: Powerful quake hits central Papua New Guinea, disrupts oil and gas operations
summary: A 7.5-magnitude earthquake struck Papua New Guinea's Southern Highlands province, disrupting communications and oil and gas operations. The quake hit near the center of the main island, approximately 560 km from Port Moresby, at 3:45am local time. There were no immediate reports of damage or casualties.

site_title: Cordlife partners US-Based PlumCare to offer genetic screening service
summary: Cordlife Group, a Singapore-listed healthcare company, has partnered with US-based PlumCare to offer a genetic screening service, PlumCare DNA Advisor, to identify gene variants associated with inherited conditions. The service is expected to capitalize on the growing global DNA testing market, which is projected to reach US$10.04 billion by 2022. The partnership aims to provide a non-invasive prenatal testing, urine-based metabolic screening, and paediatric vision screening services to families in Asia.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.4% higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index rising 12.7 points to 3,545.92. About 97 million shares worth S$92 million changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 123 to 33. Active stocks included DBS, OCBC Bank, and Thai Beverage, with Rowsley being the most traded stock, rising S$0.014 to S$0.131.

site_title: Daimler in 11.9b yuan China investment with BAIC as Geely swoops
summary: Daimler and its Chinese partner BAIC plan to invest $2 billion in a state-of-the-art factory in China, modernizing it to build premium Mercedes-Benz cars, including electric vehicles. Meanwhile, Geely, a rival carmaker, has acquired a 10% stake in Daimler, valued at $9 billion, to access Mercedes-Benz technology. Geely's Chairman Li Shufu plans to meet Daimler executives and German government officials, but Berlin has deemed the investment as a minority stake, requiring no action.
