site_title: Australia shares rise on resources, CBA; NZ also up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.8% on Friday, driven by gains in resources shares and Commonwealth Bank of Australia, which rose 1.1% after denying anti-money laundering claims. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 5,999.800, advancing 1.6% for the week but still down for February due to global market volatility.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks recover on foreign buying, won strengthens
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 1.13% to 2,442.15 at 01.31 GMT, driven by strong purchases from domestic institutions and foreign investors. The won strengthened to 1,077.6 per dollar, while bond yields fell. Market heavyweight Samsung Electronics rose nearly 2%. Despite a 2.2% decline so far this year, the Kospi index remains above its 30-day low. Foreign investors were net buyers of 68,251 million won worth of shares, while US dollar has risen 1.03% against the won this year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 1.29 points to 1,853.78. Trading volume reached 80.51 million lots worth RM42.99 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 129 to 87. The index's performance was not influenced by recent global market trends, as investors focused on domestic market activity.

site_title: Malaysian police freeze leave for March to May in further indication of polling date
summary: Malaysian police have frozen leave for police personnel from March to May, indicating the country's general election is near. Commissioner Abdul Ghafar Rajab stated the freeze is part of preparations for the upcoming polls. The police force has also conducted multiple drills and has 130,000 personnel ready to be deployed. The Election Commission has placed an order for indelible ink, which will be shipped soon, while schools nationwide are preparing to serve as polling centers.

site_title: US gun debate stirs conservative conference after Florida tragedy
summary: The Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) in National Harbor, Maryland, drew thousands of Republicans to discuss conservative issues, including the ongoing debate on gun control following the Florida school shooting that killed 17 people. Gun rights advocates, including the National Rifle Association (NRA), pushed back against calls for stricter gun laws, while some attendees expressed support for President Donald Trump's efforts to address gun safety. The conference featured hardline conservative speakers and panelists who emphasized the importance of the Second Amendment and criticized gun control advocates.

site_title: Swiss Re highlights rising prices as disasters wipe out profit
summary: Swiss Re reported a net income of US$331 million, beating analysts' average estimate of US$287 million, despite a costly hurricane season that wiped out its full-year profit. The company expects to benefit from rising prices and will raise its dividend to 5 Swiss francs, while authorizing a new share buyback program.

site_title: Three Times A Lady
summary: Dolce & Gabbana has launched its "Customise Your Eyes" eyewear line, featuring oversized round sunglasses with interchangeable clip-ons. The collection, available in end-February, pays tribute to the brand's Sicilian roots with various designs, including leo print, stripes, and roses. This innovative project allows customers to wear three different models on one pair, showcasing the brand's creativity and commitment to its heritage.

site_title: Australia's scandal-hit deputy prime minister to quit
summary: Australia's Deputy Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce is quitting amid scandal over an affair with a former aide, who is now pregnant. Joyce denied a sexual harassment complaint against him, but stepped down as National Party leader and Deputy Prime Minister after colleagues grew frustrated with his handling of the scandal. The move comes as the country's coalition government faces a crisis and the global #MeToo movement against sexual harassment gains momentum. Joyce will step down on Monday, and the new National Party leader will automatically become Deputy Prime Minister.

site_title: Indonesia to challenge latest US biodiesel duty ruling at WTO
summary: Indonesia plans to challenge the US ruling on anti-dumping and countervailing duties on Indonesian biodiesel at the World Trade Organization (WTO). The US Commerce Department imposed duties of up to 159% on Argentine biodiesel and up to 341% on Indonesian biodiesel, effectively blocking sales in the US market. The move is seen as a significant setback for Indonesia's biodiesel exports, which are a major revenue source for the country.

site_title: Gold swings higher as US dollar surrenders gains
summary: Gold prices rose 0.6% to $1,331.56 per ounce as the US dollar surrendered early gains, snapping a four-session losing streak. Despite being down 1.2% for the week, analysts expect trading to remain rangebound due to inflation concerns and interest rate hikes. The Fed's latest minutes showed policymakers committed to hiking rates to control inflation, which could spur safe-haven buying of gold. However, rising interest rates may also pressure the metal.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.6% on Friday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,511.07, driven by gains in JEP Holdings and OCBC Bank. The rally comes despite mixed US stock performance and ongoing tariff uncertainty. Gainers outnumbered losers 119 to 33, with 54.2 million shares changing hands. This marks the 5th consecutive day of gains ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Taking the Asean trade horse to the water
summary: Singapore, as Asean's chair, aims to leverage the region's growing economic potential, with the combined population of 600 million expected to live in cities by 2030, and the region producing over half of the world's economic output. The Asean digital economy has the potential to grow to $200 billion by 2025, with e-commerce accounting for $88 billion. To capitalize on this, Asean member states need to deepen economic integration, focusing on e-commerce, digital infrastructure, and data security. The region's trade architecture is also being enhanced, with initiatives such as the Asean Single Window and framework agreements for investments and services.

images.alt_text: Ravi Velloor

site_title: Australia: Shares rise, helped by financials; NZ higher too
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% on Friday, driven by strong earnings results and a partial admission by Commonwealth Bank of Australia to claims against it. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached its highest point since February 6, with materials and financials contributing to the gain. Other top gainers included NEXTDC Ltd, BHP, and Rio Tinto Ltd, while consumer staples fell due to Woolworths Group Ltd's increased profit. In New Zealand, the S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.4% due to healthcare and industrial stocks.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.23% and the Topix index up 0.19%. The rebound was attributed to a positive performance on Wall Street. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data and a surge in the US market despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging past previous highs.

site_title: Hot stock: Creative stock nearly doubles, company responds to SGX query
summary: Creative Technology's stock nearly doubled to S$2.48 a share, its highest price since April 2014, after a 98% surge. The company responded to a Singapore Exchange query, stating it's unaware of any material information explaining the price movement. Creative mentioned its upcoming '3D' sound technology for headphones, developed with a US$100 million R&D investment, but attributed the price surge to a reported story in The Business Times. The company reported a net loss of US$4.2 million for the second quarter.

site_title: China to hold key conclave with PBOC, policy jobs in play: sources
summary: President Xi Jinping is set to convene a Communist Party meeting to select China's next government, including monetary and financial regulators, ahead of annual legislative meetings. The meeting will approve personnel appointments and government restructuring decisions, potentially transforming the leadership of the central bank and other financial oversight bodies. With current PBOC governor Zhou Xiaochuan expected to retire, Xi has an opportunity to install his favored candidates, which could impact China's efforts to defuse its growing debt and stabilize the economy. The appointments will also shape the country's economic policy and global influence.

site_title: Large vessels are fishing 55% of world's oceans
summary: Large commercial vessels from China, Spain, Taiwan, Japan, and South Korea account for over 85% of observed fishing efforts on the high seas, with half of the vessels from China. Satellite data tracked industrial fishing, revealing that 55% of the world's oceans are being fished, possibly up to 73%. The global fishing industry is a $160 billion market, with over a third of world stocks being overfished, and experts estimate that humans have been fishing for 42,000 years without a clear picture of fishing practices.

site_title: Anbang to be taken over by China regulators for one year
summary: China regulators will take control of Anbang Insurance Group for one year following a probe that began in June. Wu Xiaohui, chairman, will be removed and face prosecution. The takeover aims to address concerns over the insurer's solvency, despite its stable operations. Anbang, with assets of over $416 billion, has been under regulatory scrutiny since Wu's detention in June. The move is part of China's efforts to control financial risks, with President Xi Jinping's administration prioritizing this goal.

site_title: Cinema With A View
summary: The Peroni Sunset Cinema, an inaugural event held last year at Tanjong Beach in Sentosa, is set to return from May 2-13. The event features a lineup of new film releases, live DJs, food, and drinks, with attendees provided with wireless headphones to minimize distractions. The 2018 lineup includes films such as "All the Money in the World," "Battle of the Sexes," and "Darkest Hour." Tickets are available for booking on www.sunsetcinema.com.sg.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: US expands laundering, fraud charges against ex-Trump campaign chief
summary: US charges former Trump campaign chief Paul Manafort and his partner Richard Gates with tax and bank fraud, adding to existing money laundering and tax evasion charges. The 32-count indictment alleges they laundered $75 million through offshore accounts to avoid income tax. The charges, unrelated to the 2016 election campaign, stem from their work for Russia-backed former Ukraine president Viktor Yanukovych. Manafort's team claims he will be acquitted, but Mueller's team says he and Gates hid income from US authorities while enjoying the money. The indictment marks another move by Mueller to pressure Trump's former aides.

site_title: New Silkroutes to acquire 2 Chinese firms for S$65m in new medical consumables push
summary: New Silkroutes Group has announced the acquisition of two Shanghai-based companies, Shanghai Fengwei Nonwovens and Shanghai Fengwei Garment Accessory, for S$65 million. The acquisition aims to expand the company's healthcare division and supply medical consumables in China and South-east Asia. The deal will fund the issuance of new shares at 50 Singapore cents apiece, with the company's CEO stating that the acquisition will help lower the cost of consumables for healthcare providers and enhance operating efficiency.

site_title: OCBC to issue 500m euros of 5-year covered bonds at 0.375% coupon
summary: OCBC Bank is issuing 500 million euros of 5-year covered bonds at a 0.375% coupon, maturing in 2023. The bonds, issued under the bank's US$10 billion global covered bond programme, will be secured by a portfolio of assets. Moody's Investors Services and Fitch Ratings are expected to rate the paper "Aaa" and "AAA" respectively. Net proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes.

site_title: Off To The Oscars!
summary: The 2018 Best Picture nominees offer a diverse range of films, from "Darkest Hour" and "Dunkirk" to "The Shape of Water" and "Get Out." The coming-of-age genre has matured, with films like "Lady Bird" and "Call Me By Your Name" showcasing the complexities of teenage characters. The Oscars also recognize the contributions of great actors, including Daniel Day-Lewis, who announces his retirement with a stunning performance in "Phantom Thread." The awards season brings relief from the dominance of superhero films, highlighting the importance of solid, original storytelling in cinema.

site_title: DMX files police report in Singapore, alleges wrongdoing by former management
summary: DMX Technologies Group, an IT solutions provider, filed a police report in Singapore alleging wrongdoing by former management and entities involved in suspicious transactions. The allegations arose from further analysis of documents released in Hong Kong for further investigations. DMX made the announcement through the Singapore Exchange (SGX) statement.

site_title: Commonwealth Bank of Australia denies most new claims in money-laundering case
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia denied most of 100 new claims in a money-laundering case, admitting to 11 claims of systemic non-compliance. The bank blamed a single systems-related error for late filing of transaction reports, affecting over 53,800 claims. It admitted to 56 breaches of customer due diligence requirements but denied 53 allegations. The maximum penalty for a single contravention is up to A$21 million, potentially exposing the bank to billions of dollars in fines if treated separately.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip as earnings flurry fails to lift sentiment
summary: European shares fell 0.2% on Thursday as a flurry of corporate results failed to lift sentiment, with speculation about US interest rate hikes contributing to the decline. Despite positive earnings from British banks and a few biotechnology companies, the Stoxx 600 index remained down 5.7% from its two-and-a-half year peak. A rebound on Wall Street helped shares come off lows, and analysts attributed the weakness to the release of the Federal Reserve's minutes from its latest meeting.

site_title: Steve Jobs' pre-Apple job application could fetch US$50,000 at auction
summary: A job application from 1973, filled out by Steve Jobs, is set to be auctioned off next month, with an estimated value of around US$50,000. The one-page application lists Jobs' aspirations to work in technology and design, referencing his time at Reed College and his interest in Hewlett-Packard. The document, which includes spelling and punctuation errors, does not specify the position Jobs was applying for. The auction will take place between March 8 and 15, alongside other items including a signed Mac OS X technical manual and a love letter from Amy Winehouse.

site_title: No plans to move Singapore marketing hub: BHP CEO
summary: BHP CEO Andrew Mackenzie stated that the company's Singapore marketing hub will not be relocated, even if Australia cuts corporate taxes. The Singapore office is at the center of a tax dispute with Australia's tax office, which claims the company shifts profits to minimize tax on Australian products.

site_title: EU leaders to clash over post-Brexit budget
summary: EU leaders will discuss the size and aims of the bloc's next long-term budget, which faces a 10-12 billion euro gap due to Brexit. Germany, Italy, and France are likely to support increasing the budget, while the Netherlands, Sweden, and Denmark are opposed. The European Commission proposes covering the gap with spending cuts and new revenue sources, but agreement is unlikely. The summit also addresses the European Parliament's role in choosing the next European Commission head and reducing parliamentary seats.

site_title: HK exec is new Datapulse CEO
summary: Datapulse Technology has appointed Wilson Teng Wai Leung as its new CEO, effective March 8. Teng, 53, joins from iAdvantage, where he was vice-president of sales and business development since 2016. He succeeds Kee Swee Ann, who left the company on February 2 due to the "recent events surrounding the company." The board is currently facing a dispute with the company's co-founder Ng Khim Guan's family over a potential acquisition and allegations of business diversification. Teng will undergo training to familiarize himself with the responsibilities of a director of a public-listed company.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Oil prices climb after unexpected drawdown in US crude stocks
summary: Oil prices rose to two-week highs on Thursday, boosted by a surprise drawdown in US crude inventories and a drop in the dollar. US crude futures rose 1.8% to $62.77 a barrel, while Brent crude futures rose 1.5% to $66.39 a barrel. Inventories unexpectedly fell 1.6 million barrels last week, with exports surging to a record 2 million barrels per day. A weaker dollar and market structure called backwardation also contributed to the price increase.

site_title: Little place, big menu
summary: Origin Grill & Bar, a new restaurant under Shangri-La hotel's Tower Wing, offers a unique concept with a big menu that includes a comprehensive beef selection. The restaurant's design, inspired by luxury train travel, features a mechanical contraption at the entrance and a gentlemen's club look. The menu is a mix of starters, mains, and desserts, with dishes such as charred octopus and a grass-fed Australian lamb rack. The beef menu boasts a variety of high-quality cuts, including wagyu and dry-aged options. Despite some inconsistencies, Origin has an encouraging start, promising to be a promising dining spot.

site_title: Airbnb expands offerings with new upscale categories
summary: Airbnb has introduced new upscale categories, including premium lodging and properties for "trips of a lifetime," as part of its expansion plans. The "Plus" category features 2,000 homes in 13 cities, while the "Beyond" category, acquired from Luxury Retreats, will offer customized trips in the coming months. The company aims to serve one billion guests annually by 2028. The new categories join existing options such as bed-and-breakfast, boutique, and unique spaces, with a focus on comfort, cleanliness, and design. This move is part of Airbnb's growth strategy and response to changing traveler demands.

site_title: BOE rate rises could come faster than expected
summary: The Bank of England's chief economist, Andy Haldane, struck a hawkish tone, suggesting interest rates may rise faster than expected due to a stronger-than-anticipated economic growth. Haldane warned that growth could overshoot forecasts, requiring more rate hikes than initially anticipated. The BOE's Monetary Policy Committee had previously projected three rate hikes over three years, but Haldane believes the risks lie to the upside, potentially leading to higher rates sooner.

site_title: British PM May plans Brexit speech next week
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May plans to deliver a speech next week outlining Britain's partnership with the EU after Brexit. The speech comes after a cabinet meeting at Chequers, where senior ministers discussed economic ties with the EU. The meeting involved key figures such as Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson and Finance Minister Philip Hammond, with discussions on the automotive sector, agri-foods, and digital trade. The EU is set to issue guidelines for talks on future ties at a summit on March 22-23, with negotiations expected to begin in April.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp Industries, ST Engineering, OUE, Trek 2000, Sheng Siong
summary: Sembcorp Industries plans to list its India energy business and reposition its utilities arm, posting an 85% drop in net profit to S$22.8 million for Q4 2017. ST Engineering reported a 6% increase in profits for FY2017, while OUE Limited's net profit fell 31.5% to S$98.9 million. Trek 2000 reported a 1.6% increase in net profit, and Sheng Siong Group's net profit rose 9.3% for Q4. The companies are proposing final dividends, with ST Engineering and OUE unchanged, and Sheng Siong increasing it to 3.30 cents per share.

site_title: ST Engineering's full-year profit up 6%; proposes final dividend of 10 S cents per share
summary: ST Engineering reported a 6% increase in full-year profit to S$511.9 million, driven by growth across sectors except marine. Revenue remained flat at S$6.62 billion. The company proposed a final dividend of 10 cents per share and has a strong order book of S$13.2 billion for 2018, with growth expected from A330 and A320 conversion programs and smart city offerings.

site_title: Economic insecurity a hallmark of globalisation
summary: Global economic insecurity, fueled by cheaper imports, automation, and digitization, is a major concern for workers, surpassing income inequality. Despite a relatively strong social safety net in Europe, right-wing anti-immigrant populism is on the rise. Workers fear job loss, cultural insecurity, and the perceived threat to their community life. To address this, a universal basic income supplement could provide economic security, allowing workers to retrain or start new jobs. Constructive policies, such as global skill partnerships and community programs, can also diffuse anti-immigrant tension and cultural insecurity, ultimately confronting right-wing populism.

site_title: SembMarine taps WSG programme to reskill workforce
summary: SembMarine, a Singaporean marine and offshore engineering company, has tapped the Workforce Singapore (WSG) programme to reskill its workforce and enhance its adaptability to changing industry demands. This move comes as the sector faces sectoral downturns and declining opportunities in traditional markets such as rig-building, with a focus on emerging markets like liquefied natural gas (LNG). By upskilling its workforce, SembMarine aims to remain competitive and weather industry cycles.

site_title: Healthway Medical narrows Q4 net loss to S$28.8m
summary: Healthway Medical Corporation reported a Q4 net loss of S$28.8 million, narrowing by 35.6% from S$44.8 million in the previous year. The loss per share was 0.7 Singapore cent, down from 1.82 Singapore cents. Full-year net loss also decreased by 21.1% to S$34.8 million. The group's main losses were attributed to goodwill impairment and operating losses due to a challenging operating environment. Revenue rose 24.6% to S$29 million for the quarter and 8.4% to S$104.8 million for the full year.

site_title: Sembcorp Q4 profit down 85%; plans to list India energy business
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a 41.6% drop in net profit to S$230.8 million for the full year 2017, citing losses in its marine businesses and lower utility contributions. Despite a 4.8% increase in revenue to S$2.1 billion for Q4 2017, the company plans to list its India energy business and reposition its utilities arm. A final dividend of two Singapore cents per share is proposed, with an initial public offering (IPO) of Sembcorp Energy India also in the works to deliver estimated cash proceeds of up to S$0.5 billion.

site_title: UE books revaluation gains but dividend falls
summary: United Engineers' (UE) full-year net profit from continuing operations rose 227% to S$89.6 million, driven by a net revaluation gain of S$44.4 million from investment properties in Singapore and a S$16.8 million reduction in rental support provisions.

site_title: Fat is back and premium butter makers are taking the cream
summary: Global butter inventories have dwindled to less than 12 days' supply, prompting higher prices amid strong demand for premium brands. Retail butter sales are expected to grow 2.9% to $19.4 billion in 2018, driven by consumer shifts towards natural fats and lower health risks from consuming dairy-fat. Premium brands, such as Arla's Lurpak and Kerrygold, are benefiting from higher prices, with some countries experiencing price increases of up to 19%. Experts predict butter prices will remain high in 2018 and potentially reach new highs within the next decade.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Lack of data on Singapore's reserves limits discussion on its use
summary: Singapore's Budget 2018 has sparked debate on the country's significant reserves, but a lack of publicly disclosed data hinders discussion on their use. To provide clarity, one panellist suggested splitting the reserves into two parts: setting aside a portion as a base for generating contributions to the Budget, while keeping the other portion secret. This approach would give Singaporeans a clearer understanding of the sums involved, allowing for more informed discussion on the use of the country's reserves.

site_title: Saudi Arabia to splurge on Western entertainment
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to spend billions on building new entertainment venues and hiring Western acts, part of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's social and economic reforms. The move marks a significant shift for the ultra-conservative kingdom, which has traditionally limited entertainment options. The new developments are expected to attract more tourists and boost the economy, as the country seeks to modernize and diversify its economy. This initiative is part of the kingdom's broader efforts to become a more attractive destination for investment and tourism.

site_title: How will car dealers survive in car-lite S'pore?
summary: Inchcape Singapore's managing director, Jasmmine Wong, aims to bring fresh thinking to the struggling motor trade in Singapore. The industry faces challenges due to the "car-lite" market, where consumers are increasingly opting for alternative modes of transportation. Wong spends her weekends observing consumers at car showrooms to better understand their needs and preferences. Her goal is to help car dealers adapt to the changing market and remain relevant in the face of declining car sales.

site_title: Taking the Asean trade horse to the water
summary: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) is poised to become a major economic hub, with a combined population of 1.3 billion and an economy of $2.7 trillion. Singapore, as Asean's chair, aims to deepen economic integration and leverage the region's growing consumer market. Key initiatives include e-commerce, digital highways, and infrastructure alignment. The Asean digital economy has the potential to grow to $200 billion by 2025, with e-commerce alone accounting for $88 billion. However, challenges include creating an enabling environment, addressing data security concerns, and overcoming geopolitical rivalries and domestic politics.

images.alt_text: Ravi Velloor

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Lower initial carbon tax aimed at helping companies transit: Masagos
summary: Singapore has introduced a lower initial carbon tax of S$5 a tonne to help companies adjust to the new tax regime. The tax rate will increase to S$10-S$15 a tonne by 2030. The government aims to allow companies time to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions and improve energy efficiency. The tax will be uniform and simple, with low compliance costs. The Singapore Green Building Council has welcomed the move, citing benefits for both the environment and building occupants. The government plans to use the new tax to encourage companies to transition to a low-carbon economy.

site_title: Creative brings '3D' sound to headphones after US$100m R&D
summary: Creative Technology has developed the Super X-Fi chip, a $150 dongle that powers 3D sound in headphones, capable of recreating a customized listening experience. The technology uses artificial intelligence to map an individual's ear shape and acoustics, and then performs reverse computations to create a 3D audio experience. The company aims to have 50 million users within two years and plans to release a free app that samples the technology before its market release this summer. The technology is seen as a game-changer in the headphone industry, with potential competition from existing 3D audio technologies being minimal.

site_title: US: Stocks end choppy session mostly up
summary: US stocks ended the day mostly up, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.7% to 24,962.48. The S&P 500 edged up 0.1% to 2,703.96, while the Nasdaq Composite Index dipped 0.1%. Analysts expect continued volatility amid expected interest rate hikes, which could impact growth and investor sentiment. Some experts, like Phil Davis of PSW Investment, believe stock prices are overvalued and need to correct. Petroleum-linked shares saw gains, with Halliburton and ExxonMobil rising 1.3% and 2.2%, respectively.

site_title: Family Matters
summary: A retired pharmacist, Lim Cheng See, and her husband upgraded their intergenerational home with the help of their son, Tan Cher Ming, an architect. The new two-storey home features an L-shaped design with private spaces for each family group, including a lap pool, outdoor kitchen, and a garden. Cher Ming incorporated his favorite materials, such as Burmese teak wood and Borneo ironwood, to create a warm and welcoming space. The design prioritizes both private spaces and shared areas, allowing the families to coexist comfortably.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Dollar higher on Fed minutes, rising inflation
summary: The dollar rose to a 10-day high after the US Federal Reserve's January meeting minutes showed policymakers confident in rising inflation. The minutes also indicated that the European Central Bank would avoid abrupt adjustments to its monetary policy. The euro remained unchanged despite its own central bank's policy minutes. Expectations of future interest rate hikes by the Fed, following the release of the minutes, drove the dollar's gain, with a 2% increase from its three-year low.

site_title: Recreating Nostalgic Flavours
summary: Food enthusiasts are reviving traditional artisanal treats, including Hakka Abacus Seeds and Peranakan kueh. Veteran pastry chef Pang Kok Keong is recreating Hakka flavors at his offshoot, Pang's Hakka Delicacies, while food blogger Alan Goh shares his late mother's recipes, making traditional Peranakan kueh. Entrepreneurs Stella Lee and Veron Tang are modernizing the humble gyoza with Pin Dumplings, offering unique flavors while maintaining an artisanal touch. These ventures aim to preserve local cuisines and share nostalgic flavors with a wider audience.

site_title: PNB scandal was not a lone-wolf crime
summary: The Punjab National Bank (PNB) scandal, a $1.8 billion heist that went undetected for seven years, is unlikely to be attributed to a single rogue banker, as PNB claims. The Reserve Bank of India's (RBI) November 2016 circular on misuse of Swift user IDs and the recent Bangladesh Bank heist suggest a systemic abuse issue. The RBI's sudden action and the industry's leniency in the face of a major scandal also raise questions about the involvement of other banks and financial institutions, including the central bank itself.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: An olive branch in lower-than-expected carbon tax
summary: The Singapore government has unveiled a lower-than-expected carbon tax of S$5 per tonne of carbon emissions for the first five years, from 2019 to 2023, as part of the 2018 budget. This is lower than the initially announced S$10-20 range. The tax will be raised to S$10-15 per tonne by 2030, giving industries ample lead time to adapt. The decision is seen as an olive branch to affected industries, despite rejecting their request for industry-specific tax benchmarks.

site_title: SembMarine shares fall double digits on poor Q4 results
summary: SembCorp Marine shares plummeted 11.4% to close at S$2.33 after the rig-builder reported a net loss of S$33.8 million in Q4, reversing from a S$34.3 million profit the previous year. Analysts attribute the poor performance to "kitchen sinking costs" but maintain positive outlooks, with some raising target prices. SembCorp Industries' strategic review has sparked speculation on a potential privatisation or divestment of SembMarine.

site_title: Singapore M&OE remains relevant despite headwinds
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Trade and Industry (MOTI) has launched an industry transformation roadmap (ITM) for the marine and offshore engineering (M&OE) sector, aiming to boost value-add to S$5.8 billion. Despite sectoral headwinds, the roadmap emphasizes Singapore's relevance in the global M&OE industry. The Skills Framework also outlines career pathways for M&OE professionals, highlighting the government's commitment to supporting the sector's growth and competitiveness.

site_title: Dhaka Ups Its Cultural Stakes
summary: Billionaire couple Nadia and Rajeeb Samdani have been instrumental in putting Bangladesh on the art map with the biennial Dhaka Art Summit. The event, now in its fourth edition, has drawn thousands of international art lovers and featured works by 300 artists from 35 countries, addressing topics such as the refugee crisis and transnational labor migration. The summit has successfully showcased Bangladesh's rich cultural heritage and complex identity, with major museums like the Tate and the Metropolitan Museum of Art now collecting Bangladeshi artists. The Samdanis plan to expand their art endeavors with the unveiling of Srihatta, an art center and sculpture park in Sylhet, aimed at boosting tourism in the region.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: #MeToo gathers force in S Korea through chat app
summary: A South Korean chat app called Blind has added a #MeToo feature, allowing users to anonymously share stories of workplace sexual misconduct. The move is shedding new light on the country's male-dominated corporate culture, where many employees fear retaliation for reporting harassment. Since its launch, the app has received over 1,600 posts, including allegations of groping, sexist jokes, and unwelcome advances. Blind's co-founder says the feature was inspired by a recent public prosecutor's complaint, and the app's users are drawn to its anonymity and ability to bypass traditional whistleblower hotlines.

site_title: The Internet - the US economy's weakest link
summary: The US economy's weakest link is identified as the Internet, according to a quiz published in 2018. The article suggests that the Internet poses a significant threat to America's economy due to its potential to disrupt traditional industries and create new challenges. This finding is not directly related to the subsequent articles, which cover various topics such as global economic trends, AI talent wars, and US foreign policy under Donald Trump.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018 addresses healthcare needs but costs remain a challenge
summary: Singapore's Budget 2018 addresses healthcare needs, but costs remain a challenge. The country's healthcare spending has more than doubled to S$10.2 billion in FY2018, and is expected to rise to 3% of GDP by 2028. The ageing demographic and chronic disabilities will require increased healthcare subsidies. To address this, the government plans to build six more hospitals, four new polyclinics, and expand eldercare services. Medical inflation remains a challenge, but fee guidelines are expected to be published this year to rein in costs. Ultimately, all parties must play their part to keep healthcare accessible and affordable.

site_title: Twitter cracks down on automated 'bot' accounts
summary: Twitter has cracked down on automated "bot" accounts, a move aimed at curbing disinformation, propaganda, and provocation. The platform has enforced its rules to rid the service of spam-spewing automated accounts, not targeting users who follow the rules. This is the latest effort by Twitter to address concerns raised during the 2016 US election.

site_title: Conservation vs en bloc sale: Money talks louder?
summary: The Pearl Bank Apartments in Singapore may be demolished unless CapitaLand, the owner, decides to preserve it. In 2015, the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) supported conservation efforts, stating they would facilitate a proposal if 100% of owners supported it. However, an en bloc sale can be approved with just 80% of owner votes, leading to a conflict between conservation and financial gain. This highlights the tension between preserving cultural and historical sites and prioritizing financial interests.

site_title: Singapore public service among world's least corrupt
summary: Singapore's corruption perception index has improved, moving up a notch to the rarefied club of least corrupt countries, according to Transparency International's latest Corruption Perceptions Index. The country's zero-tolerance approach to corruption has not been tarnished by a bribery scandal involving government-linked firm Keppel Offshore & Marine, despite the firm's involvement in a Brazilian scandal. Singapore's improved ranking highlights the country's strong governance and commitment to transparency.

site_title: Run Around Town
summary: The District Race, the world's first urban exploration race, will take place on March 3 at Gardens by the Bay. Participants will run across five districts, completing challenges and clearing checkpoints via an app within a two-hour time frame. The event has no set route or distance, allowing participants to strategize and explore their city. Prizes include luxury yacht tickets valued at S$4,500. Registration is available at districtrace.com/events/singapore.

site_title: Could this card change the way you look at Mazdas forever?
summary: Mazda has launched Dezire, a rewards programme for its luxury car models, offering perks such as priority booking for servicing, S$1,000 in aftersales vouchers, and a year of Accor Plus membership. The programme aims to build customer loyalty and elevate the brand's status, shifting focus from price to a lifestyle experience. Similar programmes are being rolled out by other car brands, including Audi and BMW Motorrad, with the goal of differentiating dealerships from parallel importers and fostering customer goodwill.

site_title: Fit And Fabulous
summary: Only 26% of Singaporeans meet the minimum weekly physical activity recommendation of 150 minutes of moderate to vigorous exercise. Experts recommend exercises such as squat with twist, holding the soup, and balance exercises to improve fitness levels. Assessments like the chair test, timed up and go test, and six-minute walk test can also be done at home to evaluate fitness components. Regular exercise can lower the risk of chronic diseases, boost energy, and improve productivity.

site_title: Eye drug Eylea has mysterious rise in side effect reports
summary: Regeneron Pharmaceuticals' top-selling eye drug Eylea has seen a mysterious rise in reports of a rare side effect, characterized by a sharp decline in sight, pain, and panic in patients after injection. The FDA received 71 reports last year, almost triple the number in 2014. Doctors are warning of the condition, which is treatable but can cause temporary vision loss. The company is closely monitoring the reports and allowing doctors to swap out affected medicine. Despite concerns, the benefits of the treatment outweigh the risks, according to the American Society of Retina Specialists.

site_title: Saudi Arabia ends airport concession deal with Changi
summary: Saudi Arabia's General Authority of Civil Aviation (GACA) has terminated a 20-year concession agreement with Changi Airports International and its Saudi partner to operate the King Abdulaziz International Airport in Jeddah. The reason for the cancellation was not elaborated. The companies had "strictly observed the request for proposal process stipulated by GACA" and submitted required documentation prior to the award of the concession. This move is part of Saudi Arabia's broader privatisation drive, which includes selling stakes in airports.

site_title: A Singapore Budget for the future
summary: Singapore's Budget 2018 aims to prepare the country for the next decade of disruption driven by technology, globalization, and demographic shifts. The budget addresses challenges such as an aging population and introduces initiatives to support companies' innovation and transformation. Key measures include the extension of the Productivity Solutions Grant, the introduction of a new tax deduction scheme for intellectual properties, and the extension of the GST rate to cover imported services. The government also plans to increase taxes, with the GST rate set to rise from 7% to 9% and carbon taxes adjusted from $5 to $15 per tonne of carbon emission.

site_title: STI falls after US slumps on Fed minutes
summary: Singapore shares ended lower on Thursday as regional markets followed the US Dow's 0.67% decline, weighed down by the release of the latest Federal Reserve minutes. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.79% lower, while China's CSI 300 Index rose 2.2% after the country reopened from a week-long Chinese New Year hiatus. Analysts expect a rate hike at the March meeting under new Fed chief Jerome Powell, citing recent minutes' indication of a hike.

site_title: Sniffing out Bordeaux wine futures
summary: Investors in Bordeaux wine futures are benefiting from the 2015 vintage, which is being compared to the legendary 1982 vintage due to its quality. The author, a new wine collector, was introduced to Decanter magazine, which provided valuable recommendations for the best 1982 releases, setting them up for success with the 2015 vintage. This stroke of luck highlights the importance of staying informed and seeking expert advice in the world of wine collecting.

site_title: Deep price discount raises fears over Hyflux perp redemption
summary: Hyflux's 6% retail perpetual securities (perps) traded at 76.5 cents to the dollar, raising concerns about the company's ability to redeem them at the first call date of April 25. Analysts believe Hyflux is unlikely to call the perps due to the relatively low step-up interest rate of 8% per annum, which is considered "cheap" for the company's financial standing. The company has not missed an interest payment and is expected to redeem the perps.

site_title: Staff cuts can be a double-edged sword
summary: Singapore Airlines no longer penalizes cabin crew for taking casual sick leave, following a flight attendant's death in a hotel room last year. This change may not directly impact the airline's share price, but staff costs rose 15% to S$84.7 million in the past quarter. Companies should be aware that unhappy staff can be unproductive and that retrenchments can come with significant severance payouts. The move may also influence investors' perception of staff benefits and company priorities, with some arguing that employees should be shareholders.

site_title: Seoul to quickly conduct due diligence on GM's S Korea unit
summary: South Korea plans to conduct due diligence on General Motors' (GM) financially strapped South Korean unit before taking action. Finance Minister Kim Dong Yeon stated that GM should play a "responsible role" in normalizing its operations and come up with a sustainable development plan. The Korea Development Bank, which holds a 17% stake in GM Korea, and the local labor union will also "share the pain" of the plant shutdowns. GM has asked for financial support for its money-losing South Korean unit, and its head of international operations, Barry Engle, met with senior officials in Seoul.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sanli Environmental Engineering secured four EPC contracts worth S$18.1 million, increasing its order book to S$121.3 million. Sunningdale Tech reported a 64% drop in fourth-quarter earnings due to foreign exchange loss and retrenchment costs, despite a 1.6% revenue increase. Sheng Siong Group saw a 9.3% rise in net profit for the fourth quarter, driven by government grants. These companies' earnings and dividends were announced on February 22, 2018.

site_title: OUE's full-year profits slump 31.5% on lower revenue, surge in certain expenses
summary: OUE Limited's full-year net profit fell 31.5% to S$98.9 million due to a 14.7% decline in revenue and increased administrative expenses. Revenue from investment properties and hospitality divisions rose, while the development property division benefited from the sale of luxury units. The healthcare division contributed S$33.8 million in revenue. The board proposed a final cash dividend of 2 cents per share, unchanged from last year. OUE executive chairman Stephen Riady expects increased contributions from new properties to enhance shareholder value.

site_title: BreadTalk's full-year earnings up 91% on consolidation strategy
summary: BreadTalk Group reported record earnings of S$21.8 million for the full year ended Dec 31, 2017, a 91% jump from the previous year, driven by its consolidation strategy. Revenue dipped 2.5% to S$599.7 million. The company recommended a special dividend of one Singapore cent per share and a final dividend of two Singapore cents per share. Net profit for the three months ended Dec 31 rose 14.4% to S$5.1 million.

site_title: Digital assimilation - it takes a lot more than marketing hype
summary: Businesses struggling to implement emerging technologies face steep learning and implementation curves, with over two-thirds of IoT projects failing to go into production. The main issue lies in siloed data that doesn't feed into other systems, resulting in lost potential ROI. To overcome this, businesses must consider the data question, bolster digital trust and security, and invest in talent to stay competitive. A new approach is needed, focusing on integrating technologies within a digital workflow and adopting a more holistic strategy, rather than just relying on marketing hype.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: KSH Holdings, a Singapore-based construction company, sees potential in the property market despite a recent share price drop. Analysts believe the negatives in the construction sector are now priced in, and the company's landbank and cheap land acquisition costs make it a profitable investment. The company's purchase of Serangoon Ville at a lower price than a nearby site demonstrates its execution astuteness. With a solid landbank, KSH is well-positioned to ride Singapore's property upcycle over its 10-year development cycle.

site_title: PSA raises stake in CrimsonLogic to 45%, deepens cooperation
summary: PSA International has raised its stake in CrimsonLogic to 45% through share acquisitions from Singapore Telecommunications and the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore. The remaining 55% is held by International Enterprise Singapore. PSA and CrimsonLogic will collaborate on innovations and trade solutions to improve global trade flow and supply chain processes.

site_title: Poignant Stage Drama
summary: The Father, a poignant stage drama, opens at the Victoria Theatre on March 2, 2018, and runs till March 18. Directed by Tracie Pang, the play explores the complexities of dementia through multiple perspectives, ultimately revealing a brutally truthful and moving story. The stellar cast includes Lim Kay Siu, Tan Kheng Hua, and Janice Koh.

site_title: Wishes, wants and the hongbao handout in BT Weekend
summary: The article discusses the purpose of wish lists and public needs in a government's fiscal plan, referencing the upcoming Budget. It touches on various topics, including corporate purpose, gratitude and resentment in the workplace, and the success of minimalist brands like Muji. The article also mentions a call to rethink the government's hongbao handouts, a topic further explored by a Saturday Soapbox columnist. The article concludes by highlighting various sections of The Business Times, including investing advice and health tips.

site_title: UK economy lags behind G-7 after 2017 growth rate cut
summary: The UK economy grew at 1.7% in 2017, its lowest rate since 2012, according to official data. The country's economy slowed in the fourth quarter, with a 0.4% growth rate, down from a previous estimate of 0.5%. This raises concerns about the strength of the economy as the Bank of England prepares to raise interest rates, with economists disagreeing on whether a rate hike is necessary. The UK's economy lags behind the global recovery and is the weakest of the G-7 economies.

site_title: SBF targets over 100 Singapore companies for first China International Import Expo
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) plans to send over 100 Singapore companies to the China International Import Expo (CIIE) in Shanghai, representing the country's diverse business ecosystem. The expo, themed "New Era, New Platform," aims to facilitate business matching and networking opportunities for Singapore companies in the Chinese market. The SBF will cluster exhibitors by sector and set up a national pavilion to showcase Singaporean products collectively, while also providing online and offline transaction services. The event is seen as an opportunity for Singapore companies to tap into China's growing market and strengthen bilateral trade ties.

site_title: Nelson & Terence Loh
summary: Nelson and Terence Loh, cousins and co-founders of Novena Global Lifecare Group, started the company in 2010 to offer affordable aesthetics treatments in Asia. Despite facing a major crisis in 2015 when their Singapore partner quit, they successfully rebranded and expanded the business. Novena now has over 100 clinics across Asia, treating over two million patients, and is expanding into integrated healthcare. The cousins aim to make Novena a global brand, similar to Singapore Airlines, and have received an award for best enterprise in China in 2016.

site_title: StanChart first major foreign bank to consolidate all Singapore operations
summary: Standard Chartered Singapore (StanChart) will consolidate its local operations into its Singapore subsidiary, marking the first major foreign bank to do so. The move will involve transferring commercial, corporate, and institutional banking, as well as private banking businesses to the local unit. The decision is expected to close within 12-18 months and may pave the way for listing the local operations. StanChart Singapore will be required to set aside additional capital and maintain a higher capital buffer, but analysts expect the bank to continue to contribute to Singapore's growth and remain a key player in the market.

site_title: Australia's Westfield says 'No Plan B' as Unibail deal shrinks
summary: Australia's Westfield Corp has ruled out increasing its US$16 billion buyout offer from France's Unibail-Rodamco, citing no Plan B after a decline in Unibail's shares reduced the deal's value by an estimated A$2.5 billion. Westfield co-CEO Peter Lowy stated there's nothing to speculate about, and the company is committed to the transaction. Unibail has also refused to change the deal terms. The deal, announced last December, would see the Lowy family sell their 9.3% stake in Westfield.

site_title: Dynamic Duo
summary: Stockholm chefs Adam Dahlberg and Albin Wessman, known for their restaurant Adam/Albin, are collaborating with Ivan Brehm of Restaurant Nouri on a six-hands dining event. The event, taking place on March 1-2, offers a five-course tasting menu with customizable courses. The event aims to showcase Nordic sustainability and simplicity, priced at S$170++ for lunch and S$265++ for dinner. Reservations can be made by calling 6221-4148.

site_title: The Individualist

He finds inspiration in various aspects of life, including fashion, design, music, and art, and values a holistic approach. Chew practices tai chi, yoga, and meditation, and travels frequently for work, citing Sao Paulo as a city that transformed his perspective. This article, part of MINI's "The Individualist" series, aims to inspire and awaken creativity in readers.

The sale is seen as a rare opportunity for redevelopment in the area, with interest from developers, investors, and high-net-worth individuals.

site_title: AXA posts net profit of 6.21b euros
summary: AXA, Europe's second-largest insurer, posted higher-than-expected 2017 net profits of 6.21 billion euros, driven by stronger earnings in the US and a diversified business model. AXA plans to float its American life insurance and asset management businesses in Q2 to free up capital and pursue growth opportunities, particularly in health insurance and Asia.

site_title: Cooking Cause
summary: The Man Cooker is a charity cookbook published by the Man Group to support Room to Read, a global literacy and education organization. The cookbook features 50 recipes from employees worldwide, representing various cuisines, and retails for S$20. All proceeds will be matched by the Man Charitable Trust, doubling the funds donated to Room to Read. The cookbook aims to support education and literacy in low-income countries while providing home cooks with new and convenient recipes.

The ASICS GEL-BURZ 1 sneakers, priced at S$449, combine elements of the Gel-Nimbus 20 and Gel-Venture 6 with ASICS FlyteFoam technology. Clytemnestra succeeds in killing her husband, prompting their daughter Electra to seek revenge against her mother. The book offers a unique perspective on the classic Greek tragedy, shedding light on the experiences of a powerful female character.

site_title: How GE gambled on fossil fuel power, and lost
summary: General Electric's power-plant business made a bullish forecast in March 2018, predicting revenue and profit growth despite flat demand for new natural gas power plants. However, industry estimates now suggest that conventional plants are unlikely to reach 2017 levels for at least a decade, due to increasing competition from renewable energy sources. This shift in the energy landscape has significant implications for GE Power and the broader industry.

site_title: Wilmar Q4 net down 24% due to tropical oil, sugar segments
summary: Wilmar International reported a 23.8% decline in net profit to US$427.5 million in its fourth quarter due to lower sales volume and weaker average selling prices in its tropical oils and sugar segments. The company's tropical oils segment saw a 43% drop in pre-tax profit, while the sugar segment's pre-tax profit plummeted 70%. Despite this, Wilmar's full-year net profit rose 25.4% to US$1.22 billion. The company's chairman and CEO Kuok Khoon Hong expects satisfactory performance in 2018, barring unforeseen circumstances.

site_title: Hong Kong data centre VP to join embattled Datapulse as new CEO
summary: Datapulse Technology, a Hong Kong-based disk drive maker, has appointed Wilson Teng Wai Leung as its new CEO, replacing Kee Swee Ann, who quit just weeks after taking the job. summary: Singapore shares closed lower on Thursday, following a drop in US markets overnight. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.79% to 3,488.46, with 121 gainers and 331 losers. Sembcorp Marine led the decline after reporting a fourth-quarter loss of S$33.8 million, down from a net profit of S$34.3 million a year ago. site_title: US: Dow opens higher after two sessions of losses
summary: The US stock market opened higher on Thursday after two days of losses, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 101.75 points to 24,899.53. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, with the S&P 500 rising 11.77 points to 2,713.1 and the Nasdaq Composite adding 36.10 points to 7,254.33. The gains came as bond yields eased off four-year highs and traders took stock of the Federal Reserve's views on inflation.

site_title: Qantas outlines pilot academy plans as profit soars
summary: Qantas Airways reported a 17.9% jump in interim net profit to A$607 million, driven by a strong performance from its domestic arm. The airline also announced plans to establish one of the southern hemisphere's biggest pilot academies, investing A$20 million to train 500 pilots per year. This move comes as the global demand for skilled pilots is booming, with Boeing estimating 640,000 more pilots needed in the next 20 years. Qantas shares jumped 6.45% following the announcement.

site_title: Wilmar Q4 net profit down 24% due to tropical oil and sugar segments
summary: Wilmar International reported a 23.8% decline in net profit to US$427.5 million in its fourth quarter due to challenging conditions in tropical oils and sugar segments. Revenue dropped 3.3% to US$11.55 billion, mainly due to lower sales volume and weaker average selling prices. The decline was attributed to the firm's segments, which faced difficulties.

site_title: Fed officials say tax cuts could boost economy
summary: US Federal Reserve officials say tax cuts could boost the economy more than expected, potentially leading to further interest rate hikes. Despite this, some officials are cautious about raising rates, citing uncertain economic impact and low inflation. The Fed expects three interest rate hikes this year, but the minutes suggest a possible fourth move. The impact of tax cuts remains uncertain, and the central bankers are debating the use of the term "further" to describe the likely path of interest rate increases.

site_title: Investments pay off for European telecom's old guard
summary: European telecom companies, including Deutsche Telekom, Telefonica, and Orange, reported growth in their home markets after years of competition. Investments in better networks have paid off, allowing them to offer faster, bigger bundles of broadband and mobile connections at a higher price. The established operators have adapted to regulatory changes by allowing new entrants to use their infrastructure, resulting in increased revenue. This shift marks a turning point for the industry, with the old guard finally seeing growth after being under attack from challengers. Market share and profits have been boosted as a result.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore aims to create 1,500 new jobs and boost the marine, offshore and engineering industry to S$5.8 billion. Standard Chartered Bank transferred its Singapore operations to a locally incorporated unit, highlighting the country's strategic importance.

site_title: Trek 2000 FY17 net profit up 1.6% to US$6.2m despite 32% dip in revenue
summary: Trek 2000 International reported a 1.6% increase in net profit for FY2017 to US$6.2 million, despite a 32% dip in revenue to US$112.6 million. Earnings per share rose to 1.9 US cents from 1.87 US cents in the previous year. The disposal of a 19% stake in Racer Group contributed to the revenue decline.

site_title: Amara Holdings FY17 profit down 36%
summary: Amara Holdings reported a 36% drop in net profit for FY17 to S$23.89 million, primarily due to a decline in the share of results from a jointly-controlled entity. Revenue rose 10% to S$89.8 million, driven by growth in the Hotel Investment and Management segment and Property Investment and Development segment. The company declared a final dividend of one cent per share, unchanged from last year, and expects its Amara Signature Shanghai Hotel to be fully operational in the second half of 2018.

site_title: Ford US chief departs abruptly after behaviour probe
summary: Ford US chief Raj Nair is leaving the company immediately after an internal investigation found his behavior was "inconsistent with the company's code of conduct". The investigation was launched after a report of inappropriate behavior, with Nair apologizing for instances where he failed to exhibit leadership behaviors consistent with the company's principles. As North American chief, Nair was responsible for operations generating 90% of Ford's global profits, but will stand to lose $4.8 million in restricted shares. The company has not investigated other executives for similar cases, amid efforts to improve profitability and address allegations of harassment.

site_title: Malaysia's Axiata swings to profit on cost cuts, data earnings
summary: Malaysia's Axiata Group Bhd reported a net profit of 24.7 million ringgit in the fourth quarter, reversing a net loss of 309.5 million ringgit a year earlier. Revenue rose 8.2% to 6.3 billion ringgit, driven by strong data earnings from its main mobile units in Indonesia, Malaysia, and Bangladesh. The data business contributed 49.2% to service revenue, up from 37.9% a year earlier. Cost cutting helped improve the company's financial performance.

site_title: Michelin-Starred Fashion
summary: The Michelin Guide has awarded a star to the Emporio Armani restaurant and caffe in Paris, recognizing the "lovely Italian cuisine, mainly Milanese, using very fine ingredients" under the helm of chef Massimo Tringali. The award comes after a 2016 renovation of the Paris restaurant and cafe, which also includes a flagship store. This marks the first Michelin star for Giorgio Armani's eateries, solidifying his luxury brand's reputation in the culinary world.

site_title: Li Ka-shing unit is buyer of City Towers
summary: Japura Development, linked to Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing's Cheung Kong empire, has acquired City Towers in Bukit Timah Road through a collective sale. The award was announced by Colliers International on February 7, after the tender for the en bloc sale closed. Japura Development beat six other contenders to secure the freehold collective sale site, marking a significant deal in Singapore's property market.

site_title: Embattled Australian deputy PM faces call to step down as party leader
summary: Australian Deputy Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce is facing a call to step down as leader of his party amid an extramarital affair. Member of Parliament Andrew Broad has urged Joyce to step down, citing concerns the affair could undermine support in state elections. The National Party, part of the ruling coalition, has withdrawn support for Joyce, with two-thirds of voters wanting him to resign. Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has described the affair as a "shocking error of judgment." Joyce has refused to resign, but a party meeting is set to discuss the issue on Monday.

site_title: Bashing 'the other' is wrong, whoever does it
summary: US President Donald Trump has been accused of being xenophobic, nativist, and racist for his public statements targeting various groups, including Chinese, Mexican, and Muslim immigrants. The article highlights Trump's nationalist stance and its implications for US foreign policy, while also touching on other global issues such as AI talent wars and China's economic influence.

site_title: Is this the best car in Singapore for under S$100K?
summary: The Hyundai i30 is a Korean car designed and engineered in Germany, and its European features make it a contender for the best car in Singapore under S$100K. With a 1.4-litre turbo engine and 7-speed twin-clutch automatic, the i30 offers a fun and pleasant driving experience. Its suspension is well-mannered, and the interior is solidly built with modern conveniences. The i30's price of S$90,999 makes it a bargain compared to the Volkswagen Golf, which starts at S$108,900. The Hyundai i30 could be the best car on sale today for less than S$100,000.

site_title: JEP appoints UMS founder and CEO as new executive chairman

site_title: Broker's take: UOB upgrades KSH to "buy", cites profit potential of China project
summary: UOB Kay Hian analysts have upgraded their call on KSH Holdings to "buy" and increased the target price of the property firm's shares from S$0.87 to S$1.08. They cite profit potential from KSH's China project and a recovery in Singapore's construction sector. The analysts note that the recent share price drop has priced in the weakness in the construction sector, and KSH's landbank may enable its construction and property development portfolios to ride on Singapore's property upcycle. However, risks include the GaoBeiDian project and weak results in the current fiscal year.

site_title: Kingsmen FY2017 bottomline falls 18.1% to S$9.7m
summary: Kingsmen Creatives reported a 6.8% decline in revenue to S$307.3 million in FY2017, with a 18.1% drop in net profit to S$9.7 million. Earnings per share decreased to 4.9 Singapore cents from 6.02 Singapore cents in the previous year. Despite the decline, the company's group CEO, Andrew Cheng, expressed optimism about the market's buoyancy in exhibition, event, and hospitality segments, and plans to expand into new areas. The company declared a dividend of 1.5 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: Insurer AXA's 2017 profit up ahead of IPO of US business
summary: AXA, Europe's second-largest insurer, reported higher-than-expected 2017 net profits of 6.21 billion euros, beating analysts' forecasts. The company attributed its strong earnings to reinsurance contracts and a diversified business model, which helped it avoid costly natural catastrophes. AXA also announced a 9% increase in its 2017 dividend to 1.26 euros per share. The insurer plans to float its US business in the second quarter, aiming to free up capital and pursue takeover targets.

site_title: Ascendas-Singbridge appoints new chief executive for India operations
summary: Ascendas-Singbridge has appointed VINAMRA Srivastava as the new chief executive of India operations and private funds, effective April 1. Srivastava, currently head of corporate strategy & development, will lead the company's operations in India, overseeing business development, strategic planning, and expanding the group's portfolio of assets. The company manages over 13 million square feet of assets across India, with a presence spanning over two decades.

site_title: India seizes billionaire jeweller's Rolls-Royce, Porsche in bank fraud probe
summary: India's Enforcement Directorate has seized luxury vehicles, including a Rolls-Royce and Porsche, belonging to billionaire jeweller Nirav Modi and his firms in a probe into a $1.8 billion bank fraud. The alleged fraud involves illegally issued letters of undertaking from Punjab National Bank, used to obtain loans from overseas banks. Modi and his uncle Mehul Choksi are at the center of the probe, with over a dozen people arrested so far. site_title: Hong Kong shares retreat, Shanghai reopens with rally

site_title: Revaluation gains lift United Engineers' full year net profit; dividend reduced
summary: United Engineers' full-year net profit from continuing operations rose 227% to S$89.6 million in 2017, driven by a net revaluation gain of S$44.4 million from investment properties and a S$16.8 million reduction in rental support. The company declared a first and final dividend of 4 cents per share, lower than previous years. Revenue increased 12% to S$539.4 million, with property development revenue rising 106% to S$146 million.

site_title: Soul-searching as symbol of 70s Singapore faces demolition
summary: A 37-storey, 1976-built tower block in Singapore's Chinatown, Pearl Bank Apartments, is set to be demolished to make way for a modern residential building. The structure, which was the tallest residential building in Singapore at the time, holds sentimental value for some as a reminder of the country's rapid development after independence in 1965. However, residents and architectural experts argue that conservation is not practical due to high costs, leaving the nation to question whether enough is being done to protect its recent history.

site_title: Riverstone posts 5% drop in Q4 profit
summary: Riverstone Holdings reported a 5% drop in Q4 net profit to RM34.23 million due to increased operating expenses and finance costs. Revenue rose 15.1% to RM210.69 million. The company's full-year net profit increased 7.4% to RM129.29 million, with revenue jumping 24.8% to RM817.44 million. However, gross profit margin fell to 24.2% due to a drop in average selling price and product mix changes.

site_title: Thai mall operator profits up 47% on tourism boom
summary: Thai retail property developer Central Pattana Pcl reported a 47% increase in net profit to 13.6 billion baht for its 2017 fiscal year, beating estimates. The company attributed the growth to the country's tourism boom, driven by Chinese arrivals. Revenue from rent and services rose 3.2% to 26 billion baht, with average occupancy rates at 92%. The company plans to achieve a compound annual growth rate of at least 13% until 2022, focusing on mixed-use and residential developments in Southeast Asia.

images.alt_text: Thai retail property developer Central Pattana Pcl (CPN) reported net profit of 13.6 billion baht (S$570 million) for its 2017 fiscal year on Wednesday, up 47 per cent from a year earlier.

site_title: Far East Orchard's full-year profit slumps 66.8%
summary: Far East Orchard reported a 66.8% slump in net profit for the full year ended Dec 31, 2017, to S$21.61 million due to a decline in revenue and share of profit from joint ventures. Revenue fell 18.2% to S$151.17 million, mainly due to the end of hospitality lease agreements in Australia and New Zealand. The company expects positive sentiments for residential properties, but a subdued outlook for the hospitality sector in Singapore.

site_title: Regeneron's eye drug Eylea has mysterious rise in side effect reports
summary: Regeneron's eye drug Eylea has seen a mysterious increase in reports of a rare side effect, characterized by a sharp decline in sight, pain, and panic in patients after injection. The FDA received 71 reports last year, almost triple the 2014 high, and the company is closely monitoring the issue. While the effect is treatable and doesn't lead to long-term vision loss, doctors are advised to look out for the condition, which may be linked to inflammation or a manufacturing error. The company is allowing doctors to swap out affected vials and the FDA has deemed a recall unnecessary.

images.alt_text: Doctors say they're seeing an unexplained increase in a rare, frightening side effect in patients getting Regeneron Pharmaceuticals' top-selling product, the blockbuster eye drug Eylea.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won down as Fed worries dampen sentiment
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index and the Korean won dropped to one-week lows due to Fed worries about further rate hikes this year. The KOSPI fell 0.63% and the won weakened 0.75% against the US dollar. This move follows minutes from the latest Federal Reserve meeting, which suggested policymakers will continue raising interest rates.

site_title: Next stop for SIA's new Boeing 787s? Perth
summary: Singapore Airlines will launch flights to Perth, Australia, starting in May, with the new Boeing 787-10 fleet, marking the second destination after Osaka, Japan. The airline is committed to the Australian market and believes customers will appreciate the enhanced travelling experience. The 787-10s will feature new regional cabin products and seat 337 passengers. This is the start of SIA's investment in the future of the airline, allowing for a modern and fuel-efficient fleet and expansion opportunities.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines (SIA) on Thursday announced that Perth will become the second scheduled destination to be served by its new Boeing 787-10 fleet.

site_title: Malaysia's Sime Darby Q2 net profit halves after demerger
summary: Malaysia's Sime Darby Bhd reported a net profit of 305 million ringgit (S$103.5 million) in its second quarter, down from 653 million ringgit last year, following the spin-off of its plantations and property divisions in November. Revenue remained stable at 8.8 billion ringgit. The company's demerger resulted in a significant decline in net profit, but revenue remained unchanged.

site_title: Seoul to quickly conduct due diligence on GM's South Korea unit: finance minister
summary: South Korea plans to conduct due diligence on General Motors' South Korea unit, which is financially strapped. The country will not take action until the due diligence is completed. Finance Minister Kim Dong-yeon stated that GM should play a responsible role in normalizing its operations and come up with a sustainable development plan. The government and Korea Development Bank may share the financial burden, and GM's union will participate in the due diligence process. GM has announced plant shutdowns in Gunsan and plans to decide on its remaining three plants in the country within weeks.

images.alt_text: South Korea plans to quickly conduct due diligence on the financially strapped South Korean unit of General Motors Co, Finance Minister Kim Dong-yeon said on Thursday.

site_title: Indian surgeons remove 'heaviest recorded' brain tumour
summary: Indian surgeons successfully removed a massive 1.87-kilogram brain tumour from a 31-year-old shopkeeper, Santlal Pal, in a seven-hour procedure. The tumour, considered the heaviest ever recorded, weighed nearly two kilos and appeared as if he had two heads mounted on top of each other. The patient has made a good recovery and is now walking and eating normally, with minimal vision expected to improve. The surgery was deemed extremely complex and rare, with 11 units of blood required.

site_title: Malaysia: shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 3.10 points lower at 1,855.07 on Thursday, with volume reaching 2.34 billion shares worth RM2.06 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 442 to 453.

site_title: Singapore travellers affected as Malaysian coach operator Konsortium shuts down
summary: A Malaysian coach operator, Konsortium Express & Tours, has unexpectedly shut down, leaving Singaporean passengers affected. The agency, which had nearly sold out coach tickets for the Chinese New Year Eve period, cited a "financial crisis" as the reason for its closure. Passengers are advised to claim travel insurance or apply for a refund through the small claims tribunal. Other affected travelers can contact member agencies for free trips to Malaysia until March 1. The sudden closure has caused surprise among workers and the travel industry.

site_title: StanChart transfers rest of Singapore operations to locally incorporated unit
summary: Standard Chartered Bank (StanChart) has announced it will transfer the rest of its Singapore operations to its locally incorporated subsidiary, Standard Chartered Bank (Singapore) Limited. The move aims to reinforce its long-term commitment to the ASEAN market, with the process expected to take 12-18 months. The bank's commercial, corporate, and private banking businesses will be consolidated, with no impact on client service levels. StanChart, which has operated in Singapore for 159 years, sees Singapore's strategic location as a key gateway to other ASEAN markets.

site_title: AusNet prices A$400m of bonds
summary: AusNet Services priced around A$400 million of bonds, comprising notes due 2028, 2030, and 2033. The proceeds will be used to refinance debt and fund asset growth. AusNet maintains a diversified debt maturity profile and has access to debt markets in Australia and offshore due to its investment-grade credit ratings. The company has A$625 million of undrawn committed bank debt facilities.

site_title: Malaysian rapper Namewee in the dog house over "obscene" Lunar New Year video
summary: Malaysian rapper Namewee was detained amid controversy over an "obscene" Lunar New Year music video, "Like a Dog", which depicted people in dog masks dancing and mimicking sexual positions. The video was deemed to insult Malaysia's religious and cultural norms, sparking calls for Namewee's investigation and arrest. This is not the first time Namewee has courted controversy, having been arrested in 2016 for allegedly insulting Islam in another music video. The government is planning to amend internet laws to broaden enforcement powers against content deemed detrimental to public order and security.

images.alt_text: Malaysia detained rapper Namewee on Thursday amid an uproar over an "obscene" Lunar New Year music video depicting people in dog masks dancing in what appears to be the administrative capital of Putrajaya.

site_title: Singapore moves up 1 spot, claims 6th place among least corrupt countries
summary: Singapore has moved up one spot to 6th place in Transparency International's 2017 Corruption Perceptions Index, scoring 84 points. The city-state's ranking has improved from 7th in 2016, with its score remaining unchanged from the previous year.

site_title: Audi A7 Sportback review: Rear admiration
summary: The Audi A7 Sportback boasts a stylish and aerodynamic design, particularly in its rear end, where its "true beauty" resides. The car's second iteration features a cleaner, sharper silhouette with a full-width taillight, making it a head-turner. The A7 is powered by a turbocharged 3.0-liter V6 engine, delivering smooth and flexible power. Its four-wheel steering system and adaptive air suspension contribute to its effortless cornering progress. With a spacious interior, advanced technology features, and a comfortable ride, the A7 is a fun and stylish alternative to traditional sedans, setting the stage for future high-performance variants.

site_title: Changes in ECB policy stance premature -minutes of Jan meeting
summary: European Central Bank policymakers concluded that changing their communication stance to signal policy normalization was premature, despite growing confidence in inflation returning to target. They agreed to avoid abrupt adjustments and keep a close eye on the euro's firming, which could cut into inflation. Policymakers may revisit their stance early this year, but for now, they will continue to develop monetary policy with a view to avoiding disorderly adjustments. The ECB left policy on hold and warned that US officials' attempts to talk down the dollar could prompt a rethink.

site_title: Indonesia's car exports now under threat from Vietnam
summary: Indonesia's car exports to Vietnam are under threat due to a new Vietnamese regulation requiring Vehicle Type Approval (VTA) certification and sampling inspections for imported cars. The regulation, which took effect on January 1, 2018, has prompted Indonesian automakers to halt production of 9,337 vehicles bound for Vietnam. The move is expected to impact Indonesia's car exports, with the country losing around $85 million in the December-March period, according to the Trade Ministry.

images.alt_text: As they face sluggish demand back home, Indonesia's four-wheel car manufacturers face a bleak future in exports following a new regulation from Vietnam, which is poised to build its own automotive industry.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets slide at open
summary: European stock markets declined at the start of trading on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.5% to 7,243.32 points. Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 also dropped 0.9% and 0.6% respectively. The decline was attributed to investors' anticipation of US interest rate hikes, while traders digested earnings updates from major companies.

site_title: Australia: Shares down on Wall St, Qantas rallies; NZ up on a2 Milk boom
summary: Australian shares fell on Thursday, weighed down by Wall Street weakness, while Qantas Airways rallied 9.8% on strong profits, its highest in over 2.5 years. Global miner BHP also rebounded after a week of losses, driven by a dividend boost.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down at open, Shanghai rallies
