The model requires brands to order textiles and get early feedback from commercial buyers to avoid unsold stocks, and top couture houses have resisted the concept so far.

site_title: Venezuela set to launch 'petro' cryptocurrency
summary: Venezuela is set to launch its "petro" cryptocurrency, a move aimed at addressing the country's economic crisis. The cryptocurrency is backed by a barrel of Venezuelan crude oil and has a total value of $6 billion. The launch is seen as an attempt to skirt US sanctions, but opposition leaders have called it an illegal debt issuance. The petro will be sold through a private sale, with no information on exchanges or investment. The move has been met with skepticism from blockchain experts, who warn it may not attract significant investment.

site_title: Guitar maker Gibson fighting for survival
summary: Gibson, the iconic guitar maker, is facing serious financial problems, threatening its survival. The company has brought in a new financial director, Benson Woo, to rescue the ailing group. Gibson Brands has a $375 million debt payment due in August and is working with an investment bank to set up a debt refinancing plan. CEO Henry Juszkiewicz plans to streamline the company's business strategy, eliminating underperforming products, and expects improved financial results within the next year.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets remained steady at the start of trading on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index down fractionally. The eurozone markets saw a slight increase, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 climbing 0.1% and Paris CAC 40 remaining flat.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Koh Brothers Group has signed a joint venture agreement with Global Skyline Sdn Bhd to develop a mixed-use property in Johor Bahru, Malaysia. The deal involves Changi Properties Pte Ltd subscribing for new shares in Global KB Venture Sdn Bhd, with Changi Properties owning 25% of the enlarged share capital. This follows Delong Holdings' expected significant increase in net profit for FY2017 and Q4 2017, while China Environmental Resources Group expects to record an increase in losses due to higher general and administrative expenses.

site_title: The Thai rocker-turned-drinks mogul energising English football
summary: Thai rocker Aed Carabao is set to present the Carabao Cup to either Arsenal or Manchester City in London. His company has invested £30 million in English football, including sponsoring Chelsea's training kit and the EFL cup. The move aims to boost global brand recognition for the energy drink company, which outsells Red Bull in Thailand. Carabao's investment follows a trend of Thai businesses investing in English football, including billionaire Thaksin Shinawatra's purchase of Manchester City and Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha's acquisition of Leicester City.

site_title: Hong Kong Disneyland FY loss doubles to HK$345m
summary: Hong Kong Disneyland reported a net loss of HK$345 million (S$57.91 million) for 2017, doubling from the previous year, due to expansion plans and higher operating costs. Revenue rose 8% to HK$5.1 billion, driven by a 3% increase in visitors to 6.2 million, with international visitors reaching a record high of 1.6 million. The park's Iron Man Experience has become the most popular attraction, but faces stiff competition from other theme park operators, including Ocean Park.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler CEO 2017 compensation was 9.7m euros
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV CEO Sergio Marchionne received a total of 9.7 million euros in pay and benefits for 2017, including a 3.5 million euro salary and a 6.1 million euro bonus. This is a decrease from the 9.91 million euros he received in 2016. Marchionne also received 2.7 million euros in benefits, but his board incentive bonus for 2017 will be paid in 2018.

site_title: China Environmental Resources Group posts profit warning
summary: China Environmental Resources Group issued a profit warning, citing increased losses due to launch of a recycled metal trading business and changes in fair value of biological assets. The company expects to record an increase in losses for the period ended Dec 31, 2017, with finance costs also expected to rise. The warning is attributed to general and administrative expenses, loss on settlement of promissory notes, and decreases in other income and fair value adjustments.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Iras releases consultation papers on e-commerce transactions
summary: Singapore's Inland Revenue Authority (Iras) released consultation papers on taxing e-commerce transactions, following Minister of Finance Heng Swee Keat's announcement to implement GST on imported services from 2020. The papers propose an overseas vendor registration regime for foreign suppliers with a global turnover exceeding S$1 million, and a reverse charge mechanism for business-to-business transactions. Iras accepts submissions until March 20 and will provide a summary of responses by May 31. The aim is to make the tax system fair and resilient in a digital economy.

site_title: Eurozone yields up as ECB speculation mounts
summary: Eurozone government bond yields rose across the board on Wednesday amid speculation over the next European Central Bank (ECB) chief, potentially leading to a more "hawkish" stance on monetary policy. The move comes after Spanish Economy Minister Luis de Guindos was chosen to succeed ECB vice president Vitor Constancio, increasing the likelihood of a candidate from a "core" eurozone country becoming head of the ECB next year. This could push yields higher, negatively impacting European government bonds.

site_title: Koh Bros unit enters into JV with Malaysian parties
summary: Koh Brothers has entered into a joint venture with Malaysian parties, Global Skyline Sdn Bhd and Global KB Venture Sdn Bhd, to purchase a plot of land in Johor Bahru, Malaysia. The plot, valued at RM35.96 million, will be developed into a mixed-use property. Changi Properties, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Koh Brothers, will own 25% of the enlarged share capital of GKV and pay RM7.5 million in relation to the purchase. The deal marks a significant investment by Koh Brothers in Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Japan's Abe sets sights on more foreign workers, higher sales tax
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has ordered his advisory panel to consider increasing foreign workers to address labor shortages, amid the country's aging population and declining birth rate. The government will examine visa requirements and regulations for both high-skilled and low-skilled foreign labor. Abe also asked Cabinet ministers to consider ways to limit fluctuations in consumer spending when the nationwide sales tax is raised to 10% in 2019. The move aims to ensure the country's recent economic growth remains on track.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Tuesday, down 1.33 points to 1,855.99. Volume reached 2.28 billion shares worth RM2.1 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 556 to 409.

site_title: 7 traits key to the resilience of family businesses: Stewardship Asia Centre
summary: A study by the Stewardship Asia Centre found seven key traits for the resilience of family businesses in the Asia-Pacific region. These traits include having a clear corporate purpose, a long-term vision, trustworthiness, adaptability, a socially orientated outlook, and prioritizing social responsibility and employee care. Younger firms (under 50 years old) had different priorities, focusing on creating social impact, using ESG guidelines, and believing in the next generation of leaders. These traits were found to be crucial in overcoming challenges in geopolitics, regulations, and disruptive technologies.

site_title: Britain's Supreme Court hears key case on gig economy worker
summary: Britain's Supreme Court is hearing a key case regarding gig economy workers, potentially affecting major firms such as Uber, Addison Lee, and Deliveroo. The case, involving plumber Gary Smith, centers on whether he should have been considered a worker due to restrictions on his work and minimum hours. A tribunal judge ruled in Smith's favor, and the case now reaches the Supreme Court, which is expected to make a decision within 3-6 months. This decision could impact the business models of thousands of firms operating in the gig economy.

site_title: India's IT firms expect continued growth amid shift to new tech
summary: India's IT firms expect a 7-9% growth in fiscal 2019, driven by automation and digital technologies. The National Association of Software and Services Companies (Nasscom) forecasts a 7.8% revenue increase to $167 billion in the current fiscal year. The industry is adapting to the shift from hourly billing to digital services, with digital revenues expected to grow 1.5-2 times the rest of the business. Despite uncertainties over US visas, Nasscom president R Chandrashekhar remains optimistic, citing a "cautious optimism" outlook for the year.

site_title: Indonesia suspends infrastructure projects after string of accidents
summary: Indonesia suspends the construction of elevated infrastructure projects, including rail and roads, after a series of accidents, including a girder collapse that injured 7 workers and a crane collapse that killed 4 people. The government will evaluate design, equipment, and standard operating procedures to ensure safety. The suspension follows a series of accidents in the past six months, with 14 reported incidents. The move aims to address concerns about the safety of the government's infrastructure upgrade drive, which was launched by President Joko Widodo in 2014 with a $450 billion investment goal.

site_title: IHG puts special payouts on ice as it announces new strategy
summary: InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG) announced a new strategy to speed growth, focusing on business customers and a cheaper fee model. The company reported a 7% rise in 2017 operating profit to $759 million and plans to launch an upscale brand in 2018. IHG aims to target $125 million in annual savings by 2020 and expand its franchise offer in Greater China. The company will also change its operating model for Kimpton Hotels & Restaurants and combine its regional operations. IHG plans to stay independent and has no plans to pay out additional capital to investors in 2018.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: SME reactions
summary: Singapore's 2018 budget has been generally welcomed by small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), with many expressing gratitude for the extension of the Wage Credit Scheme and tax rebates. Companies such as The Benjamin Barker Group, ValueMax Group, and ZWEEC Analytics praised the budget's focus on longer-term strategies to enhance SME capabilities and encourage innovation. The Wage Credit Scheme's extension is seen as helpful, while the corporate income tax rebate is expected to benefit businesses with smaller profits. However, some concerns were raised about the potential impact of the GST increase on retail companies.

site_title: J&J is said to explore sale of US$2b sterilisation division
summary: Johnson & Johnson is exploring the sale of its US$2 billion sterilization products division, working with an adviser to solicit bids from strategic buyers and private equity firms. The asset is drawing interest and bids are due this week. No final decision has been made, and J&J may choose not to divest the division.

site_title: Keppel Reit subsidiary secures S$350m loan facility
summary: Keppel Reit's subsidiary, Keppel REIT Fin. Company, has secured a S$350 million term loan facility secured by RBC Investor Services Trust Singapore. The loan is contingent on the manager remaining in place, with potential for prepayment in the event of a change. This loan is part of a larger S$3.758 million debt, excluding interest and fees, that could be affected if the Keppel REIT group crosses a default under other borrowings.

site_title: Dubai property firm Meraas hires Kuwait sovereign fund executive as CEO
summary: Dubai government-linked property firm Meraas Holding has hired Osama al-Ayoub, a senior executive at Kuwait's sovereign wealth fund, as its chief executive officer. Al-Ayoub has over two decades of experience managing sovereign wealth funds, previously working at Kuwait Investment Authority and Goldman Sachs. His appointment aims to bolster Meraas' expertise in managing large-scale projects and investments.

site_title: Mining giant BHP half-year profit hit by US tax charges
summary: BHP reported a first-half net profit of $2.02 billion, 37% lower than the previous period, due to a US$1.8 billion charge from US tax reforms. Higher commodity prices and a solid operating performance generated $4.9 billion in free cash flow, which was used to reduce debt and increase dividends. Underlying profit was $4.05 billion, a 25% jump from the prior period. The company also made progress on social and environmental recovery programs after the Samarco mine collapse in 2015 and plans to sell its US shale assets.

site_title: China entrepreneur starts US$100m hedge fund with own money
summary: Chinese entrepreneur Qian Yongqiang is launching a $100 million hedge fund, QQQ Capital Fund, with his own money. The long-short fund will focus on education, tourism, and technology stocks, targeting a 15% annual return. Qian, who made his fortune in Chinese education and tech startups, has seeded the fund with $100 million of his own shares, including a long position in Tesla Inc. and a short bet on United Continental Holdings Inc. The fund will use fundamental research and have a concentrated portfolio of up to 30 stocks listed in Hong Kong and the US.

site_title: HSBC more than doubles pre-tax profits to US$17.2b in 2017
summary: HSBC reported a 2.4-fold increase in pre-tax profits to US$17.2 billion in 2017, driven by cost-cutting measures. Adjusted pre-tax profit rose 11% year-over-year to US$21 billion, outpacing revenue growth. The bank attributed the success to its recovery drive.

site_title: Iran teams find wreckage of plane in Zagros mountains
summary: Iranian search teams found the wreckage of a plane that went missing in the Zagros mountains on Sunday, with 66 people on board. The Aseman Airlines flight EP3704 disappeared 45 minutes after taking off from Tehran. After two days of heavy snow and fog, the wreckage was discovered on Tuesday morning with improved visibility. The cause of the disappearance is still unknown.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended Tuesday with losses, falling 0.78% or 241.80 points to close at 30,873.63, following a subdued trading day after the Lunar New Year holiday. Mainland Chinese markets remained closed.

site_title: Delong announces profit guidance for Q4 2017, FY2017
summary: DELONG Holdings announced a "significant increase in net profit" for Q4 2017 and FY2017 due to higher average selling prices amid tighter supplies following production cuts and increased infrastructure and construction activities in the PRC. However, this will be partially offset by a decrease in contributions from a subsidiary that ceased steelmaking operations in August 2017.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks snap three-day winning streak
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 1.01% on Tuesday, snapping a three-day winning streak, as investors locked in profits after recent gains. The Nikkei 225 dropped 224.11 points to 21,925.10, and the Topix index fell 12.70 points to 1,762.45. The losses come as investors wait for the release of US GDP data and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Carabao: Thai rocker turned drinks mogul energising English football
summary: Thai rocker Yuenyong Opakul, known as Carabao, will present the Carabao Cup to either Arsenal or Manchester City at Wembley Stadium. Despite being a relatively unknown figure in English football, Opakul is a legend in Thailand, where he has been active in the music scene for decades. His involvement in the Carabao Cup is a unique fusion of Thai and English football, marking a significant presence of Thai culture in English sports.

site_title: HSBC boss scores bumper farewell pay package as bank profits rise
summary: HSBC's departing CEO Stuart Gulliver received a £6.1 million pay package for his final year, including a £2.1 million bonus, £3.9 million in salary and benefits, and £4 million in shares. The bank's total variable bonus pool rose 8.8% in 2017, amidst criticism of the lender's generous pay practices. Gulliver's departure marks the end of his 37-year tenure with the bank.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.3% down on Tuesday
summary: Singapore stocks ended 0.3% lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index shedding 11.35 points to 3,476.53. About 1.91 billion shares worth S$1.31 billion changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 280 to 180. Top stocks included banks and telecommunications companies.

site_title: Two maritime cadet training programmes to receive S$12.6m in 3-year funding
summary: Singapore's SkillsFuture Singapore, Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore, and Singapore Maritime Officers' Union have allocated S$12.6 million in a three-year funding plan for two maritime cadet training programmes, the Tripartite Nautical and Engineering Training Award (TNTA and TETA). The programmes aim to groom 200 Singaporeans into deck and marine engineer officers, supporting the development of talent in the maritime industry.

site_title: Australia maps steady rate path, wary on mortgage debt
summary: Australia's central bank maintained interest rates at 1.50% for the third consecutive meeting, citing a need for wage growth to push inflation closer to its 2-3% target. Despite a strong labor market and low unemployment rate, wage growth remains stagnant at 2%, constraining consumer spending due to high household debt levels. The RBA forecasts GDP growth to average 3% over the next two years, but rates are expected to remain steady due to the sensitivity of household consumption to interest rate changes.

site_title: Australian shares end flat; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Tuesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index falling 0.700 points to 5,940.90. The decline was driven by losses in financials and materials, offset by gains in energy and IT stocks. The Australian financial index slipped 0.2% and banks were the biggest drag.

site_title: LVMH names Serge Brunschwig as chairman and CEO of Fendi
summary: LVMH has appointed Serge Brunschwig as chairman and CEO of its Fendi fashion house, replacing Pietro Beccari, who will now lead Christian Dior Couture. This internal reshuffle comes after LVMH reported higher annual profits and a favorable start to 2018, driven by a revival in Chinese demand and boosted sales for major brands like Louis Vuitton. Brunschwig will report to Toni Belloni, LVMH Group managing director.

site_title: Uber CEO plans to make fresh push in Japan via taxi partnerships
summary: Uber CEO Dara Khosrowshahi plans to form partnerships with Japanese taxi companies to expand the ride-hailing giant's presence in the country's $16 billion taxi market. This move comes after Uber's failed solo approach, with the company facing heavy operating losses in the US and retreating from international markets. Japan is seen as a potential bright spot for Uber, which is set to go public next year. Khosrowshahi made the announcement at a public event in Tokyo, without specifying any potential partnerships.

site_title: Court rules against S$17.5m collective sale of Beauty World Food Centre
summary: A Singapore court has ruled against a potential S$17.5 million collective sale of the Beauty World Food Centre, citing that the price may not be the best available. The decision was made after a valuation was not conducted before the option to purchase was granted to an interested buyer. The court's ruling does not preclude the trustees from pursuing another collective sale in the future, according to their lawyer. The food centre, which comprises 41 food stalls, had been held off from sale due to objections from four stall owners.

site_title: Israeli visual aid company OrCam valued at US$1b
summary: Israeli visual aid company OrCam has completed a funding round valued at US$1 billion, preparing for a planned initial public offering (IPO). The company raised US$30.4 million by selling 3% of its stake to investors, including Clal Insurance and Meitav Dash. OrCam plans to use the funds to complete its development and prepare for the IPO.

site_title: No-sweat exercise may prolong life for the elderly: study
summary: Researchers found that even brief, light exercise, such as walking the dog or gardening, can lower the risk of death in older men. A study of 1,200 men aged 70-80 years showed that 30 minutes of light-intensity exercise per day reduced the risk of death by 17%, while 30 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise reduced the risk by 33%. The study challenges traditional guidelines that recommend strenuous and longer workouts for older adults, suggesting that all activities, regardless of intensity, are beneficial for longevity.

site_title: Mitsubishi Corp considers raising stake in M'bishi Motors in tender offer
summary: Mitsubishi Corp is considering a tender offer to raise its stake in Mitsubishi Motors, potentially worth US$1.1 billion, to around 20%. The move could double its interest in the carmaker. The plan, reportedly worth 120 billion yen (S$1.45 billion), would involve buying shares held by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd and Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ. No decision has been made, but the move is seen as a strategic investment in the company.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks extend fall; won weakens against dollar
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index fell 1.13% to 2,415.12, marking further losses. The Korean won weakened against the dollar, quoted at 1,073.5 per US dollar on the onshore platform, 0.55% weaker than its previous close. Domestic institutions sold major tech shares, including Samsung Electronics, which reportedly cut OLED panel production. Bond yields rose, and the won was quoted at 1,072.55 per dollar in offshore trading, down 0.56% from the previous day.

site_title: Fashion firms dither over instant shopping on catwalk
summary: Luxury fashion brands are experimenting with "see now, buy now" models, where clothes are available for instant purchase after runway shows. Britain's Mulberry and Burberry have adopted this trend, but it's still not industry standard. The strategy aims to boost sales and cater to young, tech-savvy consumers, but some designers, like Tom Ford, have found it backfires. Challenges include maintaining sales momentum and keeping up with manufacturing cycles. The success of this model depends on brands' business set-ups and ability to balance novelty with manufacturing needs.

site_title: AngloGold posts lower FY earnings on lay-off costs, silicosis provision
summary: AngloGold Ashanti, Africa's top bullion producer, reported lower annual earnings due to restructuring costs and a provision for a US$46 million settlement related to a class-action suit over silicosis. The company attributed the decline to US$71 million in retrenchment provisions and post-tax expenses. This resulted in adjusted headline earnings of US$9 million, down from US$143 million last year. AngloGold also announced an agreement with Ghana's government to redevelop the Obuasi Gold Mine into a modern operation.

site_title: Moncler to unveil monthly 'Genius' series at Milan Fashion Week
summary: Italian outerwear maker Moncler will unveil its monthly "Genius" series at Milan Fashion Week, starting with a show on Tuesday. Eight renowned designers, including Pierpaolo Piccioli and Simone Rocha, will present their collections, with each one released monthly from summer onwards. The strategy aims to disrupt the traditional twice-yearly fashion calendar. The 64-show extravaganza runs until February 26, featuring top Italian fashion brands and designers.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars ease with risk appetite, RBA sticks to script
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars eased on Tuesday as Asian markets declined due to a lack of risk appetite. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) reiterated its stance on unchanged policy, citing weak wage growth and inflation. The RBA minutes showed no urgency to hike interest rates this year, with a possible rate increase in the second half of 2018 or 2019. Treasury yields in the US also nudged back up, and the US budget deficit expanded, potentially pressuring the dollar.

site_title: Archaeologists find fossils, Mayan relics in giant underwater cave in Mexico
summary: Archaeologists in Mexico have discovered fossils and Mayan relics in the world's largest underwater cave, Sac Actun. The cave, connected to Dos Ojos network, features ancient artifacts including a shrine to the Mayan god of commerce, burnt human bones, ceramics, and wall etchings. The relics date back to the Pleistocene epoch (2.6 million to 11,700 years ago) and include remains of extinct animals like gomphotheres, giant sloths, and bears. The discovery is considered significant, with Guillermo de Anda stating that it's unlikely to find another site with such characteristics.

images.alt_text: Archaeologists who have been exploring the world's largest underwater cave - recently discovered in Mexico - presented their findings on Monday, including fossils of giant sloths and an elaborate shrine to the Mayan god of commerce.

site_title: Egyptian firm to buy US$15b in Israeli natural gas
summary: Egyptian firm Dolphinus Holdings has signed two 10-year agreements with Israeli companies to buy $15 billion worth of natural gas from Israel's Tamar and Leviathan offshore gas fields, starting in 2020 and 2019 respectively. The deal aims to strengthen regional ties and boost Israel's economy, with 64 billion cubic meters of gas to be supplied over a decade. The agreements follow a historic peace treaty between Israel and Egypt in 1979 and could pave the way for further gas exports to Egypt.

site_title: GM offers US$2.2b debt for equity swap in return for Seoul's support: sources
summary: General Motors (GM) has offered a US$2.2 billion debt-for-equity swap to its South Korean operation in exchange for financial support and tax benefits from the Seoul government. The proposal aims to keep GM's business in South Korea operating and comes after the company announced plans to shut its Gunsan plant by May and decide on the future of three remaining plants. GM wants Seoul to provide over US$1 billion in fresh capital and designate its factory sites as special foreign investment zones for tax breaks.

images.alt_text: General Motors (GM) has offered to convert debt of around US$2.2 billion owed by its ailing South Korean operation into equity in exchange for financial support and tax benefits from Seoul, four sources with direct knowledge of the matter said.

site_title: Asia: Markets dip as investors look for clues
summary: Asian markets declined on Tuesday, with Tokyo falling 1.2% and Hong Kong edging up 0.57% after the Lunar New Year holiday. Investors sought clues on US interest rates and the pace of rate hikes this year, amid a narrow euro-dollar range and a strong yen. Oil markets showed cautious optimism after Opec's production cuts and Middle East tensions. Asian markets await the release of the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting minutes for fresh insights.

site_title: Samsung Elec to slash OLED panel production as iPhone X demand disappoints - Nikkei
summary: Samsung Electronics plans to slash OLED panel production due to weak demand for the iPhone X, cutting output from 45-50 million to 20 million units in the January-March quarter. This decision follows Apple's decision to halve its iPhone X production target to around 20 million units. The move is expected to negatively impact Samsung Electronics stock and shares of Japanese OLED component makers.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics Co will slash output of its organic light-emitting diode (OLED) panels in response to its customer Apple Inc's decision to cut production of iPhone X amid weak demand, the Nikkei reported on Tuesday.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Tuesday as exporters fall
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday due to a firm yen, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.45% to 22,049.95. Investors sought fresh trading clues amid global market trends. The broader Topix index also declined 0.43%. The yen's strength negatively impacted exporters, contributing to the decline.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Singapore still competitive despite higher taxes, Iswaran says
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry, S Iswaran, stated that the country remains competitive for businesses despite higher taxes and restrictions on foreign workers. The government's budget focused on future tax hikes to boost revenue, with the goal of balancing the financial burden over time. Key tax increases include a goods and services tax levy, property duties, and a carbon tax. Businesses also saw wins, including an extension of the corporate income tax rebate and more support for research and development projects. Iswaran emphasized that Singapore remains open to talent flows and investment.

images.alt_text: The industry transformation maps (ITMs) rolled out by the government are not static plans but need to adjust to changing conditions, Minister for Trade and Industry (Industry) S Iswaran said on Wednesday.

site_title: US dollar steadies but dogged by worries over deficits, inflation
summary: The US dollar inched higher against a basket of major currencies, steadying above a three-year low, but concerns over a ballooning US fiscal deficit and rising inflation continue to weigh on its value. The dollar's index rose 1.2% to 89.347, driven by short-covering in the wake of its recent fall. However, economists warn that US President Trump's tax cuts and spending plans could backfire by overheating the economy and causing inflation. The euro also edged up, while the yen rose 0.2% against the dollar.

images.alt_text: The US dollar inched higher versus a basket of major currencies on Tuesday, clinging above a three-year low set last week, but its outlook was clouded by concerns that the ballooning US fiscal deficit could disrupt the economy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge down after holiday
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.28% at the start of trade on Tuesday, following a muted return after the Lunar New Year holiday. The Hang Seng Index closed at 31,028.93. Mainland Chinese markets remained closed.

site_title: SoftBank is said to work with Nomura on US$19b mobile IPO
summary: SoftBank is working with Nomura on a potential US$19 billion initial public offering (IPO) for its domestic telecom business, with plans to market most of the offering to Japanese individuals. The company is advising on matters such as strategy and corporate governance, and may secure a lucrative global coordinator role for the IPO. Nomura, Japan's largest brokerage, is well-positioned to manage the deal due to its retail franchise. The IPO is part of SoftBank's efforts to separate its activities into investing and telecommunications arms, with a potential listing within a year.

site_title: Japanese 'baby factory' man wins custody of 13 kids born to Thai surrogates
summary: A Bangkok court granted Japanese man Mitsutoki Shigeta "sole parent" rights to 13 children fathered through Thai surrogate mothers. The ruling allows Shigeta to take custody of the children, who were born to Thai surrogates in 2014. The decision comes after Shigeta sued Thailand's Ministry of Social Development and Human Security for custody. The court deemed the children's biological father due to the surrogates signing away their rights, and Shigeta's wealth and preparedness to care for the children in Japan.

images.alt_text: A Bangkok court on Tuesday granted a Japanese man "sole parent" rights to 13 children he fathered through Thai surrogate mothers, a ruling that paves the way for him to take custody of the group.

site_title: Seafood producer Thai Union's FY profit jumps, beats estimate
summary: Thai Union Group Pcl, the world's largest seafood producer, reported a 15% increase in 2017 net profit to 6.02 billion baht, beating analyst estimates. Sales rose 1.6% to 136.5 billion baht, driven by strong sales and higher income from Red Lobster. The company targets a 5% sales growth this year, despite a 30% rise in tuna prices and gross profit margin of 13.3%, which it aims to keep below 15%. Thai Union cited international regulation and raw material costs as potential risks, but expects revenue from emerging markets to grow.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: MAS still expected to tweak monetary policy, say economists
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) is expected to tighten monetary policy despite the government's decision to delay the Goods and Services Tax (GST) hike. Economists, including Standard Chartered Bank and Bank of America Merrill Lynch, predict a 50 basis point increase in the Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate (S$NEER) policy band in April. However, ING Asia economist Prakash Sakpal believes the expansionary fiscal policy will keep the MAS neutral, citing subdued inflation and export performance.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) remains likely to tighten monetary policy despite the government's decision to push back the highly-anticipated Goods and Services Tax (GST) hike, economists said.

site_title: Noble's sea of red shows post-restructuring challenge for trader
summary: Noble Group, a Singapore-based commodity trader, has issued a profit warning, citing US$1.5 billion write-downs and an annual loss approaching US$5 billion. The company expects to post a quarterly loss of US$100 million from its continuing operations, which may impact its debt restructuring efforts. Unless its legacy business can become profitable, a successful restructuring may be a temporary solution to the company's three-year crisis marked by losses and controversy.

site_title: No change to CPF interest rates, HDB mortgage rate for April-June
summary: The Central Provident Fund (CPF) Board and Housing Board announced no changes to interest rates for the Ordinary Account (OA) and Special and Medisave Accounts (SMA) from April 1 to June 30. The OA interest rate remains at 2.5% per year, while the SMA interest rate will be 4% per year. The Retirement Account (RA) interest rate will also be maintained at 4% per year. The concessionary interest rate for HDB mortgage loans will stay at 2.6% per year during this period.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.51 points to 1,855.81. Volume was 80.45 million lots worth RM29.29 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 117 to 47.

site_title: Former cyclone Gita hits New Zealand; emergency declared in southern city
summary: Cyclone Gita, a tropical cyclone that hit Pacific island nations, brought severe weather to New Zealand, prompting a state of emergency in the southern city of Christchurch. Heavy rains caused flooding in Christchurch, prompting evacuations and flight cancellations. The cyclone had previously hit Fiji, Tonga, Samoa, and American Samoa, causing widespread destruction and flooding. New Zealand's Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern declared troops would be deployed to affected areas, and the national Civil Defence office was on standby to assist. The storm caused significant disruptions, with over 40 schools closed and transport authorities shutting a highway.

images.alt_text: New Zealand's national carrier on Tuesday cancelled all flights in and out of the capital, Wellington, and the southern city of Christchurch declared a state of emergency as the remnants of tropical cyclone Gita pummelled the country.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Vibrant economy a key pillar in 'strategic and integrated financial plan', says PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Budget 2018 aims to support a "vibrant and innovative" economy through grants and internationalization efforts. The government will also implement a S$5 carbon tax to reduce emissions and introduce a Silver Generation Office for seniors. With a surplus in 2017, each Singaporean will receive an SG Bonus of S$100 to S$300. The government will increase GST to 9% to maintain fiscal stability.

images.alt_text: This year's Budget is aimed at helping businesses grow to support a "vibrant and innovative" economy, and at the same time give workers a leg up in developing capabilities and skills to adapt to an economy which is increasingly going digital, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said in a Tuesday morning Facebook post.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: 'Well-calibrated', will help lift wages, say Money FM 89.3 panellists
summary: Singapore's 2018 Budget is seen as "well-calibrated" to address productivity and lift wages, according to experts. The Wage Credit Scheme will be extended for three years with reduced government funding, aiming to encourage employers to share productivity gains with staff. The scheme will cost the government S$1.8 billion. Experts also discuss the proposed rise in Goods and Services Tax (GST) and increase in corporate tax rebate, with some predicting a 10-15% GST rate. The budget aims to narrow income disparity and ensure well-being across the board.

images.alt_text: From left to right, Vikram Khanna, associate editor of The Straits Times; Vishnu Varathan, head of economics and strategy at Mizuho Bank; Ajay Sanganeria, tax partner at KPMG; and Toby Koh, managing director at Ademco Security.

site_title: Foxconn is manufacturing a higher value in China
summary: Foxconn, a Taiwanese assembler of Apple's iPhones, plans to spin off a subsidiary in Shanghai, Foxconn Industrial Internet, to manufacture higher-value products such as 8K displays and 5G telecommunications equipment. The move aims to tap into mainland China's capital markets and fund over $4 billion of projects. The spinoff could value the subsidiary at $77.3 billion, surpassing Foxconn's $52 billion market capitalization, and reduce the parent company's net profit and earnings per share. The move is part of Foxconn's efforts to diversify and become a service provider.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks down on foreign selling, won pulls back
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 0.63% to 2,427.41, pressured by foreign selling and weaker regional markets. The won eased 0.16% to 1,069.3 per dollar, while bond yields rose. A US Commerce Department recommendation to slap a tariff on steel imports from 12 countries, including South Korea, is weighing on sentiment. The Kospi is down 1.0% so far this year, and MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index fell 0.15%.

site_title: Singapore shares begin afternoon trading on negative ground; STI at 3,477.22
summary: Singapore shares began afternoon trading on February 20, 2018, in negative territory, with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 3,477.22, down 0.3% or 10.66 points. Losers outnumbered gainers 232 to 129, with 894.9 million shares worth S$650.8 million changing hands. Active stocks included DBS Group Holdings up 0.774% and Singtel down 1.46%.

site_title: Manhattan's Little Italy is very little, and not very Italian
summary: Manhattan's Little Italy has shrunk significantly since its Italian immigrant roots, with a once-thriving neighborhood now dominated by tourist spots and souvenir shops. The recent fire at Angelo's of Mulberry St, the oldest Italian restaurant in the area, has left the space shuttered for months. As rents skyrocket, long-time business owners, such as Gustavo Fernandez and Baby John the Cannoli King, worry about the future of their establishments, with prices increasing and the neighborhood becoming increasingly unaffordable for locals.

site_title: Australia's ANZ reports fall in Q1 impaired assets
summary: ANZ reports a 9.3% decrease in impaired assets to A$2.16 billion in Q1, driven by a reduction in New Zealand division. Total provision charge was A$202 million. The bank's common equity tier 1 ratio was 10.82% at the end of December, exceeding the 10.5% target set by the regulator. Total credit risk-weighted assets rose 0.7% from the previous quarter.

images.alt_text: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd (ANZ) said on Tuesday its impaired assets fell 9.3 per cent in the first quarter, helped by a reduction in impaired assets in its New Zealand division.

site_title: German court could open way to bans on diesel cars
summary: Germany's Federal Administrative Court is set to decide whether to allow local authorities to ban diesel vehicles from certain city areas to reduce air pollution. The decision, which could be a landmark judgment for the "car nation," comes after years of failure to slash emissions. If upheld, it could pave the way for bans on older diesel vehicles, affecting around 70 cities in Germany, including Stuttgart and Duesseldorf. The ruling would send a signal to other tribunals and put pressure on the federal government to take action.

site_title: UK manufacturers say they urgently need clarity on Brexit
summary: UK manufacturers are urging the government to provide clarity on a Brexit transition period, citing confusion about the impact of the country's departure from the European Union. The EEF group's chair, Judith Hackett, said the industry needs a clear plan to avoid new trade barriers and ensure access to EU workers' skills. Hackett also criticized the government's apprenticeship levy, calling it "complex" and "another tax on business" that has led to new apprenticeship collapses. A two-year transition deal is expected to be discussed with EU peers next month.

site_title: Biggest takeaway from Singapore Budget 2018?
summary: The Singapore Budget 2018 was marked by a focus on supporting businesses, with measures such as a 2% increase in the Goods and Services Tax (GST) offset by a 4% increase in the personal income tax band. Experts praised the budget's emphasis on innovation and digitalization, while also noting its lack of significant increases in social welfare spending. Overall, the budget was seen as a balanced effort to promote economic growth while maintaining social stability.

site_title: Japan's Aso: Economy out of asset price deflation doldrums
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Taro Aso stated the country has largely escaped asset price deflation, despite consumer price inflation still below the 2% target. Japanese stocks have reached a 20-year high, and land prices are rising. The government and Bank of Japan will work together to achieve the 2% inflation target. Japan's economy has grown for eight consecutive quarters, but caution among companies hinders price increases. Aso's comments come after the reappointment of BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda for a second term.

images.alt_text: Finance Minister Taro Aso said on Tuesday that Japan has essentially escaped from the economic malaise linked to asset price deflation, although policymakers need to do more.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Tuesday; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index falling 7.03 points, or 0.2%, to 3,480.85. About 49.8 million shares worth S$65 million changed hands. Vallianz rose 7.1%, while Singtel fell 0.9%. The market saw a 78-56 gainers-to-losers ratio.

site_title: Uber Eats driver charged with murder in the shooting death of a customer, police say
summary: An Uber Eats driver, Robert Bivines, 36, has been charged with murder in the shooting death of 30-year-old Ryan Thornton in Atlanta's Buckhead neighborhood. Bivines delivered Thornton's meal and then fired multiple shots, hitting him, before fleeing the scene. Bivines turned himself in and was booked into jail on a murder charge, claiming self-defense after Thornton allegedly became aggressive and threatened him. The incident is under investigation, and Uber is cooperating with authorities.

site_title: Mythical guitar-maker Gibson fighting for survival
summary: Gibson, a renowned guitar maker, is facing financial struggles that threaten its existence. The company, which has been in business since 1894, has a $375 million debt payment due in early August and has brought in a new financial director to try to rescue the company. CEO Henry Juszkiewicz says the company is streamlining its business and expects to achieve "the best financial results" within the next year, with full debt repayment within several years. The company's iconic Les Paul guitar and other products have been played by famous musicians such as John Lennon and Elvis Presley.

site_title: Singapore property stocks fall on higher tax for home purchases
summary: Singapore property stocks fell on Tuesday after the government raised taxes on home purchases of more than S$1 million to 4% from 3%, effective immediately. This move comes as the housing market starts to recover from a four-year slump. UOL Group and City Developments declined over 2% in early trading, while CapitaLand dropped for the first time in a week. Analysts say the tax increase may weigh on sentiment but is unlikely to derail the ongoing home price recovery.

site_title: Asia debt binge to dampen growth but not derail it, Oxford says
summary: Asia's high debt levels, particularly in China, Malaysia, Thailand, and India, may weigh on growth over the next decade but won't derail the region's economy. Oxford Economics forecasts Asia will remain the world's growth engine, with high domestic savings and resilient supply side dynamics serving as buffers. The region's debt levels, expected to remain above 100% of GDP, may lead to spending cutbacks in vulnerable countries, but overall growth is expected to remain strong, with Asia contributing to global growth.

site_title: Japan's Sony to form alliance to build taxi-hailing system: Nikkei
summary: Sony plans a joint venture with Daiwa Motor Transportation and four other domestic taxi firms to develop an AI-based hailing system in Japan, potentially entering the country's taxi and ride-hailing market. The move comes as regulators face pressure to ease rules limiting ride-hailing services. This follows similar plans by SoftBank Group and Didi Chuxing to provide matching services in Japan, and Toyota Motor Corp's stake in JapanTaxi. Uber's new CEO is also expected to meet with regulators in Tokyo.

site_title: Emas Offshore to appeal against Oslo Stock Exchange's decision to delist firm
summary: The Oslo Stock Exchange has decided to delist Emas Offshore, a dual-listed company in Singapore and Norway, due to the company's inability to disclose financial information within the prescribed deadlines. Emas plans to appeal the decision by March 5 and hopes the Oslo Stock Exchange will reverse its decision once all relevant facts are presented. The company's restructuring efforts have made significant progress, with initial expressions of support from secured creditors and a revised term sheet with investors.

site_title: Central American nations to sign trade deal with South Korea
summary: Five Central American nations - Costa Rica, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, and Panama - will sign a free trade deal with South Korea on Wednesday, easing tariffs and barriers on various products. The agreement, after two years of talks, covers 21 chapters and aims to balance market access and sector sensitivities. The pact is expected to be ratified by participating countries' legislatures after signing. The deal builds on 2016 Central American exports of $143 million to South Korea and imports of $1.08 billion.

site_title: Higher home buyer tax seen cooling Singapore's collective sales frenzy
summary: Singapore has raised stamp duty on expensive home purchases to 4% for the portion exceeding S$1 million, aiming to cool the city-state's collective sales frenzy. The move, part of a progressive tax, is expected to prompt developers to become more cautious on "en bloc" deals. Analysts predict the increase will lead to reduced prices and a dampened market, as seen in the recent slowdown in en bloc sales and the stabilisation of the private home market in 2017. This may also influence developers to factor in the additional cost in their redevelopment purchases.

site_title: US probe looking at Kushner foreign business contacts: report
summary: Special counsel Robert Mueller is investigating Jared Kushner's efforts to secure foreign financing for his company during the presidential transition, including contacts with Chinese and Qatari investors. Kushner Companies, backed by Kushner's father, faced financial setbacks after purchasing the 666 Fifth Avenue office building in New York. Mueller's team has spoken with over 50 foreign contacts, including those from China, Qatar, and Russia, but has not yet contacted Kushner Companies or requested interviews with its executives. The investigation focuses on Kushner's conversations to secure financing for the building after the financial setbacks.

site_title: M&A is the best policy for Hong Kong life insurers
summary: Hong Kong's insurance market is experiencing a surge in mergers and acquisitions (M&A) as insurers look to sell units due to stiff competition and limited growth prospects. Axa and MassMutual have already sold their Hong Kong life insurance units, with MetLife reportedly considering a sale valued at over $600 million. Buyers are attracted to Hong Kong licenses, which can be used to sell products to mainland China, despite Beijing's efforts to curb capital outflows. The sale of insurance units could provide a lucrative exit for firms, with some potentially fetching hundreds of millions of US dollars.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Spackman, Halcyon Agri, Serial System
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group sold distribution rights to thriller film "Golden Slumber" to various markets, including Asia, Australia, New Zealand, and the US. Halcyon Agri increased its stake in Ivory Coast rubber producer Tropical Rubber Côte d'Ivoire SA to 70%. Serial System's Hong Kong unit invested in two subsidiaries, resulting in a 2.4% increase in its shares. These developments may impact trading of these companies' shares.

site_title: Australia: Shares dragged by financials; NZ slips
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.3% on Tuesday, weighed down by financials and materials sectors. Super Retail Group plummeted 17.5% to a three-year low after reporting lower half-year net profit. BHP and Rio Tinto also declined, with BHP on track to end lower for a second straight session. Energy stocks were among the few gainers, while New Zealand's benchmark slipped 0.2% as healthcare stocks fell.

site_title: Indonesia foregoing billions of dollars in investment, says US
summary: The US Ambassador to Indonesia, Joseph Donovan, stated that Indonesia is forgoing billions of dollars in investment from American companies, despite the US trying to improve its trade balance with the country. Donovan rejected complaints of increasing American protectionism, saying US tariffs are less than 3% and Indonesia's are around 10%. He urged Indonesia to grant more access to American companies, particularly in the agriculture sector, and encouraged foreign businesses to invest in the country, citing a "Trump effect" where Chinese companies are seeking investment in Indonesia.

site_title: Gold steady as dollar claws back some losses
summary: Gold prices fell 0.11% to $1,346.31 an ounce on Monday, as the dollar recovered from recent losses and US stocks rose, despite concerns about US inflation. The metal rose 2.4% last week, its biggest weekly gain in over five months, amid worries about US inflation and geopolitical uncertainty. Trading is expected to be slower this week due to Lunar New Year celebrations in China.

site_title: Macron's migrant law faces rough ride in parliament
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron's proposed migrant law faces opposition in parliament, with lawmakers and charities criticizing it as repressive. The law aims to cut asylum application waiting times and deport economic migrants more swiftly, but critics say it erodes the rights of vulnerable migrants. Macron's own party is split on the issue, and staff at France's asylum court are set to strike over the law. The government has promised a policy that balances efficiency with humanity, but its proposals are under fire from both sides.

site_title: Spackman's Korean thriller film 'Golden Slumber' sold to international markets
summary: Spackman Entertainment Group has sold distribution rights to its Korean thriller film "Golden Slumber" to various international markets, including Asia, Australia, New Zealand, and the US. The film, starring Gang Dong Won and Han Hyo Joo, will be released in Singapore on March 8 and in US cities on February 23. The estimated production budget is around 10.5 billion Korean won. Following the success of "Golden Slumber," Spackman's subsidiary Zip Cinema is set to release another film, "Sovereign Default," in Korean theatres later this year.

site_title: Revised Trans-Pacific trade pact text to be released on Wednesday: NZ PM
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced the release of the revised Trans-Pacific trade pact text on Wednesday, after the US pulled out of the original deal in 2017. The pact has undergone 20 changes, and the final text will be published by New Zealand. The agreement is set to be signed by 11 nations in Chile in March, with the possibility of more members joining later. Despite initial US opposition, President Donald Trump expressed interest in joining the deal.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Big surplus, lower spending, one-off bonus for Singaporeans
summary: Singapore's FY17 budget surplus reached S$9.61 billion, the largest in absolute value in three decades. The surplus, 2.1% of GDP, was driven by exceptional contributions from statutory boards, including the Monetary Authority of Singapore, which saw a net profit increase of S$28.7 billion. A one-off SG Bonus of S$100 to S$300 for all Singaporeans aged 21 and above will be distributed, costing the government S$700 million. The government will allocate S$5 billion to the Rail Infrastructure Fund and S$2 billion to healthcare support.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Trump backs improved background checks on gun buys
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed support for improved background checks on gun purchases amid pressure for reform following the Florida school shooting that killed 17 people. Trump's stance comes as students who survived the shooting continue to advocate for changes in US gun laws.

site_title: BoE's Carney says Bitcoin has "pretty much failed" as currency
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney stated that Bitcoin has "pretty much failed" as a currency, failing to meet traditional aspects of money such as being a store of value and medium of exchange. However, he noted that the underlying technology may still prove useful for verifying financial transactions in a decentralized manner.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: StarHub CEO Tan Tong Hai purchased 200,000 shares at S$2.59 each, increasing his stake to 754,854 shares, representing a 10.4% discount to the stock's closing price of S$2.86. The deal comes as the stock fell to a six-month low of S$2.56 on Feb 15, a 10.14% plunge. Meanwhile, Indofood Agri Resources invested S$9.6 million for a 50% stake in a Brazilian sugar mill business, with operations expected to begin in 2020.

site_title: Indonesia expects to have more than 5 unicorns by 2019
summary: Indonesia is expected to have more than five unicorns by 2019, driven by its large youth population and growing economy. The country currently has four unicorns, including ride-hailing company Go-Jek and marketplaces Bukalapak and Tokopedia. Minister of Communication and Information Rudiantara predicts the education sector will be the next to produce a unicorn, citing the country's large education budget and existing successful startups in the sector.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Stock analysts expect knee-jerk dip for developers, support for consumer sector
summary: Singapore's Budget 2018 introduced a higher buyer's stamp duty for residential properties, with the top marginal rate increasing to 4% for properties above S$1 million. Analysts predict a knee-jerk dip in developer stocks but remain bullish on the sector, citing marginal impact on demand. The budget also raised the Goods and Services Tax (GST) to 9% from 7% by 2025, benefiting consumer firms like Courts and Sheng Siong. The government's wage credit scheme extension and new rail infrastructure fund are also expected to positively impact consumer and property sectors.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Innovation, R&D to get shot in the arm
summary: Singapore's 2018 budget prioritizes innovation, with measures to support firms across their entire value chain. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced new initiatives to help companies innovate, including buying new solutions, building their own, or partnering others to co-innovate. This move aims to boost innovation and drive growth, with experts welcoming the government's support for SMEs and R&D.

site_title: Pacific Radiance notes: SIAS calls Friday meeting
summary: Singapore's Securities Investors Association (SIAS) will hold an informal meeting for noteholders of Pacific Radiance's S$100 million 4.3% medium-term notes due 2018 on Feb 23. The meeting comes ahead of a Feb 26 vote on resolutions, as the company faces a debt-to-equity conversion proposal that could impact noteholders' seniority protections. SIAS aims to enable informed decisions and understanding of the company's situation amidst the oil and gas crisis. Noteholders must register their interest by Feb 8 to attend the meeting.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: S$700m bonus; delayed pain for long-term gain
summary: Singapore's Budget 2018 announced a S$700m bonus for citizens, utilizing the country's S$9.6 billion surplus. The Goods and Services Tax (GST) hike, initially expected, will now be delayed until between 2021 and 2025. Buyer's stamp duty will also increase. The government aims to cope with rising spending needs, positioning its coffers for long-term gains.

site_title: SRC completes US$500m upgrade on Jurong Island
summary: Singapore Refining Company (SRC) has completed a US$500 million upgrade on its Jurong Island refinery, resulting in increased energy efficiency, higher-quality products, and reduced sulphur oxide emissions. The project, announced in 2014, is SRC's smallest refinery upgrade and is the company's largest investment.

site_title: Indonesia expects to have more than 5 unicorns by 2019
summary: Indonesia is expected to have more than five startups worth at least $1 billion each by 2019, driven by its large youth population and growing economy. The country currently has four unicorns, including ride-hailing company Go-Jek and online marketplaces Bukalapak and Tokopedia. Communications Minister Rudiantara predicts that education and healthcare sectors will be the next to spawn new unicorns, citing the country's large budget allocations for these areas.

site_title: Australia, US, India, Japan in talks on Belt & Road 'alternative'
summary: Australia, the US, India, and Japan are discussing a joint regional infrastructure scheme as an alternative to China's Belt and Road Initiative. The plan aims to counter Beijing's influence and deepen security cooperation among the four countries. The talks are still in their early stages and won't be announced during the upcoming visit of Australian Prime Minister Turnbull to the US. This initiative seeks to provide regional partners with alternatives for infrastructure funding, following China's multibillion-dollar Belt and Road project.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: New Infrastructure Office for projects in Asia
summary: Singapore will establish an Infrastructure Office to help firms tap into Asia's infrastructure opportunities, particularly those created by China's Belt and Road Initiative. The office will bring together local and international firms across the value chain to develop, finance, and execute projects. This move aims to capitalize on emerging infrastructure needs in the region, fostering collaboration and investment in key projects.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Reckitt earnings miss forecast as challenges continue
summary: Reckitt Benckiser, a British consumer goods group, reported higher fourth-quarter sales but missed 2017 profit expectations. Tough trading in developed markets and rising commodity costs are expected to continue, impacting shares. The company forecasts an increase in sales for this year, looking to recover from a turbulent 2017. Despite this, the company's earnings miss and ongoing challenges suggest a tough road ahead for the company.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Building a sustainable foundation
summary: The 2018 Singapore Budget focuses on building a sustainable foundation, emphasizing long-term growth and development. Key initiatives include a new centre to advance sustainable aviation in the Asia-Pacific, increased support for tariff-hit businesses, and a study on Singapore's potential as a global hub for advanced chip packaging. The government also aims to improve employment rates, particularly for graduates, and offers training support for workers who lack the necessary skills. The budget aims to create a resilient and sustainable economy, with a focus on future-proofing workers' careers.

site_title: Global inflation may take a while to stir
summary: Global inflation appears to be rising, according to the US bond market, but data does not confirm this trend. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates three times in 2018, while the European Central Bank will continue to pour on stimulus. Despite robust US growth, core inflation rates remain historically low, with forecasters predicting inflation will remain similar. Analysts recommend calm, citing wage growth forecasts and the risk of a sudden economic downturn.

site_title: Going the distance with e-commerce
summary: Indonesia-focused logistics firm Satsaco Group is poised to turn its fortunes around by expanding into e-commerce logistics. The company has seen a significant increase in revenue from its e-commerce services, which now account for more than half of its 2016 revenue of S$11.3 million. By switching to sea freight, Satsaco is able to reduce costs and increase efficiency, allowing e-commerce firms to reach its Indonesia warehouse within seven days at a third of the previous cost. This move is expected to drive growth in the company's e-commerce segment.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Oil hits 2-week high on share market recovery, Mideast tensions
summary: Oil prices rose to a nearly two-week high on Monday, driven by a global equity market recovery and tensions in the Middle East. Brent crude rose 89 cents to $65.73 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude gained 82 cents to $62.50 a barrel. The increase was tempered by concerns of rising US production, which has offset Opec's efforts to curb production. Tensions in the Middle East, including a warning from Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, also contributed to the price rise.

site_title: Pottering about for a good cause
summary: Sixty United Overseas Bank (UOB) clients and employees participated in a pottery-making workshop at Jalan Bahar Clay Studios on January 19, creating vases, pots, and bowls to raise funds for charity. The proceeds from the auction of a specially commissioned piece by master potter Iskandar Jalil will support initiatives such as artistic development and support in Singapore, benefiting organizations like The Business Times Budding Artists Fund and The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund. The event raised money for various causes during the festive period in 2018.

site_title: Competition panel needs more time to review Uber-Comfort deal
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore has completed an initial review of the proposed alliance between ComfortDelGro Corp and Uber Technologies, but requires up to 120 more days for a more detailed analysis. The Commission will study issues such as entry barriers to the food-delivery services business and the impact on taxi availability. The review aims to ensure the proposed tie-up will not result in shorter waiting times for commuters or fewer job opportunities for drivers. A final decision is expected to be made after the additional analysis period.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Impact of buyer's stamp duty hike to be felt most for big-ticket purchases
summary: Singapore's top marginal buyer's stamp duty (BSD) rate has been increased from 3% to 4%, affecting residential properties exceeding S$1 million. The change, announced in the 2018 budget, aims to collect more revenue and implement a more progressive tax system. While the impact is expected to be mild on property demand, big-ticket purchases, such as luxury condos and land sales, may feel the effects more significantly. Developers may absorb the higher BSD as a bargaining point to keep buyers happy, but some may trim their bids to reflect the increased cost.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Asean's digital economy key to unlocking growth
summary: Asean's digital economy is crucial for unlocking the region's growth potential. Despite free trade agreements in place for over a decade, barriers to seamless corporate and trade payments remain. The Asean Economic Community (AEC) has struggled to eliminate restrictions, with some tariffs and non-tariff barriers persisting. To achieve true integration, Asean needs to boost resilience and innovation, particularly in its digital economy, to overcome these challenges and unlock its full potential.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: S$550m increase in spending on health and social services
summary: Singapore's government has allocated S$550 million to increase spending on health and social services for seniors, with a focus on consolidating services and providing holistic support. The Ministry of Health will take over social care functions, and the Agency for Integrated Care will coordinate services. The Community Networks for Seniors programme will be expanded nationwide by 2020, and the Pioneer Generation Office will be renamed the Silver Generation Office. The government will also increase funding for the Community Silver Trust, Senior's Mobility and Enabling fund, and transport subsidies for eldercare and dialysis centres.

site_title: Why fewer grants can be a good thing for small businesses
summary: A reduction in government grants for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore may be beneficial for their growth and innovation. By no longer relying on monetary incentives, SMEs are forced to become self-sufficient and adapt to new technologies. This shift can lead to improved digital strategies, such as embracing digital payments, building a strong online presence, and utilizing artificial intelligence to streamline operations. By focusing on solid fundamentals and competitive pricing, SMEs can thrive in a digital economy.

site_title: Britain will not have regulation-light economy to undercut rivals: Brexit minister
summary: Britain's Brexit minister David Davis stated that the country will not adopt a "regulation-light" economy to undercut European rivals, dispelling concerns of EU leaders. He emphasized that Britain will maintain high global standards and is committed to workers' rights, financial regulation, and the environment. Davis also sought to reassure business leaders by stating that Britain's plan for life outside the EU is a "race to the top" in global standards, not a regression. This move aims to alleviate fears of a "race to the bottom" in economic regulation.

site_title: Europe: Share rebound loses steam, steel stocks gain on US move
summary: European shares declined 0.6% on Monday, following a 3.3% gain last week, as Reckitt Benckiser missed profit expectations and its shares fell 7.5%. Steel stocks, however, rose after the US outlined proposals for hefty import curbs, with Tenaris and Outokumpu gaining 3% and 4.5% respectively. The Stoxx 600 index needs a 7% rise to return to its 2.5-year peak.

site_title: 'Fake news tycoon' game to combat misinformation
summary: Researchers at Cambridge University and a Dutch media collective have developed an online game to combat misinformation, called "Fake News Tycoon." Players simulate spreading false news, using tactics like fabricating evidence and cultivating Twitter bots, to build immunity against misinformation. A pilot study found that teenagers who played the game showed a decrease in the perceived reliability of fake news compared to a control group. The game aims to "grow 'mental antibodies'" against misinformation, using the psychological theory of inoculation, which suggests that exposure to weak or demystified versions of arguments can make them easier to refute.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: OIP will accelerate innovation and digital transformation
summary: Singapore's Open Innovation Programme (OIP) aims to accelerate innovation and digital transformation among businesses through a virtual crowdsourcing platform. Launched in the second quarter of 2018, the OIP will match digital requirements to solutions created by ICT firms. Business leaders must identify their digital requirements and understand what "going digital" means to them, and the programme should support iterative development and short iteration cycles. The initiative is part of the government's efforts to strengthen Singapore as an air and sea hub and to support the commercialisation of intellectual property.

site_title: Singapore developers seeing some en bloc fatigue?
summary: Singapore developers may be experiencing "en bloc fatigue" due to a recent surge in en bloc sales, which totalled over S$3.1 billion in the first two months of 2018. This could lead to more cautious pricing strategies and lower upward pressure on final selling prices. Analysts believe the slowing momentum is positive for the market, as it indicates lower prices for upcoming projects. Despite this, residential prices are expected to rise more quickly through 2018 due to improving buyer sentiment and economic growth.

site_title: Rare copy of US Declaration resurfaces
summary: A rare copy of the US Declaration of Independence, one of 200 exquisite facsimiles made in the 1820s for founding father James Madison, has resurfaced after being hidden for decades. The document was initially hidden in Virginia during the US Civil War, later stored in a Kentucky closet, and finally found in a Houston office. Its whereabouts were unknown until it was discovered behind a cabinet. The document's past is now public knowledge, shedding light on its history and significance.

site_title: Lego builds foundations in China classrooms as US, Europe sales slow
summary: Lego, a Danish toymaker, is focusing on promoting its use in Chinese classrooms to boost sales, as US and European sales slow. The company is partnering with local education departments and schools to utilize Lego as a tool for developing motor skills, creativity, and attention spans in children. This strategy aims to increase Lego's presence in China and potentially expand its market share in the country.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: S$190m yearly to boost philanthropy
summary: Singapore's government has allocated S$190 million yearly to boost philanthropy through various initiatives. The government will extend a 250% tax cut for donations to Institutions of a Public Character (IPC) for three years, increase the cap for Community Development Councils (CDCs) to S$40 million, and introduce dollar-for-dollar matching on donations to the Empowering for Life Fund (ELF) for five years. These measures aim to encourage more people to give and support charitable causes.

site_title: Govt can't comment on CPIB probe; Keppel board accountable to shareholders: Indranee
summary: Singapore's government cannot comment on the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau's (CPIB) probe into Keppel Offshore & Marine, but will investigate if there's a "good reason" to do so. Senior Minister of State for Law Indranee Rajah stated that the CPIB's work should not be jeopardized and that affected parties should not be prejudiced. Keppel Corp's board remains accountable to shareholders, and the company has asserted a zero-tolerance policy for corruption.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Singapore's carbon tax to start at S$5 a tonne
summary: Singapore has introduced a carbon tax starting at S$5 a tonne, with a planned increase to S$10-15 a tonne by 2030. The tax will be applied uniformly to all sectors and will generate nearly S$1 billion in revenue over five years. The government will provide support through schemes to encourage energy efficiency improvements and reduce emissions. The tax is expected to affect 40 companies, accounting for 80% of Singapore's national greenhouse gas emissions, with a minimal impact on individual households.

site_title: US lawmakers consider new rules for federal oversight of cryptocurrencies
summary: US lawmakers are considering new rules for federal oversight of cryptocurrencies, amid concerns over speculative trading, scams, and potential risks to the financial system. Bipartisan momentum is growing in the Senate and House of Representatives to address the emerging asset class, with some lawmakers advocating for regulation by the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). The recent growth of the virtual currency market has raised alarm bells, with global regulators warning of potential money laundering and terrorist financing risks.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Govt could provide guarantees on borrowings
summary: Singapore's government is considering providing guarantees for long-term borrowings made by statutory boards and government-owned companies to build critical national infrastructure. This move aims to lower financing costs and avoid drawing directly on reserves. The government will set up a Rail Infrastructure Fund with an initial injection of S$5 billion and consider guarantees for infrastructure projects like the Changi Airport Development Fund and the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail. The move is expected to help distribute funding more equitably across generations and deepen Singapore's capital markets.

site_title: Black Panther pounces to box office glory
summary: Disney's Black Panther dominated the North American box office over the Presidents' Day weekend, earning an estimated US$218 million, surpassing predictions and Deadpool's 2016 record. The film, featuring a predominantly black cast led by Chadwick Boseman, took the top spot, while Peter Rabbit and Fifty Shades Freed followed in second and third place, respectively.

site_title: Noble warns of Q4 loss of US$1.7-1.9 billion
summary: NOBLE Group has warned of a net loss of US$1.7-1.9 billion in the fourth quarter and a full-year net loss of US$4.8-5 billion, marking the group's fourth consecutive quarterly net loss. This is attributed to a decline in the company's business operations, resulting in significant financial losses. The warning comes as the global economy faces uncertainty, with rising US tariffs and slowing China's GDP growth adding to market volatility.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: One for the long haul: Ensuring a sustainable fiscal future
summary: Singapore's 2018 Budget, presented by Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat, focuses on long-term fiscal sustainability, with a 2030 horizon. The budget aims to position the country for future challenges and opportunities, including an Asia-centric global order, technological advancements, and an ageing society. Key measures include a two-point GST hike to 9% by 2025, a carbon tax to reduce emissions, and a capability transfer programme to support skills shortages. The budget also outlines plans to strengthen innovative capabilities and find business partners domestically and abroad.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: GST up 2 points to 9% - but only from 2021-2025
summary: Singapore's government has announced plans to increase the Goods and Services Tax (GST) to 9% from 7% in 2021-2025, with the aim of funding future expenditure, particularly in healthcare costs due to an ageing population. The increase will be implemented progressively and will help to offset the rising costs of healthcare, which is expected to overtake education spending within the next decade. The government will also provide additional support to lower-income households through the permanent GST Voucher scheme.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries 'sets stage for spin-off of India energy ops'
summary: Sembcorp Industries has consolidated its thermal and renewable energy units in India under a single entity, paving the way for a potential spin-off. The move involves three shareholding interest transfers, which could raise up to US$500-600 million in an initial public offering (IPO). Analysts view this as a defensive play benefiting from market volatility, with some raising their target prices for the company's earnings.

site_title: Can Singapore banks find formula for growth and dividend?
summary: Singapore banks' strong dividend payouts and growing efficiency are key to sustaining dividend payments. To understand how they are growing efficiently, shareholders should ask three questions: how banks are tackling commoditized business, expanding into growth markets, and efficiently seeking out capital-light businesses. DBS's digital approach has shown promising results, with its digital customers generating higher returns on equity. OCBC is expanding into the Greater Bay Area through its acquisition of Wing Hang, while UOB is applying digital investments across Asean markets. The banks' ability to balance dividend payments and growth will be crucial in the years ahead.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Tackling challenges of next decade
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat reported a surplus of 2.1% of GDP ($9.6 billion) in FY2017/18, exceeding the budgeted surplus of 0.4% of GDP. This is the third year in 27 years where the actual fiscal balance was worse than the projection at Budget time. The country's real GDP grew 3.6% in 2017, and property prices began to rise anew, providing a revenue bonanza for the government.

site_title: Japan exports grow but manufacturers' mood sours as rising yen clouds outlook
summary: Japan's exports grew 12.2% year-over-year in January, but manufacturers' business confidence declined sharply due to the rising yen, which eats into profits and could disrupt an export-led recovery. The Bank of Japan faces a challenge in stimulating the economy as global demand is expected to continue driving Japanese exports, despite the rising yen. The yen's appreciation could lower GDP-based real exports by 0.2% in the first year and 1.1% in the second year.

site_title: Pension funds need to consider divesting from fossil fuels
summary: New York's five public pension funds plan to divest $5 billion from fossil fuel investments over the next five years, amid growing concerns over climate change. The move comes as the city sues the five largest oil companies, including BP, Chevron, and Exxon.
