This decision aims to address the potential harm caused by these investments to the lives of pension fund members.

site_title: SGX to roll out Nifty successor products before August
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) plans to launch successor products to its Nifty-linked derivatives before August 2018, following India's decision to curb trading of offshore derivatives tied to its benchmark indices. The move aims to provide market participants with the same ability to invest in Indian capital markets and maintain risk exposure. The SGX will list the successor products, which will be constructed and priced on mechanisms similar to the India Single Stock Futures, before the six-month notice period for the termination of the licensing agreement expires.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Reit ETFs to enjoy tax transparency
summary: Singapore has announced tax transparency treatment for Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) and exchange traded funds (ETFs) invested in these Reits, effective July 1. This move aims to encourage the growth of the Reits sector and strengthen Singapore's status as a Reits listing hub. The extension of tax transparency treatment to Reit ETFs will ensure parity in tax treatments between investing in individual S-Reits and Reit ETFs.

site_title: Richard Branson unveils hyperloop plans for India
summary: Richard Branson-backed Virgin Hyperloop One has proposed a hyperloop system connecting Pune and Mumbai in 25 minutes, saving three hours. A demonstration track will be built in 2-3 years, with the full route aiming to be completed in 5-7 years. The project could result in $55 billion in socio-economic benefits over 30 years. Branson believes the hyperloop system could have a similar impact on India as trains did in the 20th century, with the Pune-Mumbai route being an ideal first corridor for a national hyperloop network.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Calibrated approach to future-proof Singapore's plan for sustainable future
summary: Singapore's Budget 2018 emphasizes thrift and self-reliance while investing in education, innovation, and social services. The government aims to capitalize on Asia's growth potential and mitigate the impact of an aging population. Key measures include a targeted approach to tax incentives, enhanced schemes for businesses, and increased support for the young and elderly. The budget also allocates surplus funds to cover increased expenditure, demonstrating long-term planning and prudence. The government encourages self-reliance and partnerships to drive growth, while providing assistance when needed.

site_title: Siemens plans Healthineers IPO in first half
summary: Siemens plans to list its medical imaging and diagnostics business Healthineers on the Frankfurt stock exchange in the first half of 2018, offering existing shares in the firm. The initial public offering (IPO) is expected to value the business at approximately 40 billion euros, making it Germany's largest listing since Deutsche Telekom's privatization in 1996. Investment banks Goldman Sachs, Deutsche Bank, and JP Morgan will act as joint global coordinators for the listing. Siemens plans to sell a significant minority stake in Healthineers, with proceeds going to the company, not its Healthineers unit.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Massive surplus in FY17, slight deficit for FY18
summary: Singapore's Budget 2018 revealed a massive surplus of SGD 12.7 billion in FY17, with a slight deficit of SGD 1.7 billion expected in FY18. The government aims to maintain fiscal discipline while supporting key sectors, including aviation and advanced chip packaging. A new centre will be established to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific. Tariff-hit businesses will receive a grant of up to SGD 100,000, and workers are advised to future-proof their careers before potential crises. The government will also provide training support to address workforce shortages.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Bigger handouts under enhanced Proximity Housing Grant
summary: Singapore's enhanced Proximity Housing Grant (PHG) scheme now offers more generous handouts to singles and families buying resale public housing flats. Singles living with parents receive a one-time grant of S$15,000, up from S$10,000, while families buying a resale flat to live with parents or children will receive S$30,000, up from S$20,000. The revised definition of "near" expands to 4km, allowing more families to benefit from the grant. The additional cost of S$80 million will be covered by the government.

site_title: A bright future for Artificial Intelligence throughout Asia
summary: Asia is rapidly emerging as the hub for Artificial Intelligence (AI) innovation, challenging Silicon Valley's dominance. Key players such as Chinese web giant Baidu, Singapore, and India are investing heavily in AI, with Singapore setting up a national AI programme and India designating Trivandrum as a hub for AI innovation. Meanwhile, US giants like Google and Facebook continue to invest in AI technology, but Asia is poised to take the lead in applying AI to solve problems and deliver value for enterprises.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Measures to bolster R&D and IP tax regime are heartening
summary: Singapore's Budget 2018 introduces measures to bolster research and development (R&D) and intellectual property (IP) tax regime. Key measures include a 250% tax deduction on qualifying R&D expenditure, increased tax deductions for IP registration costs and R&D activities, and a new IP tax regime. The enhanced R&D deduction aims to keep pace with regional economies, but may pose challenges for smaller businesses to meet documentary requirements. The budget also tweaks partial and startup tax exemption schemes, reducing benefits but potentially discouraging tax avoidance.

site_title: Escalating costs of sports broadcast rights 'in no one's interest in the long term': Yaacob
summary: Singapore's Minister for Communication and Information Yaacob Ibrahim warned that escalating sports broadcast rights fees may alienate consumers if prices continue to rise, potentially making major international sports events less accessible. The government will not intervene in negotiations, leaving broadcasters to decide on the best course of action. Yaacob cited the 2016 Rio Olympics as an example of rapidly escalating fees, with rights owners seeking to maximize profits, which could lead to broadcasts becoming less accessible to fans, ultimately not in anyone's interest in the long term.

site_title: SoftBank's IPO plan raises doubts on US$33b bond guarantees
summary: SoftBank's plan to list its mobile division, SoftBank Corp, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange is raising concerns about canceling US$33.4 billion in bond guarantees. The company's huge debt and junk bond rating have sparked market worries. SoftBank's bond-default risk is among the highest in Japan, and its total debt has increased 28% in two years. If the mobile unit cancels the guarantees, investors may face losses, but debt holders could still rely on stock investments worth over 17 trillion yen. SoftBank is considering opening talks with bond investors to gain their consent, but negotiations may be challenging due to the large number of individual investors.

site_title: New Indonesia web system blocks 70,000 'negative' sites
summary: Indonesia has blocked over 70,000 "negative" websites, including pornography and extremist content, since launching a new internet filtering system in January. The system, installed at $15 million, uses 44 servers to search and block content deemed harmful. Communications Minister Rudiantara said the system has helped block 72,407 pornography sites and is improving its relationship with social media companies, including Google and Facebook, to combat hate speech and fake news.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Businesses to get S$1.8b boost over next 3 years
summary: Singapore's Wage Credit Scheme (WCS) will be extended for three more years, providing 20% co-funding for wage increases in 2018, 15% in 2019, and 10% in 2020. The scheme aims to encourage employers to share productivity gains with staff and will cost the government approximately S$1.8 billion. The government also announced an enhanced corporate income tax rebate, increasing the rebate rate to 40% of tax payable, capped at S$15,000, and extending it to 2020. These measures aim to help firms cope with near-term cost pressures and boost employment.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Working together for the collective good
summary: Singapore's Budget 2018 focuses on supporting Singaporeans, particularly those in need, to build a stronger and more cohesive society. Key measures include expanding successful programs, such as the Community Networks for Seniors, and introducing new initiatives like the SkillsFuture Earn and Learn Programme. The government aims to provide equal opportunities and deepen its social compact, encouraging businesses and individuals to invest in worthy causes. While inequality is a complex issue, the budget seeks to facilitate access to opportunities and support deep transformation for all Singaporeans, with implementation and effective communication crucial to its success.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Startups unfazed by lower tax exemptions
summary: Singapore's Budget 2018 reduced tax exemptions for startups, but industry players say this move will have little impact on the country's startup ecosystem. The changes, announced by Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat, will affect startups that have just turned profitable, but most startups are not yet profitable. The adjustments aim to support Singapore's tax base needs while providing targeted grants for companies showing potential for growth. The effective corporate tax rate for startups remains low at 4.3%.

site_title: The US$1.8b Indian bank fraud that went unnoticed
summary: A US$1.8 billion bank fraud was uncovered at Punjab National Bank in India, with a lone manager and his subordinate engineering the scheme from 2011 to 2017. The alleged misuse of the SWIFT interbank messaging system and incomplete ledger entries led to the largest fraud in Indian banking history going undetected for seven years. The bank's failure to detect the fraud points to a breakdown in checks and balances, and standard banking practices. The Reserve Bank of India has taken supervisory action, and the case is ongoing, with charges yet to be filed against the individuals involved.

site_title: Frasers Property to buy German, Austrian logistics assets
summary: FRASERS Property is acquiring 22 logistics and light industrial assets in Germany and Austria from Alpha Industrial for 282.5 million euros (S$460.5 million). The portfolio includes 16 completed facilities with a combined 393,800 sq m of gross leasable area, and six development projects with an additional 162,500 sq m. The acquisition will contribute stable income and expand Frasers Property Europe's portfolio to 1.6 billion euros and 1.3 million sq m of GLA. The Alpha Industrial management team will join Frasers Property's European platform, led by Jörg Schröder as chief investment officer.

site_title: UK commercial deals still strong despite Brexit
summary: UK commercial property investment volume has risen 20% year-on-year to £60 billion in 2017, driven by the weaker pound and foreign investment. Asian investors, particularly from Singapore and Malaysia, have dominated London's investment market. Despite Brexit fears, banks are not relocating their headquarters to other European countries, but rather moving back-end functions to Eurozone countries. Experts expect transaction volume to remain significant and demand from overseas investors to continue in 2018, with London remaining a preferred market. However, the removal of capital gains tax exemption on commercial real estate may impact demand from overseas investors.

site_title: Blockchain revolution comes to world of humanitarian aid
summary: Blockchain technology is being explored in humanitarian aid to improve efficiency, transparency, and security. Aid charities are experimenting with blockchain to create virtual identities, track donations, and facilitate transactions between organizations and partners. The technology has the potential to reduce transaction costs, fight corruption, and ensure accurate tracking of aid distribution. However, concerns about governance, data protection, and regulatory frameworks remain. Organizations such as Unicef, the World Food Programme, and Mercy Corps are testing blockchain-based solutions, including virtual identity models and cash transfer programs, to support refugees and vulnerable populations.

site_title: Johor govt plan for levy on Touch n Go cards gets mixed views
summary: The Johor state government plans to impose a RM30 (S$10) surcharge on Touch n Go cards with insufficient balance for vehicles entering Johor from Singapore to ease traffic congestion at the Causeway and Second Link. The plan has drawn mixed views, with some motorists welcoming the move to improve traffic flow, while others express concerns about the impact on first-time drivers. The government is also considering other measures, including removing reload booths and increasing the number of toll booths and security personnel.

site_title: 'End of the boom' for London housing: Rightmove
summary: London's housing market has moved out of its boom phase, with asking prices down 1% from a year ago, according to Rightmove. Prices rose 4.4% on the month, but this is a sixth consecutive fall. Cautious sellers are limiting supply, supporting prices, and the market is not expected to rebound due to Brexit uncertainty and years of inflation pushing ownership out of reach. The mean asking price in London is almost £630,000, more than 20 times average UK earnings.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Jumbo Group's Q1 FY2018 results fell 19.8% due to higher operational expenses and promotions. Analysts lower their FY2018 core earnings estimate by 3.6%. In contrast, Far East Hospitality Trust's results were within expectations, with a continued recovery from a low base. Meanwhile, Singapore's en bloc sales slowed, with most projects sold at reserve prices, indicating developers' caution.

site_title: Asean's digital economy key to unlocking growth
summary: Singapore's chairmanship of Asean aims to boost growth by harnessing the region's digital economy and promoting free trade and regional interdependence. Despite a decade of free trade agreements, seamless corporate and trade payments remain elusive. The region's rapidly growing digital consumption market, with 480 million internet users by 2020, presents a significant opportunity for growth. A single digital market with norms for cybersecurity and low transaction rates could enhance intra-regional trade and business activity, while adopting disruptive technologies could boost profits by $25-45 billion by 2030.

site_title: Electricity retailer Red Dot Power to install 50 EV charging stations
summary: Singapore electricity retailer Red Dot Power plans to install 50 EV charging stations by the end of next year, with a total investment of S$500,000. The charging stations, which will cater to different charging standards, will be installed in phases and will include solar panels and battery storage solutions. The network will also allow EV users to discharge electricity into the power grid. The first phase will include 10 stations, and the second phase will add 40 more stations, providing both fast and slow charging capabilities.

site_title: Dollar edges higher after hitting 3-year low
summary: The US dollar experienced a small rebound, rising 0.1% to 89.215 on the dollar index, after hitting a three-year low. The dollar's decline was attributed to concerns over the US budget deficit and the perceived erosion of its yield advantage. Investors bought back the dollar after a big stock market fall in early February, but analysts warn that the dollar's outlook remains uncertain in the long-term, with inflation worries and concerns about the US fiscal and trade deficits expected to keep the dollar on the defensive.

site_title: Who bears the credit risk in a sharing economy?
summary: The sharing economy's rapid growth has led to a surge in capital investments in assets like homes and vehicles, but has also created a significant credit risk for lenders. Ride-share firms like Uber, Gojek, and Grab have financed their drivers' vehicles, but it's unclear how they're financing these assets. Banks and consumer finance firms are also involved, but may be underestimating the risk. The lack of transparency in financing models and the high risk of default pose significant challenges for lenders, who may be sacrificing credit quality for short-term growth.

site_title: Untangling fake news from climate science
summary: The Singapore government's decision to form a Select Committee to examine online falsehoods is a response to the spread of fake news via social media. Climate change reporting has been plagued by biased and misleading reporting, creating a false dichotomy between "settled science" and "anti-science" denial. The 97% consensus claim on human-caused climate change is misleading, as scientists have varying opinions on the issue. Climate policy should consider economic costs and benefits, and not rely on apocalyptic visions. There is little systematic evidence linking specific weather events to climate change, and the links between the two are tenuous. A sober discussion of costs, benefits, risks, and uncertainty is needed to inform climate policy.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Tax transparency to apply for S-Reit ETFs
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced tax transparency for S-Reit ETFs in the 2018 budget, subjecting distributions made by S-Reits to S-Reit ETFs to the 17% corporate tax rate. This change aims to reduce tax evasion and increase transparency in the sector.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: SG Bonus 'hongbao' of S$100, S$200 or S$300 for all citizens aged 21 and above, depending on income
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a one-off "SG Bonus" for all citizens aged 21 and above, with a "hongbao" of S$300, S$200, or S$100, depending on income. The SG Bonus, costing S$700 million, reflects the government's commitment to sharing the nation's development with citizens.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Top marginal buyer's stamp duty for residential properties up to 4% from 3%
summary: The Singapore government raised the top marginal buyer's stamp duty rates for residential properties from 3% to 4%, applying to properties valued over S$1 million. The change aims to make the tax system more progressive, Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat said. The new rate will take effect immediately, with the goal of discouraging speculative buying and encouraging genuine investment in the market.

site_title: Market continues to recover from sell-off
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.3% to 3,487.88, driven by gains in cyclical counters like Venture, Hi-P International, and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. Real estate investment trusts (Reits) also rose on speculation of tax parity between individual Reits and Reit ETFs. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) rose 4.6% after announcing plans to launch successor products to its Nifty derivatives and a trading link with India's National Stock Exchange. Singtel rebounded 3% to S$3.43 after speculation on its associate Bharti Airtel's plans to list its African unit.

site_title: Budget deficits, bad faith and 'balance'
summary: The US Republican Party has consistently acted in "bad faith," prioritizing the interests of wealthy donors over those of ordinary families and vulnerable populations. This has been evident in their budget initiatives, including a tax cut that benefits the wealthy and a budget deal that exacerbates the budget deficit. The party's actions are not a departure from previous principles, but rather a consistent pattern of deception and manipulation. The media and professional centrists have been complicit in this by failing to acknowledge the party's true agenda and instead focusing on perceived "balance" between parties.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Ministries to spend S$80 billion
summary: Singapore's Budget 2018 projects a small overall deficit of S$0.6 billion, or 0.1% of GDP, with total spending expected to rise S$80 billion, a 8.3% increase. Key areas of spending include transport (up 50% to S$13.7 billion) and home affairs (up to S$6.5 billion). Operating revenue is projected at S$72.7 billion, down 3.3% from FY17. The government expects higher investment returns and a jump in top-ups to endowments and trust funds.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Australia would welcome UK interest in joining Pacific trade group
summary: Australia's Foreign Minister Julie Bishop welcomed Britain's interest in joining the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) regional trade group, following the UK's Brexit decision. Bishop expressed interest in pursuing a bilateral free trade agreement with Britain, prioritizing rights for Australian citizens to work in the UK. The TPP, comprising 11 countries including Japan, Canada, and Mexico, is set to sign its agreement in March, with the US considering a potential re-entry.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to cut at least 250 investment banking jobs
summary: Deutsche Bank is cutting at least 250 investment banking jobs, with the figure potentially rising to 500, in locations including London and the US. The move is part of a broader 9,000 job cut plan, affecting around one in 10 staff. The Corporate and Investment Bank had 17,251 full-time employees at the end of 2017.

site_title: Malaysia: shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 19.04 points to 1,857.32 on Monday, with 2.35 billion shares traded worth RM1.88 billion. Gainers outpaced losers 824-193. This follows a broader market trend, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: Thai Q4 GDP slows but govt maintains 2018 outlook on solid exports
summary: Thailand's economy grew 2.8% in 2017, its strongest growth in five years, driven by solid exports and tourism. Despite a slower-than-expected fourth quarter, the government maintained its 2018 growth outlook, citing resilient exports. The economy's main engine of growth, exports, is expected to continue performing well.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: GST to be hiked to 9% in "earlier" part of 2021-2025 period
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced plans to raise the goods and services tax (GST) by 2 percentage points to 9% in the 2021-2025 period, with the exact timing dependent on economic factors. This move is expected to occur "earlier rather than later" in the period. The decision aims to balance growing expenditures with existing tax buoyancy.

site_title: Serial System unit invests S$135,000 in China automotive components distributor
summary: Serial System, a Singaporean electronic components distributor, has invested S$135,000 in two Chinese subsidiaries, Xuanhong Automotive Electronics and Xuanli Automotive Electronics. Serial Microelectronics (HK), its 91%-owned Hong Kong unit, now holds a 63.7% stake in both companies. The investments aim to expand Serial System's presence in the Chinese automotive market.

site_title: Competition Commission still assessing impact of Uber-ComfortDelGro alliance
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore is assessing the impact of a proposed alliance between ComfortDelGro Corp and Uber Technologies, which involves ComfortDelGro acquiring a 51% stake in Uber's rental car business, Lion City Holdings. The commission has not determined that competition concerns will not arise, and will proceed to a second stage of deliberation. The joint venture aims to centralize fleet management, combining ComfortDelGro's taxis and Lion City Rental's private-hire cars under one system.

site_title: Arsenal announce record shirt deal with Emirates
summary: Arsenal has announced a record £200 million shirt deal with Emirates, extending their partnership by five years until the 2023/2024 season. The deal, which began in 2006, features Emirates branding on Arsenal's shirts and training kits. The agreement makes the partnership the longest-running in the Premier League, rivaling Chelsea's seven-year deal with Chevrolet. The increased investment is expected to help Arsenal compete for trophies and bring more success to the club.

site_title: Australia would welcome UK interest in joining Pacific trade group
summary: Australia's Foreign Minister Julie Bishop welcomes interest from the UK in joining the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) regional trade group after the UK's Brexit. Bishop says Australia would be keen to pursue a bilateral free trade agreement with Britain, prioritizing rights for Australian citizens to work in the UK. The 11-nation TPP is set to sign its agreement in March, with the US potentially rejoining.

site_title: Govt cannot comment on investigations by CPIB but Keppel's board will be held to account: Indranee
summary: The Singapore government cannot comment on the investigation by the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) into Keppel Offshore & Marine, citing the need to avoid jeopardizing investigative work. However, Senior Minister of State for Law Indranee Rajah stated that the company's board will be held accountable for its actions, and Keppel's current management has asserted a zero-tolerance policy for corruption. The company has also reached a US$422 million global settlement with the US, Brazil, and Singapore.

site_title: SRC completes US$500m upgrade on Jurong Island
summary: SRC completes a US$500m upgrade on Jurong Island, featuring a new petrol clean fuels facility and cogeneration plant. The project reduces sulphur oxides emissions by 15% and carbon dioxide emissions by 190,000 tonnes annually. The plant, which employs 34 engineers and technicians, has a capacity of 72 megawatts and eliminates electricity expenses for the refinery. The upgrade bolsters SRC's competitiveness and supports Singapore's goal of a cleaner environment.

site_title: Chicken shortage shuts hundreds of KFC stores in UK
summary: KFC has shut over 700 of its 900 UK stores due to a chicken shortage caused by German delivery supplier DHL, which left the company without fresh chicken. The shortage has forced restaurants to close or offer limited menus, causing inconvenience to customers. KFC has brought a new delivery partner onboard but is working to resolve the issue. The company apologized for the disruption to its customers and assured that it would not compromise on quality. DHL is also working to resolve the problem, according to a statement.

site_title: Trump junior to wine and dine luxury flat buyers in India
summary: US President Donald Trump's son, Donald Trump junior, will host dinner for dozens of luxury flat buyers in Delhi, India, as part of the Trump Towers development. The luxury apartments, priced at 2.5 million rupees (S$50,796) for the downpayment, cater to high-end buyers. Trump's local partners have promised a "lifestyle concierge" and state-of-the-art amenities to the buyers, who have invested in the high-rise apartments on the outskirts of the Indian capital.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: 250% tax cut for donations made to IPC extended to end-2021
summary: Singapore will extend the 250% tax cut for donations to institutions of a public character (IPCs) until December 31, 2021, to foster community giving. This tax cut was initially set to expire in 2019. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the extension during the 2018 Budget speech to encourage Singaporeans to contribute to the community.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: SIAS to hold informal meeting on Friday for Pacific Radiance noteholders
summary: The Securities Investors Association (SIAS) in Singapore will hold an informal meeting for noteholders of Pacific Radiance's S$100 million 4.3% medium-term notes. The meeting aims to enable noteholders to make informed decisions about their noteholdings amid the current oil and gas crisis. This comes after Pacific Radiance began a consent solicitation exercise earlier this month and held informal clinic sessions.

site_title: Indonesia expects to have more than 5 unicorns by 2019
summary: Indonesia expects to have more than 5 startups worth at least $1 billion each by 2019, driven by a youthful population and growing economy. The country currently has 4 unicorns, including ride-hailing company Go-Jek and marketplaces Bukalapak and Tokopedia. Minister of Communication and Information Rudiantara predicts that unicorns will come from the education and healthcare sectors, citing the country's significant investments in these areas. He also aims to facilitate easier listings for unicorns in Indonesia, moving from a regulatory to facilitator role.

site_title: For timing of Aramco IPO, watch future oil price curve
summary: Saudi Arabia is considering the timing of its Aramco initial public offering (IPO) based on future oil prices, with officials aiming for prices around $70 per barrel in one to two years. The government is analyzing the future price curve structure in oil markets to achieve a high valuation for the IPO, which could be the largest in history. The ideal moment for the listing may be some way off, as long-dated prices are currently around $60, and officials may need prices to rise at least $10 higher before proceeding.

site_title: VIDEO/PODCAST: Biggest takeaway from Singapore Budget 2018?
summary: The Business Times' roundtable discussion on the Singapore Budget 2018 featured experts' takeaways. Key points included the focus on innovation and technology, with a $1 billion fund for startups and the introduction of a new research, development and innovation fund. The budget also allocated $1.1 billion for healthcare and $1.1 billion for education. Experts noted the government's emphasis on addressing housing affordability and providing support for low-income families. Overall, the budget aimed to drive economic growth, improve living standards, and enhance Singapore's competitiveness in the region.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Maid levy to go up from April 2019
summary: Singapore's monthly levy for foreign maids will increase to S$300 for the first maid hired and S$450 for the second starting April 1, 2019. The levy for the aged person scheme will also rise from S$265 to S$450 for those aged 65-67, with 80% of employers currently benefiting from the S$60 concessionary rate. The increase aims to ensure the demand for foreign maids is in line with the need, as the number of FDWs in Singapore has increased by 40% over the last 10 years.

site_title: Australia's Domain steady in slipping property market
summary: Australia's Domain Holdings Australia Ltd reported a 12.5% rise in revenue to A$183.3 million for the six months to Dec 24, exceeding expectations. The company, spun off from Fairfax Media Ltd in November, attributed the growth to its successful shift to online operations. Despite a downturn in the property market, Domain expects listings to be "flat to potentially a small decline" in the second half of the year, with a decline in staff costs expected to moderate in the second half. The company declared an interim dividend of 4 cents per share.

site_title: Halcyon Agri increases stake in Ivory Coast rubber producer
summary: Halcyon Agri, a natural rubber supplier, has increased its stake in Ivory Coast rubber producer Tropical Rubber Côte d'Ivoire SA (TRCI) by 18.8 percentage points, now owning 70% of the company. Halcyon paid US$5.1 million in cash for the additional stake, a premium over the unaudited net asset value of TRCI's shares at end-Sep 2017. This move follows a streamlining exercise, where existing holdings in TRCI were transferred from Cameroon Holdings Pte Ltd to SDCI Singapore.

site_title: German property prices up to 35% overvalued: Bundesbank
summary: Germany's real estate prices may be 15-30% overvalued, with some cities like Berlin, Frankfurt, and Munich potentially overvalued by up to 35%, according to the Bundesbank. The central bank warns that this could be a risk for financial stability. Despite this, the European Central Bank notes that property bubbles are limited to key cities and prime commercial real estate, requiring local measures rather than a change in monetary policy. Rent costs increased by 7.25% in Germany last year, with 9.25% growth in the seven biggest cities.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: 'Netflix tax' from 2020 for a new revenue stream
summary: Singapore plans to introduce a "Netflix tax" in 2020, charging a goods and services tax (GST) on imported digital services, making it the first country in South-east Asia to do so. The tax will apply to services sourced from abroad, with businesses and consumers expected to pay 9% GST. The move aims to ensure the country's tax system remains fair and resilient in a digital economy. Businesses selling imported services will need to register with the taxman and collect GST on behalf of the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Strengthening the foundations
summary: The Singapore Budget 2018 aimed to strengthen the country's foundations by investing in key sectors such as healthcare, education, and infrastructure. The budget allocated S$43.7 billion for these initiatives. Meanwhile, global economic trends showed a slowdown in China's GDP growth, while the UK economy contracted for the second consecutive month. The US trade talks also faced challenges, with South Korea's trade chief seeking a 'landing zone' for negotiations. In regional news, Malaysia's May industrial production rose 0.3%, and Asean agreed that the Myanmar election was not a priority.

site_title: Dubai's biggest bank to plan March bid for Sberbank Unit
summary: Dubai's largest bank, Emirates NBD PJSC, plans to submit a bid for Sberbank's Turkish unit, Denizbank AS, in March. The bank is evaluating an offer for the 99.9% stake, valued at up to $4.12 billion. This move is part of Gulf lenders' efforts to expand in Turkey, following previous acquisitions by Qatar National Bank and Commercial Bank of Qatar. Sberbank's CEO, Herman Gref, has stated there's no time frame for an offer, but has acknowledged receiving a "very good offer" for Denizbank due to sanctions on Russia's operations in Turkey.

site_title: Singapore shares close 1.3% up on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.3% to 3,487.88 on Monday, driven by a rebound led by Singtel, which gained 3% to S$3.43. The stock had previously hit a multi-year low of S$3.33. The 1.38 billion shares traded on Monday had an average unit price of S$0.81.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Singapore unveils targeted budget for sustainable growth
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat unveiled the 2018 budget with a total expenditure of S$80 billion, a 8.3% increase from FY2017, and a slight overall budget deficit of S$0.6 billion. The budget aims to achieve 'vibrant and innovative' economic growth without leaving anyone behind, with a focus on laying the foundation for the nation's development in the next decade.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Singapore to inject initial S$5b into new Rail Infrastructure Fund
summary: Singapore will inject an initial S$5 billion into the new Rail Infrastructure Fund in FY2018 to save for major rail lines. The government plans to borrow from Statutory Boards and government-owned companies to spread the cost of infrastructure projects over more years. This move aims to distribute the share of funding more equitably across generations, develop Singapore's bond market, and generate economic returns from completed investments.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: New Infrastructure Office to be set up to tap Asia's growth
summary: Singapore will establish an Infrastructure Office to develop, finance, and execute infrastructure projects, bringing together local and foreign firms across the value chain. The office aims to tap Asia's growth and support infrastructure development and economic growth.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Catalan corporate property market cools on political uncertainty
summary: Global pension funds and investors are holding back on buying office space in Catalonia, Spain, due to fears of a split from Spain and an exodus of business from the region. Investment in office space in Catalonia dropped 63% from October to December, with a 84% decline on a year-ago period. This decrease is attributed to the disputed independence referendum in October and pro-independence parties' efforts to reinstate a sacked leader. The cooling of the corporate property market in Catalonia has resulted in a significant decrease in investment, with 71.5 million euros invested in office space during the period.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a potential 9% Goods and Services Tax (GST) hike in the "earlier" part of Singapore's 2021-2025 budget period, depending on the economy's state. Meanwhile, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and Citigroup forecasts a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI's global equity index. Thaksin Shinawatra remains confident that his daughter's suspension as Thailand's PM in an ethics case will be cleared by the court.

site_title: Bitcoin closes in on $11,000 threshold in fourth day of gains
summary: Bitcoin surged 8.9% to $10,985, its fourth consecutive day of gains, with a 54% increase since February 6. The cryptocurrency outperformed its closest rivals, including Ripple, Ethereum, and Litecoin. S&P Global Ratings warns that digital currencies will struggle for wider acceptance in mainstream finance until regulators gain better control.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Singapore to review Eldershield to provide subsidies for lower-middle income
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the review of ElderShield, an insurance scheme for those with severe disabilities, to provide premium subsidies for lower and middle-income Singaporeans. The government will also pilot a new financial education curriculum at polytechnics and ITEs to boost youth financial literacy. Additionally, existing services for flat purchases and retirement planning will be boosted to make informed decisions at these milestones.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Social and health related services for seniors to come under MOH
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the consolidation of social and health services for seniors under the Ministry of Health (MOH), starting April 2018. The Ministry of Social and Family Development will transfer its functions to MOH, with the Agency for Integrated Care (AIC) coordinating services. The Pioneer Generation Office (PGO) will be merged with AIC, renamed the Silver Generation Office, to support the expansion of the Senior Cluster Network nationwide.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: S$400m set aside to top up funds to support active ageing
summary: Singapore's 2018 budget allocated S$400 million to support active ageing, with S$300 million going to the Community Silver Trust to match donations for long-term care services and S$100 million to the Seniors' Mobility and Enabling Fund for assistive devices and consumables. Additionally, S$150 million will be spent over five years on transport subsidies for eldercare and dialysis centres. These measures aim to improve the quality of life for seniors in Singapore.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Singapore must prepare for 3 major shifts - economy, technology, ageing
summary: Singapore Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that the country must prepare for three major shifts in the coming decade: a shift in global economic weight towards Asia, the emergence of new technologies, and an ageing population. These shifts will interact and bring new opportunities and challenges. To capture future opportunities, Singapore must transform in response to these shifts.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Tax deduction for businesses partnering charities to be extended
summary: Singapore's government has extended the Business and IPC Partnership Scheme for three more years, allowing businesses to enjoy a 250% tax deduction on associated costs incurred when supporting staff volunteering with IPCs. Additionally, the SHARE as One scheme will be extended until fiscal year 2021, providing dollar-for-dollar matching on donations to the Community Chest, with over 440 new companies joining since its launch.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: S$80m more per year to support family members to live with or near each other
summary: Singapore has allocated an additional S$80 million annually to encourage family members to live together or near each other through the Proximity Housing Grant (PHG) for families buying resale flats. The grant amount increased to S$30,000 for those buying a resale flat to live with their parents, and to S$20,000 for those buying near their parents. Singles buying a resale flat to live with their parents will now receive S$15,000.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: S$200m per year to increase support for education
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a budget increase to S$200 million annually for education support, starting from January 2019. The Edusave contributions for primary and secondary school students will be raised to S$230 and S$290, respectively. The government will also update income eligibility criteria for bursaries and increase meal coverage for secondary school students. Additionally, students in special education schools will benefit from these enhancements.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: S$800m over three years set aside for industry grants
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a budget of S$800 million over three years for three industry grants: the productivity solutions grant, the enterprise development grant, and the PACT scheme. The grants offer up to 70% funding support for qualifying costs, aiming to encourage collaboration and growth among enterprises of all sizes. The grants will provide holistic support to companies in various sectors, promoting productivity, internationalization, and innovation.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Overall budget surplus of S$9.6b for FY17; budget deficit of S$0.6b expected for FY18
summary: Singapore's budget surplus for FY2017 reached S$9.6 billion, exceeding the forecasted S$1.9 billion. Contributions from statutory boards, particularly the Monetary Authority of Singapore, and increased stamp duty collections contributed to the surplus. This marks a 2.1% of gross domestic product (GDP), higher than the S$6.12 billion surplus in FY2016. The budget deficit for FY2018 is expected to be S$0.6 billion.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: No carbon tax imposed on petrol, diesel, CNG
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced in the 2018 budget that the government will not impose a carbon tax on petrol, diesel, and compressed natural gas. Excise duties on these fuels will continue, but will be reviewed and adjusted periodically.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: S$250m set aside for sustainability projects
summary: Singapore's Budget 2018 allocates S$250 million for three sustainability projects: the Energy Grid 2.0, a "Closing the Waste Loop" initiative, and the Cities of Tomorrow R&D programme. The projects aim to develop next-generation energy grid architectures, minimize waste environmental impact, and drive innovation in urban development. The government also announced plans for an Energy Grid 2.0, while starting work on the "Closing the Waste Loop" project.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Spending needs to grow in healthcare, infrastructure, security and education
summary: Singapore's 2018 Budget allocates S$10.2 billion for healthcare, S$20 billion for infrastructure, and S$12.8 billion for education. The government aims to increase healthcare spending to 3% of GDP by 2028, surpassing education spending. Infrastructure investments include expanding the rail network and building Changi Airport Terminal 5, Tuas Port, and the KL-Singapore High Speed Rail. The government will also invest in security and education, with a focus on providing a good start for young Singaporeans, while building new healthcare capacity and investing in medical technologies.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: U-Save rebates adjusted to help offset carbon tax impact
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced additional U-Save rebates to offset the impact of a 1% carbon tax on household utilities expenses. Eligible households will receive S$20 more per year from 2019 to 2021, with higher amounts for executive flat dwellers. This adjustment aims to help mitigate the carbon tax's impact on low- to middle-income households.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Ministries' budget growth to be moderated further
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced that the government will further moderate the growth of ministries' block budgets, reducing the allowed growth rate from 0.4 times GDP growth to 0.3 times from fiscal 2019. This is part of a permanent 2% downward adjustment to the budget caps of ministries and organs of state, previously announced in 2017. The move aims to control public spending and maintain fiscal discipline.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Singapore to pilot Capability Transfer Programme
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the pilot of the Capability Transfer Programme (CTP) to address skills gaps in key fields. The CTP will transfer skills from foreign specialists to Singaporean trainers and trainees. The Minister of Manpower will provide more details during the upcoming Committee of Supply debate. This initiative aims to support the development of a more skilled workforce.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Singapore to slap carbon tax from 2019, to collect revenue of S$1b in first 5 years
summary: Singapore will implement a carbon tax of S$5 per tonne of greenhouse gas emissions from 2019 to 2023, targeting major emitters that account for 80% of the country's emissions. The tax is expected to collect nearly S$1 billion in revenue over the first five years, with the rate to be reviewed by 2023 and potentially increased to S$10-15 per tonne by 2030. The government aims to encourage firms to further reduce emissions.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Singapore to build skills in workforce for overseas expansion
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced plans to develop deep skills in the workforce for overseas expansion. The government will launch an Asean Leadership Programme to train business leaders in Southeast Asian markets. Additionally, the Singapore Business Federation and Singapore Management University will collaborate on an initiative for SME leaders. The SkillsFuture Leadership Development Initiative aims to train over 360 Singaporeans, with 180 more in the pipeline. This move aims to enhance the country's competitiveness in the region and support its expansion plans.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Employers of multiple foreign domestic workers to pay higher levy
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced in the 2018 budget that employers hiring multiple foreign domestic workers (FDWs) will face higher levies, starting from April 1, 2019. Those without dependents will pay S$300 for the first FDW and S$450 for the second. However, families caring for young children, the elderly, or disabled family members can continue to pay S$60 per month. The government aims to balance demand for FDWs with the need for domestic workers, following a 40% increase in the number of FDWs in Singapore over the last decade.

site_title: Electricity retailer Red Dot Power to install 50 EV charging stations by end-2019
summary: Singapore electricity retailer Red Dot Power plans to install 50 electric vehicle charging stations by the end of 2019, with an initial 10 stations and 40 more in the following year. The charging stations will cater to different charging standards and allow EV users to discharge electricity into the power grid. The company will also install solar panels and battery storage solutions to complement the charging network and alleviate future stress on the electricity grid. The charging network will be supported by Finnish technology specialist PlugIT.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Additional $145m for tech skills accelerator over next 3 years
summary: Singapore will allocate an additional $145 million over the next three years to support the Tech Skills Accelerator (TeSA), aiming to build and strengthen the digital workforce. TeSA will focus on emerging digital skills such as data analytics, AI, IoT, and cybersecurity, and expand into new sectors like manufacturing and professional services. The initiative aims to enhance employability outcomes for individuals in the IT profession.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Singapore to pilot innovation platform
summary: Singapore's government plans to pilot an Open Innovation Platform (OIP) in the second quarter of 2018, a virtual crowdsourcing platform where companies can list challenges for digital solutions. The platform will match companies with info-communications and technology firms and research institutes to co-develop solutions. The move aims to foster innovation and drive economic growth.

site_title: Singapore shares enter Monday afternoon trade on higher ground, STI at 3,477.59
summary: Singapore shares rose 1% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 3,477.59, driven by gains from Marco Polo Marine and Rowsley. About 677.2 million shares changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 322 to 81. Notable movers included Singtel, Genting Singapore, and PSC. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and amid a global stocks rally, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: Europe: Stocks ahead at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened higher on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.1% to 7,304.62 points, Frankfurt's DAX 30 gaining 0.4% to 12,495.07 points, and Paris' CAC 40 advancing 0.3% to 5,295.33 points. US financial markets remain closed for the President's Day holiday, while Asian markets continue to rally, with Singapore's STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

images.alt_text: Europe's main stock markets edged higher at the start of trading on Monday, in subdued deals amid a long holiday weekend in the United States.

site_title: Forward oil price curve may decide timing of Aramco IPO
summary: Saudi Arabia is carefully analyzing the future price curve of oil to determine the timing of its initial public offering (IPO) of Aramco. Industry sources say the government is looking for oil prices to reach around $70 per barrel in one to two years, a significant increase from current levels, before considering a listing. If prices meet this threshold, it could indicate a listing may be several months away, as Brent oil futures for March 2019 are currently valued at $60.60.

images.alt_text: It's the burning question in the oil industry: when will Saudi Arabia pull the trigger on the Aramco stock market listing?

site_title: For London housing, it's the 'end of the boom,' says Rightmove
summary: London's housing market has moved out of its boom phase, with asking prices down 1% from a year earlier, according to Rightmove. Prices rose 4.4% on the month, but cautious sellers are preventing a glut in the market, supporting prices. The capital's housing market was the worst performing in the UK in 2017, with Brexit uncertainty and inflation pushing ownership out of reach. The mean asking price in London is almost £630,000, and the average time to sell a property is 83 days, up from 73 days a year ago.

images.alt_text: London's property market has moved out of its boom phase and home sellers need to be more realistic about their price demands, according to Rightmove.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Foreign worker levy rates for marine shipyard, process sectors unchanged
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced that foreign worker levy rates for marine shipyard and process sectors will remain unchanged for another year. The rates for work permit holders in these sectors will stay at S$300 and S$400 respectively, and S$450 and S$750 respectively for MYE and Waiver tier R2 workers. This decision was made in the 2018 budget.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Singapore's net investment returns contribution stands at S$15.9b in FY2018
summary: Singapore's net investment returns (NIR) contribution increased to S$15.9 billion in FY2018, surpassing all single taxes. This growth, from S$7 billion in FY2009, is the largest contributor to Singapore's revenues. The NIR framework, introduced in 2008, now includes Temasek Holdings and is managed by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and GIC. The Finance Minister stated that NIR is now the largest contributor to Singapore's revenues, replacing the goods and services tax and corporate and personal income taxes.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Australian shares firm on financials and healthcare stocks; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% to a two-week high, driven by gains in financials and healthcare stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,941.6, with top gainers including financials, healthcare stocks, and GWA Group Ltd, which rose 11.4%. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark slipped 0.1% to 8,115.25, with utilities and consumer discretionary stocks leading the fall.

site_title: Tokyo stocks jump on weak yen, gains on Wall Street
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 1.97% to close at 22,149.21, driven by investor relief over a weaker yen and continued gains on Wall Street. The dollar hovered around 106 yen, rebounding from a low since November 2016. Key stocks such as Toyota and Nintendo surged, while banks like Mizuho and Mitsubishi UFJ also gained. The week was the sixth straight positive close for the Dow, with gains attributed to falling volatility in both Japan and the US.

images.alt_text: Tokyo's benchmark index surged nearly 2 per cent on Monday, buoyed by investor relief over a weaker yen and continued gains on Wall Street last week.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Singapore to streamline productivity grant schemes, support firms to build own innovations
summary: Singapore's 2018 budget introduced a streamlined Productivity Solutions Grant (PSG) to support businesses in adopting technologies and productivity solutions, providing up to 70% funding for qualifying costs. The government also raised tax deductions for intellectual property (IP) registration fees, research and development expenses, and licensing payments, with caps of $100,000 per year for smaller businesses. These measures aim to encourage innovation and support businesses in building their own innovations. The changes took effect from April 1, 2018.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Singapore to inject S$100m for NRF-Temasek IP Commercialisation Vehicle
summary: The Singapore government has allocated S$100 million for the National Research Foundation (NRF)-Temasek IP commercialisation vehicle to support the commercialisation of intellectual property from publicly-funded research. The joint venture will focus on start-ups with cutting-edge science and technology, leveraging NRF's connections with the R&D community and Temasek's global investment networks. This move aims to grow companies that draw on IP from publicly-funded research, fostering innovation and economic growth in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: New R&D programmes for aviation, maritime industries; expansion of robotics scheme
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the launch of the Aviation Transformation Programme (ATP) and Maritime Transformation Programme (MTP) with a combined budget of up to S$500 million. The programs aim to develop R&D for aviation and maritime industries, addressing challenges such as increased air traffic and maritime traffic management. Additionally, the National Robotics Programme will be expanded to encourage robotics use in construction.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Singapore to boost corporate income tax rebate, to cost S$475m over 2yrs
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a corporate income tax (CIT) rebate increase to 40% of tax payable, capped at S$15,000 for 2018, and 20% of tax payable, capped at S$10,000 for 2019. This move is expected to cost S$475 million over two years. The changes aim to boost economic growth and encourage businesses to invest in Singapore.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: ITMs to take a more "cluster-based" approach
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced a "cluster-based" approach for Industry Transformation Maps (ITMs) to create synergies and strengthen industry linkages. The ITMs aim to foster pervasive innovation, build deep capabilities, and forge partnerships to tap new opportunities. This approach will help Singapore compete on value and skills, rather than just costs. The move is part of the government's efforts to transform the economy and drive growth.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Singapore to restrict tax exemption for start-ups, small firms
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced in the 2018 budget that the government will restrict tax exemptions for smaller firms and startups, starting from the 2020 tax year. The tax exemptions will be limited to the first S$200,000 of chargeable income, with 75% exemption for startups' first S$100,000. This move aims to ensure that tax schemes do not hinder firms' development capabilities, while maintaining a low corporate tax rate of 4.3% for startups and 8.1% for older firms.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks up for 4th session; won ends at 3-week high
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose for a fourth consecutive session, reaching its highest in two weeks, driven by improving global sentiment. The won strengthened to a three-week high, closing at 1,067.6 per dollar, while bond yields climbed. The benchmark index was supported by mild gains in US stocks and a 1.97% rise in Japanese stocks.

images.alt_text: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose for a fourth straight session on Monday to reach its highest in two weeks.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Singapore to build innovative economy, improve urban sustainability
summary: Singapore's 2018 budget focuses on building an innovative economy, improving urban sustainability, and fostering a caring society. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the country's strong position as a well-connected nation and its need to prepare for a fiscally sustainable future amidst geopolitical uncertainty. Key areas of focus include developing smart, green, and liveable cities, strengthening social safety nets, and planning for infrastructure development. The budget aims to seize opportunities beyond Singapore using technology and ensure a secure future for the country.

site_title: Chinese and Indian tourists visiting Australia surge to record
summary: Chinese and Indian tourists visiting Australia surged to record levels last year, with 1.4 million Chinese visitors and 302,900 Indian visitors, a 13% and 15% increase respectively. The growth is attributed to the growing middle-class wealth in China and India, drawn by Australia's pristine environment, high-quality restaurants, and hotels. The decline in the Australian dollar has also made the country more attractive to visitors. Local operators are scrambling to refurbish tourism infrastructure to cope with the influx, with calls for direct flights between mainland China and Tasmania.

site_title: Indonesia's Mt Sinabung spews massive smoke-and-ash column
summary: Mount Sinabung in Indonesia erupted Monday, releasing a massive column of ash and smoke 5,000 meters into the air. The volcano, which has been active since 2010, sent debris to local villages and officials distributed face masks to residents. There were no reports of injuries or deaths, but hundreds of houses outside the danger zone were covered in volcanic ash. Officials are monitoring pressure inside the crater to prevent collapses. This is the largest eruption for Sinabung this year, following previous eruptions in 2016 and 2014 that left 23 people dead.

images.alt_text: An Indonesian volcano erupted Monday, sending a massive column of ash and smoke some 5,000 metres into the air, leaving local villages coated in debris and officials scrambling to hand out face masks to residents.

site_title: Asia: Markets edge up as investor sentiment calms
summary: Asian markets edged up on Monday, with Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index gaining 1.33% and the Topix index up 1.58%. The gains followed a positive close on Wall Street, despite ongoing concerns about volatility. Trading was subdued in the region due to the Lunar New Year break. Japanese stocks, including Toyota and Nintendo, rose, while banks such as Mizuho and Mitsubishi UFJ also increased. The positive trend was also seen in European markets, with the Dow notching its best weekly gain since November 2016.

site_title: France's Unibail-Rodamco rules out upping Westfield bid: report
summary: Unibail-Rodamco, Europe's largest commercial landlord, has ruled out increasing its bid for Westfield shopping mall operator in Australia. The initial offer of 0.01844 shares and $2.67 cash valued the company at $24.7 billion. The bid, announced in December, has seen its premium fall to under $9 per Westfield share due to currency volatility and Unibail's declining stock price. Unibail-Rodamco's CEO believes the price is "full and fair" and sufficient for shareholders, but some fund managers see room for the offer to be sweetened. The deal is expected to be completed once Unibail-Rodamco secures 75% Westfield shareholder approval.

site_title: Amplats declares first dividend in 7 years, plans no big projects this year
summary: Anglo American Platinum (Amplats), the world's top platinum producer, declared its first dividend in seven years, with a 900 million rand (S$101.3 million) cash dividend for the second half of 2017. The company's net debt decreased to 1.8 billion rand. Amplats plans no major projects in 2018, citing a tight-fisted investment stance. The move highlights the fragile state of platinum mining in South Africa, where the industry faces soaring costs, depressed prices, and policy uncertainty. Amplats has been shifting to more mechanized mining methods, which appears to be paying off.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOB Kay Hian keeps 'buy' on Sembcorp, sees possible IPO for Indian units
summary: UOB Kay Hian maintains its "buy" call for Sembcorp Industries due to its planned IPO of Indian units, which could raise up to $500 million. The consolidation of thermal and renewable energy businesses under a single entity, Thermal Powertech Corporation India, is seen as preparation for the IPO. The brokerage expects the IPO proceeds to be used to reduce debts and interest expenses, making up 25% of the power plants' annual expense. The target price remains unchanged at S$3.87.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Singapore to spend S$1.8b over next 3 years to extend Wage Credit Scheme
summary: Singapore will spend S$1.8 billion over the next three years to extend the Wage Credit Scheme (WCS) for three more years to 2020, with government co-funding of qualifying wage increases decreasing from 20% to 10%. The WCS supports businesses undergoing transformation efforts and encourages employers to share productivity gains with workers by co-funding wage increases. This extension aims to encourage employers to invest in their employees and promote productivity growth.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Couple who had taken in Florida gunman say he was quirky, naive
summary: A couple in Florida who took in the 19-year-old gunman who killed 17 people at his former high school described him as quirky and naive. Nikolas Cruz lived with James and Kimberly Snead in late November after his mother's death, and they reported no violent tendencies. The FBI had received a tip about Cruz's behavior, but took no action. Cruz had odd habits, was lonely, and seemed depressed, but the Sneads said they had no inkling of his violent tendencies.

site_title: Japan Jan export growth points to continued economic recovery
summary: Japan's exports grew 12.2% in January, the 14th consecutive month, driven by strong shipments to China and Asia. The result exceeded economists' expectations of a 10.3% increase. Semiconductor-related products and hybrid cars led the growth, while a rising yen and US protectionism concerns may impact exports, particularly car shipments. The trade balance turned into a deficit of 943.4 billion yen ($8.87 billion) for the first time in eight months.

images.alt_text: Japan's exports grew in January for a 14th straight month led by brisk shipments of China-bound hybrid cars and electronics parts, a sign solid global demand for Japanese goods continued to underpin growth in the world's third largest economy.

site_title: Abu Dhabi awards oil field stake to Cepsa for US$1.5b
summary: Abu Dhabi National Oil Co (Adnoc) awarded a 20% stake in the Sateh Al Razboot and Umm Lulu fields in the Persian Gulf to Spanish refiner Cepsa for $1.5 billion. The 40-year contract is the second Adnoc has signed for its offshore deposits this month, following a $600 million deal with Indian companies for the Lower Zakum field. Adnoc seeks to expand its partner base and attract international partners to contribute technology, financing, or access to growing markets.

site_title: New Zealand service activity edges down to 55.8 in January: BNZ
summary: New Zealand's services sector activity eased in January, with the Bank of New Zealand-Business NZ's seasonally adjusted performance of services index (PSI) dropping to 55.8 from 56. The sub-index measuring new orders and business fell to 57.6, the first time it had slipped below 60 since April 2017. The decline signals a slowing in GDP growth for the near term, according to BNZ senior economist Craig Ebert.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Enterprise grants to be combined under Enterprise Development Grant
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat announced the combination of the Capability Development Grant and Global Company Partnership grant into the Enterprise Development Grant (EDG) to provide holistic support to local enterprises. The EDG will offer up to 70% funding support for qualifying costs from FY2018 to FY2019. Businesses can apply through the Business Grants Portal, and the government also plans to increase the expense limit for Double Tax Deduction for Internationalisation to S$150,000 per year of assessment, effective from YA2019.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Search for soulmate comes up empty for single Syrian women
summary: Syrian women, particularly those in their 20s and 30s, are facing a severe shortage of eligible bachelors due to the ongoing conflict, with over 340,000 people killed and thousands deployed on the front lines. Many women are forced to pursue alternative paths, such as education, as potential suitors have emigrated, joined the army, or lost their lives. The conflict has also led to a widening of sectarian rifts, making interfaith marriages less likely, and economic instability, with rising inflation and unemployment, making marriage seem like an impossible dream.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.61 points to 1,842.89 on Monday, with 191 gainers outnumbering 29 losers. The index saw a trading volume of 128.32 million lots worth RM48.87 million.

site_title: Singapore property stocks show 'fatigue' with surge in en-blocs
summary: Singapore's property market is experiencing "fatigue" due to the surge in en-bloc sales, which may lead developers to be more cautious with landbanking and pricing strategies. Collective apartment sales in the first two months of 2018 reached S$3.1 billion, almost twice the 2007 peak. Analysts see this slowing momentum as positive, as it reduces upward pressure on final selling prices. Despite this, residential prices are expected to rise more quickly through 2018 as buyer sentiment improves due to a stronger-than-expected economic growth outlook in Singapore.

site_title: US dollar finds footing after steep fall, holds above 3-year lows
summary: The US dollar found stability after a steep fall, holding above a three-year low against a basket of currencies. The dollar index was mostly steady at 89.045, rebounding from a 88.253 low on Friday. Factors weighing on the dollar include concerns over the US budget deficit and perceived erosion of its yield advantage. Despite this, some buyers picked up the dollar at perceived bargains, leading to a modest bounce. Longer-term, the dollar's outlook remains uncertain due to inflation worries and trade deficits.

images.alt_text: The dollar found some traction on Monday following last week's steep fall and managed to hold above a three-year low against a basket of currencies.

site_title: EU single currency reform won't be 'perfect': Moscovici
summary: EU Economic Affairs Commissioner Pierre Moscovici stated that a "perfect" accord on single currency reform is unlikely at an EU summit in June. While progress on crisis management and shock-absorbing measures is expected, Moscovici acknowledged that not all countries agree on the best approach to strengthen the eurozone. The EU is seeking to better weather future economic storms, but a unified solution remains elusive.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries to re-group energy businesses into single entity
summary: Sembcorp Industries is reorganizing its energy businesses into a single entity, Sembcorp Energy India Limited (SEIL). Three shareholding transfers have taken place, with Sembcorp Utilities (SCU) transferring 88% of its stake in Sembcorp Gayatri Power (SGPL) to SEIL, and SCU and its partner Gayatri Energy Ventures (GEVPL) transferring their remaining stakes. The reorganization aims to consolidate the group's thermal and renewable energy businesses under SEIL, with Sembcorp Industries holding 93.7% and GEVPL holding 6.3%. The proposed buyout of Sembcorp Green Infra (SGI) remains on track for completion in this quarter.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.72% to 21,875.57, and the Topix index up 0.82% to 1,751.65. The gains followed investor relief over continued Wall Street gains last week.

site_title: IndoAgri takes 50% of Brazilian sugar mill business for 23.6m real
summary: IndoFood Agri Resources (IndoAgri) has invested 23.6 million Brazilian real (S$9.6 million) to acquire a 50% stake in Canápolis, a Brazilian sugar mill business, for 137.8 million real. The acquisition, completed in December 2017, includes a 1.8 million-tonne annual cane crushing capacity and 6,048 hectares of land. Operations are expected to begin in 2020 following cane planting and rehabilitation. The investment will be funded through bank borrowings.

site_title: SoftBank's IPO plan raises doubts on US$33b bond guarantees
summary: SoftBank's plan to list its Japanese telecom business may lead to the cancellation of its US$33.4 billion bond guarantees, which could worsen the quality of its credit. The mobile division, SoftBank Corp, needs to prove its independence to get listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, and canceling guarantees is a necessary step. The move could raise concerns among investors and limit their gains, with some analysts suggesting SoftBank could offer alternative forms of assurance or negotiate with bondholders to gain their consent.

site_title: OUE Lippo Healthcare adds 2 board members, wraps placement to Itochu
summary: Japanese conglomerate Itochu completes its acquisition of 562.5 million new shares in OUE Lippo Healthcare, becoming a strategic shareholder with a 25.3% stake. Singapore-listed OUE retains its majority stake of 64.4%. The new shares were priced at 14 Singapore cents apiece following a private placement.

site_title: SGX to roll out Nifty successor products before August
summary: SGX to list successor products to its Nifty family of derivative products before August 2018, providing market participants with the same ability to invest in Indian capital markets. The move aims to transition market participants to these products before the expiry of SGX's licence agreement with the National Stock Exchange of India (NSE).

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on financials; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% on Monday, driven by gains in financial and industrial sectors, despite losses in energy stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5,928.8, with top gainers including Infigen Energy and GWA Group. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index slipped 0.1% due to falls in consumer discretionary and healthcare stocks.

site_title: Wynn bids high-life perks goodbye as casino cuts ties
summary: Billionaire Steve Wynn won't receive a golden parachute from Wynn Resorts Ltd due to his resignation amid sex allegations. He must leave his leased villa by June 1 and stop company-paid administrative assistance by May 31. His health benefits will end on December 31.

site_title: Plan by Johor govt to impose surcharge for Touch n Go cards from Johor to Singapore gets mixed response
summary: The Johor state government proposes imposing a S$10 or RM30 surcharge on Touch n Go cards with insufficient balance for vehicles entering Johor from Singapore to ease traffic congestion at the Causeway and Second Link. The plan has received mixed responses, with some motorists welcoming the move to improve traffic flow, while others express concerns about the impact on first-time drivers. The government is also considering other measures, such as removing reload booths and increasing toll booths, to address the issue.

site_title: Noble gets in-principle nod for 3-year US$700m loan; warns of Q4, full-year 2017 loss
summary: NOBLE Group reached an in-principle agreement with its senior creditors for a three-year, $700 million trade finance facility. The agreement, facilitated by ING, represents 51% of Noble's existing senior debt. The company warned of potential Q4 and full-year 2017 losses as restructuring discussions with stakeholders continue. A Restructuring Support Agreement (RSA) is expected to be launched, outlining the basis for a debt restructuring.

site_title: Thai Q4 GDP grows less than forecast, but exports to stay buoyant
summary: Thai Q4 GDP grew 0.5% in the October-December quarter, less than the 0.7% forecast, due to a decline in government investment. However, exports and tourism remain buoyant. The economy grew 4% in the December quarter, lower than expected, and 3.9% in 2017, the fastest since 2012. The National Economic and Social Development Board maintained its 2018 GDP growth forecast of 3.6-4.6%.

site_title: The US$1.8b Indian bank fraud that went unnoticed
summary: A US$1.8 billion bank fraud was uncovered at the Punjab National Bank branch in south Mumbai, India. The fraud, which occurred from 2011 to 2017, was engineered by a lone manager and his subordinate, involving unauthorized transactions. The case has shaken confidence in India's state banking sector, which accounts for 70% of the country's banking assets. Authorities are investigating the matter, but no further details are available.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks, won at multi-week high as trading resumes after holiday
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.62% to a near two-week high on Monday, while the won jumped to its highest in three weeks. The index was supported by improved sentiment after a recent market rout. Steel shares were weak due to US plans to impose tougher tariffs on imported steel products. The won was quoted at 1,068.4 per dollar, up 0.82% from its previous close.

site_title: StarHub CEO buys S$518,000 worth of shares as stock falls to 6-month low
summary: StarHub CEO Tan Tong Hai purchased over 200,000 shares worth S$518,000 at S$2.59 apiece, a 10.4% discount from the closing price of S$2.86 on Feb 14. This comes as the stock hit a six-month low of S$2.56, a 10.14% decline, on Feb 15. The purchase is seen as a vote of confidence in the company amidst market volatility.

site_title: Iran postpones hunt for plane lost in mountain blizzard
summary: Iran has postponed its search for a plane that disappeared with 66 people onboard in the Zagros mountains due to severe blizzard conditions. The Aseman Airlines flight EP3704 vanished 45 minutes after taking off from Tehran, and despite 45 teams and helicopters being deployed, no wreckage has been found. The search operation has been halted until morning, with five helicopters on standby to resume the search if weather conditions improve. The incident is the third disaster to hit Iran in recent months, following an earthquake and an oil tanker collision.

site_title: Sentiment positive as inflation picks up
summary: Global markets remain positive despite inflation concerns, with oil prices recovering to around $65 per barrel. Investors are waiting for the "dust to settle" before making moves, with sentiment not turning sour despite a steep correction in Chinese equities. Asian stocks are expected to see gains, particularly in Taiwan's Internet of Things and artificial intelligence sectors. Meanwhile, inflation is expected to rise, with the US 10-year yield reaching 2.9% and the Singapore Budget set to be delivered, which may include tax hikes and a potential e-commerce tax.

site_title: Stocks to watch: StarHub, Noble, SGX, Sembcorp Industries, IndoAgri
summary: StarHub CEO Tan Tong Hai bought over half a million shares, reducing the stock's value to a six-month low of S$2.56. Noble Group reached an in-principle agreement with senior creditors for a $700 million trade finance facility. SGX listed successor products to its Nifty derivatives before August 2018. Sembcorp Industries consolidated its thermal and renewable energy businesses under a single entity. IndoAgri invested $9.6 million in a Brazilian sugar mill business, taking a 50% stake.

site_title: Frasers Property to acquire German, Austrian logistics assets for 285.2m euros
summary: Frasers Property is set to acquire 22 logistics and light industrial assets in Germany and Austria for 282.5 million euros (S$285.2 million). The assets include 16 completed facilities with a combined gross leasable area of 393,800 square meters, and six development projects with an additional 162,500 square meters.
