The acquisition is expected to contribute stable, recurring income to Frasers Property Europe.

site_title: Earnings season sweetened by dividend highs
summary: Corporate earnings season has started with a positive tone, with many companies meeting or exceeding forecasts. DBS Group, the largest bank in Southeast Asia, reported record profits and proposed a significant dividend payout increase, with plans to pay S$1.20 per share annually. This trend is expected to continue, but market watchers warn that the low-hanging fruit has been picked, and future growth may be more challenging. Despite this, the market remains optimistic, with stocks continuing to rally.

site_title: PSA 'to launch tender for driverless vehicles this year'
summary: PSA Singapore plans to launch a tender for the supply of automated guided vehicles (AGVs) or driverless vehicles for its next-generation Tuas mega port by this year. The first fleet of AGVs have been successfully deployed in a trial at Pasir Panjang terminals for over a year, and industry expectations are high for the tender's imminent rollout.

site_title: Abu Dhabi awards Spanish firm stake in offshore oil concession
summary: Abu Dhabi's state-owned oil company, Adnoc, awarded a 20% stake in a concession of two offshore oil fields to Spanish firm Cepsa in a $1.5 billion deal. The 40-year agreement aims to double production at the emirate's offshore fields to 215,000 barrels per day, with Adnoc retaining a 60% stake. The deal is part of a broader effort to boost production and diversify revenue streams for the oil company.

site_title: Goldman sees US interest cost surge on rising yields, deficit
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts a surge in US interest costs due to rising bond yields and a growing national debt. The average maturity of US debt is nearly six years, causing rising yields to take time to impact the interest rate paid by the Treasury. If current fiscal policies continue, the US net interest expense relative to GDP will exceed levels seen in the 1980s by 2027, with debt-to-GDP potentially exceeding 100%. This could lead to a worse fiscal position than the 1940s or 1990s, with elevated interest costs causing debt ratios to continue deteriorating.

site_title: Anti-corruption officers arrest Latvian central bank governor
summary: Latvian central bank governor Ilmars Rimsevics was arrested by anti-corruption authorities on Saturday and questioned for seven hours before being taken to another location. He was detained at his residence and offices at the Bank of Latvia. Authorities assured there is "no sign of danger" to the financial system, and Rimsevics' arrest was not related to the bank's operations. The governor was appointed in 2001 and had been under scrutiny for potential corruption. The reason for his arrest has not been disclosed.

site_title: Amazon's Jeff Bezos turning his boundless ambition to healthcare
summary: Amazon founder Jeff Bezos is shifting his company's focus to healthcare, aiming to disrupt the US healthcare system with lower-priced alternatives and frictionless services. Amazon has partnered with Warren Buffett and Jamie Dimon to provide a healthcare system for employees and plans to become a supplier of medical equipment for hospitals. Bezos faces the challenge of taming skyrocketing healthcare costs and has identified the US healthcare system as ripe for reform, with analysts predicting a potential game-changer in the industry.

site_title: Proxy advisory firm ISS says Qualcomm should negotiate sale to Broadcom
summary: Proxy advisory firm ISS recommends Qualcomm shareholders vote for four out of six Broadcom nominees at Qualcomm's shareholder meeting on March 6, suggesting a negotiated deal could deliver value. Qualcomm rejected Broadcom's initial US$70 per share offer, but the company raised its bid to US$82 per share and offered concessions. ISS believes Broadcom's offer is a reasonable starting point for negotiations, but notes that Qualcomm's standalone value may be superior in the short term. The recommendation aims to find a middle ground between Qualcomm's resistance to the deal and its desire to secure a better offer.

site_title: Japan's Mizuho sees pickup in US M&A lending after tax cut
summary: Japan's Mizuho Financial Group expects a pickup in US mergers and acquisitions (M&A) lending after a recent corporate tax cut, with major banks increasing emphasis on overseas lending to boost growth. The bank's head of overseas business, Akira Sugano, stated that companies will accelerate acquisitions due to the tax cut, and Mizuho is already working with US clients on billion-dollar deals. This trend is part of a broader shift by Japanese banks to focus on M&A lending in the US market, driven by low domestic interest rates.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Monday, advancing 0.4% or 15.08 points to 3,458.59. The Straits Times Index saw 64.3 million shares worth S$99.7 million change hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 123 to 40.

site_title: Oil extends gains, but upside limited as dollar edges up
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, with US West Texas Intermediate crude up 5 cents to $61.73 a barrel and London Brent crude up 15 cents to $64.99 a barrel. The increases were limited due to the dollar recapturing some ground after touching its lowest level in over three years. The US oil rig count rose to 798, its highest since April 2015, despite OPEC's efforts to curb production. Speculators cut their bullish wagers on oil futures, citing concerns of oversupply, and a new tax credit for oil producers will help boost output.

site_title: Sex-scandal takes toll on Australia government in poll
summary: The Australian government's poll ratings have fallen to 47-53% in favor of Labor after Deputy Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce's extramarital affair with a former aide. The scandal has damaged Joyce's credibility as a family man and led to calls for his resignation as Nationals leader. Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's approval ratings have also declined, with his lead over Labor leader Bill Shorten halved to 7 points. The issue has distracted from the government's policy agenda and threatens to fracture the ruling coalition. Joyce is expected to face a party room meeting when parliament returns in a week.

site_title: South Africa widens corruption hunt for Zuma allies to India, China
summary: South Africa has expanded a corruption probe into allies of ex-president Jacob Zuma, targeting individuals in India, China, and Dubai. Police Minister Fikile Mbalula announced the move days after issuing an arrest warrant for Ajay Gupta, a brother of the Gupta business family, who is accused of corruption. The expanded probe aims to bring Zuma's associates to justice, following his forced removal from power. The investigation is ongoing, with those targeted currently out of the country.

site_title: Florida students to march on Washington in call for gun reform
summary: Florida students who survived the Parkland school shooting announced plans to march on Washington to "shame" politicians into reforming gun laws. The "March for our Lives" will take place on March 24, with sister rallies planned across the country. Students, including Emma Gonzalez and Cameron Kasky, vowed to make the shooting a turning point in the country's debate on gun control, singling out politicians who take money from the National Rifle Association. The event aims to push for tighter controls and a "new normal" where politicians who accept NRA funding face shame.

site_title: Biggest shareholder in Australia's Myer seeking support to oust the board
summary: Australian retail veteran Solomon Lew, owner of 10.8% of Myer Holdings, is seeking support to oust the entire board, accusing the company of lying to investors about its turnaround plan. Lew claims Myer's current CEO and chairman are ineffective, citing declining sales and profits, and an artificially-inflated balance sheet. Lew's company, Premier Investments, plans to request a meeting to remove the board, requiring support from more than 50% of shareholders, and will formally notify the board if it gains sufficient backing.

site_title: Trump name carries presidential cachet in India
summary: US President Donald Trump's eldest son, Donald Trump Jr, is set to visit India on a sales trip to promote luxury residential units worth over $1 billion, built by the Trump Organization and local partners. The visit comes as President Trump strengthens ties with India, with both leaders discussing greater military cooperation and trade. The younger Mr Trump's trip has raised concerns about potential conflicts of interest, but he claims to have cultivated relationships in India over nearly a decade. The visit is expected to generate buzz and drive sales for the Trump-branded projects in cities such as Gurgaon, Kolkata, and Mumbai.

site_title: Audi chairman rubbishes report that CEO Stadler to be removed
summary: Audi Chairman Matthias Mueller has denied a report that CEO Rupert Stadler is set to be removed, amid the ongoing Dieselgate scandal. Mueller urged workers to ignore the media speculation, citing Stadler's "proven leadership" in overcoming the crisis. The report, published in German tabloid Bild, claimed Stadler would leave in April and take on a new role as VW group finance chief. However, sources close to Audi and VW say there has been no discussion about replacing Stadler, and VW Chairman Hans Dieter Poetsch has expressed no reason to question Mueller's position.

site_title: Seeking post-Brexit unity, EU leaders find more fights
summary: EU leaders face challenges in post-Brexit unity as they discuss budget and commission chief succession. French President Emmanuel Macron's push for a reformed Europe clashes with European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker's federalist vision. The EU may need to increase its budget to fill the Brexit gap, but member states are divided on the issue. The EU's attempts to overcome Brexit's shock are hindered by classic problems of money and sovereignty. The summit aims to lay out options for commission chief succession and the EU's post-Brexit budget.

site_title: Gilead wins reversal of US$2.54b hepatitis C drug patent verdict
summary: A US federal judge in Delaware has overturned a record US$2.54 billion patent verdict against Gilead Sciences Inc for its hepatitis C drugs Sovaldi and Harvoni, ruling that a patent held by Merck & Co Inc was invalid due to a lack of disclosure of how to make the treatment. The verdict was the largest ever in a US patent case, but Gilead had always believed the patent was invalid, and the judge confirmed this opinion. Merck plans to appeal the decision.

site_title: Spanish cheesemakers defend Manchego from Mexican 'copy'
summary: Spanish cheesemakers are defending their Manchego cheese from Mexican producers, who they claim are engaging in "crude plagiarism" by using the name for their own cow's milk cheese. Manchego is an EU-protected designation of origin product, made from ewe's milk and aged for at least a month, whereas the Mexican version is made from cow's milk within seven days. The dispute has become a point of contention in trade talks between the EU and Mexico, with Spanish producers arguing that the name is essential to their livelihoods and the EU seeking exclusive rights to the "Manchego" name.

site_title: Giving a tech lifeline - for a lifetime
summary: Informatics Education, a global education group, is extending its expertise in IT and business education to those in need, including individuals with physical disabilities, women from low-income families, and students from primary and secondary schools. The company has partnered with organizations such as REACH Community Social Services and SGEnable to offer free IT courses and bookkeeping classes. Informatics also sponsors volunteer training courses for Junior Achievement Singapore and has a CSR policy allowing staff to take leave for community activities. This initiative aims to equip individuals with skills to succeed in the future workplace.

site_title: GCBs remain a draw for Singaporeans
summary: Notable transactions in Singapore's Good Class Bungalow (GCB) Areas include Simon Israel buying a bungalow in Binjai Park for S$18.26 million and Edlan Chua purchasing a two-storey bungalow in the Swiss Club Road GCB Area for S$14.5 million. Analysts, such as William Wong, expect a 20% increase in GCB transactions this year, driven by strong demand and a more upbeat mood about Singapore's economic performance. Last year's 41 deals totaling S$867 million reached a five-year high, with prices declining 17% from their peak before increasing by up to 5% in the second half of 2017.

site_title: Who should the core provisions of the Employment Act protect?
summary: Singapore's Employment Act, enacted in 1968, aims to promote worker productivity and economic expansion. However, the Act's core provisions, protecting public holiday and sick leave entitlements, timely payment of salary, and redress for unfair dismissal, currently only apply to employees earning up to S$4,500 per month. The Ministry of Manpower is reviewing the Act to extend these protections to all Professionals, Managers, and Executives (PMEs), regardless of salary. This change is driven by the increasing proportion of PMEs in the workforce and the need for greater job security in the digital economy.

site_title: PSA launches new container terminal in Maharashtra, set to be India's biggest
summary: PSA International launched its $1.2 billion Bharat Mumbai Container Terminals (BMCT) in Maharashtra, India, becoming the country's largest container terminal. The terminal, set to be completed by 2022, will have an annual capacity of 4.8 million TEUs. India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi officiated the opening remotely. The terminal is expected to support India's 'Vision 2022' and elevate Mumbai as an international hub for global trade and commerce, creating jobs and facilitating trade growth.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Economists expect bumper surplus
summary: Singapore's strengthening economy has boosted government coffers, with economists predicting a larger-than-expected budget surplus for the financial year ending March. UOB economist Francis Tan expects an overall surplus of S$3.1 billion, while DBS economist Irvin Seah predicts an even larger surplus of S$5 billion or 1.2% of GDP. The government's revenue is expected to rise due to higher corporate income tax receipts and stamp duties, although revenue from the goods and services tax and personal income taxes may not meet expectations.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Hue and cry for designer Bailey at his Burberry swansong
summary: Christopher Bailey, Burberry's star designer, bid farewell to the British brand with a colorful show during London Fashion Week, featuring rainbow checks and bold designs. Bailey leaves after 17 years, helping propel the brand to global prominence. He will step down from the board in March and lend support to the brand until 2018, while exploring other projects. The show ended with a standing ovation and a multi-color lighting spectacular, as Bailey praised Burberry's future prospects and expressed excitement for his next endeavors.

site_title: US cities use ride-hailing fees to fix roads
summary: US cities are implementing ride-hailing fees to fund transportation and infrastructure improvements. Fees range from 15 cents to over 1%, generating millions in revenue. Chicago, Philadelphia, and Massachusetts have seen significant revenue from ride-hailing fees, with Chicago collecting nearly $39 million in 2016. New York is considering a congestion pricing plan, with proposed fees of $2 to $5 per ride, expected to generate up to $605 million annually. Advocates argue ride-hailing companies should pay for using public streets and resources, while some drivers and passengers argue they are unfairly targeted.

site_title: MindChamps to enter China with joint venture partner
summary: MindChamps, a Singapore-based preschool operator, has signed a joint venture agreement with China First Capital Group to enter China's preschool market. The joint venture aims to raise US$200 million and establish preschool centers under the MindChamps brand. MindChamps will own 49% of the master franchisee, with CFCG holding the remainder. The venture is expected to capitalize on China's growing preschool education market, valued at 380 billion yuan in 2016 and expected to exceed 540 billion yuan by 2020.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Will exposure drive change in N Korea?
summary: North Korean athletes and officials have engaged with the outside world during the Pyeongchang Olympics, sparking questions about whether exposure to global culture and knowledge could drive change in the isolated country. Despite being subjected to endless scrutiny, North Koreans seemed to enjoy Western music and food, and some even formed friendships with South Korean athletes. Analysts and officials wonder if this exposure could eventually alter the preferences of North Koreans, paving the way for regime change. However, many experts believe that the regime's nuclear ambitions and repressive nature make significant change unlikely, with some predicting a gradual, evolutionary shift rather than a revolutionary one.

site_title: Few wealthy investors increased holdings during meltdown, says UBS survey
summary: A UBS survey of over 1,000 high-net-worth individuals and business owners found that only 10-15% of investors took advantage of the recent market pullback to boost their equity allocations. Despite this, 68% believe it's a good time to buy equities, while 80% keep their cash holdings unchanged. 86% of investors believe economic fundamentals are strong, but optimism about the economic outlook has dropped to 58% from 72%. The survey also found that business owners are tempering their actions, with 24% planning to increase hiring and 22% planning to invest more in their business.

site_title: Covert Russians 'liked' Facebook most to sow discord across US
summary: The US Justice Department has charged 13 Russians and three companies with executing a scheme to subvert the 2016 US presidential election and support Donald Trump's campaign. The indictment reveals that the Russians repeatedly used Facebook and Instagram to sow discord, creating groups, distributing divisive ads, and posting inflammatory images. The social network was singled out by the Justice Department, with Facebook and Instagram mentioned 41 times in the indictment. Facebook has struggled with illicit activity on its platforms and has since hired thousands of people to monitor content and changed its advertising policy to vet ads mentioning candidates' names.

site_title: Aussie treasurer defends tax cuts for companies
summary: Australian Treasurer Scott Morrison defended his plan to reduce company taxes, stating it won't jeopardize the national budget's return to surplus by 2021. He argued that other countries, including the US, France, and Britain, are also considering similar tax cuts, which could lead to job losses and economic stagnation if Australia doesn't keep up. Morrison emphasized the importance of maintaining Australia's AAA credit rating and ensuring the budget remains balanced despite the tax cuts.

site_title: Indian banks 'may take more than US$3b hit from PNB scandal'
summary: Indian banks may face losses of over $3 billion due to loans and corporate guarantees provided to diamond companies linked to billionaire jeweller Nirav Modi and his uncle Mehul Choksi. The tax department estimates that banks had extended loans and guarantees worth $3.6 billion to companies tied to Modi and Choksi as of March 2017. The loans and guarantees have since increased, potentially exceeding $3 billion. The Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) has arrested several PNB employees in connection with the alleged fraud, which is India's biggest bank scam.

site_title: Couple, in their 80s, watch a-movie-a-day to stay on 'cutting edge'
summary: An elderly couple, Erika and Ulrich Gregor, have maintained their 60-year marriage through a shared passion for watching movies daily, with the goal of staying on the "cutting edge." Now in their 80s, they attend film festivals in Berlin, watching five to six movies a day. Their love of cinema began in the 1950s and has kept their relationship thriving. The couple's passion for film led to them co-founding the Arsenal cinema and showcasing Eastern European films, despite facing opposition due to strong anti-communist prejudices.

site_title: Tennis: 'One of the best weeks of my life', says Federer after 97th title
summary: Roger Federer won his 97th career title, the Rotterdam Open, defeating Grigor Dimitrov 6-2, 6-2. Federer, 36, celebrated his return to the top of the world rankings, calling it "one of the best weeks of my life." He is now the oldest No.1 in history, surpassing Jimmy Connors' record of 109 career titles.

site_title: PSA officially launches new port terminal in India
summary: PSA International officially launched its new port terminal, Bharat Mumbai Container Terminals (BMCT), in Jawaharlal Nehru Port, India. The $1.2 billion terminal, which will have an annual container handling capacity of 4.8 million TEUs, was inaugurated by Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi. BMCT is one of the largest foreign direct investments in the Indian port sector and aims to consolidate Mumbai's position as a premier seaport gateway for India. The terminal is expected to facilitate global trade and commerce, generating employment opportunities and boosting the local economy.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Iran increasing freight discount to boost oil sales to India
summary: Iran has offered to increase the freight discount on oil sales to India to 100% of the Platts assessment, or a discount of up to $1 per barrel, in an effort to boost oil sales and retain market share against rivals Saudi Arabia and Iraq. The move aims to counter US sanctions and increase Indian oil imports from Iran, which had declined by 17% in the first 10 months of the fiscal year. Iran's oil minister, Bijan Zanganeh, said the country expects Indian orders to grow and is optimistic about the future of the relationship between the two countries.

site_title: Iran turns to Russia for wheat to boost flour sales
summary: Iran is negotiating to import 1 million tonnes of wheat from Russia to boost flour sales to neighboring countries Iraq and Afghanistan. Iranian flour millers are operating at 50% capacity and are seeking additional wheat to meet demand. The country's wheat consumption is expected to reach a record 18.35 million tonnes, surpassing domestic production of 15 million tonnes. This move comes as Iran faces a smaller wheat crop due to rain and wheat imports for domestic use are currently banned to support local farmers.

site_title: Sanli Environmental - a play on Asia's water story
summary: Sanli Environmental, a Singapore-based water treatment company, has seen significant growth since its IPO in 2017. Founded by CEO Sim Hock Heng and his colleagues, the company focuses on municipal contracts and has a stable earnings stream. Sanli's conservative approach has paid off, with a market capitalization of over S$75 million and a 24% increase in shares since the IPO. The company is optimistic about its prospects, driven by the growing demand for water treatment services in Asia and Singapore's plans to develop its water infrastructure.

site_title: Release the drones!
summary: Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a launch event in Mumbai. The company also announced plans to expand its robotaxi services to California and Arizona. Meanwhile, FedEx partnered with a Singapore startup to deploy robots for commercial deliveries. In other news, Delta Air Lines expressed optimism about travel demand, lifting its shares. Japan's carmakers reduced export prices to the US to counter the effects of tariffs. Additionally, EV battery makers BYD and others faced increased pressure to cut emissions.

site_title: Nasdaq Dubai launches Abu Dhabi, Dubai equity index futures
summary: Nasdaq Dubai has launched futures contracts on the main indexes of Abu Dhabi and Dubai, providing exposure to the General Index of the Abu Dhabi Securities Exchange and the Dubai Financial Market. The move is expected to attract fresh money to the UAE's equity markets and offer investors new opportunities to hedge. The exchange has seen encouraging response to single-stock futures, with trading volumes in many contracts being modest, but has plans to expand its offerings, including futures covering regional MSCI equity indexes.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Emas Offshore, a Singapore-based offshore support solutions provider, successfully obtained the High Court's leave to convene a creditors' meeting to consider a proposed scheme of arrangement. The court also extended moratoriums until June 30, allowing the group to progress its restructuring plan with the support of principal bank lenders. Meanwhile, Pacific Radiance announced the termination of a charter contract worth over US$140 million without liability, and the company remains committed to exploring opportunities in key strategic markets.

site_title: Is it game over for Midas Holdings?
summary: Midas Holdings, a Singapore-based aluminum company, is facing uncertainty after a trading suspension was triggered by the discovery of freezing orders for shares in several of its subsidiaries. The company's debt and cash flow situation may be worse than previously thought, and investors are concerned about the potential for fraudulent transactions. Analysts have ceased coverage, and minority shareholders may want to take a prudent write-down on their investments. The company's board has brought in a China-based independent director to help navigate the situation, but the future remains uncertain.

site_title: Tarnished? Olympic brand mints money like never before
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has never been in better financial health, with revenue from broadcast rights reaching a record $2.87 billion at the 2016 Rio Games. The IOC's top sponsor program, which made up a fifth of its revenues, topped $1 billion for the first time between the 2014 Sochi winter Games and Rio 2016. Despite scandals and declining interest in staging the Games in Western cities, the IOC's financial health is boosted by growing support from Asian sponsors, governments, and sports fans, with the Tokyo 2020 Games already accumulating $3 billion in domestic sponsorship.

site_title: For China-backed startup, fund sales go online
summary: Lu International, a China-backed startup, is launching its English app in Singapore, targeting the online wealth management market. The company, backed by Ping An, has already gained popularity in China with its Lufax platform. Lu International aims to provide simple, yield-based products and differentiate itself by sourcing products not usually available to investors. The firm is also exploring the use of algorithms to flag suspicious transactions and provide event-triggered investing advice. With a capital markets services license from the Monetary Authority of Singapore, Lu International is poised to compete with established players in the online wealth management space.

site_title: General equity market in Europe appears lacklustre
summary: The European equity market, as measured by the Euro Stoxx 50 Index, appears lacklustre compared to the US market, despite the European Central Bank's unconventional monetary policies. The index lags behind the S&P 500 Index, and its recent performance is correlated with a rising economic sentiment indicator. With the indicator hovering above the 112.8 extreme euphoria level, analysts predict a mean reversion and potential correction of up to 30% in the Euro Stoxx 50 Index, driven by the ECB's tightening of quantitative easing.

site_title: Netanyahu says Israel will act against Iran's 'empire'
summary: Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu stated that his country will take action against Iran, not just its proxies, if necessary, to prevent Iran from becoming a dominant force in the Middle East. Netanyahu addressed the Munich Security Conference, displaying a map showing Iran's growing presence in the region. Iran's Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif responded by calling Netanyahu's presentation "a cartoonish circus" and denying that Iran seeks hegemony in the Middle East. Netanyahu warned that Iran's increasing power poses a significant threat to the region.

site_title: 66 feared dead as Aseman Airlines plane crashes in Iran mountains
summary: Aseman Airlines flight EP3704, carrying 66 people, crashed in Iran's Zagros mountains on February 18, 2018, after taking off from Teheran. Emergency services struggled to locate the wreckage in blizzard conditions, with conflicting reports on the crash site. The plane, an ATR-72 twin-engine plane, was in service since 1993. Iran's President Hassan Rouhani ordered a crisis group to investigate the crash and coordinate rescue efforts. The incident occurred amid Iran's ageing fleet of passenger planes and ongoing sanctions.

site_title: Dogged determination
summary: Business leaders in Singapore are looking forward to the Year of the Dog, which began in 2018, with hopes for growth, innovation, and positive change. Key areas of focus include adopting "old-school" values such as integrity, loyalty, and reliability, embracing technology and digital disruption, and fostering inclusive and sustainable growth. Many leaders hope to see increased trust building among governments, businesses, and citizens, and to support the next generation of entrepreneurs and youth in driving positive change. The year is expected to bring new opportunities for businesses, with a focus on innovation, customer experience, and personal branding.

images.alt_text: John Bittleston, Founder & Chair, Terrific Mentors International Pte Ltd

site_title: AstraZeneca's immunotherapy drug wins key lung cancer approval
summary: AstraZeneca's immunotherapy drug Imfinzi has won US FDA approval for treating non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients with inoperable mid-stage disease that hasn't spread widely. The approval, based on a trial of 713 patients, shows patients survived an average of 16.8 months without disease worsening. This approval opens up a multibillion-dollar market for AstraZeneca, with analysts predicting annual sales of up to $2 billion. The company has a lead of 2-3 years over competitors in this area, and plans to combine Imfinzi with another immunotherapy drug to target advanced lung cancer.

site_title: Myanmar farmers going against the grain - with apps
summary: Myanmar farmers are turning to mobile apps to improve their yields and combat pests, following decades of isolationist rule that limited access to modern technology. The "Green Way" app provides farmers with information on weather, crop prices, and best practices for pesticides and fertilizers, helping them to overcome challenges such as the stem borer moth that has plagued rice paddies. With smartphone penetration rising to 80% in 2017, apps like Green Way are helping to bridge the knowledge gap in agriculture, potentially reshaping the country's economy and society.

site_title: Waymo gets OK for commercial, driverless, ride-hailing service
summary: Waymo, a unit of Alphabet, has received approval to operate as the first US commercial ride-hailing service without human drivers. The Arizona Department of Transportation granted a permit in late January, allowing Waymo's fleet of driverless Chrysler Pacifica minivans to pick up and drop off paying riders in the state. The service, set to launch in Phoenix this year, will be limited by the number of vehicles available and may offer competitive pricing. Waymo has been testing autonomous vehicles in Arizona since November and plans to expand its services beyond ride-hailing.

site_title: US dollar extends losses against yen
summary: The US dollar dropped to a 15-month low of 106.30 yen on February 15, 2018, extending its losses against the yen. The dollar had previously reached a peak of 110.50 yen in early February, but fell 3.8% from that level. Market participants expect further near-term weakness in the US currency.

site_title: Coinbase in spat with card networks, banks over complaints of extra charges
summary: Coinbase, the largest US cryptocurrency exchange, is in a dispute with card networks and banks over complaints of extra charges and phantom fees. The exchange, which relies on debit and credit cards for 20% of its sales, has been accused of being responsible for the issues, but it denies any wrongdoing. Coinbase claims that banks and card networks, such as Visa, are to blame for the troubles, and has vowed to evaluate its long-term payment methods to prevent future issues. The dispute has raised concerns about the impact on Coinbase's business and public confidence in the cryptocurrency market.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange's latest shipping insights report reveals a mixed market for tankers and dry bulk vessels. VLCC rates declined in the Middle East Gulf to China, while Suezmax rates fell in West Africa. The Caribbean/upcoast market saw a 25-point increase in Aframax rates, while Panamax and Supramax rates remained steady. Handysize rates slipped in the Atlantic, but some signs of improvement were seen in the US Gulf market. The market is expected to stabilize after the Chinese New Year celebrations, with renewed optimism that the market has reached its bottom.

site_title: Emas, subsidiaries obtain High Court's approval to convene creditors' meeting
summary: Emas Offshore, a Singapore-based oil and gas company, has obtained the High Court's approval to convene a creditors' meeting to consider its proposed scheme of arrangement. The company has secured support from its principal bank lenders and will work closely with investors and stakeholders to progress its restructuring exercise. The court has also extended moratoriums until June 30, allowing the company to focus on the restructuring plan. This move aims to provide stability and clarity for the group's stakeholders as it moves forward with its restructuring exercise.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Firms seek help to ease in next year's carbon tax
summary: Singapore firms are seeking assistance as the country prepares to implement a carbon tax next year. The government has not confirmed the tax price, but it will be between S$10-20 per tonne of greenhouse gas emissions. Companies are hoping for a gradual implementation or possible grants for energy efficiency projects. Heavy emitters are also waiting for details on the specific carbon price in the upcoming Budget.

site_title: Pacific Radiance's joint venture, client terminate charter contract
summary: Pacific Radiance's joint venture company DOT Radiance and its client have mutually terminated a charter contract worth over $140 million without liability. The contract was originally set to be delivered in 2016/17 but was deferred to December 31, 2017. Pacific Radiance has not recognized any revenue from the contract, stating it will continue to explore opportunities to strengthen its presence in key markets.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Do your customers think your product is worth the wait?
summary: A study found that waiting times for food and beverages negatively impact customer satisfaction and loyalty, with those waiting 10 minutes or more experiencing lower satisfaction and loyalty scores. However, making the waiting experience more enjoyable, such as through technology or entertainment, can mitigate this effect. Offering pre-ordering and attentive service can also improve the overall experience, ultimately leading to increased customer satisfaction and loyalty.

site_title: Trump visits emergency workers who responded to school shooting
summary: President Donald Trump visited medical staff at Broward Health North hospital and the local sheriff's office in Florida to thank them for assisting victims of the Parkland school shooting. Seventeen people were killed and at least 14 others were injured. Trump also met with victims and praised the medical staff's work, saying it was "incredible." He plans to work with Congress on improving school security, but did not specify what legislation he is pushing for.

site_title: Tax overhaul may not stop the US corporate borrowing spree
summary: US corporate borrowing is expected to remain strong despite the tax overhaul package, with UBS and Wells Fargo forecasting record levels of investment-grade and junk bond debt issuance. The tax cuts are freeing up cash for companies, but investors are not worried about leverage, leading to tighter risk premiums for corporate bonds. Companies are more likely to use the cash to boost shareholders rather than pay down debt, and the impact on corporate bond market may prove muted.

site_title: Fed seeks to ban, fine ex-Barclays trader in FX manipulation
summary: The Federal Reserve has fined former Barclays trader Peter Little $487,500 and banned him from US banking for life, following allegations that he engaged in electronic chat room coordination with other traders to manipulate foreign-exchange rates. Little was accused of coordinating with competitors 13 times to profit from benchmark fixes. The sanctions follow similar penalties imposed on two other former Barclays traders. Little's lawyer denies the allegations, stating that the Fed denied him a meaningful opportunity to explain the charges.

site_title: Unilever lays bare palm oil supply chain in rare industry move
summary: Unilever has made a rare industry move by publishing its entire palm oil supply chain, including over 1,400 mills and 300 direct suppliers, to boost transparency. The move comes as the $62 billion palm oil industry faces concerns over deforestation and human rights abuses in countries like Indonesia. This is the first time a consumer goods company has disclosed such detailed information, aiming to increase accountability and sustainability in its operations.

site_title: British PM to warn EU over security cooperation
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May will warn the European Union at the Munich Security Conference that lives depend on an unprecedented security partnership, as Brexit looms. She will stress the need for cooperation to ensure citizens' security, despite no current deal between the EU and the UK.

site_title: Uber plans to sell South-east Asia business to Grab: CNBC
summary: Uber is planning to sell its South-east Asia business to Grab in exchange for a substantial stake in the Singapore-based company, according to CNBC. The deal is contingent on no other ride-hailing assets being combined with Grab's assets, following SoftBank's multi-billion dollar investment in Uber. No agreement has been reached yet, and the timing is uncertain. This move could potentially strengthen Grab's position in the region.

site_title: Audi chairman rubbishes report that CEO Stadler to be removed
summary: Audi Chairman Matthias Mueller has dismissed a report that CEO Rupert Stadler will be removed, citing "proven leadership" under Stadler's management. The report, in German tabloid Bild, claimed Stadler would leave in April due to his handling of the diesel emissions scandal. Mueller urged workers to ignore the speculation, saying the company needs full concentration to overcome its challenges. The scandal has led to conflicts between management, the powerful Piech family, and trade unions.

site_title: Japan, short of workers, eyes hiking optional pension age beyond 70
summary: Japan has approved plans to let people choose to start drawing state pensions beyond age 70 due to severe labor shortages and a greying population. The government aims to raise the mandatory retirement age for 3.4 million civil servants to 65 from 60, and will consider further changes. This move may serve as a model for other countries facing similar demographic challenges. Japan's population is expected to shrink to 88 million by 2040, with a life expectancy of the highest in the world.

site_title: Offer by Olivia Lum for HyfluxShop Holdings is voluntary
summary: Hyflux's CEO Olivia Lum has made a voluntary offer for HyfluxShop Holdings, a consumer business, with an offer price of 17.83 Singapore cents per share. The offer is not mandatory, contrary to earlier statements, and will be funded by Lum's personal finances. Lum aims to continue HyfluxShop's existing business with no plans for major changes or asset redeployment. An independent financial adviser will advise HyfluxShop's directors on the offer, which could potentially lead to a listing to unlock value for shareholders.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Singapore's digital tax agenda: A matter of time
summary: Singapore's digital tax agenda is a pressing concern due to the shift in businesses operating globally. The Internet has enabled businesses to supply markets without a local presence, making it challenging for existing tax systems to operate effectively. The OECD's Base Erosion Profit Shifting (BEPS) project aims to formulate tax policy options, while the European Union considers introducing an equalisation tax for the tech sector. Singapore should use its position in the BEPS project to reach a global consensus before leading harmonisation in the region.

site_title: China says insurance funds must serve real economy
summary: China's insurance regulator has emphasized that insurance funds must serve the real economy, not be used for covert funding of local governments. Deputy chairman Chen Wenhui stated that "fake creativity" in investment must be banned, instead promoting long-term, value investments. The move comes as China's insurance sector faces challenges due to a state-led crackdown on risky investment products and a slump in net operating cash flow of 65% in 2017. The regulator aims to guide investment towards serving the real economy, aligning with national strategy.

site_title: EDF sees 2018 rebound but nuclear output lower again in 2019
summary: EDF's 2017 core earnings dropped 16.3% due to nuclear reactor outages and lost customers. The utility suffered extended unplanned and maintenance outages at 58 reactors in France, resulting in a 21% decline in electricity generation income to 4.8 billion euros. Despite this, EDF's CEO expects a rebound in 2018, citing a return to normal operations.

site_title: A C$3.93b deal creates Canada's largest Reit to tap boom
summary: Choice Properties Real Estate Investment Trust agreed to buy Canadian Real Estate Investment Trust for about C$3.93 billion, creating Canada's largest Reit with an enterprise value of about C$16 billion. The deal will give Choice more industrial and office space, as well as a seasoned management team. Investors are seeking to capitalize on Canada's booming commercial-property market, following recent transactions such as Blackstone Group's purchase of Pure Industrial Real Estate Trust for US$2 billion. The transaction is expected to be approved in April and will require at least 66 shareholder votes.

site_title: No, millennials, the yen is NOT the official currency of China
summary: A recent HQ Trivia game asked contestants what China's official currency is, with many millennials incorrectly answering "yen." The correct answer is the Chinese yuan. The incorrect response highlights a common misconception among non-finance types. The article does not provide further context or conclusions beyond this event.

site_title: Credit Agricole said to start 6b euro Italy loan sale
summary: Credit Agricole, a French bank, plans to sell approximately 6 billion euros of Italian non-performing loans, acquired between 2006 and 2008, through a process called securitization. The sale, dubbed "Project Poppy," includes loans to small-and-medium enterprises, consumer debt, and secured loans, with a focus on southern and central regions. The sale aims to capitalize on increasing appetite for Italian debt, driven by the country's economic rebound and efforts to clean up balance sheets. The sale is expected to be completed by June.

site_title: Air Canada expects Air China JV in the spring
summary: Air Canada's CEO, Calin Rovinescu, announced that the company expects a joint venture with Air China to be finalized by spring, which will help it compete more aggressively in the Pacific market. The joint venture will expand lounge and codesharing services, benefiting Air Canada, which faces yield pressures and competition from WestJet Airlines. The airline reported a better-than-expected fourth-quarter profit, with operating margins rising to 3.5% and fuel costs rising 13.6% to 67.5 Canadian cents per litre.

site_title: SEC kills Chinese-linked takeover of Chicago Stock Exchange
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) rejected a Chinese-linked consortium's bid to take over the Chicago Stock Exchange, citing non-compliance with US rules governing stock exchanges. The deal, which aimed to create an international listing venue, would have given 29% of the company to a China-based shareholder. The SEC's decision denies the exchange an opportunity to address concerns about US companies going public in China. The Chicago Stock Exchange had hoped to sell itself and create a conduit to China, but the SEC's rejection ends an ambitious project.

site_title: HNA is said to sell NYC office tower for at least US$300m
summary: HNA Group, a debt-laden Chinese conglomerate, sold a Manhattan office tower at 1180 Avenue of the Americas in Midtown for at least US$300 million to Northwood Investors, a firm led by John Kukral. This sale is part of HNA's efforts to dispose of over US$6 billion in properties worldwide to repay debts. The tower, which was previously valued at US$274 million, was acquired by HNA in 2011. The sale marks a significant development in HNA's efforts to restructure and reduce its debt burden.

site_title: Allianz considers group's stance on coal insurance
summary: Germany's Allianz is considering whether to stop insuring new coal power plants, amid a debate over balancing profit with environmental concerns. The company has formed a working group to study the issue, with a decision expected in late April or early May. Allianz's CEO Oliver Baete has expressed a desire to transition from coal, but the company will continue to offer insurance for the coal-powered energy industry for now. Environmental campaigners remain unhappy with the stance, calling it a contradiction between Allianz's ambition to be a climate champion and its support for coal.

site_title: Next Nafta talks scheduled to start with auto content rules
summary: US, Canada, and Mexico will discuss rules of origin for automotive content at the upcoming Nafta talks in Mexico City, starting on Feb 25. The US proposes raising regional automotive rules of origin for passenger cars to 85% from 62.5% to revive US factories. Automakers warn that the proposal would upend supply chains. Canada has proposed fresh ideas to calculate the value of regional content in vehicles, including giving more credit for electric cars. The talks aim to revive Nafta negotiations, which began in August after President Trump initiated the renegotiation process.

site_title: Hedge funds pile into Time Warner in bet on merger success
summary: Hedge funds, including Baupost Group and Viking Global Investors, have invested in Time Warner shares ahead of a March trial over AT&T's acquisition. The funds are betting that the Trump administration will fail to block the deal. According to Porter Bibb, managing partner at MediaTech Capital Partners, these hedge funds believe the acquisition will go through. The trial will determine the future of the $85.4 billion deal, which has garnered significant attention and investment from the smart money.

site_title: Banks replaced with blockchain at international food program
summary: The World Food Programme (WFP) is expanding its blockchain-payments system to cut millions of dollars in bank transfer fees, replacing traditional banking services with distributed ledgers based on Ethereum's digital-currency network. The program, which began in 2016, aims to save $150,000 a month and eliminate 98% of bank fees for 100,000 Syrian refugees in Jordan. The move is part of the WFP's effort to reduce costs and promote collaboration, and demonstrates the potential for blockchain technology to be used in various industries beyond digital currency.

site_title: Swiss regulatory unveils new rules for crypto-currencies
summary: Switzerland's market watchdog Finma has released new guidelines to govern cryptocurrencies, creating a regulatory framework for the industry. The guidelines aim to set out basic principles for clarity and transparency, particularly for Initial Coin Offerings (ICOs). Finma has divided ICOs into three categories: payment tokens, utility tokens, and asset tokens, with a balanced approach to manage risks while allowing the industry's innovative potential to thrive. The move comes as Switzerland emerges as a global hub for cryptocurrencies, following a sharp increase in ICOs applying to base their operations in the country.

site_title: BP plans no Azeri platform shutdowns in 2018, eyes more investment
summary: BP plans no maintenance shutdowns of its oil and gas platforms in Azerbaijan for 2018, according to the company's regional president Gary Jones. Jones stated that no shutdowns are planned for this year, but some may occur in 2019. The company aims to minimize shutdowns by using drones for inspections, reducing the need for major maintenance work.

site_title: Jan exports up 13% despite electronics slide
summary: Singapore's trade grew 13% in January, driven by non-electronics exports, which outpaced economists' estimates. Despite this, overall non-oil domestic exports (NODX) growth is expected to moderate this year after last year's brisk pace. January's growth was led by non-electronic exports, particularly engines, motors, and measuring instruments, while electronics exports declined 3.9% due to a slowdown in the Asia-Pacific semiconductor market. Economists predict NODX growth to remain supported by global demand, but with a possible slowdown in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: All eyes on Fed meeting and T-bill markets
summary: US stocks surged last week, with the S&P 500 rising 4% to its biggest weekly gain since 2013, after a correction of over 10%. Bulls hope for sustained momentum, while bears warn of more swings. The Fed's meeting minutes and Treasury markets may trigger buying or selling. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note reached 3% for the first time since 2014, but interest rates remain relatively low. Inflation data may influence the Fed's rate hike predictions, with some strategists predicting a rosy economic picture despite potential sell-offs.

site_title: Evita still rocks
summary: Evita, a 40-year-old rock opera, continues to impress audiences with its spectacle and operatic numbers. The musical, based on the true story of Eva Peron, is now touring in Singapore, playing at the Mastercard Theatre at Marina Bay Sands from February 23 to March 18. The original Tony-winning Broadway and West End version, directed by Hal Prince, features big numbers like "Don't Cry For Me Argentina" and "You Must Love Me." This production remains a sublime spectacle that makes a powerful statement about fascism, with Eva Peron's story serving as a testament to her enduring legacy.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Morgan Stanley is dropping some wealth customers overseas
summary: Morgan Stanley is terminating some international wealth-management clients, advising them to liquidate or transfer accounts within 30 days. The decision, made due to increased complexity in serving clients outside the US, is part of a review of international account policies. This exit will impact some international relationships, although the bank's statement does not specify which clients or countries will be affected.

site_title: MindChamps PreSchool enters China through China First Capital Group joint venture
summary: MindChamps PreSchool has entered China through a joint venture with China First Capital Group (CFCG). The joint venture aims to raise US$200 million to set up and acquire preschool centers under the MindChamps brand. MindChamps will own 49% of the master franchisee, with CFCG holding the remainder. The preschool's education model, Champion Mindset, is expected to benefit from China's growing preschool education market, valued at 380 billion yuan (S$78.6 billion) in 2016 and expected to exceed 540 billion yuan by 2020.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Facebook faces big challenge to prevent future US election meddling
summary: Facebook faces a significant challenge in preventing future US election meddling, as a Russian influence operation in 2016 used a combination of old-school espionage tactics and 21st-century technologies. The indictment of 13 Russian nationals revealed the use of shell corporations, stolen IDs, and virtual private networks to avoid detection. Experts say that even with significant investments and new vetting procedures, Facebook may struggle to stop such activities, and that internet companies may need to adopt "know your customer" practices similar to banks. Facebook has vowed to guard against future attacks and is working with authorities to deter election interference.

site_title: Goldman sees the power of BOE tightening increasing through 2018
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts the Bank of England's (BOE) interest-rate increases will have a more significant impact on the UK economy in 2018, driven by a boost from global growth. Economists found that surprise rate hikes have a bigger effect during expansions, reducing GDP by 0.4% and inflation by 0.1% after two years, compared to a negligible effect at the trough. This suggests the BOE will need to tread carefully when communicating its next steps to avoid surprising the market and cramping growth, particularly as governor Mark Carney prepares to testify on the BOE's Inflation Report.

site_title: ECB's Coeure expects talks soon on policy wording for stimulus
summary: European Central Bank policy maker Benoit Coeure signaled that officials are close to starting talks on altering their policy language as they prepare for the end of bond purchases and potential interest rate hikes. Coeure stated that their communication on monetary policy will change, with discussions expected in early 2018. The ECB aims to signal that the euro area's economic expansion warrants halting asset-buying.

site_title: Silicon Valley singles are giving up on the algorithms of love
summary: Silicon Valley singles are increasingly opting out of dating apps, citing frustration with algorithmic matches. Digital marketer Kate Chan, 30, has stopped using dating apps after six months of unfulfilling connections and now meets potential partners in person at hobbies and interests-based events. This shift reflects growing dissatisfaction with the reliability of algorithm-driven matchmaking.

site_title: Buffett just messed things up for Teva short-sellers
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has made a significant investment in Teva Pharmaceutical Industries, buying back $1.2 billion worth of shares from short-sellers who had bet against the Israeli generic-drug maker. This move is seen as a major blow to those who had taken a short position on Teva, with Buffett's investment effectively nullifying their bets. The unexpected turn of events is a rare instance of Buffett's influence on the market.

site_title: Every bite hits the spot
summary: Chef Andre, Singapore's chef royal-designate, abdicated his throne at Restaurant Andre, marking the end of his two-Michelin-starred reign. A final tasting of his Octaphilosophy meal took place on Feb 13, following his announcement in October last year. The restaurant will be resurrected in 2018 under a new concept, while Andre embarks on a new phase as a culinary entrepreneur. His departure was met with 7,000 email requests for reservations, highlighting his near-mythical status.

site_title: Why Tencent is slow to monetise WeChat
summary: Tencent, a $22 billion Chinese tech giant, is slow to monetize its WeChat social media app, unlike Facebook, which generates 98% of its revenue from advertising. WeChat, launched in 1999, has 18% of its revenue coming from online ads. Tencent's philosophy prioritizes user experience over monetization, a strategy that began when the company was founded in 1998 by Ma Huateng. This approach has allowed WeChat to maintain a large user base, but analysts believe it's an opportunity cost for the company.

site_title: Go East
summary: Singer Nathan Hartono is set to debut in the Mando-pop market with his Mandarin single "Electric Love," a reworked version of his 2016 English single "Electricity." The song is part of a five-track EP due later this year. Hartono hopes to connect with a new audience and bring his music to more parts of the world, following his success on the reality singing contest Sing! China.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Must-Have Polo Shirt
summary: Lacoste has unveiled the new Paris Polo, a high-quality tennis shirt designed by founder Rene Lacoste 86 years ago. The polo shirt is made of stretch cotton mini piqué and features a slim straight fit, without comfort slits. Available in eight colors at $139, it's set to be released in all Lacoste stores at the end of February.

site_title: Property brokers may succumb to M&A in battered UK market
summary: UK property brokers, such as Foxtons Group and Countrywide, are facing financial struggles due to a stagnant housing market and increased competition from online agents. Investors have lost patience, with shares tumbling by nearly a quarter and more than half in the past year. Analysts suggest that mergers and acquisitions (M&A) may be a viable option for these companies to cut costs and stay afloat. Research indicates that 19% of UK estate agents show warning signs of insolvency, with private-equity firms considering a takeover.

site_title: Yen jumps after Japan's finance minister says no need for intervention
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso stated that the yen's recent move does not warrant special intervention, citing it as not rising or falling abruptly. The yen jumped to its highest level in over a year, trading at 106.63 against the US dollar, amid Aso's comments. A higher yen adds to Japan's challenges in reviving growth and inflation, weighing on exporters and import prices.

site_title: SGX, MAS intensify lobbying against Reit ETF withholding tax
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) are intensifying their lobbying efforts against the 17% withholding tax on Reit ETFs, a move that has been discussed for two years. The tax affects ETFs tracking real estate investment trusts (Reits). The talks come as investors and industry players express concerns over the tax, which could impact the attractiveness of Reit ETFs. The outcome of these talks remains uncertain, but the SGX and MAS are pushing for a more favorable tax environment for Reit ETFs.

site_title: Food To Remember
summary: Five chefs share their most memorable Chinese New Year reunion dishes, each with a special story behind them. Chef Leong fondly remembers learning from Chef Chan, who taught him refined Cantonese dishes like black pepper beef. Chef Low revived his childhood dish ngoh hiang, adding his own twist. Chef D'Silva recalls prawns being a luxury in his childhood, and now serves a spicy prawn salad. Chef Lai continues his mother's tradition of a vegetarian stew, while Chef Lee Chiang Howe shares his family's centuries-old tradition of eating around a copper steamboat.

site_title: Singapore helps Asia-Pac property deals to new record of US$157b
summary: Singapore's real estate transactions in 2017 reached a record US$157.5 billion, driven by large deals and industrial asset purchases. This surpassed the previous peak in 2015 by 2%. The country saw a 50% year-on-year increase in acquisitions to US$21 billion, with US$6 billion in land sale sites. Singapore ranked fifth in the Asia-Pacific region, behind China, Japan, Australia, and Hong Kong.

site_title: Origin Energy's profit jumps on soaring prices
summary: Origin Energy, Australia's top power and gas retailer, reported a 215% increase in half-year underlying profit to A$582 million, driven by soaring energy prices. The company raised its earnings forecast for energy markets to A$1.78-1.85 billion and aims to cut costs at its APLNG project, targeting a break-even point of US$45 a barrel by June. Origin's shares rose 6% and the company expects to cut net debt to less than A$7 billion by June, with debt reduction and improving returns seen as key measures to revive its dividend.

site_title: Good Scents
summary: Perfume enthusiasts, mostly men, are seeking unique olfactory experiences, driving a rise in demand for bespoke fragrances. Companies like Parfums Henry Jacques, founded by Anne-Lise Cremona, are catering to this trend by offering custom-made scents and educational experiences in their laboratories. Men, in particular, are embracing perfume collecting as a niche hobby, valuing the artistry and history behind each fragrance. With a focus on natural ingredients and no alcohol content, bespoke perfumes are becoming increasingly popular among men seeking a unique identity and sensory experience.

site_title: Lonely Souls
summary: Singapore artist Sarah Choo Jing's exhibition Accelerated Intimacy at Yeo Workshop explores loneliness in urban city centres through projected video works. The show transforms a hotel room setting, featuring a young boy playing violin and a woman breaking down in a bathtub, all reciting film lines. The bleak reality of loneliness is portrayed through these moving images. The exhibition runs at Yeo Workshop until March 4, with free admission.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: In free trade U-turn, Modi raises India's import duties
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi has raised import duties to their highest in three decades, making it more expensive to import parts for cars, cameras, televisions, electricity meters, and smartphones. This move, seen as a protectionist turn, could threaten foreign direct investments and escalate trade disputes with major trading partners like the US and China. The decision may also harm local businesses, particularly small and medium-sized companies, and could have negative consequences for India's double-digit growth targets.

site_title: Dogs & their heroes
summary: Celebrities Andrea De Cruz and Pierre Png discuss the importance of adopting dogs, not just during the Year of the Dog, but for a 15-year commitment. They share the story of adopting Oreo, a Shih Tzu they rescued after being abandoned by a family due to unforeseen circumstances. De Cruz and Png emphasize that owning a dog requires dedication, responsibility, and care, not just for the dog's sake but also for their own well-being.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Eating Clean
summary: Marks & Spencer introduces a new range of packed vegetarian and vegan meals, making clean eating easier. The meals are packed with superfoods like seaweed, sprouted grains, and pea protein. Available at Wheelock Place, the Edamame & Coriander cakes are a highlight, made with black quinoa, brown rice, and baby corn. This move aims to cater to the growing demand for healthier and more sustainable food options.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Australia, New Zealand currencies make the most of US dollar malaise
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars surged against the US dollar, with the Aussie up 0.8% and the kiwi up 1.3%, as risk appetite rebounded and offset rising US bond yields. The strong labor market and low unemployment rate supported the Australian dollar, while the New Zealand dollar benefited from emerging concerns about the US budget and current account deficits. The US dollar drop boosted commodity prices, including gold, copper, and iron ore, which rose in response.

site_title: Most expensive CNY yet, but milder price hikes offer some cushion
summary: The 2018 Chinese New Year in Singapore saw a 2.4% increase in the average price of a basket of four festive items - mandarin oranges, beer, abalone, and bak kwa - making it the most expensive year on record. However, the price hikes were milder than expected, with beer prices remaining the same. The increase was attributed to a combination of factors, including supply-side pressures and demand-driven factors. The price of mandarin oranges and bak kwa rose significantly, while abalone prices increased by 4.4%. Economists attribute the slower price rise to a more stable economic landscape and strong consumer sentiment.

site_title: Globalisation 2.0 could see different players taking the lead
summary: Globalisation 2.0 is emerging, with key players like the US and UK withdrawing from the globalisation juggernaut, creating space for other nations to lead. China is poised to gain from this shift, with plans to set up an AI industrial park and increase visas for academics and Indian students. India will need to write its own globalisation strategy, leveraging its digitalisation and low-cost advantages. Turkey and Israel are also emerging as potential players, with Turkey's eastern hemisphere strategy and Israel's innovation edge. Japan and South Korea are on the upswing, while Brazil, Asean, and Africa are expected to follow suit. The shift towards a more multipolar world is expected to bring fresh dynamism to global trade, with the fast movers gaining fast.

site_title: Creating an inclusive cashless society
summary: Singapore aims to create an inclusive cashless society, building on the concept first proposed by aerospace engineer Simon Ramo in 1961. Despite progress, a unified payment system remains elusive, with merchants citing high transaction costs ranging from 1% to 3%. The government is exploring a "Super Identity" digital profile to facilitate easy integration and ensure inclusivity. Cross-border collaborations and advances in machine learning and AI-powered fraud detection are also being leveraged to enhance the cashless payment ecosystem.

site_title: Expert says stolen virtual currency being traded on dark web
summary: A stolen virtual currency, equivalent to $712.6 million, was stolen from Coincheck Inc in Tokyo, with up to $1 billion in NEM potentially already exchanged on the dark web. An expert found multiple addresses used for transactions, indicating third parties were profiting by buying and selling the stolen currency. A website on the dark web was used to exchange NEM for bitcoin and other currencies, with over 200 remittances made to a Russian-Chinese virtual currency exchange operator since February 7. The Metropolitan Police Department analyzed communications records, but the actual origin of the transmission remains unclear, with speculation including North Korea involvement.

site_title: US: Stocks end strong week on mixed note
summary: US stocks ended a strong week on a mixed note, with the Dow and S&P 500 edging higher, while the Nasdaq fell slightly. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.1% to 25,219.38, and the S&P 500 inched up less than 0.1% to 2,732.22, marking its sixth consecutive gain. Despite a muted session, the week ended with the Dow and S&P 500 near record highs, while the Nasdaq fell to 6,770.66.

site_title: Singdollar bond issue down to a trickle amid interest rate volatility
summary: The Singapore dollar bond market has slowed down significantly due to interest rate volatility, with only one S$50 million bond issue in February, compared to 12 issues worth S$2.2 billion in January 2018. Despite the slowdown, bankers say longer-term bond financing still has non-rate benefits, and companies are reviewing their refinancing and funding plans. Experts advise companies to ensure diversity in funding sources to manage risk and consider tapping the bond market for longer-dated financing to match their debt maturity profile with cash flow.

site_title: Qualcomm, Broadcom hold talks over revised US$121b bid
summary: Qualcomm met with Broadcom to discuss the latter's revised $121 billion bid, marking the first time the two companies have talked about the potential acquisition. The meeting followed Qualcomm's rejection of Broadcom's revised cash-and-stock bid of $82 per share, citing undervaluation and lack of deal certainty. Qualcomm's board will now determine its next steps, which could include negotiations or continuing to defend itself against the takeover. The outcome of the meeting is uncertain, with Broadcom's top executives saying Qualcomm's counterparts listened but did not engage in discussion.

site_title: Japan's Dec machinery orders dip 11.9% - worst in 3 years
summary: Japan's core machinery orders dropped 11.9% in December, the largest decline in three years, with companies expecting only a 0.6% rise in January-March. This follows a 5.7% increase in November and raises concerns that recent capital expenditure gains may slow. Despite this, economists believe the economy can continue to grow due to consumer spending and exports, but consumer prices will ultimately determine the success of the Bank of Japan's inflation experiment.

images.alt_text: The 11.9 per cent decline in December core orders, the largest fall since May 2014, was more than the median estimate of a 2.3 per cent fall and followed a 5.7 per cent increase in November.

site_title: Shark fin consumption down in China, up elsewhere
summary: Shark fin consumption has declined by 80% in China since 2011, largely due to public awareness campaigns and a government crackdown on extravagant banquets. However, the trend is reversed in other Asian countries, including Thailand, Vietnam, Indonesia, and Macao, where consumption is growing. Despite the decline in China, shark fin remains a popular dish in Hong Kong and Taiwan, and the report warns of mercury, cadmium, and arsenic poisoning due to shark fin consumption. The global shark population is threatened, with 100 million sharks killed annually, and conservation efforts are needed to protect the marine ecosystem.

images.alt_text: Activists from non-governmental organisation WildAid protesting outside an outlet of Maxim's, the largest Chinese restaurant group in Hong Kong, on Feb 10. Maxim's serves blue shark fin on request; the dish is popular on Chinese New Year banquet menus.

site_title: Barrick Gold expects output to slide as reserves, production fall
summary: Barrick Gold, the world's largest gold producer, forecasts a 10-20% decrease in gold output over the next four years due to falling reserves and production. The company expects to produce 4.5-5 million ounces of gold this year, with costs ranging from $765-815 per ounce. Barrick plans to increase capital spending by over 60% in 2018 to develop new projects. The company reported adjusted net earnings of $253 million in the fourth quarter, largely unchanged from the same period last year.

site_title: Opec pact likely to evolve rather than end
summary: OPEC is unlikely to end its production curbs, instead, it will likely evolve to include higher production limits to maintain market share without triggering steep price falls. The current curbs, which began in 2016, have successfully cut global inventories and pushed up prices, but may need to be adjusted to include new production limits. The agreement, led by Saudi Arabia and Russia, will likely be extended and modified to include a new set of production limits, but securing a broad agreement may be challenging due to differing capacities and priorities among member states.

images.alt_text: At some point, Opec and its allies will be forced to shift their focus back towards boosting output and stemming the erosion of their market share. The only question is when.

site_title: Far East H-Trust Q4 payout slips to 0.97 cent
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust reported a 9.7% decline in income available for distribution to S$18.2 million in Q4 2017 due to lower occupancy rates and revenue from its hotel and serviced apartment segments. Average occupancy fell to 85.4% and revenue per available room decreased 2.4% year-on-year. Distribution per stapled security slipped to 0.97 Singapore cent from 1.12 Singapore cents a year ago.

site_title: Japanese trading houses on the prowl for assets with US$50b war chest
summary: Japanese trading houses, led by Mitsubishi Corp and Mitsui & Co, are utilizing their US$50 billion war chest to bolster their global commodity supply chain networks. They are focusing on undeveloped assets, taking bigger stakes in existing projects, and trading up to better quality operations. The five major trading houses reported record April-December net profits, with combined annual net income expected to reach 1.88 trillion yen (S$23.2 billion) for the year to end-March 2018.

site_title: TMC Education announces new management, board following sale of TMC Academy
summary: TMC Education Corporation, a CATALIST-listed company, has announced new management and a board of directors following the sale of its education subsidiary, TMC Academy, to its former controlling shareholders for S$6.32 million. The sale brings the controlling shareholders, Chin Kon Yuen and Yeow Cheng Khim, back to the helm, with Koh Wee Meng's stake increasing to 53.05%. The company has also appointed new executives, including Koh Kian Soo as executive chairman and CEO, and Tan Chee Wee as executive director and COO, effective May 1.

site_title: Airbus's problem planes take gloss off earnings surge
summary: Airbus reported a record year of jetliner deliveries, with 800 planes set to be handed over in 2018. However, the company's earnings were tempered by a 1.3 billion euro charge related to its troubled A400M military transport model and ongoing issues with its A320neo single-aisle jet. Airbus faces challenges in meeting its 2018 earnings targets, dependent on overcoming engine issues and cost overruns that have exceeded 7 billion euros since the A400M program began in 2003. CEO Tom Enders stated the company is working to address the problems.

images.alt_text: "The A320neo ramp-up remains challenging and requires that the engine suppliers deliver in line with commitments," says CEO Tom Enders.

site_title: Ascendas-Singbridge wins tender for 'mixed-use exec centre'
summary: Ascendas-Singbridge won the tender for a 2.4-ha mixed-use executive centre in one-north, Singapore, beating four other contenders. The development will feature an upscale hotel, office space, and F&B outlets, as well as flexible workplaces and community development programs. The project is the first shared executive learning centre in Singapore, targeting talent development players and companies, and is expected to draw demand from corporate universities, learning units, and executive business schools.

images.alt_text: The mixed-use executive centre will be Singapore's first shared executive learning centre dedicated to the development of talent and leadership for the next generation, said the Temasek Holdings unit.

site_title: Economic convergence - so near and yet so far
summary: The world is experiencing a "synchronised" growth upswing, raising questions about the economic convergence of developed and developing countries. After the Great Recession, developing economies began to grow faster than advanced counterparts, with a 2.5 percentage point per capita growth lead from 1990 to 2007. However, growth slowed in many emerging economies, particularly in Latin America, while the US experienced a rebound. The key engine of convergence, manufacturing, has been largely exhausted, and technological catch-up is more challenging in the services sector. New technologies, such as robotics and AI, may slow convergence but can also create new opportunities for developing countries if they deploy them efficiently.

site_title: Keeping Singapore economy sustainable: New options in offing
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat's upcoming Budget speech is expected to focus on raising revenue due to rising social and healthcare spending. The country's 2017 GDP growth was 3.6%, but expenditure growth outpaced it. To address this, the government is considering new tax options, such as higher Goods and Services Tax (GST) rates and wealth taxes. However, these measures may harm Singapore's status as a major wealth management hub. The Budget speech will also discuss trimming spending and implementing targeted measures to ensure better value for money, with long-term growth and competitiveness being key to sustaining the economy.

site_title: US carrier in South China Sea tries to prove a point
summary: A US aircraft carrier, the Carl Vinson, is conducting a routine mission in the South China Sea, where it is operating in disputed waters. The ship's presence aims to reassure allies and demonstrate the US's commitment to regional stability, amid criticism that the Trump administration has been distracted by North Korea. China claims most of the South China Sea, which is believed to hold vast oil and gas deposits, and has rapidly built artificial islands capable of hosting military planes. The US is pushing "freedom of navigation" operations to counter China's assertiveness.

images.alt_text: Rear Admiral John Fuller is in command. The ship's voyage comes just a month after the Pentagon's national defence strategy labelled China a "strategic competitor" that bullies its neighbours.

site_title: Guardians Of Her Universe
summary: Coco Chanel's fascination with wheat is celebrated in the high jewellery collection Les Blés de Chanel. The collection, launched in 2016, features 62 pieces showcasing the life cycle of wheat, from tender shoots to mature fields. Wheat was a symbol of prosperity and one of Chanel's few happy childhood memories. The collection, now on display in Singapore, includes necklaces, rings, bracelets, earrings, watches, and a standing clock, paying homage to Chanel's superstition and her father's association with wheat. The collection is a tribute to Chanel's personal symbol and her legacy.

images.alt_text: "Brins de Diamants" bracelets in 18k white gold set with diamonds.
"Premier Bins" necklace in 18k white gold set with 350 brilliant cut diamonds.
"Moisson de Perles" necklace in 18k white gold set with pear-cut diamonds, brilliant-cut diamonds, Japanese and Indonesian cultured pearls.
Lion holding an ear of wheat between its teeth by Willy Fleur, 1966, Patrimonie Collection.
