summary: iFast Corporation reported a 30.8% increase in revenue to S$28.2 million for its fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2017, with net profit more than doubling to S$2.5 million from S$1.1 million in the previous year.

site_title: STI slips 12 points; focus on US inflation
summary: The Straits Times Index slipped 12 points, with US inflation fears lingering ahead of key inflation indicators. Despite strong Singapore economy and sterling bank results, market gains were short-lived. Experts, including Michael Arone and David Blitzer, note that while inflation is on the rise, there are no immediate hints of surging prices. The market is expected to remain fragile until the release of the Consumer Price Index and Producer Price Index in the US.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: The worst of India banks' bad-loan woes may be yet to come
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has halted existing loan-restructuring mechanisms and introduced new rules to push more debt defaulters into bankruptcy courts. The move aims to tackle India's worsening bad-loan woes, which have nearly doubled in the past four years. The RBI requires banks to resolve debts of defaulters with 20 billion rupees or more by September 1, or take them to bankruptcy court. This will lead to stricter timelines and penalties for banks, but analysts say it will bring discipline to the banking sector and benefit banks in the long term.

site_title: For White, a big comeback on the half pipe
summary: Shaun White, 31, won his third Olympic gold medal in snowboarding, dominating the halfpipe event in Pyeongchang, South Korea. Despite a disappointing performance in Sochi at 27, White completed a remarkable comeback, surpassing his previous gold medal wins at 19 and 23. His final run, which included consecutive 1440s and 1260s, earned him a score of 97.75, securing the gold medal and solidifying his status as the greatest snowboarder ever.

site_title: US mortgage applications fall as home loan rates hit 4-year high - MBA
summary: US mortgage applications declined to a five-week low due to a 4.1% drop in the Mortgage Bankers Association's index to 399.4 in the week ending Feb 9. This was the lowest reading since 390.2 in the Jan 5 week. The decline is attributed to a 4-year high in 30-year fixed-rate home loan interest rates.

site_title: Baidu plans US IPO of Netflix-like unit as Q4 sales top estimates
summary: Baidu plans to list its Netflix-like video streaming service iQiyi on a US exchange, with an estimated valuation of $15 billion. The move aims to provide iQiyi with financial power and compete with rivals Tencent Holdings and Alibaba Group Holding in the streaming video market. Baidu's fourth-quarter sales exceeded analyst estimates, with revenue reaching 23.6 billion yuan and net income of 4.2 billion yuan. The planned listing will give iQiyi a significant influx of funds, allowing it to continue investing in content and expand its market share.

site_title: Shooting outside US NSA headquarters, one hurt
summary: A shooting occurred outside the National Security Agency (NSA) headquarters in Fort Meade, Maryland, leaving one person injured. The incident happened near a black SUV that crashed into a concrete barrier, with bullet holes visible in the vehicle's front windows. The FBI's Baltimore office is handling the investigation, which is still ongoing. The NSA has confirmed that the situation is under control, and the president has been briefed on the incident. This marks the second incident at the NSA facility in five years, following a similar incident in March 2015.

site_title: Netflix lures Ryan Murphy in deal said to be worth as much as US$300m
summary: Netflix has signed a five-year deal worth up to $300 million with hit producer Ryan Murphy, who was previously with 21st Century Fox. The deal comes after Amazon also courted Murphy, and he will join Netflix in July. Murphy's contract with Fox expires in the summer, and his shows, including "American Horror Story" and "Pose", will continue to air on FX. The move is a significant blow to Disney, which acquired most of 21st Century Fox for $52.4 billion.

site_title: Australia's banking regulator flags new capital rules on loans
summary: Australia's banking regulator, Apra, proposes higher risk weightings on interest-only and investment loans to bolster bank defenses against risk. The changes aim to avoid public bailouts in a crisis, aligning with the Basel III capital rules adopted worldwide. The Australian parliament has passed laws requiring major banks to set up "living wills" for crisis management, similar to those in the US. The country's biggest banks, including National Australia Bank and Westpac, say they will meet Apra's existing key capital requirements by 2020. The proposed changes aim to strengthen the country's banking system.

site_title: US: Stocks open lower on jump in inflation
summary: US stocks fell early Wednesday after data showed consumer inflation jumped in January, sparking fears of faster Federal Reserve interest rate hikes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index all declined 0.3% in the first few minutes of trading. The decline followed a three-day streak of stock gains, with investors concerned that the Fed's rate hikes could end the rally.

site_title: French bank Natixis posts surprise rise in Q4 profit
summary: French bank Natixis reported a 5% rise in Q4 net profit to 518 million euros, beating analysts' expectations of a 22% fall. The gain was driven by a one-off benefit from the US tax reform and stronger revenue growth in asset management. Natixis expects market volatility to boost client activity and plans to focus on industries such as energy, natural resources, and real estate. The bank's revenues fell 1% in Q4, while asset and wealth management revenue grew 22% to 899 million euros.

site_title: Two KS Energy directors served with writ of summons by Actis Excalibur
summary: Two directors of KS Energy, Kris Taenar Wiluan and Richard James Wiluan, have been served with a writ of summons by Actis Excalibur, a derivative action brought against them for allegedly breaching fiduciary duties to KS Distribution and its units. The two men are taking legal advice and have filed an appeal against the Singapore High Court's decision to grant leave for the action. KS Energy's shares fell 9.1% following the announcement.

site_title: US consumer prices jump 0.5% in January
summary: US consumer prices jumped 0.5% in January, exceeding analyst expectations, according to the Labor Department. The core index rose 0.3%, the largest increase since January 2017, fueling worries about interest rate hikes. Consumer spending fell 0.3% seasonally adjusted, driven by a drop in auto sales and a decline in spending on reconstruction after hurricanes. Despite this, American consumers spent an estimated $492 billion, a 3.6% increase from January 2017. The report sparked jitters on Wall Street, with investors concerned about the potential for mounting inflation and faster interest rate hikes.

site_title: Privatisation offer by Fu Yu for Malaysian unit 'not fair but reasonable': adviser
summary: Fu Yu Corporation's proposed selective capital repayment (SCR) exercise to privatise its Bursa Malaysia-listed subsidiary, LCTH Corporation, has been deemed 'not fair, but reasonable' by independent adviser Mercury Securities. Entitled shareholders will receive a total capital repayment of RM61.3 million, representing a cash repayment of RM0.58 for each LCTH share. The deal is valued at around RM61.3 million and is conditional on shareholder approval at an upcoming EGM in March.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Jumbo Q1 profit drops 20 per cent
summary: Jumbo Seafood reported a 20% year-on-year drop in Q1 profit to S$2.1 million, driven by increased expenses. Revenue rose 9.3% to S$35.75 million, primarily from Singapore and China outlets. The company plans to expand the Jumbo Seafood brand to other Chinese cities and explore franchising opportunities to diversify its business offerings.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rebound sharply ahead of Chinese New Year holiday
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 2.27% on February 14, 2018, with the Hang Seng Index reaching its largest one-day percentage gain since May 2016. The market will close early on Thursday for the Lunar New Year holiday and resume trading on February 20. China's Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.46% and the CSI300 index increased 0.8%. The rebound was seen ahead of the holiday, with investors likely to take profits before the markets close.

site_title: Singapore shares end a shade lower ahead of US CPI data
summary: Singapore shares ended 0.36% lower on Wednesday ahead of US CPI data, closing at 3,402.86. The benchmark Straits Times Index opened higher, driven by Singapore's better-than-expected economic growth of 3.6% last year. United Overseas Bank and OCBC ended lower, while DBS rose 1.45%. Singapore Airlines bucked the trend, increasing 5%. The better-than-expected economic growth and strong quarterly results from Singapore's banks supported the market, despite the impending US inflation data.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Boom time for German economy as politicians bicker
summary: Germany's economy experienced robust growth in the fourth quarter of 2017, driven by strong exports, with a quarterly growth rate of 0.6%. Inflation remained subdued in January. The upbeat business and household sentiment defied an uncertain political backdrop. Analysts attribute the growth to the "German growth turbo" being fully activated. The positive economic signs suggest Germany's upswing will extend into 2018.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks gain for 3rd day; won advances
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose for the third day, gaining 26.64 points or 1.11% at 2,421.83. The Korean won also advanced, reaching 1,077.2 per dollar. Foreign investors, particularly those buying Samsung Electronics shares, supported the gains. The won was bolstered by the stronger yen. Markets will be closed on Thursday and Friday for the Chinese New Year holiday, resuming on February 19.

images.alt_text: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose on Wednesday. The Korean won extended its gains on the local platform while bond yields fell.

site_title: Thai Bev net profit down 62% in Q1
summary: Thai Beverage, a Thai spirits maker, reported a 62.3% decline in Q1 net profit to 2.91 billion baht (S$122 million) due to non-recurring business acquisition costs from four acquisitions completed in the first quarter. Revenue fell 2.6% to 45.6 billion baht, with spirits sales revenue dipping 5.8% and beer sales declining 4%. However, the company maintained its share of the beer market and reported growth in its food business, driven by the acquisition of KFC stores.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with key companies such as Grab and OCBC seeing changes in leadership and analyst expectations. Grab's earnings growth is expected to slow in H2, prompting a downgrade to 'hold' by CGSI. Meanwhile, China's GDP growth is forecast to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Additionally, Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a launch event in Mumbai, and Citigroup set a target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026. These developments have significant implications for the markets and economies.

site_title: KOP swings to S$7m profit in Q3
summary: KOP Holdings, a Catalist-listed property developer, reported a third quarter profit of S$7 million, up from a loss of S$667,000 in the previous year. Revenue rose to S$14.82 million, driven by increases in real estate origination, management services, and hospitality segments. However, trade and other receivables decreased to S$20.9 million, while earnings per share fell to 0.22 Singapore cent. The company's net asset value per share slipped to 9.78 Singapore cents, and no dividend was proposed.

site_title: ASL Marine swings to S$6.4m loss in second quarter
summary: ASL Marine, a Singapore-based shipbuilder, reported a S$6.4 million loss in its second quarter due to lower margins, a higher foreign exchange loss, and finance costs. Revenue declined 24.1% to S$63.54 million, mainly due to a drop in shipbuilding revenue. The company's net asset value per share fell to 57.24 cents, down from 59.68 cents six months ago. ASL Marine's counter closed at 9.8 cents, down 2.97%. The loss was partially offset by higher other operating income from the sale of vessels and cranes.

site_title: Feng shui masters predict claws out in Year of Dog
summary: Hong Kong feng shui experts predict a challenging Year of the Dog, with US President Donald Trump facing a run of bad luck due to his zodiac animal clashing with the year's canine theme. Trump's birth date makes him a "fire dog," but 2018 is an "earth dog" year, creating an imbalance of elements. Experts foresee tensions between the US and North Korea, and potential misunderstandings between Trump and China on trade and economy issues. Despite this, some positive predictions include a happy wedding for Prince Harry and Meghan Markle and a smooth transition for the couple.

images.alt_text: As the Chinese zodiac switches into the Year of the Dog later this week, Hong Kong feng shui experts predict anything but a walk in the park for global leaders.

site_title: Asiatravel announces restructuring exercise; Singapore HQ to be shifted to Philippines
summary: Asiatravel.com, a travel website, announced a restructuring exercise to focus on profitability. The company will divest, close, and scale down loss-making business lines and subsidiaries. Its central Singapore operations will be shifted to the Philippines, where it holds a leading position. The company aims to scale down its B2C business, close B2C units, and significantly ramp up its B2B operations. The restructuring is expected to have a material impact on its financials, with savings going towards launching an augmented reality digital tour project.

site_title: Real estate brokers may succumb to M&A in battered UK market
summary: Real estate brokers in the UK are facing a stagnant housing market and losing market share to online competitors, leading analysts to predict a wave of mergers and acquisitions (M&A). Industry analysts, such as ETX Capital's Neil Wilson, suggest that traditional brokers like Foxtons Group Plc and Countrywide Plc may need to merge or be acquired to cut costs and stay competitive. With shares tumbling by 10-33% this year, investors are growing impatient, and private-equity firms are circling.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's economy expanded 3.6% in 2017, beating initial estimates, driven by strong manufacturing growth. Economists expect slightly slower growth in 2018 and a tightening of monetary policy. Non-oil exports rose 8.8% in 2017, with the government revising its forecast for 2018 upwards. Manufacturing growth slowed to 4.8% in Q4, while condo rents increased 0.5% and HDB rents dropped 0.2%. Singapore Airlines' net profit surged 62% in Q3, leading to upgrades by DBS and CGS-CIMB.

site_title: Singapore O&G posts higher Q4 profit
summary: Singapore O&G reported a 165% increase in Q4 profit to S$2.02 million, driven by higher revenue from obstetrics and gynaecology, cancer-related segments, and a new paediatrics segment. Earnings per share rose to 0.42 Singapore cents, up from 0.16 cents last year. Full-year profit dipped 3.4% to S$8.5 million, while revenue edged up 4.3% to S$29.9 million. A final dividend of 0.89 Singapore cents per share was announced for FY17, down from 1.57 cents previously.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Low Keng Huat inks en bloc deal for Cairnhill Mansions
summary: Singapore-listed property developer Low Keng Huat has inked a S$362 million deal to purchase Cairnhill Mansions, a freehold development in prime district 9. The group plans to redevelop the site into a high-rise residential condominium, yielding approximately 200 units. This purchase aims to replenish Low Keng Huat's land bank for residential developments in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Raffles Education remains in the red with S$1.4m Q2 loss
summary: Raffles Education Corp reported a net loss of S$1.4 million for the second quarter ended Dec 31, 2017, a decrease from S$3.9 million in the preceding year. Revenue grew 1% to S$24.6 million. The group attributed the loss to a challenging global education environment, currency volatility, and increasing interest rates. Cash inflows came from a refund of S$10.2 million and a loan of S$37.8 million. The company's first half loss was S$7.3 million, a 30% decrease from the previous year.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Airlines' target price is set at S$12.00, but closed at S$11.15 on Feb 14. BS Group Research upgraded the airline to "buy" due to expected benefits from a global economic recovery, strong travel demand, and stable cargo business. The research firm also expects improvements in Silkair and Scoot's performance.

site_title: Jewellery companies vie for China's independent women in marketing blitz
summary: Diamond companies globally are increasing their marketing budgets by up to 50% to tap into China's growing pool of independent female spenders, who are driving demand for diamond jewellery. The market, which saw 12% annual growth in 2016, is seen as a key prize due to low penetration rates and rising spending power among an increasingly wealthy female population. Companies such as Tiffany & Co, Debeers, and the Diamond Producers Association are focusing on promoting diamonds as a way for women to express themselves, rather than traditional notions of marriage.

images.alt_text: A woman dressed elegantly in a black pants suit, hands tucked in her pockets, poses with confidence as she displays a collection of glistening silver medals gleaming from her tailored jacket.

site_title: LTA to take over NE Line, Sengkang-Punggol LRT assets worth $30.8M
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) will take over operating assets of the North-East Line and Sengkang-Punggol LRT line, valued at $30.8M, from SBS Transit starting April. This move brings all rail assets under the Government, relieving SBS Transit from capital expenditure and revenue risks. SBS Transit will pay LTA a licence fee to operate and earn revenue from the lines.

site_title: Logistics specialist Chasen's subsidiaries bag S$11.4m of projects
summary: Logistics specialist Chasen Holdings' subsidiaries in Malaysia, Vietnam, and China have secured four projects worth S$11.4 million. A US solar manufacturer awarded a contract to Chasen's Penang-based subsidiary for RM6.6 million (S$2.2 million) and a similar contract to Chasen's Vietnam subsidiary for uncrating and rigging of machinery. Chasen's China subsidiary secured two projects worth 36 million yuan (S$7.5 million) for rigging and move-in positioning of tools and equipment for two LCD manufacturing plants. The projects are expected to contribute positively to the company's operations for 2018 and 2019.

site_title: IREIT Global's Q4 DPU falls
summary: IREIT Global's distribution per unit (DPU) for Q4 2017 fell to 0.94 euros from 1.03 euros, a decline of 10.1% for the full year. Despite a 1.3% year-on-year increase in gross revenue to 8.69 million euros, net property income and income to be distributed to unitholders fell 0.3% and 7.2% respectively. Strong rental income from its German assets and a 10% rental uplift at Bonn Campus contributed to the results.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Singapore condo rents up 0.5% in January; HDB rents drop 0.2%: SRX
summary: Singapore condo rents rose 0.5% in January, reversing a decline, while HDB rents fell 0.2% for a third consecutive month, according to SRX. Year-on-year, private rents decreased 0.9%, while HDB rents dropped 3%. Rental volumes increased 21.7% for condos and 16.7% for HDB flats in January.

site_title: Cyber breach hits "limited number" of employee email mailboxes: Sembcorp Industries
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a limited cyber breach affecting a "limited number" of employee email mailboxes. The company has contained the incident and is working with external consultants to strengthen its cyber security defences.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: South Korea vows firm action against illegal, unfair cryptocurrency trading
summary: South Korea has vowed to take firm action against illegal and unfair cryptocurrency trading following a 280,000-signature petition to the presidential Blue House. The government, led by Minister Hong Nam Ki, aims to prevent illegal acts while nurturing blockchain technology. Despite previous regulations, including a ban on anonymous bank accounts, South Korea will not shut down domestic cryptocurrency exchanges. Plans to develop the blockchain industry are also underway, with measures to be announced in the first half of the year.

site_title: US teacher's deportation back to Bangladesh postponed mid-flight
summary: A US teacher, Syed Ahmed Jamal, 55, who has lived in the US for 30 years, was temporarily stopped from being deported to Bangladesh while en route to his native country. His deportation was halted after an immigration appeals court granted a stay mid-flight, allowing Jamal to remain in the US. Hundreds of people have written letters and signed a petition urging immigration officials to halt his deportation, citing his status as a father of three US citizen children and a law-abiding immigrant.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.22 points to 1,835.24. Volume reached 20.46 million lots worth RM10.61 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 96 to 45.

site_title: Riviera Point sold to Macly Group for S$72m
summary: The Riviera Point property in Singapore's District 9 has been sold to the Macly Group for S$72 million, according to CBRE. The site area is 14,579 sq ft, with a plot ratio of 3.379 and a height control of 36 storeys. This marks the fourth collective sale attempt by Riviera Point, with previous attempts in 2007, 2011, and 2013. The sale price works out to approximately $1,461 psf ppr.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Singapore shares enter afternoon session on Wednesday flat; STI at 3,416.67
summary: Singapore shares remained unchanged in the afternoon session on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 3,416.67. About 1.02 billion shares worth S$777 million changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 184 to 182. Key stocks including DBS and OCBC Bank saw gains, while Magnus Energy and DISA were among the most actively traded. The market remains steady ahead of upcoming GDP data and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: No Signboard posts increased profit in Q1
summary: No Signboard Holdings reported a 56% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$1.44 million in Q1 2018, driven by 2.9% revenue growth to S$4.14 million. The company declared a special dividend of 0.31 Singapore cent per share. No Signboard plans to expand its casual dining concept and beer business, including establishing its own brewery.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Brexit a boon for Lithuania's 'fintech' drive
summary: Lithuania is experiencing a surge in fintech and blockchain-based start-ups following the UK's Brexit vote, with the country issuing 51 fintech licenses since 2016. Companies such as Revolut and Contis Group are seeking licenses, and the country's central bank is offering speedy processing and a regulatory environment to attract foreign firms. Lithuania aims to become a northern European hub for fintech firms and blockchain-based start-ups, with the goal of mitigating Brexit risks and attracting young talent to well-paid jobs.

site_title: Malaysia: shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.91 points to 1,834.93 on Wednesday, with a trading volume of 1.93 billion shares worth RM1.98 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 580 to 338.

site_title: How cockroaches crash into walls and keep going
summary: Scientists have discovered that American cockroaches can run full-speed into walls and continue, due to their shock-absorbent exoskeletons. A study found that 80% of the insects crash headfirst into the wall, but can still make the transition to scaling a vertical wall in about 75 milliseconds. Researchers used high-speed videography and a cockroach-sized robot to validate the findings, which could influence the design of future robots. The study suggests that simple, robust bodies can be used to safely bump into obstacles, rather than relying on complex sensors and control systems.

images.alt_text: Anyone who's tried to kill a cockroach knows that the ancient pests have some world-class evasive maneuvers. Or at least they appear to.

site_title: Apple executive bench is deep as CEO succession question raised
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook addressed succession at the company's annual shareholder meeting, stating that passing the baton is one of his most important roles. The company has a deep bench of experienced managers, including Jeff Williams, Eddy Cue, Phil Schiller, and Angela Ahrendts, who could potentially succeed Cook. Williams, a veteran operations chief, is considered a likely successor, while Ahrendts, a former Burberry CEO, has been discussed as a potential candidate due to her experience and ability to connect with employees and customers.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks climb for a third session, won gains
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose for a third consecutive session, gaining 22.31 points or 0.93% to 2,417.50. The won edged up, and bond yields climbed, driven by foreign investors' bargain-hunting in the tech sector. The benchmark index is down 2.9% this year, but supported by a rally in Samsung Electronics' shares.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS, CGS-CIMB upgrade on SIA as airline set to benefit from global economic recovery
summary: Singapore Airlines' third-quarter net profit surged 62% to S$286.1 million, with DBS and CGS-CIMB upgrading their target prices by at least 13% to S$12 and S$12.05, respectively. The upgrades are attributed to the airline's strong travel demand from the global economic recovery, expected to maintain load factors and passenger yields. However, the companies note that operating margins remain thin, and the airline is vulnerable to demand shocks and fuel price increases.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks hit fresh 4-month low on strong yen
summary: Tokyo stocks hit a fresh 4-month low on Wednesday due to a strong yen, which weighed on market sentiment. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index closed 0.43% lower at 21,154.17. The broader Topix index also fell 0.82% to 1,702.72. The decline erased early gains, with volatility affecting market sentiment.

site_title: In race for cancer therapy, a Chinese biotech surges
summary: A Chinese biotech firm, GenScript Biotech Corp, is emerging as a major player in the global race for cancer therapy, with its shares rising over sixfold since June. The company's CAR-T cancer therapy has shown promising results in early studies, and it expects approval from Chinese regulators to start formal human trials in the second quarter. GenScript's technology is similar to others in the global field, but the company's ambitions are being fueled by a surge of money flowing into the Chinese pharmaceutical industry.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks build on gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.62% at the start of trade on Wednesday, extending a previous day's rally, driven by a positive lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index reached 30,024.47, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.10% and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.08%. Traders are monitoring US inflation data later in the day, despite a strong start to the day.

site_title: Prince Henrik, husband of Denmark's Queen Margrethe II, dies at 83
summary: Prince Henrik, husband of Denmark's Queen Margrethe II, has died at 83 after a battle with dementia. He died on February 13, 2018, at Fredensborg Castle, surrounded by his family. Prince Henrik, born Henri de Laborde de Monpezat, had been in hospital since January 28 for a lung infection and had expressed disappointment over not being given a royal title of king. His funeral arrangements have not been disclosed.

site_title: New private home sales jump 37% year-on-year in January: URA data
summary: Singapore developers sold 522 private homes in January, a 37% year-on-year increase, and 100 executive condominium units, a 45.7% drop. January sales are the best since 2014, with analysts attributing the surge to a fear of rising prices and the upcoming launch of new projects after Chinese New Year. Property consultants expect a range of 11,000 to 14,000 private home sales for 2018, driven by a positive economic outlook and a growing demand for ECs.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: 5G is here: Super speed makes global debut at Olympic games
summary: South Korea has debuted the world's first 5G network at the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, showcasing its speed and capabilities. The technology is being used to repel wild boars that roam the mountainous region around the Games. 5G is expected to revolutionize wireless technology, enabling faster data transmission and paving the way for the "Internet of things". The technology is also being used to power autonomous shuttle buses and provide 360-degree images of events in real-time. The rollout is seen as a significant step towards the widespread adoption of 5G, with estimates suggesting 1 billion people will be 5G-enabled within five years.

site_title: HNA executives buy offshore dollar bonds amid credit crunch
summary: HNA Group, a Chinese conglomerate, has taken steps to shore up its finances amid a credit crunch. The company's executives have bought offshore dollar bonds, totaling US$13 million, as part of a series of measures to address concerns over its debt. HNA has also announced a US$2 billion deal for two Hong Kong land parcels and is in talks with creditors about its outstanding loans. Despite announcing a "very healthy financial position" with 1.5 trillion yuan in assets, the company faces increased scrutiny from Beijing and investors over its finances.

site_title: New York bomber sentenced to life in prison
summary: A US federal judge has sentenced Ahmad Khan Rahimi, a 30-year-old Afghan-born restaurant worker, to life in prison for wounding 31 people in a 2016 New York bombing. Rahimi claimed he was radicalized by FBI harassment and showed no remorse for the attack. He was convicted on all eight counts, including using a second bomb to cancel a US Marine Corps run in New Jersey. The judge deemed Rahimi "extremely dangerous" and criticized his lack of remorse.

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC upgrades ComfortDelGro to 'buy'
summary: OCBC Investment Research has upgraded its call on ComfortDelGro from "hold" to "buy", increasing the fair value of the taxi operator's shares from S$2.12 to S$2.25. OCBC expects the taxi business to remain competitive, with a potential earnings boost if the planned alliance with Uber is approved. ComfortDelGro plans to maintain its fleet size and only replace taxis that are due to be scrapped. This upgrade follows a slowdown in the decline of ComfortDelGro's taxi business in fiscal 2018.

site_title: UOB Q4 profit grows 16% to S$855m
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) reported a 16% increase in Q4 net profit to S$855m, driven by higher net interest income, fee and commission income, and net trading income. The bank recommended a final dividend of 45 Singapore cents per share and a special dividend of 20 Singapore cents per share. Net interest margin improved to 1.81%, while non-performing loans formed 1.8% of gross customer loans. The bank's balance sheet remains strong, with robust capitalisation and reserves buffer.

site_title: Baidu plans US IPO of Netflix-like unit as sales top estimates
summary: Baidu plans to list its video streaming service iQiyi on a US exchange, valuing the business at around $15 billion. The move comes after the company's fourth-quarter sales topped analyst estimates, with revenue reaching $4.9 billion. iQiyi's growth is crucial for Baidu, which faces competition from rivals Tencent and Alibaba. The listing is expected to provide iQiyi with much-needed financial power, allowing it to fund content costs, which are expected to rise as video remains a key feature for keeping users engaged.

site_title: Australia shares end lower; Fletcher Building hurts NZ
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% on Wednesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index closing at 5,841.2, amid cautious investor sentiment ahead of US inflation data. The decline was driven by losses in Commonwealth Bank of Australia and a 9.3% drop in Fletcher Building, New Zealand's biggest construction company, which cited a $660 million loss in its commercial building unit. Meanwhile, healthcare giant CSL Ltd jumped 5.1% and insurance Australia Group rose 3.2% after reporting strong earnings.

site_title: OCBC Q4 profit climbs 31% to S$1.03b on growth across all core businesses
summary: OCBC Bank announced its Q4 profit, beating forecasts with a 31% jump to S$1.03 billion, driven by sustained growth across its banking, wealth management, and insurance segments. The group's net interest income grew 14% to S$1.42 billion, while non-interest income rose 30% to S$1.21 billion. OCBC proposed a final tax-exempt dividend of 19 cents per share, up from 18 cents last year. The bank's funding and liquidity position remained resilient, with customer loans rising 8% to S$237 billion.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rebound at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rebounded at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index climbing 0.7% to 7,220.78 points, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 gaining 0.8% to 12,294.85 points. The rebound was driven by solid German economic growth, with the country's economy expanding 0.6% between October and December. Investors await US inflation numbers for clues on interest rate rises, which have been a major concern for global markets.

site_title: South Korea to take dispute on US steel anti-dumping duties to WTO
summary: South Korea's trade ministry announced it will file a dispute with the World Trade Organization (WTO) against the US for imposing high anti-dumping duties on Korean steel and transformers. The duties, up to 60.81%, were imposed in 2016 using the Adverse Facts Available (AFA) provision, which the ministry claims was unfairly applied. The move comes amid increased US efforts to protect its industry, including the renegotiation of free trade agreements. South Korea's trade chief will seek a bilateral discussion with the US under the WTO agreement.

site_title: Chinese trio proving that advertising is cool again
summary: Chinese online advertising market has seen significant growth, with Weibo, Sina, and Baidu reporting strong ad-revenue increases. Weibo's ad-revenue rose 77% in the fourth quarter, while Sina's grew 16.5% and Baidu's 33%. Notably, these increases were driven by economies of scale, not excessive marketing budgets, unlike Alibaba's 90% increase in sales and marketing spend. Increased mobile engagement also contributed to the growth, with Baidu's mobile app usage rising 30%. This turnaround suggests advertising is "cool again" in China.

site_title: Sunseap International, InfraCo Asia to jointly develop solar project in Vietnam
summary: Sunseap International and InfraCo Asia Development have signed an agreement to jointly develop a 168 megawatt-peak solar power project in Vietnam's Ninh Thuan province. The project, one of the country's first large-scale solar projects, is expected to generate enough electricity to power 200,000 households annually. InfraCo Asia will provide funding, while Sunseap International will hold a majority stake. The project is expected to create jobs during construction and sustain 30 long-term positions when operational. The solar project aims to promote green energy investments in Vietnam and support the country's transition to cleaner energy.

site_title: Economists maintain view of moderated 2018 growth after forecast-beating 2017
summary: Singapore's economy grew 3.6% in 2017, beating expectations, and economists maintain a view of moderated 2018 growth. United Overseas Bank raised its 2018 GDP forecast to 2.8% due to potential trade protectionist measures and semiconductor sales growth peaking in 2017. DBS economist Irvin Seah expects 2018 growth to moderate to 3.0% as the manufacturing sector cools, while the services sector benefits from a global recovery. The Monetary Authority of Singapore may end its neutral stance this year due to strong economic growth and a bottoming-out labor market.

site_title: Uber loss leapt to US$4.5b in 2017 as final quarter showed hope
summary: Uber reported a significant increase in losses to $4.5 billion in 2017, up from $2.8 billion in 2016. However, the final quarter of 2017 showed signs of improvement, with a loss of $1.1 billion and revenue growth to $2.22 billion. Freshly appointed CEO Dara Khosrowshahi has implemented cost-cutting measures and is steering the company towards a stock market debut in 2019. Uber also settled a lawsuit with Waymo, agreeing to pay $244 million and refrain from using the company's autonomous driving technology.

site_title: Food group Danone to sell 14% stake in Japan's Yakult
summary: Danone, a French food group, plans to sell a 14% stake in Japanese probiotics maker Yakult, which could fetch 1.5 billion euros. The sale is part of Danone's efforts to boost shareholder returns amid investor pressure. The French group will retain a 7% stake in Yakult and participate in a 36 billion Japanese yen share buyback program. The move comes after Danone sold its dairy business Stonyfield to Lactalis last year and faces challenges in its European dairy business. The sale is expected to be settled in March.

site_title: Malaysia Q4 GDP grows 5.9% y-o-y, 2017's pace hit three-year high
summary: Malaysia's economy expanded 5.9% in Q4 2017, surpassing expectations and reaching a three-year high. The country's full-year growth for 2017 was also 5.9%, its best result since 2014. Domestic demand drove growth, with private consumption and capital spending increasing. The central bank attributed the growth to wage and employment gains. However, analysts expect growth to slow down this year, citing declining export growth and large Chinese-backed infrastructure projects. The ringgit currency strengthened 12.8% against the dollar in the past year.

site_title: Japan posts longest growth streak since bubble economy
summary: Japan's economy has experienced its longest continuous expansion since the 1980s, with eight straight quarters of growth in October-December. The expansion was driven by robust consumer spending, exports, and capital expenditure, and is seen as a positive sign for the Bank of Japan's inflation target of 2%. Economists expect growth to continue, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's policies, including labor market reforms, showing fruit. The economy expanded at a 0.5% annualized rate, less than the median estimate.

site_title: Texan fights to save remaining son - who plotted his family's murder
summary: A Texas man, Kent Whitaker, is fighting to save his son, Bart, who plotted and executed the murder of his family in 2003. Bart, who was 19 at the time, had hired a gunman to kill his parents and brother, and was motivated by a desire to seize an inheritance. Despite being convicted of murder and sentenced to death, Bart has been working to reform himself and has been deemed a model inmate. Kent Whitaker, who has become a vocal advocate for his son's clemency, is now seeking to save his son's life, citing his own personal forgiveness and Bart's efforts to change.

site_title: Tesla's China dream threatened by standoff over Shanghai factory
summary: Tesla's efforts to establish a factory in China are stalled due to a disagreement over ownership structure with the Shanghai government. The central government requires a joint venture with local partners, while Tesla wants to own the factory completely. This delay puts Tesla at risk of being relegated to an expensive niche in China, where domestic rivals such as BYD and NIO are gaining ground with cheaper models. Tesla's sluggishness in local manufacturing means it's missing out on China's lucrative market for new-energy vehicles, with the government offering billions of dollars in subsidies to encourage consumers to switch to electric cars.

site_title: Automakers to provide up to US$130m for Takata's US settlement
summary: Thirteen automakers have agreed to contribute up to $130 million to compensate those injured by faulty Takata air bag inflators. The deal clears the way for the sale of Takata's non-inflator business for $1.6 billion, ensuring a steady supply of car parts. The automakers will also contribute to a $125 million compensation fund and can offset judgments with payments from a $850 million restitution fund. Honda will create a trust to compensate for its vehicles, shielding itself from further lawsuits and punitive damages.

site_title: Singapore, Egypt sign fintech cooperation pact
summary: Singapore and Egypt have signed a fintech cooperation pact, allowing the two countries to refer fintech companies to each other for better understanding of regulatory regimes. The agreement also establishes a framework for joint innovation projects and sharing of information on emerging trends. This move aims to accelerate the growth of fintech through collaboration and knowledge-sharing between the two countries, creating more opportunities for fintech firms.

site_title: DBS, OCBC, UOB all post double-digit growth for Q4 FY17
summary: Singapore's three major banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, posted double-digit profit growth for Q4 FY17. DBS and OCBC saw a 31% increase in net profit, while UOB raised net profit by 9%. For the year, OCBC grew 19% to S$4.1 billion, UOB by 9% to S$3.4 billion, and DBS by 3% to S$4.4 billion. DBS also increased its dividend payouts, offering a 5.18% yield. The banks' strong performance reflects the country's robust financial sector.

site_title: Singapore notches record US$229m fintech funding in '17: KPMG
summary: Singapore achieved a record high of US$229.1 million in fintech funding in 2017, according to KPMG's Pulse of Fintech report. This was largely driven by US$122.75 million of funding in the fourth quarter. Despite a decline in the number of deals, the average deal size increased to US$7.9 million, surpassing the 2016 average of US$5.9 million.

site_title: iFAST Q4 earnings more than double to S$2.5m on higher revenue
summary: iFAST Corporation Ltd reported a 125% increase in net profit to S$2.5 million in its Q4 earnings, driven by higher revenue from product offerings. Revenue rose 30.8% to S$28.2 million, with annual net profit increasing by 65.9% to S$9.04 million. The company expects a higher dividend per share for fiscal 2018. iFAST's shares remained unchanged at S$0.88.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Wednesday, advancing 0.6% to 3,434.28, following a rebound on Wall Street. The Straits Times Index gained 19.21 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 91 to 34, with DBS and OCBC Bank leading the gains. The market saw significant trading volume, with 52.7 million shares changing hands.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip ahead of US inflation data; NZ follows suit
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.1% to 5,847.5 ahead of US inflation data, as gains in healthcare and IT sectors were overshadowed by losses in financials. The financial index fell 0.8% due to a US rate hike, which makes high-dividend stocks less attractive. Healthcare stocks rose, with CSL jumping 6% after reporting a 35% profit increase. New Zealand shares also fell 0.5% due to Fletcher Building's decline.

site_title: Tokyo stocks open higher as sentiment improves
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on February 14, 2018, as investor sentiment improved despite a stronger yen. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.16% to 21,277.94, while the Topix index increased 0.26%. US stocks closed higher on Tuesday, supporting Japanese shares, but a higher yen discouraged investors. Key movers included Rakuten, Nintendo, and Sony, while Toyota and Panasonic fell. The dollar traded at 107.76 yen in early Asian trade.

site_title: United Airlines plane lands in Hawaii after engine covering rips apart
summary: A United Airlines flight from San Francisco to Honolulu experienced a scare on Tuesday when the casing around one of its engines ripped apart over the Pacific Ocean. The Boeing 777, carrying over 370 people, landed safely at Honolulu International Airport after the pilots declared an emergency due to a vibration in the right engine. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) will investigate the incident, and passengers described the experience as the "scariest flight of my life."

site_title: Gold climbs as dollar weakens ahead of US inflation data
summary: Gold prices rose 0.4% to $1,327.52 per ounce ahead of US inflation data, as the US dollar weakened. The dollar's decline provided support for gold, which had previously pulled back nearly 2% from its one-month low. Investors anticipate the inflation data, which may influence future interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. Silver, platinum, and palladium also rose, with palladium up 0.2% despite a 14% decline since its record high in January.

site_title: Franklin Templeton favours Australia bonds, bets RBA on hold
summary: Franklin Templeton Investments predicts the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) will keep interest rates at record lows in 2018, citing controlled inflation. The bank's governor, Philip Lowe, has expressed a lack of urgency to raise rates, instead focusing on reducing the jobless rate and moving inflation to the midpoint of its target range. This outlook is in contrast to swap traders, who expect a 60% chance of a rate hike in December. Franklin Templeton favors Australian bonds over US bonds, with the Australian dollar expected to trade between 78-80 US cents in 2018.

site_title: Paris Grand Palais to get facelift
summary: France has unveiled a €450 million (S$815 million) renovation project for the Paris Grand Palais, transforming the complex into a pedestrian-friendly hub. The overhaul will link the Champs Elysees with the River Seine, opening up the space for galleries, exhibitions, and the Palace of Discoveries science museum. The project aims to revitalize the area, providing a new public space for Parisians and tourists alike.

site_title: Singapore economy expanded 3.6% in 2017; slower growth expected this year
summary: Singapore's economy expanded 3.6% in 2017, exceeding initial estimates, driven by strong growth in the manufacturing sector. The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) expects growth to moderate but remain firm in 2018, with a forecast of 1.5 to 3.5% this year. The manufacturing sector, particularly electronics and precision engineering, is expected to continue growing, while externally-oriented services sectors are also expected to benefit from firm external demand.

site_title: Oil prices flat on oversupply concerns, weak dollar
summary: Oil prices ended unchanged on Tuesday, despite a weaker dollar, after the International Energy Agency forecasted supply could outstrip demand. US crude inventories rose 3.9 million barrels, exceeding expectations. Brent futures hit a two-month low but settled at $62.72 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures closed at $59.19 a barrel, down 10 cents. The oversupply concerns and dollar weakness led to a rebound from an early slide.

site_title: US: Stocks end higher for third straight day
summary: US stocks rose for a third straight day, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.2% to 24,640.45, the S&P 500 gaining 0.3% to 2,662.94, and the Nasdaq Composite Index advancing 0.5% to 7,013.51. The gains came ahead of a closely-watched US inflation report, indicating somewhat better investor sentiment.

site_title: World Class Global sinks further into the red with full-year loss of S$9m
summary: World Class Global, an overseas real estate arm of Aspial Corporation, posted a full-year net loss of S$9 million from S$6.3 million a year ago. The loss was mainly due to increased employee benefits, listing expenses, and higher holding costs. The company's loss per share was 1.04 Singapore cents, down from 0.79 cents in FY2016. Despite no revenue from the sale of development properties, the group expects to receive S$700 million in sales proceeds from ongoing projects in Australia.

site_title: Japan sticking with Kuroda will bring policy continuity
summary: The Bank of Japan is expected to maintain its radical easing policies under the leadership of Haruhiko Kuroda, who will likely be reappointed as governor. Deputy governors Masayoshi Amamiya and Etsuro Honda will also be appointed, with Amamiya and Honda being closely aligned with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's reflationary agenda. Analysts expect the BOJ to continue easing monetary policy in the short term, but may make adjustments in the future as inflation remains subdued and global peers normalize monetary policy.

site_title: CBRE hires Troy Shortell to lead supply chain advisory business in Asia
summary: CBRE has hired Troy Shortell as executive director of its supply chain advisory business in Asia. Shortell, with 25 years of regional industry experience, joins from AssuranceBox and Veracity, bringing expertise in supply chain management from roles at DHL, CEVA, and Havi Logistics. The appointment complements CBRE's existing transaction execution and project management services, enabling clients to better secure facilities that meet evolving requirements. Shortell will be based in Singapore, further building CBRE's supply chain practice capabilities in the region.

site_title: As Boeing weighs new 797, Delta wants to fly the jet first
summary: Delta Air Lines is expressing confidence in Boeing's new mid-sized jetliner, dubbed the 797, and wants to be a launch customer, according to CEO Ed Bastian. The airline views the plane as a potential replacement for its aging fleet of Boeing 757s and 767s. Delta recently ordered 100 Airbus A321neo jets, but Bastian's statement suggests the carrier is committed to Boeing. The 797's development cost is estimated to be between $10 billion and $15 billion, with two models being considered: a 225-seat version with a 5,000-mile range and a 275-seat version with a 4,500-mile range.

site_title: Coincheck users pull 40.1b yen in first chance since hack
summary: Coincheck users withdrew 40.1 billion yen ($489.13 million) from the cryptocurrency exchange on its first day of allowing yen withdrawals after a $500 million cyber-theft in January. The exchange, which had previously promised to compensate users, is considering capital alliances and has engaged a third-party firm to verify its security before resuming full operations. Coincheck's chief operating officer, Yusuke Otsuka, stated that the business will continue and has the necessary funding, but faces a review by Japan's Financial Services Agency to decide whether to grant a license.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip as skepticism looms on recovery
summary: European shares fell 0.6% on Tuesday, as investors remained skeptical about a recovery, despite strong corporate results. The US S&P 500 also dipped slightly, ahead of data on US inflation that could revive concerns over inflation and interest rate hikes.

site_title: CapitaLand acquires historic Pearl Bank in S$728m collective sale
summary: CapitaLand acquired the historic Pearl Bank Apartments in a collective sale for S$728 million, planning to redevelop the site into an 800-unit condominium project. This marks a significant development after a four-year hiatus, with the site's high demand driven by limited land availability in Singapore. The acquisition comes as land prices have increased, with developers facing keen bidding. The redevelopment project is expected to boost the condominium market in Singapore.

site_title: Singapore non-oil exports up 8.8% in 2017, forecast for 2018 revised upwards
summary: Singapore's non-oil exports rose 8.8% in 2017, the highest growth rate in seven years, surpassing the earlier forecast of 6.5-7%. The 2018 forecast has been revised upwards, with non-oil domestic exports (NODX) expected to grow 1-3% and total trade 3-5%. Favourable trends in machinery and chemicals, as well as a slight global growth pick-up, are driving the optimism. However, growth is expected to ease for some key trade partners, such as China and Japan.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: TUI Group says summer trading good, on track to hike profits
summary: TUI Group reported strong summer trading, with bookings for Greece, Turkey, and Cyprus increasing, and is on track to hike profits by at least 10% this year. The company narrowed its underlying core loss by over half to 25.4 million euros in the first quarter, thanks to its hotels and cruises businesses. CEO Fritz Joussen stated that Q1 2018 has shown TUI is on track to continue growing.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing continues to outshine services in Q4, but shows clear signs of slowing down
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector continued to drive economic growth in Q4 2017, with a 4.8% year-on-year growth, but at a slower pace than the 19.1% in the previous quarter. The electronics and precision engineering clusters contributed to the growth, while the transport engineering and biomedical engineering clusters were negatively affected. The services sector grew 3.5% in Q4, driven by a strong construction sector, which contracted 5% year-on-year. Manufacturing accounted for 10.1% of 2017's growth, while services grew 2.8%.

site_title: New 3-tier global trade system may be worth considering
summary: A new three-tier global trade system may be worth considering to address economic malaise in the Western world, driven by stagnant wages and rising inequality. The system would include tier one countries (developed and non-threatening nations), tier two countries (developing economies with protections for workers), and tier three countries (remaining nations with bilateral agreements and economic sanctions). This tiered system aims to provide incentives for political change, improve standards of living, and calibrate change in tier one countries, potentially mitigating the disruptions caused by China's rise.

site_title: Yen hits five-month high as US dollar extends fall
summary: The Japanese yen rose to a five-month high against the US dollar, gaining 1.5% this month, amid speculation that the Bank of Japan may dial back record levels of monetary stimulus. The yen's rally reversed some of the US dollar's gains of last week, as investors sought safer currencies amid market volatility. The yen's high of 107.42 yen surpasses its previous peak in September 2016, and the euro rose 0.5% to 132.83 yen, while emerging market currencies remained stable.

site_title: Amazon laying off hundreds after years-long hiring spree
summary: Amazon is laying off hundreds of workers in its Seattle headquarters and globally, reversing a years-long trend of rapid hiring and expansion. The company, which added nearly 130,000 employees last year, will cut "a few hundred" positions in Seattle and hundreds more worldwide. This move comes as Amazon shifts focus to rapidly-growing sectors, trimming sections of its existing retail business. The layoffs are part of a broader restructuring effort by the online giant.

site_title: What higher oil prices might mean for Asean economies
summary: Asean economies face potential implications from higher oil prices, with concerns about growth recovery, inflation, and fiscal balance sheets. As oil prices approach $70/bbl, there is a risk of hurting growth and posing upside risks to inflation, potentially leading to policy rate hikes. The region's economies are in a growth cycle, with inflation still manageable, but higher oil prices could alter this trajectory. The impact on trade, fiscal balance sheets, and policy rates will be closely monitored.

site_title: Sterling rises after UK inflation beats expectations
summary: The British pound strengthened on Tuesday after inflation data showed it remained at 3.0% in January, beating expectations and solidifying bets for a Bank of England interest rate hike in May. Sterling rose to a high of US$1.3924, up 0.4% on the day, following the BoE's previous indication of faster rate hikes to bring inflation back to 2% within two years. Analysts expect the pound to continue its long-term uptrend, with a downside limit of US$1.34.

site_title: Opioid makers paid millions to advocacy groups: US Senate report
summary: US Senate report reveals that five opioid manufacturers, including Purdue Pharma, paid over $10 million to advocacy groups and doctors who amplified industry messages supporting the use of painkillers. These groups may have contributed to the 2016 opioid overdose deaths that reached 42,000. The donations were made in an attempt to align with industry goals and promote the use of opioids, raising concerns about the role of these groups in the opioid epidemic.

site_title: SembMarine rebounds following late Monday selloff
summary: SembMarine's shares surged 5% on Tuesday after closing 12 Singapore cents higher at S$2.49 following a query from the Singapore Exchange over a 12% fall in its stock price on February 12. The company responded it was unaware of any information or possible explanation for the unusual trading activities. DBS Equity Research maintained its "buy" rating, citing a potential role for SembMarine in a Norwegian petroleum conglomerate's FPSO vessel project, which could be worth more than US$1 billion.

site_title: Dutch PM overwhelmingly survives vote of no-confidence
summary: Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte has survived a no-confidence vote by a large margin, with 101 MPs voting against and 43 in favor. The vote came after Foreign Minister Halbe Zijlstra admitted to lying about a key meeting, prompting his resignation. The rare motion was brought by far-right MP Geert Wilders, who criticized the scandal as "unacceptable". Rutte's four-party coalition has a one-seat majority, but his survival of the vote suggests stability in the Dutch government for now.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific's Q4 net profit falls 39%
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings' Q4 net profit fell 38.9% to S$7.3 million, down from the previous year, due to lower revenue from developments in Singapore and an absence of revenue from completed projects. Revenue for the quarter plummeted 53.5% to S$43.3 million. The company plans to launch six development sites in Singapore in FY2018, focusing on sustainable long-term growth.

site_title: Dutch shipping bosses in court over 'toxic' ship dumping
summary: Six Dutch shipping company bosses face court over allegedly dumping old ships on Indian and Turkish beaches in 2012, violating European waste transfer laws. The companies, part of the Seatrade group, could face fines of up to 750,000 euros and prison sentences of up to six months. Investigations found that the vessels contained hazardous substances, including bunker oil and asbestos, which must be treated as toxic waste before being dismantled. The incident is similar to the 2006 dumping of toxic waste from the Probo Koala freighter in the Ivory Coast.

site_title: Former NZ PM Bill English quits politics after election loss
summary: Former New Zealand Prime Minister Bill English has announced his retirement from politics, citing the need for a new leader to return to government in 2020. English, 56, will resign as National Party leader on February 27 and leave Parliament early next month. Despite narrowly losing the 2017 election to Labour's Jacinda Ardern, English believes his party has the talent and energy to regain power. National will select a new leader in the coming weeks, with potential successors including Simon Bridges and Paula Bennett.

site_title: Needy bag 'blessings and joy' this CNY
summary: More than 6,000 "fu dais" or bags of blessings and joy containing essential food items were distributed to underprivileged seniors and families in Singapore to support the Chinese New Year. The event, co-organised with Heartwarmers and supported by Standard Chartered Singapore and other corporate partners, aimed to bring festive cheer to those in need. The Community Chest and SG Cares movement inspired the event, which also saw the launch of a new mobile app to connect volunteers with volunteering opportunities.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

site_title: Property earnings and oil prices stir trade
summary: Singapore stocks finished up for the second day, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 30.09 points, or 0.89%, to 3,415.07, driven by investor interest in local banks. CapitaLand, Bukit Sembawang Estates, and Koh Brothers Eco Engineering saw gains, while Hatten Land lost 0.2 Singapore cent. Oil prices remain volatile ahead of official numbers, affecting companies like Mermaid Maritime and Marco Polo Marine. Asian markets were mostly up, with the Hang Seng and Shanghai Composite gaining, while the Nikkei fell.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: New loans by Chinese banks surge to record 2.9t yuan in Jan
summary: Chinese banks extended a record 2.9 trillion yuan in new loans in January, nearly five times the previous month's figure, as policymakers aim to sustain economic growth while reining in debt risks. This surge in demand from both households and companies suggests a strong outlook for consumption and investment. The figure surpassed economists' most bullish forecast, indicating a sharp rise in credit demand.

site_title: What if oil prices stay higher for longer?
summary: Oil prices are expected to have a mixed impact on ASEAN economies, particularly Malaysia, where higher prices will bolster the current account surplus, but pose a drag on Indonesia and the Philippines. Inflation is also expected to rise, but mitigating factors such as fuel subsidies and currency appreciation will help. Central banks are likely to normalize policy rates, with the most upside risk to the Philippines. Higher oil prices will also affect fiscal balances, with Malaysia and Indonesia running fuel subsidies, while Indonesia's subsidy burden may rise in a non-linear manner.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, UOB, SIA, Comfort DelGro, Marco Polo Marine
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

OCBC Bank reported a 31% increase in Q4 net profit to S$1.03 billion, while UOB saw a 16% rise in net profit to S$855 million. Singapore Airlines' Q3 net profit soared 61.5% to S$286.1 million. ComfortDelGro Corp's net earnings dropped 4.9% to S$301.5 million, and Marco Polo Marine posted a net loss of S$6.64 million. The banks are recommending final dividends, while Singapore Airlines is expected to increase its dividend payout. The companies' Q4 results may affect trading of their shares.

site_title: UN aviation agency warns of looming pilot shortage
summary: The International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) warns that hundreds of thousands of pilots will need to be trained by 2036 to meet growing air transport demand, with the number of commercial flights and passengers forecast to double in the next 15 years. The workforce contraction is attributed to aging populations, lower birth rates, and other attrition factors.

site_title: Trump seeks to shift Energy Dept priorities with clean energy cuts
summary: The Trump administration's fiscal 2019 budget proposal would increase spending at the Energy Department by 1.3% to $30.6 billion, with a focus on nuclear security. The National Nuclear Security Administration would receive a 17.5% increase, from $12.8 billion to $15.1 billion. In contrast, funding for renewable energy and energy efficiency programs would be slashed. The budget prioritizes nuclear security over clean energy, marking a shift in the department's priorities.

images.alt_text: The Trump administration requests US$696 million for the Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy programme - a 66% cut from the 2017 budget.

site_title: British government seeks to win over Brexit detractors at home and in Europe
summary: The British government is launching a campaign to persuade EU and domestic detractors that Brexit can have positive outcomes. Cabinet members, including Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson and Prime Minister Theresa May, will make visits to EU countries and the UK to highlight the UK's security partnership, trade deals, and impact on Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. The efforts come ahead of March talks with the EU.

site_title: Quad dialogue group gives India chance to grow military ties
summary: India has welcomed the Quadrilateral Security Dialogue, a military alliance with the US, Japan, and Australia, but cautions it must address existential questions, including how to handle China. The Quad aims to promote peace, stability, and prosperity in the Indo-Pacific region, but faces challenges such as safeguarding Indian security interests and establishing a rules-based world order. The alliance needs to take decisive steps, including developing physical infrastructure and cooperating on freedom of navigation, to counter China's growing military power and Belt and Road Initiative.

site_title: No rise in claims for flood damage, say car insurers
summary: Singapore motor insurance companies have not seen an increase in flood-related claims in December and January, with minimal claims reported by AXA Insurance and NTUC Income. Despite heavy rain causing flash floods in various areas, motorists are generally careful when driving in affected zones, and insurers do not foresee a significant impact on claim experience. However, AXA Insurance's Ankush Bhardwaj notes that flood risk is a factor considered when pricing motor insurance, and premiums may increase if the frequency of flash floods increases.

site_title: Asia's central banks grapple with ageing populations
summary: Asia's central banks face significant demographic challenges, particularly in South Korea, Thailand, Taiwan, Japan, and Singapore, where ageing populations will lead to smaller workforces and reduced economic growth. The issue cannot be easily addressed by monetary policy, and governments are expected to implement structural policies and increased immigration to mitigate the effects. By 2030, the 60-and-older population is projected to make up 17% of Asia's population, approaching the size of the younger-than-15 crowd. Central bankers acknowledge the need for fiscal policy solutions, but ultimately, governments must take action to address the demographic shift.

site_title: US intelligence chiefs say Russia meddling threatens 2018 vote
summary: US intelligence chiefs stated that Russia's meddling in US politics continues, posing a threat to the mid-term congressional elections in November. They also warned of a potential "existential threat" from North Korea's nuclear programme. The chiefs, including Mr Coats and heads of the CIA, FBI, and NSA, agreed that Russia's efforts to disrupt US politics are as intense now as they were in the 2016 presidential election.

site_title: MAS sets out e-payment guidelines for banks, consumers
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has outlined guidelines for banks and consumers regarding e-payment transactions, setting a six-month timeline for banks to notify customers of transactions. The guidelines, set to be published in the first half of 2018, outline customers' liabilities in the event of unauthorised transactions and banks' responsibilities in notifying customers. Account holders who take reasonable measures to protect their accounts will not be liable, but those found careless may be liable for up to S$100.

site_title: CapitaLand eyes AUM of S$100b by 2020 and S$3b in capital recycling each year
summary: CapitaLand aims to increase its total assets under management (AUM) to S$100 billion by 2020, growing at a rate of S$3 billion per year through capital recycling. The company plans to achieve this by co-investing with funds or managing assets on behalf of funds without taking on equity stakes. This will free up capital for new investments and drive growth in return on equity (ROE), which reached 8.5% in 2017. Divesting S$3 billion of investment properties annually will also unlock value from stabilised assets, with more recycling likely to occur in Singapore and China.

site_title: Gucci fever boosts Kering's fourth-quarter sales growth
summary: Kering, the luxury goods group, reported a 27.4% year-on-year increase in fourth-quarter sales, driven by strong demand from Chinese consumers. Gucci, a key brand under Kering, saw comparable sales growth of nearly 43% in the quarter, beating rival brands. The company's overall revenues rose to 4.26 billion euros, beating analyst forecasts. Kering's adjusted operating income rose 56.3% for 2017, driven by growth at Gucci and other brands. The company expects to continue outperforming the market in 2018 despite uncertain global conditions.

site_title: Latest research shows Snapchat has US kids hooked
summary: Snapchat has maintained its advantage among US kids, with a 72% rise in quarterly revenue that beat analysts' forecasts. Despite Instagram's feature copying, Snapchat's younger audience and safeguards against poor placement drive enthusiasm for advertising on the app. Research firm eMarketer estimates Snapchat will add 1.9 million Americans under 25 this year, while Instagram will add 1.6 million. This demographic advantage is expected to widen, making businesses feel obligated to spend on Snapchat.

site_title: Mugabe's fall has veteran miners jockeying for Zimbabwe comeback
summary: Veteran miners Andrew Groves and Phil Edmonds are preparing to relist their Zimbabwe coal, chrome, and gold assets in London through a reverse takeover of a cash shell company. The move comes after Emmerson Mnangagwa, a former spy chief and longtime ally of former President Robert Mugabe, took office in November and abolished rules requiring mining operations to be at least 51% owned by black Zimbabweans. The new company aims to build a mid-tier mining business, with coal production expected to begin before the end of the year.

site_title: SATS reports uptick in Q3 profit despite challenging environment
summary: SATS, a Singapore-based ground handler and in-flight catering service provider, reported a small uptick in its fiscal third-quarter earnings to S$66.6 million, despite a 0.2% year-on-year dip in revenue to S$439.8 million. Revenue from gateway services increased 2.6%, while food solutions revenue fell 2.5%. Operating profit fell 1.5%, but overseas operations contributed 7.9% to after-tax profits. Despite a challenging environment, SATS' performance is considered "resilient".

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: RHT reaches agreement to sell portfolio to Fortis
summary: RHT Health Trust has agreed to sell its entire portfolio of healthcare assets to Fortis Healthcare for 46.5 billion Indian rupees (S$950 million). The sale includes 12 clinics, four greenfield clinics, and two operating hospitals in India. The consideration represents a premium of 10.3% to the trust's adjusted net asset value per unit and a return of 65.5%. Fortis, India's second-largest healthcare provider, will distribute the bulk of the net proceeds to unitholders. The deal is subject to the advice of KPMG as an independent financial adviser.

site_title: Weaker taxi business drags ComfortDelGro earnings down
summary: ComfortDelGro Corp, a Singapore-based transport giant, reported a 4.9% drop in net earnings to S$301.5 million for 2017 due to weaker contributions from its taxi division, stiff competition in overseas markets, and foreign exchange losses. Revenue shrank 2.2% to S$3.97 billion, and operating expenses rose 1%. The group's taxi operating profit fell 19.3% to S$135.1 million, while its bus and train division saw a 0.4% rise in operating profit.

images.alt_text: Christopher Tan

site_title: Technology critical to driving change in work culture
summary: Involving firstline workers in digital transformation can drive unprecedented opportunities for workers, companies, and society. The modern workplace requires companies to invest in culture development and adopt new technologies to empower employees. A study by Microsoft Asia Workplace 2020 found that more than three-quarters of workers in Singapore felt that more can be done by their organisations to invest in culture development. Companies such as Asiawide Print Holdings and Puma have successfully implemented digital transformation, enabling their firstline workers to work more efficiently and effectively. As technology continues to evolve, leaders must take an active role in shaping an open workplace culture that fosters collaboration, agility, and trust.

site_title: Striking a share swap ratio can be a delicate balancing act
summary: A merger between Viva Industrial Trust (VIT) and ESR-Reit is challenging due to market volatility. VIT's unit price has fallen 9% since February, but its premium over book value remains high, making a "perfect" share swap ratio difficult to determine. Analysts, such as DBS senior vice-president Derek Tan, estimate that a swap price close to current trading prices could be necessary to make the deal accretive to both sets of unitholders. The ideal ratio is around 1.6 to 1.7 new ESR-Reit units for every VIT unit to avoid dilution.

site_title: Maersk rolls out digitisation strategy in bid to stop customers from turning into rivals
summary: AP Moller Maersk, the world's largest container shipping line, is implementing a digitization strategy to improve delivery services and provide better information to customers like Amazon. CEO Soren Skou aims to combine Maersk's container activities with Amazon's needs, offering an integrated supply chain. The company is using blockchain technology and has reduced booking times from 2 hours to 22 minutes in two years. Maersk's goal is to provide seamless end-to-end container shipping, which could also speed up automation across supply chains and make it harder for competitors like Amazon to enter the market.

site_title: Keppel O&M unit served summons in new law suit by EIG
summary: Keppel O&M's offshore and marine unit has been served with a summons in a US$660 million racketeering suit filed by EIG Global Energy Partners and its managed funds in New York's federal court. The suit concerns Keppel's role in a Brazilian bribery scheme connected to a failed drill ship venture. Keppel's unit maintains that the reported cause of action is without merit and will vigorously defend itself. The suit is related to a previous settlement reached by Keppel's parent company, Keppel Corp, for a US$422 million bribe payment.

site_title: Google hires former Samsung exec to coordinate IoT projects
summary: Google has hired Injong Rhee, former Samsung Electronics Co's chief technology officer, to lead its Internet of Things (IoT) business. Rhee will serve as entrepreneur-in-residence under Diane Greene, aiming to harmonize Alphabet's various IoT projects and create distinct consumer and enterprise product lines. This move is part of Google's growing effort in the IoT space, which encompasses devices like self-driving cars, home appliances, and weather sensors. Rhee's experience at Samsung, where he led the launch of the company's Knox security system and Bixby digital assistant, will likely contribute to Google's IoT endeavors.

site_title: Immigrant's daughter wows the Games and the world
summary: Chloe Kim, a 17-year-old American snowboarder, won the gold medal in the halfpipe event at the Winter Olympics. She impressed the crowd with her talent and charisma, scoring a 98.25 on her final run. Kim's victory was seen as a significant moment for American snowboarding, and she is expected to become a prominent figure in the sport. Her parents, South Korean immigrants, were in attendance, and Kim credited her father with introducing her to snowboarding at a young age.

site_title: Iraq aims to raise its oil output to 7m barrels a day by 2022
summary: Iraq aims to increase its oil production to 7 million barrels a day by 2022, according to Oil Minister Jabbar al-Luaybi. The country currently produces around 4.7 million barrels per day under an OPEC output cut agreement. Iraq's proven crude reserves are estimated at 145 billion barrels, which could increase to 250 billion barrels with sufficient investment. The nation also plans to boost natural gas production to 7 billion cubic feet per day by 2021.

site_title: Security ITM to boost tech, sourcing, skills in industry
summary: Singapore is launching the Security Industry Transformation Map (ITM) to boost the security industry by promoting tech solutions and improving skills. The initiative, led by the Ministry of Home Affairs, aims to move away from just supplying manpower and encourage the use of technology. The plan includes outcome-based security contracts, risk assessments, and training programs for procurement staff. The government will invest S$10 million over three years to support the initiative, and most government agencies will adopt outcome-based contracts by 2020.

site_title: Lotte chief embroiled in influence-peddling scandal sentenced to 20 years jail
summary: Lotte Group chairman Shin Dong Bin was sentenced to 2 years and 6 months in prison for his role in an influence-peddling scandal involving former South Korean President Park Geun Hye and her confidante Choi Soon Sil. Choi was sentenced to 20 years in jail for receiving bribes from companies including Samsung. The verdict creates a leadership vacuum at Lotte, a major South Korean conglomerate, amid mounting losses in its China operations.

site_title: SIA reports higher Q3 profit
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported a 61.5% surge in net profit to S$286.1 million in Q3, driven by higher passenger and cargo revenues. The airline's operating profit rose to S$329.4 million, despite competition from rival carriers and rising fuel prices. SIA flagged these challenges, but said its three-year transformation programme is "well on track" and is already bearing fruit. The airline also expects to benefit from hedging its fuel requirements and investing in new aircraft.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: With more floods, call for better business continuity umbrellas
summary: Singapore is experiencing more frequent and intense flash floods due to climate change, posing significant risks to businesses. Experts recommend companies develop better business continuity plans to mitigate the impact of floods, including alternative operational processes, flood emergency response plans, and measures to prevent floods. The government has spent $1.2 billion on drainage improvement works, but private sector efforts are lacking.
