Companies must consider protecting valuable equipment, reviewing supply chains, and preparing for rising sea levels and changing social behavior, including increased regulations and consumer awareness of sustainability.

site_title: Two firms land deal to conduct on-demand bus trials
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) of Singapore has awarded contracts to Via Transportation and Ministry of Movement to conduct on-demand bus trials, worth S$466,194.50. The two firms, with proven track records in on-demand ride-sharing, will develop dynamic matching and routing algorithms and conduct simulations to refine the service standard. The trial, in two phases, aims to test and calibrate software and hardware solutions, with the operational trial to begin in the fourth quarter of this year.

site_title: Global growth outlook seen intact as stock market rebounds
summary: Wall Street rebounded on Monday, preserving investors' optimistic outlook on the global economy, which analysts expect to continue growing at a steady pace. Factors contributing to this growth include China's high single-digit growth, Europe's recovery from sovereign debt woes, and US tax cuts and increased spending. Despite a two-week market turbulence, analysts consider it a "modest" risk, and the current correction is expected to be short and shallow.

site_title: Star Alliance, Accenture launch digital services platform
summary: Star Alliance and Accenture have launched a digital services platform to enhance travel experiences for its 28-member airlines. The platform allows data sharing and can be integrated into member airlines' digital applications. Currently, Lufthansa and United Airlines are using the platform, with features such as seat selection and baggage tracking available for customers. The goal is to enable seamless travel across the network, with a single app or website controlling the entire travel experience for frequent travellers.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Time to consider tech for tax compliance
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat is expected to announce sweeping changes to the Goods and Services Tax (GST) regime, including a possible rate hike and an e-commerce tax on cross-border online transactions. Tax compliance costs are expected to rise, with businesses spending an average of 60 hours a year on manual data extraction and tax returns. The government is urging businesses to adopt technology for tax compliance, citing the benefits of automated tax reporting solutions and data analytics to reduce errors and increase efficiency.

site_title: M1 announces board reshuffle, appoints new non-executive independent director
summary: M1 Limited has announced a board reshuffle, appointing Tan Wah Yeow as a non-executive independent director, effective February 13, 2018. Tan, formerly with KPMG, will join the audit, remuneration, and risk committees. Board chairman Danny Teoh will also join the remuneration and nominating committees. The appointments take effect on February 13, with M1 shares closing at S$1.80, up 1.12%.

site_title: Robots take to the slopes on sidelines of Winter Games
summary: Robots participated in the Ski Robot Challenge at the Welli Hilli ski resort in South Korea, competing in a US$10,000 prize. Eight robotics teams met specific requirements, including height, power, and ski capabilities, and were equipped with camera sensors to detect flagpoles. Teams were awarded points for flagpole avoidance and fastest time to the finish line. The event aimed to promote South Korea's robotic technology during the Pyeongchang Games, with organisers predicting robots may have their own Winter Games in the future.

site_title: Google's next Android overhaul is said to embrace the iPhone 'notch'
summary: Google is working on an Android overhaul to mimic the iPhone X's "notch" design, aiming to persuade more iPhone users to switch to Android. The update, due later this year, will integrate Google's digital assistant, improve battery life, and support new designs like multiple screens and foldable displays. The goal is to close the gap with Apple in the high-end smartphone market. However, outdated Android versions remain a security concern, and not all devices will feature the notch design.

site_title: Caveat emptor for those still in thrall of cryptocurrencies
summary: Cryptocurrency investors experienced a violent sell-off, with bitcoin briefly dipping below US$6,000, but has since recovered to around US$8,800. Despite this, the market remains volatile and speculative, with little fundamental value to determine prices. Regulators, including those in Singapore and the US, have taken a tolerant stance on virtual currencies, while some countries, like China and South Korea, have sought to ban them. The recent sell-off was also attributed to security breaches, such as the US$530 million hack on Coincheck's cryptocurrency NEM.

site_title: Assange loses bid to halt UK legal action against him
summary: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange lost a UK court bid to halt legal action against him for breaching his bail conditions in 2012, when he entered the Ecuadorean embassy in London. Assange, 46, has remained in the embassy for nearly six years, with a warrant for his arrest over the breach. A judge ruled that arresting Assange would be a proportionate response, emphasizing the need for individuals to face consequences for their actions. The decision maintains the British authorities' pursuit of Assange for breaching bail terms.

site_title: One cause of market turbulence: computer-driven index funds
summary: Computer-driven index funds, particularly exchange-traded funds (ETFs), have become a dominant force in the stock market, fueling both its rise and fall. These funds, which track financial indexes and are managed by sophisticated computer programs, now own close to 40% of US stocks, according to research by Bank of America Merrill Lynch. The increasing popularity of ETFs has concentrated financial power in the hands of a few providers, including BlackRock and Vanguard, raising concerns about the potential for market instability and the marginalization of active fund managers.

site_title: Great Eastern eyes growth markets; Q4 profit more than doubles
summary: Great Eastern, a Singapore-based insurer, reported a more than doubling in net profit in Q4 2017, driven by stronger insurance sales and gains from investments. The company aims to expand in Indonesia and Thailand, with a goal of becoming the top 10 insurer in Indonesia within five years. Its operating profit from the insurance business rose 37% to S$156.1 million, and total weighted new sales grew 36% to S$471.7 million. The group's net profit for FY2017 surged to S$1.16 billion, up from S$589.3 million the previous year.

site_title: Asia's LNG market set for shake-up
summary: Asia's liquefied natural gas (LNG) market is poised for a shake-up as buyers demand better terms from suppliers amid abundant supplies. Korea Gas Corp's arbitration move over a contract with Australian exporters may spark a wave of contractual disputes. Analysts predict more Asian cases, with over 15 LNG contracts under price review or review this year, as buyers seek to renegotiate "take or pay" clauses, destination clauses, and oil-link pricing. This shift could lead to a surge in LNG trading, similar to the European gas market 10 years ago.

site_title: 'Digitalise and upskill' employees for modern workplace with technology
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can differentiate and upgrade themselves by investing in digitalisation and upskilling their employees. SMEs contribute to nearly half of Singapore's GDP and provide seven in 10 local jobs. To support this, the Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD) has launched a new office for AI and Digital Innovation, while various companies, including BHP, Oracle, and Grab, have set up AI-focused innovation hubs in Singapore. Digitalisation can help SMEs improve business operations and stay competitive in the market.

site_title: Condo resale prices up 1% in Jan: SRX
summary: Resale prices of condominiums and private apartments in Singapore rose 1% in January 2018, according to SRX Property. This marks a faster pace of appreciation compared to the previous month. Year-on-year, prices climbed 6.3% and are now just 1.2% off from the peak in January 2014. The number of resale units also increased by 15.1% in January 2018, with a total of 1,097 units sold. This trend is attributed to factors such as en bloc sales and a steady Singapore economy.

site_title: Trump's infrastructure plan faces battle in Congress
summary: US President Donald Trump unveiled a long-awaited infrastructure plan, aiming to encourage spending on improvements by states, localities, and private investors. The plan, valued at $200 billion over 10 years, seeks to rebuild the nation's crumbling infrastructure. However, it faces an uphill battle in Congress, with Democrats criticizing it for placing a burden on local governments without providing enough federal dollars. The plan's lack of new federal funding and reliance on private sector investment have raised concerns about its feasibility, with some lawmakers labeling it "embarrassingly small" and "magical thinking."

site_title: Fed rate hikes squeezing even the hottest automaker in the US
summary: The Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes are affecting Subaru, the US's hottest automaker, by increasing the cost of cheap financing deals. Despite the rising rates, Subaru continues to offer competitive financing options, but this is becoming more expensive for the company, pinching margins in a plateauing US market. Industry experts warn that carmakers will eventually have to adjust to the rising costs, with some predicting a decline in market share. Subaru's president, Tom Doll, says someone will have to "blink" and back away from zero-percentage financing offers to maintain profit margins.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sembcorp Marine's stock price plummeted 12% after market hours on Feb 12, amid speculation of a corruption scandal or a potential rights issue. However, analysts at BS Group Research believe the likelihood of a scandal is low, and the company's strong order win pipeline suggests a buy recommendation with a target price of S$3.10. In contrast, Singapore Exchange's GS-CIMB downgraded Sembcorp Marine to "hold" due to potential earnings gaps from the loss of the SGX Nifty 50 index futures, cutting its target price to S$7.85.

site_title: Hi-P posts strong profit growth in Q4; proposes final dividend of 4 cents a share
summary: Hi-P International, a consumer electronics manufacturer, reported a net profit of S$59.62 million for Q4 2017, more than doubling from S$28.53 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 38% year-on-year to S$491.82 million, driven by higher sales volumes. The company declared a final dividend of 4 cents per share and expects higher revenues and profits for Q1 2018 and FY2018. CEO Yao Hsiao Tung attributed the improvement to the company's efforts to improve operational performance and grow the business.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: DVF keeps it all in the family
summary: Diane von Furstenberg (DVF) has introduced its new collection, featuring 18-year-old Talita von Furstenberg, granddaughter of the iconic designer, as its muse. Nathan Jenden, the brand's new chief design officer, has reunited with DVF, citing a "coming home" feeling. The collection showcases archival prints, stretch fabrics, and reimagined designs, with TVF enthusiastically modeling the outfits and even suggesting styles for her grandmother. This marks TVF's debut and Jenden's second stint with the brand, which he previously worked with from 2001-2011.

site_title: Board gender diversity makes some headway in 2017
summary: Singapore's listed companies showed a year-on-year increase in gender diversity on their boards, with women making up 10.8% of board seats in 2017, up from 9.5% in 2015. Despite progress, Singapore still trails other countries like Norway and France. The Diversity Action Committee (DAC) proposes revisions to the Code of Corporate Governance, including a "nine-year rule" to encourage board renewal and increase diversity. The goal is to reach 20% women's participation on boards by 2020, 25% by 2025, and 30% by 2030.

site_title: IMF sounds alarm for Lebanon over its unsustainable debt path
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned Lebanon that its economy is on an unsustainable path due to a ballooning public debt and strained public finances. The IMF predicts Lebanon's debt will reach 180% of GDP in five years and urges the government to make significant fiscal adjustments to restore investor confidence. The IMF recommends improving the balance sheet by 5% of GDP through spending cuts, tax increases, and eliminating subsidies, with the central bank adopting conventional interest rate policy instead of financial operations. A "significant fiscal adjustment" is deemed necessary to maintain the pegged exchange rate.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Singapore stocks have notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with MAS and PBOC to deepen collaboration in green and transition finance. CGSI downgraded Grab to 'hold' due to expected earnings growth to slow in H2. OCBC CEO Helen Wong is retiring, with Tan Teck Long named successor. Sats CEO Kerry Mok's pay rose 30.5% to S$3.1 million. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Tesla marked its formal India entry with a launch event, while Citigroup sets a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index.

site_title: UE's offer for WBL: Raw deal for minorities?
summary: United Engineers (UE) is set to acquire a 29.9% stake in WBL Corp for S$174 million from OCBC, its founding Lee family, and Yanlord Perennial Investment (YPI) consortium. The offer, which is a 16.9% discount to WBL's net tangible asset (NTA) value, has raised questions about the valuation of WBL's assets and its future prospects. UE already holds a 67.6% stake in WBL and majority control. The deal has been criticized by minority shareholders, who were not informed about UE's plans to buy up WBL and have concerns about the company's ability to deliver returns.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower after two-day bounce
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, following a two-day gain, and fell 0.63% to 24,446.87 on the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The S&P 500 lost 0.554593% to 2,641.27, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.57% to 6,942.01. Despite recent market gains, investor nerves remain about a potential market correction.

site_title: Hi-P International more than doubles net profit in Q4
summary: Hi-P International more than doubled its net profit in Q4 to S$59.62 million, driven by a 38% year-on-year revenue increase to S$491.82 million. The company's earnings per share rose to 7.39 Singapore cents, and it declared a final dividend of four Singapore cents per share. For the full year, net profit jumped to S$121.49 million. CEO Yao Hsiao Tung attributed the improvement to strategic efforts to improve operational performance and grow the business, expecting higher revenues and profits for 1Q2018 and FY2018.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Trump is pushing the US further towards kleptocracy
summary: US President Donald Trump is pushing the country towards kleptocracy, prioritizing policies that benefit the wealthy over the majority. Unlike his predecessors Bill Clinton and Barack Obama, who used "triangulation" strategies to appeal to both sides of the aisle, Trump has instead appealed to right-wing nativists, dismissing concerns about police brutality and white supremacy. His infrastructure plan, touted as a potential bipartisan effort, lacks a coherent policy design process and instead relies on public subsidies for private investors, favoring monopolies over public goods. This approach further erodes national unity and cements Trump's reputation as a president out of touch with most Americans.

site_title: Behind the human error that crashed NETS
summary: A nationwide crash of the NETS system on February 2, 2018, was attributed to an inadvertent human error during system maintenance. The 30-year-old cashless payment scheme, used by millions, experienced disruptions at over 100,000 acceptance points, affecting transactions and online payments. NETS has completed investigations and submitted a report to the Monetary Authority of Singapore, with plans to enhance its processes to prevent similar incidents. Experts highlight the need for robust IT systems, streamlined processes, and automation to prevent human error and ensure the system's resilience.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Overcoming the challenges women seafarers face
summary: A new booklet, published by the International Seafarers Welfare and Assistance Network and Anglo-Eastern Ship Management Limited, aims to increase gender diversity on board merchant ships. The booklet addresses challenges faced by women seafarers, including sexual harassment, bullying, and negative attitudes from male colleagues. The goal is to create a more inclusive and diverse industry, with women constituting only 2% of the total number of seafarers. The booklet is part of efforts to bridge the gender gap in the shipping industry, which has a global workforce of 39.3% women but only 2% women seafarers.

site_title: Transforming labour for the future economy
summary: Singapore's aging population poses a threat to its economy, with a predicted 1.5% GDP drag by 2060. To address this, the government has invested $4.5 billion in Industry Transformation Maps and implemented policies to discourage cheap foreign labor. However, SMEs face difficulties in hiring Singaporeans, and workers reject low-paying jobs. To overcome this, automation and upgrading of workers' skills are necessary, particularly in blue-collar jobs. The government's SkillsFuture program may need fine-tuning, and a gig economy solution could provide a workforce for digital transformation, but measures must be taken to protect freelancers' rights and welfare.

site_title: Singapore hits record US$229m of fintech funding in 2017: KPMG
summary: Singapore achieved a record US$229.1 million in fintech funding in 2017, driven by two large deals in the fourth quarter. The country's ability to attract venture capital and large corporates contributed to its growth as a regional fintech hub. However, the total value of fintech deals in Asia fell to US$748 million in the fourth quarter, with a 50% drop in VC funding and a significant decrease in fintech investment in China.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish higher after recent losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed 1.29% higher on Tuesday, following a positive lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose to 29,839.53, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased. This marks a small recovery from the hefty losses suffered over the past week.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.85 points to 1,833.02. The market saw 1.62 billion shares worth RM2.44 billion, with 495 gainers compared to 409 losers.

site_title: Home prices in two-thirds of US cities have hit record highs
summary: Home prices in 64% of US cities reached record highs in the fourth quarter, with 15% experiencing double-digit growth. Single-family home prices increased 5.3% nationally, while existing homes were 10.3% less available for sale. The shortage of new homes built over the past decade is burdening local markets, making homebuying less affordable. This trend is driven by an improving job market and low inventory, with median home prices 48% higher since 2011, yet incomes have only grown 15%.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets steady at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets steadied at the open on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index climbing 0.1% to 7,186.69 points, and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 flat at 12,282.76 and 5,136.09 points respectively.

site_title: UK inflation proves stickier than expected at start of 2018
summary: UK inflation remained steady at 3.0% in January, exceeding economists' expectations, as the Bank of England prepares to raise interest rates to combat price growth. The BoE aims to return inflation to 2% within two years, potentially leading to a quarter-point rate hike by May. The economic impact of the UK's Brexit decision continues to be felt, with limited wage growth and high inflation expected to weaken Britain's economy compared to other EU economies this year.

site_title: Lotte chief and ex-president's friend jailed in South Korea scandal
summary: A Seoul court sentenced Choi Soon-sil, a friend of former South Korean leader Park Geun-hye, to 20 years in jail for receiving bribes from conglomerates including Samsung and the Lotte Group. Lotte's chairman, Shin Dong-bin, was sentenced to two years and six months in prison. The verdict came after Choi was convicted of influence-peddling and abuse of authority. Shin's arrest creates a leadership vacuum at Lotte, a retail-to-chemicals giant, amid mounting losses at its China operations.

site_title: Dyna-Mac warns of Q4 loss
summary: Dyna-Mac Holdings, an offshore engineering services firm, has warned shareholders that it expects to report a net loss for Q4 2017 and a cumulative loss for the full year ended Dec 31. The group did not disclose reasons for the loss. Its shares ended at 14.6 Singapore cents, up 0.1 cent. Investors are advised to exercise caution when dealing with the company's shares.

site_title: Norway wealth fund to firms: fight corruption
summary: Norway's $1 trillion sovereign wealth fund has set new expectations for companies it invests in to prioritize fighting corruption. The fund, which invests in 9,100 companies, suggests that boards establish anti-corruption policies and procedures, and communicate them to employees. The goal is to reduce the fund's risk, with data on corporate governance and sustainability influencing investment decisions.

site_title: SIA Q3 net profit up 61% on higher revenue, absence of write-down
summary: Singapore Airlines' (SIA) third-quarter net profit surged 61.5% year-over-year to S$286.1 million, driven by higher revenue and absence of a write-down. Revenue increased 6% to S$4.08 billion, with all business segments posting higher revenues. Operating profit rose to S$329.4 million, despite a 5.4% increase in expenditure. The airline attributed the results to challenging market conditions, with pressure on yields and fuel price volatility expected to persist.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas reappoints CEO for another 3 years: Bernama
summary: Malaysia's state energy firm Petronas has reappointed Wan Zulkiflee Wan Ariffin as its CEO for another three years, effective April 1, 2018. This renewal comes after his initial three-year contract, which began in April 2015. The decision was made by the prime minister's office, but Petronas did not immediately comment on the matter.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: New guidelines for consumer rights with e-payments have been proposed, ensuring no liability for secure account holders. CapitaLand acquired Pearl Bank Apartments for S$728m and reported a 38% decline in Q4 profit. Resale condo prices rose 1% in January, with potential for 10% increase this year. Female board representation in SGX-listed firms increased to 10.8% in 2017. The Land Transport Authority awarded contracts for on-demand bus trials, while DBS and NTU partnered to train next generation of wealth managers.

site_title: Singapore private home prices may rise up to 10% this year, says CapitaLand CEO
summary: Singapore private home prices may rise up to 10% this year, according to CapitaLand CEO Lim Ming Yan, citing increased home sales as a precursor to price growth. The prediction comes after the developer reported a 38% decline in net income due to fewer homes sold in China. A 5-10% increase is possible if capital market volatility is minimal.

site_title: Courts Asia Q3 profit falls 28% on flat revenue
summary: Courts Asia reported a 28.7% drop in net profit to S$3.51 million for Q3 FY18, mainly due to lower credit sales in Malaysia after the introduction of Consumer Protection (Credit Sale) regulations. Revenue was flat, increasing 0.6% to S$186.8 million. The company plans to focus on driving productivity and investing in growth areas, while reviewing store closures. Earnings per share fell to 0.68 Singapore cent, and net asset value per share increased to 44.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: Self-driving cars will kill things you love
summary: Self-driving cars are set to revolutionize transportation, with limited tests already underway and widespread adoption expected within six years. The shift could drastically alter daily lifestyles, urban planning, and industries such as ride-hailing and trucking. While concerns over job loss and safety are valid, experts believe autonomous vehicles will improve safety and make transportation more affordable and convenient. As a result, public transit may dwindle, and new industries and opportunities will emerge, including changes in how we work and spend our leisure time.

site_title: Marco Polo Marine posts S$6.6m Q1 loss before wrapping debt revamp
summary: Marco Polo Marine reported a net loss of S$6.64 million in Q1 2018, reversing from a net profit of S$3.39 million in the same period last year. Revenue declined 34% to S$7.46 million due to lower contribution from shipbuilding and repair operations. The company attributed a lower gross margin and unrealised foreign exchange gain to the decline. CEO Sean Lee stated that the results did not fully reflect the outcome of the debt restructuring exercise, which is expected to reverse the company's negative equity position in the next quarter.

site_title: Write-backs help push Koh Bros Q4 net profit up by 74% to S$12m
summary: Koh Brothers Group reported a 74% increase in fourth-quarter net profit to S$12.17 million, driven by write-backs of S$5.58 million and S$919,000. Despite a 21% decline in revenue, the company's earnings per share rose to 2.94 Singapore cents. The group also posted a 49% rise in full-year net profit to S$19.83 million. Managing director Francis Koh expressed optimism about the private residential market and plans to pursue acquisitions and expand its construction arm.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Keppel O&M served with summons in new EIG lawsuit
summary: Keppel O&M's offshore and marine unit has been served with a summons in a new US$660 million racketeering lawsuit filed by EIG Global Energy Partners and some of its managed funds. The lawsuit claims Keppel O&M's role in a Brazilian bribery scheme related to a failed drill ship venture. Keppel Corp maintains the lawsuit is without merit and will vigorously defend itself. This is the second lawsuit against Keppel O&M, following a US$422 million settlement in 2018.

site_title: Gucci-fever boosts Kering's fourth-quarter sales growth
summary: Kering's luxury goods group reported better-than-expected sales growth in the fourth quarter, driven by Gucci's strong performance. Gucci's overhaul over the past two years contributed to its status as an industry star performer in 2017. Rising online sales and a bounceback in demand from Chinese consumers also fueled growth. Kering's decision to spin off Puma to focus on luxury brands has been successful, with the company benefiting from a strong recovery in the luxury market.

site_title: SATS Q3 revenue dips, net profit inches up
summary: SATS reported a Q3 revenue dip of 0.2% to S$439.8 million, with underlying revenue up 2.4% excluding the deconsolidation of SATS HK Limited. Net profit inched up to S$66.6 million, driven by a resilient performance despite a challenging operating environment. SATS expects opportunities for growth at Changi Airport, with plans to strengthen operations and innovate products and services.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Singapore shares close up 0.89% on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 30.09 points, or 0.89%, to close at 3,415.07, marking its second consecutive day of gains. The index saw a slight dip from STI constituent CapitaLand, but overall, gainers outpaced losers 289 to 183. The market traded 2.19 billion shares worth S$1.75 billion.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: NSL eyes share swop for 30% interest in German engineering group
summary: NSL Engineering Holdings, a unit of former NatSteel, has agreed to take a 30% stake in German mechanical engineering group Salzgitter Maschinenbau in exchange for its entire interest in Peiner SMAG Lifting Technologies. The deal, valued at around S$45.6 million, will give NSL access to a wider portfolio of European engineering companies. Upon completion, Peiner SMAG Lifting Technologies will become a wholly-owned subsidiary of Salzgitter Maschinenbau, allowing for greater synergies and value creation within the group.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Weaker taxi business drags Comfort DelGro earnings down
summary: ComfortDelGro Corp reported a 4.9% drop in net earnings to $301.5 million for the year ended Dec 31, 2017, due to weaker contributions from its taxi division and overseas markets. Revenue shrank by 2.2% to $3.97 billion, while total operating expenses rose by 1% to $3.56 billion. The group's taxi operating profit fell by 19.3% to $135.1 million, and its gearing ratio decreased to 10.6%. Despite this, the company's bus and train division posted a 0.4% rise in operating profit, and its overseas businesses have become more profitable than those in Singapore.

site_title: Pressure mounts on Australia deputy PM over affair
summary: Australian Deputy Prime Minister Barnaby Joyce faces mounting pressure amid allegations of an affair with a younger former staffer, Vikki Campion, who is pregnant with their child. Joyce has made a public apology to his wife and defended the two jobs given to Campion after she left his employ. The relationship has breached ministerial rules, sparking intense scrutiny and public backlash. Joyce's 24-year marriage and four daughters have been particularly affected by the scandal.

images.alt_text: Pressure was mounting on Australia's deputy prime minister Tuesday amid fresh allegations that his affair with a younger former staffer, who is pregnant with their child, breached ministerial rules.

site_title: TUI Group says summer trading good, takes hit from Niki insolvency
summary: TUI Group reported strong summer trading, with bookings for Greece, Turkey, and Cyprus growing, and is on track to increase profits by at least 10% this year. The company narrowed its underlying core loss by more than half to 25.4 million euros in the first quarter, driven by its hotels and cruises businesses. However, TUI took a hit from the insolvency of Austrian airline Niki, taking a 20 million euro write-down. Despite this, the company remains optimistic and CEO Fritz Joussen stated that Q1 2018 has shown TUI's growth momentum.

site_title: Beijing ups trade tensions with new measures on US chemical
summary: China has launched an investigation into US chemical imports, specifically styrene, amid growing trade tensions between the two nations. The investigation found dumping of the chemical from the US, Taiwan, and South Korea, causing harm to China's domestic styrene industry. China's commerce ministry has called for importers to place anti-dumping deposits, which could lead to tariffs if the final ruling is made. This move comes after the Trump administration launched new tariffs on Chinese-made solar panels and washing machines, and follows China's own anti-dumping investigation into US sorghum imports.

site_title: RHT Health Trust reaches agreement to sell portfolio to Fortis Healthcare
summary: RHT Health Trust has agreed to sell its portfolio of healthcare assets to Fortis Healthcare for 46.5 billion Indian rupees (S$950 million). The deal includes the sale of RHT's Indian subsidiaries and 49% interest in Fortis Hospotel, along with its entire asset portfolio, including 12 clinics, four greenfield clinics, and two operating hospitals in India. The consideration represents a 10.3% premium to the trust's adjusted net asset value and a 65.5% return on investment. RHT will distribute the bulk of the net proceeds to unitholders.

site_title: Fresh guidelines ahead on consumer rights with e-payments
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has proposed new guidelines for consumer rights related to e-payments, providing assurance to individuals and small businesses that they will not be liable for unauthorized transactions if they keep their account details secure. Account holders who are careless but not reckless will be liable for up to S$100, while reckless behavior will result in actual loss. The guidelines also require banks to notify customers of e-payment transactions and provide daily transaction summaries. MAS is seeking public feedback on the guidelines until March 16.

images.alt_text: Consumers and small businesses wary of e-payments due to fears of unauthorised transactions through their bank accounts can soon be assured of no liability as long as they keep the account details secure, new guidelines proposed on Tuesday showed.

site_title: Bannon wanted Yellen to stay Fed chair, calling her 'My Girl'
summary: Former White House strategist Steve Bannon considered endorsing Janet Yellen for a second term as Federal Reserve chair, praising her "dovish monetary policy" as beneficial for boosting wages. However, President Donald Trump chose Jerome Powell instead, despite Bannon's efforts. Bannon's change of heart came after being ousted from the White House in August, and he reportedly saw Yellen's moderate approach as a concern for economic growth.

images.alt_text: Former White House strategist Steve Bannon considered endorsing Janet Yellen for a second term as Federal Reserve chair but instead kept quiet as President Donald Trump passed her over in favour of fellow Republican Jerome Powell.

site_title: Pump iron and eat more protein, especially if you're older than 40
summary: A comprehensive scientific review of research found that eating more protein, especially for those over 40, significantly augments the effects of weight training, leading to larger and stronger muscles. The review, published in the British Journal of Sports Medicine, concludes that consuming 1.6 grams of protein per kilogram of body weight per day is the ideal amount for maximizing muscular strength and mass. This amount is significantly higher than the current federal recommendations, which suggest about 56 grams of protein per day for men.

site_title: Two firms land deal to conduct on-demand bus trials
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore has awarded contracts to Via Transportation and Ministry of Movement to conduct on-demand bus service trials. The LTA received 10 proposals from local and overseas tenderers, and the two selected firms will receive nearly half a million dollars to carry out the trials. The LTA praised the selected firms for having a strong understanding of the tender requirements.

site_title: Japan's Coincheck reports to regulators over US$530m cryptocurrency heist
summary: Japan's cryptocurrency exchange Coincheck Inc. has filed a report with regulators on the hacking that resulted in a US$530 million cryptocurrency heist in late January. The Financial Services Agency ordered Coincheck to raise its standards and submit a report on the security of its systems and measures to prevent a repeat. Coincheck's investigation into the heist is included in the report, which outlines steps to bolster its risk management system. The exchange faces pressure to better safeguard investors following the daring theft.

images.alt_text: Japanese cryptocurrency exchange Coincheck Inc, under pressure to better safeguard investors after the daring theft of US$530 million of digital money last month, said it had on Tuesday filed a report with regulators on the hacking.

site_title: Australia shares track Wall Street into positive territory; NZ gains
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.6% to 5,855.9 points, following Wall Street's rebound from its biggest weekly drop in two years. The index had slipped 0.3% on Monday. Strategists remain cautious about the market's direction, despite the positive start to the week.

site_title: Public transport satisfaction falls following major MRT incidents in 2017: PTC survey
summary: Commuter satisfaction with public transport in Singapore dropped to 94.5% in 2017, down from 96.4% in 2016, following major incidents such as MRT tunnel flooding in 2017. The Public Transport Council's survey found lower satisfaction scores for MRT services, with 91.8% rating, and lower reliability, waiting time, and comfort scores. However, scores for MRT station accessibility and bus services improved, with 80.8% of respondents feeling bus services had improved. The survey attributed the decline to MRT delays due to new signalling system testing.

images.alt_text: Commuter satisfaction with public transport here dropped last year, following serious incidents such as the MRT tunnel flooding in October last year.

site_title: Investors await Goldman's US$5b answers as trading picks up
summary: Goldman Sachs CEO Lloyd Blankfein is set to address investors about the bank's ambitious $5 billion revenue growth plan, amid rising trading activity. Since unveiling the goal in September, analysts have questioned the underlying assumptions and cited investor concerns. Blankfein's public presentation, scheduled for an industry conference in Miami Beach, will be the first time he directly addresses investors. The move comes as markets have picked up, with investors awaiting Goldman's ability to meet its lofty revenue targets.

images.alt_text: Last year, Goldman Sachs Group Inc executives met with some skepticism after unveiling an ambitious plan to grow revenue by $5 billion, whether or not markets remained subdued. Now that trading has picked up, Wall Street is hoping the bank can do even better.

site_title: Blackstone gets a shot at buying back assets it sold to Anbang
summary: Blackstone Group, which sold New York's Waldorf Astoria hotel to Anbang Insurance Group in 2016 for a record $1.95 billion, is in early discussions about bidding to buy back the iconic landmark and Strategic Hotels & Resorts, which Blackstone sold to Anbang for $6.5 billion. China's government is overseeing the sale of Anbang's assets due to the company's turmoil, and Blackstone could potentially bid for assets despite early-stage deliberations. The sale would be a significant opportunity for Blackstone, which benefited from Anbang's largesse, selling $9.5 billion of assets to the insurer.

images.alt_text: Blackstone Group, which scored big four years ago when a company it owned sold New York's Waldorf Astoria hotel for a record-setting price to a little-known Chinese insurer, may soon get a chance to own the iconic landmark again.

site_title: LMIRT's Q4 DPU down 9.2%
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) reported a 9.2% decrease in fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.79 Singapore cents, due to costs related to the change in trustee, depreciation of the Indonesian rupiah, and lower gains from hedging contracts. Despite a 0.8% increase in net property income and a 1.5% rise in gross rental income, the trust's overall portfolio occupancy remained at 93.7%. The trust's DPU for the full year 2017 increased by 0.9% to 3.44 Singapore cents.

site_title: Paris Grand Palais to get half-billion-euro facelift
summary: The Grand Palais in Paris will undergo a €500 million renovation, set to open a pedestrian boulevard linking the Champs Elysees with the River Seine. The project will also revamp the complex's galleries and exhibition spaces, including the Palace of Discoveries science museum. The historic building, first constructed for the 1900 Exposition Universelle, will retain its Art Nouveau landmark status. The renovation is expected to increase accessibility to the complex and provide a new public space for Parisians and tourists alike.

images.alt_text: France unveiled a spectacular near half-billion-euro (S$811 million-dollar) overhaul of one of its beloved buildings Monday, driving a new pedestrian boulevard through the Grand Palais in Paris to link the Champs Elysees with the River Seine.

site_title: Chairman of Taiwan navy contract ship firm charged with fraud
summary: Taiwan's Chairman of Ching Fu Shipbuilding Co, Chen Ching-nan, was indicted for a loan fraud case involving $202 million in illicit loans taken out after the company won a $15.7 billion contract to build six naval ships in 2014. The indictment, which includes Chen's son and wife, seeks a 30-year jail sentence. The scandal has damaged Taiwan's defense industry ambitions and raised concerns about the island's military procurement process. Prosecutors found no wrongdoing by the defense ministry, which dissolved the contract in December amid the probe.

site_title: UK govt must act urgently to put energy price cap in place by next winter : lawmakers
summary: The UK government must act urgently to implement a domestic energy price cap by next winter to address the country's broken energy market. The Energy and Industrial Strategy Committee urges the government to pass a law by summer to set a cap, limiting the difference between the highest and lowest prices charged by each supplier. The Committee criticizes big six energy companies for overcharging customers and Ofgem for being slow to act. A price cap is seen as necessary to protect customers from rip-off energy prices, which have doubled in the past decade.

site_title: Opioid makers paid millions to advocacy groups: US Senate report
summary: US Senate report reveals that five opioid manufacturers, including Purdue Pharma, paid over $10 million to advocacy groups and doctors who amplified industry messages supporting opioid use, contributing to the 2016 opioid epidemic that led to 42,000 overdose deaths. The groups received donations and issued guidance promoting opioids for chronic pain, and lobbied against laws to curb their use. The largest donor was Purdue Pharma, giving $4.15 million to 12 groups from 2012 to 2017.

images.alt_text: Five opioid manufacturers including OxyContin maker Purdue Pharma LP have paid more than US$10 million to advocacy groups and doctors tied to them, many of whom amplified industry messages supporting the use of the painkillers, a US Senate report said on Monday.

site_title: H&M drops dividend spending plan after hitting too many hurdles
summary: Hennes & Mauritz (H&M) has abandoned its plan to have shareholders reinvest dividends into new shares, citing technical issues and time constraints. The proposal, aimed at strengthening the control of chairman Stefan Persson's family, would have provided the company with much-needed cash to address issues in its physical shops and online presence. The board will instead propose an unchanged dividend payout of 9.75 Swedish kronor per share for the 2016-17 financial year.

images.alt_text: Hennes & Mauritz (H&M) has abandoned a plan to try to get shareholders to reinvest their dividends in new stock.

site_title: Vietnam's coffee exports may climb 9% on rising production
summary: Vietnam's coffee exports are expected to rise 9% in 2018, with total shipments projected at 1.55 million metric tons, driven by a 4.5% increase in production to 1.6 million tons. Favorable weather and higher prices last year are expected to boost production. This could weigh on benchmark robusta futures, which have fallen 17% in London over the past year.

site_title: Workplace death rate hit 13-year low in 2017 but occupational diseases up 9%
summary: Singapore's workplace death rate reached a 13-year low in 2017, falling to 42 deaths, with a fatality rate of 1.2 per 100,000 employees. However, occupational diseases rose 9% to 799 cases, with significant increases in musculoskeletal disorders, noise-induced deafness, and skin diseases. The government plans to enhance targeted programs to prevent these diseases, and inspections and enforcement operations will continue in 2018.

site_title: Singapore poised for first sales tax hike in more than a decade: Reuters poll
summary: Singapore is expected to introduce its first sales tax hike in over a decade, with 9 out of 10 economists polled by Reuters predicting a 1% increase in the goods and services tax (GST) to 8%, starting April 1. The move aims to boost revenue to fund social spending needs for a rapidly ageing population. Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat may also introduce taxes on e-commerce retailers, wealth, and sugar. The tax hike is seen as a necessary measure to address the country's demographic challenges, with economists expecting it to boost inflation and net government revenues.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng Q4 net profit down 2.4% on higher administrative costs, lower income
summary: Chip Eng Seng's Q4 net profit fell 2.4% to S$14.5 million due to higher administrative costs and lower income from other sources. Revenue grew 2.4% to S$256.1 million, driven by stronger performances in property development and hospitality divisions. The construction and property investment arms saw revenue decline due to a weaker order book and divestment of an office building. The company expects to replenish its land bank in Singapore and complete the acquisition of a hotel in Adelaide. A first and final dividend of four Singapore cents per share was declared.

site_title: China's HNA sells Hong Kong land for US$2b as it races to beat cash crunch
summary: China's HNA Group is selling two land parcels in Hong Kong to Henderson Land Development Co for $2 billion to address a liquidity crunch. The conglomerate, which has faced scrutiny over its opaque ownership and use of leverage after a $50 billion acquisition spree, is racing to alleviate financial strain. The sale is part of HNA's efforts to dispose of assets and alleviate severe financial strain.

images.alt_text: China's HNA Group is selling two land parcels in Hong Kong to Henderson Land Development Co for US$2 billion), as the Chinese conglomerate ramps up asset disposals to address a liquidity crunch.

site_title: Samsung SDI turns to used phones for cobalt as prices surge
summary: Samsung SDI, a battery supplier to major carmakers, plans to recycle cobalt from used mobile phones to secure supplies amid surging prices. The company will partner with a recycling firm to extract 25,000 metric tons of cobalt from dead batteries by 2025. This trend aims to reduce reliance on the Democratic Republic of Congo, the world's largest cobalt producer, as prices have more than tripled since 2016. The move is part of a shift towards recycling to meet growing demand for electric vehicles.

site_title: Female board representation in SGX-listed firms rises to 10.8% in 2017: study
summary: Singapore-listed firms showed a 10.8% female representation on their boards in 2017, up from 9.9% in 2016 and 9.5% in 2015. The top 100 primary-listed companies achieved the highest increase, with 13.1% women's participation. However, Singapore still trails other countries like Norway and France, with a female board representation of 42% and 27.6%, respectively. The Diversity Action Committee (DAC) proposed revisions to the Code of Corporate Governance, including a "nine-year rule" to encourage board renewal and diversity.

site_title: MGM opens for Macau holiday players as China challenge looms
summary: MGM Resorts International has opened its US$3.4 billion property in Macau, the world's biggest casino hub, amidst China's growing challenge to the region's gaming industry. The resort's opening coincides with the Chinese New Year holiday, which has seen rooms at major hotels fully booked with increased rates. Analysts predict continued growth for Macau despite competition from new destinations and potential regulatory changes from China. MGM's addition to the Cotai strip is expected to drive gambling revenue growth, with analysts forecasting a 20% increase in betting volume in the first quarter.

site_title: British horse racing plans 'Formula One' team series
summary: British horse racing plans to launch a multi-million pound "Formula One" team series, featuring 12 branded teams competing over eight consecutive Thursdays. Each team will have a squad of 30 horses and four dedicated jockeys, with prize money exceeding £100,000 per race. The series aims to draw a new audience into the sport and create an easy-to-follow points system, similar to Formula One. The initiative is seen as a way to boost prize money and engagement in a sport often criticized for being complex and expensive.

site_title: Google hires former Samsung exec to coordinate Internet of Things projects
summary: Google has hired Injong Rhee, former Samsung Electronics Co's chief technology officer, to lead its Internet of Things business. Rhee will serve as entrepreneur-in-residence under Diane Greene, chief executive of Google's cloud computing group. This move aims to strengthen Google's presence in the Internet of Things market.

site_title: Resource-rich Mongolia rejects cap on foreign workers for 2018
summary: Mongolia has rejected a proposal to limit foreign worker permits to 100 per year, citing concerns over domestic job protection. The proposal, aimed at limiting foreign workers in the resource-rich nation, was rejected by lawmakers. Instead, the existing system of quotas on specific business sectors will continue, allowing foreign workers to enter the country without a cap. The decision is seen as a positive move for the country's economy, which relies heavily on foreign labor.

site_title: GM will shut a South Korean plant, more cuts could follow
summary: General Motors (GM) will close its compact vehicle assembly plant in Gunsan, South Korea, employing about 2,000 workers, as part of its restructuring efforts. The company will take $850 million in charges to reflect the costs of the plant closure and other operations in South Korea. GM aims to focus on profitable markets, mainly the US and China, and new technologies. The company's long-term presence in South Korea depends on government incentives and labor cost agreements with unions.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific Q4 net profit falls 39% on lower revenue recognition in property development
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings reported a 38.9% decline in net profit to S$7.3 million in its Q4, primarily due to lower revenue recognition from property developments such as Jade Residences and LIV on Wilkie. Revenue plummeted 53.5% to S$43.3 million, mainly resulting from the completion of these projects in 4Q2016 and early 2017. This decrease in revenue recognition eroded the company's results, leading to a significant drop in net profit.

site_title: Asia: Markets post strong gains after Wall St, Europe bounce
summary: Asian markets rallied on Tuesday, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Shanghai leading gains after a week of turmoil, as traders took cues from strong gains in New York and Europe. Despite concerns over US inflation data, markets were boosted by dealers picking up bargains. Key gains were seen in Tokyo (1.3%), Hong Kong (2.3%), and Shanghai (1.8%), while Seoul, Singapore, and Sydney also rose. The positive mood supported high-yielding currencies, but the South African rand was sold due to political uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore stocks enter afternoon session higher; STI at 3,430.7, up 1.4 % on day
summary: Singapore shares began the afternoon session higher, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 1.4% to 3,430.7 points. About 1.02 billion shares worth S$769 million were traded, with gainers outnumbering losers 300 to 90. DBS and OCBC Bank shares were among the top movers, up 0.7% and 3.59% respectively. The rally comes ahead of GDP data release and follows a 5-day rally.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise on foreign buying; won steady
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 9.81 points or 0.41% to 2,395.19 at 0632 GMT, driven by foreign buying and large purchases of chipmakers like Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix. The won remained steady at 1,084.5 per dollar, while bond yields fell.

site_title: China small caps' vanishing profit growth adds to bear case
summary: China's small-cap stocks, measured by the ChiNext gauge, saw a 5.3% increase in combined profits in 2017, down from 51% in 2016. This slowdown in earnings growth, combined with high valuations, adds to the bear case for the sector. Funding costs have risen for smaller companies, limiting their ability to boost earnings through debt-fueled mergers and acquisitions. Experts predict small caps will continue to underperform large-cap companies, citing the risks of goodwill impairment and deteriorating growth momentum.

site_title: Unilever threatens to pull ads from 'divisive platforms'
summary: Unilever threatens to pull ads from digital platforms that fail to protect children or promote division in society. The company's chief marketing officer, Keith Weed, stated that "fake news, sexism, terrorists that spread messages of hate, toxic content directed at children" are unacceptable. Unilever plans to prioritize investing in responsible platforms that create a positive impact on society, citing its 7.7 billion euro annual marketing budget. The company employs 169,000 people worldwide and owns over 400 household brands.

site_title: Tickled pink: Japan lovers taste new chocs on Valentine's Day
summary: In Japan, Valentine's Day has become a lucrative business, with women traditionally giving gifts to men. To capitalize on this trend, KitKat stores in Tokyo have released naturally bright pink chocolate, a "fourth" type of chocolate after milk, dark, and white. The promotion is part of a marketing push, as the country's love for cute and unique products continues to drive sales, particularly in the shopping district of Ginza.

site_title: New plan launched to get security companies to use more tech, rely less on manpower
summary: Singapore launches a new plan, the Security Industry Transformation Map (ITM), to encourage security companies to adopt technology-based solutions, reducing reliance on manpower. The plan aims to improve security services, jobs for Singaporeans, and overall security. Key initiatives include outcome-based security contracts, risk assessment, and tech innovation support. The government will invest $10 million over three years to support the plan, and a new specialist diploma in security consultancy will be introduced to train professionals.

site_title: London City airport reopens following removal of WWII bomb
summary: London City Airport reopened Tuesday after a World War II bomb was safely removed from the River Thames, grounding services for a day. The 500kg device was discovered during construction work and was removed by Royal Navy divers and bomb disposal teams. The airport, which serves London's financial districts, had been closed for 24 hours. Services resumed after the exclusion zone was lifted, allowing normal operations to resume.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.5% to 3,402.82, driven by gains from QT Vascular and MarcoPolo Marine. US stocks finished stronger overnight, contributing to the positive start. About 63.2 million shares changed hands, with 125 gainers outnumbering 22 losers.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher after Wall St gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, following a two-day gain on Wall Street, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.98% to 21,592.53. The broader Topix index also rose 0.64% to 1,743.07. This follows a market holiday in Japan on Monday. The gains come as traders brush off new US threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Mirach Energy's unit to acquire 70% interest in Malaysian timber firm in plan to expand core business
summary: Mirach Energy's wholly-owned subsidiary is acquiring a 70% interest in Malaysian timber firm RCL Kelstar Sdn Bhd for RM21 million. The investment aims to diversify into the property and construction business, seeking to strengthen Mirach's financial performance. The company plans to jointly develop a multi-storey project in Malaysia with the Kelantan State Economic Development Corporation. A general meeting will be convened to seek shareholders' approval for the proposed deal.

site_title: Infinio Group to acquire Kim Chuan Terrace property for S$10.8m
summary: Infinio Group, a Singapore-based mineral oil and gas firm, plans to acquire a Kim Chuan Terrace property for S$10.8 million. The acquisition is part of the company's diversification into property development and related business. The purchase will be funded through a share placement and bank borrowings, and is subject to shareholders' approval. The company also proposes a name change, which will be discussed at an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Jamaican escapism for Ralph Lauren on NY runway
summary: Ralph Lauren's 2018 spring collection showcased a dose of escapism inspired by Jamaica at New York Fashion Week, featuring a blue infinity-pool effect runway and classic maritime looks. The collection, part of the brand's see-now, buy-now strategy, included bright and energetic colors and inter-seasonal clothes. Despite struggling with falling revenue, the collection received praise for its unique silhouette and clean design. Ralph Lauren's sales have fallen 10% in North American stores, with e-commerce down 27%, but the brand remains confident in its ability to reverse the trend.

site_title: Linger over lunch to lose weight: study suggests
summary: A study of nearly 60,000 Japanese individuals found that eating slower can lead to weight loss and lower obesity rates. Those who chewed longer and paused between bites had a smaller average waist circumference and fewer obese individuals compared to those who ate quickly. The research suggests that interventions aimed at reducing eating speed may be effective in preventing obesity and associated health risks.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 3.60 points to 1,833.77. The FTSE index saw 87.90 million lots traded worth RM37.08 million, with 201 gainers outnumbering 61 losers.

site_title: India fintech seeking to raise at least US$87m to grow tech capabilities
summary: India's Lendingkart Technologies is seeking at least $87 million in equity funding to expand its technological capabilities. The series C capital-raising round, led by Fullerton Financial Holdings, will also enable the company to deepen its reach to small enterprises and "underserved micro enterprises." The funding will be used to enhance its credit product offerings and leverage Big Data analytics and machine learning to assess creditworthiness. With this round, Lendingkart's cumulative equity and debt raising will exceed $173 million.

site_title: Australia: Shares recover amid thin trade; NZ rises
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to 5,838.0 on Tuesday, following a similar US stock rally, but gains were capped by underwhelming corporate earnings. Materials and financials sectors performed well, while investment manager Challenger dropped to a 4-month low. New Zealand shares rose 0.7% to 8,115.22, snapping a five-session losing streak, as gains across most sectors supported the benchmark.

site_title: In rare move, Amazon laying off hundreds of workers as it adds aggressively elsewhere
summary: Amazon is laying off hundreds of workers in its Seattle headquarters and globally as part of a strategy to trim parts of its existing retail business and focus on rapidly-growing areas such as Amazon Echo devices, digital entertainment, and cloud business. The company, which added nearly 130,000 employees globally last year, will cut "a few hundred" positions, while aggressively hiring in other areas. The layoffs do not affect plans to hire 50,000 warehouse workers and 50,000 full-time workers for a second North American headquarters.

site_title: Trump daughter-in-law taken to hospital after receiving 'suspicious' mail
summary: US President Donald Trump's daughter-in-law, Vanessa Trump, was taken to a New York hospital as a precaution after receiving a "suspicious package" containing an unidentified powder. The package was addressed to Donald Trump Jr. and tested as non-hazardous. Vanessa Trump, a mother of five, was taken to New York Presbyterian-Weill Cornell Medical Center with no indication of injury or danger. The Secret Service is conducting an active investigation.

site_title: China Sky: 800m yuan loan to entity represented by ex-director not recorded in financial statements
summary: China Sky Chemical Fibre Co Ltd reported that an 800 million yuan loan to an entity represented by former director Zheng Kai Su was not recorded in its financial statements. The loan was made by a unit of the company. The High Court of Singapore received a suit against Mr. Zheng in 2016 for improper use of funds and assets. China Sky has seized assets from its subsidiaries and faces multiple lawsuits, including a petition for a loan. The company's shares have been suspended since August 2016.

site_title: China Jan new loans surge to record 2.9t yuan, blow past forecasts
summary: China's banks extended a record 2.9 trillion yuan in new loans in January, exceeding forecasts and nearly five times the previous month. This surge in lending is expected to support growth in China and may underpin global liquidity as Western central banks withdraw stimulus. Net new loans surpassed the previous record in January 2016, with sharp pickups in demand for credit from households and companies. Authorities are proceeding cautiously to avoid excessive financial market volatility, while warning banks to rein in new lending growth.

site_title: London airport to reopen after WWII bomb removed
summary: London City Airport reopened on Tuesday after the removal of a 500kg World War II German bomb discovered in King George V Dock. The airport was shut down and two exclusion zones imposed, affecting up to 16,000 passengers. The bomb disposal operation successfully removed the unexploded ordnance and lifted the exclusion zone, allowing flights to resume normally. The airport handled 4.5 million passengers in 2017, mainly used by business travelers, and was closed for 24 hours due to the incident.

site_title: BOJ Kuroda says cryptocurrency won't threaten yen, largely speculative
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that cryptocurrencies, such as bitcoin, are unlikely to threaten the yen as they are primarily used for speculative trading. Kuroda emphasized that cryptocurrencies lack assets to back their value and are not considered legal tenders. The BOJ is monitoring cryptocurrency developments to ensure they don't erode public trust in existing settlement systems. Kuroda's comments come as global policymakers discuss regulating cryptocurrencies, including a potential meeting in March.

site_title: Former New Zealand PM Bill English resigns
summary: Former New Zealand Prime Minister Bill English has announced his retirement after failing to retain office in the 2017 general election. English, who served as prime minister for nearly a year, cited a desire for a break from politics and a chance to start a new life. He outpolled Labour leader Jacinda Ardern in the popular vote but was unable to form a government, leading to her election as prime minister. English's retirement marks the end of a 27-year career in parliament.

site_title: Hit by political crossfire, Lotte's China exit said to stall
summary: Lotte Group's efforts to sell its China stores have stalled due to allegations of fire safety infractions, which led to the suspension of operations at 74 of its 99 outlets in China. The company has invested heavily in China but the setbacks have been a financial blow, with Lotte Shopping losing 50 billion won (S$61 million) every quarter. Negotiations with potential buyers are ongoing, with the company considering various sale possibilities, including selling its entire China mart business or splitting up operations to sell to several firms.

site_title: Star Alliance, Accenture enhance seamless travel experience with digital services platform
summary: STAR Alliance and Accenture have launched a digital services platform to enhance travel experiences across its 28-airline network. The platform aggregates data from member airlines, allowing them to integrate it into their own digital applications. Currently, Lufthansa and United Airlines are using the platform, with features such as seat selection and baggage tracking available across the alliance. The goal is to enable customers to control their entire travel experience through a single app or website, with the platform to be progressively rolled out across member airlines.

site_title: For advertisers, Snapchat's got the kids
summary: Snapchat retains its advantage over Instagram among the younger generation, with a 72% rise in quarterly revenue beating analyst forecasts. The app's "discover" tab and safeguards against poor placement drive enthusiasm for advertising, with Snapchat expected to add 1.9 million Americans under 25 this year, compared to Instagram's 1.6 million. Marketers praise Snapchat's ability to provide a controlled environment for advertisers, while Instagram's "explore" tab lacks its counterpart. Despite Instagram's features, Snapchat's unique appeal and control over content keep advertisers loyal.

site_title: Google's next Android overhaul is said to embrace iPhone 'notch'
summary: Google is working on an Android overhaul to mimic Apple's iPhone X "notch" design, aiming to persuade more iPhone users to switch to Android devices. The update, expected later this year, will integrate Google's digital assistant, improve battery life, and support new designs like multiple screens and foldable displays. The goal is to catch up with Apple's high-end smartphone market, where Android dominates the middle and low-end. However, the update may not address the issue of outdated Android versions, which expose security holes and hinder Google's innovations.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks inch up, won slightly firmer
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 0.29% to 2,392.31, while the Korean won pushed up 0.06% to 1,083.9 per dollar. The stock index is down 3.3% this year, but foreign investors bought 43,019 million won worth of shares. US dollar rose 1.58% against the won this year, with the won's high at 1,056.67 per dollar on January 14.

site_title: China charges former Politburo member with bribery
summary: Former Politburo member Sun Zhengcai has been charged with bribery in China, with the Supreme People's Procuratorate stating he "should be held criminally responsible" for accepting huge sums of money. Sun was once a contender for China's top leadership but was formally expelled from the Communist Party in September. This development comes ahead of China's annual plenary session, where President Xi Jinping is expected to cement his position as the most powerful Chinese leader in a generation. The charge is part of Xi's ongoing anti-corruption campaign.

site_title: DBS, NTU partner to train next generation of Singapore wealth managers
summary: DBS Bank and Nanyang Technological University (NTU) have partnered to train the next generation of wealth management talent in Singapore. The Applied Wealth Management track, launched in August 2018, will equip students with regulatory certifications and digital skillsets. The program, accepting up to 50 students per year, aims to provide job-ready wealth managers to cater to the growing affluent class in Singapore. Graduates will undergo internships with DBS and be offered full-time jobs or places in DBS Treasures after graduation.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, Great Eastern, Infinio, HMI, Cordlife
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

Singapore stocks to watch: CapitaLand acquired Pearl Bank Apartments for S$928 million, Great Eastern's net profit more than doubled to S$423.6 million, Infinio Group intends to purchase a property for S$10.8 million, HMI's second-quarter net profit nearly tripled to RM15.72 million, and Cordlife Group reported a third consecutive quarterly net profit with a 7.6% year-on-year revenue increase. These developments may impact trading of the companies' shares.

site_title: URA trying to harmonise rules for property developers: analysts
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) is seeking public feedback on proposed changes to rules for non-residential property developers in Singapore. The changes aim to enhance transparency and raise industry standards, similar to those for residential developers. Key proposed changes include requiring developers to obtain a sales license, set up project accounts, and provide accurate information in advertisements. The URA also plans to implement anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing requirements for all developers. The public has until March 12 to provide feedback on these proposals.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Manchester City squad most expensive in history: report
summary: Manchester City has the most expensive squad in history, valued at 878 million euros, according to a report by the CIES Football Observatory. The Premier League leaders spent heavily on players, including Aymeric Laporte for 65 million euros, and Kylian Mbappe's loan deal. The average Premier League squad cost a record high of 291m euros, more than double La Liga's average of 131m euros. Other top teams, such as Manchester United and Barcelona, also spent over 700m euros on their squads. This highlights the high costs of competing at the highest level in football.

site_title: French budget minister questioned in rape inquiry
summary: French budget minister Gerald Darmanin, 35, was questioned by investigators over rape accusations dating back nearly a decade, which he has denied. The accusations, made by a 46-year-old former call girl, were reopened after she renewed her complaint in January. Darmanin's lawyers have accused her of slander, while government officials have rallied in support of the minister. This case comes amid a global outpouring of accounts of sexual harassment and rape, prompting debate in France over media coverage of old cases.

site_title: Holographic models, virtual jellyfish are the new draw in China
summary: In China, a new light-show theme park in Haining has attracted over 700,000 visitors since its opening, with the city's largest leather mall investing heavily in holographic shows and augmented reality to engage tourists. The trend is part of a larger effort by cities to boost consumption and the economy through experiential tours. With at least 17 billion yuan in venture capital poured into the travel sector in 2016, China is embracing holographic and augmented reality technologies to draw tourists, with other cities such as Shanghai and Guangzhou also investing in similar projects.

site_title: Hot stock: SembMarine up 5.5% at S$2.5 following late Monday selloff
summary: SembMarine's shares surged 5.5% on Tuesday to S$2.5 following a late Monday selloff. The oil and gas firm received a query from the Singapore Exchange regarding a 12% drop in its stock price in the last 20 minutes of trading hours on Feb 12. Despite this, DBS Equity Research maintained its "buy" rating and target price of $3.10, citing potential opportunities from Statoil's Johan Castberg development project. Industry sources suggest SembMarine could still play a role in the project, despite Norway's Kvaerner appearing to have an upper hand.

site_title: Schneider Electric, Ikea tap solar power in Singapore
summary: Schneider Electric and Ikea Singapore have partnered with Sun Electric to tap into solar power, reducing their reliance on traditional energy sources. Schneider Electric will use 2,600 megawatt-hours of solar energy annually, while Ikea Singapore has installed two solar systems, one generating 1.3 million kWh per year. The hybrid energy model offers greater energy efficiency and brings Schneider Electric closer to its global target of 80% renewable energy by 2020 and 100% by 2030.

site_title: North Korea's Kim describes South as very impressive: KCNA
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un praised South Korea as "very impressive" following his sister Kim Yo Jong's visit to the Winter Olympics, according to state media KCNA. The visit sparked a rare moment of rapprochement after months of tensions over Pyongyang's nuclear program. Kim expressed satisfaction and thanked Seoul for prioritizing the visit of North Korean athletes. He also invited President Moon Jae In to a summit in Pyongyang, aiming to build on the rapprochement and continue improving north-south relations.

site_title: Banks keep STI in positive territory
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 7.74 points higher, or 0.23%, at 3,384.98 on Monday, driven by gains in local banks DBS, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank. The index was lifted by DBS's new dividend payout policy and upcoming results from OCBC Bank and UOB. However, Singapore Exchange (SGX) fell 7.35% to S$7.31 due to news that India's national stock exchanges will end trading of offshore derivatives tied to the SGX Nifty 50 Index Futures.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Facial recognition works best if you're a white guy
summary: A study by Joy Buolamwini found that facial recognition technology performs significantly better on white males than on darker-skinned individuals, with error rates ranging from 1% to 35%. The technology's bias is attributed to the predominantly white male data used to train it, which can lead to inaccurate identifications. The study's results raise concerns about fairness and accountability in AI, particularly in applications such as law enforcement and hiring. Companies like IBM and Microsoft have taken steps to improve their facial recognition technology, but more work is needed to address the issue.

site_title: Amazon focuses on chips with Blink acquisition
summary: Amazon has acquired Blink, a maker of energy-efficient home security cameras, for approximately $90 million. The deal allows Amazon to explore chips exclusive to Blink, which could lower production costs and extend battery life of other gadgets, including its Cloud Cam and Echo speakers. The acquisition underscores Amazon's strategy to deepen its relationship with shoppers and expand its presence in the security camera market.

site_title: Europe: Shares bounce back after turbulent week
summary: European shares rebounded 1.2% on Monday, ending a six-month low, after volatility concerns eased. The Stoxx 600 index rose, with cyclicals sectors, such as materials, driving the gains. Copper prices rose and miners like Glencore and Rio Tinto increased 1.6-2.8%. TDC surged 13.4% after a US$6.7 billion cash offer, while Victrex and Delivery Hero rose 3.3% and 4.7% respectively. Renault added 3% as the French government backed its CEO's nominee.

site_title: HNA sells Hong Kong land for HK$16b, disposals speed up
summary: HNA Group sold two plots of land in Hong Kong to billionaire Lee Shau Kee's Henderson Land Development for HK$16 billion, accelerating asset disposals to repay mounting debt. The cash-strapped conglomerate has been under financial strain after spending billions on debt-fueled acquisitions. HNA aims to sell HK$100 billion in assets during the first half, with other disposals in the US and London. The disposal may ease financial strain, but investors remain skeptical about the company's ability to roll over borrowings, with the yield on HNA's yuan-denominated bond doubling to 14.2% this year.

site_title: Firms need to engage with minority shareholders more with rule changes
summary: The Singapore Exchange has proposed rule changes to enhance the role and responsibility of minority shareholders. The changes include requiring votes from minority shareholders to exit quarterly reporting and consider the independence of independent directors. These proposals aim to give minority shareholders actual decision-making capabilities, rather than mere influence. The move is expected to increase transparency and improve investor relations, allowing retail investors to make more informed decisions and potentially affecting company outcomes. Minority shareholders are now expected to be more serious and engaged in the voting process.

site_title: It's been a baptism of fire for the new Fed chair
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell faces significant challenges in his first days in office, with bond and stock markets warning of inflation risk and a potential global recession. The Fed's slow response to interest rate hikes has allowed asset bubbles to inflate, and Powell must decide whether to raise rates as planned or intervene to calm markets. His decision will depend on market volatility and the state of the US economy, with some experts advising him to consider unconventional measures like "helicopter money" to stimulate growth without distorting financial markets.

site_title: Koda aims to double China outlets by 2020; Q2 profit slips 5.1% on delayed shipments
summary: Furniture maker Koda reported a 5.1% slip in Q2 net profit to US$993,000 due to delayed export shipments. Despite this, the company's in-house brand Commune saw sales growth, and the gross profit margin improved by 5 percentage points. Koda aims to double its presence in China by 2020, with plans to expand into Indonesia, Taiwan, and Thailand. The company expects to be profitable in fiscal 2018 and is declaring an interim dividend payout of 0.25 Singapore cent per share.

site_title: Three new judicial commissioners of High Court appointed
summary: President Halimah Yacob appointed Tan Puay Boon, Mavis Chionh, and Ang Cheng Hock as judicial commissioners of the High Court, effective March 12 and May 14 respectively. Tan, 62, and Chionh, 48, will serve for three years, while Ang, 47, will serve for 18 months. Chionh is a veteran prosecutor with over 30 years of experience, having led high-profile cases, while Ang is a partner at Allen & Gledhill with expertise in civil and commercial litigation.

site_title: Snapchat redesign sparks backlash among some users
summary: Snapchat's latest app redesign has sparked a backlash among users, with over 578,000 signing an online petition to roll back the update. The redesign separates media content from friends, aimed at avoiding misinformation, but users claim it's made features more difficult to use. Many users have lost messages or archived data, and some have expressed frustration on Twitter, with some even calling for an uninstallation workaround. Despite analyst predictions that users will adapt to the new layout, the redesign has sparked significant user discontent.

site_title: Amazon threat has Maersk racing to stop clients becoming rivals
