summary: Maersk, the world's largest container shipping line, is racing to stop Amazon and Alibaba from becoming competitors in the logistics industry. CEO Soren Skou believes Amazon's growth poses a threat if Maersk doesn't provide a seamless and integrated supply chain experience. Maersk is modernizing its operations, including digitization and blockchain technology, to meet Amazon's demands. The company aims to bring booking times down to 2 minutes from 22 minutes, and may acquire small companies to expand its capabilities. Maersk sees Amazon as a disruptor and is working to integrate with the e-commerce giant to maintain its competitive edge.

site_title: Global growth outlook seen intact as stock market rebounds
summary: Wall Street rebounded on Monday, preserving investors' outlook on a steady global growth path. Analysts point to factors such as China's high single-digit growth, Europe's sovereign debt recovery, and US tax cuts as reasons for their optimism. Goldman Sachs estimated the global economy expanded at 5.2% in January, and analysts believe the current market turbulence will be short and shallow. However, if market turbulence persists, it could hurt consumer confidence and slow investments, potentially altering the global growth outlook.

site_title: Gold rises, but gains capped before US price data
summary: Gold prices rose 0.5% to $1,323.16 an ounce, despite muted gains, ahead of US inflation data and potential interest rate hikes. The dollar eased against major currencies, making dollar-denominated gold cheaper for holders of other currencies. US inflation data for January is due on Wednesday, and the US Federal Reserve meets on March 20-21, fueling concerns about faster rate hikes.

site_title: US budget outline calls for huge Pentagon increase, cuts to State
summary: The US Pentagon has unveiled a budget proposal for fiscal 2019 that would see a 10% increase in spending, adding 25,900 troops and major investments in aircraft, ships, and missile defense. The proposal is framed in response to a "Great Power" competition with Russia and China. In contrast, the State Department's budget proposal calls for deep cuts, with Secretary of State Rex Tillerson requesting only a slight increase. The cuts have been met with opposition from lawmakers, who argue that they would compromise US diplomatic efforts.

site_title: Oil prices settle flat, steady after a week of losses
summary: Oil prices settled flat on Monday, ending a week of losses. Brent crude futures rose 0.2% to $62.59, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 0.2% to $59.29. A weaker dollar and traders regaining long positions supported oil prices. However, concerns over surging US production and potential Opec output cuts kept prices steady. Analysts expect US crude output to rise to 11 million bpd by the end of the year, and demand growth remains robust.

site_title: Condo resale prices rise 1% in January, 6.3% y-o-y: SRX Property
summary: Condo resale prices rose 1% in January 2018, with a 6.3% year-on-year increase. This follows a sustained trend of island-wide price appreciation, with core central region rising 1.2% and outside central region 0.6%. Resale volume also increased by 15.1% month-on-month and 99.8% year-on-year. The market's recovery is attributed to factors such as the en bloc sale fever, steady economic growth, and the government's tweak of seller's stamp duty. Resale prices are now 1.2% off their last peak in January 2014.

site_title: Ford revs up large SUV production to boost margins, challenge GM
summary: Ford is increasing production of its large SUVs, including the Expedition and Navigator, by 25% this year to boost margins and challenge General Motors' dominance in the US market. The move aims to improve profit margins, which have shrunk to 3.7% in the fourth quarter of 2017. Ford plans to add $25 million in investments at its Kentucky Truck Plant to support the production target hike. The new models have aluminium bodies and are designed to offer better fuel efficiency and driving dynamics.

site_title: Rail travel on the rise as Chinese take trains in annual pilgrimage home
summary: China sees a surge in rail travel during the Chinese New Year holiday, with 400 million people expected to take trains over the 40-day period. The country's high-speed rail network is expanding, with a focus on connecting the east and west, and has become a more affordable option, with top speeds of 250km/h and prices starting at 263 yuan for a single-trip ticket. The expansion aims to bridge economic imbalances between China's east and west, stimulating growth in tourism and other businesses.

site_title: As China marches forward on artificial intelligence, the White House is silent
summary: China has unveiled a plan to become the world leader in artificial intelligence by 2030, with a goal of creating an industry worth $150 billion to its economy. The plan, which was similar to reports released by the Obama administration in 2016, outlines the Chinese government's aggressive approach to treating AI as a national priority. In contrast, the Trump White House has taken little action to respond to the competition, with some experts expressing concern that the US is not providing sufficient direction on how to respond.

site_title: Australia business conditions boom in Jan, as sales and profits surge
summary: Australia's business conditions reached near-boom levels in January, with a National Australia Bank index of business conditions climbing 6 points to +19, a strong reading above the long-run average of +5. Sales and profits surged, with the sales index rising 8 points to +26 and the measure of profitability jumping 9 points to +23. The construction industry was particularly upbeat, driven by strength in home building and public works projects. Economists expect stronger economic growth in coming quarters, with the Reserve Bank of Australia predicting growth of over 3% this year and next.

site_title: Great Eastern's Q4 profit more than doubles to S$424m; eyes growth in Indonesia
summary: Great Eastern's Q4 profit more than doubles to S$424m, driven by stronger insurance sales and gains from investment sales. The company expects to expand into Indonesia and Thailand through bancassurance channels and partnerships. Net profit for the full year 2017 surged to S$1.16 billion, up from S$589.3 million the previous year. The group's group CEO, Khor Hock Seng, aspires to be among the top 10 in Indonesia in the next five years, with a focus on delivering profitable growth and long-term sustainable value for shareholders.

site_title: US: Stocks end higher after calm session, Dow +1.7%
summary: US stocks ended higher on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 1.7% to 24,601.27, and the S&P 500 gaining 1.4% to 2,656.00. The calm session followed a week of volatility, with investors shifting focus to fundamental considerations, such as business results. Key gains were seen in tech stocks, including Apple, Boeing, and CSRA, which surged after agreeing to a $9.6 billion acquisition deal. Analysts will monitor this week's data on consumer price inflation and retail sales for signs of lasting stability.

site_title: China's Fosun set to takeover struggling fashion house Lanvin: sources
summary: China's Fosun is set to acquire a majority stake in struggling French fashion house Lanvin, following a cash crunch and slump in sales. Fosun, which owns Club Med and a stake in Caruso, outbid Qatari investment fund Mayhoola for control. The deal, worth over 100 million euros, sees Fosun investing in Lanvin, with Taiwan-based media magnate Shaw-Lan Wang retaining a minority stake. Lanvin's sales have slumped since the departure of designer Alber Elbaz in 2015, and the company had been facing a cash shortage.

site_title: Indonesia's new cybersecurity head has rough start as polls loom
summary: Indonesia's new cybersecurity chief, Djoko Setiadi, faces criticism for his comments and actions, including suggesting "constructive hoaxes" could be beneficial and proposing to collect tax from e-commerce companies. The country is vulnerable to hackers and social media hoaxes ahead of regional and presidential elections, which could spread false information and radicalization. Indonesia has seen a rise in online misinformation, including a "fake news factory" that spread false information during a recent election. Setiadi vows to ensure the election will be free and fair, but experts question his ability to address the issue, citing the agency's secrecy and lack of cooperation with other branches of government.

site_title: Smart regulation of cryptocurrencies needed in Hong Kong and Singapore
summary: Hong Kong and Singapore are working together to regulate cryptocurrencies and protect investors, curb money laundering, and ensure transparency in the rollout of initial coin offerings (ICOs). Despite differing approaches, both countries aim to balance innovation with prudential regulation, following China's ban on ICOs and Singapore's stance of not regulating cryptocurrencies. Hong Kong views bitcoin as a commodity, while Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister suggests there's no strong case to ban cryptocurrency trading. A harmonized regulatory framework is crucial to ensure safe markets for investors and prevent illicit activities.

site_title: Lower profit margins take a toll on OKP's Q4 earnings
summary: OKP Holdings, a Singapore-based infrastructure and civil engineering company, reported a 75% fall in net profit for the fourth quarter, with earnings per share (EPS) decreasing to 0.64 Singapore cents. The company attributed the decline to lower profit margins from projects due to a competitive pricing environment and rising manpower costs. For the full year, net profit fell 11% to S$12.7 million, and revenue rose 6% to S$117.3 million. OKP has proposed a final dividend of 0.7 Singapore cent per share and a special dividend of 1.3 cents per share for shareholders' approval.

site_title: On the green path
summary: Direct air capture companies aim to remove 10 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere by 2070 to meet climate goals. Companies like Climeworks, Carbon Engineering, and Global Thermostat are developing pilot plants to capture CO2 from the air. Climeworks plans to scale up production to 3,000 tonnes per year, while Carbon Engineering aims to capture millions of tonnes per year. However, direct air capture is four times more expensive than reforestation and requires significant investment. The industry is hoping for a mandatory carbon tax to finance large-scale projects.

site_title: S$25m LTA fund to boost mobility-linked research and trials
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore has set aside S$25 million over five years to boost mobility-related research and trials. The fund aims to create 8,000 new jobs by 2030, primarily in the bus and rail sectors, with the current workforce expected to grow to 21,000 by then. The LTA will collaborate with industry partners, including ST Kinetics, on projects such as autonomous robot movers and augmented reality devices. The government also plans to up-skill workers through institutes of higher learning and a Public Transport Skills Framework.

images.alt_text: Christopher Tan

site_title: Heineken cheers rising profits in 2017
summary: Heineken reported a 25.6% increase in net profit to 1.93 billion euros in 2017, driven by higher sales of its premium brand beer across nearly all regions. The company's sales rose 5.3% to 21.9 billion euros, with the Heineken brand performing well, including the launch of Heineken 0.0 in 16 countries. The brewer also announced a 4.5% increase in sales of its premium brand beer. Despite warning of volatility and uncertainty in 2018, Heineken proposed a 9.3% increase in its dividend payout.

site_title: Queen Elizabeth is behind a royal push to cut plastic waste
summary: Queen Elizabeth II has pushed for environmental changes at Buckingham Palace, banning straws and bottles at all royal estates and implementing a composting system. The move is part of a decade-long refurbishment to make the palace more green, featuring solar panels and energy-efficient systems. The initiative follows the success of a BBC documentary, Blue Planet II, which highlighted the effects of plastic waste on the world's waters. The royal household aims to reduce its environmental impact, joining a growing list of initiatives to tackle plastic waste globally, where 300 million tonnes of plastic are produced annually.

site_title: CapitaLand buys Pearl Bank Apartments for S$728m; Q4 profit falls 38%
summary: CapitaLand acquired the Pearl Bank Apartments in Chinatown for S$728 million, with an estimated land price of S$1,515 per square foot per gross floor area. The sale price translates to a minimum gross profit of between S$1.8 million and S$4.9 million for apartment owners, and S$1.2 million to S$6.9 million for commercial unit owners. The developer plans to redevelop the site into a high-rise residential development with around 800 units and social facilities. This acquisition comes as CapitaLand reported a 38% drop in its fourth-quarter net profit to S$267.7 million.

site_title: Metro's Q3 profit soars to S$146.6m
summary: Metro Holdings reported a significant increase in Q3 profit to S$146.6m, driven by the disposal of eight property projects and the sale of its 30% interest in Nanchang Fashion Mark.

site_title: Punting on O&M recovery is foolhardy before solid research
summary: The oil and gas (O&M) sector in Singapore is showing signs of recovery, with brokers maintaining buy calls for companies like Keppel Corp and Sembcorp Marine despite recent market volatility. New orders have risen significantly, particularly for large turnkey projects, and analysts expect more E&P projects to enter the tender pipeline, bolstering earnings. However, the sector still faces severe challenges, including the US shale industry's impact on offshore oil and gas projects, and the need for companies to manage costs and execute projects effectively to ensure profitability.

site_title: Hype & hustle beckon in 2018
summary: The Singapore residential market is expected to see a surge in demand and prices in 2018, driven by improving economic sentiment, record land prices, and a shortage of prime properties. The market has seen a 74% increase in total transaction volume in 2017, with median prices rising 1.8% and 5.6% year-over-year in Q3 and Q4 2017, respectively. The government's initiatives to attract foreign investment and the growing popularity of ultra-luxury homes are also expected to contribute to the market's growth. However, interest rates and global trade protectionism may pose risks to the market, and property investors should monitor these factors and weigh their financing options carefully.

site_title: French companies lack qualified staff despite 3.5m jobless
summary: France's economic recovery faces challenges as companies struggle to find qualified staff, despite a 3.5 million jobless rate. Companies like Airbus supplier FIGEAC-AERO cite difficulty in hiring as one of their biggest problems. The issue highlights the need for revamped worker-training programs and improved incentives to work.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Cost, talent crunch forcing firms to outsource abroad
summary: Singapore's tech industry faces a talent crunch, with companies like Shopmatic and RedDoorz turning to offshoring to hire programmers and developers. The industry is calling for flexible foreign manpower policies for tech roles, but experts say this is only a short-term fix. Longer-term solutions, such as teaching tech skills in schools and providing relevant training, are needed to equip the workforce with skills matching industry needs. The government has already launched initiatives, including the TechSkills Accelerator programme, to address the talent gap.

site_title: 2018's big picture
summary: In 2018, the global market trend favored equities, particularly in Asia and emerging markets, with the S&P 500 returning over 27%, Asia ex-Japan stocks over 41%, and emerging markets nearly 39%. However, experts advise investors to scale back expectations due to the potential end of the "Icarus trade" and an aggressive downgrade of risk assets as central banks withdraw liquidity. High net-worth investors are recommended to invest in private equity or venture capital, with a focus on mega-trends such as the Internet of Things and cryptocurrencies.

site_title: Pyeongchang Games: South Korea's billboard to the world
summary: The Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea, have brought a unique opportunity for the country to present a positive image to the world, capitalizing on a "brand makeover" after a tumultuous 2017. While the event's economic impact is often overstated, South Korea can learn from the example of New Zealand, which successfully transformed its reputation by showcasing its natural environment and unique brand. To maximize the Olympics' benefits, South Korea must pursue a concerted strategy that aligns all stakeholders around a single, coherent vision for its country brand, highlighting its strengths and fostering favorable international perceptions.

site_title: World's tallest hotel opens in Dubai
summary: The Gevora Hotel, a 75-storey gold-tinted skyscraper, has officially opened in Dubai, surpassing another Dubai landmark to become the world's new tallest hotel at 356 meters tall.

site_title: ECICS gets credit rating downgrades from AM Best
summary: Rating agency AM Best downgraded ECICS (Singapore) financial strength rating to "B++" (good) from "A-" (excellent) and issuer credit rating to "bbb+" from "a-". The outlook was revised to stable from negative.

site_title: Valentine's Day roses save Colombians in thorny situation
summary: Colombians working in greenhouses near Bogota to prepare roses for Valentine's Day have found temporary refuge from the Venezuelan border crisis. Many Venezuelans have fled to Colombia, resulting in a surge in labor demand, which has allowed Colombians to find work. The high demand for roses has provided a welcome distraction from the economic and humanitarian challenges posed by the Venezuelan migration crisis.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean companies reported significant earnings growth in the fourth quarter of 2017. SBS Transit saw a 50.3% rise in net earnings to S$47.1 million, while Bukit Sembawang Estates' net profit doubled to S$10.7 million. Civmec's net profit jumped to S$6.9 million, driven by higher contributions from existing contracts. Cordlife Group reported a third consecutive quarterly net profit, driven by growing public awareness of pre-emptive healthcare in Asia. In contrast, Hatten Land Limited's net profit fell 49.4% due to higher selling and distribution expenses.

site_title: Sapphire says growth prospects of core business intact
summary: Sapphire Corporation's CEO Wang Heng stated that the growth prospects of the group's core business remain unaffected by the termination of a proposed transaction with substantial shareholders. The transaction, which would have led to a new substantial shareholder, has been terminated. Despite this, Wang emphasized that the company is securing new contracts and increasing its order book, with 3.4 billion yuan in new rail contracts won in December 2017. Wang plans to leverage her 27 years of experience in civil engineering to strengthen the business and accelerate growth in China.

site_title: Composer Jóhann Jóhannsson dies at 48
summary: Icelandic composer Jóhann Jóhannsson, known for his Oscar-nominated scores in The Theory of Everything and Arrival, has died at 48. His body was found in his Berlin apartment, with his manager confirming the news. Jóhannsson was described as "one of the most talented musicians and intelligent people" by his manager. The cause of death has not been disclosed.

site_title: 2018: A year of two halves
summary: US economic growth has picked up since Donald Trump's presidency, with investors profiting from a "Goldilocks" environment of low interest rates, synchronized economic growth, and improving corporate earnings. Market momentum is strong, but analysts like Bank of Singapore's Sean Quek caution that valuations are no longer supportive and central bank balance sheets are expanding. Quek expects markets to become more challenging as the year progresses, with a potential "year of two halves" for the US. Key indicators include corporate capital expenditure, deregulation, and inflation, which could spur the Federal Reserve to more aggressive rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Hyundai throws weight behind ride-sharing firms
summary: Hyundai Motor Co is in talks with ride-sharing firms Waymo, Uber, and Grab to provide a flexible, open platform for its cars, allowing buyers to customize applications to suit their needs. The company is betting against individuals owning robot cars, instead preparing for a future where ride-sharing giants will be the biggest buyers. This move comes as companies like Waymo and General Motors Co race to bring driverless cars to showrooms, challenging the traditional car ownership model. Hyundai's strategy aims to capitalize on the growing demand for ride-sharing services.

site_title: Riding the AI wave
summary: Allianz Global Investors has launched an artificial intelligence fund, the Allianz Global Artificial Intelligence Fund, allowing investors to invest in the early stages of AI development. The fund aims to capitalize on the transformative potential of AI in various industries, including finance, healthcare, and transportation. According to AllianzGI director Stephen Jue, AI will drive productivity, time savings, and enhancements across industries, making services better and jobs more productive. The fund is seen as a strategic move to tap into the rapidly growing AI market.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Peering into the crypto ball
summary: In 2018, cryptocurrencies experienced rapid growth, with bitcoin's value increasing nearly twenty-fold. Predictions for the year include: more investors, including friends and family, buying ether and other altcoins; ICO whitepapers being poorly understood by average investors; some projects launching while others fail; altcoins rising due to outdated technology and the emergence of newer, more innovative competitors; increased regulation and institutional investment; and the bulls and bears continuing to disagree over the asset class's potential. These predictions highlight the speculative nature of the cryptocurrency market and the potential for both success and failure in the industry.

site_title: China property outbound investment expected to drop by up to 40%
summary: China's overseas property investments are expected to drop by 30-40% in 2018, down from a record $42.2 billion in 2017, due to tighter government controls and approval procedures. The decline is attributed to a clampdown on "irrational" investments in sectors such as property, hotels, and entertainment. The move aims to restrict capital outflows and stabilize the yuan and foreign exchange reserves.

site_title: SGX down 7.4% on Nifty futures doubts; brokers maintain ratings
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) fell 7.4% on Monday amid doubts about the future of its Indian equity index-linked derivatives, following India's announcement that it will stop providing data feeds to foreign rivals and halt trading of offshore derivatives tied to the Nifty 50 index. Analysts at RHB Research, DBS Bank, and OCBC Bank maintained their ratings on SGX's stock, citing the company's efforts to drive market liquidity and new product initiatives. The SGX stated that its market for India products will remain open until at least August.

site_title: Brick-and-mortar firms need to up their game in digital space
summary: Small and medium brick-and-mortar businesses in Singapore need to adapt to the digital age to remain competitive. Despite the growth of e-commerce, many travel agencies and retail outlets have yet to adopt digital technologies. To succeed, businesses must establish an online presence, focusing on platforms like Facebook and WhatsApp, and offering e-commerce, delivery options, and customer support. Additionally, they should target niche areas and engage with mobile users. Those that fail to adapt risk becoming victims of digital disruption, as seen with the bankruptcy of Toys "R" Us Inc.

site_title: One-stop agency for SMEs to grow Singapore's startup ecosystem
summary: The Ministry of Trade and Industry has announced plans to merge IE Singapore and SPRING Singapore, aiming to provide a more holistic approach for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to tap government support. This move is expected to benefit SMEs by having a single agency tasked with supporting their growth and related needs, addressing the long-standing call from local enterprises for such a unified support system.

site_title: Sochi misstep lifts Canada to Olympic gold
summary: Canadian ice dance star Scott Moir and partner Tessa Virtue won the Olympic figure-skating team gold in Pyeongchang, South Korea. Moir attributed their victory to a "too casual" approach four years ago at Sochi, where they came in second. This defeat was "irksome" for a country born on ice, but it motivated them to work harder. Moir and Virtue defeated defending champions Russia and the United States, marking Canada's first gold in the Winter Games' heavyweights in South Korea.

site_title: Transparency in sporting contracts could head off doping scourge
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has refused to invite 28 Russian athletes who were cleared by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) to compete in the 2018 Pyeongchang Olympics, despite their reinstated records. The IOC cited that the CAS's decision was based on evidence not available to their own investigation team. The World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) has welcomed the decision, calling it a boost for clean sport and the integrity of the Games. The controversy highlights the ongoing issues of doping and corruption in professional sports, with some athletes and officials accusing the IOC of being "amoral and politicised".

site_title: Smog in major China regions worsened in January
summary: China's Yangtze River delta region near Shanghai saw a 20% increase in smog concentrations in January, reaching 72 micrograms per cubic meter, despite a 17.9% year-on-year decrease nationwide. The rise in smog in the region has raised concerns that pollution crackdowns in northern China may force heavy industry to move further south, exacerbating pollution problems. This trend could lead to increased environmental and health concerns for local populations.

site_title: Who loves and hates the FBI now?
summary: The US party system appears to have shifted, with the GOP now seen as the party of Political Change, rather than the traditional Law and Order party. This change is attributed to the presidency of Donald Trump, who has been associated with a more permissive approach to globalism and security institutions. The shift in perception may be due to Trump's unconventional methods and policies, which have led to a reevaluation of the GOP's values and stance on national security.

site_title: GSH buying 50% stake in prime Jalan Petaling plot
summary: GSH Corporation has agreed to invest RM164.5 million to acquire a 50% stake in a 1.4-hectare plot in Kuala Lumpur's Chinatown precinct for a premium condominium project. The 99-year leasehold site will feature about 1,700 units. The project, located near Pasar Seni and Masjid Jamek LRT stations, will target a different market seeking urban living in a rich, historical area. This is GSH's second residential project in Kuala Lumpur after Eaton Residences, which has sold almost all units.

site_title: Mumbai's hope lies in docklands' inclusive revival
summary: Mumbai's Sassoon Dock is set for a massive overhaul under a redevelopment plan, offering a chance for a more sustainable and inclusive future for residents. The fishing community, the city's original residents, had a say in the redevelopment, with a recent art project showcasing colourful installations inspired by their culture. The docklands project aims to address the city's space shortage, providing a unique opportunity for residents to engage with the redevelopment process and potentially transform the area into a thriving, inclusive space.

site_title: No need to burn midnight oil at this 'Harvard' for horror
summary: The Miskatonic Institute of Horror Studies, named after a fictional university from HP Lovecraft's stories, offers a unique learning experience focused on horror. Unlike the fictional Miskatonic University, which is portrayed as a typical New England college with occult elements, the real-life institute provides courses and workshops on horror, the supernatural, and the macabre. The institute aims to create a community of horror enthusiasts and provide a platform for students to explore their interest in the genre.

site_title: Euro pushback ends US dollar recovery
summary: The US dollar experienced a reversal in its recovery, as the euro edged higher and the dollar fell 0.2% against a basket of currencies. The dollar's rally ended after a strong start to the week for equity markets, which boosted appetite for risk-taking in currency markets. Investors are now betting on the euro, driving up its value to 1.2270. This move erases some of the dollar's gains from last week, which saw the euro reach a three-year high. Analysts attribute the shift to reduced risk aversion and anticipation of US inflation data on Wednesday.

site_title: Doing business in China: Politics is still in command
summary: China's business environment remains heavily influenced by politics, with the Communist Party maintaining control over key sectors and decision-making processes. The country's emphasis on inspirational quotes, such as Chairman Mao Zedong's "The Chinese people have stood up," is reflected in the widespread use of fortune cookies and quote websites. Meanwhile, global events like the US-China summit and Donald Trump's foreign policy shift are shaping the country's international relationships. As China continues to develop its AI talent pool, it faces competition from other nations in the global AI talent war.

site_title: Rail fight threatens coal giants' Australian exports
summary: Aurizon Holdings Ltd, Australia's top coal hauler, is set for a showdown with major coal exporters after a regulator capped its revenue at A$1 billion less than the company sought. The cap, worth A$4 billion in export income, would cut throughput on its network by 20 million tonnes a year, affecting coal giants like BHP Billiton and Glencore. The decision is seen as a blow to the coal industry, with the Queensland Resources Council accusing Aurizon of using its power as a monopoly rail operator.

site_title: This Chinese New Year, delivery startups keep tradition alive
summary: In Singapore, delivery startups are experiencing high demand for Chinese New Year (CNY) orders, with some reporting a 50% increase in orders compared to normal weekends. Restaurants are offering delivery services for CNY dishes, with companies like foodpanda and Uber Eats ramping up their fleets and offering special menus. However, the increased demand has put pressure on manpower needs, with some companies hiring more staff and raising kitchen salaries. The travel industry is also seeing a boost, with bookings rising 15% for Dynasty Travel and 10% for Chan Brothers.

site_title: Nafta's red tape fight hits snag as business group sounds alarm
summary: The US, Canada, and Mexico are at odds over a proposal to strengthen Nafta's powers to cut red tape. Canada wants to roll the existing US-Canada Regulatory Cooperation Council into the agreement, which would simplify regulations on issues like food safety and drones. However, the US is threatening to quit Nafta, and some business groups warn that simplifying regulations could lead to a step backward. The Canadian proposal aims to boost business efficiency while also adding Mexico to the mix. The outcome of the negotiations remains uncertain.

site_title: Asia's economic growth boosts diesel demand in the region
summary: Asia's economic growth boosts diesel demand, despite refineries being shut for seasonal maintenance, which may squeeze supplies in the region. Strong consumption of diesel, used to power everything from lorries to ships and factories, has underpinned crude's bull run last year, now threatened by US output surges. Refiners in India and other Asian countries expect robust growth, with demand outpacing supply, and prices supported by the global economic recovery. However, experts warn that too much supply may follow in the latter half of the year once refineries return online.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore's industrial real estate investment trusts (REITs) are expected to be influenced by market momentum for the next few days. Large-cap REITs are preferred for their diversified portfolios, but may be sensitive to rate hikes. Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust is recommended for its exposure to the Australian economy and minimal leasing risks. Small-to-mid-cap REITs, such as Viva Industrial Trust, are recommended for their potential to trade at higher valuations after a potential merger with ESR-Reit. The sector's performance is expected to improve with tapering supply of industrial space in 2018, but occupancy rates may still be affected by negative reversions.

site_title: Disruption is the new norm
summary: Singapore's fintech industry has shifted from a competitive landscape to a collaborative one, with incumbents working with startups to adopt disruptive technologies. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has played a key role in creating a fertile environment, showcasing the country's achievements as a fintech hub. Regulators are taking a wait-and-see approach to cryptocurrencies, while the government has announced initiatives to bolster the industry. A unified payments system is also being developed, with the MAS releasing a proposed Payment Services Bill to streamline regulation. The country is positioning itself as a digital port, harnessing data analytics to unlock insights and enhance financial supervision.

site_title: Venture & conquer
summary: Finian Tan, co-founder of Vickers Venture Partners, is considered one of the world's most successful venture capitalists due to his determination, intellect, and financial acumen. Tan's career began with a strong academic record, including winning all awards at the University of Glasgow, and he went on to work at Shell and Goldman Sachs before joining the Singapore government to help transform the country into a Silicon Valley. He discovered his passion for venture capital through the TIF fund and co-founded Vickers Venture Partners, which has raised over $2 billion in assets. Tan's firm is known for its unique approach, including a dynamic filter and high alignment of interest between investors and the firm, and has delivered impressive returns, including a 41% net internal rate of return. Tan is now mulling his succession plan, aiming to take on a "lesser" role by 65 and transition into philanthropy, focusing on environmental conservation and education in developing regions.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Key themes to chew on in 2018
summary: Markets ended 2017 on a buoyant note, carrying into 2018 with expectations of a more hawkish stance among central banks and inflation concerns dampening fixed-income performance. Strategists favor equities, but question how long the party will last. Fund flows reflect a strong appetite for emerging-markets equity and bond funds, while investors are split on the timing of an equity market peak. A survey found 83% of investors believe bond markets are overvalued, and net protection against a market correction has risen.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Powering ahead
summary: A 2018 roundtable discussion with wealth experts assesses major macro-themes, including the "hunger for yield" and biggest risks. Experts like John Woods, Managing Director and Chief Investment Officer at Credit Suisse, discuss market movements and investment strategies. Key takeaways include a focus on yield, macro-economic risks, and the impact of global events on markets. The discussion highlights the importance of adapting to changing market conditions and seeking diversification to mitigate risks.

site_title: Chinese stock investors complain about losses on US embassy Weibo account
summary: Chinese investors expressed frustration on the US embassy's Weibo account over stock losses, with over 10,000 comments posted. The embassy allowed comments to remain active despite deleting those violating its terms of use. The comments came after China's equities suffered their steepest weekly decline in two years.

site_title: SingPass, CorpPass systems under maintenance again from midnight to 4am on Feb 13
summary: The SingPass and CorpPass systems in Singapore will be unavailable from midnight to 4am on February 13 due to maintenance. The systems had previously experienced outages last week, causing disruptions to hundreds of e-government services. The Government Technology Agency of Singapore (GovTech) stated that the maintenance is not related to cybersecurity issues, but rather a server fault. The agency apologizes for any inconvenience caused and assures users that the systems will be available again after the maintenance period.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 10.35 points to 1,830.17. The index saw 1.8 billion shares traded worth RM2.27 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 484-453.

site_title: European firms form consortium to bid for high-speed railway
summary: European firms Siemens, Alstom, Ferrovie dello Stato Italiane, and PORR have formed a consortium with George Kent to bid for the high-speed rail link between Kuala Lumpur and Singapore, targeting completion by 2026. The 350km link has attracted bids from Chinese and Japanese companies, including a consortium of 10 Japanese companies. Bids must be submitted by mid-2018, with the contract expected to be awarded by year-end. The European consortium brings together expertise in high-speed projects and local knowledge of the Malaysian market.

images.alt_text: Christopher Tan

site_title: German court rules Facebook use of personal data illegal
summary: A German regional court ruled that Facebook's use of personal data is illegal due to inadequate informed consent from users. The Federation of German Consumer Organisations found Facebook's default settings and terms of service breached consumer law, leading to invalid consent for data usage. Facebook plans to appeal, but has already made changes to its terms of service and data protection guidelines. The ruling comes as Facebook faces scrutiny from Germany's competition authorities over its handling of user data, including concerns over third-party data access and location sharing.

site_title: OUE Lippo Healthcare still in the red for Q4 and fiscal 2017
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare Limited reported a net loss of S$55.2 million for the fourth quarter and full year ended Dec 31, 2017, due to other operating losses of S$44.3 million and S$62.7 million, respectively. Revenue declined 0.5% to S$10.6 million. The company has announced a strategic partnership with ITOCHU Corporation to strengthen its financial position and execute business plans, aiming to become a leading healthcare company in Asia.

site_title: Baker Technology secures time charter contract
summary: BAKER Technology Limited has secured a time charter contract for its liftboat, the Blue Titanium, to support rejuvenation works for an oil company in South-east Asia. The charter, with an undisclosed contract sum, is expected to contribute to the group's financial performance for the 2018 financial year. The contract was awarded in the second quarter of 2018.

site_title: India's move to stop trading of Indian indices abroad a slap to SGX's face
summary: India's National Stock Exchange (NSE) has stopped trading of Indian indices abroad, effectively isolating its derivatives market, giving the Singapore Exchange (SGX) six months to work out a resolution. The move affects the SGX, which relies heavily on trading the Nifty 50 index futures, accounting for 11-12% of its total derivatives volume. India's decision is seen as counter-intuitive, as the country enjoys 90% of the global Nifty derivatives market, and foreign investors have grown significantly in the onshore market.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Tillerson says 'too early' for direct talks with N Korea
summary: US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson stated it's "too early" to discuss direct negotiations with North Korea, following Vice President Mike Pence's comments on the US being open to talks. Pence mentioned the US would impose "steep and escalating costs" on North Korea until it takes clear steps toward denuclearisation. Tillerson emphasized the need for North Korea to demonstrate readiness to engage in a "meaningful" conversation, amid a diplomatic charm offensive by North Korean leader Kim Jong Un following the Winter Olympics.

site_title: EU antitrust regulators to fine NYK, Wilhelmsen, other car shipping firms - sources
summary: EU antitrust regulators are set to fine Nippon Yusen KK (NYK), Wallenius Wilhelmsen Logistics ASA (WWL), and other Japanese and Norwegian shippers for rigging bids for shipping cars. The investigation, launched in 2012, found the companies admitted wrongdoing in exchange for a reduced fine. The sanctions come after a near six-year investigation, with the companies involved including K Line and Mitsui OSK Lines. The fines are expected to be announced in the coming weeks.

site_title: GSH to buy prime Jalan Petaling plot in Kuala Lumpur for S$55m
summary: GSH Corporation is investing S$55.2 million (164.5 million ringgit) to acquire a 50% stake in a 1.4-hectare plot in Kuala Lumpur's Chinatown precinct. The 99-year leasehold site will be developed into a 1,700-unit premium condominium. The development is expected to be built near the M101 Skywheel integrated development, a new iconic landmark with a shopping mall and Planet Hollywood Hotel. The acquisition is funded by a combination of internal resources and borrowings.

site_title: Pence says US ready to talk with North Korea in policy shift
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence announced a policy shift, signaling readiness to engage in talks with North Korea over its nuclear program while maintaining pressure on the regime. Pence dubbed this approach "maximum pressure and engagement," stating that sanctions relief would only be granted after concrete steps towards denuclearization are taken. This marks a departure from the Trump administration's previous stance, and Pence's comments were seen as a significant shift in American policy.

site_title: Chinese stock investors vent on US Embassy Weibo account
summary: Chinese investors flooded the US embassy's Weibo account with over 10,000 comments criticizing the stock market and its regulator, Liu Shiyu, following the Shanghai Composite Index's 9.6% tumble. Investors blamed the US for the decline and criticized the China Securities Regulatory Commission for not intervening, with some threatening to have a bad time during the Lunar New Year holiday due to their losses. The CSRC didn't respond to requests for comment, and public criticism of senior officials is generally forbidden in China.

site_title: Metro reports sevenfold jump in Q3 net profit
summary: Metro Holdings reported a sevenfold increase in Q3 net profit to S$146.61 million, driven by associate Top Spring International Holdings' disposal of eight property projects and Metro's sale of its Nanchang Fashion Mark stake. Revenue grew 5.4% year-on-year to S$39.3 million, with improved results from property and retail segments. The group expects rental income stability for its UK and Shanghai properties, and has entered new joint ventures in Jakarta and London.

site_title: Anwell Technologies to be wound up, no further extensions for judicial management
summary: Singapore-listed company Anwell Technologies will be wound up after its judicial managers announced no further extensions to the judicial management order. The company's China subsidiary and officers were found guilty of fraud, resulting in hefty fines and prison sentences. The judicial managers will apply to the Singapore High Court for the company's release and discharge of the order, followed by its winding up. The officers, including Fan Kai Leung, Wu Wai Kin, and Kwong Chi Kit Victor, received life imprisonment, prison sentences, and significant fines.

site_title: Pacific Star Development's Q4 net profit up 28%
summary: Pacific Star Development's Q4 net profit rose 28.6% to S$3.88 million, driven by a 78.3% surge in revenue to S$30.73 million from the Puteri Cove Residences & Quayside project in Malaysia. Total assets grew 40.3% to S$183.5 million. Phase 1 of the project is expected to be completed before the end of February. The company has also formed strategic alliances with leading property players and capital partners.

site_title: No pot party for Canada's landlords seeking limits on use
summary: Canada's landlords are seeking limits on marijuana use in rental units ahead of the country's July legalization of recreational weed. Concerns include safety, damage to buildings, and disturbance to other tenants. Proposals include allowing private residences and limiting grow-ops to four plants per unit. Landlords fear potential costs, including damage deposits and higher rents, while provinces are still working out rules for recreational pot consumption and cultivation. Some provinces, like Ontario, have blocked landlords from extracting damage deposits, while others, like Quebec, may apply existing tobacco smoking bans to marijuana.

site_title: Vallianz posts 26.2% boost in Q3 on higher operating profits
summary: Vallianz Holdings reported a 26.2% boost in third-quarter earnings due to higher operating profits, reaching US$5.9 million. The company attributed the increase to reduced depreciation expenses and a strategic focus on its core chartering and brokerage services business. Revenue rose 29.6% to US$53.6 million, driven by new charter contracts and vessel management services. Despite a challenging operating environment for the offshore support vessel segment, Vallianz expects to deploy additional vessels and secure long-term vessel charters with national oil companies.

site_title: HMI reports jump in Q2 profit, declares dividend
summary: Health Management International (HMI) reported a significant jump in its second-quarter net profit to RM15.72 million, a nearly triple increase from RM5.33 million, driven by improved performance and increased hospital ownership. Revenue rose 8.5% year-on-year to RM115.99 million, while earnings per share increased to RM1.9 cents. The company declared an interim dividend of RM1 cent per share and adopted a new dividend policy to pay out at least 20% of core operating earnings.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: US: Tech, financials lead Wall Street higher at the open
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Monday, led by technology and financial stocks, as they rebounded from their worst week in two years. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 215.99 points, or 0.89%, to 24,406.89, while the S&P 500 gained 22.68 points, or 0.87%, to 2,642.23. The Nasdaq Composite added 62.39 points, or 0.91%, to 6,936.88. The gains come despite ongoing US trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: Airbus says 30% of Pratt-powered A320neo jets flawed
summary: Airbus has revealed that 30% of its Pratt & Whitney-powered A320neo jets are affected by a new engine glitch, with 14 jets impacted by the issue. The problems are isolated to "a limited subpopulation" of the engines and are from the most recent batches. Deliveries of A320neos with Pratt engines have been suspended, and Airbus is working with Pratt to swap out faulty engines. The issue is a blow to the A320neo, Airbus's best-selling plane, and has forced the company to halt deliveries.

site_title: Cordlife posts third straight quarter of profit
summary: Cordlife Group reported its third consecutive quarterly net profit, driven by growing public awareness and appreciation of pre-emptive healthcare in Asia. The company's stem cell banking business showed significant growth, with revenue rising 7.6% year-on-year to S$16.4 million. The turnaround was attributed to increased contributions from India, Singapore, and the Philippines, as well as reduced discounts and higher prices in these markets. The group's bottom line also benefited from an absence of non-operating costs, with a net profit of S$736,000 for the quarter.

site_title: Living it up on the Highlands
summary: Scotland was voted the world's most beautiful country by readers of Rough Guides in 2018. The country offers various luxury travel options, including scenic drives, golfing in St Andrews, and luxury train rides along the Silver Sands of Morar. Belmond Royal Scotsman, a luxury sleeper train, offers itineraries ranging from two to seven nights and combines fine dining, personal service, and stunning Scottish scenery. Guests can also stay at iconic hotels like The Balmoral and The Gleneagles Hotel, which offer world-class amenities and activities such as golf, falconry, and off-road safaris.

site_title: SBS Transit profit grows 50% to $47m
summary: SBS Transit, a Singapore bus and train operator, reported a 50.3% increase in net earnings to $47.1 million for the year ended Dec 31, 2017, driven by a government bus contracting model, higher ridership, and the commencement of Downtown Line 3. Revenue rose 8.5% to $1.2 billion, while operating costs increased 7.1%. The company's operating margin before tax, interest, and depreciation improved to 13.1%. Directors expect transport revenue to continue growing this year and recommended a final dividend of 3.95 cents.

site_title: UBS increases bonus pool for Asia-Pacific investment bankers by 6%: sources
summary: UBS increased the 2017 bonus pool for its Asia-Pacific investment bankers by 6% as dealmaking rebounded and the bank sought to retain junior staff focusing on China. Junior bankers in the region received average 12% compensation increases, with some receiving raises of 15-20%. This marks a reversal from the previous year's 15% cut in the regional investment banking payout pool. UBS's regional investment bank saw a 66% pretax profit jump in 2017, driven by a revival in China equity and equity-related deals.

site_title: Surbana Jurong inks deal to develop New Clark City
summary: Surbana Jurong has signed a memorandum of cooperation with the Bases Conversion and Development Authority (BCDA) and Japan Overseas Infrastructure Investment Corporation for Transport and Urban Development (JOIN) to develop New Clark City in the Philippines. The project aims to create a "smart, green, disaster-resilient city" with a population of two million, set to contribute $1.57 trillion to the national economy. Surbana Jurong will assist in drafting development management frameworks and advising on public-private partnerships to attract investors, while JOIN will benefit from the Manila-Clark Railway project, cutting travel time from Manila to Clark to an hour.

site_title: Britain's Saga signs reinsurance quota share with Hannover Re, NewRe
summary: Saga Plc, a British tourism and insurance group, signed a quota share deal with Hannover Re and NewRe to take on 80% of the motor underwriting risk of its in-house underwriter AICL. The three-year agreement reduces Saga's exposure to underwriting risk and provides further capital relief. The deal is effective February next year and replaces an existing quota share arrangement. Saga's shares rose 3.1% following the announcement, with the company's CEO stating that the move will help maintain underwriting quality.

site_title: OKP Holdings' Q4 net profit falls 75%
summary: OKP Holdings, a Singapore-based infrastructure and civil engineering company, reported a 75% fall in net profit for the fourth quarter of 2017, to S$2 million, due to lower profit margins from projects and rising costs. The company's gross profit margin declined to 19.5% from 31.3% in the previous year. Revenue dropped 24% to S$26.1 million, mainly due to a decrease in construction projects. Despite this, the company's full-year revenue rose 6% to S$117.3 million. OKP has proposed a final dividend of 0.7 cents and a special dividend of 1.3 cents per share.

site_title: Coincheck heist sheds light on Japan's rush to create cryptocurrency rules
summary: A recent cryptocurrency heist at Coincheck in Japan exposed flaws in the country's regulatory framework, which was designed to balance protection of traders with the growth of the industry. The exchange's failure to store assets securely led to a $530 million theft, rivaling the 2014 Mt Gox hack. Japan's system, which allowed unapproved exchanges to operate, was deemed too lenient by some, while proponents argue the approach was necessary to nurture the start-up-heavy industry. The incident raises questions about the effectiveness of Japan's regulatory approach, contrasting with stricter oversight in countries like South Korea and China.

images.alt_text: After the Mt Gox cryptocurrency exchange was stung by a half-billion dollar theft in 2014, Japanese regulators swung into action.

site_title: VIDEOS: SME wishlists for Singapore Budget 2018
summary: Singapore's SMEs expressed hopes for various initiatives in the 2018 Budget, including increased support for innovation, digitalization, and funding for small businesses. Past winners and finalists of key awards shared their wishlists, calling for measures to enhance entrepreneurship, improve access to funding, and promote economic growth. The budget, announced by the government, aimed to address these concerns and provide a boost to the country's small and medium-sized enterprises. The outcome of the budget was not explicitly stated in the article.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rebound at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rebounded on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 jumping 0.9% to 7,159.18 points, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 advancing 1.1% and 1.0% respectively. The rebounds follow recoveries in other markets and come as investors look to US-EU trade talks and the ongoing tariff uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Europe's main stock markets rebounded at the start of trading on Monday following recoveries elsewhere, as volatility grips global equity markets.

site_title: China property outbound investment to drop by up to 40 per cent: Cushman & Wakefield
summary: China's overseas property investment is expected to drop 30-40% in 2018, from $42.2 billion last year, due to tighter government controls and approval procedures. The yuan's decline and China's foreign exchange reserves led to restrictions on capital outflows, including property investments. Chinese investors are expected to favor projects backed by Beijing, such as infrastructure and business parks, and avoid trophy office assets, hotels, and retail malls. Hong Kong, the US, and Britain remain popular destinations, but investment is expected to be limited by onshore holding patterns.

images.alt_text: Overseas property investments by Chinese institutions are expected to drop by 30-40 per cent in 2018, from a record US$42.2 billion last year, amid tighter government controls and approval procedures, a real estate services firm said.

site_title: More growth expected in tourism this year after a bumper 2017
summary: Singapore's tourism sector is expected to continue growing this year, with projected tourism receipts increasing by 1-3% to S$27.1-27.6 billion and visitor arrivals expected to rise by 1-4% to 17.6-18.1 million. The sector registered record highs in 2017, driven by an improving global economy and rising travel demand in the Asia-Pacific. China became the top source market, with a 13% increase in arrivals, while India saw the highest growth rate at 16%. The tourism board is optimistic about the outlook, citing positive factors such as intra-regional travel and the launch of new flights.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

After yet another milestone year in 2017, the Singapore Tourism Board (STB) is betting on further growth, its optimism underpinned by an improving global economy and rising travel demand in the Asia-Pacific.

site_title: O&M firm Gaylin spills more red ink with loss of S$2.6m in Q3
summary: Gaylin Holdings, a multidisciplinary offshore and marine services firm, reported a loss of S$2.61 million in the third quarter of 2018, a 29.8% decrease from the previous year. Revenue fell 23.6% to S$14.6 million due to a weak oil and gas market. The company received a S$68 million investment from PeakBayou Limited, which will be used to strengthen its capital base and support general working capital purposes. Gaylin's shares closed at S$0.09 apiece, and the company expects to list and quote the new shares, representing 75.64% of its enlarged share capital.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks claw back some of last week's losses; won firms
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index recovered some of last week's heavy losses, rising 0.9% to 2,385.38. The Korean won also gained, with a value of 1,084.6 per dollar on the onshore settlement platform. The currency was buoyed by exporters' dollar-selling ahead of Chinese New Year holiday. The KOSPI is down 4.2% so far this year, but the overall market trend is expected to stabilize following the recent losses.

images.alt_text: South Korea's KOSPI stock index recovered some of last week's heavy losses on Monday.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Land Transport Authority in Singapore will allocate S$25 million to drive innovation in the land transport sector, aiming to create 8,000 new jobs by 2030. Tourism receipts in Singapore reached a new high, with S$26.8 billion in 2017, driven by growth in visitor arrivals from top markets. Retail sales in Singapore surged 4.6% in December, while the government is considering an e-commerce tax to address online retail's impact on brick-and-mortar vendors.

images.alt_text: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) will set aside S$25 million over five years to kick-start mobility-related research and trials for the land transport industry - a sector which will create 8,000 new jobs by 2030.

site_title: Civmec posts Q2 profit of S$6.9m, progresses in ASX dual listing
summary: Civmec, an engineering services group, posted a net profit of S$6.9 million in its second quarter, up from the previous year, driven by higher contributions from existing contracts. Revenue increased 158.7% to S$179.7 million, while gross profit rose 33.2%. The company is progressing in its bid to dual list on the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) and has received in-principle approval to list. Civmec expects to be profitable in the current financial year, despite a 2.8% decline in its shares.

site_title: URA seeking public feedback on changes to commercial property sales rules
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) is seeking public feedback on proposed changes to the Sale of Commercial Properties Act (SCPA) and Sale of Commercial Properties Rules (SCPR) to better protect buyers of uncompleted non-residential properties. The changes aim to improve transparency and raise industry standards, requiring developers to obtain a sale licence, maintain a project account, and provide accurate information to buyers. The URA also proposes new anti-money laundering and counter financing of terrorism requirements for all developers. Public feedback is open until March 12 at https://ura.sg/scpafeedback.

site_title: Need to maintain trust in Singapore's system of criminal justice
summary: Singapore's criminal laws and administration need review to maintain trust and confidence. Recent scandals, such as the Keppel Offshore and Marine corruption scandal and the City Harvest Church ex-leaders' conviction, highlight the need for a review of existing laws. The government proposes changes to the Criminal Procedure Code to allow for deferred prosecution agreements (DPAs), which could encourage corporate cooperation with law enforcers. However, DPAs cannot replace tougher laws, and their use must be subject to judicial oversight. The Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Act, which provides severe powers to detain individuals without trial, also raises concerns about its necessity and potential misuse.

images.alt_text: In the long-drawn CHC case, after a careful study of Section 409 of the Penal Code (CBT by an agent), the Court of Appeal ruled that "agent" referred to a professional agent who offered commercial services, which the six CHC ex-leaders were not.

site_title: Singapore stocks resume Monday afternoon trading on higher ground; STI at 3,392.08
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Monday with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 3,392.08, up 0.4% or 14.84 points. The index saw 1.17 billion shares worth S$793.2 million traded, with Allied Technologies and Jiutian Chemical being the most actively traded counters. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and despite US tariff uncertainty, with gainers outnumbering losers 219 to 172.

site_title: Philippines expands ban for workers in Kuwait
summary: The Philippines has expanded its ban on citizens working in Kuwait, with Labour Secretary Silvestre Bello announcing a "total ban" on new employment, including those who had already obtained permits. The ban is in response to reports of Filipino workers suffering abuse and exploitation. The move affects 252,000 Filipinos who work in Kuwait, with authorities considering revoking permits of those currently working there or returning on new contracts. The ban takes effect immediately, with officials eyeing alternative markets in China and Russia.

site_title: Timeless brillance
summary: Luxury watch brands have responded to declining sales by introducing more affordable timepieces, with some brands offering "affordable luxury" options. However, prices for complicated models remain high, with many watches selling for over $100,000. Examples include Greubel Forsey's $1.13 million Grande Sonnerie, Richard Mille's $1.37 million RM 50-03 McLaren F1, and Patek Philippe's $109,000 Reference 5320G. Other brands, such as Chopard and Vacheron Constantin, have also released high-end timepieces with innovative features, including chiming mechanisms and grand complications. Despite efforts to make luxury watches more accessible, many remain out of reach for consumers.

site_title: Q3 earnings double to S$10.7m for Bukit Sembawang Estates on higher sales, profit recognition
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates reported Q3 earnings of S$10.7 million, doubling the S$5.35 million in the same period last year. Higher sales and profit recognition contributed to the increase, driven by the recognition of profits for the Watercove Ville project and two houses in Lengkok Angsa. Turnover rose 69% year-on-year to S$17.53 million. Earnings per share rose to 4.13 Singapore cents, while finance income decreased 57.7% due to a decrease in interest income.

site_title: Ahead of Lunar New Year, China's Xi says will banish "ghost" of poverty
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has vowed to banish "poverty ghosts" ahead of the Lunar New Year, a week-long holiday marking the beginning of the new year. During a visit to a remote southwestern region, Xi told villagers that poverty, ignorance, and backwardness were the causes of "ghosts" that needed to be exorcised. Xi has made poverty alleviation a signature policy issue, aiming to lift 70 million people out of poverty by 2020. The vow comes as China seeks to improve its social and economic development before the Lunar New Year.

images.alt_text: China will banish the "ghosts" of poverty, Chinese President Xi Jinping told villagers in a poor southwestern part of the country during a traditional visit to outlying regions before the Lunar New Year.

site_title: 3.5 million jobless and French companies still can't find staff
summary: France is struggling to fill job vacancies, with 3.5 million people unemployed and companies citing difficulty in hiring as one of their biggest problems. Despite President Emmanuel Macron's plans to revamp worker-training programs and incentives, many companies, such as Figeac-Aero, are finding it hard to find qualified candidates. The issue is particularly acute for small firms, with three quarters of unfilled job offers due to a lack of qualified candidates. Macron's government is investing 15 billion euros in education and vocational training to tackle the problem, but the economy is predicted to continue lagging in coming years.

site_title: Amazon paid US$90m for camera maker's chip technology
summary: Amazon has acquired camera maker Immedia Semiconductor, the maker of Blink home security cameras, for approximately $90 million. The deal highlights Amazon's strategy to develop its own energy-efficient chips, which could lower production costs and extend battery life for its devices. The acquired technology will be used to create proprietary chips for Amazon's Cloud Cam and Echo speakers, aiming to deepen its relationship with customers and gain a competitive edge in the security camera market.

images.alt_text: Amazon.com Inc paid about US$90 million to acquire the maker of Blink home security cameras late last year, in a secret bet on the startup's energy-efficient chips, people familiar with the matter told Reuters.

site_title: Debt collection in Asia-Pacific nations among world's toughest: report
summary: Debt collection in Asia-Pacific nations is among the world's toughest, according to a report by Euler Hermes. The region has the highest number of countries ranking in the "severe" category for debt collection complexity, with Malaysia ranking third. Singapore is the only country in the region to escape the "severe" category, ranking 27th in the "high" category. Western European countries, such as Sweden, Germany, and Ireland, are the easiest to collect debt in, while countries like Saudi Arabia and the UAE have the most complex procedures.

site_title: Surbana Jurong inks memorandum of cooperation to develop New Clark City in the Philippines
summary: Surbana Jurong has signed a memorandum of cooperation with the Bases Conversion and Development Authority and Japan Overseas Infrastructure Investment Corporation to develop New Clark City in the Philippines. The 9,450-hectare smart, green, and disaster-resilient city is expected to be completed in 30-40 years, with a population of 2 million and a projected annual contribution of 1.57 trillion pesos to the national economy. The project aims to leverage public-private partnerships and smart city technologies, with Surbana Jurong providing expertise and management support.

site_title: Insurance unit of Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway opens Dubai office
summary: Berkshire Hathaway Specialty Insurance (BHSI), a subsidiary of Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway, has established an office in Dubai's International Financial Centre. The office will provide specialty and commercial insurance to brokers and companies, focusing on construction, energy, and other sectors. BHSI already has regional hubs in Hong Kong and Singapore, and has appointed Alessandro Cerase, former AIG executive, as senior executive officer for Dubai operations. This expansion aims to expand BHSI's presence in the Asian market.

images.alt_text: An insurance subsidiary of Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway said on Monday it had established an office in the Dubai International Financial Centre after gaining a licence from the regulator.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower after late sell-off
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended lower on Monday, extending losses after a 9% drop last week, with analysts warning of further volatility. The Hang Seng Index declined 0.16% to close at 29,459.63. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.78% and the Shenzhen Composite Index jumped 2.65%. The late sell-off follows a strong rally in Asia's markets, with Singapore stocks rising for a fifth consecutive day and the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

images.alt_text: A late sell-off saw Hong Kong stocks end in the red again on Monday, extending losses after diving more than nine percent last week, with analysts warning of further volatility.

site_title: UBS increasing Asia investment banking bonus pool by 6% : sources
summary: UBS increased the 2017 bonus pool for its investment bankers in the Asia-Pacific region by 6% due to a rebound in dealmaking and efforts to retain junior staff focusing on China. Junior bankers in the region saw a 12% average rise in total compensation, with some receiving 15-20% raises. This marks a reversal from the previous year's 15% cut in the regional investment banking payout pool. The bank's regional investment bank saw a 66% profit jump in 2017, driven by a revival in China equity and equity-related deals.

site_title: Singapore shares close up 0.23% on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 7.74 points, or 0.23%, to 3,384.98 on Monday, despite a mass sell-off the previous week. The index was lifted by local banks, with DBS up 2.25% to S$27.31. However, the Singapore Exchange was down 7.35% to S$7.31. QT Vascular topped the active list, with shares up 11.11% to S$0.02.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Big Oil takes stage for post-austerity beauty contest
summary: Major oil companies, including Royal Dutch Shell and Total, are competing to attract investors with promises of growth and higher rewards after years of austerity. ExxonMobil, the largest publicly traded oil company, has underperformed due to a weaker outlook. Total has emerged as a frontrunner with plans to increase dividends by 10%, buy back $5 billion in shares, and abolish its scrip policy. Analysts hail Total as the "new benchmark in shareholder returns" and Shell as a close second, with both companies expected to boost payouts to shareholders.

site_title: As oil falters, fuel that drove bull run is cruising in Asia
summary: Oil investors face mixed signals as US production threatens a crude glut, while diesel demand in Asia remains strong. Refineries in Asia are set to shut for spring maintenance, squeezing diesel supplies and boosting prices. Despite concerns over a potential glut, Fitch Group expects diesel demand to stay strong this year due to emerging markets' infrastructure spending. The Asian diesel market is expected to tighten in March and April, with prices supported by the "significant growth recovery" in the global economy.

images.alt_text: Oil investors rattled by the threat of US output can find some cheer from diesel demand in Asia.

site_title: Global markets seeing 'necessary corrections': IMF chief
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde says global markets' recent volatility represents "necessary corrections." She expressed confidence in the markets, urging focus on long-term change and growth rather than short-term fluctuations. Lagarde also urged Arab countries to implement reforms to achieve sustainable growth and create jobs, citing low oil prices and economic challenges.

site_title: Australia fails to "close gap" in improving lives of Aborigines: report
summary: Australia has failed to meet more than half of its targets to improve the lives of indigenous Australians, including increasing life expectancy and literacy, according to a government report. The report found Australia was failing in four of seven measures, including reading and writing among indigenous students. Despite improvements in some areas, the report highlighted the country's failure to close the 10-year gap in life expectancy by 2031. The government has acknowledged the report's findings and Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has called for the imagination and drive of indigenous people to be the solution to the country's shortcomings.

site_title: China prohibits glass, cement capacity expansion in 2018
summary: China's Ministry of Industry and Information Technology (MIIT) prohibits the expansion of glass and cement production capacity in 2018, as part of a sweeping environmental protection campaign. New projects must follow replacement capacity rules to ensure production decreases, not increases. This move is part of China's supply-side reforms to eliminate excess capacity in industries, with 392.7 million tonnes of capacity expected to be eliminated by 2020.

site_title: Singapore seen leading race to tax US$38b shopping boom
summary: Singapore may introduce an e-commerce tax in its upcoming budget, aiming to level the playing field for traditional vendors amid the rapid growth of online retailing. The tax could be implemented as a levy on online vendors, with some Southeast Asian governments, including Thailand, Indonesia, and Malaysia, considering similar plans. The move is expected to ease competition for offline retailers and generate additional revenue for the region's governments, with projected e-commerce growth reaching US$64.8 billion by 2021.

site_title: Singtel, Ericsson achieve mobile speed of 1Gbps
summary: Singtel and Ericsson have achieved a mobile speed of 1Gbps in a successful trial. This speed will be rolled out in high-traffic locations such as Orchard Road and Clarke Quay, with handsets supporting the higher speed expected to be available in the second half of 2018. The technology will also enable Singtel to optimize its network usage and enhance the consumer mobile experience, with average mobile broadband speeds expected to be up to 20% faster. This is part of Singtel's plan to provide a future-ready, ultra-fast and low latency mobile network as the world prepares for the 5G era.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars pop up, investors nervous as US inflation data looms
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose on Monday due to a rebound in equity markets, despite nervous sentiment ahead of US inflation data. The Australian dollar jumped 0.3% to US$0.7834, while the New Zealand dollar edged up 0.2% to US$0.7270. Investors are concerned about the potential impact of US inflation data on markets, with a stronger-than-expected print expected to re-ignite selling.

site_title: Abu Dhabi financial regulator may create framework for virtual currencies
summary: The Financial Services Regulatory Authority (FSRA) of Abu Dhabi is considering creating a framework for virtual currency exchanges, which could pave the way for the trade of cryptocurrencies like bitcoin in the UAE. The regulator plans to consult with industry participants and professional bodies to establish guidelines. This move suggests that authorities in the UAE may be open to regulating virtual currencies, potentially allowing them to develop in the country.

site_title: Malaysia's Q4 GDP growth pace seen cooling to 5.7% y-o-y: poll
summary: Malaysia's economy is expected to grow at a slower pace in the fourth quarter of 2017, with a median forecast of 5.7% y-o-y, down from 6.2% in the previous period. Exports increased at a slower rate, with a 12.4% rise in October-December, down from over 20% in the first three quarters. Despite this, growth in the full year of 2017 is still expected to be the fastest since 2014, with annual growth of 5.7-6.1%.

site_title: Foxconn to use proceeds from unit's Shanghai IPO to fund US$4b projects
summary: Taiwan's Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics manufacturer, plans to use proceeds from the Shanghai IPO of its subsidiary, Foxconn Industrial Internet Co Ltd (FII), to fund eight projects totaling US$4 billion. The projects focus on building smart manufacturing platforms, cloud computing services, and 5G solutions. FII made a net profit of 16.2 billion yuan in 2017 and has clients including Amazon, Apple, and Huawei. The IPO is sponsored by China International Capital Corporation.

images.alt_text: Taiwan's Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics manufacturer, said it plans to use proceeds from a Shanghai listing of one if its subsidiaries to fund eight projects totalling US$4 billion.

site_title: Queen Elizabeth is behind a royal push to cut plastic waste
summary: Queen Elizabeth II has pushed for environmental changes at Buckingham Palace, including banning straws and bottles, using china plates and glasses, and installing solar panels to improve energy efficiency. The move follows the success of the BBC's "Blue Planet II" documentary, which highlighted the effects of plastic waste on the world's oceans. The royal household aims to reduce its environmental impact, with plans to phase out single-use plastics and increase the use of reusable items. The changes are part of a broader effort to make the palace more sustainable.

site_title: Land transport sector to get S$25m fund to drive innovation; grow 8,000 new jobs by 2030
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has announced a S$25 million fund to drive innovation and growth in the land transport sector by 2030, creating 8,000 new jobs. The fund will support research and trials for mobility-related projects, including autonomous robot movers and augmented reality devices. The industry is expected to expand from 123,000 employees to 131,000 by 2030, with the government focusing on upskilling and reskilling workers through institutes of higher learning and centralized academies.

images.alt_text: Christopher Tan

site_title: Heineken sees below-target margin improvement on Brazil unit
summary: Heineken NV, the world's second-largest brewer, forecasts profitability below its medium-term target this year due to the integration of a Brazilian business from Kirin. The operating profit margin is expected to expand about 25 basis points, driven by sales growth in Asia Pacific. Revenue rose 5% organically in 2017, beating analyst estimates. Despite this, Heineken's medium-term target of a 40 basis-point increase in profitability is not met. The company is also investing in African markets.

images.alt_text: Heineken NV, the world's second-largest brewer, forecast profitability this year will be below its medium-term target as it integrates a Brazilian business it bought from Japanese rival Kirin.

site_title: Gains from condom unit sale catapults Australia's Ansell profit six-fold
summary: Australia's Ansell Ltd reported a six-fold increase in underlying half-year profit to US$428.2 million, driven by a US$359.9 million gain from the sale of its Sexual Wellness unit to Humanwell Healthcare Group Co Ltd. The sale was initially expected to yield US$365 million. Ansell's earnings per share rose to US$45.3 cents, and the company raised full-year earnings per share guidance to US$0.96-$1.06. The company is now focusing on its core industrial and healthcare businesses.

site_title: Singapore, Kiribati ink open skies pact
summary: Singapore and Kiribati signed an open skies agreement, allowing airlines to fly without restrictions between the two countries and to any third country.
