site_title: China's Didi Chuxing takes aim at Japan's taxi market
summary: Chinese ride-hailing giant Didi Chuxing has announced a deal with Japanese telecom firm SoftBank to develop a taxi app in Japan, where services like Uber have struggled. The partnership aims to provide platform services for the taxi industry, with trial runs expected within the year. Didi Chuxing plans to use advanced AI technologies to enhance efficiency for taxi operators and drivers. This move represents another step for the Chinese firm to rival Uber, which has struggled to gain traction in Japan's market.

site_title: Good Class Bungalows to remain sought-after this year
summary: Good Class Bungalows (GCBs) in Singapore saw a five-year high in sales last year, with 41 transactions worth S$867 million. Prices are expected to rise by 5-8% this year, despite the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) and Total Deposit Scheme Reserve (TDSR) remaining in place. The surge in sales is attributed to the location, plot size, terrain, and condition of the bungalow.

site_title: F&N's Q1 net profit up 16.3%
summary: F&N, a Singaporean beverage company, reported a 16.3% increase in Q1 net profit to S$26.1 million, driven by strong performance from its associate company, Vietnam Dairy Products. Revenue declined 1.6% to S$487.1 million, primarily due to a 16% drop in its beverages segment.

site_title: Single premiums boost Singapore insurance growth for Q4
summary: Singapore's life insurance industry experienced growth in Q4 2017, with single premiums boosting the market. The Life Insurance Association Singapore (LIA) is working with member companies to create standardized claim forms, aiming to simplify the process for policy holders. A workshop will be held to discuss industry issues and potential solutions, involving companies like AIA Singapore and Aviva. The association aims to improve the industry's efficiency and user experience.

images.alt_text: With the life insurance industry in Singapore growing in all aspects in the fourth quarter last year, the Life Insurance Association Singapore (LIA Singapore) is looking into bringing member companies together to create one seamless platform for policy holders to submit claims more easily.

site_title: Challenger Technologies posts Q4 net profit of S$5.9m
summary: Challenger Technologies reported a net profit of S$5.9 million for Q4 2017, a 94% increase from the previous year. Revenue rose 7% to S$89 million, driven by IT products and services. The company also posted a full-year net profit of S$16.2 million, up 32% from the previous year. Despite a cautious outlook on the retail industry, Challenger Technologies plans to execute cost management and operational efficiency improvements.

site_title: Watch sellers dial in higher Q3 profits
summary: Two luxury watch retailers, Cortina Holdings and The Hour Glass, reported a rise in profits in the third quarter despite volatile market conditions. Cortina Holdings' earnings more than doubled to Dec 31, while The Hour Glass posted a 6% rise in net profit, despite a slide in revenue. The companies' success can be attributed to strong sales and effective pricing strategies.

site_title: Deals for big planes in small supply at the Singapore Airshow
summary: The Singapore Airshow saw a lack of blockbuster commercial aircraft deals, despite robust growth in passenger traffic, with Boeing and Airbus not unveiling any plane orders. Global passenger traffic is projected to expand at 6% this year. No major deals were also announced on the defense side.

site_title: US: Stocks bounce in opening trading
summary: US stocks rose in early trading on Friday, bouncing back from a prior session's rout, amid heightened volatility. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 1.1% to 24,120.83, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 1.1% and 1.4%, respectively. The gains came despite investors' concerns over potential further direction changes and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: DBS gives staff limited edition jewellery to mark golden jubilee
summary: DBS Group Holdings celebrated its 50th anniversary by giving employees gold-plated cufflinks and necklaces as a limited edition jewellery gift. The bank also announced a special dividend and a higher dividend policy for shareholders. This comes after sharing its fourth-quarter results at an employee town hall, where CEO Piyush Gupta made the surprise announcement.

site_title: How big tech companies are weaning themselves off... tech
summary: Tech executives and entrepreneurs in Silicon Valley are adopting "tech diets" to limit their use of digital services and gadgets, citing distractions from text messages, social media updates, and emails. Some, like Apple executives and Facebook billionaires, use tools or devices to restrict screen time, while others, like Indiegogo co-founder Slava Rubin, have strict no-screen policies for gatherings and personal use. This trend reflects a growing awareness of the negative impact of excessive tech use on mental and physical health.

site_title: Forget fake news. Worry about fake history Oscars
summary: Two World War II movies, Dunkirk and The Darkest Hour, have received Oscar nominations despite containing historical inaccuracies. Dunkirk's cinematography is notable, but the films' portrayal of events is marred by errors. Critics argue that these movies should be categorized as propaganda films, similar to Objective Burma, which depicts a fictional hero defeating the Japanese army. These films' focus on British heroism overshadows historical accuracy, sparking debate about the representation of historical events in cinema.

site_title: China's HNA reverses buying binge with US$4b selling spree in the US
summary: HNA Group, a Chinese conglomerate, is selling several US properties to cut its massive debt. The company is selling 245 Park Ave in New York and other buildings across the US, following a buying spree that included over $4 billion in US assets. This move comes after the company's once-voracious acquisition pace slowed down, indicating a shift in its strategy to reduce its debt burden.

site_title: LTA awards S$573m for upgrading works on North-South, East-West lines
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has awarded S$573 million contracts to upgrade and renew power supply and track circuit systems on the North-South and East-West MRT lines. Japanese firm Meiden Singapore won two deals worth S$500 million, while a consortium of Siemens and Engie Services Singapore won a S$73 million contract. The projects are expected to be completed by the early 2020s, with the new systems featuring real-time monitoring and improved fault detection capabilities. The upgrades aim to reduce power-related faults and increase the lines' power capacity.

site_title: Yorkshine Holdings says former CEO withheld records, books; police report filed
summary: Yorkshine Holdings' former CEO, Chow Kin Wa, withheld records and books, including accounting vouchers and trading contracts. He was ousted in January after an investigation into the group's trading and distribution practices. The company has filed a police report and will not assess the impact of potential losses until the investigation is complete. Yorkshine Holdings will review its internal control system and adopt remedial measures, with further announcements to follow. The company's trading will not be affected until the investigation is resolved.

site_title: The next phase towards European glory awaits
summary: The UEFA Champions League's round-of-16 stage is set to begin, featuring eight former winners with a combined 55% of all UCL titles. The draw has created intriguing matchups, including a high-profile clash between Real Madrid and Paris Saint-Germain on February 14, pitting Cristiano Ronaldo against Neymar. This fixture is expected to be a classic, with both teams in different stages of their seasons. The competition promises to be fierce, with less prominent teams capable of causing upsets.

site_title: LTC Corporation controlling shareholders plan takeover offer at S$0.925 per share
summary: LTC Corporation's controlling shareholders plan a voluntary conditional cash offer of S$0.925 per share for all ordinary shares, surpassing the highest closing price since 1998 and a premium of 44.5% over the stock's last close. The offer, made by Mountbatten Enterprises, has secured irrevocable undertakings for approximately 48.54% of shares. The proposal is conditional on receiving acceptances resulting in a 90% stake, with the option to reduce this threshold.

site_title: Increased borrowings pull down RHT Health's Q3 DPU by 8.4%
summary: RHT Health Trust's Q3 DPU declined 8.4% to 1.09 Singapore cents due to increased borrowings and interest expenses. This is a decrease from 1.19 Singapore cents in the preceding year. The decline is attributed to higher borrowing costs, negatively impacting the trust's financial performance.

site_title: Singapore Airshow 2018 sees 10% increase in trade visitors
summary: The 2018 Singapore Airshow saw a 10% increase in trade visitors, with over 70% of exhibitors committed to return in 2020. Strategic partnerships were established, showcasing the digital data revolution in the aviation industry, including Airbus' Skywise Predictive Maintenance Services and Rolls-Royce's IntelligenceEngine. The airshow also featured start-up exchanges and new exhibitors, including Turkish Aerospace Industries. The 2020 edition of the Singapore Airshow will be held from Feb 11-16.

site_title: Tennis: Serena ready for comeback after 'ups and downs'
summary: Serena Williams is set to make her comeback in competitive tennis after a year away, citing a new outlook and focus following the birth of her daughter. Despite struggling in an exhibition match in Abu Dhabi, Williams is now ready to compete, with her sights on the US Open. The 36-year-old will begin her comeback at the Fed Cup in Asheville, North Carolina, where the US team will face an unfancied Netherlands team. Williams' strong Fed Cup record and newfound sense of zen from her family life are expected to aid her in her quest to dominate the sport once again.

images.alt_text: Serena Williams has spoken out about the "ups and downs" she faced during her year away from competitive tennis but insists she's now focused and ready for her quest to once more dominate her sport.

site_title: Maersk profit miss puts CEO's shipping route under scrutiny
summary: Maersk, the world's largest container shipping firm, missed profit forecasts, with shares down 2.9% after the fourth-quarter profit miss. CEO Soren Skou remains optimistic about global trade despite higher fuel costs and lower freight rates. The company expects Ebitda at $4-5 billion, below analyst expectations of $5.3 billion. Maersk's decision to focus on transport and jettison oil has put its strategy under scrutiny, with some analysts questioning the company's future direction.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: DBS and Singtel are recommended to buy by analysts, with DBS offering a 4.5% net dividend yield and strong net profit growth expected in 2018. Meanwhile, Singtel is expected to deliver strong revenue growth and improve credit costs. The Singapore stock market is on a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and Citigroup sets a target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026.

site_title: Pacific Century's FY17 net profit up by 9.9%
summary: Pacific Century Regional Developments reported a 9.9% increase in FY17 net profit to S$95.6 million, driven by a 13.2% rise in revenue. The company attributed the growth to dividends from its Hong Kong-listed associate PCCW, which successfully completed strategic activities, including selling down its stake in HKT and introducing new investors to its OTT Media business. Earnings per share rose to 3.608 cents, and a final proposed dividend of 2.2 cents was declared for the year.

site_title: Shoot me, don't jail me, Philippines' Duterte tells Hague court prosecutor
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte told the International Criminal Court (ICC) to proceed with an investigation into him for crimes against humanity, stating he'd prefer a firing squad over jail. He questioned the ICC's jurisdiction, citing a lack of official announcement of the Philippines' accession to the ICC's Rome Statute. Duterte denied ordering police to kill drug suspects and accused the ICC of lacking jurisdiction in the Philippines, amid allegations of thousands of extrajudicial killings during his war on drugs campaign.

site_title: Reinsurers turn sexy as suitors see disaster-scarred targets
summary: The US$500 billion reinsurance industry is experiencing a surge in deal talks as companies seek to capitalize on depressed valuations and increased competition. Natural disasters such as Harvey, Irma, and Maria led to a record-breaking US hurricane season, compressing reinsurer valuations and prompting dealmaking. Swiss Re AG is in talks with SoftBank Group Corp, while Allianz SE is potentially interested in acquiring XL Group Ltd. The industry is attracting investors looking to generate returns, with private equity firms, pension funds, and family offices also showing interest.

site_title: The end of 2017 was horrible for Swedish property developers
summary: Swedish property developers experienced a significant decline in home sales and housing starts at the end of 2017, with combined starts falling 28% and sales dropping 42% to 1,898 and 1,330, respectively. This was the biggest drop in prices since 2008, with high-end apartments in Stockholm being particularly hard hit. The decline was attributed to a slowdown in the capital, low household optimism, and increased construction supply. This marks the fourth consecutive quarter of declining housing starts for JM AB and its peers.

site_title: Facebook testing a 'downvote' button to judge people's comments
summary: Facebook is testing a "Downvote" button on public comments to notify the company about uncivil or misleading comments. The button, which appears alongside "Like" and "Reply" options, allows users to provide feedback without affecting a post's visibility. This test, for a small percentage of US users, marks a departure from Facebook's prior stance against dislike buttons, which it believed could spread negativity. The feature is similar to Reddit's comment downvoting system and aims to improve comment moderation.

site_title: Markets roiled again, but bottom-fishers are in action
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended the week 1.13% lower at 3,377.24, despite US stocks falling 10% from their peaks, with losses outnumbering gains 448 to 85. The market is bracing for the consequences of HNA Group's liquidity crunch and profit-taking ahead of the Chinese New Year holiday. However, analysts remain optimistic, with a sanguine tone still dominating, and warn that volatility will define the coming weeks due to inflationary pressure and potential interest rate hikes.

site_title: Is Flipkart worth US$20b? Walmart weighs price of India bet
summary: Walmart is weighing a potential $20 billion valuation for its proposed majority stake in Flipkart, India's e-commerce leader, in a bid to challenge Amazon's dominance. The deal would give Walmart a 20% stake, surpassing existing investors SoftBank and Tiger Global Management. If successful, the partnership would mark a significant expansion for Walmart in the Indian market, which is expected to reach $28 billion by 2020. Analysts say the alliance would make Flipkart a stronger rival to Amazon, with Walmart providing additional capital and retail muscle.

site_title: Frasers Property, parent to acquire more shares in Ticon
summary: Frasers Property, a Singapore-based company, has agreed to acquire 26.1% interest in Ticon Industrial Connection Public Company for 8.57 billion baht (S$359 million) or 17.90 Thai baht per share. This move will allow Frasers Property to extend its presence in Thailand's industrial and logistics market, building on its existing 40.95% stake in Ticon.

site_title: Ex-Credit Suisse banker found guilty as fraud tops 143m Swiss francs
summary: A former Credit Suisse wealth manager, Patrice Lescaudron, was found guilty of orchestrating a scheme that resulted in damages of 143 million Swiss francs, with 130 million to be paid in damages and 22 million in compensation to his clients. Lescaudron was sentenced to 5 years in prison, despite claiming he never profited from his illicit trades. The judge described his motivations as egotistical and driven by profits, and ordered him to pay the damages and compensation.

site_title: North Korean cheer squad is playing a different Olympic game
summary: The North Korean cheerleading squad, consisting of 230 young women, made their Olympic debut at the Pyeongchang Games, wearing matching red wool coats and black accessories. The squad, known as "the army of beauties," aims to normalize and humanize the regime through their fashion. With a strict selection process, the squad has worn various outfits, from traditional Korean garb to modern brands like Nike. Their synchronized performances may provide a visual message of a different kind, offering a glimpse into North Korean culture and potentially striking a chord with the global audience.

site_title: Vicom's net profit for FY17 down 5.9%
summary: Vicom, the vehicle inspection and testing unit of ComfortDelGro, reported a net profit of S$26.5 million for FY17, down 5.9% from the previous year, due to lower business volumes. Revenue declined 4.1% to S$97 million. The company declared a dividend of 22.88 cents, a 161% increase from the previous year.

site_title: Malaysia: shares close down on Friday
summary: Malaysia's stocks closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 19.62 points to 1,819.82. Volume reached 2.45 billion shares worth RM2.67 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers by 900 to 208.

site_title: Roche wins UK watchdog's nod for lymphoma drug after initial snub
summary: Roche's lymphoma drug Gazyvaro has been recommended by Britain's healthcare watchdog NICE for previously untreated advanced follicular lymphoma patients. The decision comes after Roche revamped its analysis, focusing on higher-risk patients, and agreed to provide the drug at a discount. The recommendation affects about 1,200 people annually and is seen as a positive example of flexibility between Roche and NICE. The drug was initially rejected last year due to concerns over cost-effectiveness, but NICE now recommends its use with chemotherapy in patients with a higher risk of relapse.

site_title: US oil reserve would fall nearly in half under budget deal
summary: The US is set to sell 100 million barrels of oil from its Strategic Petroleum Reserve, reducing the reserve's volume by 45% to about 303 million barrels, with the sale expected to raise around $6 billion. The White House plans to sign the bill, despite criticism that the move defies the purpose of the reserve as a hedge against supply disruptions. The sale is the largest non-emergency sale in US history, and experts warn it could be "liquidation of a safety net."

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei index closes down 2.3%, extending global slump
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index plummeted 2.32% to close at 21,382.62, following a global slump in stocks. European and US markets experienced significant drops, with the broader Topix index down 1.91%. The decline is attributed to ongoing market volatility.

site_title: Bid to find a Valentine for Romeo, world's 'loneliest frog'
summary: A conservation team, in partnership with dating website Match, is searching for a mate for Romeo, the world's "loneliest frog," a 10-year-old Sehuencas water frog from Bolivia. Romeo, the last known individual of his species, has enlisted human help to find a Juliet, with the goal of establishing a conservation breeding program to save the species. The team aims to raise $15,000 by Valentine's Day to fund expeditions and DNA searches, with cloning also considered as a means of preserving the species if all else fails.

site_title: Hour Glass records 6% rise in Q3 profits despite revenue slide on lower spending
summary: Hour Glass reported a 6% rise in net profit to S$14.19 million in Q3 2017, despite a 7% decline in revenue to S$182.94 million. The company attributed the increase to lower spending and a foreign exchange gain. Earnings per share rose to 2.01 Singapore cents from 1.9 cents previously. The company expects to remain profitable for the financial year, barring unforeseen circumstances.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end near 5-month low, won pares losses
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index closed at its weakest level since September, falling 1.82% to 2,363.77, due to a renewed sell-off on Wall Street. The Korean won also declined to two-month lows, while bond yields rose. The Kospi index is down 2.4% this year and 0.81% in the past 30 days, with foreigners net selling 308.94 million won worth of shares.

site_title: Singapore shares close 1.1% down on Friday in broad market selloff
summary: Singapore stocks ended 1.1% lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index retreating 38.66 points to 3,377.24, amid continued market volatility and a plunge in China stocks. Despite a strong buying sentiment for DBS, which ended trading unchanged, losers outnumbered gainers 448 to 85.

site_title: Market Street to get park, footpaths from Golden Shoe Car Park redevelopment: Lawrence Wong
summary: Minister Lawrence Wong announced the redevelopment of the former Golden Shoe Car Park, featuring a 12,500 sq ft public park, widened footpaths with added greenery, and sheltered linkways. The site at 88 Market Street will be transformed into an S$1.82 billion integrated development, with Market Street Food Centre reopening at the second and third levels, owned by the Ministry of Environment and Water Resources.

site_title: Eurostar to add Amsterdam in April in biggest network expansion
summary: Eurostar to launch service from London to Amsterdam on April 4, marking its largest network expansion since 1994. The 3-hour 40-minute journey will be operated with two daily departures from London St Pancras. Passengers will need to stop in Brussels for passport controls due to Dutch stations not being equipped for checks. Eurostar aims to capture a significant share of the 4 million people traveling between London and Amsterdam by air, and marketing the train as a "leisure experience" to attract tourist traffic.

site_title: Ryanair staff called to strike in Italy, but pilots to keep flying
summary: Ryanair staff in Italy are set to strike for four hours on Feb 10, with three unions calling for the walkout over exclusion from contract negotiations. However, Italy's main pilots union, Anpac, will not participate, citing ongoing talks for a pay increase. Ryanair has agreed to recognize unions for all staff, but has prioritized pilot union negotiations. The airline operates from 87 European bases, flying to 210 airports with 430 aircraft, and has faced criticism over cancelled flights and labor disputes.

site_title: Cortina's Q3 net profit more than doubles on the back of positive inventory change
summary: Luxury watch retailer Cortina Holdings' Q3 net profit more than doubles to S$5.64 million, driven by positive inventory changes. Revenue surges 20% to S$122.89 million, while expenses increase 27% to S$102.15 million. Despite rising costs, the company's inventory changes more than triple to S$7.33 million, resulting in higher earnings per share. Cortina expects to remain profitable, with plans to adapt cost-saving measures and aim for better performance.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: China's HNA reverses buying binge with US$4b selling spree
summary: HNA Group Co, a Chinese conglomerate, is selling $4 billion worth of US properties to cut its massive debt, which has reached $185.2 billion yuan. The company, once a voracious acquirer, is facing a liquidity crunch due to China's crackdown on "irrational" investments and stagnant real estate values. HNA owns over $14 billion in global real estate properties, and the sales effort marks the latest sign of its dramatic fall from a symbol of China's overseas property buying spree.

site_title: L'Oreal shares climb after strong Q4 figures, CEO comments on Nestle's stake
summary: L'Oreal shares rose 1% in early trading after the company reported a 5.5% organic sales increase in Q4 2017, beating expectations. CEO Jean-Paul Agon expressed confidence in 2018 growth and reiterated L'Oreal's willingness to buy Nestle's 23% stake in the firm, further boosting shares. This move could be accretive to L'Oreal, with analysts retaining "hold" and "buy" ratings on the stock.

site_title: F&N's net profit for Q1 up 16.3%, due to contribution from associate company
summary: Frasers and Neaves (F&N) posted a net profit of SGD 26.1 million for Q1 2018, a 16.3% increase from the previous year, driven by strong performance from associate company Vietnam Dairy Products Joint Stock Company. Revenue declined 1.6% to SGD 487.1 million, mainly due to a 16% dip in beverages segment sales in Malaysia. Earnings per share rose to 1.8 cents, and the group expects increased contribution from Vinamilk, with plans to invest in new markets and capex projects.

site_title: Jim Rogers says next bear market will be worst in his life
summary: Veteran investor Jim Rogers predicts the next bear market will be the worst in his lifetime, citing high global debt levels. He attributes this to the accumulation of debt since the 2008 financial crisis, especially in the US. Rogers expects the current market selloff to continue until the Federal Reserve increases borrowing costs, which he believes will lead to a market rally. The S&P 500 Index has already plummeted 10% since January 26, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping over 1,000 points.

site_title: REACH: Singaporeans most concerned about planning ahead for future
summary: Singaporeans are most concerned about planning ahead for the future, with a six-week feedback exercise revealing a strong desire for skills development, career planning, and financial literacy. Participants also called for assistance for the elderly and incentives to encourage family support. The REACH chairman expressed optimism about the feedback, stating that it shows Singaporeans care for the country and want to shape government policies. The feedback will be shared with the Ministry of Finance, with participants advocating for alternative revenue methods before a potential tax increase.

site_title: US Congress passes funding bill to reopen government after hours-long shutdown
summary: The US Congress passed a bipartisan spending bill to reopen the government after a three-week shutdown, sending it to President Donald Trump's signature. The House voted 240-186 in favor of the package, which extends funding until March 23 and includes a $300 billion increase in military and non-military spending limits. The bill was blocked by Senator Rand Paul, but ultimately passed after a last-minute deal was reached. The measure will end the nation's second government shutdown in three weeks and is seen as a step towards breaking the cycle of government funding crises ahead of the mid-term elections.

site_title: China traders cancel US corn cargoes on tighter GMO controls, buy from Ukraine: sources
summary: China's buyers have cancelled US corn shipments due to tightened controls on genetically modified (GMO) strains, instead opting for non-GMO supplies from Ukraine. This shift could impact US farmers preparing for a bumper crop and may mark a new front in trade tensions between China and the US. Chinese buyers had previously increased purchases of US corn following a price rally, but the tougher permits process has forced traders to turn to Ukraine, a move that has driven up export prices from Ukraine to a 9-year high.

site_title: Sabic plans new production facility in Singapore for ULTEM resins
summary: Sabic plans to build a new production facility in Singapore to increase capacity of ULTEM resins, a polyetherimide material. The facility, expected to go online in 2021, will localise supply for Asian customers, reducing lead times. Currently produced in the US and Spain, the Singapore facility will increase capacity by 50% over 2018 levels, positioning Sabic as the only petrochemical company to produce the resin in Asia, the Americas, and Europe. The expansion is driven by increased customer demand in Asia, particularly in shorter qualification cycle applications.

site_title: Broadcom says US$121b Qualcomm bid is 'best and final'
summary: Broadcom has reaffirmed its US$121 billion bid for Qualcomm, calling it the "best and final" offer after the target's board rejected the proposal. Qualcomm's board unanimously rejected the offer, which includes US$60 in cash and 17% more shares than its initial offer. The bid is contingent on Qualcomm's pending acquisition of NXP Semiconductors NV and the outcome of regulatory approvals. Qualcomm's board has expressed concerns that the deal undervalues the company and falls short of regulatory commitments needed for approval. A shareholder vote on March 6 will determine the future of the bid.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: DBS Group Holdings celebrated its 50th anniversary by giving employees limited edition jewelry. Meanwhile, LTC Corporation's controlling shareholders plan a takeover offer of S$0.925 per share. DBS Research ceased coverage of Midas Holdings due to litigations and enforcement orders. National authentication systems SingPass and CorpPass experienced disruptions, while Noble Group's major shareholder Goldilocks Investment Company urged stakeholders to oppose restructuring plans. Asian markets were affected by the Bank of England's hawkish tone, and Singapore improved its global intellectual property index score to 9th.

site_title: New business insurance premiums hit all time high of S$4.09b in 2017: LIA
summary: The total value of weighted new business insurance premiums in Singapore reached a record high of S$4.09 billion in 2017, a 24% increase from the same period in 2016, according to The Life Insurance Association. This growth was driven by a 43% rise in weighted single premiums to S$1.463.9 million, with 73% of these products being single premium par and non-par. The industry also saw a 12% increase in total sum assured for first-time insurance product owners to S$130.5 billion.

site_title: Australia shares hit by Wall St gloom; NZ posts biggest weekly drop in nearly 8 years
summary: Australian shares fell 0.9% on Friday, reaching a near four-month low, amid global market concerns over inflation and interest rates. The S&P/ASX 200 index declined 4.6% for the week, its largest drop in nearly eight years, following a 4% tumble in US stocks. The decline was triggered by strong wages growth in the US, sparking fears of faster interest rate hikes and impacting global financial markets.

site_title: Oil slides towards steep weekly loss as supply fears mount
summary: Oil prices fell for a sixth day, on track for their biggest weekly losses in 10 months, due to record-high US crude output and concerns about a sharp rise in global supplies. US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 42 US cents to $60.73 a barrel, while Brent futures dropped 30 cents to $64.51 a barrel. The US Energy Information Administration reported a record 10.25 million barrels per day in domestic crude production, surpassing Saudi Arabia's output. Opec member Iran plans to increase production by at least 700,000 barrels a day over the next four years.

site_title: Australia's Myer sees profit slump, writedown as board spill looms
summary: Australia's department store chain Myer Holdings Ltd warned of a 41% profit slump in its first half, citing a decline in sales and a probable writedown. The company's stock fell to a record low, prompting billionaire investor Solomon Lew to call for a board spill. Myer's online sales rose 49% but still account for a fraction of total turnover, highlighting the challenges faced by traditional department stores in the face of online competition. The company is expected to write down the carrying value of its assets.

site_title: Midnight US shutdown almost certain as senator holds up spending bill
summary: The US government is on track for a shutdown as a spending bill faces a last-minute hurdle. Senate Republican Rand Paul blocked a vote, objecting to increased federal spending limits, and the House's fate is uncertain. The bill would extend funding for six weeks, raise the debt ceiling, and increase spending limits for two years. If passed, it could result in a brief shutdown, but the deal's fate is uncertain due to opposition from fiscal conservatives and liberal Democrats.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end near 5-month low; won pares losses
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index closed near a five-month low, falling 1.82% to 2,363.77 points, as a renewed selloff on Wall Street sapped confidence. The won pared earlier losses but remained at two-month lows, while bond yields rose. The KOSPI has declined 2.4% this year and 0.81% in the past 30 days.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 31.48 points to 1,807.96 on Friday, with losers outnumbering gainers 577 to 22. Volume reached 192.64 million lots worth RM62.84 million.

site_title: Maersk drops as company misses estimates after an 'unusual' year
summary: AP Moller-Maersk A/S, the world's largest shipping company, fell short of earnings expectations in 2017 with earnings of $3.5 billion, missing estimates. Despite this, CEO Soren Skou promised a 43% growth in profits in 2018. Maersk attributed the disappointing results to a cyberattack, weaker shipping rates, and increasing bunker costs. The company still expects to grow its earnings and proposed a dividend of $24 per share for 2018. Skou expressed a positive outlook for the global economy and shipping industry, citing promising demand and a manageable capacity growth plan.

site_title: DBS Research ceases coverage of Midas Holdings
summary: DBS Research has ceased coverage of Midas Holdings due to the company's disclosure of several litigations, enforcement orders, and court documents involving its subsidiaries. A 30 million yuan (S$6.3 million) liability was uncovered, and approximately 12 million yuan of its ledger balance was frozen. The group also has outstanding orders freezing shares owned by its associates. DBS analyst Paul Yong stated that the asset risk, business continuity, and corporate governance issues are key concerns, making it difficult to value the stock without reliable financial statements. Trading was suspended on Friday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks dive 3.1% at end of volatile week
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 3.1% at the end of a volatile week, with the Hang Seng Index falling 3.10% to close at 29,507.42. The sell-off was driven by global market turmoil, with US interest rates tightening, and fears of higher borrowing costs. Energy firms were among the biggest losers, with PetroChina and CNOOC diving 3.41% and 2.96% respectively. The Shanghai Composite Index also fell 4.05%, with the Shenzhen Composite Index losing 3.19%.

site_title: New raids on Japan crypto exchanges after Coincheck hack
summary: Japan has launched raids on several cryptocurrency exchanges following a massive hack on Coincheck that saw thieves steal US$530 million in virtual currency. The hack, which occurred on January 26, was one of the largest of its kind, and authorities have been searching the firm's offices since last week. The raids aim to examine the internal governance structure of the exchanges and follow Coincheck's example, which lacked proper security measures. The government has admitted it needs to strengthen supervision of virtual currency exchanges, with reports suggesting hackers may have accessed Coincheck from abroad.

site_title: FCT: Has not acquired Waterway Point stake, contrary to headline on SGX service
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) has denied acquiring a one-third stake in Waterway Point mall, contrary to a headline on the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) StockFacts service. FCT's manager stated that the information was untrue and notified the SGX of the error. Despite this, analysts expect FCT to eventually acquire Frasers Property's stake in the mall. The trust's shares dropped 1.8% following the announcement.

site_title: SingPass, CorpPass services restored after 4-hour disruption, second outage in 2 days
summary: The Government Technology Agency of Singapore (GovTech) restored access to national authentication systems SingPass and CorpPass after a four-hour disruption on Friday, the second outage in two days. The services were initially slowed down due to a server fault and error messages, affecting hundreds of essential e-government services. GovTech stated that it is conducting a thorough review and implementing further measures to minimize disruptions. The outage follows a similar incident on Thursday, which was caused by a server fault and fully restored by 5:15pm.

site_title: China, Hong Kong are the biggest losers as stock rout spreads
summary: China and Hong Kong experienced the biggest losses in two years due to a global stock rout, with benchmark indexes falling faster than major peers since the market slump began. China's Shanghai Composite Index plummeted 4.1% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index lost 3.1% on Friday, snapping their longest-ever streaks without a 10% correction. The declines are attributed to a Chinese deleveraging campaign and rising interest rates, but analysts remain optimistic about China's growth outlook, with a consensus estimate of 6.5% for 2018.

site_title: DNV GL sets up Singapore lab to develop 3D printing technology for O&M sector
summary: DNV GL has established a 3D printing center in Singapore to develop and test additive manufacturing technology for the oil and gas (O&G) and offshore and marine (O&M) sectors. The center aims to provide technical standards and guidelines for qualifying and certifying advanced manufacturing equipment, processes, and personnel. The facility will collaborate with local research institutes and industry partners, starting with Sembcorp Marine and SIMTech to develop laser-aided additive manufacturing technology for large-scale vessel structures. The center is expected to enhance the manufacturing competitiveness of Singapore's O&M engineering industry.

site_title: Former British banker denied new trial in Hong Kong double murder case
summary: A former British banker, Rurik Jutting, has had his bid for a new trial in the Hong Kong double murder case denied by the Court of Appeal. Jutting, 32, was previously jailed for life for the murder of two Indonesian women he tortured and raped in 2014. His lawyer argued that the judge misdirected the jury by conflating an abnormality of mind with a psychiatric disorder. Jutting pleaded guilty to manslaughter and was sentenced in 2016. The decision upholds his original conviction.

site_title: Goldilocks urges Noble stakeholders to oppose restructuring approach, seeks more transparency
summary: Goldilocks Investment Company, a 8.1% stakeholder in Noble Group, is urging stakeholders to oppose the company's restructuring approach, seeking more transparency. Noble rejected Goldilocks' request to be released from non-disclosure agreements, citing "extensive and confidential information" shared under the agreement. Goldilocks claims Noble's disclosures are incomplete and inaccurate, and has asked regulators to intervene. The company has reached an in-principle agreement with 30% of creditors to halve its US$3.5 billion debt, with the new entity to be 70% owned by senior creditors and 20% by management.

site_title: Everything's a sell in China After US$828b equity rout
summary: China's currency, the yuan, plummeted 1.2% on Thursday, its largest decline since 2015, amidst a global equity rout worth $828 billion. The country's equities, including large caps and banks, have also been hit hard, with traders seeking to unwind risk and take cash. The yuan's decline is attributed to a combination of factors, including a stronger dollar and nervousness in the equity market. The Shanghai Composite Index suffered its first correction in 743 days, with investors fleeing risk globally despite calls to buy the dip.

site_title: Singapore shares enter Friday afternoon on lower ground; STI at 3,367.18
summary: Singapore shares resumed trading on Friday afternoon in negative territory, with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 3,367.18, down 48.72 points or 1.4% as of 1:01pm. Losers beat gainers 443 to 59, and 1.3 billion shares worth S$1.1 billion were traded. Notable losers included Jiutian Chemical Group and Singapore Telecommunications, while DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank also fell.

site_title: LTA awards S$573m in contracts for upgrading works on North-South, East-West MRT lines
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has awarded three contracts worth S$573 million to upgrade and renew power supply and track circuit systems on the North-South and East-West MRT lines. Meiden Singapore won two deals, worth S$500 million, and a consortium of Siemens and Engie Services Singapore won the track circuit system contract for S$73 million. The upgrades aim to reduce power-related faults, increase power capacity, and improve resilience, with design and work set to begin this year and completion expected by the early 2020s.

site_title: DBS gifts staff limited edition jewellery to mark golden jubilee
summary: DBS Group Holdings celebrated its 50th anniversary by gifting its 24,000 employees gold cuff links and necklaces, part of the DBS Sparks collection. The bank also announced a special dividend of 60 cents a share and a higher dividend policy for shareholders, with a record S$1.19 billion in fourth-quarter earnings. The gifts and dividend payout were revealed during an employee town hall, where CEO Piyush Gupta highlighted the bank's spirit and values. The bank's shares surged 5.3% following the announcement.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks plunge at open after Wall St rout
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 3.13% in early trade on Friday, following a Wall Street rout, as investors worry about rising US interest rates. The Hang Seng Index fell to 29,498.57, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 2.73% to 3,172.85. The decline is the second in a week, amid concerns about the impact of US interest rate hikes on global markets.

site_title: Australia: Shares ravaged; NZ on track for worst week in nearly 8 years
summary: Australian shares plummeted 1.5% to near four-month lows, tracking Wall Street's overnight falls. The S&P/ASX 200 index is on track for its worst week since January 2016, with financials and materials stocks taking a hit. The benchmark has shed nearly 3% this year, with Commonwealth Bank and Westpac leading the decline. In New Zealand, the benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 1.3% to a near three-month low, with healthcare and industrial stocks contributing to the losses.

site_title: News Corp CEO rails at 'dysfunctional' online environment
summary: News Corp CEO Robert Thompson criticized Google and Facebook for fostering a "dysfunctional" online environment, which harms the news media and responsible journalism. He welcomed steps by Google and Facebook to improve online news quality, but said the digital environment remains "chaotic" and "debased." Despite a US$66 million loss, News Corp reported a 3% increase in total revenue to US$2.18 billion, driven by growth in online visits and subscriptions to its media properties.

site_title: US stock rout: Will machines make it worse?
summary: US stocks experienced a sharp decline on Thursday, with the S&P 500 index falling 3.75% and entering a correction. Machine-guided fund managers are expected to sell riskier assets, such as equities, to achieve a constant level of volatility. However, analysts disagree on the impact of these strategies, with some attributing the sell-off to financial advisors selling options on clients' accounts. The market is now vulnerable to further weakness, with the overall amount of money in volatility-contingent strategies estimated at around $1.5 trillion.

site_title: Singapore improves global intellectual property index score, takes 9th spot
summary: Singapore has improved its intellectual property index score, ranking 9th out of 50 economies with a score of 84% (33.45 out of 40 indicators). The country's score is ahead of Switzerland, Australia, and New Zealand, but still second in the Asia-Pacific region, behind Japan. The US tops the list, followed by European countries. Singapore's score improved from 82% in the previous year's index, reflecting strong performance in new indicators added, including patent prosecution and IP as an economic asset.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Gold prices flat, concern over rising interest rates weighs
summary: Gold prices remained flat on Thursday, influenced by concerns over rising US bond yields and global interest rates. Despite early selling, gold prices rebounded when they hit a technical support level of $1,312 an ounce. This support level was seen as a significant level from late December and early January, when gold prices rallied to a 1-1/2 year high. Spot gold was unchanged at $1,318.12 per ounce, while silver increased 0.4%, and platinum declined 0.4%.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks skid to 5-month low on global rout, won slides
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index slid 1.9% to a 5-month low of 2,361.30, following global market losses and a weaker Korean won. The won fell 0.6% against the US dollar, and bond yields rose. The Kospi has lost nearly 8% in February and 4% in 2018, with foreigners selling 64.6 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: China's Shanda Games says Tencent to invest $474m
summary: China's Shanda Games says it will receive a $474 million investment from Tencent Holdings, boosting Tencent's lead in the local video game market. The investment comes as Tencent prepares to launch "PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds" in China, and will help Shanda's core business and collaborate on current games. Shanda, which owns popular titles "Dragon Nest" and "The World of Legend", has slipped behind local rivals including Tencent over the past decade. The deal is part of Tencent's efforts to expand its presence in the world's largest video game market.

site_title: China's Didi, SoftBank to roll out taxi venture in Japan
summary: Chinese ride-hailing giant Didi Chuxing is set to launch a venture with SoftBank Group Corp in Japan, aiming to provide ride-hailing and other services in the country. The joint venture, to begin trial services this year, intensifies Didi's global battle with US rival Uber. Didi expanded rapidly overseas after buying Uber's local business in China, ending a subsidy war that cost Uber $2 billion. SoftBank is an existing investor in Didi, valuing the firm at over $50 billion. The move underscores Didi's push to expand outside China.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks dive more than 3%, extending global slump
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted more than 3% on Friday, following a global slump, as volatility continues to affect equity markets. The benchmark Nikkei index dropped 698.26 points to 21,192.60, while the Topix index fell 53.88 points to 1,711.81. This extends a global market downturn, with European and US stocks also experiencing significant declines.

site_title: Hero labrador sniffs out survivor in Taiwan quake wreckage
summary: A four-year-old golden labrador named Tie Hsiung helped Taiwanese search and rescue workers locate two people trapped in a damaged building after a 6.4-magnitude earthquake in Hualien, Taiwan, killing 10 people. The dog, on his first mission, braved aftershocks to sniff out the survivors, one of whom was pulled from the rubble relatively unscathed after 15 hours. The dog's trainer praised his determination, saying he did great despite the dangerous terrain. The incident marked a significant milestone for Taiwan's rescue dog teams, which have trained around 50 dogs since their establishment seven years ago.

site_title: FLASH: Mountbatten Enterprises announces voluntary cash offer for LTC Corp at S$0.925 per share
summary: Mountbatten Enterprises has announced a voluntary cash offer for all ordinary shares of LTC Corp at S$0.925 per share. The offer is made by a group of controlling shareholders from the Cheng family.

site_title: Property upturn based on true supply and demand: ERA
summary: ERA Realty's key executive officer Eugene Lim notes the current property market upturn is driven by true supply and demand, rather than speculation. This differs from the 2005-2007 bull years, where cooling measures were ineffective in halting buying momentum. The market's persistence in buying sentiment, despite cooling measures, indicates a strong demand for properties. Lim suggests the duration of the buying momentum depends on how fast prices rise, implying a potential shift in the market if prices continue to escalate. This suggests a positive outlook for the Singapore property market.

site_title: Cutting Edge

The H8i boasts a minimalist design, while the H9i features adaptive memory foam ear cushions. Vivo has launched the V7+ smartphone with a 24MP front-facing camera and full screen display, while the Apple Watch Series 3 will be available in Singapore, offering built-in cellular and a new NumberShare service.

site_title: 'Escobar' gastropub to drop picture of Colombian drug lord after complaints
summary: A Singapore gastropub named "Escobar" has faced backlash after displaying a picture of Colombian drug lord Pablo Escobar on its sign, drawing complaints from the Colombian embassy and Singapore's narcotics agency. The bar's owner, Stan Sri Ganesh, initially thought the name was a good fit but later apologized for any offense caused, stating he never intended to condone Escobar's actions. The Central Narcotics Bureau warned the owner to uphold a strict anti-drug policy, and the bar's logo will be changed at a cost of $20,000.

site_title: British PM reassures Japanese executives on Brexit
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May reassured Japanese executives that Brexit presents an "opportunity" for free trade deals, but acknowledged the challenges ahead. Japan's ambassador warned of "high stakes" and potential cost increases for Japanese companies in the UK, including carmakers Honda and Nissan. A leaked government assessment suggests cost increases of 5-13% for the car industry and 5-10% for financial services. The meeting with Japanese executives came amid uncertainty and concerns about the impact of Brexit on businesses, with some firms planning to move their EU bases from London to Frankfurt.

site_title: Frasers Property JV to take 26.1% stake in Ticon; will trigger takeover offer for Thai developer
summary: Frasers Property has entered into an agreement to purchase a 26.1% stake in Ticon Industrial Connection Public Company Limited for 8.569 billion baht (S$358.56 million). The stake represents approximately 478.7 million ordinary shares. The completion of the sale will trigger a takeover offer for the remaining Ticon shares, with the estimated total amount payable estimated to be up to 20 billion baht. This move is part of Frasers Property's existing 49-51 venture, Frasers Assets, which has a 40.95% stake in Ticon.

site_title: Asian markets shaken again by Bank of England's hawkish tone
summary: The Bank of England's hawkish tone has shaken Asian markets, with stocks in Singapore, Malaysia, Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Australia experiencing significant declines. The Straits Times Index in Singapore fell 1.64%, while the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong plummeted over 900 points. The Bank of England hinted at earlier-than-expected monetary policy tightening, citing a need to "tighten somewhat earlier and by a somewhat greater extent" compared to November. The regional bloodbath follows big falls on Wall Street and in Europe overnight, with US yields initially rising before falling back.

site_title: LTC Corporation controlling shareholders plan takeover offer at S$0.925 per share
summary: LTC Corporation's controlling shareholders, led by the Cheng family, plan a voluntary conditional cash offer of S$0.925 per share for all ordinary shares, representing a premium of 44.5% over the stock's last close. Mountbatten Enterprises Pte Ltd, the bid vehicle, has secured irrevocable undertakings for approximately 48.54% of LTC's total shares. The offer price is final, but Mountbatten may revise it if a competitive situation arises, and the takeover is conditional on receiving acceptances that would result in its concert parties holding at least 90% of the issued shares.

site_title: Made To Order
summary: A Hong Kong-based service, Stay One Degree, offers bespoke experiences for luxury home stays, including castles, villas, and super yachts. Members can book private apartments, chateaus, and ski chalets, and owners can rent out their properties. This unique service provides exclusive access to unique and luxurious accommodations, allowing travelers to experience the insider life. By partnering with property owners, Stay One Degree offers a personalized and immersive experience for its members.

site_title: Golden Energy sells US$150m in debt due 2023 at 9% coupon
summary: Golden Energy and Resources Limited, an Indonesian coal miner, priced US$150 million senior secured notes due 2023 at a 9% coupon. The issue price is 98.53% of the principal, with a yield to maturity of 9.4%. The notes are secured by shares of its subsidiary and may be redeemed early with a redemption premium. US$50 million of the proceeds will be used to prepay a secured term loan facility, while the remainder will be used for general corporate purposes.

site_title: Valuetronics Q3 profit up 35.7%
summary: Valuetronics reported a 35.7% increase in its third-quarter net profit to HK$58.2 million, driven by increased demand for industrial and consumer electronics. Revenue rose 34.2% to HK$788.3 million. The company attributed its performance to stronger sales in both segments, but warned of ongoing supply chain challenges.

site_title: LA police send Weinstein sex assault cases to prosecutors
summary: LA police have submitted three sexual assault cases against Harvey Weinstein to prosecutors, following a wave of allegations from dozens of Hollywood women. The cases, submitted on February 1, are under review by the District Attorney's Office. Weinstein, who denies non-consensual sex, is facing parallel investigations in New York and London, and has reportedly sought treatment for sexual addiction. The scandal has led to re-examination of workplace policies in industries beyond entertainment.

site_title: Neo Group corrects Q3 working capital changes; Q3 earnings rise to S$2.1m
summary: Neo Group, a food solutions provider, corrected its working capital changes for Q3, revealing trade and other receivables were S$821,000, not S$2.52 million. This correction increased net cash from operating activities to S$8.2 million and cash and cash equivalents to S$11.6 million. The firm posted a net profit of S$2.1 million, up from S$125,000, and a 4.2% decline in revenue to S$44.7 million.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday; STI drops 2%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 69.85 points, or 2%, to 3,346.05. The decline followed a late selloff on Wall Street, which saw its equities gauges in correction territory. Losers outnumbered gainers 247 to 8, with Marco Polo Marine and Jiutian Chemical Group leading the decline. The market was affected by global market volatility, with investors awaiting GDP data and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Growing deficit could drive up US borrowing costs: official
summary: US Treasury bill yields rose to 2.88%, the highest level since January 2014, due to a mounting sovereign debt and potential budget deficits. Federal Reserve President William Dudley attributed the rise to the US economy's strength, global economy growth, and financial conditions, not fiscal worries. He also downplayed the recent market correction, stating it had "virtually no implications" for the economic outlook. The recent tax overhaul forecasted to add over $1 trillion to the federal budget deficit over a decade may contribute to higher borrowing costs in the future.

site_title: The market collapse blame game
summary: The global market is experiencing a free fall, with experts warning it may be an overdue unwinding of years of excess. Despite reassurances from Janet Yellen that a global economic crisis would not occur in her lifetime, the market collapse bears similarities to the 2008-09 Great Recession. The academic community's virtual silence on market bubbles and former Federal Reserve chief Yellen's denial of a global crisis have raised concerns that policymakers and experts are not taking responsibility for the current market situation. The extent of the damage to the general economy remains to be seen.

site_title: Overseas property investments: the grass isn't always greener
summary: A Singaporean investor's £270,000 overseas property investment turned into a fire risk due to substandard fire safety features in a UK luxury apartment building. The freeholder refuses to foot the bill for repairs, and leaseholders may be liable for £1.5 million. The incident highlights the hidden pitfalls of overseas property investments, including building defects, hidden taxes, and scams. Experts warn that investors must conduct thorough due diligence and consider local building codes and regulations before investing. The UK's Grenfell Tower tragedy led to a wave of inspections and safety work, with residents facing increased service charges and repair costs.

site_title: US Republicans, Democrats fight over infrastructure plans
summary: US House Democrats proposed a $1 trillion infrastructure spending plan, five times the amount President Trump's expected $200 billion plan. The plan includes funding for schools, rural broadband, airports, and energy efficiency. Trump's plan shifts the burden onto cities and states, according to Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi. The Trump administration has rejected Democrats' call for $1 trillion in new spending, citing fiscal irresponsibility. A spending deal was unveiled, including $20 billion in additional funding for infrastructure projects, with specifics to be determined by Congress.

site_title: Qualcomm rejects Broadcom hostile bid, opens door to talks
summary: Qualcomm rejects Broadcom's record $121 billion hostile bid, citing the offer "materially undervalues" the company. The board believes the offer fails to account for regulatory risks and doesn't value Qualcomm's plans for NXP and 5G devices. However, Qualcomm is open to discussing the offer, saying it would meet with Broadcom to address "significant issues." The deal, which would create a global chipmaking giant, must still pass regulatory muster.

site_title: Startup showcase at Singapore Airshow excites onlookers
summary: A startup showcase at the Singapore Airshow featured nearly 70 exhibitors from nine countries, showcasing innovative technologies such as emotion-detecting video analytic platforms, 720-degree panoramic drones, and virtual reality headsets. The event, titled "What's next @ Singapore Airshow," highlighted cutting-edge technologies that are set to revolutionize various industries. The startup showcase aimed to attract visitors' attention and provide a platform for startups to demonstrate their innovative products and services.

site_title: Alliance Mineral Assets Q2 loss deepens to A$1.36m
summary: Alliance Mineral Assets Limited reported a widened net loss of A$1.36 million for its second quarter, a significant increase from A$989,400 in the previous year. The company attributed the widening loss to increased expenses, including consulting and directors' fees, administrative expenses, and employee salaries, despite a surge in interest income. site_title: EU doubts 2020 Brexit vision, sees longer goodbye
summary: The European Union has expressed doubts about the UK's ability to leave the EU by the end of 2020, citing concerns about Britain's readiness for a full break. This extends the UK's departure timeline beyond the initial Brexit transition plan, leaving the EU bracing for a longer goodbye.

site_title: Unboxing corporate governance: Three fabled tests for a better code
summary: The Corporate Governance Council of Singapore has proposed significant reforms to enhance corporate governance, including a revised Code of Corporate Governance. The revised Code aims to move away from "box-ticking" and focus on nurturing a supportive ecosystem, with a holistic approach to governance. The revisions include changes to board composition, director independence, remuneration disclosure, and stakeholder engagement. The Code will undergo a two-month consultation period, with recommendations to be evaluated using the "goose test" (ensuring companies serve all stakeholders), the "dog test" (prioritizing existing guidelines), and the "tortoise-and-hare test" (adopting a steady pace).

site_title: Oil hits 7-week low on expectations of higher US, Iran output
summary: Oil prices fell to a 7-week low on Thursday due to fears of rising global supplies, with Brent futures dropping 1.1% to $64.81 a barrel and US WTI crude falling 1% to $61.15 a barrel. site_title: Startups key to Singapore's digitisation charge, says IMDA chief
summary: Singapore's Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) is betting on startups to drive the nation's digitisation efforts, citing their innovative and problem-solving capabilities. This focus on startups is part of Singapore's broader strategy to build a competitive infocomm media sector.

summary: Singapore's government is launching initiatives to help firms in property transaction services and facilities management (FM) raise their skills and adopt innovation. Second Minister for National Development Desmond Lee emphasized the initiatives' potential to future-proof the real estate sector and affect other sub-sectors of the real estate value chain.

summary: Google is taking back Nest, the smart home unit it acquired in 2014 for $3.2 billion, as part of an effort to battle rivals like Amazon and its Alexa digital assistant. site_title: Lucky In Love
summary: Burberry's second capsule collection with Gosha Rubchinskiy is now available at Dover Street Market Singapore, featuring classic Burberry icons reinterpreted with a streetwear vibe. The collection is part of a series of limited-edition collaborations.

summary: Swiss Re is in preliminary talks to sell a minority stake to SoftBank Group, a deal potentially worth $10 billion or more, marking the Japanese firm's biggest financial services deal. summary: A couple in Acton, Massachusetts, has been receiving free items from Amazon without ordering them, including a plastic fan and a phone charger. site_title: China studying restrictions on US soybean imports: sources

China has already imposed anti-subsidy and anti-dumping investigations on US grain sorghum and is considering measures on US soybeans, which would significantly impact US prices.

site_title: Real estate ITM aims to improve efficiencies, not replace jobs, says Chuan-Jin
summary: Singaporean Speaker of Parliament Tan Chuan-Jin stated that the government's Real Estate Industry Transformation Map (ITM) aims to improve property transaction efficiency, not replace jobs. Despite concerns from agents that the new HDB online resale portal may render their jobs redundant, Tan emphasized that the goal is to make transactions "pain-free" and improve quality of life for all Singaporeans. He urged agents to upgrade their skills and take on higher-value roles, acknowledging that technological transformation is inevitable and can create opportunities for growth.

site_title: Why planes could still vanish into thin air like MH370
summary: The disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 remains a mystery four years after the incident, with the search continuing. New planes won't be required to broadcast their locations in trouble until January 2021, despite proposals aimed at preventing similar incidents. The Indian Ocean search resumed last month, with no conclusive findings yet. The lack of international requirements for real-time location broadcasts contributes to the ongoing uncertainty, leaving the world's longest jet hunt unresolved.

site_title: Suntec City to launch Alipay payment option to attract more Chinese tourists
summary: Suntec City has partnered with Alipay to launch the mobile payment platform in its shopping mall, aiming to attract more Chinese tourists. The partnership will roll out Alipay payment terminals to 60% of stores by July 2018. This move follows a similar agreement between the Singapore Tourism Board and Alipay last year, aiming to increase exposure of Singapore's offerings to Chinese tourists. The partnership is seen as a key strategy for Suntec City to enhance engagement with Chinese shoppers in the digital space.

Changes are being drafted to address these concerns, potentially identifying specific "critical technologies" or monitoring them through existing export control agencies.

site_title: Sponsors shy away from Winter Olympics
summary: South Korea's Winter Olympics, hosted in Pyeongchang, are marked by a lack of corporate sponsorship due to recent scandals.
