summary: VLV, a Chinese restaurant and club lounge in Clarke Quay, introduces its new Soul Lounge jazz programme on Valentine's Day and Tuesdays to Thursdays. The upscale venue features live jazz performances by an all-star ensemble, including Sean Hong on sax, Audrey Tengkey on keys, and Kenji Nakano on double bass. The jazz band performs from 9:30pm to 11:30pm, with admission costing S$15. Inspired by live jazz venues in Tokyo and London, VLV offers a unique blend of fine Cantonese cuisine and top jazz talents in a chic, heritage setting.

site_title: Hyundai Kona review: Warrior class
summary: The Hyundai Kona Warrior is a highly stylized and attention-grabbing crossover that sets itself apart from its rivals. Its unique design features, including a slim grille and minimalist lights, make it a head-turner. The Kona's performance is impressive, with a 7.9-second 0-100km/h time and a 177hp turbo engine. The car's handling and ride are also noteworthy, offering a balance of control and agility. However, the Kona's cabin feels somewhat plasticky, and its price is inflated by a S$20,000 pollution tax. Despite this, the Kona is a fun and lively companion, making it suitable for those who prioritize style, safety, and performance.

site_title: Wijet's 16-plane deal is Honda's single biggest order
summary: Honda Aircraft has signed a deal with European air taxi company Wijet for 16 of its five-passenger HondaJet aircraft, valued up to $80 million. The order is Honda's largest to date, replacing Wijet's current fleet of 15 Cessna aircraft. The HondaJet features a longer range, greater silence, and improved fuel efficiency, and will expand Wijet's service to 1,500 airports across Europe, Africa, and the Nordic and Baltic countries. The deal marks a significant milestone for Honda Aircraft, which took about three decades to develop the aircraft.

site_title: Ademco Security acquires stake in Vietnamese firm
summary: Ademco Security Group announced its first acquisition in Vietnam, acquiring a 60% stake in TNT Technologies Joint Stock Company, a high-end security solutions provider. The deal aims to boost Ademco's overseas revenue by 50% over the next three years. Established in 2005, TNT provides security solutions to clients across various sectors, including aviation and retail. The acquisition marks Ademco's seventh expansion in Singapore, China, India, Malaysia, and the Philippines, with plans to establish a global regional presence in 14 markets by 2020.

site_title: Thai Art Superstar
summary: Thai artist Natee Utarit's solo exhibition Optimism is Ridiculous: The Altarpieces features large and ambitious works that critique capitalism and its impact on Thai society. The exhibition, now at The Private Museum Singapore, presents Western-style paintings infused with Buddhist traditions of restraint and simplicity. The show garnered acclaim in Manila's Ayala Museum and Indonesia's National Gallery, further solidifying Natee's reputation as a prominent Thai artist. His unique blend of classical European art and strong social commentary has garnered international attention, highlighting the artist's distinctive voice in the art world.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Spring Singapore, 9 partners in S$200m bid to boost tech startups
summary: Spring Singapore has appointed nine co-investment partners to catalyze over S$200 million in investments into tech startups in Singapore over eight years. The partners, including Armstrong Industrial Corporation and Silicon Solution Partners, will match SSC's S$100 million commitment with private capital. The move aims to boost innovation and economic growth in sectors such as advanced manufacturing, health, and urban solutions. Spring Singapore and the partners will focus on identifying high-potential startups, assisting their development, and fast-tracking their entry into the global market.

site_title: Abolishing fossil fuel subsidies has little impact on CO2 emissions: study
summary: Researchers found that abolishing fossil fuel subsidies would only slightly slow the growth of CO2 emissions, with a modest 1-5% decrease by 2030. The study challenges widely held assumptions that removing subsidies would curb carbon pollution and speed the transition to a greener economy. Fossil fuel subsidies, valued at around $260 billion in 2016, mainly benefit oil, gas, and electricity producers, rather than coal, which is the dirtiest of fossil fuels. The findings contradict the Paris climate treaty goal of capping global warming below two degrees Celsius.

site_title: Trillions of plastic bags in circulation, yet little is known about their usage
summary: The use of single-use plastic bags has grown exponentially over the past half century, with trillions in circulation, yet little data exists on their usage. Despite efforts to restrict their use, there is no precise handle on whether measures are working, as governments and agencies use different thicknesses in their definitions. Small-scale data sets suggest restrictions can be effective, but a global picture is lacking, with only 0.6% of global plastic bag usage accounted for in England. The lack of clear data hinders efforts to curb plastic waste and manage consumption, with the Ellen MacArthur Foundation emphasizing the need for better evidence and transparency.

site_title: Board of SBI Offshore receives request to remove 3 directors
summary: The board of SBI Offshore has received a request from shareholders carrying over 10% of the company's shares to remove three directors, Ling Yew Kong, Lawrence Kwan, and James Kho Chung Wah, and appoint three new ones. The shareholders, who own 66.82 million shares, are asking for Hui Choon Ho, Jen Shek Voon, and Percival Jeyapal s/o David to be appointed as directors. The company is verifying the shareholdings and seeking legal advice on the validity of the request.

site_title: Total pledges higher dividend as confidence in oil recovery grows
summary: Total SA, a French energy giant, is raising its dividend by about 10% from 2018 to 2020 and plans to buy back up to $5 billion of shares over the same period. The company's adjusted net income rose 19% in the fourth quarter, driven by rising oil prices and increased production. Total aims to achieve cost savings of $4 billion in 2018 and make organic investments of $14 billion. The company's CEO, Patrick Pouyanne, expressed confidence in the industry's recovery, citing higher oil prices above $50 per barrel.

site_title: Trucking and the future of work
summary: The future of trucking may hold clues to the future of work, as automation threatens jobs, but also creates new opportunities. The US trucking industry faces a shortage of drivers, with 55% of its 3.5 million drivers aged 45 or older. Experts suggest that automation could alleviate this shortage, but also lead to job losses in blue-collar sectors. A new study by Uber argues that driverless trucks may actually stimulate the need for more drivers, as long-haul transportation could be performed by autonomous tractor-trailers, leaving local workers to handle deliveries.

site_title: M&C Hotels 2017 revenue up, but Europe occupancy down
summary: MILLENNIUM & Copthorne Hotels reported a 7.9% rise in annual revenue per room, driven by a weaker sterling and strong growth in non-European markets. However, revenue per available room in Europe fell 2.9% due to Brexit-related concerns, particularly in London. RevPAR rose to £82.78 (S$152) for the year ended Dec 31, up 3.2% on constant currencies.

site_title: Australia's central bank does not see "strong case" for rate hike
summary: Australia's central bank governor Philip Lowe stated that there's no "strong case" for a near-term interest rate hike, despite economic growth and inflation concerns. The Reserve Bank of Australia aims for 2-3% inflation and unemployment below 5.5%. Lowe expects steady progress, but gradual growth, with a possible rate increase when inflation rises and the jobless rate falls. The bank projects steady economic growth and inflation between 2.0-2.5% over the next couple of years.

images.alt_text: Australia's central bank does not see a "strong case" for a near-term rate increase even though it is optimistic a pick-up in economic growth would gradually spur inflation and reduce unemployment, governor Philip Lowe said on Thursday.

site_title: Met gets to keep iconic Picasso work
summary: A federal judge in New York has dismissed a lawsuit by the estate of a German businessman who sought to recover a Picasso painting sold at a discount in 1938 to raise money to flee the Nazis. The painting, "The Actor," will remain at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where it has been on display since 1952. The judge ruled that the estate's claim of duress was not enough to prove a legal claim, and the museum will not be forced to surrender the art.

images.alt_text: "When people walk through those galleries, that work is so commanding, its absence would have been deeply felt." - Art dealer David Norman.

site_title: Are long-tenure directors bad for effective corporate governance?
summary: A public consultation in Singapore is reviewing the criteria for determining director independence, with a focus on the nine-year term limit for long-tenure directors. The current code lists six tests, but the guideline for reviewing long-serving directors' independence is unclear. Experts debate the merits and risks of board tenure, with some arguing it can lead to loss of objectivity and others citing its benefits of deep experience and positive board dynamics. The consultation proposes revising the term limit to a mandatory limit or adopting a "comply or explain" approach, with disclosure of director appraisal criteria and board renewal plans.

images.alt_text: A study of S&P 500 firms from 2003 to 2013 found that more board membership changes, from incoming and outgoing directors, led to lower firm performance, suggesting disruptive effects on board dynamics.

site_title: Hygge House
summary: A Singaporean couple, Calvin Chan and Zoe Luo, have transformed their four-storey home into a Scandinavian-inspired haven, dubbed "Hygge House." The design director, Terence Neo, aimed to create a timeless look with minimal carpentry work and a predominantly white backdrop, allowing the couple's personal items to shine. The home features Eames furniture, artwork from Moderna Museet, and a focus on natural light, with sliding doors connecting the indoors to the lush outdoor space, where the couple grows their own fruit trees and herbs. The result is a cozy, inviting space that embodies the concept of hygge, or Danish warmth and contentment.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang
White walls and furniture with clean lines are the key features of this residence.
A painting depicting a wintry scene.
A seamless blend of the indoors and outdoors.
Calvin Chan and Zoe Luo in the hygge home.
The light woods contrast with the black framed door for a chic look.

site_title: Betting on batik
summary: Batik, a resist-dyeing technique originating from 4th century Egypt, gained popularity in Indonesia and later in Singapore in the 1900s. In Singapore, batik became iconic in the 1950s and 1960s, particularly in the "bouquet" motif popularized by Dutch enterprises. The style remains a significant part of Singapore's fashion culture, with modern batik prints still being used today. Batik's influence extends beyond fashion, with its unique patterns and textures being used in various materials, including cotton and silk.

site_title: Deep Sea Adventure
summary: The BBC's Blue Planet II submarine, Alucia, has been listed on Airbnb for a unique underwater exploration experience. Three lucky travelers will embark on a 1,000m journey to witness marine life in the Bahamas, accompanied by an economy class ticket to Nassau, two-night stay on the Alucia, and a two-night stay at an Airbnb property. To participate, applicants must submit a 50-550 word essay on their dream adventure and why they deserve the spot. Entries close on February 10. The experience aims to raise awareness about ocean exploration and conservation.

images.alt_text: The submarine from the show Blue Planet II, OceanX's Alucia.

site_title: Best Foot Forward
summary: ASICS has partnered with Novak Djokovic to launch the Gel-Resolution Novak tennis shoe. Developed at the ASICS Institute of Sport Science, the shoe features a Lateral Support Brace for stability, a FlexionFit upper, and an External Heel Counter for rearfoot support. The shoe was unveiled ahead of Djokovic's Australian Open appearance and is priced at S$229 at ASICS stores in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
The Gel-Resolution Novak.

site_title: Nissan slashes profit forecasts after inspection scandal
summary: Nissan slashed its full-year operating profit forecast by 12.4% to 565 billion yen (S$6.9 billion) due to a damaging inspection scandal in Japan. The scandal, which involved staff conducting final inspections on vehicles without authorization, led to a recall of 1.2 million vehicles and a 55% drop in passenger car sales in Japan. CEO Hiroto Saikawa voluntarily returned his pay, and the company remains focused on improving its business performance despite market headwinds.

site_title: Walmart turns to goods of at least US$10 to turn its e-commerce around
summary: Walmart is shifting its e-commerce strategy to focus on higher-priced merchandise, with a goal of selling items at least $10 and up, in an effort to turn a profit on its online business. The move comes after years of offering low prices to drive sales, but is seen as a necessary step to compete with Amazon. Suppliers will be encouraged to provide more expensive goods for sale online, while Walmart will continue to offer lower-priced items at its brick-and-mortar stores. The strategy carries significant risk, as bargain hunters may reject the new approach and seek lower-priced goods elsewhere.

images.alt_text: Walmart's directive to suppliers marks a shift in strategy. The retailer for years has squeezed them for pennies to drive the lowest prices for shoppers, both online and at its brick-and-mortar stores. This new emphasis comes after the retailer is striving to make its online business more competitive.

site_title: HDB resale prices dip 0.5% in Jan, volume slumps by 31.4%: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore dipped 0.5% in January, with prices of three- and five-room flats decreasing by 2.3% and 1.2%, respectively. Sales volume dropped 31.4% from December last year, with 1,089 units sold. The median Transaction Over X-Value (TOX) was negative, indicating buyers were overpaying. The decline in prices and sales volume marks the 2nd consecutive year of price drops, with prices slipping 2% year-on-year and resale volume down 8.7% from January 2017.

site_title: Man Utd post loss as Trump's tax reform offsets broadcast boom
summary: Manchester United reported a £29 million loss for the second quarter of 2017, despite a 17.3% increase in broadcast income to £61.6 million. The loss was attributed to an exceptional "accounting write off of £48.8 million" due to the US corporate tax rate reduction from 35% to 21% following President Trump's tax reform. The club's total revenue increased by nearly 4% to £163.9 million, and a new Premier League TV rights deal is expected to be announced soon.

site_title: Canada Goose plunges after rally leaves investors restless
summary: Canada Goose Holdings Inc plummeted 15% to C$40.87 after reporting better-than-expected quarterly results, which failed to meet investors' lofty expectations. The company topped estimates with a profit of 58 cents per share, but its sales to wholesalers fell as it moved shipments forward. Canada Goose appointed a new finance chief and declined to provide an annual forecast, weighing on shares. Despite defying retail malaise, the company's direct-to-consumer strategy and luxury parkas continue to drive growth, with analysts praising the brand's strong adoption story.

site_title: Flight crews, please do turn on your electronic devices
summary: Airline Philippine Airlines has successfully transitioned to digital flight bags, reducing paper usage and environmental impact. The move to electronic flight bags (EFB) allows pilots to access flight information on mobile devices, streamlining processes and improving safety. This shift has also enhanced security, as compromised devices can be remotely wiped and locked. Sri Lankan Airlines has also implemented digital transformation, enabling employees to work remotely and improving customer service. The aviation industry is experiencing a tailwind in its digital transformation journey, with mobility and accessibility driving benefits.

site_title: Singtel's Q3 profits down 8.5 per cent on Airtel woes
summary: Singtel's third-quarter profits declined 8.5% to S$890 million due to tougher market conditions in India and lower contributions from associates. The telco's operating revenue grew 4.4% to S$4.6 billion, while its Australian consumer business saw a 7.8% increase. However, voice revenue declines and higher network depreciation also affected the bottom line. Regional associates, particularly Airtel, were largely to blame for the decline. Despite this, analysts remain bullish on Singtel's long-term prospects, citing strong momentum in its core business and a "buy" call from DBS analyst Sachin Mittal.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: China's yuan plunges most since 2015
summary: China's yuan plummeted 0.7% to 6.3375 against the US dollar, its largest decline since August 2015, amid speculation policymakers will curb its gains. The currency's value dropped after trade figures missed estimates and China reported a narrower trade surplus than expected. The yuan's climb to a two-year high this week fueled speculation of official intervention, and the foreign-exchange regulator expressed a willingness to allow two-way yuan moves. This move may signal a shift in the country's approach to currency management.

site_title: Govt transfers, taxes keep income gap at bay
summary: Singapore's income inequality remained relatively stable in 2017, with government transfers and taxes narrowing the gap between the rich and poor. The lowest 50% of households saw income from work rise 2.1-3.6% in real terms, while the top 10% experienced 2.6% growth. The Gini coefficient, a measure of income inequality, rose slightly to 0.459, but remained unchanged after accounting for government transfers and taxes. Median household income from work grew 2% in nominal terms and 1.5% in real terms.

images.alt_text: Singapore's income inequality changed little in 2017 from 2016, as government transfers and taxes narrowed the gap between the rich and poor, according to a Department of Statistics (DOS) report released on Thursday.

site_title: UK central bank raises growth forecasts, says rates need to rise faster
summary: The Bank of England raised its growth forecasts for the UK, citing a strong global recovery, and indicated that interest rates may need to rise sooner and by more than initially thought. The central bank's rate-setters voted to hold interest rates at 0.5% and set a more conventional horizon for returning inflation to its 2% target. Sterling rose against the US dollar, while British government bond prices fell and share prices slipped. The BoE now expects the economy to grow at an average annual rate of 1.75% over the next three years, below its previous forecast of 4% global growth.

images.alt_text: BoE governor Mark Carney speaking during the bank's quarterly inflation report news conference on Feb 8. The BoE lifted its forecasts for economic growth and suggested it may need to raise interest rates faster than previously indicated.

site_title: ST Engineering divests 5% stake in ST Aerospace Guangzhou for US$7m
summary: ST Engineering divested its 5% stake in ST Aerospace Guangzhou for US$7 million to Japan Airlines. The joint venture, set up in 2014, provides aircraft maintenance services at Guangzhou Baiyun International Airport in China. The deal allows Japan Airlines to become a strategic partner with a 5% stake, while ST Engineering and the Guangdong Airport Authority will retain majority ownership. The divestment is expected to have no material impact on ST Engineering's financial performance for the current year. The new partnership is expected to enhance safety and quality standards for STA Guangzhou.

site_title: Wheat Inspiration
summary: Chanel's high jewellery collection Les Blés de Chanel celebrates the life cycle of wheat, paying tribute to founder Gabrielle "Coco" Chanel's love of wheat. The 62-piece collection features diamonds, peridots, and other gemstones in pieces such as Premiers Brins and Fête des Moissons, evoking images of young wheat stalks and summer harvests. A large-scale wheat field installation, Blés Vendome, will be displayed in Singapore's Event Plaza from Feb 23 to March 1, accompanied by an invite-only exhibition at the ArtScience Museum and at Chanel boutiques.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Limited Time For The Ladies
summary: At this year's SIHH luxury watch show, women's timepieces were underrepresented, with only a third of major brands unveiling new novelties. Despite the #MeToo movement's impact, women's watches were given limited attention. However, brands like Van Cleef & Arpels, Audemars Piguet, and IWC introduced new women's collections, including the Royal Oak Concept Flying Tourbillon and the Da Vinci Automatic Moon Phase 36 Edition "150 Years". Unisex pieces, such as the IWC Da Vinci watch, also made appearances.

site_title: First Sponsor Q4 profit falls 41.5% on absence of one-off gain
summary: First Sponsor Group's Q4 profit fell 41.5% to S$42.7 million due to the absence of a one-off gain from the Star of East River Project divestment in 2016. Despite a 660.3% year-on-year increase in revenue to S$180.3 million, earnings per share declined to 7.23 Singapore cents. The company will undertake a 1-for-4 rights issue to raise S$161.5 million and strengthen its balance sheet. Full-year net profit was 21.9% lower at S$88.3 million.

site_title: James Foley
summary: Film director James Foley, 64, is set to release the final installment of the Fifty Shades trilogy, Fifty Shades Freed, after directing the previous two films. Foley, a respected industry veteran, has worked with notable actors like Al Pacino and Kevin Spacey, despite receiving negative reviews for his previous film, Fifty Shades Darker. Foley attributes his success to his ability to translate complex psychological scenes from author E.L. James' books into convincing on-screen performances. He expressed his openness to the #MeToo movement, stating that it has changed his perspective, but still doesn't fully understand the issue.

images.alt_text: "The first reaction after reading the (fifty shades) books was - to my surprise - that I enjoyed the psycho-sexual adventure. I have always been interested in complex psychological stuff and I was given the opportunity to do a character study - it intrigued me a lot." ~ James Foley.

site_title: China Star Food Group posts profit net of tax of 8m yuan for Q3, down 33.7% from a year ago
summary: China Star Food Group reported a profit net of tax of 8 million yuan (S$1.7 million) for the third quarter, down 33.7% from the same period last year. Revenue fell 20.2% to 92.3 million yuan due to the Zilaohu factory's production halt. The group expects its production to be restored to normal levels by early 2019 and will focus on high-value products.

site_title: Tritech Group's proposed acquisition of 2 companies falls through; to establish JV in Shanghai
summary: Tritech Group has terminated its proposed acquisition of Shanghai Haihan Environmental and Nanjing Qinghai Environmental due to regulatory restrictions in China. Instead, the companies will establish a 60-40 joint venture in Shanghai, with Tritech holding 60% equity interest. The acquisition was deemed too costly and time-consuming, prompting the group to pursue a more efficient route. The termination does not affect Tritech Environmental, the wholly-owned subsidiary of Tritech Group.

site_title: Dollar at 2-week high as weakness seen overdone; euro dips
summary: The dollar reached a two-week high against a basket of major currencies, driven by investors covering short positions and bets on at least three US interest rate hikes in 2018. The euro fell to a two-week low, while traditional safe-havens like the yen and Swiss franc saw modest gains. The dollar's strength was attributed to US yield rises and a market in consolidation mode following recent stock market volatility. However, a Reuters poll of strategists suggests the dollar's rebound may not be sustainable.

site_title: Midas Holdings flags litigations, enforcement orders, among other irregularities during audit
summary: MIDAS Holdings announced it has uncovered several litigations, enforcement orders, and court documents during an audit. A 30 million yuan (S$6.3 million) undisclosed liability was found against a PRC subsidiary, Jilin Midas Aluminium Industries, and approximately 12 million yuan was frozen from ledger balances. The company is appointing an independent non-executive director, Xu Wei Dong, to oversee group assets and approve payments. The board will assess whether the group can continue as a going concern and issue further announcements as necessary.

site_title: Singapore shares close above 3,400 level on Thursday
summary: Singapore stocks rose 1% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index closing at 3,415.90, driven by gains from DBS and Marco Polo Marine. The most actively traded counters were Singtel and Jiutian Chemical. Despite uncertainty over tariffs, investors remained positive, with 224 gainers versus 231 losers.

site_title: Tesla sticks by Model 3 target, warns spending could rise in 2018
summary: Tesla reiterates its Model 3 production target for 2018, despite delays and production issues, citing the car's long-term viability as a key factor. The company's net loss widened to $675.4 million in the fourth quarter, but revenue rose to $3.29 billion. Tesla plans to increase spending in 2018, with capital investments related to the upcoming Model Y SUV. The company's cash burn eased in the quarter, thanks to customer deposits and inventory reduction. Despite challenges from competitors, Tesla's stock has soared 35% in the last year, making it the second-most valuable US carmaker.

site_title: US jobless claims drop to near 45-year low
summary: US jobless claims dropped to a nearly 45-year low of 221,000 for the week ended February 3, beating economists' forecasts. The labor market is near full employment, with the jobless rate at a 17-year low of 4.1%. Strong wage growth, including a 2.9% year-on-year increase in January, supports optimism among Federal Reserve officials that inflation will rise towards the 2% target this year.

site_title: BRC Asia reports 36% jump in Q1 net profit
summary: BRC Asia reported a 36% increase in its quarterly net profit to S$2.6 million, driven by a 26% year-on-year revenue increase to S$100.9 million, largely due to higher unit selling prices. Earnings per share rose to 1.39 cents from 1.02 cents. The company's shares finished two cents higher at S$1.38.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: ARM embraces technology revolution under SoftBank and loses money
summary: ARM Holdings Plc, a 27-year-old UK chip company, posted a loss of $200 million for the nine months to Dec 31 under SoftBank's ownership. The company has rapidly expanded in size and headcount, returning a sizable loss, primarily due to increased hiring of engineers. Despite the losses, ARM remains confident, citing gains in market share and growth in new customers using its designs for 5G cellular modems and smartcards. SoftBank chairman Masayoshi Son aims to make ARM more valuable than Google.

site_title: Tesla averts cash crunch as Musk mystique offsets late cars
summary: Tesla has avoided a cash crunch, with its cash balance remaining stable despite production struggles with the Model 3 sedan. CEO Elon Musk's salesmanship and promotional efforts, including a recent stunt with the Roadster sports car, have supported customer deposits totaling over $850 million. Tesla remains on track to meet its goal of producing 5,000 Model 3 sedans a week by the end of June, and its negative free cash flow decreased to $277 million in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Canada's new home prices stall for first time since 2015
summary: Canada's new home prices stagnated in December for the first time since 2015, according to Statistics Canada. The Toronto market, which had been booming, slowed down due to higher interest rates and stricter buyer rules. Prices in Toronto remained flat, while Vancouver saw a 0.2% monthly gain and an 8.9% year-over-year increase. Nationally, prices rose 3.3% over the past year. The slowdown is attributed to policy changes, including interest-rate increases and tougher rules for buyers, which may have cooled the housing market.

site_title: Hit-and-miss dining at Lavo
summary: Lavo, a high-end Italian restaurant on the rooftop of Marina Bay Sands, offers loud and brash decor but mediocre food. The reviewer had a poor experience, with a bouncer-like staff member turning away a latecomer and unfriendly service. The food was hit-or-miss, with some dishes, like the Charred Octopus and Crispy Chicken "Dominick," being decent, but others, such as the Penne Alla Vodka, being overpriced and lacking substance. The reviewer concluded that Lavo's reputation depends on its famous "Meatball" dish, but even that failed to impress. Rating: 6/10.

images.alt_text: From left: Charred Octopus (S$32), 'The Meatball' (S$38), and Crispy Chicken 'Dominick' (S$48).

site_title: ComfortDelGro Insurance Brokers becomes wholly-owned unit of ComfortDelGro
summary: ComfortDelGro Corporation has acquired a 51% stake in ComfortDelGro Insurance Brokers Pte Ltd for S$22.9 million, making CDGI a wholly-owned subsidiary. The acquisition was based on 1.5 times the brokerage fees of CDGI for the financial year. ComfortDelGro will finance the deal with internal funds, which is not expected to impact its net tangible assets per share or earnings per share for the current financial year.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Save The Kitties
summary: The Cat Museum in Singapore may shut down after June 10 due to a lease renewal issue. Founder Jessica Seet aims to raise S$1 million for a permanent space and education programs. The funds will also support cat adoption and responsible cat parenthood initiatives. Supporters can donate at gogetfunding.com/savethecatmuseum.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang
The Cat Museum.

site_title: Europe: M&A, banks brighten lacklustre European stock markets
summary: European stocks fell 0.5% on Thursday, weighed down by commodities and technology stocks, despite merger and acquisition activity driving gains for companies like TDC and Swiss Re. Financials, however, limited the damage, with euro zone banks rising 0.4% after strong earnings. Valuations of the Stoxx 600 have fallen back below their one-year average, but Credit Suisse's Pierre Bose says it's "much closer to fair value."

site_title: B Capital raises US$360m to invest in tech-enabled small businesses
summary: B Capital Group, a global venture capital firm co-founded by Facebook co-founder Eduardo Saverin, has raised $360 million to invest in tech-enabled small businesses with a "global-first" mindset. The firm aims to invest in financial services, healthcare, industrial logistics, and consumer enablement, with portfolio companies including Mswipe Technologies and Ninja Van. B Capital's vision is to help bridge the gap between innovative entrepreneurs and corporations seeking to innovate and partner with emerging technologies. The firm expects to invest up to $20 million in each portfolio company and believes that "tech enablement" of the world has a long runway.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

From left: B Capital partners Gavin Teo, Kabir Narang and Eduardo Saverin. Mr Saverin says there is tremendous growth potential in Asia for "technology-enabled'' financial services, healthcare, industrial logistics and consumer enablement.

site_title: DBS to end 'dirty coal' lending, but resists all-out ban
summary: DBS, Singapore's most valuable bank, will end financing of "dirty coal" projects by year-end, but will continue to finance projects with higher quality coal. The bank's CEO, Piyush Gupta, stated that coal remains a significant source of energy in the region and will still account for 40% of the generation mix by 2040. DBS will start building a portfolio of renewable energy projects to shift its loans. The bank has financed over $2.29 billion in coal projects since 2012, with some of these deals in Indonesia and Vietnam.

site_title: SingPass, CorpPass disruption due to 'server fault', not cyber attacks; lasted six hours
summary: SingPass and CorpPass, Singapore's national authentication services, experienced a six-hour disruption on Feb 8 due to a "server fault", not a cyber attack. The outage lasted from 11am to 5:15pm, causing inconvenience to users trying to access e-government services. The GovTech agency behind the services apologized for the disruption and stated that the system has been fully restored. The cause was attributed to a technical glitch, not a cyber attack, and users were informed of the issue through website messages.

site_title: Ezion Holdings requests for time extension for release of FY2017 financial statements
summary: EZION Holdings has requested a 30-day extension for the release of its FY2017 financial statements, from March 1 to March 31, 2018. The company is finalizing a refinancing exercise to strengthen its cash flow and working capital position. It is in discussions with bank lenders and holders of securities regarding its US$1.5 billion Multicurrency Debt Issuance Programme, which is expected to address anticipated cash flow challenges. The outcome of the refinancing exercise is expected to be clear after the expected Extraordinary General Meeting (EGM) in March 2018.

site_title: Oil falls to 2018 low as US output soars, North Sea supply restarts
summary: Oil prices dropped to a 2018 low after US crude output reached record highs and the North Sea's largest crude pipeline reopened. Brent crude futures fell 29 cents to $65.22 a barrel, while US futures eased 2 cents to $61.77 a barrel. The US Energy Information Administration raised its 2018 average output forecast to 10.59 million barrels per day, surpassing Saudi Arabia. Analysts say the high prices in late January were unsustainable due to the sharp rise in US oil production, which could lead to renewed oversupply if OPEC does not adjust its market share.

site_title: SIA Engineering and Stratasys sign JV agreement to establish additive manufacturing service centre for commercial aviation
summary: SIA Engineering and Stratasys have signed a joint venture agreement to establish an additive manufacturing service centre for commercial aviation, with SIAEC holding a 60% equity stake. The centre will offer 3D printed parts for airlines, MRO providers, and OEMs, leveraging on additive manufacturing technology to produce plastic aircraft cabin interior parts and tooling for MRO providers. The joint venture aims to tap into growing demand for additive manufacturing services in the aerospace industry.

site_title: It may be time to end summer time, European Assembly says
summary: The European Parliament urges the European Commission to re-evaluate daylight-saving time due to potential benefits for human health, despite its benefits to the transport industry and outdoor leisure activities. A thorough assessment is recommended, with the goal of maintaining a unified time regime even after any end to daylight-saving time. The European Commission has expressed non-committal views, and any proposal to amend the law would require approval from EU national governments and the Parliament, a process that can take over a year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.76 points to 1,839.44. Volume reached 2.1 billion lots worth RM2.1 billion, with 577 gainers outnumbering 365 losers. The gains come despite global market uncertainty, with US stocks nearing fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Kingsmen Creatives' US-based subsidiary to partner with Hasbro to open NERF brand family entertainment centres in APAC
summary: Kingsmen Creatives' US-based subsidiary, Kingsmen Xperience, has entered into a licensing agreement with Hasbro International to create and operate NERF brand family entertainment centers across the Asia-Pacific region. The first location is expected to open by 2019 in Singapore, marking the company's entry into the development and operation of location-based entertainment. This new concept attraction expands Kingsmen's business portfolio, offering unique experiences to customers.

site_title: Creative Technology posts Q2 net loss of US$4.2m, easing from a year ago
summary: Creative Technology reported a net loss of US$4.2 million for its second quarter, easing from a US$6.5 million loss in the same period last year. The company's turnover decreased 6% to US$20.9 million due to uncertain market conditions. Loss per share was US$0.06, compared to US$0.09 previously. The company expects no significant change in market conditions and an operating loss in the upcoming quarter.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 dip amid volatility in US stocks
summary: US stocks declined early Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.4% to 24,795.98, and the S&P 500 shedding 0.2% to 2,676.46. Despite strong earnings from Twitter, which surged 25.8% after reporting its first profit, markets struggled to shake off volatility. Analysts attributed the market's lack of conviction to its recent behavior. The Nasdaq Composite Index edged up less than 0.1% to 7,054.61.

site_title: BMW X2 review: Dressed for success
summary: The BMW X2 is a stylish and practical crossover that blends sporty and utility features. Based on the X1, the X2 boasts a unique design with a broad and low-slung front, slim windows, and a flowing roofline. The car is spacious, with a generous boot and foldable rear seats. The X2 is also praised for its agile handling and composure around corners, thanks to its sporty suspension setup. The sDrive20i model, set to launch in April, is expected to be a hit, with a price under S$200,000. The X2 is part of BMW's successful X car lineup, which has seen a 9.7% sales growth last year.

site_title: Twitter posts first real profit, sending shares soaring
summary: Twitter Inc. reported its first-ever profit in the fourth quarter, surpassing analyst estimates with a 2% revenue increase to $731.6 million. The company's shares surged 15% in early trading after closing at $26.91. Twitter's focus on video and improved software algorithm have led to increased user engagement, with daily active users rising 12% from the prior year. The milestone marks a significant turnaround under CEO Jack Dorsey's efforts, with the company also suspending accounts linked to a Kremlin troll farm and verifying major party candidates for the 2018 midterm elections.

site_title: SunMoon Food in the red in Q3
summary: SunMoon Food Company reported a loss of S$1.25 million in the third quarter, down from a profit of S$5.3 million a year ago. Revenue jumped to S$10.8 million, driven by increased sales to Shanghai YiGuo E-Commerce. The company plans to focus on brand-building, marketing, and sourcing higher-value products to improve margins. Operating environment remains challenging, and no dividend was declared for the quarter.

site_title: Most Asia markets up but warning of further volatility
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday, with Tokyo and Hong Kong gaining 1.1% and 0.4% respectively, while Shanghai fell 1.4%. Despite a rebound on Wednesday, traders remain cautious due to volatility and warnings of further market upheaval. Central banks, particularly the Federal Reserve, are expected to lift borrowing costs, which has led to a rise in the US dollar against high-yielding currencies. Oil prices also fell due to increased US production, affecting energy firms.

site_title: Parkson Retail Asia deepens loss in Q3
summary: Parkson Retail Asia reported a net loss of S$3.1 million for Q3, deepening from S$2.2 million a year ago. Revenue increased 0.9% to S$112.1 million. The company closed three underperforming stores and expects challenging operating conditions in the second half due to subdued consumer sentiment and stiff competition. Festive buying during Lunar New Year and Hari Raya may provide some support, but uncertainties from Malaysia's General Election and Indonesia's local election may impact performance.

site_title: Frasers Property's Q1 profit falls 59%
summary: Frasers Property's Q1 profit plummeted 59% to S$76.9 million due to falling revenue and exceptional items. This marks a significant drop from S$187.5 million in the same period last year. The company's recurring income sources accounted for 78% of operating profit, up from 53% previously. Earnings per share also declined, standing at 2.63 Singapore cents, down from 6.45 Singapore cents a year ago. The company formally changed its name to Frasers Property following shareholders' approval.

site_title: Hot stock: DBS up 5% on surprise dividend jump
summary: DBS Group Holdings rose 5% after announcing a surprise dividend jump, with the stock reaching S$26.72 per share. The bank will pay S$1.20 per share in dividends from 2018 onwards, doubling its payout in three of the past four years. DBS also proposed a final dividend of 60 Singapore cents per share for 2017 and a special dividend of 50 Singapore cents per share to mark its 50th anniversary, with record earnings of S$1.19 billion for the fourth quarter.

site_title: Walmart makes push to sell online goods at US$10 and up to capture elusive e-commerce profit
summary: Walmart is shifting its online business strategy to focus on higher-priced merchandise, aiming to increase profit margins. The retailer is asking vendors to supply products priced at $10 and up, such as dry grocery items and home furnishings. This move aims to offset the costs of online delivery and potentially turn a profit in the e-commerce segment.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end higher after five-day sell-off
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended Thursday with a 0.42% gain, snapping a five-day sell-off that had erased around 8% from the Hang Seng Index. The benchmark index closed at 30,451.27. Despite the gain, traders remain cautious due to volatility across world markets.

site_title: US, Israeli drone makers keep wary eye on rising Chinese
summary: US and Israeli drone manufacturers are monitoring the rise of cheaper Chinese military drones, which are gaining traction in smaller countries in Africa, the Middle East, and Central Asia. Chinese drones, such as the Wing Loong, are priced lower than US and Israeli systems, making them attractive to less affluent militaries. Despite concerns over reliability and safety, Chinese companies are adapting quickly and have already secured a large overseas order. Analysts predict that countries like Sri Lanka, Kazakhstan, and the Philippines may consider Chinese drones, while US and Israeli manufacturers remain competitive due to their years of experience and proven track record.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rebound after 4 days of losses, won weaker
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 11.06 points or 0.46% to 2,407.62, snapping a four-day losing streak. The Kosdaq 150 jumped nearly 6% and triggered a circuit breaker. The won edged down 0.12% to 1,087.9 per US dollar, while bond yields rose. The Kospi is down around 2.9% so far this year, but foreign investors were net buyers of 92.55 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: Australia tourism industry under climate change threat: study
summary: Australia's multi-billion dollar tourism industry is under threat from climate change, with rising temperatures and sea levels posing a risk to top natural wonders such as beaches, national parks, and the Great Barrier Reef. The Climate Council report urges the government to reduce carbon emissions to mitigate this impact. Tourism is Australia's second-largest export industry, valued at A$40 billion and employing 580,000 people. The study highlights the need for urgent action to protect the country's natural attractions and economy.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: DBS Group Holdings will pay a double dividend of S$1.20 per share starting from FY18. Singapore household incomes rose in 2017, but at a slower pace for the lower half compared to the wealthier half. HDB resale prices dropped 0.5% in January, and Singtel's results were in line with expectations, with analysts upgrading RHB's stock to 'buy'. Sakae Holdings and MC Payment inked a deal to launch a food and beverage digital token, while Singapore Airlines will operate its first B787-10 aircraft to Osaka from May. DBS plans to end 'dirty coal' lending by year-end.

site_title: Wynn Macau shares jump 8% in Hong Kong after founder resigns
summary: Wynn Macau shares surged 8% in Hong Kong after founder Steve Wynn stepped down as chairman and CEO following allegations of sexual misconduct. Trading was suspended before the announcement, and shares rose to HK$27.00. Wynn's resignation may ease pressure on the casino's licence renewal in 2022, which is up for renewal. Analysts believe the departure may alleviate scrutiny, as Macau's regulator emphasizes suitability of key persons in casino operators.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets resume slide
summary: European stock markets slid at the start of trading, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.8% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 down 0.7%. The decline follows a 2.5% slump on Tuesday, with markets ending Wednesday's sessions with gains of 1.5-2.0%. Investors are watching the Bank of England's interest rate decision and UK growth forecasts.

site_title: China coke futures hold near 7-week top on upbeat outlook
summary: Chinese coke futures rose for a sixth consecutive session, trading near a seven-week high, due to optimism that steel mills will replenish stockpiles after the Lunar New Year holiday. The most-actively traded coke contract closed up 0.4% at 2,147 yuan (S$450) a tonne. This follows a surge in iron ore imports, which reached 100 million tonnes in January, the second highest level on record, as steel mills built inventories before the holiday. The move aims to meet China's target to reduce steel production capacity two years earlier than planned.

site_title: China's yuan plunges most since aftermath of devaluation in 2015
summary: China's yuan plunged 0.7% to 6.3375 against the US dollar, its largest decline since 2015, amid trade figures missing estimates and speculation of policy makers stepping up to curb the currency's gains. The onshore spot rate dropped as much as one percent earlier, with volatility surging and the gap between onshore and offshore rates tripling. The yuan's recent climb to a two-year high fueled speculation that officials may seek to rein in the currency's appreciation.

site_title: Singapore household incomes rise in 2017, but at faster pace for top 50%
summary: Singapore's household incomes rose in 2017, with the lower half experiencing slower growth compared to the top 50%. Despite this, income inequality remained largely unchanged due to government transfers and taxes. Wage growth was muted, and the labour market improved amid an economic upturn.

site_title: Bank of England's forecast horizon increasingly clouded
summary: The Bank of England's forecast horizon is becoming increasingly clouded due to Brexit uncertainty. The central bank will release its economic forecast on Thursday, but two-thirds of the forecast period will be after the UK's exit from the European Union. The lack of clarity on the UK's future trading relationship makes it challenging for the Bank to predict the economy's performance over the next three years. Governor Mark Carney will face questions on the topic from journalists, highlighting the difficulties in predicting the UK's economic future.

site_title: Sakae, MC Payment ink MOU, aim to launch South-east Asia's F&B digital token
summary: Sakae Holdings' subsidiary, Sakae Fintech, has signed an MOU with MC Payment to develop a custom blockchain for "Bitecoin," a food and beverage digital token for the South-east Asia market. The decentralised token aims to provide secure peer-to-peer transactions between consumers and merchants, reducing time delays and costs. The use of Bitecoin will also allow merchants to gain insights into consumer demographics and preferences, enabling targeted marketing. The project is expected to improve efficiency, enhance convenience, and experience for both consumers and merchants.

site_title: The mysterious tale of the couple who keep receiving free items from Amazon - and want it to stop
summary: A couple in Massachusetts, Kelly and Mike Gallivan, have been receiving over 20 free packages from Amazon, all addressed to Mike, with no indication of who sent them or why. The packages contain a variety of gadgets, including phone chargers, flashlights, and a humidifier, with no invoices or receipts. The couple fears their names may be connected to a scam and is uncomfortable with the mysterious deliveries. Amazon has stated it is investigating the issue and removing sellers who violate its policies, but the couple has yet to receive a response.

site_title: Toyota bets on future of taxis with ride-hailing app investment
summary: Toyota is investing an additional 7.5 billion yen ($91.1 million) in Japan Taxi, a cab-hailing app, to collaborate on data collection and connected taxi terminals. This investment aims to redefine Toyota as a mobility services provider, with President Akio Toyoda seeking to capitalize on the shift towards connected, autonomous, and electrified vehicles. The partnership will utilize cloud computing and data to disrupt the taxi industry and create new revenue opportunities. Toyota's move follows growing competition from ride-hailing services, with the company aiming to play a bigger role in defining the future of connected mobility.

site_title: Doping hangs over Olympics before they even begin
summary: The Pyeongchang Olympics face scrutiny over doping allegations, with more than 50 cross-country skiers set to compete under a neutral flag after their country was banned for a state-sponsored doping system. Recent Winter Games have revealed grounds for skepticism, including a 2006 Turin Games incident and a 2014 Sochi Games scandal involving Russian officials and athletes. World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) president Craig Reedie has assured athletes of a fair and honest competition, but experts warn of "micro-doses" of endurance boosters and anabolic steroid use.

site_title: Nissan slashes profit forecasts after inspection scandal
summary: Nissan slashed its full-year operating profit forecast to 565 billion yen, a 12.4% drop from the previous estimate, due to the impact of a damaging inspection scandal. The scandal, which involved staff conducting final inspections on vehicles without proper authorization, led to a recall of 1.2 million vehicles and a significant decline in passenger car sales in Japan. The company's CEO, Hiroto Saikawa, is voluntarily returning his pay, and Nissan is implementing measures to cope with the situation. The company expects to normalize operations by the end of the fiscal year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end higher on bargain-buying
summary: Tokyo stocks ended higher on Thursday, supported by bargain-hunters, after wild price swings over the past two days. The Nikkei index rose 1.13% to 21,890.96, and the Topix index gained 0.90% to 1,765.69. The dollar strengthened to 109.61 yen in Asian trade.

site_title: Why Google's bosses became 'unpumped' about Uber
summary: Uber's former CEO Travis Kalanick testified that Google's top lawyer and Alphabet's CEO Larry Page became "unpumped" about Uber due to a rivalry in developing autonomous vehicles. The two companies had a "big brother, little brother" relationship, but it deteriorated after Uber acquired Otto, a startup founded by a former Google engineer. Google alleged that Uber stole trade secrets, while Kalanick claimed that Google was concerned about Uber's self-driving car technology. The rivalry led to a breakdown in their partnership, with Kalanick stating that Google was "super not happy" about Uber's actions.

site_title: Real estate ITM aimed at improving efficiencies, not replace jobs: Tan Chuan-Jin
summary: Singaporean Speaker of Parliament Tan Chuan-Jin stated that the Real Estate Industry Transformation Map (ITM) aims to improve efficiency, not replace jobs. He emphasized that the government's objective is to make property transactions more pain-free, benefiting all Singaporeans. Tan encouraged real estate agents to upgrade their skills, moving from tour-guide roles to advising on property purchases, rather than fearing job replacement by technology.

site_title: US dollar will stay weak if China has its way: Morgan Stanley
summary: Morgan Stanley predicts the US dollar will remain weak due to China's strong yuan, which is boosting consumption and attracting foreign investment. China's embracing of a stronger yuan is seen as a strategic move to support its economy, while also having a "messaging function" that signals advantages in a weak US dollar. This could lead to a prolonged period of dollar weakness, with Morgan Stanley citing the yuan's resilience as a key factor.

site_title: Brazilian fashion models seek Chinese success
summary: Brazilian fashion model Sandra Passos, known as "Brazil's Cinderella," aims to introduce a more Brazilian sense of beauty to China's rapidly growing fashion market. Passos, who overcame a difficult childhood to build a career as a model in China, now runs a modeling agency and teaches young Brazilian women the basics of modeling and English. She hopes to take some of her students to Guangzhou, China, to showcase diverse models, including non-whites and plus-sizes, in a market where such models are still rare.

site_title: Gold hits 4-week low on firmer US dollar amid US rate hike views
summary: Gold prices fell to a four-week low of $1,312.41 per ounce amid a firmer US dollar and expectations of US rate hikes this year. Investors liquidated long positions, and spot gold dropped 0.4% for a third consecutive session. The US dollar rose, marking its biggest one-day gain in over three months, and Treasury yields jumped, dampening demand for non-yielding gold.

site_title: Bangkok air pollution warning, children asked to stay indoors
summary: Bangkok's air quality has reached "dangerous levels" prompting residents to stay indoors, particularly children, due to severe smog and respiratory issues. The Air Quality Index (AQI) has been affected by pollutants such as PM2.5, carbon monoxide, and nitrogen dioxide. This is the latest in a series of air pollution concerns in the Thai capital, with some schools already closed or keeping children indoors.

site_title: Manhattan tenants get big breaks as rents fall most since 2011
summary: Manhattan tenants are securing significant rent reductions, with concessions reaching a record 49% of newly signed leases in January, surpassing the previous peak of 36%. This trend is driven by a surplus of new supply and renters' growing bargaining power. Landlords are responding with rent-free months, gift cards, and price reductions, indicating a shift in the market balance.

site_title: China's private funds face staff exodus, business scramble as rules bite
summary: China's private fund managers are facing an employee exodus and business struggles due to Beijing's crackdown on leverage and financial risk. The regulations, which limit permitted leverage to 200% and ban implicit guarantees, have led to a rush of fund closures and a decline in assets. The industry's growth has slowed, with some funds experiencing a 15% decline in assets last year. Analysts see the crackdown as necessary to clean up the industry, but some are struggling to adapt, with employees opting for jobs at mutual funds and wholly foreign-owned enterprises.

site_title: Asia: Traders battle to recover as volatility hits world markets
summary: Asian markets struggled to recover on Thursday, amid concerns over rising borrowing costs and uncertainty from central banks. The recent surge in global markets, driven by cheap money and economic optimism, ended with the US jobs and wage growth data, sending Wall Street and world markets tumbling. Traders are navigating turbulent waters as the Federal Reserve is expected to lift borrowing costs, further spooking investors.

site_title: JTC rolls out S$15m 'smart' facilities management solutions across 39 properties
summary: JTC has rolled out a S$15 million "smart" facilities management (FM) solutions across 39 properties, aiming to curb rising costs and improve service levels. The initiative is driven by JTC's growing portfolio, manpower constraints, and the need to manage aging assets. The "smart" FM systems are housed in the J-Ops Command Centre, launched by Second Minister Desmond Lee. This move is part of JTC's efforts to optimize its operations and maintain high service standards.

site_title: Australia shares end higher after NAB earnings; NZ slips
summary: Australian shares rose 0.24% to close at 5,890.700, led by a 2.3% gain in National Australia Bank Ltd's shares, its largest percentage gain in nearly seven months. The S&P/ASX 200 benchmark added 0.8% on Wednesday. Meanwhile, New Zealand shares slipped.

site_title: DBS to end 'dirty coal' lending by year-end, says its chief
summary: DBS Bank's CEO, Piyush Gupta, announced the bank will end financing of projects burning "dirty coal" by the end of the year. However, it will continue to finance higher-quality coal projects in emerging markets and invest in renewable energy. Gupta cited the importance of coal's role in energy needs, particularly in Asia, where it will still account for 40% of generation mix by 2040. DBS has committed to these low-grade coal deals, but plans to transition to greener projects.

site_title: Record profit for Geely's Volvo in 2017 as China boosts sales
summary: Volvo Car Group, owned by Geely, reported a 28% increase in operating earnings to a record high of 14.1 billion Swedish crowns ($2.3 billion) in 2017, driven by strong demand for new models, particularly in China. The company also achieved its fourth consecutive year of record sales, with revenues rising 17% to 210.9 billion crowns. The revamped model line-up helped Volvo compete with larger rivals like Mercedes-Benz.

site_title: Brits too busy to shop are a boost for UK convenience stocks
summary: British consumers are increasingly opting for convenience stores due to their busy lifestyles, visiting stores more frequently to purchase fewer items. This shift is driven by a desire for time rather than price, according to Trevor Green, head of UK equities at Aviva Investors. As a result, convenience stocks are seeing a boost.

site_title: Alibaba to take US$486m stake in China retail data firm
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd has invested US$486 million for a 38% stake in Shiji Retail Information Technology Co, a domestic big-data firm focused on hotels and retail. This deal is part of Alibaba's push to deepen its offline presence through its "new retail" strategy, leveraging big data to shake up China's retail market. This investment follows Alibaba's over US$10 billion investments into brick-and-mortar outlets to compete with rival Tencent Holdings Ltd.

site_title: Swiss Re in talks to sell stake to SoftBank; deal said worth US$10b
summary: Swiss Re, the world's second-largest reinsurer, is in preliminary talks with SoftBank Group to sell a minority stake worth up to $10 billion. The deal would be SoftBank's largest financial services investment and would allow the Japanese firm to offer Swiss Re's insurance products to users of its invested companies, such as Uber and WeWork. The sale would also provide SoftBank with a source of cheap funding. The talks come as SoftBank aims to build a group of industry-leading companies that can endure for 300 years, with a focus on technological advancements.

site_title: China trade machine sparks back to life in January; imports, exports beat forecasts
summary: China's trade machine showed a significant rebound in January, with exports rising 11.1% and imports growing 36.9% year-over-year, exceeding forecasts. This strong start to the year is a welcome relief for policymakers, who have expressed concerns about slowing GDP growth. The robust trade data may also boost investor confidence, as Citigroup has set a target of 1,150 for the MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026.

site_title: ARM embraces tech revolution under SoftBank and loses money
summary: ARM Holdings Plc, a 27-year-old UK chip company, has rapidly expanded under SoftBank ownership, posting a loss of $200 million for the nine months to December 31, despite $1.4 billion in net sales. The company's aggressive growth at the expense of profits is unusual for a tech startup, but its conservative past is no longer the case. This shift raises questions about the company's long-term financial sustainability. SoftBank's investment in ARM is expected to continue, despite the company's current financial struggles.

site_title: Hermes sales growth slows in Q4, but margins to hit record in 2017
summary: Hermes reported a 5% sales growth in Q4 at constant currencies, slightly below market expectations of 6%. The slowdown was attributed to tougher year-ago comparisons in its silk division and low stock levels of handbags following high demand in 2017. Despite this, the company expects to hit record margins in 2017.

site_title: Singapore Airshow 2018: ST Aerospace unit inks LOI for potential A320 P2F conversion order
summary: ST Aerospace's joint venture ELBE Flugzeugwerke (EFW) has signed a letter of intent (LOI) with Guangdong Aerocity Holding Co for a potential order of 10 A320 Passenger-to-Freighter (P2F) conversions. This comes after EFW secured a launch contract for 10 A321 P2F conversions at the Singapore Airshow. The A320/A321 P2F conversion programmes offer a main deck and lower deck containerised loading solution ideal for express domestic and regional operations. A firm order is expected to be secured before the end of the year.

site_title: Singapore shares enter afternoon session on Thursday flat; STI at 3,383.03
summary: Singapore shares entered the afternoon session flat on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index down 0.74 point to 3,383.03. About 981 million shares worth S$1.17 billion changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 224 to 142. This follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with investors staying positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Ademco partners IE Singapore to buy Vietnam security firm, aims to grow overseas revenue
summary: Ademco Security Group, a security solutions provider, has partnered with IE Singapore to acquire 60% of Vietnam-based TNT Technologies Joint Stock Company. The deal aims to boost Ademco's overseas revenue by 50% over three years. Established in 2005, TNT provides security solutions to clients in various sectors, including aviation and retail. With this acquisition, Ademco will expand its presence in Vietnam and tap into TNT's expertise, building reach through its MNC client base and strengthening operational efficiencies. The deal marks Ademco's seventh addition to its geographical footprint across Asia.

site_title: Suntec City to launch Alipay payment option to attract more Chinese tourists
summary: Suntec City and Alipay have partnered to introduce Alipay payment terminals at the mall, aiming to attract more Chinese tourists. Approximately 350 shops will offer Alipay as a payment option, covering 60% of stores by July 2018. This move follows Alibaba's acquisition of a 33% stake in Ant Financial, the parent company of Alipay. The partnership is expected to enhance the shopping experience for Chinese tourists in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Singapore Airshow 2018: Honda Aircraft announces largest single order to date of 16 HondaJets
summary: Honda Aircraft announced its largest single order to date, worth up to $80 million, for 16 five-passenger HondaJets to European air taxi company Wijet. The deal will replace Wijet's current fleet of 15 Cessna aircraft over the next 18 months, marking a milestone for the relative newcomer to the business jet market.

site_title: Watchdog failing to guarantee responsibly sourced jewellery: campaign group
summary: A campaign group by Human Rights Watch found the Responsible Jewellery Council (RJC) to be failing to guarantee responsibly sourced gold and diamonds by its members. The RJC, a standards and certification body, offers only a "weak assurance" that responsible sourcing standards are being met, stating that membership does not guarantee that a company's jewellery is responsibly sourced.

site_title: How the entry of Chinese tech giants is transforming Asean's e-commerce scene
summary: Chinese tech giants such as Alibaba, JD.com, and Tencent have invested heavily in Asean's e-commerce scene, bringing capital and know-how to the region. This influx is expected to intensify competition and ease constraints on logistics and e-payment adoption, transforming the Asean e-commerce market. Despite rapid expansion over the past five years, e-commerce penetration remains less than 2% of total retail sales in Asean, with the region's lack of efficient logistics and fulfilment holding back growth.

site_title: Seven injured in Australia hot air balloon crash
summary: A hot air balloon crash in Australia's Dixons Creek injured 7 people, with 16 being assessed by paramedics. The balloon, operated by Go Wild Ballooning, landed heavily due to strong winds, with some passengers thrown from the basket. All 7 injured were taken to hospital with back injuries and fractures, and their conditions were reported as stable. The incident occurred during a dawn tour, with the pilot experiencing an unexpected wind change.

site_title: Spring Singapore arm appoints private sector partners to co-invest over S$200m in deep-tech startups
summary: The investment arm of Spring Singapore, Spring Seeds Capital, has appointed nine private sector partners to co-invest over S$200 million in deep-tech startups over the next eight years. The partners will match SSC's S$100 million commitment, bringing the total investment to over S$300 million. The new partners will focus on sectors such as advanced manufacturing, health, and urban solutions, with the goal of supporting high-potential startups and accelerating their entry into the global market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.52 points to 1,838.20. Gainers outnumbered losers 107 to 43, and volume was 31.25 million lots worth RM11.73 million.

site_title: Australia shares down on losses in materials; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% to 5,866.70, weighed down by losses in material stocks, including BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto, amid rising US Treasury yields and global interest rates. Financials rose, however, driven by strong earnings from wealth managers AMP and National Australia Bank. In New Zealand, the benchmark index remained flat, with healthcare sector gains offsetting losses in telecommunication and consumer staples.

site_title: Pelosi gives longest US House speech in more than a century
summary: US House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi delivered the longest address to the chamber in over 108 years, speaking for 8 hours and 7 minutes to protect young undocumented migrants from deportation. The speech, which lasted a full day, broke the record held by former Congressman Champ Clark since at least 1909. Pelosi opposed a compromise federal budget deal that did not address immigration, calling for immigration legislation to be brought to the floor for a vote.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up at open after run of losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.77% at the open, adding 232.60 points to 30,555.80, following a volatile three-day period that saw the Hang Seng Index decline 6%. This comes as Asian markets recovered from losses, with the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also showing gains. The gains come despite ongoing US-China trade tensions and uncertainty surrounding the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday; STI up 32.71 points to 3,416.48
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index rising 32.71 points to 3,416.48. About 72 million shares changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 81 to 40. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.08% on Wall Street, while regional markets saw mixed results. The rally follows a 0.4% gain on Wednesday, with investors staying positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Singtel Q3 profit down 8.5% to S$890m on lower contributions from units
summary: Singtel's Q3 net profit fell 8.5% to S$890m due to voice revenue declines and lower contributions from regional associates Airtel, Telkomsel, and Globe. The decline was also attributed to higher net finance expenses. Despite this, operating revenue was up 4% to S$4.6 billion, driven by strong contributions from core and digital businesses. Singtel's shares fell 1.16% after the announcement.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Singapore Airshow 2018: CAAS to provide aviation training in Macedonia and Rwanda
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) has signed agreements with Macedonia and Rwanda to provide aviation training in the two countries. The agreements, signed at the Singapore Airshow, aim to support the International Civil Aviation Organization's 'No Country Left Behind' initiative. CAAS will develop and conduct training programs to enhance aviation development in Macedonia and Rwanda, focusing on safety, navigation, and security. This move is seen as a significant step in advancing civil aviation internationally and sharing knowledge and skills with partner countries.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: US senators propose bill to block US from using Huawei, ZTE equipment
summary: US Senators Tom Cotton and Marco Rubio introduced a bill to block the US government from buying or leasing telecommunications equipment from Huawei Technologies Co Ltd or ZTE Corp, citing concerns over potential spying by Chinese companies. The legislation comes amid a harder line on policies initiated by President Trump, following previous actions against Chinese companies over national security concerns. The bill is similar to one introduced in the House and is seen as a response to China's rapid development and the US commitment to market economics.

site_title: Harley-Davidson recalls 175,000 bikes on brake safety fears
summary: Harley-Davidson is recalling approximately 175,000 US motorcycles from 2008 to 2011 model years due to brake safety concerns. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) warns that brake fluid deposits can form if not replaced within two years, reducing braking ability and increasing crash risk. Owners will receive a free brake fluid flush notification starting February 12, with dealerships offering the service. The recall follows a 2016 investigation into complaints of sudden brake loss.

site_title: Changi Airport's new Terminal 4 handled over 1.6m passengers, 9,400 flights since opening
summary: Changi Airport's Terminal 4, which opened on Oct 31, 2018, has handled over 1.6 million passengers and 9,400 flights since its operational start. The terminal now serves 11 airlines with 21 regional destinations. New airlines JC (Cambodia) International Airlines and VietJet Air, which will operate 28 weekly services, have increased the terminal's capacity. The airport expects over 8.3 million passengers per annum at T4.

site_title: China Yuanbang warns of Q2, H1 loss on higher costs
summary: China Yuanbang Property Holdings expects to report a loss for its second quarter and half year ended Dec 31, 2017, due to higher labor and materials costs and increased commissions for sales agents. The company reported a net loss of 11 million Chinese yuan in the first quarter of 2018. The loss is attributed to the need to accelerate pre-sales of residential projects in Guangzhou City. China Yuanbang expects to report its results on or before Feb 14.

site_title: Former Uber chief Kalanick denies plot to steal secrets in tense courtroom exchange
summary: Former Uber CEO Travis Kalanick denied conspiring to steal autonomous driving technology in a tense courtroom appearance, contradicting earlier evidence that showed he asked a key engineer to bring Google secrets to Uber. Kalanick claimed he didn't request proprietary data and was unaware of the engineer's actions, but acknowledged hiring the engineer to lead Uber's self-driving car technology efforts. The trial, pitting Uber against Waymo, could determine the outcome of a potential $1 billion lawsuit over allegedly stolen trade secrets.

site_title: Gold slips as stronger dollar pushes metals liquidation
summary: The US dollar strengthened, pushing gold prices down 0.9% to $1,313.67 per ounce, as investors liquidated gold and other precious metals. Despite rate hike expectations, analysts believe the dollar's bear run remains, supporting gold prices above $1,300. Platinum briefly moved into a premium over palladium, while silver fell 1.7%. The stronger dollar makes gold costlier for non-US investors, but analysts expect gold to remain above $1,300 in the next few months.

site_title: Aftershocks rattle Taiwan as quake toll rises to nine, 62 missing
summary: A powerful earthquake struck Taiwan's Hualien city, killing at least 9 people and injuring 265. A 6.4-magnitude quake on Tuesday and aftershocks on Thursday hindered rescue efforts. Four buildings collapsed, and 62 people remain missing, including those trapped in a 12-storey residential building. The city's infrastructure was severely damaged, with large cracks along major roads. Taiwan is prone to earthquakes due to its location near the junction of two tectonic plates.

site_title: HDB resale prices dip 0.5% in January, volume slumps by 31.4%: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore dipped 0.5% in January, with prices of three-room and five-room flats declining 2.3% and 1.2% respectively. Sales volume also dropped 31.4% compared to December 2017, with 1,089 flats sold in January. Median Transaction Over X-Value (TOX) was negative, indicating buyers were overpaying, with Kallang/Whampoa and Geylang posting the highest median TOX of $17,000.

site_title: DBS will pay annual dividend of S$1.20 per share from FY18
summary: DBS Group Holdings will pay an annual dividend of S$1.20 per share from FY18, doubling its payout in three of the past four years. The bank reported a record high of S$1.19 billion in earnings for the fourth quarter, up 31% from the previous year. DBS's total income grew 10% to S$3.06 billion, driven by higher Singapore-dollar interest rates and record fee income. The bank's net interest income rose 15% to S$2.1 billion.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, following a decline in US stocks amid wild price swings. The Nikkei index rose 0.38% to 21,726.61, while the Topix index increased 0.51%. This follows a 5% fall on Tuesday and a 0.16% rebound on Wednesday. The market rally comes despite uncertainty over US trade policies, with investors remaining positive and awaiting GDP data from Singapore.

site_title: BOJ's Suzuki advocates continued easing despite rising cost
summary: Bank of Japan board member Hitoshi Suzuki advocates for continued easing despite rising costs, citing the need to hit the central bank's elusive 2% inflation target. Suzuki warns of the risk that recent share-market plunges could cloud Japan's recovery prospects and notes the need to closely watch US and European central banks' policy moves. He also expresses concern over the rising cost of massive stimulus, which could hurt financial institutions' profits and discourage lending. Suzuki's remarks suggest the BOJ may delay exiting crisis-mode stimulus, as inflation remains distant from the target.

site_title: Perennial Q4 profit up 7.9% to S$27.6m
summary: Perennial Real Estate reported a 7.9% increase in fourth-quarter net profit to S$27.6 million, driven by net fair value gains on revalued investment properties. Revenue fell 25.7% to S$16 million due to the absence of TripleOne Somerset revenue. The group retains a 30% stake in the mall and reported S$3.3 million in revenue from Singapore assets and S$9.3 million from operational assets in China. A proposed dividend of one Singapore cent is expected, with a books closure date of May 4, 2018.

site_title: First Sponsor Q4 profit falls 41.5% in absence of one-off gain; announces rights, bonus issues
summary: First Sponsor Group reported a 41.5% drop in Q4 earnings to S$42.7 million, despite a 660.3% increase in revenue to S$180.3 million. The decline was attributed to the absence of a one-off gain in 2016's Q4. The company announced a 1-for-4 rights issue and a 1-for-10 bonus issue to raise S$161.5 million, aiming to strengthen its balance sheet for expansion opportunities. Full-year net profit fell 21.9% to S$88.3 million.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific to buy adjoining property on Lorong Kismis
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings' subsidiary has entered into a put and call agreement to acquire a property in Singapore for S$5.7 million. The property, a 99-year tenure site with 9,473 sq ft, will be amalgamated with another development, Kismis View, for residential development. The combined site has an estimated land area of 100,336 sq ft. The acquisition is expected to be financed by internal funds and bank borrowings, with no material impact on the company's financial results for the current financial year.

site_title: SIA to operate its first B787-10 to Osaka from May
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will operate its first Boeing 787-10 to Osaka from May, marking a significant expansion of its network reach. The 337-seater aircraft features a two-class configuration with 36 seats in Business Class and 301 in Economy Class. SIA has 49 firm orders for 787-10s and 20 firm orders for 777-9s, with the latter set to enter service from FY2021/22. The introduction of the 787-10 is part of SIA's growth strategy to enhance the premium travel experience for customers.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: US dollar rebound fleeting; set to slip a bit more this year: poll
summary: The US dollar is expected to weaken slightly against most major currencies this year, according to a Reuters poll of nearly 70 foreign exchange analysts. The dollar index is forecast to end the year at 88.7, down from 89.9.
