Despite the Federal Reserve's expected interest rate hikes, the dollar's weakness is attributed to rising US wage inflation and expectations for the end of European Central Bank stimulus. Currency speculators have increased bets against the dollar, citing shifts in interest rate differentials and the lack of coherent dollar policy from the US administration.

site_title: Brokers' take: Singtel results in line with expectations; RHB upgrades stock to 'buy'
summary: Singtel's third-quarter results met expectations, with an 8.5% decline in net profit to S$890 million. Despite this, analysts RHB Research and DBS Group maintained their "buy" calls, citing the stock's low valuation and potential upside. The stock's ratio of forecast enterprise value to Ebitda is 5.3 times, below the five-year average. Analysts also highlighted the company's diversified regional exposure and attractive dividend yield. RHB Research upgraded its call to "buy" with a target price of S$4.10, while DBS Group maintained its target price at S$4.30.

site_title: Broker's Take: CIMB expects Venture to beat consensus on FY17 results, raises target price
summary: CIMB has raised its target price on Venture Corporation from S$24.74 to S$29.13, maintaining its "add" rating. The broker expects Venture to beat FY17 consensus forecasts, raising its net profit forecast by 5.1% to S$352.5 million. Venture's acquisition of a US property and plans to renovate it are seen as a positive sign. CIMB also expects Venture to pay a higher dividend per share, lending support to its optimistic earnings forecast. The target price represents a 30.7% upside to Venture's current share price.

site_title: Real estate ITM identifies property transactions services, facilities management for transformation
summary: The Singapore government has launched the Real Estate Industry Transformation Map (ITM) to future-proof the real estate sector by embracing innovation and technology. The ITM focuses on facilities management and property transaction services, aiming to raise professionalism and skills in these areas. The government plans to promote the adoption of Smart FM solutions, encourage consultants to design buildings with maintenance in mind, and streamline processes to boost productivity. The Council for Estate Agencies (CEA) is also working on making property transactions more efficient, with plans to share government data and develop digitalised contract templates.

site_title: Smart home unit Nest is spun back into Google
summary: Google is taking back Nest, the smart home unit it acquired in 2014 for $3.2 billion, to incorporate its artificial intelligence with Nest's hardware. The move aims to compete with Amazon's Alexa and other smart home devices. Google's senior vice-president, Rick Osterloh, said the goal is to create a "more thoughtful home" with Nest's smart home hardware and Google's AI. The combined effort will create a home that is "safer, friendlier to the environment, smarter and even helps you save money."

site_title: Flash: DBS Q4 profit up 31%
summary: DBS Vickers, a Singapore-based bank, reported a 31% increase in its quarterly profit to S$1.19 billion. The bank's total income grew 10% to S$3.06 billion, while it also halved its total allowances. This is the bank's highest quarterly profit on record.

site_title: New Zealand dollar at 1-month lows on dovish RBNZ, A$ struggles
summary: The New Zealand dollar dropped to a one-month low after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand cut inflation forecasts, signaling easy monetary policy. The local dollar fell to US$0.7209, while the Australian dollar also slid 1% to US$0.7820, a level not seen since early January. The dovish stance contrasts with other rich-world peers tightening monetary policy, and the Aussie has fallen in 8 out of 10 sessions.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, Singtel, Singhaiyi, Perennial, First Sponsor, RE&S, Neo Group, mm2 Asia
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean companies reported their quarterly earnings, with DBS reaching a record high of S$1.19 billion, up 31% from the previous year. Singtel's third-quarter net profit fell 9% to S$890 million, while Singhaiyi Group's net profit rose 12.8% to S$1.4 million. Perennial Real Estate's net profit increased 7.9% to S$27.6 million. Meanwhile, First Sponsor Group's earnings fell 41.5% to S$42.7 million, and RE&S Holdings posted a net profit of S$1.1 million for the second quarter. Other companies, such as Neo Group and mm2 Asia, also reported significant increases in their quarterly earnings.

site_title: SBI Offshore board receives shareholders' request to replace 3 directors
summary: SBI Offshore's board has received a request from shareholders carrying over 10% of the company's shares to hold an extraordinary general meeting to remove three directors, Ling Yew Kong, Lawrence Kwan, and James Kho Chung Wah, and appoint three new ones. Shareholders are requesting the appointment of Hui Choon Ho, Jen Shek Voon, and Percival Jeyapal s/o David to the board, citing their experience in the cyclical oil and gas industry. The company is verifying the shareholdings and seeking legal advice on the validity of the request.

site_title: North Korea has 'no intention' to meet US in South: KCNA
summary: North Korea's state media stated that the country has no intention to meet US officials during the Pyeongchang Winter Olympics in South Korea. However, US Vice-President Mike Pence is scheduled to attend the opening ceremony, potentially leading to a meeting with North Korea's ceremonial head of state, Kim Yong Nam. Pence has announced the US will impose its toughest sanctions to date on North Korea, amid Pyongyang's Olympics-linked publicity drive.

site_title: US announces takedown of global cyber theft ring
summary: The US Justice Department announced the takedown of a global cyber theft ring, known as the "Infraud Organization", with 36 indictments and 13 arrests in the US and internationally. The group, created in Ukraine in 2010, stole and sold credit card and personal identity data, causing $530 million in losses. Senior administrators, including Russian co-founder Sergey Medvedev, were arrested, but leader Svyatoslav Bondarenko remains at large. The group operated an online marketplace for cybercriminals, with over 10,900 registered members.

site_title: Euro drops on German finance minister news
summary: The euro dropped 0.4% against the dollar after German Finance Minister Martin Schulz was unlikely to take the position, despite speculation that he would be the next finance minister. This led to uncertainty over Germany's financial situation and spending plans. The euro's decline was partly offset by the dollar's drop against the yen, which was seen as undervalued. Investors remain cautious due to global economic concerns and the prospect of monetary tightening, with traditional safe havens such as the yen seeing modest gains.

site_title: New Zealand leaves base interest rate unchanged
summary: New Zealand's central bank left the official cash rate at a record low of 1.75% on February 7, 2018, citing improved global growth and a strong equity market. Governor Grant Spencer stated that monetary policy remains accommodative but is becoming less stimulatory. The base rate has remained unchanged since November 2017, with Spencer indicating it's unlikely to change soon. Global growth continues to improve, and New Zealand's GDP is expected to strengthen.

site_title: Samsung to begin investing in 2nd domestic memory chip line
summary: Samsung plans to invest in a second domestic memory chip line at its Pyeongtaek production facilities in South Korea, with the goal of meeting booming demand for semiconductors. The company aims to expand capacity by 2021 with a 30 trillion won investment. The second line is expected to be completed around 2020, potentially softening prices of memory chips. Analysts see this as a positive move, as other chipmakers are also boosting investments, which can lower prices.

site_title: Europe: Shares recover from seven-day losing streak
summary: European shares rose 2.1% on Wednesday, ending a seven-day losing streak, as investors took heart from a Wall Street recovery and reduced volatility. The Stoxx 600 index, a pan-European benchmark, marked its best gains since Emmanuel Macron's presidency in April. Despite a year-to-date decline of 2.2%, the index's volatility gauge fell 30% to 21.4. Strong earnings updates from companies like Hexagon and Statoil contributed to the gains, but analysts warned that further turbulence could occur due to inflation concerns.

site_title: Market tests millennial traders who've never seen a crash
summary: Millennial traders, born after 1981, are facing their first major market test as global stocks sink and central banks withdraw stimulus. Unlike their older counterparts, who lived through the 2008 financial crisis, millennials have only seen a prolonged period of low interest rates, inflation, and market stability. Many are taking a risk-averse approach, with some even questioning their readiness for a downturn. However, younger traders like Victor Massue, 28, are embracing humility and caution, recognizing that markets are inherently unpredictable and that survival is the primary goal.

site_title: US: Stocks end with losses as rally fades, Nasdaq down 0.9%
summary: US stocks ended lower on Wednesday, with the Nasdaq falling 0.9% to close at 7,051.98, amid concerns over higher interest rates and chaotic trading. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dipped 0.1% and the S&P 500 fell 0.5%. Analysts say worries about interest rates and computerized trading programs are driving the volatility, with some predicting a bottom in the market. Despite this, many analysts remain upbeat on the US economy and potential for further gains.

site_title: China supersizes pig farms to cut costs in world's top pork market
summary: China is rapidly modernizing its pig farms to boost production and cut costs, with over 10,000 sows expected to live in two massive barns by the end of the year. The shift towards automated, intensive hog barns is expected to increase pork production, improve food safety, and reduce environmental impact. However, concerns remain about the industry's ability to adapt to new standards, disease risks, and labor shortages. Experts predict a growing surplus of pork in the coming years, potentially making Chinese producers international competitors.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Dudley eyes risks of betting on volatility
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of New York President William Dudley expressed concerns about financial products that bet on market volatility, citing the 1987 stock market crash as a risk to market stability. Dudley urged regulators to monitor these products to ensure they are well-designed and appropriate. He also spoke about banking culture, stating that progress has been made but more can be done to improve investor and consumer confidence. Dudley praised the progress made by banks to improve company culture, but noted that there is still room for growth.

site_title: Why do women chefs keep missing out on Michelin stars?
summary: Women chefs continue to face a glass ceiling in the culinary world, with only 2.7% of Michelin-starred restaurants in France run by women. Despite efforts to increase representation, women remain a minority globally, holding less than 5% of Michelin stars. Factors such as ingrained stereotypes, a military atmosphere in kitchens, and a lack of media visibility contribute to the issue. Women chefs must often "act like a man" to succeed, and obstacles like sexual harassment, family pressures, and a lack of support can hinder their careers.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: CSC Holdings narrowed its net loss to S$2.1 million in Q3 FY2018, with revenue increasing 69.7% to S$94.9 million. mm2 Asia posted a net profit of S$6.4 million, up 52.9%, with revenue jumping to S$52.4 million. Meanwhile, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018 not expected to target property upswing
summary: The Singapore government is unlikely to target the property sector with measures in the 2018 budget, despite the real estate upswing. However, revenue-raising tax tweaks may still affect the sector, including possible increases in property tax rates for higher-value properties or non-owner-occupied properties. The government may also consider extending additional conveyance duties to non-residential properties. Experts note that any changes to property taxes could dampen market sentiment, but it is unlikely to have a significant impact on total tax revenues.

site_title: Oil hits one-month low on US crude stocks build, record output
summary: Oil prices fell to a one-month low on Wednesday, with US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude falling 2.5% to $61.79 a barrel, and Brent crude futures falling 2% to $65.51 a barrel. US crude inventories rose 1.9 million barrels last week, while crude production hit a record 10.25 million barrels per day. The market is concerned that record US production could undercut prices, and speculators are trimming their long positions, citing fading bullish sentiment due to the US's ability to surpass 10 million bpd.

site_title: New funding to get SME staff better prepared for terror incident
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower has launched a funding initiative to encourage small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in higher-risk sectors to prepare for potential terror attacks. Industry groups will receive between S$25,000 and S$55,000 to develop a plan, train employees, and raise awareness about terrorism threats. The move aims to enhance workplace safety and security, following the enhancement of the bizSafe programme to incorporate elements of SGSecure, a national push to involve Singaporeans in the fight against terror.

site_title: ST Aerospace JV wins conversion contract for 10 A321 aircraft
summary: ST Aerospace's joint venture ELBE Flugzeugwerke (EFW) has won a contract to convert 10 Airbus A321 aircraft into 14-pallet freighters for Vallair Solutions Sàrl. The conversion program, valued but undisclosed, is EFW's first for the A321 family and will be completed by the end of 2019. The A321P2F offers containerized loading and a payload-range capability of up to 27.9 tonnes, making it suitable for express domestic and regional operations.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: ComfortDelGro unit acquires UK transport operator for £13.4m
summary: ComfortDelGro Corporation, a Singapore-based transport company, has acquired UK transport operator New Adventure Travel (NAT Group) for £13.4m (S$25m). The acquisition expands ComfortDelGro's presence in the UK, particularly in South Wales, and broadens its bus operations outside of London. The deal is expected to have no material impact on ComfortDelGro's financial performance for the current year. This marks ComfortDelGro's strategic expansion into Wales and outside of London, according to Managing Director Yang Ban Seng.

site_title: Snapback for Snap on upside revenue surprise
summary: Snapchat's parent company, Snap Inc, reported a 72% year-on-year increase in revenue to $286 million in the fourth quarter of 2017, beating expectations. The company's daily active users rose to 187 million, a 18% increase, and the average revenue per user increased 46%. Despite a widening loss of $350 million, Snap shares surged 23% in after-hours trade to $17.26, offering hope for reaching profitability. The strong revenue growth was seen as a surprise, reversing the company's post-IPO decline.

site_title: George Soros donated money to campaign for a rerun of Britain's EU referendum
summary: Billionaire George Soros donated £400,000 (S$735,000) to the Best for Britain campaign group, which aims to halt Brexit and secure a rerun of the 2016 EU referendum. Soros's contribution, through his foundations, was reported by the Daily Telegraph. The campaign group's chairman, Mark Malloch-Brown, said the donations were significant and aimed to give the British people a "final say" on the Brexit deal. The move comes as Prime Minister Theresa May has stated that Britain will leave the EU on March 29, 2019, with no rerun of the referendum.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality invests S$250m in serviced residence in Tokyo's Ginza
summary: Frasers Hospitality is investing S$250 million to develop a 200-room serviced residence in Tokyo's Ginza district, set to open in 2020 under its Capri by Fraser brand. The property, a two-minute walk from Chuo-dori and Shimbashi station, is expected to capitalize on Tokyo's growing popularity, hosting global events such as the 2020 Summer Olympics. This investment complements Frasers' existing presence in Japan, including the 2010 opening of Fraser Residence Nankai in Osaka.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit buys nursing home in Saitama prefecture for 1.5 billion yen
summary: Parkway Life Reit announced the acquisition of a 120-room nursing rehabilitation facility in Saitama prefecture, Japan for 1.5 billion yen (S$17.8 million) under a sale-and-leaseback agreement. The property is expected to generate a net property yield of 6.7% and deliver "immediate yield growth" to the trust. The acquisition is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2018 and will bring the Reit's portfolio to 50 properties worth S$1.75 billion.

site_title: German politicians stitch together coalition deal
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel's conservatives and the Social Democrats (SPD) agreed to a coalition deal, ending months of uncertainty and taking Europe's economic powerhouse closer to a new government. The SPD will take the finance ministry, a post held by conservative Wolfgang Schaeuble, while Merkel's conservatives will get the economy and defense ministries. The deal is expected to shift Germany's euro zone policy, with the SPD promising to end "forced austerity" and set up an investment budget. The agreement allows Merkel to secure her fourth term in office, despite the SPD's worst election result in the post-war era.

site_title: Share of job vacancies for PMETs up in 2017
summary: Singapore's job market saw a decline in overall job vacancies for the third consecutive year in 2017, with 53,100 openings available as of end-September. However, the number of job vacancies for professionals, managers, executives, and technicians (PMETs) increased, reflecting the shift towards higher-value-added jobs. PMETs accounted for 49% of all job openings, with the most in-demand occupations including software developers and management executives. Employers cited lack of work experience as the top challenge in hiring local PMETs, while unattractive pay and shift work were main reasons for non-PMET job vacancies.

site_title: Short hops
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) has partnered with various companies to conduct trials and development activities with drones in Singapore, aiming to create a safe and economically-viable aerial parcel delivery system. Thales signed a memorandum of understanding with CAAS to develop new air traffic management technologies, while IATA and CAAS collaborated to establish a Global Safety Predictive Analytics Research Center. Meanwhile, Airbus is seeking to boost sales of its A330neo aircraft and Honeywell secured a contract with Lion Air Group for auxiliary power units.

site_title: Japan Foods posts 73% rise in Q3 profit
summary: Japan Foods Holding reported a 73.1% increase in net profit to S$2.5 million in Q3, driven by a 11.4% rise in revenue to S$18.7 million. The company attributed the growth to strong sales from its Ajisen Ramen, Menya Musashi, and Shitamachi Tendon Akimitsu brands. Despite a reduction in the number of restaurants to 48, the firm remains cautiously optimistic about the outlook for the next 12 months, citing the strength of its brands and operational efficiency.

site_title: Visionary's latest feat is to blast his car into space aboard his rocket
summary: Elon Musk successfully blasted a cherry red Tesla car into space aboard his SpaceX rocket, marking the latest feat in his innovative endeavors. The 46-year-old entrepreneur, who has been hailed as a leading innovator and visionary, has a history of ambitious ventures, including co-founding Zip2, PayPal, and SpaceX. The car reached an orbit near Mars, powered by the massive Falcon Heavy rocket, and was visible with the words "DON'T PANIC" on the dashboard. This achievement is part of Musk's plan to make humans an "interplanetary species" and establish a colony on Mars.

site_title: ECB urges banks to clean up before next crisis
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) urges EU banks to clean up their balance sheets before the next financial crisis, citing a 760-billion-euro mass of bad loans weighing on banks. ECB chief Daniele Nouy says banks must reduce non-performing loans to avoid diverting resources and financing the real economy. The ECB will update its guidance on setting aside cash for future bad loans and may advance plans for a eurozone-wide deposit insurance scheme. The ECB also warns banks to prepare for a potential hard Brexit, with uncertainty surrounding London-based lenders' access to EU markets after the UK leaves next year.

site_title: Report of lower US crude inventories gives lift to oil prices
summary: US crude inventories fell by 1.1 million barrels to 418.4 million barrels, supporting oil prices. Brent crude futures rose 0.9% to $67.44 per barrel, while WTI crude futures rose 0.8% to $63.88 per barrel. Analysts warn of the risk of lower oil prices due to weaker seasonal demand and rising US production, which is expected to reach 10.59 million barrels per day in 2018. Despite this, Goldman Sachs maintains a bullish call on commodities.

site_title: Vacations made to order and Valentine's Day stories in the Weekend magazine
summary: A Weekend magazine of BT features personalized travel experiences, including renting exclusive homes and private dining tours. Valentine's Day stories reveal that high-end dinners may not be as romantic as expected. James Foley discusses sex and directing Fifty Shades Freed in an interview. Meanwhile, lifestyle articles cover topics such as mod-Indian cuisine, zero-waste living, and financial literacy for women.

site_title: Rio Tinto full-year profit jumps 69%; announces US$1b buyback
summary: Rio Tinto reported a 69% increase in full-year profit to $8.63 billion, driven by higher commodity prices, particularly iron ore and coal. The company announced a $1 billion share buyback and a record dividend of $2.90 per share. Operational cash flow jumped 60% to $13.9 billion. Despite a decrease in iron ore prices forecast by Australia's government, Rio maintained its production guidance and capital expenditure forecast of $5.5 billion.

site_title: Wynn joins list of powerful men toppled by harassment claims
summary: Steve Wynn, casino mogul and former CEO of Wynn Resorts, has stepped down amid a deluge of sexual harassment allegations. The 76-year-old billionaire, who dominated the US casino business for five decades, quit as chairman and CEO of the company, as well as finance chair of the Republican National Committee. The allegations, which include a 2005 settlement and a 1998 lawsuit, have led to investigations in Macau, Massachusetts, and Nevada. Wynn's company has lost nearly a fifth of its market value, and his departure may lead to a takeover or changes in the company's leadership.

site_title: Goldman still a raging bull on commodities
summary: Goldman Sachs reaffirms its bullish call on commodities, citing the recent global markets selloff as evidence that raw materials will perform well in the months ahead. The bank's head of commodities research, Jeffrey Currie, notes that commodities, including base metals and gold, have historically performed well during rate-hiking cycles. Goldman forecasts copper to rise to $8,000 a tonne, Brent crude to top $82 a barrel, and iron ore to gain to $85 a tonne within the next 12 months.

site_title: ATR signs 2 aircraft deals with S-E Asian firms
summary: ATR, a French-Italian turboprop aircraft manufacturer, signed its first new commercial aircraft order at the Singapore Airshow. Bangkok Airways, a regional airline based in Thailand, inked a deal for four new ATR 72-600s worth over US$100 million. The airline plans to expand into new destinations, such as those in Indochina. ATR also announced a deal with Berjaya Hotels & Resorts for two pre-owned ATR 42-500 aircraft to serve Redang island in Malaysia, reducing travel time from six hours to one hour.

images.alt_text: Mr Anawat Leelawatwatana (left) and Mr Christian Scherer signing the aircraft deal on Wednesday. ATR also announced another deal involving Berjaya Hotels & Resorts.

site_title: SGX retail trades spike as investors pick up bargains
summary: Investors in Singapore are taking advantage of the market's recent pullback, with retail trades in securities spiking 25% on Tuesday. Analysts recommend buying blue-chip stocks such as Keppel Corp, Venture Corp, and Genting Singapore, which have retraced from recent peaks. The Straits Times Index saw a third of its constituents trade at three-month lows, with Golden Agri-Resources, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings, and Keppel Corp among the top losers. Analysts believe the earnings season could bring growth, with sectors like technology and manufacturing showing potential.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow
A third of the benchmark Straits Times Index's constituents traded at three-month lows on Tuesday, bourse operator Singapore Exchange (SGX) has noted.

site_title: Ping An Ventures to raise up to US$1.3b for healthcare investments
summary: Ping An Ventures, the venture capital arm of China's largest insurer Ping An, plans to raise up to $1.3 billion in two healthcare-focused funds, targeting growth-stage and pre-IPO investments. The funds will deepen the group's push into the healthcare sector and build up its firepower for later-stage investments. The fundraising comes as valuations in the tech and healthcare industries have spiked, with Ping An seeking to tap prospective investors for the new funds, which are expected to be completed within this year.

images.alt_text: Ping An Insurance, China's largest insurer by market value, is looking to boost its direct investments and expertise in the healthcare industry.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: ST Engineering secured new contracts worth S$2.8 billion and S$742 million for its aerospace and electronics arms in Q4 2017, respectively. The company's fair value increases from S$3.61 to S$4.00 due to positive outlooks for its electronics and aerospace sectors. The Singapore Exchange is expected to see healthy trading activity due to the Bursa Malaysia-Singapore Exchange trading link. Manulife US Reit's FY17 results are in line, with attractive valuation and growth potential.

site_title: As US rattles sabre on trade, Asia bites its tongue on soft dollar
summary: US President Donald Trump's aggressive trade rhetoric has led Asian policymakers to refrain from openly discussing currency devaluation, instead opting for subtler measures to manage their currencies. Despite the US dollar's slump to multi-year lows, Asian central banks are focusing on capital outflows to cap their currencies, such as Thailand's relaxation of rules to allow retail investors to buy foreign securities. The US dollar's decline is attributed to Trump's threat of protectionism, which has drawn a line in the sand for Europe and Japan, causing their currencies to appreciate.

site_title: MAS expands digital identities options for bank account openings
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has expanded digital identity options for bank account openings, allowing customers to verify their identities through biometric identification, secure digital signatures, or real-time video conferencing. This move aims to streamline customer due-diligence checks and improve risk management. Financial institutions can also use Singapore's MyInfo platform to access customers' personal data, reducing the need for physical visits to bank branches. The MAS expects this change to save time and costs, while maintaining robust controls to prevent impersonation.

site_title: Nissan targeting sales of more than 1.6m vehicles in China this year
summary: Nissan targets selling over 1.6 million vehicles in China this year, a 5.3% growth rate, surpassing official forecasts. The company aims to boost sales to 2.6 million vehicles by 2022, up from 1.5 million last year. Nissan's Chinese joint venture, Dongfeng Motor, is privately aiming for sales of over 1.7 million vehicles, and the company plans to invest 60 billion yuan (S$12.5 billion) in China over the next five years.

site_title: UK defence firms tout tech transfers in Asia
summary: The UK is seeking to increase its presence in Asia's defence market by offering technology transfers to local contractors. British defence companies, such as BAE Systems, are partnering with Asian firms to transfer high-tech jobs and intellectual activities to the UK, while delivering and sustaining defence systems in Asia. This approach aims to sustain UK jobs and create local support and manufacture. However, concerns about the security of technology transfers have been raised due to the involvement of countries like China, India, and Japan in the region.

site_title: WeWork set to grow Singapore footprint to over 300,000 sq ft
summary: US-based co-working space provider WeWork is set to expand its presence in Singapore, with plans to lease over 300,000 sq ft of space across multiple locations, including City House, Mapletree Anson, and Suntec City. The company has already signed up at several new locations and is in advanced talks for more. WeWork's expansion aims to cater to the growing demand for flexible office spaces, with the co-working sector expected to continue its growth in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

WeWork's space in City House (above) is said to take up four floors of the 23-storey building. This is part of the space now taken up by building owner City Developments Ltd (CDL) for its headquarters. CDL is to move to Republic Plaza this year.

site_title: Game Of Thrones creators to go to 'a galaxy far, far away'
summary: Game of Thrones creators David Benioff and DB Weiss will write and produce a new series of Star Wars films separate from the main Skywalker saga. Lucasfilm announced the plans, praising their storytelling abilities. The films will be released after the final season of Game of Thrones is complete. This move aims to build on the lucrative sci-fi franchise, which has exceeded expectations since Disney acquired Lucasfilm in 2012. The new series will be the latest addition to the Star Wars franchise, which has grown into the most lucrative and influential movie franchise of all time.

images.alt_text: David Benioff (left) and Dan Weiss, creators of Game Of Thrones, will write and produce new Star Wars films that are separate from the main Skywalker saga and the trilogy by Rian Johnson.

site_title: EU's defence funding demand may swell UK's Brexit bill
summary: The UK will be asked to make financial contributions to the European Union after Brexit, potentially exceeding the agreed amount, according to a draft EU document. The UK will have to cover foreign and defense spending during the transition period (2019-2020) and abide by EU laws without a say in decision-making. The UK has expressed disagreement with seven EU directives, including new legislation and expanding EU citizens' rights. The development may strain Brexit talks and anger hardliners in the UK.

site_title: Tax experts on how to burnish Singapore's status as Reit listing hub
summary: Tax experts in Singapore propose several measures to enhance the country's status as a Reit listing hub. These include introducing tax transparency for exchange-traded funds (ETFs) tracking Reits, granting tax concessions to Reit managers, and revising the sunset clause for tax concessions on S-Reits investing overseas. The goal is to bring Reit ETFs on par with Reits in terms of tax efficiency and make listing a Reit in Singapore more attractive to investors, thereby warding off competition from other jurisdictions like Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Singapore real estate investment trusts (Reits) welcomed the extension of tax incentives on Tuesday, with the FTSE ST Reit index rising a modest 0.6 per cent to 804.29.

site_title: Asean e-commerce - Hidden tigers meet tech dragons
summary: Asean's e-commerce market is poised for significant growth due to the entry of Chinese tech giants, such as Alibaba and Tencent, which bring capital and know-how to the region. Despite challenges like inefficient logistics and lack of e-payment adoption, the region's large middle-class consumers and young consumer market offer significant potential. The rise of e-commerce could transform the retail industry, benefiting brand owners but potentially harming convenience stores and department stores. E-commerce giants may also use e-tailing as a platform to accumulate consumer data and move into financial services, disrupting traditional financial institutions.

site_title: Embraer, Boeing still locked in tie-up talks
summary: Embraer and Boeing are still in talks on a proposed tie-up, with no formal proposal on the table yet. The Brazilian plane-maker, Embraer, has not received a proposal and is working on identifying suitable structures. The talks follow Airbus' acquisition of Bombardier's C-Series programme. Embraer aims to boost E-Jet operators to 20 by 2020 and globally to 100, with the E190-E2 set to be delivered to launch customer Wideroe in April.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
Mr Slattery said Embraer is at an inflection point with the entry of the E190-E2 jet into service this year. He expects that "marquee names" will come onboard once the aircraft is certified.

site_title: Unusual Ltd's profit up in Q3, buoyed by higher revenue
summary: Unusual Ltd, a Singapore-based events production firm, reported a net profit of S$2.5 million in the third quarter, up from S$971,000 previously, driven by a surge in revenue to S$10.6 million. The company attributed the growth to higher promotion revenue. CEO Leslie Ong expressed confidence in the demand for concerts by well-known entertainers, with plans to expand into North Asia. Unusual's shares closed at S$0.425, up 0.5 cents.

site_title: APAC will need 2,050 planes in 60-150-seat segment in next 20 years
summary: Bombardier projects that the Asia-Pacific region will need 2,050 aircraft in the 60-150 seat segment by 2036, accounting for 16% of a worldwide market valued at US$820 billion. Strong growth and a booming middle class in the region are expected to triple passenger traffic in the next 20 years. The demand for domestic and regional connectivity will drive growth, particularly in small and medium-sized cities. Bombardier's new C Series aircraft is designed to fill the emerging 100-150 seat segment.

images.alt_text: Bombardier says demand for domestic and regional connectivity means that the fastest traffic growth in the region will come from small and medium-sized cities with challenging airports.

site_title: SingHaiyi's Q3 net profit up 12.8%; revenue more than triples
summary: SingHaiyi Group reported a 12.8% increase in net profit to S$1.4 million for its Q3 2017, with revenue more than tripling to S$41.7 million. The surge in revenue was mainly due to completed executive condominium project sales and US unit sales. The group secured a bulk sale of Phase II of Vietnam Town for US$95.3 million and expects a positive impact on its net tangible assets and earnings per share for FY19. Despite a decrease in gross profit margin, the developer remains cautiously optimistic on the Singapore property market outlook.

site_title: Singapore investors in UK project worry about costs of fixing fire hazard
summary: Several Singapore investors in a luxury London building, Nova House, are facing uncertainty over costs of fixing fire hazards after inspections found flammable cladding and poor compartmentalization. The building's warranty provider, BLP, has not yet decided if it will cover the cost, leaving investors potentially liable for the bill. Investors have been billed £15,000 for the first half of 2018, and some claim they were not sold a property to the standard promised by the developer. The issue is linked to the Grenfell Tower disaster in 2017.

site_title: Singapore government still studying e-commerce tax: Indranee - Singapore Budget 2018
summary: The Singapore government is still studying the implementation of an e-commerce tax, according to Senior Minister of State for Law and Finance Indranee Rajah, ahead of the Budget 2018 announcement on February 19. The government is cautious due to past experiences with similar tax implementations in other countries.

images.alt_text: Ms Indranee, in an interview with MoneyFM 89.3, said there have been countries which started an e-commerce tax and then having to dismantle it because it didn't work out quite well.

site_title: North Korean cheerleaders arrive in high spirits
summary: North Korean cheerleaders arrived in Inje county, South Korea, on February 7, 2018, ahead of the Pyeongchang Olympics. The 229 young women, dressed in matching scarlet coats, were escorted to their hotel and interacted with South Korean journalists, exchanging smiles and waves. The cheerleaders were reportedly selected for their skills, loyalty, and family backgrounds, and will support South Korean athletes during the Games. They are the latest in a series of North Korean cheer squads to participate in international sports events hosted by South Korea.

images.alt_text: The sprightly cheerleaders scurried past the media, who fired questions at the young visitors ranging from their condition to the chilly weather.

site_title: Shaking up Singapore's transfer pricing regime
summary: Singapore's Inland Revenue Authority (IRAS) has shifted its approach to transfer pricing, moving from a guidance-based system to a formal regime. The fourth edition of the Singapore Transfer Pricing (TP) Guidelines has 113 pages, and mandatory documentation is now required for businesses with gross revenue exceeding S$10 million and significant related-party transactions. The IRAS aims to align with the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development's (OECD) Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) initiative. The move has attracted public interest, with some lawmakers calling for personal liability and higher penalties for non-compliance, amid increasing scrutiny on multinational companies' tax practices.

site_title: Pacific Radiance noteholders should reject revised restructuring proposal: OCBC
summary: Pacific Radiance noteholders are advised to reject the company's revised restructuring proposal, according to OCBC. The plan involves redeeming bonds by issuing new shares, resulting in a 50% implied haircut for noteholders, who will also lose seniority protection. Existing shareholders will be diluted by about 35%. OCBC criticizes the plan as "unbalanced" and notes that noteholders lack information about the overall restructuring plan and other stakeholders' commitments.

site_title: mm2 Asia posts Q3 net profit of S$6.4m, up 52.9% from a year ago
summary: mm2 Asia reported a Q3 net profit of S$6.4 million, a 52.9% increase from the same period last year, driven by revenue growth to S$52.4 million due to recent acquisitions. Earnings per share rose to 0.55 Singapore cents.

site_title: World's biggest rocket soars towards Mars
summary: The Falcon Heavy, SpaceX's most powerful rocket, successfully completed its maiden test flight, carrying Elon Musk's cherry red Tesla Roadster into an orbit near Mars. The rocket's 27 engines fired, sending the car and a mannequin into space. The upper stage made a successful final burn, and the car was sent into an orbit around the Sun, approaching Mars. Two side boosters landed safely, but the centre booster failed to land on an ocean platform due to a lack of propellant. The mission was hailed as a significant accomplishment by NASA and SpaceX, with experts praising its potential to fast-track plans to return to the moon.

site_title: OKP Holdings subsidiary to purchase Perth property for A$43.5m
summary: OKP Holdings subsidiary Bennett WA Investment has agreed to purchase a property in East Perth, Western Australia for A$43.5 million. The purchase is for investment purposes, with rental income expected to contribute to the group's revenue. The property's valuation has not been commissioned by the group, and the price was arrived at through a bidding process.

site_title: Carillion collapse: Picking up the pieces
summary: Carillion, a major UK contracting firm, went into liquidation in February 2018 due to a massive hole in its net assets, leaving £1 billion pension deficit. Despite a profits warning and £845 million impairment charge, the company's financial problems were not adequately addressed by regulators, auditors, and the government. The Treasury approved a £2.2 billion contract just seven days after the profits warning, and the Big Four accounting firms turned down the administrators' job due to insufficient assets. The collapse highlights management weakness, external governance failures, and the need for tighter regulation of large companies.

site_title: At least seven killed, 67 missing after quake rocks Taiwan tourist area
summary: At least seven people were killed and 67 are missing after a 6.4-magnitude earthquake struck near Taiwan's tourist city of Hualien, injuring 260 people and causing four buildings to collapse. Rescuers are searching for those trapped in rubble, with aftershocks expected in the next two weeks. President Tsai Ing-wen directed rescue efforts, and the city's mayor described the disaster as the worst in Hualien's history in over 40 years.

site_title: Pence mixes sabre rattling and sport in landmark trip
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence attended the Winter Olympics opening ceremony, echoing his boss Donald Trump's message on North Korea's nuclear stand-off. Pence discussed pressing Pyongyang to abandon its nuclear and missile development programs, as the US administration debates a pre-emptive strike. Pence's trip comes amid disagreements over the issue, with some military leaders expressing concern. The trip aims to show Pence's effectiveness as a foreign ambassador, and he will need to balance his message with the need to avoid war-mongering. Pence's role as a foreign statesman may grow, potentially paving the way for him to assume the presidency in the future.

site_title: Thales to work with CAAS for development of air traffic management technologies
summary: Thales has signed a memorandum of understanding with the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) to develop air traffic management technologies. The collaboration aims to analyze the impact of digital trends on aviation and apply artificial intelligence. They will also create an ATM system architecture for easy integration of new technologies, enhancing the region's aviation capabilities and making a sustainable difference.

site_title: Sapphire hit by HNA blues?
summary: Sapphire Corp, a major shareholder in Singapore, has seen its stock value plummet 15% after a planned deal with HNA Group, a Chinese conglomerate, fell through. The $46 million transaction, which would have given HNA a majority stake in Sapphire, was cancelled after mutual consent. Sapphire has been performing well despite its recent acquisition of a Chinese railway firm, and analysts question whether the board's sudden overhaul was premature. The deal's collapse comes amid HNA's escalating financial woes, raising concerns for minority shareholders.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Olam to open cocoa powder plant outside Chicago
summary: Olam International Ltd, a Singapore-based commodities trader, is building a 183,000 square foot cocoa powder manufacturing facility outside Chicago, expected to be fully operational by mid-2018. The facility will create 50 jobs in Bolingbrook, Illinois. This marks Olam's transformation into a bean processing heavyweight after acquiring rival Archer Daniels Midland Co's cocoa assets in 2015 for approximately $1.2 billion.

site_title: All we are saying is give peace a chance
summary: US congressmen have nominated three Hong Kong activists, Joshua Wong, Nathan Law, and Alex Chow, for the 2018 Nobel Peace Prize, citing their efforts to promote democracy and freedom in Hong Kong. However, China's government has strongly opposed the nomination, viewing it as interference in its internal affairs. The activists were previously jailed for their role in the 2014 Umbrella Movement and have been criticized for their lack of clear focus and mature leadership. The nomination has sparked debate about the role of democracy and self-determination in Hong Kong, with some arguing that the city's autonomy is already compromised.

site_title: Open COE surprises in latest tender
summary: Singapore's Open COE prices fell below those for cars, both big and small, in a rare turn, closing 9.3% lower at S$39,903. Motorcycle COE prices reached a new high, climbing 5.6% to S$8,451, driven by aggressive bidding. Industry watchers attribute the drop in car prices to the return of private-hire car operators and the launch of new models from Toyota and Hyundai, while speculators are suspected of hoarding motorcycle certificates, despite the transport ministry's denial.

images.alt_text: Christopher Tan

site_title: It's not just luxury handbags that are wildly overpriced
summary: Luxury goods companies, such as LVMH and Kering, continue to defy market turmoil, with sales and shares holding up. However, experts warn that valuations could come under pressure due to moderating demand from China and potential US tax cuts. Companies like Tapestry and Kors are considering expansion, but should be patient and focus on growth in other areas, such as jewelry, rather than impulsive acquisitions. Valuations are currently at a near 14-year high, making it a challenging time for luxury brands to find bargains.

site_title: Cryptocurrency rout could get worse: Goldman
summary: Goldman Sachs' global head of investment research, Steve Strongin, warns that the cryptocurrency market could worsen, with most digital currencies unlikely to survive in their current form. He cites slow transaction times, security challenges, and high maintenance costs as reasons for their lack of long-term staying power. Strongin also notes that recent price swings indicate a bubble and that the high correlation between different cryptocurrencies is a concern. He cautions that most coins will likely trade to zero, but acknowledges that some may still see short-term price increases.

site_title: Pence: US to soon unveil 'toughest' sanctions on N Korea
summary: US Vice President Mike Pence announced that the US will soon unveil its "toughest" sanctions on North Korea, aiming to prevent the regime from "hijacking" the upcoming Olympics. Pence vowed to intensify maximum pressure on the North, working with Japan, and warned that all options are on the table to protect the homeland and allies. The US and North Korea have been engaged in a war of words, with tensions remaining high despite recent detente efforts.

site_title: Britain's Tesco faces record £4b equal pay claim
summary: Tesco, Britain's largest private sector employer, faces a potential £4 billion equal pay claim from mainly female store workers, who allege they are paid less than male distribution centre staff. The law firm Leigh Day estimates that over 200,000 Tesco employees may be underpaid, with potential shortfalls reaching £20,000 each. The claim could have significant implications for British industry if successful, and is likely to be bogged down in the courts for years.

site_title: SGX-Bursa link - details unknown but this time, it's different
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Bursa Malaysia (BM) plan to establish a full-fledged trading link by the end of 2018, differing from the 1998 Clob International crisis. The new link will be scripless, covering trading, clearing, and settlement, and is sanctioned by both governments. Unlike the previous Clob system, which was criticized for its one-sided benefits, the current link offers two-way benefits for both Singapore and Malaysian investors. The link will expand the investable universe to 1,600 stocks worth over US$1.2 trillion, but retail investors and governance standards will need to be convinced that history won't repeat itself.

site_title: US: Stocks open modestly lower
summary: US stocks opened modestly lower on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.1% at 24,897.88. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined 0.2% and 0.4% respectively. The recent market swings have reestablished volatility, following a 2.3% gain on Tuesday and the largest point decline on record on Monday. The market's reaction to investor sentiment and the ongoing US-EU trade talks will continue to be monitored.

site_title: Tat Hong Holdings warns of 'weak performance' in its upcoming Q3 results
summary: Tat Hong Holdings has warned of weak performance in its Q3 results, citing poor performance from its equipment distribution business in the Asean region and unrealised foreign exchange losses. The group's unaudited financial statements will be released on Feb 13, providing more details.

site_title: Unusual Limited posts Q3 net profit of S$2.5m, up from S$971,000 previously
summary: Unusual Limited, an events production firm, reported a net profit of S$2.5 million for Q3, up from S$971,000 previously. Revenue increased to S$10.6 million, driven by a rise in promotion revenue. Earnings per share stood at 0.24 cents, with no dividend declared for the quarter.

site_title: Ezion wins US$1.5b refinancing package from 6 secured lenders
summary: Ezion Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore and marine group, has secured a $1.5 billion refinancing package from six secured lenders, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB. The deal includes minimal fixed principal repayments, reduced interest rates, and up to $118 million in revolving credit facilities. In exchange, the lenders will receive 100 million Ezion shares, approximately half of the shares held by CEO Chew Thiam Keng and his family. The refinancing package is part of Ezion's months-long debt restructuring exercise, which aims to strengthen the company's cash flow and reduce its debt levels by around 40% to $1.2 billion.

site_title: Market tests millennial traders who've never seen a crash
summary: Market tests millennial traders who've never seen a crash. For 29-year-old Ben Kumar and many millennials on Wall Street, markets have always bounced back quickly. This is the first time they've faced a full-blown market downturn, which began in 2013. Unlike previous crises, which were resolved quickly, this downturn is expected to last longer. The lack of experience among millennials in navigating such a prolonged market downturn may have significant consequences for the financial industry.

site_title: Mitsubishi aims to sell more than 1,000 small regional jets in 20 years
summary: Mitsubishi Aircraft Corp aims to sell over 1,000 Mitsubishi Regional Jets (MRJs) in 20 years, with a quarter of the orders from Asia. The MRJ has passed the mid-point of its flight test program, clocking over 1,700 hours. Despite a recent setback due to a cancelled US order, the company has strong interest from potential customers, including China. With 407 orders, including a letter of intent for 20 planes, Mitsubishi Aircraft plans to deploy two more jets this year to accelerate certification. The first delivery is scheduled for mid-2020.

site_title: Blackstone's Portugal bet pays off as malls become hot property
summary: Blackstone, a US private equity firm, has seen its initial bet on Portugal's shopping centers pay off. The company began acquiring malls in 2013, and now it's selling three centers around Lisbon to Groupe Auchan for an estimated $733.3 million. Blackstone is also completing the sale of a fourth mall to Spain's Merlin Properties Socimi for up to $733.3 million. The country's economy has recovered, with a 2.6% growth rate in 2017 and unemployment at 7.8%, attracting investors to Portuguese malls, which offer higher yields compared to similar properties in other European markets.

site_title: Calls to buy the dip cushion STI drop
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore ended the day down 22.61 points to 3,383.77, a 0.66% decline from the previous day, despite being 10% higher than its level a year ago. Over 2.6 billion shares changed hands, with 258 gainers and 256 losers.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Engaging Singapore's workforce of the future digitally
summary: Singapore companies face a significant challenge in engaging and retaining talent as the millennial generation takes over the workforce. With estimates suggesting millennials will make up 75% of the workforce by 2020, local businesses must understand their needs and perspectives to remain competitive. A recent study found Singapore ranks as the worst for employee engagement in the region, with competition for talent, managing workforce diversity, and lack of data and insights identified as major HR challenges. Digital transformation is seen as a key solution to address these challenges.

site_title: China's love affair with gold heating up on property riches
summary: China's demand for gold jewellery surged 10% last year to nearly 700 tonnes, driven by a property boom and high stock market valuations boosting wealth among affluent consumers. The nation's demand for gold ornaments accounted for 60% of total gold consumption and made up a third of global jewellery demand. The market is expected to continue growing, with the World Gold Council estimating a 9% increase in demand in the six months through December. This could boost global prices due to the size of the market.

site_title: Canada building permits rise in Dec on residential plans
summary: Canada's building permits rose 4.8% seasonally in December, exceeding economists' forecasts, driven by a 15.7% increase in construction intentions for single-family homes in Ontario. Residential permits nationwide rose 8%. The increase was attributed to plans to build single-family homes in Ontario, which aimed to cool the Toronto market.

site_title: European stock markets in jittery recovery
summary: European stock markets experienced a modest recovery on Wednesday, but Wall Street remained volatile after a day of spectacular price swings. Asian stocks initially failed to benefit from the New York upswing, with investors awaiting interest rate developments and their potential impact on economic growth. Analysts attributed the recent market volatility to the US stock market's sharp upside reversal.

site_title: Freehold development City Towers sold for S$401.9m
summary: City Towers, a freehold development in District 10, Singapore, has been sold for S$401.9 million to an undisclosed buyer. The sale price exceeds the owners' reserve price by 13% and works out to a land rate of approximately S$1,847 per square foot per plot ratio. The 9,711.3 square meter land area will be developed into a 20,393.7 square meter residential project, with a Gross Plot Ratio of 2.1 under the Master Plan 2014.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Singapore's stock market rallied for a 5th consecutive day ahead of GDP data release. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Citigroup forecasts a 1,150 target for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026. Meanwhile, Grab's earnings growth is expected to slow, prompting a downgrade to 'hold' by CGSI. OCBC's CEO Helen Wong is set to retire, with Tan Teck Long named as her successor. Musk's Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a launch event in Mumbai.

site_title: Carlsberg 2017 profits hit by troubled Russian market
summary: Carlsberg's 2017 profits fell short of analyst expectations, hit by a 14% decline in beer volumes in Russia and a 4.8 billion crown impairment of the Baltika brand. The company's net profit dropped to 1.26 billion Danish crowns, down from 4.49 billion a year earlier. The decline was attributed to a law limiting plastic beer bottle size and tighter alcohol regulations in Russia, where Carlsberg relies on for around a fifth of its sales.

site_title: An investor's best friend? Israel Diamond Exchange launches digital coins
summary: Israel's diamond exchange, the Israel Diamond Exchange, has launched digital coins to make trading more efficient and less opaque. The move aims to combat money laundering and crime financing, which have been linked to the industry. Current transactions are often anonymous and lack documentation, making it a target for law enforcement. The digital currency is expected to improve transparency and reduce the risk of illicit activities. The exchange hopes to persuade traditionally conservative players to adopt the technology and inject new life into the marketplace.

site_title: Neo Group posts Q3 net profit of S$2.1m on absence of one-off loss
summary: Neo Group posted a net profit of S$2.1 million for Q3 2023, up from S$125,000 previously due to the absence of a one-off loss in the same period last year. Revenue slipped 4.2% to S$44.7 million, mainly due to a fall in Supplies and Trading business revenue. Earnings per share stood at 0.61 cent for the nine months ended Dec 31.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 24.23 points to 1,836.68, driven by a gain of 625 stocks to 460 losers, with a total volume of 3.3 billion lots worth RM3.5 billion.

site_title: Football: What's gone wrong at Chelsea?
summary: Chelsea's Premier League season has hit a new low with a 4-1 defeat at Watford, putting pressure on manager Antonio Conte. The team trails 19 points behind leaders Manchester City, with owner Roman Abramovich reportedly considering replacements. Former Barcelona coach Luis Enrique is strongly linked with the job, following Conte's potential departure. The loss has further exacerbated Conte's struggles, with Chelsea's title triumph just over a year ago now seeming like a distant memory, and Conte's future at the club uncertain.

site_title: RE&S Holdings posts Q2 net profit of S$1.1m
summary: RE&S Holdings Limited reported a net profit of S$1.1 million for the second quarter ended Dec 31, 2018, down 21.3% from the previous year. Excluding IPO expenses, the group recorded a 51.5% increase in net profit to S$2.1 million. Revenue rose 2.9% to S$37 million, driven by an increase in Quick-Service Restaurants segment. The company remains committed to expanding its businesses and streamlining operations, despite challenges in the F&B industry.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit buys nursing home in Japan for 1.5b yen
summary: Parkway Life Reit has acquired a nursing rehabilitation facility in Japan, Konosu Nursing Home Kyoseien, for 1.5 billion yen (S$17.8 million) under a sale-and-leaseback agreement. The 120-room property will be leased for 20 years at 7.4% below its valuation, generating a net property yield of 6.7%. The acquisition is expected to deliver "immediate yield growth" and will bring the Reit's portfolio to 50 properties worth S$1.75 billion, set to be completed in the first quarter of 2018.

site_title: Singapore shares end off intraday highs, fall 22 points
summary: Singapore shares ended the day down 22.61 points, or 0.66%, at 3,383.77, after investors adopted a wait-and-see stance following recent sell-offs. The benchmark Straits Times Index opened at 3,445.83 and bucked the trend with Singtel closing up 2 cents, while the Singapore Exchange rose 13 cents, or 1.65%. The three local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC closed lower ahead of their corporate results.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Bitcoin may evolve into what everyone fears, mathematicians say
summary: Bitcoin's price may never stabilize due to its reliance on fringe buyers' opinions, according to mathematical modeling by University of Pittsburgh researchers. The price fluctuates as these buyers enter and exit the market, driven by fear and perceived security. The researchers conclude that Bitcoin's value is "an asset which has no value by traditional measures" and may be in a bubble, likened to Ponzi schemes. This raises concerns about the cryptocurrency's long-term viability and potential for significant price drops.

site_title: UK house prices fall unexpectedly in January: Halifax
summary: UK house prices fell 0.6% in January, contrary to forecast, and the annual rate of price growth decreased to 2.2% from 2.7% in December, the lowest since July. This is attributed to household finances under pressure due to rising consumer prices outpacing wages, according to Halifax.

site_title: Germany's top parties 'reach deal' on Merkel coalition
summary: Germany's top parties, the conservatives and Social Democrats, have reached a deal on a new coalition, potentially ending four months of political standstill. The agreement will allow Chancellor Angela Merkel to serve a fourth term, but must still be approved by the SPD's rank-and-file. The deal addresses key issues such as migration, healthcare, and defence spending, and is seen as a relief to Germany's EU partners. A referendum on the pact will be held by postal ballot, with the result expected to be announced in early March, and could determine Merkel's fate and the country's political direction.

site_title: Chinese police don high-tech glasses to nab suspects
summary: Chinese police are using high-tech sunglasses with facial recognition technology to identify and apprehend suspects in crowded train stations. The system, part of China's digital surveillance efforts, has allowed officers to nab 33 individuals accused of various crimes, including human trafficking and using fake IDs. The technology has raised concerns among human rights groups due to its potential for abuse and lack of privacy protections. China's rapid development of facial recognition technology has drawn international attention, with experts noting the country's lax privacy laws and widespread use of biometric data.

site_title: Asean hopes to expedite code of conduct on South China Sea: Singapore
summary: Asean hopes to expedite negotiations on a code of conduct with China for the South China Sea, but a year is considered unrealistic for an agreement. China and Asean adopted a negotiating framework in August, but the lack of a legally binding objective has raised doubts. China has increased its military deployment in the South China Sea, prompting concerns among Asean member states. The association aims to resolve the century-old dispute, with Singapore's Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen expressing hope for a speedy resolution.

site_title: ComfortDelGro's unit acquires UK transport operator for £13m
summary: ComfortDelGro's subsidiary Braddell Limited has acquired New Adventure Travel (NAT Group) in South Wales for £13.4 million (S$25 million). The acquisition valuation is 5.5 times earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation of NAT Group. This move expands ComfortDelGro's UK presence and marks its entry into the UK bus and coach operator market.

site_title: Singapore Airshow 2018: Iata opens new regional office; signs deal to establish analytics research facility with CAAS
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) has opened a new regional office in Singapore, expanding its capacity to accommodate 40% more employees. The office, located at Mapletree Business City, will house a Global Delivery Center, adding 23 new jobs. IATA also signed a memorandum of collaboration with the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) to establish The Global Safety Predictive Analytics Research Center (SPARC), which will utilize predictive analytics to identify potential aviation safety hazards and assess related risks.

site_title: Saudi Aramco, Petronas are said to near US$8b loan deal
summary: Saudi Aramco and Malaysia's Petronas are near a $8 billion loan deal to finance a $27 billion refinery and petrochemical complex in Malaysia, set to be completed in 2019. The deal, which could be signed as early as next month, involves lenders BNP Paribas, HSBC, and Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ. Aramco has invested $7 billion in the project, seeking to maintain its status as the world's largest crude exporter and expand its presence in Asia. The refinery and petrochemical plant will produce fuels meeting Euro 5 emissions standards and provide feedstock for a connected plant.

site_title: Hasbro posts surprise revenue drop as Star Wars toys fail to shine
summary: Hasbro Inc reported a surprise 4.4% drop in quarterly revenue due to a decline in Star Wars toy sales and the lingering impact of Toys 'R' Us' bankruptcy. The toy industry was affected by the retailer's collapse, forcing Hasbro to find alternative sales outlets during the holiday season. The company had prewarned of potential sales disruptions in October. As a result, Hasbro's shares fell 3.2% to US$90.94.

site_title: Oil world turned upside down as America sells oil in Middle East
summary: The US has sold oil to the UAE, a rare transaction between the two countries, as the American shale industry continues to disrupt global energy markets. In December, a tanker carrying American condensate oil arrived in the Persian Gulf, where it was preferred for processing due to its superior quality. This trade highlights the shift in energy dynamics, as the UAE typically relies on regional grades of oil. The sale marks a significant development in the US-UAE energy relationship and underscores the growing influence of the American shale industry.

site_title: Get ready for most cryptocurrencies to hit zero, Goldman says
summary: Goldman Sachs' global head of investment research, Steve Strongin, warns that most cryptocurrencies are unlikely to survive in their current form, citing a bubble and lack of intrinsic value. The tumble in cryptocurrencies, which erased nearly $500 billion in market value, could worsen, with coins likely to lose all value as they're replaced by future competitors. Strongin notes that current digital coins lack long-term staying power due to slow transaction times, security challenges, and high maintenance costs.

site_title: Homebuilder shares snap their longest losing streak in 15 years
summary: US homebuilder shares snapped their 10-day losing streak, the longest since 2002, as the broader market rebounded 3.7%. The sector's decline was driven by concerns over rising interest rates, which could make housing more expensive. The average 30-year mortgage rate rose to 4.22%, its highest in about a year. Analysts say the decline was an overreaction, with some buyers speeding up purchases to beat out further rate increases. The homebuilders' performance was largely driven by the market's recovery.

site_title: Oil prices rise on report of lower US crude inventories
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday, with Brent crude futures up 58 US cents to $67.44 per barrel and US WTI crude futures up 49 US cents to $63.88 per barrel. US crude inventories fell by 1.1 million barrels to 418.4 million barrels, supporting the market. However, analysts warn that rising US crude production and seasonal demand drop could soon weigh on crude prices.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore office rental growth is expected to be the strongest in the Asia-Pacific region over the next three years, according to a report by M&G Real Estate. Meanwhile, China's GDP growth is set to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. The UK economy has also shrunk for the second month, with fresh blows to Prime Minister Starmer. In other news, Asean agreed that Myanmar's election is not a priority, and South Korea's trade chief is seeking a 'landing zone' in US trade talks.

site_title: Ezion Holdings secures US$1.5b refinancing package with 6 secured lenders
summary: EZION Holdings secured a US$1.5 billion refinancing package from six secured lenders, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, with minimal fixed principal repayments over six years and reduced interest rates. The package also includes up to US$118 million in revolving credit facilities, providing a financial lifeline for the liftboat operator during its debt restructuring process.

site_title: Gold rises from over 3-week low on bargain hunting
summary: Gold prices rose 0.5% to US$1,331.23 per ounce on Wednesday, rebounding from a 1% drop to its lowest in over three weeks. Investors took advantage of the dip to buy gold, driven by a decrease in volatility and easing US interest rate expectations. Asian markets showed signs of calm after a tumultuous period, and traders reduced bets on the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes.

site_title: Singapore Airshow 2018: ST Aerospace's JV wins contract for A321 passenger-to-freighter conversion from Vallair
summary: ST Aerospace's joint venture, Elbe Flugzeugwerke (EFW), has won a contract from Vallair Solutions Sàrl to convert 10 A321-200 passenger aircraft to 14-pallet freighters (P2F). The first aircraft will be delivered by end of 2019. The conversion program offers a unique container position on both the main and lower decks, and has a payload-range capability of up to 27.9 tonnes over 2,300 nautical miles. This is EFW's first large-scale P2F conversion program.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rebound at open
summary: European stock markets rebounded at the start of trading on Wednesday, following heavy losses the previous session. London's FTSE 100 rose 1.0% to 7,209.47 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 index climbed 0.6% to 12,466.1 points. The Paris CAC 40 also recovered, gaining 0.4% to 5,184.08 points. The rebounds came after global indices slumped on Tuesday due to US inflation worries.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks slide to over 4-month low on foreign selling; won up
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index fell over 2% to a four-month low on February 7, 2018, amid foreign selling and investor anxiety over China's share market losses. Domestic institutions sold over 700 billion won worth of shares, while the Korean won rose and bond yields fell. The KOSPI is down 0.6% so far this year, and foreign investors were net sellers of 190.8 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: Singapore office, retail rents to see strong growth over next few years: report
summary: Singapore office and retail rents are expected to see significant growth over the next three years. Office rental growth is forecasted to rise 6% per annum, driven by a shortage of grade A supply. Retail rents are projected to increase 1.5% per annum, boosted by improved tourism spending and consumer sentiment. However, a potential goods and services tax hike could initially restrain spending. The growth is attributed to increased consumer spending and e-commerce demand, with logistics warehousing also expected to see stable rental growth.

site_title: Australia shares rebound, led by materials; NZ falls to 2-month low
summary: Australian shares rebounded 0.8% on Wednesday, led by gains in materials and industrials, after a 3.2% slump on Tuesday. US stocks rebounded 2% overnight, but are expected to show volatility. Materials shares rose due to stronger iron ore and copper prices, with BHP and Rio Tinto climbing 1.8% and 3.8%, respectively. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.6% to its lowest since December 2017, with industrials and consumer staples accounting for most of the losses.

site_title: Singapore Airshow 2018: Bangkok Airways to buy 4 ATR 72-600s worth over US$100m
summary: Bangkok Airways signed a deal with ATR to buy four ATR 72-600s worth over $100 million at the Singapore Airshow. The purchase will expand the airline's fleet, adding to its current 15 ATR aircraft. The first aircraft is expected to be delivered by the end of the year, and the new planes will support the airline's plan to expand into new destinations in the region.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars come off their lows, sentiment still shaky
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars recovered from their multi-week lows on Wednesday, with the Aussie up 0.3% and the Kiwi up 0.4%. Despite this, sentiment remains shaky due to the recent sell-off in global markets. The Australian dollar has been sold in times of stress, as it is heavily leveraged to commodity prices and global growth, and has fallen to a two-month low against the Japanese yen. A solid labor market report in New Zealand failed to lift the currency, which is expected to remain at a record low interest rate.

site_title: North Korea slams Olympic protest as 'spasm of psychopaths'
summary: North Korea has condemned anti-Pyongyang activists for protesting its participation in the Pyeongchang Winter Olympics, calling them "psychopaths" who "besmirched the dignity of the DPRK supreme leadership." Hundreds of South Korean conservatives demonstrated against the North Korean ship carrying performers, burning flags and making anti-North Korean remarks. The performers, part of the Samjiyon Orchestra, will perform in Gangneung and Seoul, with tickets in high demand despite tensions between the two Koreas.

site_title: SingHaiyi's Q3 net profit rises 12.8% as revenue more than triples
summary: SingHaiyi Group reported a 12.8% increase in Q3 net profit to S$1.4 million, driven by more than tripled revenue to S$41.7 million. The surge in revenue was mainly from completed EC project and US sales. The company expects a positive impact from the sale of Phase II of Vietnam Town, expected to be completed by September 2018. However, gross profit margin decreased by 37.1 percentage points due to a change in revenue mix.

site_title: CSC narrows losses on back of more business activity
summary: CSC Holdings reported narrower losses in its third quarter of FY2018, with net losses decreasing to S$2.1 million from S$5.6 million in the previous year. Revenue surged 69.7% to S$94.9 million, while loss per share narrowed to 0.12 Singapore cents. The company's shares remained unchanged at S$0.026, and no dividend was declared.

site_title: Michael Kors' same-store sales fall less than expected
summary: Michael Kors Holdings Ltd reported a 3.2% decline in same-store sales for its holiday quarter, beating analysts' estimate of a 6.8% drop. The company cut promotions to reinvigorate sales and brand prestige. As a result, shares rose 8% in trading. The company also raised its full-year sales forecast.

site_title: World's biggest rocket soars toward Mars after perfect launch
summary: The world's most powerful rocket, SpaceX's Falcon Heavy, successfully launched on its maiden test flight on February 6, 2018, carrying Elon Musk's cherry red Tesla Roadster towards an orbit near Mars. The rocket, which is twice as powerful as the Delta IV Heavy, fired its 27 engines and rumbled into the sky, with the Tesla Roadster and a mannequin in a spacesuit on board. The rocket's upper stage made a successful final burn, sending the car into an orbit around the Sun that brings it close to Mars. The successful launch has sparked excitement and congratulations from experts and leaders around the world.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower as recovery peters out
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended lower on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index slipping 0.89% to 30,323.20. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.82% to 3,309.26. The initial rebound from the previous day's 5% collapse fizzled out, marking a fresh loss for the market.

site_title: Singapore Airshow 2018: Malaysia's Berjaya Hotels & Resorts to buy 2 ATR 42-500s
summary: Berjaya Hotels & Resorts, a subsidiary of Bursa Malaysia-listed conglomerate Berjaya Corporation, will purchase two ATR 42-500 aircraft for US$15-20 million to serve Redang island in Malaysia. The new aircraft will reduce travel time from Kuala Lumpur to the island from five to six hours to an hour. The aircraft, operated by sister company Berjaya Air, will be configured to seat 36 passengers and can take off and land on short runways, ideal for the island's 1,100-meter airport runway. Delivery is expected in April, with inaugural flights planned for June.

site_title: Fewer job openings last year, with more for PMETs: MOM
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) reported a decline in job vacancies in Singapore for the third consecutive year, with 53,100 jobs available as of end-September 2017. However, more positions were for professionals, managers, executives, and technicians (PMETs), which made up 49% of job openings. Employers cited lack of necessary work experience as a major challenge in hiring local PMETs. To address skills mismatches, MOM advised employers to redesign and improve non-PMET jobs and facilitate job matching, and to tap on government support to meet hiring needs.

site_title: No offer yet from Boeing on tie-up: Embraer
summary: Embraer is still in talks with Boeing on a proposed tie-up, with the Brazilian plane maker saying it has not received a proposal yet due to ongoing discussions. The Brazilian government holds a golden share in Embraer, requiring its approval for any deal to proceed. Embraer's CEO John Slattery stated that if a proposal is received, it will be reviewed and subject to authorities and shareholder approval. The tie-up, which could see Boeing acquire up to 90% of a new venture, remains uncertain.

site_title: Vietnam's taxi company sues Grab for unfair business practices
summary: Vietnam's taxi company, Vinasun, has filed a lawsuit against Grab, accusing the ride-hailing service of unfair business practices. Vinasun claims Grab's promotions and discounts led to its declining revenues in 2016 and 2017. The company alleges Grab's lack of compliance with government regulations and industry standards creates an unfair competitive environment. Grab's lawyers dispute the claims, arguing that Vinasun's allegations are baseless and that its software has created a level playing field. The case is being heard by a Ho Chi Minh City court.

site_title: Financial firms can accept more forms of digital identity for customer verification: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has expanded the forms of digital identity that banks and financial firms can use to verify new customers. Financial institutions can now accept biometric identification, secure digital signatures, and real-time video conferencing, as well as utilize the MyInfo system for faster and more efficient customer onboarding. This new guidance aims to streamline risk management, reduce costs, and improve the quality of customer due-diligence checks.

site_title: China's love affair with gold heating up on property riches
summary: China's gold jewelry demand rebounded 10% in 2017 to nearly 700 metric tons, driven by a property boom and high stock market valuations. Affluent consumers, particularly in second- and third-tier cities, are increasing purchases and consumption. Jewelry accounts for over 60% of China's gold consumption and a third of global demand. The market is expected to continue growing, with sales rising 16% in mainland China and 13% in Hong Kong and Macau. Rising demand in China could boost global gold prices.
