site_title: Market tests millennial traders who've never seen a crash
summary: Millennial traders on Wall Street and the City of London are being tested for their resilience in the face of a global stock market crash. Unlike their older counterparts who lived through the 2008 financial crisis, millennials have never seen a full-blown crash and are accustomed to rapid market recoveries. Many fund managers are concerned that the younger generation may be too complacent, but millennials are asserting their readiness for the next downturn, citing humility and a focus on survival over profit. As central banks withdraw stimulus, millennials are weighing whether to buy on the dip or wait longer, with some already experienced in navigating market volatility.

site_title: Rio Tinto rewards investors as profit rallies to three-year high
summary: Rio Tinto reported a three-year high annual profit of $9.7 billion, driven by buoyant commodity prices. The company met investors' calls for higher returns by raising its full-year dividend payments by 71% and extending its share buyback program. Underlying profit for 2017 was in line with estimates, and Rio's balance sheet strength allows it to invest in high-value growth opportunities. The company's chief executive, Jean-Sebastien Jacques, stated that Rio is in a unique position to deliver superior cash returns to shareholders.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks edge up in volatile trade after Wall Street rally
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.16% or 35.13 points to 21,645.37 after a volatile session, rebounding from a 5% decline on Tuesday. The Nikkei index surged nearly 3.5% at one point, with investors buying on dips following a Wall Street rally. Analysts expect the market to continue recovering, with some predicting the 21,078 as the bottom of the latest crash. Key individual stocks, including Toyota and Sony, also saw gains.

site_title: Singapore industry associations to get up to S$55,000 to prepare staff for terror attacks
summary: Singapore's industry associations in priority sectors will receive up to S$55,000 to develop risk management capabilities for terror attacks. The Ministry of Manpower aims to get 3,000 companies SGSecure-ready by 2020. Since the bizSAFE programme's launch in 2007, workplace fatality rates have decreased from 2.9 per 100,000 to 1.2 per 100,000 in 2017. The programme, which also includes simulation exercises and seminars, has already seen 2,100 companies join the enhanced bizSAFE programme since its launch in September 2017.

site_title: Brokers' take: CIMB puts out top-five 'shopping list' on market correction
summary: CIMB analyst Lim Siew Khee has released a "shopping list" of top-five stocks to buy during a market correction, citing fundamentals and upcoming catalysts. The recommended stocks include Venture Corporation, Genting Singapore, Keppel Corporation, ST Engineering, and AEM Holdings. The analysts suggest buying these stocks at their current prices, anticipating a potential correction in the market.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei index rebounds over 3% after Wall Street rally
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index surged over 3% in early trading on February 7, 2018, after a rally on Wall Street, easing concerns about market volatility. The benchmark index rose 677.02 points to 22,287.26, rebounding from a 5% drop the previous day. The rebound was attributed to investors' relief over the US stock market's rally.

site_title: Samsung to begin investing in new domestic memory chip line
summary: Samsung Electronics plans to invest in a second memory chip line at its Pyeongtaek production facilities in South Korea, following a record annual profit driven by a "memory chip super-cycle." The investment aims to meet booming demand for semiconductors, particularly for chips used in servers. This move comes after Samsung Electronics vice chairman Jay Y Lee's release from jail, and the company's first semiconductor production line at Pyeongtaek began mass production in July last year, operating at over 70% capacity.

site_title: Rescuers scour toppled buildings after Taiwan quake
summary: A 6.4-magnitude earthquake struck Taiwan's eastern port city of Hualien, killing two and injuring over 200. Five buildings, including a hotel and residential block, were severely damaged, with one 12-storey building tilting precariously. Rescue efforts continued through the night, with 117 people rescued and 214 injured. Authorities struggled to verify the number of missing residents due to frequent aftershocks. The quake, which occurred just before midnight, was the same magnitude as a 2016 quake that killed over 100 people in southern Taiwan.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally at open after mauling
summary: Hong Kong stocks rallied at the open on Wednesday, rebounding from the previous day's 5% drop, as investors tracked a recovery on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 2.36%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 1.25% and 1.59%, respectively. The rebound followed a decline in US stocks, which saw the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edge to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday; STI up 1.6%
summary: Singapore shares rose 1.6% at the opening bell on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index up 53.82 points to 3,460.2. The recovery was driven by Wall Street's overnight bounce, with the Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq all gaining. Other regional markets also rebounded, including Japan's Topix index and Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index. The rally follows a global rout in the past few days, but investors remain cautious due to tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore Airshow 2018: Asia-Pacific will need 2,050 planes in 60 to 150-seat segment over next 2 decades, says Bombardier
summary: Bombardier predicts the Asia-Pacific region will require 2,050 aircraft in the 60-150 seat segment by 2036, accounting for 16% of the global market valued at $820 billion. The region's growing economies and middle class are expected to drive passenger traffic numbers to triple in the next 20 years, with demand for domestic and regional connectivity driving growth. Bombardier's new C Series aircraft is designed to fill the emerging 100-150 seat segment.

site_title: Singapore-Malaysia stock link breaks new ground for Asean markets
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have agreed to establish a stock market trading link between the Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Bursa Malaysia, enabling investors to trade and settle shares listed on each other's exchanges more conveniently and cost-efficiently. The link will be expanded to other Asean markets and will facilitate lower trading costs and greater cross-border investments. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Securities Commission Malaysia will set up cross-border supervisory and enforcement arrangements to oversee the trading link, which is expected to be completed by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: IMF sees Indonesia's medium-term growth rising to 5.6%
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has projected Indonesia's medium-term economic growth to rise to 5.6% annually, driven by robust domestic demand. The IMF warns against building up too much debt in boosting infrastructure investment and cautions against risks such as global financial volatility and geopolitical tensions. It recommends a gradual fiscal adjustment in 2018 to protect growth and rebuild fiscal buffers, with a focus on financing infrastructure with domestic revenue and private sector participation. The IMF also suggests reducing state control and improving education spending.

site_title: Two dead, over 200 injured in Taiwan quake
summary: A 6.4-magnitude earthquake struck Taiwan's east coast, killing two people and injuring over 200, with buildings crumbling and trapping people inside. The port city of Hualien was particularly hard hit, with a hotel and residential block severely damaged. Rescuers worked to free people from the upper floors of the Marshal Hotel, which partly crumpled into the ground. At least 15 aftershocks followed the quake, and officials promised rapid disaster relief, with Taiwan's president Tsai Ing-wen offering support.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 17.41 points to 1,829.86. Trading volume reached 155.8 million lots worth RM61.24 million, with 381 gainers outnumbering 29 losers.

site_title: Asia: Markets bounce back from 'sell-off we had to have'
summary: Asian markets rebounded from a record one-day points drop on the Dow, with Tokyo and Hong Kong leading the recovery. The Dow's 4.7% drop on Tuesday sparked panic-selling, but investor confidence returned on Wednesday, with Wall Street providing a positive lead. Safe-haven gold fell, while high-yielding currencies rose against the dollar. Energy firms also rallied after a report showed US stockpiles not increasing as much as forecast, with oil prices providing support. Analysts say the volatility may not be at an end, but the losses were likely a healthy correction.

site_title: UK's May takes aim at gig economy with new safeguards for workers
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May unveiled a "Good Work Plan" to crack down on unfair working practices in the gig economy, including agency workers and those employed by companies like Uber and Deliveroo. The plan includes enforcing holiday and sick pay, providing workers with a full list of their employment rights on their first day, and defining "working time" for app-based workers. The proposals address 52 of 53 recommendations from Matthew Taylor's review, excluding a proposal to reduce national insurance contributions. The plan aims to ensure Britain has an "economy which works for all."

site_title: Japan wages fall in blow to consumer spending, BOJ's inflation quest
summary: Japan's wages fell 0.5% in December, the largest decline in five months, indicating consumers may cut back on spending and complicate the central bank's quest to reach its 2% inflation target. This trend suggests the government faces a challenge in convincing companies to raise wages by 3% or more, despite Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" agenda. Real wages adjusted for inflation fell 0.5% in December, marking the biggest decline since 2017.

site_title: House passes stopgap US spending bill as leaders eye long-term plan
summary: The US House of Representatives passed a stopgap spending bill to fund the government until March 23 and provide $659 billion for the Pentagon through September, amid efforts to reach a two-year budget deal. The measure, which also lifts budget caps, would be followed by a Senate vote on a broader budget deal that could include provisions to raise the debt ceiling. Leaders in both parties aim to avoid a government shutdown, with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell expressing optimism about reaching an agreement soon.

site_title: SGX's January daily average value up 28% year-on-year
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 28% year-on-year increase in its January daily average value to S$1.3 billion, with a 39% month-on-month rise. Total market securities turnover value reached S$29.4 billion, and derivatives trading volume increased 55% year-on-year to 18.1 million contracts. The exchange also saw strong bond listings, with 59 new listings raising S$25.1 billion. SGX attributed the growth to increased investor sentiment and bullish market conditions.

site_title: Wanted: 637,000 more pilots to handle travel surge in 20 years
summary: Boeing predicts a shortage of 637,000 pilots worldwide by 2036, with 40% of the new pilots needed heading to Asia. The shortage is driven by rising incomes boosting travel numbers to a record, with airlines ordering hundreds of billions of dollars in new aircraft. This will surpass Europe and North America combined in pilot demand. The shortage is expected to worsen the situation, highlighting the need for more pilots to handle the travel surge in the next two decades.

site_title: Casino tycoon Steve Wynn quits over sexual harassment claims
summary: US casino tycoon Steve Wynn has resigned as chairman and CEO of Wynn Resorts amid allegations of sexual harassment, with the company appointing Matt Maddox as CEO and Boone Wayson as non-executive chairman. Wynn denied the accusations, calling them "preposterous," but the company cited the negative publicity as a reason for his departure. Wynn had also resigned as finance chairman of the Republican National Committee in January.

site_title: Soros, Cohen boost stakes in Argentine mobile banking venture
summary: Billionaire investors George Soros and Steve Cohen have increased their stakes in Ualá, an Argentine mobile banking startup, by investing $10 million in a funding round. Ualá offers low-cost banking alternatives to tech-savvy Argentines, with 50,000 cards issued in its first three months, exceeding initial expectations. The company aims to expand into credit and other countries in the region, seeking to make savings, payments, and credit accessible to the unbanked and underbanked.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OKH Global, Capital World, OUE Lippo Healthcare, Japan Foods, CWG International
summary: OKH Global reported a net profit of S$3 million for its second quarter, up from S$859,000 a year ago, driven by higher income from unit sales. Capital World posted a 90% increase in net profit to RM17.4 million (S$5.9 million) due to completed projects. OUE Lippo Healthcare is expected to report a net loss for the fourth quarter. Japan Foods Holdings saw a 73.1% increase in net profit to S$2.5 million due to strong revenue growth, and is in talks for a joint venture in Indonesia.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks wobble, won marks sharp gains
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index dropped 0.23 points or 0.01% to 2,453.08 in early trade on Wednesday, weighed by selling from foreign and domestic investors. The won strengthened 1.04% to 1,080.3 per dollar, while bond yields rose. The Kospi is down 0.6% so far this year, and US stocks ended the previous session with gains, lifting MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan 0.75%.

site_title: Pan Asian Holdings awards S$3.5m contract for new headquarters and logistics centre in Tuas
summary: Pan Asian Holdings has awarded a S$3.5 million contract to Sanwah Construction Pte Ltd for the construction of its new headquarters and logistics centre in Tuas, Singapore. The project, valued at S$3.5 million, is expected to be completed by Feb 12, 2019, and will have a material impact on the company's consolidated net tangible assets and earnings per share for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2018.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Five technology trials to kick off at one-north, Singapore's first drone estate
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) has announced five technology trials at One-North, Singapore's first drone estate, to develop and test various drone-related technologies. The trials include urban air delivery services, drone traffic management, and autonomous building inspection. Airbus, Nanyang Technological University, Singtel, ST Aerospace, and JTC will participate in the trials. The designations aim to create a safe and economically viable drone ecosystem in Singapore, following the announcement by Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan at the Singapore Airshow 2018.

site_title: China supersizes pig farms to cut costs in world's top pork market
summary: China is expanding its pig farms to cut costs and boost productivity, shifting away from traditional backyard methods. The country plans to build 10,000 sows in large-scale automated farms, producing 20,000 tonnes of pork annually. This move aims to tame price volatility, improve food safety, and increase global competitiveness. Modernized farms will use imported genetics, boosting productivity and lean meat production. However, concerns remain about disease risk, labor shortages, and high investment costs, which could pose significant challenges to China's rapid industrialization of its pork industry.

site_title: Wynn Resorts' Steve Wynn steps down as CEO in wake of sexual harassment claims
summary: US billionaire Steve Wynn has resigned as CEO of Wynn Resorts amid allegations of sexual harassment. Wynn denied the claims, stating they were instigated by his ex-wife, but stepped down as finance chairman of the Republican National Committee in January. He was replaced by Matt Maddox, who has been president of Wynn Resorts since 2013. The company also appointed Boone Wayson as non-executive chairman, effective immediately.

site_title: Hong Kong to extend school holidays amid deadly flu outbreak
summary: Hong Kong will extend school holidays for kindergarten and primary school students due to a deadly flu outbreak that has claimed over 100 lives in the city. The government, citing "severe" infection, is moving the holiday start date up by 2-3 days to Feb 8. This decision follows the death of two children and 194 severe cases among adults, with 111 deaths reported. The move aims to reduce the spread of the virus and prioritize public health.

site_title: Singapore stocks begin Wednesday afternoon trading on higher ground; STI at 3,409.05
summary: Singapore stocks opened Wednesday afternoon trading at 3,409.05, up 2.67 points or 0.08% on the day. The Straits Times Index was down marginally by 9.81 points or 0.29% from the midday break. Gainers beat out losers 300 to 126, with 1.4 billion shares worth S$1.1 billion traded. Notable stocks included QT Vascular, up 5.9%, and Midas Holdings, up 2%.

site_title: Nissan aims to sell over 1.6m vehicles in China this year
summary: Nissan aims to sell over 1.6 million vehicles in China this year, representing a 5.3% growth, surpassing official forecasts but slower than last year's 12.2% growth. The target was confirmed by Nissan's China chief, Jun Seki, and is expected to be announced publicly on Wednesday. Internally, the company is aiming to sell at least 1.7 million vehicles. Nissan plans to invest 60 billion yuan in China over five years, seeking to become a top-three automaker in the country.

site_title: Australia: Shares recover from heavy sell-off; NZ at more than 2-mth low
summary: Australian shares recovered from a heavy sell-off, rising 1.2% to 5,902.6, their biggest intraday gain since July. The materials sector led the rebound, with mining heavyweights BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto rising 1.6% and 2.2% respectively. However, gains were tempered by a decline in cash profit at Commonwealth Bank of Australia. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.9% to its lowest level since late November, with consumer staples and healthcare stocks dragging on the index.

site_title: Pacific Radiance noteholders should reject revised restructuring proposal: OCBC
summary: OCBC advises Pacific Radiance noteholders to reject the company's revised restructuring proposal, citing an unbalanced trade-off. The plan, which would convert bonds to new shares, offers 19 new shares for every S$5 held, but noteholders would take a 50% haircut and give up seniority protection. In contrast, existing shareholders face a 35% dilution. OCBC's credit analyst, Nick Wong, notes that noteholders are flying blind without knowing other aspects of the restructuring. The proposal also includes waiving events of defaults and financial covenants to avoid technical default.

site_title: Singapore government still studying e-commerce tax: Indranee
summary: Singapore's government is still studying the implementation of an e-commerce tax, with Senior Minister of State for Law and Finance Indranee Rajah stating that it's not a priority. The tax was first proposed by Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat in 2017's Budget speech. Indranee emphasized the upcoming Budget's focus on innovation and helping workers, rather than "goodies" for the public. The government is cautious about implementing the tax due to its implementation in other countries not working out well.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Brokers' take: Singapore-Malaysia stock market link would likely benefit retail investors
summary: Singapore and Malaysia's proposed stock market link is expected to benefit retail investors, particularly in terms of convenience and cost efficiency. The link, set to be completed by the end of this year, will allow investors to trade and settle shares in both markets. DBS Group Research and CIMB Research predict increased securities revenue and potential benefits for retail investors, with the possibility of higher trading turnover and cross-border research reports. Both brokerages have a "buy" rating on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) with target prices of S$8.90 and S$8.50.

site_title: Elon Musk, visionary Tesla and SpaceX founder
summary: Elon Musk, founder of Tesla and SpaceX, successfully launched a Tesla electric car into space on a Falcon Heavy rocket from Cape Canaveral. The car, powered by a massive rocket, reached an orbit near Mars and played David Bowie's "Space Oddity" as it soared into space. This feat is part of Musk's ambitious plans to establish a human settlement on Mars and make humans an "interplanetary species." Musk, 46, has been hailed as a leading innovator and visionary, with a net worth estimated at $20.3 billion.

site_title: Gold slips as investors eye higher US interest rates
summary: Gold prices fell 1% to a 2-1/2-week low on Tuesday, as investors focused on expectations for higher US interest rates. Spot gold dropped to $1,326.51 an ounce, erasing Monday's gain, and US gold futures settled down 0.5% at $1,329.50 per ounce. Higher interest rates make gold less attractive, but some analysts expect gold to benefit if interest rates are reduced.

images.alt_text: Gold prices fell 1 per cent to a 2-1/2-week low on Tuesday, as investors focused on expectations for higher US interest rates, even as US stock markets swung wildly in both directions a day after the Dow and S&P 500 indexes tumbled.

site_title: Japan Foods Q3 profit up 73%, in talks with potential JV partner in Indonesia
summary: Japan Foods Holdings reported a 73.1% increase in net profit to S$2.5 million for its third quarter, driven by strong revenue growth of 11.4% to S$18.7 million. The company has reduced its restaurant count to 48 and is cautiously optimistic about the outlook for the next 12 months. Japan Foods is in advanced talks with a potential joint venture partner in Indonesia and will make an announcement as needed. The stock closed at 42 Singapore cents, down 4.5% from the previous day.

site_title: SGX-Bursa link: Start of a pan-Asean bourse?
summary: Singapore and Malaysia unveiled a plan to link their stock exchanges, dubbed the "Malaysia-Singapore Connect", allowing for end-to-end trading, clearing, and settlement connectivity. The link aims to boost liquidity and exposure to domestic companies in both markets, with Singapore investors gaining access to Bursa Malaysia's listings and Malaysian investors expanding their stock picks to Singapore-listed companies. The timing coincides with improved bilateral relations, including a high-speed rail project, but also poses potential risks, including Malaysia's upcoming high-stakes election.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
On Tuesday, the stock exchanges of Singapore and Malaysia unveiled a plan to link up "end-to-end" to better enable investors in each market to trade shares on the other market.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality invests S$250m to develop Tokyo serviced residence
summary: Frasers Hospitality is investing S$250 million to develop a 200-room serviced residence in Tokyo's Ginza district, set to open in 2020. The property will be under the Capri by Fraser brand and is a two-minute walk from Chuo-dori and Shimbashi Station. This investment follows a rise in Tokyo visitors, including those for the 2020 Summer Olympics, and complements Frasers Suites Akasaka. The company expects strong hotel occupancy rates in Tokyo, with rates over 85% in the first half of last year.

images.alt_text: Artist's impression of Capri by Fraser, Ginza. Frasers Hospitality, part of Frasers Property Group, is investing S$250 million to develop a new serviced residence in the Ginza district in Tokyo.

site_title: India's Budget woos voters with big healthcare plan
summary: India's 2018 Budget presented by Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government has been met with criticism for not offering tax breaks to the middle class and reintroducing a long-term capital-gains tax. The budget also announced a massive government healthcare scheme, which would cover 100 million vulnerable households, with an initial allocation of 20 billion Indian rupees. Critics argue that the allocation is inadequate and that India's healthcare infrastructure is not equipped to handle the program. The budget also included measures to boost agriculture, with a focus on rural infrastructure and a minimum support price mechanism.

site_title: Asia-Pac will need 14,450 planes worth US$2.3t over next 20 years
summary: The Asia-Pacific region will need approximately 14,450 new planes valued at US$2.3 trillion over the next 20 years, accounting for 40% of global demand, according to Airbus. Passenger traffic in the region is expected to triple, making it the world's largest aviation market. The demand is driven by growing markets such as China and India, and is expected to fuel orders for single-aisle and widebody aircraft, with Airbus estimating 9,800 single-aisle planes and 4,000 widebodies needed.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
In the coming weeks, Airbus will deliver the A350-1000, which is on display at the Singapore Airshow this week, to launch customer Qatar Airways.

site_title: US: Stocks close with solid gains after volatile session, Dow +2.3%
summary: US stocks closed with gains, recovering from the prior session's losses. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 2.3% to 24,915.45, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 1.8% and 2.1%, respectively. The gains were driven by a solid session, with stocks winning back lost ground.

site_title: Uber says hackers behind 2016 data breach were in Canada, Florida
summary: Uber's 2016 data breach involved hackers in Canada and Florida, compromising 25 million US residents' data, including 4.1 million drivers. The breach, which involved 57 million worldwide users, was initially kept secret for a year before being disclosed. Uber paid hackers $100,000 to destroy the data through a bug bounty program, a decision that has been criticized by lawmakers. The company's security team made mistakes, including not reporting the breach to consumers and law enforcement promptly. Uber's CEO, Dara Khosrowshahi, fired two top security officials following the incident.

images.alt_text: The two people who hacked ride-hailing firm Uber's data in 2016 were in Canada and Florida at the time, a company security executive told a US congressional committee on Tuesday.

site_title: Strategists still see year-end gains in US stocks despite selloff
summary: US stock strategists remain optimistic about year-end gains despite a 4.5% drop in the S&P 500 over the last five days. Only one strategist lowered their year-end target, while others expect the S&P 500 to reach 3,000 by the end of 2018, a 11% gain from its current level. Corporate earnings are expected to grow 14% in the fourth quarter, with 77.8% of S&P 500 companies beating analyst expectations. Strategists attribute the recent decline to a healthy correction after 2017's 19% gain, and expect the market to regain confidence with a successful retest of recent lows.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Brokers' Take: 
- NetLink NBN Trust (NLT) is a buy target at S$0.970, driven by its hedged interest rates and growth in distributions.
- Sarine Technologies is an add target at S$1.56, with its valuation seen as attractive after a 40% decline in share price.
- The Singapore Exchange's (SGX) Bursa SGX trading link is a positive catalyst, expected to improve trading activities.
- Analysts from various firms are bullish on these companies, citing growth prospects and attractive valuations.

site_title: Ellipsiz records big jump in Q2 profit
summary: Ellipsiz, a Singapore-based semiconductor equipment provider, reported a significant leap in its net income for the second quarter ended Dec 31, 2017, with a net profit of S$5.8 million, up from S$1.7 million a year ago. Revenue increased 3% year-on-year to $10.5 million, while earnings per share rose to 3.48 cents. The company attributed growth to its Singapore, China, and Taiwan operations and recorded a one-off gain on disposal of subsidiaries.

site_title: Does Noble have a future post-debt revamp?
summary: NOBLE Group, a Singapore-based trading company, has reached an in-principle agreement with creditors to restructure its US$3.4 billion debt. The plan, which must be approved by all creditors, will halve the debt by giving creditors control of a new entity and asking them to take on new debt instruments. However, the plan has raised concerns among shareholders and individual noteholders, who are unhappy with the proposed exchange terms for perpetual bonds and notes maturing this year. The company's future success post-restructuring is uncertain, with concerns over its remaining coal business and high debt levels.

site_title: Saudi Arabia plots shift to renewable energy
summary: Saudi Arabia is shifting its focus towards renewable energy, aiming to diversify its economy and reduce its reliance on oil. The country has announced plans to invest up to $7 billion in solar and wind farms, with the goal of generating 10% of its power from renewables by 2023. A recent bid for a solar farm in northern Saudi Arabia secured a low price of 2-3 cents per kilowatt-hour, making it cheaper than fossil fuel-generated electricity. The move is seen as a major step towards creating a renewable energy market and generating jobs, with energy minister Turki al-Shehri stating that the project will "create jobs, create manufacturing".

site_title: Oil dips as dollar rises to highest in a week
summary: Oil prices fell for a third day as the US dollar rose to its highest in a week, despite a decrease in US crude oil stocks. Brent crude futures settled down 76 cents to $66.86 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate futures dipped 76 cents to $63.39 a barrel. The dollar's rise has increased the cost of oil for non-US investors, while a 1.8 million barrels per day supply cut by OPEC and Russia has supported oil prices. Despite this, rising US supply is expected to put pressure on oil prices, with domestic crude oil production forecast to rise by 1.26 million barrels per day in 2018.

site_title: Gold rises as equity sell-off spurs safe-haven buying
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,342.95 per ounce on Tuesday, as investors sought safe-haven assets amid a global equity rout. The US Federal Reserve hinted at further rate hikes this year, boosting the dollar and pressuring gold. US gold futures for April delivery rose 0.7% to $1,345.60 per ounce. Analysts expect gold to retest resistance at $1,354, but rate hikes may temper upside.

site_title: Europe: FTSE suffers biggest drop since Brexit vote as stocks sell-off deepens
summary: The FTSE 100, a major British share index, suffered its largest drop since the Brexit vote, closing down 2.6% at 7,141.4 points on Tuesday. Global volatility surged, with financials, asset managers, and oil majors leading the decline. Mid- and small-cap indices also fell, with the FTSE 250 sliding 2.2%. The sell-off was attributed to a correction in equities, which had surged since the start of the year, and a spike in volatility.

site_title: Snapback for Snap on upside revenue surprise
summary: Snap Inc. reported stronger-than-expected revenue growth in its fourth quarter, with revenues increasing 72% year-over-year to $286 million. The company also saw a 23% surge in shares after-hours trade to $17.26. Daily active users rose to 187 million, and average revenue per user increased 46% from a year ago. Despite a wider loss of $350 million, Snap's efforts to boost engagement with new content and partnerships with media outlets offer hope for reaching profitability.

site_title: 2017 trade deficit hits 10-year high of US$566b
summary: The US trade deficit reached a 10-year high of $566 billion in 2017, driven by robust domestic demand and record-high imports. The December trade deficit widened 5.3% to $53.1 billion, the highest level since 2008. President Trump's "America First" trade policies aim to shrink the trade gap, but economists say tariffs and other actions may not significantly impact growth. The trade deficit, adjusted for inflation, increased to $68.4 billion, potentially dragging on GDP growth in the first quarter.

site_title: Markets stay stoic as volatility rocks stocks
summary: Stock markets in Singapore and Asia showed resilience despite a sharp sell-off on Monday and Tuesday, with many experts attributing the volatility to a correction rather than a market collapse. Despite the Dow's initial decline, it recovered and ended the day up 200 points. Experts say the low volatility in recent months may have created a sense of exuberance, but the recent sell-off is a welcome sign of a healthy market. Many are advising investors to "buy the dip" and view the current turmoil as an opportunity to scoop up shares in solidly performing companies.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Why the stock market drop is less scary than it seems
summary: The US stock market experienced a significant decline, with the Dow Jones falling 666 points, but this downturn may be less scary than it seems. The 7.8% drop in the S&P 500 over six trading days is comparable to past declines in January 2016 and August 2015, which did not leave lasting scars. The decline may be driven by optimism over higher wages and inflation, rather than economic pessimism, and the bond market has shown signs of rising interest rates despite the stock market drop.

images.alt_text: Last Friday, the Dow Jones industrial average fell by 666 points, which was followed by an even steeper decline on Monday. There is an important idea to keep in mind at a time like this: Take the long view.

site_title: Rising food prices continue to inflate sales growth in UK
summary: UK shoppers continued to spend more on food in January, with sales growth driven by rising inflation since the Brexit vote. The British Retail Consortium reported a 0.6% increase in sales compared to the previous year, while non-food sales fell 1.2% over the three months to January. This marks the first annual decline in non-food sales in nine years. Overall spending rose 3.9% in January, driven by a 4.4% increase in supermarket spending, with consumers absorbing the impact of inflation on their budgets.

site_title: Snow shuts Eiffel Tower as winter blast hits France
summary: The Eiffel Tower in Paris was closed to tourists due to heavy snowfall and black ice on roads, causing widespread traffic chaos in the city. Snow and freezing temperatures are expected to worsen, with temperatures potentially dropping as low as -10°C. Thousands of emergency accommodation spaces will be opened for homeless people, and traffic was banned for vehicles over 7.5 tonnes. The cold snap marks a contrast to recent mild weather in northern France, causing flooding and high river levels.

images.alt_text: The Eiffel Tower turned away tourists on Tuesday as snow swept across northern France, causing traffic chaos in Paris during the French capital's first real dose of wintry weather this season.

site_title: STI tumbles after Wall Street's record fall
summary: Singapore shares plummeted 2.2% on Tuesday, following a record 1,175.21-point drop in the Dow Jones Industrial Average the previous day. The Straits Times Index closed at 3,406.38, with blue-chip banks and offshore marine conglomerates leading the sell-off. Despite the global market sell-off, BMI Research says several asset classes remain in broad uptrends, and a market correction is not imminent. Experts warn of potential emerging market risks, including falling commodity prices and rising inflation, but emphasize the importance of a long-term perspective.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Frauds and flaws rise to surface as bitcoin bubble deflates
summary: The bitcoin bubble has deflated, with the value of digital tokens sliding over 50% from their peaks in early January. Hackers, Ponzi schemes, and government regulators struggling to keep up have raised concerns. The industry's design, meant to cut out middlemen and government authorities, has made bad behavior more prevalent. Regulators have brought major cases, but the problem is acute due to the rapid growth of the industry and lack of regulatory models. Several major exchanges and companies, including Facebook and JPMorgan Chase, have barred transactions with virtual currencies.

images.alt_text: One challenge facing regulators is that it is unclear how much of the deceptive activity they can legally control.

site_title: 'Game of Thrones' creators to make new 'Star Wars' films
summary: David Benioff and D.B. Weiss, the creators of "Game of Thrones," are set to write and produce new "Star Wars" films separate from the Skywalker saga, according to Lucasfilm. The new films, announced Tuesday, will be developed by the duo, who have expressed excitement about the opportunity to join the franchise. The series will be separate from Rian Johnson's trilogy and will not have release dates announced. Lucasfilm president Kathleen Kennedy praised Benioff and Weiss's storytelling abilities, calling them "some of the best storytellers working today."

images.alt_text: Lucasfilm announced plans Tuesday for a new series of "Star Wars" films made by the team behind "Game of Thrones," as it seeks to build on the lucrative sci-fi franchise.

site_title: Pacific Mansion seeks S$938m en bloc price
summary: The owners of Pacific Mansion in Singapore have put the condominium up for public tender with a reserve price of S$938 million (S$1,728 per square foot per plot ratio). The site, built in the mid-1970s, has a land area of approximately 128,352 square feet and can be redeveloped up to a gross floor area of 542,544 square feet. Developers are expected to show strong interest in acquiring the site, which offers a rare opportunity to design an iconic landmark development in the River Valley district.

images.alt_text: Built in the mid-1970s, Pacific Mansion is located in River Valley Close on a freehold site of about 128,352 sq ft. In the east, Fernwood Towers is asking S$688 million, which includes the development charge payable.
Fernwood Towers, a 216-unit freehold development in Marine Parade Road, appears set to launch an en bloc sale, according to ERA Realty.

site_title: Nissan to launch new electric vehicle model from April
summary: Nissan plans to launch its new 100% electric Nissan Leaf model in over 60 markets, including Singapore, starting from April. The new model features autonomous driving capabilities and a bigger battery capacity, costing 10-20% more than a conventional car. Nissan aims to launch one million new electric vehicles globally by 2022, with Singapore expected to see a significant increase in electric vehicle adoption, particularly among taxis and private car hire companies, despite a lack of charging points.

site_title: Pratt & Whitney receives string of turbofan orders
summary: Pratt & Whitney has received significant orders for its geared turbofan (GTF) engines from various airlines and leasing companies, including BOC Aviation, Swiss International Air Lines, and Aircalin. The orders, announced at the Singapore Airshow, are valued but undisclosed. The GTF engines offer a 16% fuel burn reduction, 50% nitrogen oxide emissions decrease, and 75% lower noise footprint compared to traditional engines. Pratt & Whitney has secured deals with 12 airlines, including BOC Aviation's 12 shipsets for Airbus A320neo aircraft and Swiss's 15 GTFs for A320neo and A321neo planes.

site_title: Olam to open US cocoa powder plant in Chicago area
summary: Olam International, a global commodities trader, is building a US cocoa powder manufacturing facility in the Chicago area, with construction expected to be completed by mid-2018. The 183,000-square-foot facility will create 50 jobs and mark the company's first US manufacturing site. Olam acquired eight cocoa processing facilities from Archer Daniels Midland in 2015 and sources beans in Africa, Asia, and South America, processing about 700,000 tonnes of cocoa powder annually.

site_title: Airbus, Boeing vying for US$8.5b Vistara order: sources
summary: Vistara, the Indian affiliate of Singapore Airlines, is in talks with Airbus and Boeing to purchase jets worth up to $8.5 billion, aiming to tap India's growing middle class. The airline is seeking 50 narrowbody jets and up to 10 widebodies to expand its services to destinations like New York and London. A final decision is expected by June, with competition between Airbus's A320neo and Boeing's 737Max on the smaller planes, and Airbus's A330neos and Boeing's 787 Dreamliners on the larger planes.

site_title: BNP sees profitability exceeding target as growth takes hold
summary: BNP Paribas reported fourth-quarter profit and trading results mostly in line with analysts' estimates, signaling a possible big European bank to reap the benefits of a stronger economy. The bank aims for a return on equity to surpass its 10% target for 2020 and posted a 12% increase in equity trading revenue. Despite a frantic market selloff, BNP Paribas expects to beat its target, with CEO Jean-Laurent Bonnafe aiming to make the bank one of the top three European players in trading and corporate banking.

site_title: Manulife US Reit aims to double AUM in 2 years
summary: Manulife US Reit aims to double its assets under management (AUM) to $2.6 billion in the next two years. The Reit manager, led by Jennifer Schillaci, is open to partnerships, acquisitions, and new investment ideas to achieve the target. The company has a gearing ratio of 33.7% and is looking at fundraising options beyond traditional bank loans. With a yield of 6.5%, Manulife US Reit is targeting core and prime properties in large diversified markets, and plans to launch a euro medium-term note programme and implement a distribution reinvestment plan this year.

site_title: China needs pension system overhaul as it struggles with shortfall
summary: China is struggling with a pension system shortfall, with expenses rising 11.6% to 2.58 trillion yuan in 2016, leaving a 429.1 billion yuan gap. The shortfall is expected to reach 600 billion yuan in 2018 and 890 billion yuan in 2020 if the system isn't reformed. The Chinese government may need to issue debt to cover the gap, and contributions from employees and companies could rise drastically or payouts may be cut. The government has pledged to increase pension payments, but experts warn of a structural increase in consumer spending and a strain on public finances.

site_title: Zuckerberg acknowledges 'mistakes' as Facebook turns 14
summary: Mark Zuckerberg acknowledged making numerous mistakes in building Facebook as the social network marked its 14th birthday. He listed mistakes including technical errors, bad deals, and trusting the wrong people. Despite criticism over misinformation and manipulation, Zuckerberg expressed a commitment to continually re-evaluating Facebook's operations and solving its greatest challenges, even if it means failure.

images.alt_text: Monday's post from Mr Zuckerberg suggested a continual re-evaluation of how Facebook works.

site_title: 2018 - the year AI comes to the fore
summary: In 2018, Microsoft predicted that artificial intelligence (AI) would become ubiquitous and drive significant impact across industries. The company believes AI should augment human capabilities, combining human and computer abilities to achieve more. To achieve this, Microsoft is developing AI-powered tools, such as Seeing AI, and integrating AI into popular products like Windows and Office. The company also emphasizes the need for ethical principles and human-centered design in AI development, with a focus on democratizing access to AI benefits and preparing people for a changing job market.

images.alt_text: AI needs to be people first and technology second. Put simply, we need to develop AI to augment human capabilities, especially humankind's innate ingenuity.When we do this, we combine the capabilities of computers with human capabilities to enable people to achieve more.

site_title: Govt has not ruled out other ways to fund T5, says Indranee
summary: Singapore's government has not ruled out alternative funding methods for Changi Airport's Terminal 5, said Senior Minister of State for Finance Indranee Rajah. The government is still exploring the optimal way to fund the project, which may involve additional fees for passengers. IATA has opposed pre-funding through taxes on travelers, but Indranee stated that the government will try to find the most optimal way to fund the project, considering different models and reviewing large-scale infrastructure projects.

images.alt_text: The Singapore government is still looking for the optimal way to pay for Changi Airport's Terminal 5, and does not rule out other funding methods, said Senior Minister of State for Finance Indranee Rajah on Tuesday.

site_title: Capital World posts Q2 net profit of RM17.4m
summary: Capital World, a Malaysian property developer, posted a net profit of RM17.4 million (S$5.9 million) for its Q2 2018, up 90% from the previous year, driven by higher revenue recognition from completed works. Revenue reached RM46 million, up from RM18 million previously. The group expects the cross-border MRT system between Singapore and Malaysia to boost its development projects in Johor Bahru. Capital World also launched an indoor theme park concept, expected to be one of the world's largest, and plans to commence operations in 2018.

site_title: SGX-Bursa link: Start of a pan-Asean bourse?
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have unveiled a plan to link their stock exchanges, known as the "Malaysia-Singapore Connect," which aims to enable seamless trading, clearing, and settlement of shares between the two markets. This is a significant move, following a 20-year wait since the failed Asean Trading Link, and could mark the beginning of an Asean power exchange. The link promises to provide better exposure to domestic companies and foreign listings, and could help boost bilateral relations, which are currently at a peak due to strong ties between Singapore and Malaysia leaders.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
On Tuesday, the stock exchanges of Singapore and Malaysia unveiled a plan to link up "end-to-end" to better enable investors in each market to trade shares on the other market.

site_title: Better news on piracy, but hold the yo-ho-ho
summary: Piracy incidents worldwide declined to 180 in 2017, the lowest annual number since 1995, according to the International Maritime Bureau. However, the number of reported incidents still raised concerns, with nine incidents off Somalia and 36 incidents in Nigerian waters. Crew members were also kidnapped and taken hostage, with 91 crew members taken hostage and 75 kidnapped in 2017. The IMB warned that complacency should not be felt, as the Gulf of Guinea and waters around Nigeria remain a threat to seafarers.

site_title: Currency market gyrations far less pronounced
summary: Currency markets showed less panic on Tuesday, with the dollar rising slightly against the euro. The yen also rose, but gains were muted. The sell-off in world stock markets led investors to rush into the dollar, helping it bounce amid prolonged weakness against the euro and commodity-linked currencies. The 10-year Treasury yield slid 10 basis points to 2.696%, down from a four-year high. Analysts expect the dollar to continue its long period of weakness unless the global economy shows signs of slowing.

site_title: Lululemon seeks new leader after CEO's misconduct leads to exit
summary: Lululemon Athletica Inc. has announced the departure of CEO Laurent Potdevin after he resigned following allegations of misconduct. The 50-year-old CEO, who led the company for four years, will receive a payment of $5 million and $1.65 million over 18 months. Potdevin's exit follows a period of successful recovery for the company, which had previously faced controversies over its products and founder's comments. The company has begun a search for a new leader, with Chairman Glenn Murphy taking on additional executive duties to steer the company through the turbulence.

images.alt_text: Mr Potdevin resigned on Monday in the wake of unprofessional behaviour that the company declined to identify.

site_title: China's coke and coking coal futures defy global market rout
summary: China's steelmaking commodities, including coke and coking coal, rose to six-week highs amid supply disruptions and production curbs to combat air pollution. Steel and iron ore prices also surged, defying a global market rout. Winter output curbs in place until March and transport disruptions due to heavy snow have fueled the rally. Analysts attribute the resilience to a tight supply-demand balance, despite concerns over inflation and interest rates. Coke futures rose 3.1%, coking coal rose 0.9%, and iron ore touched a one-week high.

site_title: Transforming business through artificial intelligence
summary: A 2016 survey by Microsoft found that business leaders in Singapore are eager to adopt the "Fourth Industrial Revolution" technologies, including artificial intelligence (AI), Internet of Things, and cloud computing. Three-quarters of respondents believe they need to transform to a digital business to enable future growth. Microsoft has made AI more accessible through its Azure Bot Service and Cognitive Services Language Understanding (LUIS), with over 760,000 developers using LUIS and 240,000 developers using the Azure Bot Service. Companies like CapitaLand and JTC are already using AI to improve customer experiences and optimize building management. The Singapore government has also partnered with Microsoft to develop conversational intelligence for public services.

images.alt_text: "With our developments geographically dispersed across Singapore, the JTC Integrated Smart Estate and Building Operations System allows us to centrally and remotely monitor, analyse and optimise its building and estate systems."- Yim Cheng Siew, chief information officer, JTC.

site_title: Time to moderate stock expectations
summary: Stock markets experienced a sudden downturn last week, posting their worst performance in two years due to concerns over higher inflation and interest rates. This marked a sharp turn in the market's trend, which had been on a bull run since last year, with global equities starting the year with a strong start. The sudden shift highlights the challenges facing investors and the need for moderate expectations in the market.

site_title: Yoma's Q3 profit surges to S$16.8m after tour business spin-off
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings, a Singapore-listed conglomerate, reported a third-quarter net profit of S$16.75 million, a 50-fold increase from the same period last year, driven by gains from the disposal of tourism-related businesses and higher revenue from automotive and consumer businesses. Revenue from the automotive and heavy equipment business increased 36.3% year-on-year, while the KFC business saw a 30% growth. The company aims to operate at least 32 KFC stores by the end of March next year.

site_title: Safeguards already in place against en bloc sale of newer projects
summary: Singapore's en bloc sale safeguards are already in place, with varying requirements based on development age. For newer projects under 10 years old, 90% owner consent is needed, while older developments require 80%. This was revealed in Parliament by Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong in response to a question about setting a minimum age for collective sales. Existing safeguards address concerns about the en bloc fever.

site_title: Singapore-Malaysia stock link breaks new ground for Asean markets
summary: Singapore and Malaysia regulators announced a stock market trading link between Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Bursa Malaysia, enabling investors to trade and settle shares listed on each other's markets more conveniently and cost-efficiently. The link will offer access to 1,600 listed firms, worth over US$1.2 trillion, by the end of the year, providing cheaper and faster trading options for investors in both countries. The move aims to strengthen economic ties and boost market connectivity between the two ASEAN neighbors.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Del Monte Pacific to list unit on Philippine exchange
summary: DEL Monte Pacific Limited (DMPL) plans to list its wholly owned Philippine subsidiary, Del Monte Philippines Inc (DMPI), on the Philippine Stock Exchange to raise funds for loan repayment and general corporate purposes. The company will retain ownership of at least 67% of DMPI for five years after the secondary offer. This move aims to strengthen the company's financial position and provide flexibility for future investments.

site_title: Doc and HealthServe win Singaporean of the Year award
summary: Dr. Goh Wei Leong, a general practitioner, and HealthServe, a healthcare charity he co-founded, have been awarded The Straits Times Singaporean of the Year for 2017. HealthServe provides affordable healthcare to migrant workers. The duo beat nine other finalists for the award, recognizing their contributions to the community.

site_title: Powering up CNY efforts with SP Group
summary: SP Group's staff volunteers, known as SP Heart Workers, visited over 300 households in the Limbang area of Singapore on January 31 to decorate homes for Chinese New Year. The volunteers aimed to support local residents in their spring-cleaning efforts and festive preparations. This community outreach initiative is part of SP Group's efforts to give back to the community.

site_title: Outdated crime fighting tools in US result in unreported 'iceberg' of cybercrimes
summary: US law enforcement agencies struggle with outdated crime-fighting tools, leading to unreported cybercrimes. The issue is exemplified by the lack of data on online Fentanyl sales and iPhone thefts, allowing illicit networks to thrive. Meanwhile, various companies and institutions are investing in AI and digital innovation, including the establishment of AI-focused innovation hubs and research centers. These efforts aim to improve business operations and combat cyber threats, but the issue of outdated tools hindering investigations persists.

site_title: Australian retail sales dim in December, but Q4 is bright
summary: Australian retail sales declined 0.5% in December, easing from a 1.3% rise in November, but still posted a 3.3% increase in the fourth quarter of 2017, beating economists' expectations of a 0.2% fall. This rebound is seen as a positive sign for household consumption and economic growth. Online sales grew 6% in December, following a 20% increase in November, driven by Black Friday discounts.

site_title: Short hops
summary: Bell Helicopter has signed a 16-helicopter deal with the Philippine Department of National Defense, worth an unspecified amount, to operate the helicopters for various missions including disaster relief and search and rescue.

site_title: Our future depends on the digitally skilled
summary: The World Economic Forum's "Creating a Shared Future in a Fractured World" theme highlights the need for reskilling the workforce and preparing the next generation for the technology-driven future. With the Fourth Industrial Revolution, 5 million jobs are expected to change or disappear globally, but technology can also bring about higher quality of life and economic opportunities. Businesses and governments must work together to ensure a diverse and digitally skilled workforce, investing in reskilling strategies and education to address the skills gap. Companies are taking the lead in enabling the workforce of the future, with initiatives such as the IT Industry Skills Initiative and SkillSET portal.

site_title: Has Trumphoria finally hit a wall?
summary: US stocks experienced a market plunge, but experts argue it may be a self-fulfilling panic. In 1987, economist Robert Shiller found that investors sold stocks not due to economic reasons, but because they saw others doing so. The Dow's 666-point fall on Friday may be a case of similar panic. The article suggests that the market's behavior is not indicative of a larger economic issue, and the cause of the slide remains unclear.

site_title: GM reports US$5.2b loss on charge for US tax reform
summary: General Motors reported a US$5.2 billion net loss in the fourth quarter due to a US$7.3 billion non-cash charge from US tax reform. However, earnings were better-than-expected when the tax hit is excluded, translating to US$1.65 a share. Despite a 5.5% decline in revenues, strong sales in the US, China, and South America helped GM achieve higher operating earnings. The company expects tax cuts to benefit the economy long-term, with shares rising 1.3% to US$40.03 after the results were announced.

site_title: Wikileaks founder Assange loses bid to have UK arrest warrant dropped
summary: A British court has rejected Julian Assange's bid to have a warrant for his arrest quashed, denying him a possible exit from the Ecuadorean embassy in London. Assange, 46, has been holed up in the embassy since 2012 to avoid extradition to Sweden and the US, where he faces prosecution over Wikileaks' leaked documents. The Swedish case has been dropped, but Assange fears being handed over to the US. The court's decision leaves him with uncertain future, as he remains in the embassy for over five years.

site_title: Samsung heir's release raises hackles along with hopes
summary: Samsung heir Jay Y Lee was released from jail on bribery charges, sparking hopes for new investments and jobs, despite concerns over cosy ties between government and business leaders. As a major conglomerate, Samsung's businesses are deeply intertwined with thousands of subcontractors and start-ups, making it a significant part of South Koreans' lives. The company's release is seen as a potential catalyst for economic growth, but ongoing concerns about its influence persist.

images.alt_text: Mr Jay Y Lee's release had many South Koreans in the business community looking forward to positive effects on the economy, including new investment in local industries and more jobs.

site_title: Italy and Singapore: 52 years of friendship, and counting
summary: Italy and Singapore have maintained a strong and long-lasting friendship for over 52 years since Singapore gained independence in 1965. Italy was the seventh country to officially recognize Singapore, and Italian traders, businessmen, and artists contributed to the city's rapid development. The two countries continue to strengthen their ties through various diplomatic and economic efforts.

site_title: BP profit rises with oil prices
summary: BP reported a significant increase in net profits to nearly $3.4 billion in 2017, driven by a recovery in the crude oil market. Oil prices rose 15% to $60 per barrel, with BP's upstream business experiencing a 12% output increase to 2.47 million barrels of oil equivalent per day. The company's downstream division also delivered solid earnings, while costs related to the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill disaster totaled $65.8 billion. CEO Bob Dudley described 2017 as one of the strongest years in BP's recent history, with the company entering the second year of its five-year plan with "real momentum."

site_title: Spreading festive cheer through healthier food packs
summary: Keppel Land staff and Republic Polytechnic students distributed festive packs and CNY red packets to Gambas residents, providing relief to families like Vimaladelvi D/O Lochumuman, who was undergoing surgery and had to minimize expenses. This initiative, supported by corporate sponsors, aimed to promote healthier food options during the Lunar New Year.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

Above: During the WeCare@NorthWest Service Weeks (Gambas), over 30 Keppel Land volunteers joined students from Republic Polytechnic to pack and distribute festive packs to about 60 needy households. Leading the volunteers to spread cheer were Mr Ong (first row, in blue shirt) and Mr Loh (to the left of Mr Ong).

"Keppel Land believes in doing good as we do well. We constantly seek ways to contribute meaningfully in the local and overseas communities where we operate." Mr Loh (third from left) with Mr Ong (second from left), bringing cheer to residents of rental flats during the WeCare@NorthWest Service Weeks (Gambas)

site_title: 3,664 flats for sale in 2018's first BTO exercise
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched 3,664 Built-To-Order (BTO) flats for sale in four estates, marking its first exercise of 2018. The flats range from two-room Flexi to five-room units, with prices starting from S$71,000 and going up to S$429,000. The exercise also includes 717 flats not selected from previous exercises, with prices ranging from S$149,000 to S$585,000. The HDB will cease offering kitchen partition walls under the Optional Component Scheme due to low take-up rates.

site_title: Saks owner Hudson's Bay hires CVS Health executive as CEO
summary: Hudson's Bay, owner of Saks Fifth Avenue and Lord & Taylor, has appointed Helena Foulkes, president of CVS' pharmacy division, as its new CEO. The move aims to improve the company's digital strategy as more shoppers shift away from physical stores. Foulkes will focus on transforming Hudson's Bay's struggling department store business.

images.alt_text: At CVS, Ms Foulkes ran the company's vast network of 9,700 retail stores and was credited with building its online prescription refill business.

site_title: US needs incentives to attract foreign solar firms: China's Longi
summary: US President Donald Trump's tariffs on solar panel imports have prompted China's Longi Green Energy Tech to consider incentives to attract foreign solar firms. Despite the tariffs, Longi plans to expand capacity overseas, aiming to double its Indian factory capacity to 2 gigawatts. The company expects India's solar market to grow rapidly, and will cautiously assess its capacity expansion plan in the overseas market. Longi currently has 15 GW of silicon wafer capacity and plans to expand it to 45 GW by 2020, with no plans to rule out setting up more factories in other countries.

images.alt_text: Mr Trump holding up Section 201 dealing with imports after signing it on Jan 23. The administration is issuing tariffs on imported solar panels and washing machines.

site_title: JTC inks MOUs on Seletar Aerospace Park with GE Aviation, Hawker Pacific, PPG
summary: JTC signed memoranda of understanding with GE Aviation, Hawker Pacific, and PPG at the Singapore Airshow. GE Aviation and PPG will move into Seletar Aerospace Park, while Hawker Pacific is expanding its facilities there. The agreements aim to enhance Singapore's aerospace capabilities and drive economic growth in the industry.

site_title: Tighter control of cryptocurrencies needed: BIS
summary: The Bank for International Settlements (BIS) has issued a warning to central bankers, urging them to take control of cryptocurrencies to prevent them from harming the wider financial system. BIS General Manager Agustín Carstens stated that authorities must act against the spread of cryptocurrencies to protect consumers and investors. This comes as bitcoin and altcoins plunged from their January bubble heights, highlighting the need for regulation.

site_title: New pay deal sets bar for rest of German workers
summary: A hard-fought pay deal between the labour union IG Metall and the Suedwestmetall employers' federation in south-west Germany has set a benchmark for millions of workers in Europe's largest economy. The agreement includes a 4.3% pay raise from April, equivalent to a 3.5% annual increase, and other payments spread over 27 months. The deal is seen as a good compromise, with analysts predicting annual wage increases of close to 4% over the next couple of years, potentially aiding the European Central Bank in achieving euro zone inflation targets.

images.alt_text: Workers of planemaker Airbus taking part in a 24-hour strike of German metal workers' union IG Metall in Hamburg last week. The strikes cost carmakers, automotive suppliers and engineering firms almost 200 million euros.

site_title: Bitcoin drops below US$6,000 for first time in 3 months
summary: Bitcoin plummeted over 20% to fall below US$6,000 on Tuesday, its first drop in 3 months, amid global stock market collapse and regulatory clampdowns. The virtual currency's value has been heavily influenced by news of crackdowns by governments in China, Russia, and South Korea, as well as concerns raised by central banks and commercial lenders. Experts attribute the sell-off to a "risk-off tone" and investors losing confidence in crypto, with some predicting a potential full round trip back to the US$1,850/US$2,966 region.

site_title: N Korean hackers could be behind US$530m digital coin theft in Japan
summary: North Korean hackers may be behind the $530 million theft of virtual coins from a Japanese cryptocurrency exchange, according to South Korea's National Intelligence Service. The agency did not present evidence but flagged the possibility as a concern due to the virtual coin market's size and lack of regulation. This incident has reignited speculation about North Korea's involvement in cyber attacks, following the 2017 WannaCry attack.

site_title: EDB moves from being investment-led to innovation-driven
summary: Singapore's Economic Development Board (EDB) is shifting its strategy from being investment-led to innovation-driven in response to digital disruption. Established in 1961, the EDB aims to transform Singapore into Asia's digital capital. This pivot is part of the government's efforts to keep pace with changing market trends and promote sustainable growth. The move is expected to focus on fostering innovation and entrepreneurship, rather than solely relying on attracting foreign investment.

images.alt_text: EDB assistant managing director Kiren Kumar says that EDB 'cannot sit still' in the face of tremendous digital disruption. One of its roles is to 'stitch the ecosystem more effectively to drive innovation', he adds.

site_title: Indian government, RBI to discuss bond yield surge at borrowing meeting
summary: India's finance ministry will discuss concerns about a sharp rise in market bond yields with the RBI at a meeting this week, amid worries about a potential increase in overall interest rates in the economy. The rise in bond yields has raised concerns among senior government officials. The meeting aims to address the issue and inform government borrowing plans for the year.

site_title: ESR-Reit trustee to divest Bukit Batok property for S$23.9m
summary: ESR-REIT announced its trustee, RBC Investor Services Trust, has entered into an option to purchase a 9-storey warehouse industrial building in Bukit Batok for S$23.9 million, 1.3% above its book value of S$23.6 million. The sale will be subject to JTC Corporation approval and is expected to take place in the first half of 2018. Proceeds will be used for debt repayment, acquisitions, and working capital. The divestment is part of ESR-REIT's efforts to recycle capital and rejuvenate its portfolio.

site_title: Britain could take control of rail line after Stagecoach contract failure
summary: Britain is considering taking control of the rail line between London and Edinburgh after Stagecoach's contract failure due to financial miscalculations. The company overbid and is now paying a price, with Stagecoach losing 200 million pounds. Transport Minister Chris Grayling plans to seek a new arrangement, which could include the government running the line until 2020 or Stagecoach operating it on a not-for-profit basis. This would be the second time in a decade that the line has been renationalised, highlighting difficulties in Britain's privatised train network.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore and Malaysia plan to connect their stock markets by the end of 2018, allowing for easier trading and settlement. Asian stocks plummeted after a record-breaking Wall Street loss, with Bitcoin also dropping 20% to a three-month low. The Singapore Airshow saw Honeywell sign long-term contracts with Singapore Airlines. Meanwhile, the Singapore government is exploring funding options for Changi Airport's Terminal 5. Globally, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and the UK economy contracted for the second month.

site_title: SIA Engineering inks MOU with tech group Safran on data analytics
summary: SIA Engineering has signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with Safran to collaborate in data analytics, particularly in predictive maintenance for the aviation industry. Safran will provide software and services expertise, while SIAEC will contribute its engineering and maintenance experience. The partnership aims to develop innovative aircraft maintenance solutions for customers worldwide, potentially improving maintenance planning and reducing disruptions. The MOU is not expected to impact SIAEC's financial performance in the FY2017/18.

site_title: Scope for short-term private home rentals in Singapore: Lawrence Wong
summary: National Development Minister Lawrence Wong stated in parliament that there is scope for short-term private home rentals in Singapore, subject to proper safeguards and controls. This was in response to a question about working with operators like Airbnb to regulate private homes being rented out. Wong emphasized the need for proper controls to ensure public safety and prevent unscrupulous operators from exploiting the market.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Ascendas India Trust has oversubscribed a private placement, increasing total proceeds from S$75 million to S$100 million. The placement, priced at S$1.027, will be used to repay debts and a bridging loan. The number of new units to be issued has also been increased from 73 million to 97.4 million. The move is seen as a strategic move to strengthen the trust's financial position.

site_title: OKH Global posts net profit of S$3m for Q2, up from S$859,000 a year ago
summary: OKH Global, a Singaporean property developer, reported a net profit of S$3 million for the second quarter of 2018, up from S$859,000 a year ago. Revenue increased to S$6.3 million, driven by higher income from completed project sales. The company plans to develop and manage warehouses in China through a strategic partnership and assess its properties for monetization to strengthen its financial position.

site_title: Sinway-led consortium's holdings reach 90.19% of CWG International
summary: A Sinway-led consortium, through ELIDOM Investment, has acquired 90.19% of CWG International's shares, taking steps to delist the company from the Singapore Exchange's mainboard. The consortium, jointly owned by Sinway Investment, H&H Wealth, and Floriland Co, made a voluntary conditional cash offer for the remaining shares at S$0.195 apiece. After receiving valid acceptances, the offer became unconditional, and CWG's shares closed flat at 19.4 Singapore cents. The delisting is expected to be completed following the acquisition of the remaining shares.

site_title: ST Electronics to develop commercial satellite system with SatixFy UK
summary: ST Electronics, the electronics arm of ST Engineering, has signed an agreement with SatixFy UK to develop a commercial satellite system for in-flight connectivity in commercial aviation. The joint venture will use SatixFy's Digital Beam Forming technology, enabling seamless and simultaneous communications with multiple satellites. The system aims to provide enhanced broadband connectivity for passengers and improve operational efficiencies for airlines. ST Electronics will invest US$20 million for a 49% stake, with SatixFy UK controlling the remaining 51%. The JVCo will be headquartered in the UK, marking a strategic move into the growing commercial aviation connectivity market.

site_title: India's doubles sugar import tax to 100%
summary: India has raised its import duty on sugar to 100% from 50%, aiming to protect local mills from falling prices and making it difficult for them to pay farmers the mandatory 11% increase in cane prices. This move could halt sporadic imports from neighboring Pakistan, which has been giving a subsidy for foreign sales.

site_title: US: Stocks recover after historic falls
summary: US stock markets recovered from historic falls, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite gaining 0.25%, 0.2%, and 0.4% respectively. The gains were driven by bargain-hunters and Apple's 2% increase. The Dow's 4% fall on Monday was its largest since August 2011, attributed to concerns over rising US interest rates and government bond yields. Analysts saw the losses as buying opportunities for the S&P 500.

site_title: Nomura said to hire Brevan's Mohideen, once fired amid Libor
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc. hired Jezri Mohideen, a former senior trader at Royal Bank of Scotland Group Plc, amid a probe into Libor misconduct. Mohideen, who was fired in 2012, will be based in Dubai and report to Steve Ashley, head of wholesale and global markets. He previously worked at hedge fund Brevan Howard Asset Management and was involved in an instant-message conversation instructing colleagues to lower RBS's London interbank offered rate submission in 2007. Mohideen also sued RBS for racial discrimination and unfair dismissal in 2014.

site_title: OUE Lippo Healthcare expects loss for Q4 and FY17
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare Limited announced it is expected to report a net loss for Q4 and FY17, primarily due to operating costs and provisions. The group is finalizing its financial results, with further details to be disclosed on March 1.

site_title: Singapore shares tumble after Wall Street's record-breaking crash
summary: Singapore shares plummeted 2.2% on Tuesday after the Dow Jones Industrial Average posted its largest single-day drop in history, 1,175.21 points. The Straits Times Index closed at 3,406.38, with blue chips like banks and offshore marine conglomerates leading the sell-offs. Over 3.8 billion shares worth S$2.9 billion changed hands, with 518 losers outweighing 90 gainers.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Saudi Arabia working with HSBC, JPMorgan, MUFG US$10b loan refinancing
summary: Saudi Arabia is working with HSBC, JPMorgan, and Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group on the refinancing of its existing $10 billion syndicated loan. The refinancing, expected to be completed by mid-February, will include a repricing of the debt facility and a maturity extension to 2023. The deal will also involve an Islamic finance tranche using a murabaha structure. Other banks, including European, American, and Japanese banks, may participate in the loan deal, which is part of Saudi Arabia's efforts to establish a prominent position in international debt markets as part of its Vision 2030 economic reform plan.

site_title: French 2018 online sales seen topping 90 bln euros: industry body
summary: French online retail sales are expected to reach 90 billion euros in 2018, surpassing the 100 billion mark in 2019, according to the E-Commerce Federation. This represents a 14.3% year-on-year rise in 2017, when sales reached 81.7 billion euros. Mobile sales increased by 38% and sales on web-based marketplaces rose 15% in 2017. The average value of the basket fell 5% to 65.5 euros due to reduced shipping costs and unlimited delivery subscriptions.

site_title: Capital World's Q2 net profit up 90%
summary: Capital World, a Malaysian property developer, reported a 90% increase in Q2 net profit to RM17.4 million, driven by higher revenue recognition from completed projects. Revenue rose to RM46 million, and earnings per share increased to RM1.37 cents. The company cited positive developments, including a cross-border MRT system between Singapore and Malaysia, and a joint development agreement for a major oil and gas hub in South-east Asia. It also launched an indoor theme park concept and plans to form strategic partnerships.

site_title: Turkey's biggest shipper UN Ro-Ro is said to plan IPO this year
summary: Turkey's largest shipper, UN Ro-Ro, is planning an initial public offering (IPO) this year, according to sources. Actera Group and Esas Holding AS, the company's owners, are likely to work with Citigroup and Morgan Stanley on the deal. This is part of a surge in IPOs in Turkey, with around a dozen offerings expected to raise $3 billion to $4 billion in 2018, surpassing the record set in 2007.

site_title: BP profits surge as oil major leaves downturn behind
summary: BP's profits surged to $6.2 billion in 2017, more than doubling the previous year, driven by higher oil and gas prices and output. The company resumed share buybacks and reported one of the strongest output increases in its history, with production rising 12% to 2.47 million barrels per day. BP aims to continue growing production into the end of the decade, with six new projects set to start up this year, boosting output by 900,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day by 2021.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks pare losses but end at 6-week low on global rout, won skids
summary: South Korean stocks fell for the third consecutive session, ending at a six-week low, amid a global rout in US markets. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed 1.5% lower at 2,453.31 points, with Samsung Electronics and Hyundai Motors down 1% each. The South Korean won also weakened, closing at its lowest in eight weeks at 1,091.5 to the US dollar.

site_title: JTC signs MOU with 3 aerospace companies
summary: JTC signed memorandums of understanding with Hawker Pacific, GE Aviation, and PPG at the Singapore Airshow. Hawker Pacific will invest S$20 million in a new 100,000 sq ft facility, doubling its presence in Seletar Aerospace Park. GE Aviation will build a S$42 million aircraft engine component facility, while PPG relocated to Seletar with a new 4,000 sq m facility. The agreements aim to establish a diverse aerospace hub in Singapore, featuring original equipment manufacturers, maintenance, and training companies.

site_title: Ellipsiz posts jump in Q2 net income
summary: Ellipsiz, a semiconductor equipment provider, reported a significant increase in its net income for the second quarter of 2018, with a net profit of S$5.8 million, up from S$1.7 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 3% year-over-year to S$10.5 million. The company remains cautious about its performance prospects for the second half of 2018, citing a volatile operating environment, but is optimistic about growth opportunities.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Despite anger, Samsung heir Lee's release lifts hopes for new jobs, investment
summary: Samsung heir Jay Y Lee was released from jail on bribery charges after an appeals court suspended his sentence, lifting hopes for new investments and jobs from the conglomerate.
