The release has been welcomed by the business community, with many anticipating increased domestic investment and job creation. Lee's return is seen as a potential boost to the economy, but also poses a setback for President Moon Jae-in, who campaigned on cracking down on corporate ties with politicians. The Supreme Court will make a final ruling on Lee's guilt or innocence, and he will be cautious in his actions to avoid further backlash.

images.alt_text: Samsung Group heir Jay Y Lee's release from jail on bribery charges has some in South Korea hoping for new investments and jobs from the massive conglomerate, despite ongoing concerns over the cosy ties between government and business leaders.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares slump on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 40.62 points lower on Tuesday at 1,812.45, with a trading volume of 5.2 billion lots worth RM5.3 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 1,215 to 121.

site_title: Olympics: Pyeongchang ready to battle cold snap, norovirus, says Games chief Lee
summary: Pyeongchang Winter Olympics officials are preparing for the games, despite battling a norovirus outbreak among staff and a cold snap expected to hit during the opening ceremony. Around 1,200 security staff have been sidelined due to fears of the highly contagious virus, with military personnel taking their place pending medical tests. Meanwhile, temperatures are forecast to be freezing, potentially affecting some competitions and fans attending the opening ceremony. Organisers are installing wind screens and distributing warm clothing to spectators to mitigate the cold.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei index closes down 4.73% after Wall Street rout
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index plummeted 4.73% on Tuesday, its worst single-day fall since Trump's 2016 election, following a sell-off on Wall Street. The benchmark index closed at 21,610.24, while the broader Topix index slid 4.40%. A surging yen also hit exporters, contributing to the decline. The Nikkei's 7% drop earlier in the day was also the largest in percentage points since November 2016.

site_title: Singapore Airshow 2018: Over 14,000 new aircraft needed in Asia-Pacific over the next 20 years, says Airbus
summary: Airbus projects the Asia-Pacific region will need approximately 14,450 new aircraft valued at US$2.3 trillion over the next 20 years, driven by a 5.6% annual growth in passenger traffic. The region's fleet is expected to grow from 6,100 planes to nearly 17,000 in 20 years. This represents about 40% of global demand, with single-aisle planes accounting for 9,800, widebodies for 4,000, and very large aircraft for 650. Airbus sees Asia-Pacific as a core market, with the region expected to be the world's largest aviation market.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Paris opens a door to exiled artists
summary: Paris has opened its doors to exiled artists, with a drop-in centre, the Studio of Artists in Exile, helping around 200 artists navigate their new lives in France. The centre, founded by Judith Depaule, provides a space for artists to relaunch their careers, leveraging France's relatively open system for artists. French Culture Minister Francoise Nyssen has publicly backed the studio, inviting exiled artists to showcase their work, and 15 artists, including Kubra Khademi and Moneim Rahma, have been featured. The move marks a shift towards Paris becoming a haven for artists fleeing oppression, similar to its past role in the 1920s.

site_title: Soaring imports push US trade deficit to nine-year high
summary: The US trade deficit widened to its highest level since 2008, reaching $53.1 billion in December, driven by robust domestic demand and record-high imports. This marks a 5.3% increase from the previous month. The trade gap surged 12.1% to $566.0 billion in 2017, with the US-China trade deficit reaching a record $375.2 billion. US President Donald Trump has vowed to shrink the trade gap through his "America First" policies, which aim to renegotiate past free trade agreements.

site_title: Zuckerberg acknowledges 'mistakes' as Facebook turns 14
summary: Mark Zuckerberg acknowledged making numerous mistakes in building Facebook as the social network turned 14. In a post, he reflected on technical errors, bad deals, and missed trends, admitting to launching failed products. Despite criticism for enabling misinformation and manipulation, Zuckerberg stated that Facebook's purpose is to solve its greatest challenges, despite knowing they will fail again. The post suggested a continual re-evaluation of how Facebook works, with a focus on refocusing on family and friends, even if it means people spend less time on the network.

site_title: North Korean hackers could be behind US$530m digital coin theft in Japan
summary: North Korean hackers may have been behind the $530 million theft of virtual coins from a Japanese cryptocurrency exchange, according to South Korea's intelligence agency. The National Intelligence Service (NIS) flagged it as a possibility, citing the virtual coin market's size and lack of regulation as a target for North Korean hackers. However, no firm evidence confirms North Korea's involvement. This comes as Japan rushes to clean up its cryptocurrency markets and amid speculation that North Korea may be unleashing cyberattacks again.

site_title: Hong Kong, China: Stocks succumb to global market rout
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 4.9% on Tuesday, the largest daily percentage drop since August 2015, amid a global market rout fueled by inflation concerns and interest rate worries. China's main indexes also fell more than 3%, with some companies suspending trading to avoid margin calls. Despite the downturn, some investors see the slump as a buying opportunity, citing relatively low valuations in the Hong Kong stock market.

site_title: British wind project draws investment heavyweights: sources
summary: British offshore wind project Triton Knoll has attracted interest from several large investment funds, including Macquarie, Partners Group, and PFA Pension, amid growing competition for assets in the sector. The 2-billion-pound project has drawn interest due to its stable cash flows and long-term revenues, as well as declining costs due to technological advances. The returns on offer, typically 6-9%, outstrip interest rates, making it an attractive option for investors despite the decline in government subsidies.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close down more than 5%
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted over 5% on Tuesday, marking one of the worst performances since a 2015 China-fueled sell-off. The Hang Seng Index fell 5.12% to 30,595.42, its largest drop since summer 2015. The decline came amid a record-breaking collapse on Wall Street and amidst global market uncertainty.

site_title: Thales to offer in-flight entertainment system to Garuda Indonesia
summary: Thales has partnered with Garuda Indonesia to equip 14 of its new A330neo aircraft with its AVANT in-flight entertainment system, the first time the companies have collaborated. The system, based on an open Android platform, will support multiple languages and feature high-definition monitors for all passengers. Business-class passengers will also have access to Avii touchscreen handsets. The deal marks a significant upgrade for Garuda, which expects to see a double-digit increase in passenger growth in 2018. No valuation for the deal was disclosed.

images.alt_text: THALES has partnered with Garuda - Indonesia's flag carrier - for the first time, both companies announced at the Singapore Airshow on Tuesday.

site_title: Commodities dragged into global selloff as oil to copper get hit
summary: Global commodity markets experienced a sharp decline, with oil, copper, and iron ore falling due to a risk-off market tone and rising market volatility. Brent crude dropped 1.2% to $66.82 a barrel, while copper sank 2% to $7,025 a metric ton. Despite this, analysts at Citigroup and Australia & New Zealand Banking Group believe the fundamental picture remains positive for commodities, driven by solid global growth and synchronized economic expansion. They recommend adding positions in metals, particularly industrial metals, as a potential investment opportunity.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality to develop new serviced residence in Ginza, Tokyo for S$250m
summary: Frasers Hospitality is investing S$250 million to develop a new serviced residence in Tokyo's Ginza district, scheduled to open in 2020. The Capri by Fraser, Ginza will feature 200 rooms and social spaces, located near key transportation hubs and shopping streets. This marks the group's expansion into Tokyo, complementing its existing Fraser Suites Akasaka. Frasers Hospitality aims to deepen its presence in Japan and other key cities globally, with a portfolio of over 145 properties and 23,000 keys.

images.alt_text: FRASERS Hospitality, a division of Frasers Centrepoint, announced after market hours on Tuesday that it is pumping S$250 million to develop a new serviced residence in Tokyo's Ginza district.

site_title: Australia's central bank upbeat on economy, keeps policy unchanged
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) held interest rates steady at 1.5% in its first meeting of 2018, citing solid economic data and optimism about household consumption. The bank upgraded its GDP growth forecast to "a bit above 3 per cent" over the next two years, citing strong retail sales figures and a trade deficit. Despite household debt and sluggish wage growth, the RBA expects inflation to pick up gradually, with a 50-50 chance of a rate hike by November.

site_title: To baldly grow: Japan scientists regrow hair at record rate
summary: Japanese scientists at Yokohama National University have developed a method to grow hair follicles at a record rate, cultivating 5,000 "hair follicle germs" in just a few days. The technique uses silicone containers and could potentially be used to generate luscious new locks, helping cancer patients and others with medical conditions that cause hair loss. A new treatment using this method may be available in 10 years, with existing medication only slowing hair loss rather than reversing it.

site_title: Global markets sink, suggesting stock rout will go on
summary: Global markets plummeted, with Japanese shares down 6%, Hong Kong and Taiwan markets dropping 4%, and US futures signaling a 3% drop. Investors are spooked by concerns of rising US inflation and a potential trade war with China. Experts predict a prolonged sell-off, with a "decent correction" possible, and warn of risks to China's economic growth and export-oriented countries.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slump at open as panic spreads
summary: Europe's stock markets plummeted by over 3% in early trading on Tuesday, driven by fears of rising US interest rates. London's FTSE 100 sank 3.5% to 7,080.61 points, while Paris' CAC 40 and Frankfurt's DAX 30 also fell 3.4% and 3.6% respectively. The selloff continues a global trend, with US stocks also reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: European air passenger growth set to slow in 2018 after bumper 2017
summary: European air passenger numbers grew 8.5% in 2017, the fastest pace in 13 years, but are expected to slow in 2018 due to rising oil prices, airline consolidation, and Britain's exit from the EU. Passenger traffic slowed at the end of 2017, with December growth at 5%, partly due to airline insolvencies and pilot rostering issues. Airport operators face pressure as airlines become more selective about routes, and the Brexit deadline looms, potentially affecting airport capacity and growth.

images.alt_text: Passengers numbers at Europe's airports grew at the fastest pace in 13 years during 2017, but growth looks set to slow with rising oil prices, airline consolidation and Britain's exit from the European Union all presenting challenges this year.

site_title: Strong baht, higher wages may slow Thai 2018 export growth
summary: Thailand's export growth is expected to slow to 3.5% in 2018 due to a strong baht and higher wages, according to a group of shippers. The estimated growth is lower than the 5.5% predicted last month and may be cut by $5 billion if no measures are taken to address the impact of the strong baht and wage increases. The Bank of Thailand has assured that it will ensure the baht's strength does not adversely impact businesses, while the Finance Ministry predicts 2018 economic growth of 4.2% with exports up 6.6%.

images.alt_text: Thailand's exports may grow at a much slower pace of 3.5 per cent this year due to a strong baht and higher wages, after expanding nearly 10 per cent in 2017, a group of Thai shippers said on Tuesday.

site_title: British fast fashion chain New Look earnings, revenue falls
summary: British fast fashion chain New Look reported a 6.3% decline in revenue to £1.07 billion in the three quarters to December, with earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization falling to £43.8 million. The company attributed the decline to challenging sales and margins impacted by high discounts. As part of its turnaround strategy, New Look aims to exit the current financial year with clean stock levels, which will enable it to deliver a strong full-price Spring/Summer offer in 2019. The company's South African owner Brait SE has written down the value of New Look to zero until its turnaround strategy takes shape.

site_title: Bank of Japan urges cryptocurrency operators to boost security
summary: The Bank of Japan has urged cryptocurrency operators to boost security and explain risks to investors. Following the 58 billion yen theft at Coincheck, a major Japanese cryptocurrency exchange, BOJ executive director Shigehiro Kuwabara emphasized the need for safety and stability in settlement and financial services. The warning comes as policymakers struggle to regulate cryptocurrencies, which are increasingly used for investment and speculative trading.

site_title: CVS executive hired to run Hudson's Bay
summary: Hudson's Bay has hired Helena Foulkes, president of CVS' pharmacy division, as its new CEO. Foulkes aims to transform the struggling department store business by improving its digital strategy and running it more profitably. Hudson's Bay operates a smaller brick and mortar network with about 480 stores, and Foulkes will have to be innovative to succeed. The company faces challenges, including declining sales and the need to capitalize on its real estate holdings.

site_title: Toyota posts 54 per cent jump in Q3 profit, lifts full-year forecast
summary: Toyota Motor Corp reported a 54% jump in Q3 operating profit to 673.6 billion yen, exceeding analyst estimates, due to strong performance in Japan and a weaker yen. The company raised its full-year forecast to 2.2 trillion yen, a 10% increase from last year.

site_title: Singapore risks destroying past in race to build: top archaeologist
summary: Singapore is racing to preserve its past as relentless development threatens to destroy its history. Archaeologist Lim Chen Sian warns that relics from the 14th to 17th century, including trading links with China, could be lost forever. Despite some recent discoveries, the city-state lacks a state archaeologist and no law requiring archaeological evaluations before construction. Lim's work aims to uncover the secrets of pre-colonial Singapore and highlight the importance of preserving its past to maintain national identity.

site_title: Singapore Airshow 2018: CAAS, US FAA reaffirm ties, revise safety pact
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) and the US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) have signed revised Bilateral Aviation Safety Agreement - Implementation Procedures for Airworthiness (BASA-IPA) to deepen cooperation and reduce duplication in certification. The agreement, signed at the Singapore Airshow 2018, aims to enhance mutual recognition of airworthiness and reduce costs for air operators. The revisions follow the launch of the US-Singapore Joint Aviation Steering Committee in December 2017 and demonstrate the "high safety standards" upheld by both agencies.

site_title: Singapore says no strong case to ban cryptocurrency trading
summary: Singapore's central bank has found no strong case to ban cryptocurrency trading, according to Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has been studying the potential risks posed by cryptocurrencies, but has not deemed them a threat to the city-state's financial system. Shanmugaratnam described cryptocurrencies as an "experiment" with uncertain outcomes, stating that their full implications will not be known for some time.

site_title: Saudi Arabia's US$32b bid to build private mortgage market
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to spend $32 billion on subsidized home loans and loan guarantees to boost the private mortgage market, aiming to expand it by over 70% by 2020. The program includes a 6.34 billion dollar loan-guarantee program and 12.5 billion dollar home down-payment support, with the goal of increasing home ownership among Saudi citizens from 50% to 60% by 2020. The move is part of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's "Vision 2030" economic transformation plan, aiming to reduce the population's reliance on state spending.

site_title: Singapore Airshow 2018: SWISS orders Pratt & Whitney's GTF engines to power 15 Airbus aircraft
summary: Swiss International Air Lines (SWISS) has ordered Pratt & Whitney's GTF engines to power 15 Airbus A320neo and A321neo aircraft, with deliveries set to begin next year. The GTF engine reduces fuel burn by 16% and lowers noise by 75%, meeting passenger demand for efficiency. SWISS already operates 15 GTF-powered Bombardier C Series aircraft.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Singapore stocks resume Tuesday afternoon trading on lower ground; STI at 3,354.4
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Tuesday afternoon at 3,354.4, down 3.7% or 128.53 points. The Straits Times Index was down 3.78 points, or 0.11%, with 2.11 billion shares worth S$1.54 billion changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 528 to 58, with key decliners including Midas, Allied Technology, and Keppel Corp. The market closed on a negative note, with the index down 3.7% for the day.

site_title: Goldman is warning of more pain ahead. Don't listen
summary: Goldman Sachs warns of more global market volatility and pain ahead, citing potential selling from managed-futures funds and long-short strategy funds, which could lead to around $190 billion in global unwinding. However, emerging markets, particularly Asia and China, are expected to offer protection against market fluctuations, with Chinese investors continuing to buy Hong Kong stocks. Despite Goldman's warnings, some analysts argue that the US dollar's weakness and emerging markets' resilience could mitigate the impact of market volatility.

site_title: Australia shares slump most in 2-1/2 years as global equities tumble
summary: Australian shares plummeted 3.2% to a four-month low, their worst single-day drop in nearly 2-1/2 years, due to worries about inflation and higher interest rates. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,833.3, with banks accounting for most losses, including the "big four" banks and Macquarie Group. Materials also fell, despite iron ore price gains, while gold miner Regis Resources was the only stock to rise. The Australian central bank held interest rates steady at 1.5% despite solid economic data.

site_title: Chevron sells 1st condensate cargo from Australia's Wheatstone LNG
summary: Chevron has sold its first condensate cargo from Australia's Wheatstone LNG project to Thailand's PTT, with a 650,000-barrel shipment set to load in February. The cargo was sold at a small discount to dated Brent. The sale comes as the Wheatstone project, which started LNG production in October, is expected to increase production with the second train expected to come online in the second quarter of this year. This marks a significant milestone for the project, which has chartered an oil tanker to load condensate from Australia.

site_title: Pacific Mansion in River Valley up for collective sale with S$938m reserve price
summary: The owners of Pacific Mansion in River Valley are selling the condominium through a collective sale with a reserve price of S$938 million (S$1,728 per square foot per plot ratio). The freehold site has a land area of 128,352 square feet and a verified existing GFA of 493,222 sq ft. The site offers a unique opportunity for developers to design an iconic landmark development, with a 7-minute walk to Orchard Road shopping belt. The tender closes on March 16, 2018.

site_title: US Senate to spotlight cryptocurrencies as bitcoin plunges
summary: The US Senate will hold a hearing on Tuesday to discuss the regulation of cryptocurrencies, following a 15% plunge in bitcoin's value to a three-month low. Chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission Christopher Giancarlo and chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission Jay Clayton will testify on the powers of their agencies to oversee cryptocurrency exchanges and protect investors from volatility and fraud. The hearing aims to address growing concerns about the risks posed by cryptocurrencies to investors and the financial system amid global unease.

site_title: Brexit may escalate 99% price jump of Frankfurt's apartments
summary: Brexit may lead to a 99% price jump in Frankfurt's apartments as up to 10,000 financial industry workers relocate from London. This influx of new residents, combined with a lack of new supply and high demand, could drive buying prices up. Asking prices for condominiums have already increased by 10.7% in the second half of 2017, with the average price per square meter reaching 4,830 euros. This could make Frankfurt's condominium market one of the most expensive in Germany.

site_title: Bannon will not testify before House committee on Tuesday: sources
summary: Former White House senior strategist Steve Bannon will not testify before the US House Intelligence Committee on Tuesday, despite a subpoena, due to a lack of authorization from the White House. This decision could lead to Bannon facing a charge of contempt of Congress. Bannon had previously refused to answer questions during a January appearance, citing executive privilege. The committee is investigating allegations of Russian influence in the 2016 presidential election, and Bannon is expected to appear before Special Counsel Robert Mueller next week.

site_title: Lululemon seeks new leader after CEO's misconduct leads to exit
summary: Lululemon Athletica Inc. CEO Laurent Potdevin resigned abruptly on Monday after unprofessional behavior, leading to a cloud of misconduct. He will receive a $5 million payment and leave with a lump-sum cash payment of $3.35 million and $1.65 million in installments. Chairman Glenn Murphy will now lead the company, while three senior leaders will take on additional responsibilities. The company's shares fell 10% in late trading, dealing a blow to the company's recent upswing. Lululemon reaffirmed its forecast, expecting a profit of $1.25 to $1.27 per share and revenue of up to $915 million.

site_title: India likely to continue sugar exports in 2018-2019 season
summary: India is likely to continue exporting sugar in the 2018-2019 season, with the exportable quantity to be best understood around July 2018. The Indian sugar industry is expected to export 1 million tonnes in the 2017-2018 marketing year, with production estimates for the year increasing by 4% to 26.1 million tonnes. India, the world's largest consumer of sugar, is expected to consume 25 million tonnes, allowing for export of surplus sugar. The 2018-2019 production estimate is too early to determine, as only 20% of planting has taken place.

site_title: BNP Paribas Q4 profits dip from year ago, yet bank sees improving earnings
summary: BNP Paribas reported a 1.2% decrease in quarterly earnings to 1.43 billion euros, below analyst expectations, due to higher costs and provisions against corporate clients. Despite this, the French bank increased its 2020 profitability target, now aiming for a return on equity above 10%. The bank cited a "gradually stronger European growth" as a driving factor, and confirmed its 2020 targets. Revenues fell 1.2% to 10.53 billion euros.

images.alt_text: BNP Paribas slightly increased its 2020 profitability target on the back of a strengthening European economy, although its quarterly earnings came below expectations due to higher costs and provisions against two specific corporate clients.

site_title: Dow plunge: How is it affecting the Singapore stock market?
summary: The Singapore stock market, represented by the Straits Times Index (STI), plummeted 3.5% on Tuesday, following a global stock rout led by the worst point plunge in the US Dow benchmark. The drop was attributed to concerns over higher wages driving inflation and the potential for faster interest rate hikes. Other Asian markets also fell, with Tokyo's Nikkei down 5.17% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng down 3.77%. Analysts believe the sell-off is a "healthy" correction, but some warn of potential further declines.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Australian retail sales dim in Dec, but Q4 bright
summary: Australian retail sales eased 0.5% in December, beating expectations, as online discounting events brought spending forward. Household goods led the falls, while department stores, clothing, and restaurants posted losses. However, retail sales rebounded 0.9% in the fourth quarter, improving the outlook for gross domestic product growth. This follows a 0.1% gain in the previous quarter, which was the slowest pace since 2008. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to keep interest rates at 1.50% in its first meeting of 2018.

images.alt_text: Australian retail sales eased more than expected in December after a barnstorming couple of months, but still posted a smart rebound in the final quarter of 2017 in a positive sign for household consumption and economic growth.

site_title: Singapore Airshow 2018: Booming aircraft leasing sector set for shakeout, says AerCap chief
summary: Singapore Airshow 2018: The aircraft leasing sector is expected to see a shakeout due to rising interest rates and intense competition, according to AerCap CEO Aengus Kelly. The industry has seen rapid growth, with Chinese capital now accounting for 28% of the global market, up from 5% nine years ago. New entrants are struggling with challenges, and analysts predict consolidation, with winners and losers emerging over time. Kelly expects pressure on newer lessors as interest rates rise, and notes that the ability to move airplanes and know their value is crucial to success in the industry.

site_title: Australia central bank holds rates at 1.5%
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) held its cash rate at 1.5% on Tuesday, as expected by analysts. This decision follows a steady outlook for the economy, with no significant changes in monetary policy. The decision aims to maintain economic growth and inflation control.

images.alt_text: Australia's central bank left its cash rate at 1.5 per cent on Tuesday, a widely expected decision given policy makers have signalled a steady outlook for some time to come.

site_title: German renewable power expansion will need gas as back-up:Wingas
summary: Germany aims to nearly double renewable power's share of its electricity mix to 65% by 2030, but gas-fired capacity will be needed as a back-up due to the volatile nature of weather-driven renewables. The country's fossil fuels-based capacity is expected to drop to 72 GW by 2020-23, requiring additional gas-fired capacity to meet demand. A new law to achieve more general climate goals is set to be implemented in 2019, and the industry is pushing for gas to be used more in heating homes and heavy vehicles.

site_title: Parliament: Govt has not ruled out other methods to fund T5, says Indranee
summary: Singapore's government has not ruled out alternative funding methods for Changi Airport's Terminal 5, according to Senior Minister of State for Finance Indranee Rajah. The government is exploring the most optimal way to fund the project, which may involve additional fees for passengers, and will review large-scale infrastructure projects through a rigorous process. This process includes scrutiny by the ministry, a Development Planning Committee, and public reviews to ensure the project's strategic business case and design are met.

site_title: 'Frasier' dad John Mahoney dies at 77
summary: Actor John Mahoney, best known for his role as Martin Crane in the TV sitcom "Frasier", has died at 77 due to complications from cancer while in hospice care in Chicago. Mahoney played the iconic character for 11 seasons until 2004 and won numerous acting accolades, including Emmy and Golden Globe nominations. A longtime member of the Steppenwolf Theatre Company, Mahoney appeared in over 30 productions, including the 1985 performance in "Orphans". His impact on Chicago theater and the world of arts and entertainment will endure.

images.alt_text: Actor John Mahoney, who portrayed the no-nonsense father in the TV sitcom "Frasier", has died in Chicago at the age of 77, his longtime theatre company said Monday.

site_title: German metalworkers win limited 28-hour week concession
summary: German metalworkers have won a limited concession of a 28-hour workweek for up to 6-24 months, with full-time salaries guaranteed upon return. Around 900,000 workers, mostly in the automotive sector, will benefit from the agreement. The union pushed for flexible working conditions, and employers agreed to salary increases, but rejected financial compensation for reduced hours. The deal is seen as a partial victory for both sides, potentially staving off fresh strikes after a week of walkouts in February.

site_title: Bitcoin drops below US$6,200 for first time in three months
summary: Bitcoin plummeted 20% to a three-month low of $6,190, its lowest point since mid-November, amid a series of setbacks and regulatory clampdowns. The collapse follows a record high of $19,511 in January, fueled by speculators. Concerns over government crackdowns, debt concerns, and rising US borrowing costs have led to a global rout, with investors cashing in profits and banks shutting down credit card purchases. Experts warn of a potential "full round trip" back to $1,850-$2,966.

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC upgrades Hutchison Port Holdings Trust to 'buy'
summary: OCBC Investment Research upgraded Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (HPH Trust) to 'buy' from 'hold', raising its fair value estimate to US$0.43 from US$0.42. The analysts view the group's FY17 results as within expectations, with 8% year-on-year increase in full-year throughput. They believe the recent regulatory measures will have a muted impact on the industry and that the 7% price correction on Feb 2 was an over-reaction. Single-digit throughput growth in FY18 is forecast, with interest costs as the main headwind.

site_title: Robots may affect 30% of UK jobs; finance to take early hit: PwC
summary: PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) predicts that 30% of UK jobs will be affected by automation by the mid-2030s, with financial services workers initially hit hardest. Women are expected to feel the effects earlier, while men will be more impacted in the third wave. Higher-educated workers may face job losses, but the less qualified will be exposed in the long run. PwC Chief Economist John Hawksworth believes the change will be positive for the British economy, with AI and robotics generating new jobs and contributing to GDP growth.

site_title: Singapore and Malaysia to set up stock market trading link by end-2018
summary: Singapore and Malaysia plan to establish a stock market trading link by the end of 2018, allowing investors to trade and settle shares in both markets more conveniently and efficiently. The link will cover trading, clearing, and settlement of stocks, and is expected to lower trading costs and encourage cross-border investments. The move is part of Asean's efforts to deepen financial connectivity, with a combined market capitalization of over $1.2 trillion and 1,600 listed companies.

site_title: Brexit hit to UK food prices pushes up spending in January: BRC retailers group
summary: Britain's shoppers spent 0.6% more on food in January, matching the growth in December and November, amid rising inflation since the Brexit vote. Non-food sales fell 1.2% over the three months to January, marking a smaller decline than in December. Overall spending rose 3.9% annually, driven by a 4.4% increase in supermarket spending. Retailers attribute the growth to consumers absorbing food price inflation, but note that wages are still falling in real terms, and inflation is expected to ease this year.

site_title: Singapore Airshow 2018: BOC Aviation orders 12 GTF engines from Pratt & Whitney
summary: BOC Aviation has ordered 12 Geared Turbofans (GTF) engines from Pratt & Whitney at the Singapore Airshow 2018 to power the new Airbus A320NEO family aircraft. This deal comes as the companies celebrate 20 years of business together. The fuel-efficient engines will support BOC Aviation's fleet and are expected to enhance the airline's operations. The list price of the deal was not disclosed.

site_title: Asia: Markets plunge as Wall Street rout spreads
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Tuesday, following a record-breaking loss on Wall Street, as investors fret over rising US borrowing costs and cashing in profits. Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Sydney led the collapse, with Tokyo diving over 5% and Hong Kong down almost 4%. The Dow suffered its worst points fall in history, wiping out 2018 gains. Growing concern over elevated US Treasury bond yields and potential Federal Reserve interest rate hikes contributed to the heavy selling. Other Asian markets, including Singapore, Seoul, Taipei, Manila, and Shanghai, also fell.

site_title: SpaceX poised to launch 'world's most powerful rocket'
summary: SpaceX is set to launch its Falcon Heavy rocket, the world's most powerful operational rocket, on Tuesday from Cape Canaveral, Florida. The maiden launch, dubbed a "game-changer" by industry experts, aims to propel the California-based company to the front of the modern space race. The rocket, essentially three Falcon 9 rockets in one, will carry a Tesla car and a mannequin into deep space, with a potential future mission to ferry people to the Moon or Mars. The launch, despite Musk's caution about potential failure, is expected to be a historic success, with SpaceX already a top cargo supplier to the International Space Station.

site_title: 3,664 BTO flats launched in Choa Chu Kang, Woodlands, Geylang and Tampines
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched 3,664 Built-To-Order (BTO) flats in four estates, including Choa Chu Kang, Woodlands, Geylang, and Tampines, as its first exercise of 2018. The flats, ranging from 2-room Flexi to 5-room units, are priced from S$71,000 to S$429,000. This is the first tranche of 17,000 BTO flats expected in 2018, and marks the introduction of an open kitchen concept in many units.

site_title: NYC dives into tough neighbourhoods, emerges as safest big city
summary: New York City has become the safest big city in the US, recording 24 consecutive years of falling crime. The city's 325 public-housing developments, including Tompkins Houses in Brooklyn, have seen a 22% drop in murders, robberies, and shootings since 2013. Mayor Bill de Blasio attributes the success to a combination of community policing and non-profit groups addressing social needs. The city's 85% drop in violent offenses since 1990 outperforms other major American cities. New York's use of "violence interrupters" and non-police crime prevention strategies has been particularly effective.

site_title: How a driverless future threatens the iron laws of real estate
summary: The rise of driverless cars threatens to disrupt the real estate industry, which has long relied on transportation links to determine property values. Advances in transport have consistently increased land values, but autonomous vehicles could change this calculus. With cars no longer needed for 95% of the time, investors are rethinking the use of space freed up by driverless technology, potentially leading to a shift towards warehouses, apartments, and outlying areas. While some see this as a threat, others believe it will bring relief to commuters and enable new development opportunities.

site_title: Singapore Airshow 2018: CAAS inks 3 pacts to advance air traffic management
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) signed three agreements at the Singapore Airshow 2018 to advance air traffic management. The first partnership will explore a space-based VHF communications system with ST Electronics and GomSpace, aiming to improve safety and reduce separation between aircraft. The second agreement with Eurocontrol will facilitate cooperation on ATM-related areas. The third partnership with The Mitre Corporation will develop machine learning techniques to enhance air traffic control operators' performance. These collaborations aim to improve ATM capabilities and support growing air traffic in the region.

images.alt_text: (From left to right) Tang Kum Chuen, president of satellite systems, ST Electronics; Soh Poh Theen, deputy director-general (Air Navigation Services), CAAS ; and Børge Witthøft, chief commercial officer, GomSpace; sign a research collaboration agreement to conduct a design study on the implementation of space-based VHF communications for air traffic management in the Singapore FIR.

site_title: Paul Simon announces farewell from touring
summary: Folk rock legend Paul Simon has announced his farewell tour, citing 50 years of touring and its toll on his personal life as the reason for his decision. The 76-year-old will open the tour on May 16 in Vancouver and conclude on July 15 in London's Hyde Park. Simon, who has released critically acclaimed albums such as "Graceland" and "Stranger to Stranger," will perform occasional concerts after his farewell tour to support causes he cares about, but has ruled out a full-time music career.

site_title: Heavy snow disrupts flights, classes in Spain
summary: Heavy snow in Spain caused disruptions on Monday, with 70 flights cancelled at Madrid's airport and tens of thousands of schoolchildren forced to skip class. The airport's runways were closed due to the weather, but reopened later in the day. Schools and bus routes were also closed in several regions, affecting over 38,000 students. Railway lines and roads across the country were closed, with similar disruptions reported in previous weeks, including a recent snow-induced emergency that required 250 soldiers to rescue people trapped in their vehicles.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares fell on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 35.06 points to 1,818.01. Losers outnumbered gainers 741 to 29, with a total of 396.1 million lots traded worth RM145.8 million.

site_title: No more security screening, baggage checks for Singapore travellers who transit in Europe
summary: Singapore travellers transiting through European airports, including Schiphol in Amsterdam, will no longer face security checks or baggage screening. The One-Stop Security arrangement, the first between Europe and an Asian nation, aims to improve transfer connections and efficiency in airline and airport operations. The partnership, sealed in a deal during the Singapore Airshow 2018, will bring benefits to air travellers and stakeholders flying between Singapore and Europe, and strengthen international cooperation on aviation security and facilitation.

site_title: Addvalue to develop broadband products with Beijing-based satellite partner
summary: ADDVALUE Technologies partners with a Beijing-based company, Huaan Xingke Information Technology, to develop and distribute satellite broadband products for fishing vessels in China and South-east Asia. The collaboration aims to integrate China Beidou navigation and satellite communications technology, with expected combined revenue of over $12 million over three years. An initial order of $1 million is expected to be fulfilled within 2018.

site_title: Singapore Airshow 2018: Honeywell, Singapore Airlines Group seal 3 long-term deals
summary: Honeywell has signed three long-term contracts with the Singapore Airlines Group to improve operational capabilities. The deals cover 30 of Singapore Airlines' Airbus A350s for 12 years, Scoot's new Airbus A320neo aircraft for 12 years, and SilkAir's Boeing 737 MAX aircraft for 15 years with an option for a five-year extension. The agreements include predictive maintenance technologies, 24/7 engineering and maintenance support, and connectivity and data analytics to improve on-time departures and customer experience.

images.alt_text: Honeywell has signed three long-term contracts with the Singapore Airlines Group to help improve the operational capabilities of the group's Singapore Airlines, SilkAir and Scoot carriers.

site_title: Singapore shares open down on Tuesday; STI falls 2.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 2.21% on Tuesday, closing at 3,406.09 points, as global equity markets continued to decline. The drop was attributed to concerns over elevated Treasury yields and potential Federal Reserve interest rate hikes. The largest losers included DBS, CapitaLand, OCBC Bank, Singtel, and Genting Singapore. The decline was part of a broader global market downturn, with stocks in Japan and Australia also falling.

site_title: Del Monte Pacific to list unit on Philippines exchange
summary: Del Monte Pacific Limited (DMPL) plans to list its wholly-owned Philippines subsidiary, Del Monte Philippines Inc (DMPI), on the Philippines Stock Exchange. The listing aims to repay loan facilities and for general corporate purposes. DMPL will retain ownership of at least 67% of DMPI for five years. The company expects a one-time gain of approximately US$304 million from the offering, which will allow it to deleverage and strengthen its balance sheet. The offering will consist of about 559.5 million shares, with an estimated maximum offering price of PhP29.88 (S$0.763) per share.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Kashkari says needs to see faster wage and price growth
summary: Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank President Neel Kashkari said he needs to see faster wage and price growth before supporting further monetary policy tightening. Despite recent signs of a strengthening economy and rising inflation, Kashkari wants to see inflation climb back to the Fed's 2% target before raising rates. He expressed optimism about the Trump administration's tax overhaul, but noted that its long-term impact is still uncertain. Kashkari also stated that the Fed should leave rates alone until data shows stronger inflation.

site_title: China's willingness to defend its stock markets put to the test
summary: China's stock markets face a test as the US stock market plummets, with the Shanghai Composite Index rising 0.7% despite a record points decline in the Dow Jones Industrial Average. Mainland investors injected $1.6 billion into Hong Kong stocks, limiting losses. China's Securities Regulatory Commission urged brokerages to ask investors to add collateral when share prices drop below critical levels. The move aims to mitigate risk and prevent steep declines in the market, which has already been shaken by tightened scrutiny of the asset management industry.

site_title: Europe: Inflation threat deepens equity sell-off
summary: European stocks fell 1.6% on Monday, marking its sixth straight decline, due to growing inflation expectations and rising bond yields. The Stoxx 600 hit its lowest level since mid-November 2017, with only Spain and Italy's markets still higher than at the turn of the year. The sell-off was driven by a surge in bond yields, particularly affecting sectors with high-dividend paying stocks. Company earnings provided little comfort, with earnings misses outnumbering beats for the first time since 2014.

site_title: Trump lauds 'tidal wave of good news' while Dow plummets
summary: US stocks plummeted 1,175 points, the largest drop in over six years, as the Dow Jones Industrial Average closed down 1,597 points during President Donald Trump's speech at a Cincinnati-area manufacturer. Despite the market downturn, Trump praised the economy, citing a "tidal wave of good news," and highlighted the Republican tax overhaul and its impact on employee bonuses and wages. The White House issued a statement focusing on long-term economic fundamentals, downplaying the market's volatility.

site_title: Lloyds Bank to ban credit card customers from buying cryptocurrencies
summary: Lloyds Bank will ban its credit card customers from buying bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies, effective Monday. The move is aimed at preventing customers from incurring huge losses due to price fluctuations. Credit card transactions involving cryptocurrency purchases will be flagged and blocked, while debit cards will still be allowed. This decision comes amidst global regulatory concerns and the recent decline in cryptocurrency prices, with bitcoin sliding below $8,000.

site_title: Yoma's Q3 profit surges to S$16.8m following spin-off of tourism business
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings reported a third-quarter net profit of S$16.75 million, a 50-fold increase from the same period last year, driven by gains from the disposal of its tourism-related businesses and higher revenue from its automotive, consumer, and investment sectors. Revenue rose 0.1% to S$24.1 million, with the automotive and heavy equipment business contributing 74% of the total revenue. The company holds a 47.6% stake in Memories Group, which was listed on the Singapore Exchange Catalist board in January.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yoma, Netlink Trust, TIH, a-iTrust, Del Monte Pacific, ComfortDelGro
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings recorded a 50-fold surge in Q3 net profit to S$16.75 million. Netlink NBN Trust posted a 32.5% increase in Q3 profit to S$21.7 million. TIH's takeover offer by Lippo Group was deemed "not fair" by Tata Capital Markets. a-iTrust raised its private placement to S$100 million after being two times subscribed. Del Monte Pacific plans to list its Philippine subsidiary on the Philippines Stock Exchange. ComfortDelGro is buying 217 taxi licences and vehicles for S$15 million to grow its fleet.

site_title: Tokyo stocks plunge 5% as Wall Street rout hits Asia; STI down 2.8%
summary: Asian stocks plummeted on Tuesday, following a historic sell-off on Wall Street, with the Nikkei 225 index down 5.17% and the Straits Times Index down 2.8%. The sell-off was triggered by rising US bond yields, which raised concerns about inflation and potential interest rate hikes. European shares also tumbled, and investors are closing positions in other assets, including the currency market and junk bonds. The sell-off is seen as a sign of market instability, with some analysts warning that the specter of inflation will undermine the attraction of equities.

site_title: Advance SCT to issue 3b fewer shares, gain loan extension under new debt plan
summary: Advance SCT has agreed to issue 3 billion fewer shares to creditors as part of changes to its debt capitalisation plan. The plan, which previously involved issuing 8.95 billion shares, will now cover S$11.19 million of debt with the issuance of 22.37 million shares. The company's new debt plan includes a one-year loan extension to Aug 15, 2019, with no additional interest. The changes were made after the original assignee, Zhang Baoan, terminated his assignment and assigned S$4.5 million of his claims to new parties.

site_title: SIA Engineering forms engine overhaul joint venture with GE Aviation
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) has formed a joint venture with GE Aviation to establish an engine overhaul company in Singapore. The 51-49% joint venture will combine GE's design and innovation strengths with SIAEC's maintenance expertise, leveraging robotics, digitalization, and data analytics. The state-of-the-art facility will cater to next-generation aircraft, including the GE9X engine powering the Boeing 777X. The partnership positions Singapore as the only place in Asia-Pacific with significant engine overhaul capabilities from top three original equipment manufacturers.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks plunge almost four percent at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted almost four percent at the open on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 3.77% to 31,028.68. This follows months of strong gains globally, and traders are reacting to market uncertainty. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also fell, with the Shanghai Composite Index down 1.99% to 3,418.01. The decline is attributed to global market routs and ongoing US-China trade tensions.

site_title: New Wave to acquire Alutech Metals Asiatic for S$2.8m
summary: New Wave Holdings has agreed to acquire Alutech Metals Asiatic Pte Ltd for S$2.8 million. The investment holding company's Chinese subsidiary primarily trades in aluminium alloy and steel products. The acquisition is part of New Wave's strategic plan to expand its aluminium product distribution business and tap into the target group's marketing strength in China. The deal, conditional on due diligence and regulatory approvals, will make Alutech Metals Asiatic a wholly-owned subsidiary of New Wave.

site_title: Australia: Stocks down 2.58% at the open
summary: Australian stocks fell 2.58% at the open on Tuesday, following Wall Street's largest one-day point drop in history. The S&P/ASX 200 dropped 155.7 points to 5,870.5, breaching the 6,000-point mark for the first time in almost a decade. Analysts attribute the sell-off to the US market's decline, but expect the upcoming company reporting season to help soften the blow, potentially limiting the local market's decline.

site_title: How a roaring economy set off the market plunge
summary: The US stock market experienced a significant plunge in February 2018, with the Dow falling 1,100 points, or 4.6%, due to investors' concerns that President Trump's stimulus measures would lead to overheating the economy and force the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates faster than expected. Critics argue that the market's downward turn is not a sign of failure, but rather a correction. Analysts, including Ray Dalio and Scott Minerd, suggest that the market's fall is a temporary correction and that the economy may be heading towards a recession, potentially around 2020.

site_title: Credit traders are hedging like mad amid the stock-market plunge
summary: Credit traders are significantly increasing hedging amid a stock-market plunge, with US bluechip corporate bond spreads rising 11% to 55 basis points, the largest since March 2018. Investors are cutting risk due to concerns over rising US wages and inflation, as well as potential Federal Reserve rate hikes. This surge in hedging activity has led to increased trading volume in credit derivatives, with over 300% more trading volume than usual for Mondays. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note also increased to 2.72%, its highest level since January 2014.

site_title: US dollar holds firm as investors seek safety from rout in equity markets
summary: The US dollar strengthened on Tuesday as investors sought safety from a rout in global equities, with the euro falling 0.7% to its lowest level in three months. The dollar index rose to an 11-day high, boosted by a strong US employment report and a sell-off in global markets. The euro's decline was attributed to investors unwinding long positions, while the dollar benefited from its perceived safe-haven status.

images.alt_text: The US dollar stood tall on Tuesday as a rout in global equities prompted anxious investors to seek shelter in the relative safety of the greenback, with peers like the euro on the defensive.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars sideswiped in global dash to safety
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars suffered significant losses on Tuesday, with the Aussie falling 0.5% and the Kiwi falling 0.5% against the US dollar. The global stock market rout and decline in commodity prices led investors to seek safe-haven assets, driving up the value of the Japanese yen. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to keep interest rates at 1.5% after the policy meeting, and the timing of a potential rate hike has been pushed out to November.

site_title: Clone of US services sector sees record growth in January: survey
summary: The US services sector expanded at a record pace in January, driven by surging new orders and rising employment, according to a business survey. The Institute for Supply Management's non-manufacturing index jumped 3.9 points to 59.9%, the highest since 2008, exceeding analyst forecasts. This growth marked the 96th month of uninterrupted expansion and is seen as a positive sign for the economy, with analysts predicting 2018 may be the year inflation finally rises above central bank targets.

images.alt_text: The US services sector expanded at a record pace in January, springing to life after slowing for two straight months, according to a business survey released Monday.

site_title: Chill out in Norway with music from ice instruments
summary: At the 13th Ice Music Festival in Norway, musicians perform on ice instruments carved from blocks extracted from a frozen lake, despite the instruments melting during play. The festival, held in a giant igloo, features unique performances, including a horn made from ice and a didgeridoo-shaped wind instrument. Organizers moved the festival to a location with guaranteed freezing temperatures after the previous venue's ice became too slushy to work with.

site_title: Asean needs to fix its digital divide
summary: ASEAN's digital economy growth is hindered by a significant digital divide among member states. Despite widespread internet and mobile phone usage, some countries like Cambodia and Laos have low user density and limited adoption of digital technologies. The region also struggles with uneven public delivery systems, regulatory frameworks, and skills training, making it challenging to compete with more advanced economies like China and India. To address these issues, Singapore, as Asean chair, has proposed initiatives to improve regulations, infrastructure, and workforce development, but more work is needed to bridge the digital divide and remain competitive in the global digital economy.

site_title: In court clash, Waymo says Uber decided 'to cheat' to get ahead
summary: Uber's founder Travis Kalanick allegedly made a decision to "cheat" to get ahead in the autonomous driving industry, according to Waymo's lawyer, Charles Verhoeven. Uber denies the allegations, which stem from a lawsuit claiming that former Google executive Anthony Levandowski stole trade secrets. The trial seeks at least $1 billion in damages for Waymo. If Uber prevails, it could impact its efforts to deploy self-driving vehicles.

site_title: China's soaring natural gas output still unable to meet demand
summary: China's natural gas output reached a record 147.4 billion cubic meters in 2017, up 8.5% from 2016, but still unable to meet the surge in demand driven by a government program to switch from coal to gas to reduce emissions. The country's gas imports are expected to rise to 317 billion cubic meters by 2020, with imports projected to reach 132 billion cubic meters. Despite holding the world's largest reserves of shale natural gas, production growth is limited by geological and technological difficulties, with shale output forecast to reach just 15 billion cubic meters by 2020.

site_title: Manulife US Reit's Q4 rights-adjusted DPU flat at 1.42 cents; beats forecast by 7.6%
summary: Manulife US Reit's Q4 rights-adjusted distribution per unit (DPU) remained flat at 1.42 US cents, beating the forecast by 7.6%. Net property income rose 48.9% to US$18.4 million, and gross revenue grew 51.5% to US$29.3 million. The Reit acquired two properties, Plaza and Exchange, contributing to the growth. The portfolio valuation increased by US$48.9 million, with assets under management (AUM) rising 57.4% to over US$1.3 billion.

site_title: Amara's 5-star hotel in Shanghai opens
summary: Amara Holdings' 5-star hotel in Shanghai, Amara Signature Shanghai, has officially opened for business after years of delays. The hotel features 343 rooms, a retail mall, and a Grade A office tower, with the office and mall set to open in the third quarter. The hotel has already started generating revenue, with co-working space operator Kr Space signing a 10-year lease for the entire office block. CEO Albert Teo aims to ramp up operations quickly, citing positive operating cashflows from Amara's last overseas hotel, Amara Bangkok.

images.alt_text: Amara Signature Shanghai in Puxi comprises a 343-room luxury hotel and a 10,500 square metre adjacent complex comprising a retail mall and Grade A office tower, both of which will open in Q3.

site_title: Singapore will wither if society is rigid and stratified by class: PM
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong warned that a rigid and stratified social system could lead to a fractured society and a "withering" of the country if income inequalities are not addressed. The government will continue to support the less well-off to ensure social mobility and integration, regardless of race, language, or social background. This is crucial to maintaining social cohesion and economic stability.

images.alt_text: Mr Lee said every citizen in a fair, just society must have chance to do better and move up in society, based on his efforts and talent.

site_title: Post-Davos depression
summary: A World Economic Forum attendee expresses deep disillusionment with the global elite's response to pressing issues like inequality, climate change, and democracy erosion. Despite CEOs' rhetoric about values and social responsibility, they prioritized tax cuts for corporations and the wealthy, ignoring the negative impact on the middle class and the environment. This prioritization reflects a narrow, materialistic worldview that neglects the failures of trickle-down economics and the importance of regulations to ensure corporate social responsibility.

site_title: Chinese developers' land-buying spree in HK winding down
summary: Mainland Chinese developers' land-buying spree in Hong Kong is slowing down, with 11% of sold land purchased in the first 10 months of 2018, down from 53% in 2016. Tighter capital controls and increased scrutiny are cited as reasons for the decline. Despite this, land prices are still rising, indicating higher housing prices in the already overheated market. Notable buyers, such as HNA Group, are now inviting outside investors to purchase land, while Wharf Holdings recently bought land for potentially record-high prices.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust's private placement two times subscribed, issues more new units
summary: Ascendas India Trust's private placement has been oversubscribed, with the number of new units to be issued increasing from 73 million to 97.4 million. The placement is valued at about S$100 million, up from S$75 million, and will be used to repay a bridging loan and existing debts. The new units will start trading on Feb 14, reducing the trust's gearing from 35.1% to 29.4%.

site_title: Nissan plans to pump 60b yuan into China business, eyes top 3 spot
summary: Nissan plans to invest 60 billion yuan (S$12.5 billion) in its China business over the next five years, aiming to boost its vehicle production to 2.6 million units per year by 2022, making it a top-three carmaker in the world's largest market. The company plans to focus on electric cars and the Venucia brand, which it hopes will compete with low-cost indigenous Chinese brands. Nissan aims to sell 1.6 million Venucia vehicles annually by 2022, up from 143,000 last year, and plans to launch 20 electrified vehicle models by 2022.

images.alt_text: "We need to go full-throttle aggressive," Mr Seki says. "If we didn't do that, we would fall behind and fail to grab market share otherwise we could take."

site_title: Gold steadies after Friday's slide on lower stock markets
summary: Gold prices steadied on Monday after a 1.2% drop on Friday, following a strong US payrolls report that boosted the US dollar and inflation concerns. Spot gold settled at $1,334.40 an ounce, still below its 17-month high. Analysts predict gold will be seen as an inflation hedge, but recent profit-taking moves in the stock market may keep a rally muted. Gold purchases ahead of the Chinese Lunar New Year also supported prices.

images.alt_text: Gold prices steadied on Monday as a slide in stock markets helped the precious metal claw back some lost ground after logging its biggest one-day loss in two months in the previous session.

site_title: Oil closes lower as stock market plunges, stronger dollar weighs
summary: Oil prices closed lower on Monday, with Brent crude futures falling 96 cents, or 1.4%, to $67.62 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude settling down $1.30, or 1.99%, to $64.15. The decline was driven by a stronger US dollar, rising US output, and a weaker physical market, following a volatile trading session in the stock market. Despite concerns over rising US crude production, analysts see the correction as a bullish economic news-driven event, potentially leading to oil price stability.

site_title: Trade barriers 'unavoidable' for UK after Brexit: Barnier
summary: EU's Michel Barnier warns that trade barriers are "unavoidable" for the UK if it leaves the single market and customs union after Brexit. He proposes a transition period for Britain to access the single market and customs union temporarily, allowing businesses to adapt. UK Brexit minister David Davis is "confident" an agreement can be reached by March, seeking a "frictionless" trade deal with the EU. The EU awaits an official position from the UK government on the future partnership.

images.alt_text: The EU's chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier on Monday warned trade barriers were "unavoidable" for Britain once it leaves the EU if it also quits the single market and customs union as planned.

site_title: Robots as building blocks of SME success
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need to accelerate technology adoption among smaller companies, citing the country's "lag" in electronic payments and Smart Nation push. SMEs contribute to nearly half of the country's GDP and make up 99% of enterprises, making them a crucial segment of the economy. The government aims to do more to support their transformation and "live smart at every age."

images.alt_text: Researchers from The Singapore University of Technology and Design have been awarded S$7.5 million under the National Robotics Programme to develop robots to clean hawker centres, pavements and drains.

site_title: Ten Greek ex-ministers allegedly involved in Novartis bribery probe
summary: Greek ex-ministers allegedly involved in a Novartis bribery probe have been implicated, with two former prime ministers and eight former ministers implicated in the scandal. The probe, launched in 2016, involves scores of people and a Novartis manager who was banned from leaving the country. Novartis has cooperated with authorities and issued a statement acknowledging media reports about its business practices. The case follows previous investigations by US authorities and a settlement with a Chinese subsidiary. Greek anti-corruption prosecutors have asked parliament to hand over files related to the alleged bribery.

images.alt_text: Two former Greek prime ministers and eight former ministers have been implicated in an alleged corruption scandal involving Swiss pharmaceutical giant Novartis, a judicial source said Monday.

site_title: US tax overhaul could see $2.0 trillion repatriated: UN
summary: The US tax overhaul could prompt US multinationals to repatriate around $2.0 trillion, significantly impacting global foreign direct investment. The reform, which slashes the corporate tax rate to 21%, may entice businesses to return with higher profits. This could lead to increased global tax competition and potentially trigger tax reforms worldwide. The repatriation of funds could reduce investible funds for future projects, but the impact remains unclear, with most of the affected cash stored in offshore financial centers.

site_title: As US stocks plummet, Trump goes silent on role in markets
summary: US stocks plummeted on Monday, falling to below 24,000, as President Donald Trump remained silent on his role in the market's decline. Contrasting with his previous praise for the "Trump rally," Trump did not mention stocks in a speech in Ohio. Former White House advisers and economists criticized Trump for focusing on the stock market, saying it distracts from the real economy. The Dow Jones industrial average has erased its gains since late November, and the S&P 500 has pulled back over 6% from its record high.

images.alt_text: As US stocks plunged on Monday, President Donald Trump was speaking at an event in Ohio but noticeably not taking credit for the market despite doing so repeatedly when stocks were rising.

site_title: US services sector sees record growth in January: survey
summary: The US services sector expanded at a record pace in January, driven by surging new orders and rising employment. The Institute for Supply Management's non-manufacturing index jumped 3.9 points to 59.9%, the highest since 2008, surpassing analyst forecasts. The growth was driven by industries such as arts and entertainment, retail, and healthcare, with 15 of 18 surveyed services industries reporting growth. The record expansion marked the 96th month of uninterrupted growth and may indicate a pickup in inflation, with analysts predicting 2018 could be the year inflation rises above central bank targets.

site_title: US: Dow ends down 4.6% after brutal session
summary: US stocks plummeted 4.6% on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling to 24,346.13, its steepest one-day point drop. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also fell 4.1% and 3.8% respectively. The decline came amid concerns over elevated Treasury bond yields and potential Federal Reserve interest rate increases this year, following a week of shaky market performance.

site_title: Developers paid S$380m in ABSD, QC extension charges
summary: Developers in Singapore have paid a total of S$380 million in additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) and qualifying certificate (QC) extension charges for not selling all residential units within stipulated deadlines as of end-2017. This amount includes S$200 million in ABSD fees and S$180 million in QC extension charges since the regimes were introduced. The fees are seen as less of a concern now due to the recovery in residential transactions.

site_title: India's pre-election budget is long on promises, but short on sums
summary: India's finance minister Arun Jaitley presented a pre-election budget that focused on promises rather than specifics, aiming to win rural votes and ease tax burdens. Prime Minister Narendra Modi appeared on national TV after the address, emphasizing the budget's benefits for the common man. The budget aimed to address the government's poor fiscal deficit management while avoiding controversy. Jaitley's move was seen as an attempt to distract from the government's performance issues.

site_title: Hack your pile of business cards: Japanese startup
summary: A Japanese startup, Sansan, has developed a platform that scans and tracks business cards to generate business leads. The platform allows users to scan their cards, track relationships, and connect with others. This approach aims to simplify the process of exchanging contact information and foster new business opportunities.

site_title: Beijing inches closer to becoming the world's busiest airport
summary: Beijing's international airport set a new record of 95.8 million passengers last year, inching closer to becoming the world's busiest airport. This growth is attributed to the swelling Chinese middle class and increasing air travel demand. As the world's air travel landscape continues to evolve, Beijing's airport is poised to take the top spot, surpassing existing contenders.

site_title: Next-gen LNG terminals shrink to offer flexible supply deals
summary: Liquefied natural gas (LNG) terminals are shrinking as they adapt to a growing market with emerging buyers seeking flexible supply deals. Traditional massive facilities are being replaced by modular designs, allowing for smaller liquefaction units that can be expanded as demand grows. The first next-generation liquefaction plant is under construction in the US, with a focus on serving small utilities and industrial users in emerging markets. Global LNG consumption is expected to grow 75% by 2027, driven by increasing demand for cleaner fuels and abundant supply.

site_title: Thailand's Wind Energy plans solar, hydro expansion
summary: Thailand's Wind Energy Holdings plans to diversify its renewable energy sources, including solar, hydro, and biomass, to balance its wind power capacity. The company aims to reach 3,000 MW of wind energy by 2025 and 3,000 MW by 2036. WEH has secured a $1.14 billion loan to finance its development and is considering an initial public offering (IPO) to access investment funds. The company is also expanding its presence in other countries, including Australia and Southeast Asia, with plans to invest $1.5 billion in Australia.

site_title: Oxley unit buys Geylang site for S$13m
summary: Oxley Holdings has acquired a 99-year leasehold plot in Geylang, Singapore, for S$13 million. The plot will be redeveloped into an eight-storey mixed-use development, Sixteen35 Residences, with residential flats and communal facilities. The project is expected to be completed within 40 months and will provide a new home for the Huang Clan Association. The acquisition is part of Oxley's redevelopment strategy in the area, and the company's shares finished S$0.03 lower on the day of the announcement.

site_title: FJ Benjamin back in the black with Q2 profit of S$960,000
summary: FJ Benjamin, a Singaporean fashion retailer, has reported a net profit of S$961,000 for the second quarter of 2018, reversing two consecutive quarters of losses. The company's operating profit improved to S$956,000, up from an operating loss of S$3.6 million in the same period last year. This significant turnaround is attributed to better management of the business.

site_title: one-north to be Singapore's first drone estate
summary: Singapore has designated one-north as its first drone estate, a research and development hub for unmanned aircraft systems (UAS). The initiative aims to support the growth of high-tech companies with UAS capabilities and spur commercial partnerships. Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan announced the plan, highlighting the need for a conducive business environment, increased capacity at airports, and a pool of competent aviation professionals. The government will also launch a new Singapore-ICAO Programme for Young Aviation Professionals to attract and train young aviation professionals.

site_title: A healthy correction from overwhelming optimism
summary: A recent US financial market correction, driven by rising 10-year Treasury yields and inflation fears, is deemed a healthy one by economists. The correction follows a period of overly optimistic markets, triggered by the strong US economy, which added 200,000 jobs in January with a 4.1% unemployment rate. However, the rapid 2.9% year-on-year wage growth has raised concerns about pressure on company margins, as productivity has not kept pace.

site_title: Dubai theme park operator seeks to restructure loan
summary: ILYAS & Mustafa Galadari Group (IMG), the Dubai-based operator of the world's largest indoor theme park, is in talks with banks to restructure a 1.2 billion dirham (S$430.5 million) syndicated loan and extend its maturity. The company is also seeking to upsize its existing loan facility due to cost overruns. This restructuring move aims to address the financial challenges faced by IMG, a major player in the Dubai theme park industry.

site_title: Asian airlines en route to digital transformation
summary: Asian airlines are poised to lead in digital transformation, driven by a growing demand for innovation and customer-centricity. Despite infrastructure constraints and competition, the region is expected to generate a net profit of $6.3 billion in 2017, with many airlines embarking on turnaround transformation initiatives. To succeed, airlines must prioritize customer understanding, collaboration, and investment in the right technologies, such as data integration and digital workforces. The Fourth Industrial Revolution presents opportunities for airlines to rethink their business models and deliver unique customer experiences, but cultural resistance, legacy technologies, and silos must be addressed to achieve this.

images.alt_text: The reality for airlines today is that they are competing with every other aspect of the world customers live in: smart appliances connected to the Internet of Things or apps in a single swipe.

site_title: Singtel to raise Bharti Airtel stake to 39.5% via investment in Bharti Telecom
summary: Singtel plans to increase its stake in Bharti Telecom to 39.5% through a proposed preferential allotment, subscribing to up to 85.45 million new shares at 310 rupees apiece. The deal will raise Singtel's stake by 1.7% for a total consideration of around 26.5 billion rupees (S$555.6 million).

site_title: UK rents rise at slowest pace since 2013
summary: The average rents for residential properties in the UK rose at their slowest pace since 2013, increasing by 1.6% last year. This was the first below-inflation rise since 2013, according to the Deposit Protection Service. Rents in London rose most slowly, at 0.4%. The slow rent growth is attributed to uncertainty about Brexit weighing on the economy.

site_title: Deferred prosecution agreements - Justice delayed or justice denied?
summary: Singapore is considering introducing deferred prosecution agreements (DPAs) as a prosecutorial tool in its Criminal Procedure Code and Evidence Act, aligning with global trends. DPAs, commonly used in various jurisdictions, allow companies to negotiate plea agreements and potential fines in exchange for cooperation with investigations. The move aims to create a more holistic approach to fighting corporate crime, but critics argue that it may lead to justice being denied. The proposed amendments are part of a broader shift in Singapore's approach to corporate wrongdoing, with the goal of creating a more coherent regime.

images.alt_text: In recent years, there has been an emerging trend of jurisdictions introducing or considering DPAs, drawing upon the largely positive experience of the US and UK.

site_title: URA offers Pre-Application Consultation Service
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) is introducing a Pre-Application Consultation Service (PACS) to guide developers, real estate agents, and property owners on development proposals before submitting a formal application. The service allows applicants to seek URA's guidance on development guidelines, including conservation, urban design, and other control guidelines, for specific sites. PACS will be an optional service, with a fee charged based on the size and complexity of the proposed development. The pilot trial will run for one year, with URA reviewing its effectiveness at the end of the period.

site_title: Dollar's rebound fizzles despite US jobs data boost
summary: The US dollar remained near three-year lows after rebounding at the end of last week due to resurgent US wage inflation data. Despite a strong jobs report, the dollar's rebound was short-lived, and it failed to gain on economic news pointing to tighter monetary policy. Analysts say the dollar's fundamentals indicate a stronger currency, but it needs a change in capital flows to sustain an upturn. The dollar index remained steady at 89.202, and net short positions swelled to $17.5 billion, just shy of a five-year high.

site_title: 'Aerospace must continue to ride the Asia-Pac growth wave'
summary: Singapore's aerospace industry, employing over 20,000 workers, is expected to continue growing due to sustained economic growth in the Asia-Pacific region. The sector controls 25% of the Asian MRO market and 10% of the global MRO market. The government is confident in its ability to capitalize on trends, including the region's expected 30% share of global aircraft deliveries over the next 20 years. Minister for Trade and Industry S. Iswaran emphasized the need for partnerships between the public and private sectors to drive innovation and development in the sector.

site_title: Netlink NBN Trust posts profit of S$21.7m for Q3
summary: Netlink NBN Trust reported a profit of S$21.7 million for its Q3, exceeding its forecast of S$16.4 million by 32.5%. Revenue was 0.6% higher than forecast at S$83.4 million, driven by higher connection revenue. Earnings per unit rose to 0.56 cents, and Ebitda was S$63.2 million, 10.8% above forecast. No dividend was declared for the quarter, but the company expects to deliver its financial performance and distribution forecast. NetLink's shares closed at S$0.83, up 0.5 cents.

site_title: Heathrow terminals should be opened up to competition: IAG
summary: Heathrow Airport operator IAG is calling for competition to be introduced in the running of the airport's terminals, citing lower costs as a result. The airline believes bringing in third-party companies, such as airlines themselves, would create competition and keep costs down. IAG owns British Airways and other carriers, and wants to minimize the cost of a new runway to keep fares low. A 10-week public consultation on Heathrow's expansion is underway, with the CAA considering IAG's proposal.

site_title: Law will be amended to plug gap in criminal breach of trust penalties: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore's Government plans to amend the law to increase penalties for directors and senior officers who commit criminal breach of trust (CBT), following a court ruling in the high-profile City Harvest Church case. Minister for Home Affairs K Shanmugam announced the move in Parliament, stating it will be part of wider amendments to the Penal Code.

images.alt_text: The Government will amend the law soon to ensure that legislation provides for higher penalties for directors and other senior officers who commit criminal breach of trust (CBT), said Minister for Home Affairs K Shanmugam, in the wake of a court ruling which resulted in lower sentences in the high-profile City Harvest Church case.

site_title: Homegrown firm Goodstuph to launch 'urgent creativity' service
summary: Goodstuph, a Singaporean creative agency, is launching "Jason", a "same-day idea delivery" service that churns out marketing ideas without a brief in a short time frame. The service aims to respond to market trends and provide maximum impact. Founded by Pat Law, Jason will be formally unveiled in February and will be a new division of Goodstuph.
