The move comes amid fears that credit card owners may buy cryptocurrencies in hopes of making a profit, only to be left with debt if the value falls.

images.alt_text: Lloyds Banking Group said on Sunday it would ban its credit card customers from buying bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 25.65 points to 1,844.83. The market saw 280.6 million lots traded worth RM97.27 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 550 to 27.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks extend losses to 2.3% after weekend earthquake
summary: Taiwan's main index fell 2.31% on Monday morning after a magnitude 6.1 earthquake struck the country's east coast on Sunday night, with no immediate reports of damage or injuries. The US Geological Survey reported the earthquake occurred 17km north-northeast of Hua-lien.

site_title: Taxmen cometh online in South-east Asia
summary: Tax authorities in South-east Asia are scrutinizing online transactions as the region's e-commerce grows. The growth of electronic retailing is predicted to outpace offline sales, with the internet economy's share of the region's GDP expected to increase from 2% to 6% by 2025. Countries such as Thailand, Vietnam, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Singapore are considering changes to tax laws to capture online transactions, including sales on social media platforms and ride-hailing apps. The proposals include levying corporate income tax, value-added tax, and personal income tax on online transactions. However, experts argue that such changes should be implemented without stifling future growth, and many online companies have already taken steps to comply with tax regulations.

images.alt_text: Tan Hui Yee

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower tracking falls on Wall Street
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, following a decline on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.47% and the Topix index dropped 1.32%. Investors were cautious ahead of corporate earnings results in Japan, tracking the US market's losses.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks plummet on opening
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 2.72% on Monday, following a sharp sell-off on Wall Street, amid fears of quicker interest rate hikes. The Hang Seng Index fell to 31,715.56, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 1.46% to 3,411.67. This decline was attributed to a strong US jobs report, which sparked concerns about the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions.

site_title: China's urbanisation rate reaches 58.5% by end of 2017: Xinhua
summary: China's permanent urban population reached 813.47 million by the end of 2017, accounting for 58.52% of the total population. This represents a 20.49 million increase and a 1.17 percentage point rise from 2016. Since 2012, 101.65 million rural people have become permanent urban residents, driven by China's urbanisation strategy to modernise the countryside and boost domestic demand.

site_title: Asia: Shares skid as inflation shadow spooks bonds
summary: Asian shares plummeted 1.9% on Monday, the largest daily drop in over a year, as inflation fears spooked bonds and sparked speculation of aggressive interest rate hikes by central banks. The US payrolls report showed wages growing at their fastest pace in 8.5 years, fuelling inflation expectations and prompting futures markets to price in three or more interest rate rises from the Federal Reserve this year. This led to a sharp decline in emerging markets and commodity currencies, including the Australian and New Zealand dollars.

site_title: Nissan to pump 60b yuan into China business, eyes top 3 spot
summary: Nissan plans to invest 60 billion yuan (S$12.5 billion) in its China business over the next five years as part of its "Triple One" strategy to become a top-three carmaker in the world's largest market. The company aims to boost its annual vehicle sales to 2.6 million by 2022, with a focus on electric cars and Venucia, a no-frills local brand. Nissan plans to launch 20 electrified vehicle models and sell 700,000 electric cars per year, with Venucia aiming to sell 600,000 vehicles annually by 2022.

site_title: Riding the bitcoin wave in search of a golden shore
summary: Bitcoin investor Jacob Melin has achieved success after investing in the cryptocurrency nearly two years ago, using the profits to buy a new house, truck, and start a consulting business. Many investors, including those who were previously unable to afford basic needs, are now pinning hopes on bitcoin's potential value. Some aim to retire early, while others hope to start businesses or pay off debts. The article does not provide further details on the current market or potential future developments, but it highlights the success of early bitcoin investors.

images.alt_text: Mr Melin (right) helping an investment client at Crypto Consulting Group in Louisville where for those who believe in bitcoin, Mr Melin, 22, is one of the most important guides.

site_title: US fintech Stripe picks Dublin for new engineering hub
summary: US fintech firm Stripe is establishing its first engineering hub outside the US in Dublin, Ireland, due to the city's growing technology workforce and global outlook. The company, valued at over $9 billion, has chosen Ireland for its international approach and widening talent pool. This move follows the firm's existing European headquarters in Dublin, which is also home to its co-founders.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble Group, Spackman, Huationg, UOB and Marco Polo Marine
summary: Noble Group rejected a request from majority shareholder Goldilocks Investment Company to waive non-disclosure arrangements. Spackman Entertainment Group is launching its own cryptocurrency, Korean entertainment utility tokens (K Coins), through an Initial Coin Offering (ICO). Additionally, stocks to watch include UOB, Marco Polo Marine, and others as market trends continue to be influenced by GDP data, US-EU trade talks, and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: QT Vascular in potential sale of coronary products
summary: QT Vascular, a medical technology firm, is potentially selling its coronary products to a multinational firm after signing a non-legally binding term sheet. The company aims to continue generating value for shareholders while developing its drug-coated products and expanding its portfolio. QT Vascular will continue to engage with the buyer with the intention to complete the deal.

site_title: Italy's League party under pressure over racist shootings
summary: Italy's far-right League party is under pressure after a racist shooting spree in central Italy left six African migrants injured. Luca Traini, a former League candidate, admitted to carrying out the drive-by shootings and showed no remorse. The incident has sparked widespread condemnation from leftist politicians, who blame the League party for promoting racism. The League is set to make major gains in the March 4 national election, but the attack has raised concerns about the party's ties to neo-Nazism.

images.alt_text: An Italian man named as Luca Traini, who has a neo-Nazi symbol tattooed above his eyebrow, admitted to carrying out the drive-by shootings and had shown no remorse, said the police.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks hit by losses in Wall Street, won slides to 8-week low
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell nearly 2% on Monday, pressured by losses on Wall Street, amid concerns of a potential inflation surge and interest rate increases. The Korean won slid to its lowest in eight weeks, while bond yields rose. The won was quoted at 1,090.3 per dollar, and MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index fell 1.10%. Foreign investors were net sellers of 159 million won worth of shares.

site_title: Noble Group rejects Goldilocks' request for non-disclosure waiver, explains sale processes
summary: Noble Group rejected Goldilocks Investment Company's request for a non-disclosure waiver, stating its earlier announcement was "accurate and not misleading". Noble provided details on its sale processes for Noble Americas Corp and Noble Americas Gas and Power Corp, which complied with listing rules and applicable laws. The group cited "distressed circumstances" and a need to reduce debt quickly after its first-quarter loss. Noble's disposals were conducted under a two-stage auction process with oversight from financial advisers, and the company believes its explanations "materially address" Goldilocks' concerns.

images.alt_text: Noble Group, in its public spat with a majority shareholder, has rejected Goldilocks Investment Company's request for Noble to waive the non-disclosure arrangements around their earlier discussions.

site_title: Asian demand for 16,000 planes spells jackpot for Airbus, Boeing
summary: Asian demand for commercial planes is driving a surge in orders for Airbus and Boeing, with the region expected to account for 39% of the total projected global demand for 41,030 aircraft by 2036. The market is expected to reach 3.5 billion passengers by 2036, with China, India, and Indonesia leading the growth. However, the rapid expansion is putting pressure on carriers, leading to financial strain and a squeeze on profitability, with average operating profit margins expected to drop to 8.1% in Asia Pacific.

images.alt_text: After a flurry of aircraft deals in the last decade, Airbus and Boeing continue wooing Asian customers for future orders as carriers in mainland China, and those in India and Southeast Asia such as SpiceJet and AirAsia Bhd expand their operations.

site_title: Snow on South Korea's Jeju Island hits world's busiest air route
summary: Heavy snow on South Korea's Jeju Island disrupted flights to and from the island's international airport, canceling or delaying over 100 flights as of Sunday. The Seoul-Jeju route, the world's busiest air route in 2017, was severely impacted. Forecasters issued warnings for snow and high winds on the island, marking the second major disruption in less than a month. The disruptions affected nearly double the number of flights on the busiest North American route, Los Angeles to San Francisco.

images.alt_text: More than 100 flights to and from Jeju Island, off the south coast of South Korea, were canceled or delayed amid heavy snow, the second major disruption in less than a month.

site_title: Singapore shares open down on Monday; STI falls 51.03 points
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 51.03 points, or 1.4%, to 3,478.79 on Monday, mirroring Asian market declines. The drop was attributed to concerns over resurgent inflation and potential interest rate hikes by central banks. The US payrolls report, which showed wages growing at their fastest pace in over 8-1/2 years, further fueled inflation expectations. Losers outnumbered gainers 277 to 12, as investors were spooked by the report.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine adds S$2b in three weeks on orders outlook
summary: Sembcorp Marine's stock price surged by almost S$2 billion in three weeks due to optimistic investor sentiment on potential new orders amid rising oil prices. The company received at least three rating upgrades from research firms, including UBS AG and Nomura Singapore, with target prices above the 12-month average of S$2.12. This boost made Sembcorp Marine Singapore's best-performing stock in the past month, following a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Jordan's King Abdullah sees no Mideast peace without US role
summary: King Abdullah II of Jordan stated that a peaceful solution between Israel and the Palestinians cannot be achieved without US involvement, despite the US decision to move its embassy to Jerusalem. Abdullah reiterated his concerns to Vice-President Mike Pence, who visited the Middle East last month. The Jordanian monarch emphasized the US role in the peace process, contradicting widespread criticism of the US stance on Jerusalem.

site_title: US airlines try and fail to increase fares as fuel costs jump
summary: US airlines are struggling to increase fares despite rising fuel costs, with six attempts in the last two months failing. The surge in available seats due to new aircraft deliveries and increased production is a significant headwind for carriers. The last successful widespread price hike occurred on October 10, 2017, coinciding with a rebound in oil prices. Airlines such as Delta Air Lines are trying to boost ticket prices, but their efforts are being hindered by the oversupply of seats.

site_title: 'Corporate giving is not just about painting walls'
summary: Alpha Development, a specialist financial training company, advocates for a partnership-based approach to corporate giving, where employees contribute to community development. The company's initiatives focus on educational programs, such as numeracy training for individuals with special needs. Alpha Development believes that true corporate giving should empower employees to make a meaningful impact, rather than just making a donation. The company is now working with financial institutions to improve their corporate giving initiatives, emphasizing that the size of the contribution matters less than the long-term sustainability of the partnership.

site_title: Asian aviation reaches new heights
summary: Asian aviation reaches new heights with a booming global air transport market, driven by strong passenger traffic and profits. The global airline industry is expected to generate $38.4 billion in profits in 2018, with Asia-Pacific airlines contributing $9 billion. Aircraft orders are at record levels, with over 13,000 planes on order, and the in-service fleet is forecast to reach nearly 39,000 aircraft by the end of the decade, growing at an annual rate of 3%.

site_title: Singtel to raise Bharti Airtel stake to 39.5% via S$555.6m investment in Bharti Telecom
summary: Singtel plans to increase its stake in Bharti Telecom to 39.5% by investing S$555.6 million in a preferential allotment of up to 85.45 million new shares at 310 rupees apiece. The investment will raise Singtel's stake by 1.7% and increase its economic interest in Bharti Airtel by 0.9 percentage point. The allotment is expected to close by March 2018.

images.alt_text: Singtel will subscribe to new shares in Bharti Telecom - the holding company of Indian telecommunications company Bharti Airtel - under a proposed preferential allotment which will see it increase its stake in Bharti Telecom.

site_title: Ready to take off, fuelled by technology and innovation
summary: The Singapore Airshow, Asia's largest aerospace and defence event, will return from Feb 6 to 11 with a focus on technology's impact on global aviation. The sixth edition will feature high-level conferences, forums, displays, and co-located events at the Changi Exhibition Centre. The airshow aims to explore the challenges and opportunities brought about by new technologies and innovations in the industry.

images.alt_text: More than 1,000 companies from some 50 countries, including 65 of the top 100 global aerospace companies, have confirmed their participation.

site_title: Vietnam's privatisation drive 'offers potential for S'pore investors'
summary: Singapore investors are taking interest in Vietnam's state-owned companies, with several major players, including Jardine Cycle & Carriage and Thai Beverage Public Company, holding significant stakes. Vietnam aims to privatise 137 state-owned enterprises by 2020, with opportunities in sectors such as consumer goods, infrastructure, and energy. However, the process can be challenging, with foreign investors facing difficulties in navigating the privatisation procedures and potential risks including hefty price tags and operational conflicts. Despite these challenges, experts believe Singapore companies can contribute to Vietnam's growth and development through their expertise in areas such as master planning and smart city initiatives.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Airport infrastructure is the starting and ending point of every journey
summary: The global aviation industry is experiencing rapid growth, with 4.3 billion passengers expected to board aircraft this year and generating over $2.7 trillion in economic activity. However, the industry faces a challenge in sustaining this growth while improving safety and efficiency. The need for sustainable infrastructure development, particularly in airports, is critical to meeting this demand. Governments and the industry must work together to address infrastructure bottlenecks, invest in cutting-edge technologies, and find effective regulatory models to balance private sector interests with public needs.

site_title: Amtrak train on wrong track in deadly South Carolina crash: governor
summary: An Amtrak passenger train collided with a parked CSX freight train in South Carolina, killing the engineer and conductor and injuring at least 116 people. Train 91, carrying 139 passengers, derailed near Columbia, South Carolina's state capital, on Sunday. The engineer, Michael Kempf, 54, and conductor, Michael Cella, 36, were killed in the crash, which is the railroad's third fatal accident in as many months.

site_title: South Korean appeals court to rule on Samsung scion Lee's conviction, jail term
summary: A South Korean appeals court is set to rule on Monday on Samsung scion Jay Y Lee's conviction and jail term for corruption, stemming from a scandal that led to the ouster of President Park Geun-hye last year. Lee, 49, has been detained for a year on charges related to cosy ties between family-run conglomerates and politics. The ruling is seen as a key moment for South Korea to move past the scandal before hosting the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang. The court's decision will determine Lee's fate in the case.

site_title: Jitters over bond rout might persist
summary: US stocks ended their worst week in two years, with the Dow Jones down 4% and the S&P 500 down 2.1%, amid fears of a bond rout and inflation worries. The US Federal Reserve may raise interest rates more quickly than expected, according to market watchers. Jerome Powell will be sworn in as Fed chair on Monday, and several data events are expected this week, including jobs and wage growth data from the US.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Malaysia cuts Goods Vehicle Levy at Second Link to RM50
summary: Malaysia has reduced the Goods Vehicle Levy at the Second Link to RM50, effective immediately, from RM200. The decision, made by Malaysian Transport Minister Liow Tiong Lai, aims to ease congestion at the Causeway. Singapore's Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan welcomed the move, noting that the subject of the Causeway jam is a recurring topic in meetings between the two ministers. The levy change applies to all goods vehicles, regardless of nationality, and does not have an equivalent at Singapore's end.

site_title: Westpac Bank to raise A$750m through notes offering
summary: Westpac Bank plans to raise A$750 million through an offering of capital notes, with each note priced at A$100 and carrying an annual distribution margin of 3.20-3.40%. The notes will be quoted on the Australian stock exchange and qualify as Additional Tier 1 Capital under the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority's framework.

images.alt_text: Australia's Westpac Banking Corp intends raising about A$750 million (S$783.9 million) through an offering of capital notes, it said on Monday.

site_title: Washington DC to introduce new rule on home-sharing
summary: Washington D.C. lawmakers are set to introduce legislation that would restrict home-sharing sites like Airbnb and VRBO. The measure, proposed by DC Council member Kenyan McDuffie, would limit hosts to renting one unit at a time in their permanent homes. The rule aims to address concerns over short-term rentals and their impact on the local housing market.

site_title: Blizzard exposes flaws in Beijing's rail, coal policies
summary: China's worst blizzard this winter exposed a flaw in Beijing's drive to create remote coal mining hubs, a lack of railroads to get the fuel to market. Heavy snowstorms snarled the world's largest rail network, closing highways, freezing ports, and cutting off critical supplies of thermal coal. Rail experts warn that chaotic episodes like this may become more frequent over the coming years until new freight lines are built, as China's railway capacity is seriously inadequate.

images.alt_text: Analysts say until China's rail network fully connects the supply hubs with centres of demand, further congestion problems look likely to persist.

site_title: Premature to call for end of the bond bull
summary: The 36-year bond bull may be ending, but its conclusion is premature, according to analysts. The 10-year Treasury yield needs to break above 2.93-3.05% to signal the start of a bond bear market. While the yield has risen since October 2017, it has not yet reached the critical threshold of 2.93% or the January 2014 high of 3.05%. The article suggests that the bond bull is not yet over, citing the need for further analysis before making a conclusion.

site_title: Bank of England at forefront of global rates dilemma
summary: The Bank of England is likely to hold off on raising interest rates due to domestic uncertainties outweighing global inflationary pressure. The decision comes as the UK economy shrinks for the second month, adding to concerns about the country's economic outlook. The central bank's peers in India, Australia, and New Zealand are also expected to keep rates unchanged. The decision reflects the bank's focus on domestic economic conditions rather than the strong global economy, which is expected to continue growing.

site_title: Apple Music US subscriber growth outpacing Spotify: WSJ
summary: Apple Music is on track to surpass Spotify in US subscriber growth, according to the Wall Street Journal. As of now, Spotify is the largest music streaming service globally, but Apple Music is gaining ground. The exact figures are not disclosed, but people familiar with the matter claim Apple Music is ahead. Representatives from Apple and Spotify were unavailable for comment. This news could potentially impact the music streaming industry, but no further details are available at this time.

site_title: Amazon receives patents for wristbands that could monitor staff performance
summary: Amazon has received patents for wristbands that could monitor staff performance in its warehouses through ultrasonic pulses. The wristbands would guide employees to specific locations, such as bins for packages, to monitor task completion. The technology aims to improve efficiency and productivity. Amazon has not commented on the patents, sparking concerns over labor conditions and workplace surveillance. The company's rapid growth has raised concerns about its warehouse culture, with some describing it as "hurtful" and "dystopian".

site_title: Broadcom said to plan US$120b Qualcomm bid
summary: Broadcom plans to increase its hostile takeover offer for Qualcomm Inc to about $120 billion, up from the previous $105 billion. The revised offer, which amounts to a 14% increase, would be $80 to $82 per share. Broadcom had initially rejected Qualcomm's lower offer, with CEO Steve Mollenkopf stating it was "not even in the ballpark." The deal would be the largest-ever technology deal, surpassing Broadcom's previous record.

images.alt_text: Broadcom plans to raise its hostile takeover offer for semiconductor rival Qualcomm Inc to about US$120 billion from US$105 billion, Reuters reported, citing people familiar with the deal that it didn't identify.

site_title: Singapore's top banks set for better profits as provisions dip
summary: Singapore's top three banks, DBS Group Holdings, Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp, and United Overseas Bank, are expected to post double-digit profit growth for the first time since 2014 due to a stronger economy, higher interest rates, and rising wealth. The banks are poised to report better profits after several quarters were hit by bad loans. DBS will report earnings on Feb 8, followed by OCBC and UOB on Feb 14, according to a Bloomberg survey.

images.alt_text: The worst may be over for Singapore's three biggest banks.

site_title: Stopping the lies, half-truths and smears
summary: Singaporeans debate the need for a law to deal with online falsehoods, with some arguing that regulation is necessary to combat the spread of fake news, while others believe that education and individual responsibility are key to solving the problem. Experts suggest that legislation should be crafted to balance freedom of speech with the need to protect the public from misinformation. The issue is further complicated by the rapid spread of fake news on digital platforms and the need for media literacy to effectively combat it.

site_title: South Australia plans to set up world's largest virtual power plant
summary: South Australia plans to install solar panels and Tesla batteries in at least 50,000 homes, forming the world's largest virtual power plant. The project, which began with a 1,100-home trial, aims to lower energy bills by 30% for participating households. The state government will finance the installation through electricity sales, and the program is expected to be expanded to all South Australian households over the next four years. Premier Jay Weatherill sees the project as a way to drive down prices and increase competition in the energy market.

site_title: US stock slump hits day 9, worst in two years
summary: US homebuilders experienced their 9th consecutive day of decline, with shares falling 7% amid rising interest rates and concerns about increased housing costs. The 30-year mortgage rate reached 4.22%, its highest in about a year. Analysts argue investors are overreacting, citing strong home sales and buyers speeding up purchases to beat further rate increases. Despite the slump, the broader S&P 500 was up 3.7% this year.

site_title: Boeing wooing Embraer with commercial jet venture: sources
summary: Boeing is reportedly wooing Embraer with a plan to form a commercial jet venture instead of an outright acquisition. The two companies have made progress on the framework for a deal, but hurdles remain. Embraer's military business would likely be excluded, addressing concerns from the Brazilian government. This move comes after Airbus acquired Bombardier's C Series jet, a competitor to Embraer's upcoming jet. Boeing had previously lost a bid to block the C Series from the US market, leading to a joint venture as a more likely outcome.

site_title: Biennial event opens amid roaring travel demand
summary: The biennial Singapore Airshow has opened amidst high travel demand and disruption in the aviation industry. The event brings together buyers and sellers, industry heavy-hitters, and government officials to explore emerging trends and tackle challenges. The International Air Transport Association projects a record profit of $38.4 billion for airlines this year, with Asia-Pacific carriers expected to rake in $9 billion. However, some airlines face overcapacity and low yields, which may impact deal-making at the event. Airbus and Boeing will compete for orders, while new entrants like China's Comac and Russia's Irkut aim to break into the market. The event also highlights emerging technologies such as digitalisation, artificial intelligence, and cybersecurity.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Singapore still 2nd freest economy in the world; gap with top-ranked HK widens
summary: Singapore retained its position as the world's second freest economy, scoring 88.8 points on the 2018 Index of Economic Freedom. The city-state's margin with top-ranked Hong Kong widened to 1.4 points, while China edged up to 110th and the US dropped to 18th. Singapore's score improved in government integrity, labour freedom, and property rights, but declined in business freedom and fiscal health. The US scored 85.4 points, up from 84.8 last year, due to better financial freedom.

site_title: Exxon sees oil demand down 20% in 2040; or maybe it'll be up?
summary: Exxon Mobil Corp released two forward-looking reports, one predicting a 20% decrease in oil demand by 2040 due to climate change curbs, and the other predicting a 20% increase. The reports were in response to a shareholder vote demanding Exxon publish climate risks. The company's CEO did not provide clarity on which scenario is more likely, leaving investors to weigh the uncertainty.

site_title: Asean foreign ministers in Singapore for annual retreat
summary: Singapore hosts the annual Asean Foreign Ministers' Retreat from Feb 4 to 6, bringing together leaders from all 10 Asean countries to discuss resilience, innovation, and regional developments. Topics include the humanitarian crisis in Rakhine, Myanmar, and tensions in the Korean peninsula. Singapore aims to develop smart cities and push for economic integration, with a focus on digital connectivity and cyber-security. The meeting is seen as an opportunity for the host foreign minister to explain the chairman's theme and priorities for the year, with a consensus needed to endorse Singapore's agenda.

site_title: Noble committed to 'open and ongoing dialogue' with shareholders: chairman
summary: NOBLE Group Chairman Paul Brough has assured minority investors that the company remains committed to open dialogue, despite a restructuring plan that would nearly wipe out existing shareholders' equity. Under the plan, senior creditors would own 70% of the restructured firm, while management would own 20%. Existing shareholders would own 10%. Brough has maintained his independence to oversee the restructuring, which aims to halve Noble's $3.5 billion debt by asking creditors to take on equity and new debt instruments. A town hall gathering is planned for shareholders once the restructuring is advanced.

site_title: US dollar rises, but investors sceptical about lasting gains
summary: The US dollar rose against several currencies, including the Japanese yen and the euro, following strong January jobs data, with non-farm payrolls jumping by 200,000 jobs. The dollar index reached its best daily performance since October 26, but investors remain skeptical about lasting gains, citing rising inflation and potential interest rate hikes. The euro fell 0.46% against the dollar, but its overall performance was seen as optimistic, with investors expecting the European Central Bank to normalize monetary policy.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Yellen admits disappointment over her exit in rare interview
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen expressed disappointment over not being reappointed by President Donald Trump, instead choosing Jerome Powell to lead the central bank. Yellen praised the economy, citing gains in the labor market and low unemployment, but noted productivity growth remains weak. She predicted the Fed would continue gradual interest-rate increases. Yellen will join the Brookings Institution after her departure, marking the end of her 15-year public service career.

site_title: No proof of broad-based market manipulation around company announcements: CFA study
summary: A study by CFA Singapore and CRISIL found no statistical evidence of broad-based market manipulation around company announcements on the Singapore Exchange between 2011 and 2016. The research analyzed over 165,000 announcements and found no evidence of systematic manipulation, with most price and trade volume movements attributed to plausible explanations. However, the study did identify potential areas for improvement, including increasing the categorization of announcements and closer monitoring of the financial and real estate segments. The CFA Institute recommended strengthening regulatory oversight to safeguard market integrity.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018: Time to relook foreign manpower restrictions?
summary: Singapore's foreign labor restrictions may be reconsidered to attract highly-skilled talent and support companies' digital transformation. Economists suggest allowing more flexible policies in sectors like cybersecurity, data analytics, and healthcare to address skill shortages. The government aims to raise productivity growth and sustain income growth for citizens, but experts warn that a near-stagnant economy could result if productivity growth fails to meet expectations. Policymakers may consider tweaks to manpower policies, such as loosening hiring restrictions in strategic sectors, but broad changes could be costly and counterproductive.

site_title: Australia won't fund mega Adani mine rail link
summary: Australia won't fund a $1 billion rail link to Adani's Carmichael mine, a key project for the $16 billion coal project near the Great Barrier Reef. The decision comes amid opposition from the state government and regulatory hurdles. The move is another blow to Adani's project, which has faced environmental concerns and a shift away from investing in fossil fuels. Despite this, the mine's developer remains hopeful the project will still go ahead, citing its importance for employment and jobs in northern Australia.

site_title: Millennials leaving the basement to buy homes
summary: US homeownership rates have risen sharply, reaching 64.2% in recent years, driven by millennials forming households and entering the workforce. The rate is highest for those aged 65 and over (79.2%) and lowest for those under 35 (36%), with the latter increasing from 34.7% the previous year. Rising wages, falling unemployment, and increasing interest rates have made buying more attractive than renting, especially for entry-level properties. As the millennial generation grows up and starts families, they are expected to remain a central force in the real estate market.

site_title: Aoxin leads China dentistry with tech
summary: Aoxin Q&M Dental Group, led by CEO Shao Yongxin, is a leading dental care provider in China. Shao, who has 30 years of experience in stomatology, focuses on adopting innovative dentistry techniques and building a comprehensive ecosystem of dental services, research, and training institutions. The company has expanded rapidly, with 11 dental centers and a market capitalization of over $74 million. Aoxin has also collaborated with Jinzhou Medical University to provide training and has acquired several dental clinics. The company's outlook for China's dental treatment market remains bright, with a projected annual growth of 25%. Shao aims to create a professional dental treatment ecosystem, educate the public on dental health, and boost awareness of lifetime dental care.

site_title: Waymo vs Uber trade secrets trial at starting line
summary: A billion-dollar trial between Waymo and Uber began on Monday, with Waymo alleging that former manager Anthony Levandowski stole confidential files and took them to Uber. Levandowski is expected to testify, and Waymo is seeking damages of at least $1 billion. The trial centers on 14,000 files allegedly downloaded by Levandowski in 2015, which Waymo claims were used to develop Uber's self-driving car program, netting Otto a $500 million buyout. The outcome could have significant implications for the autonomous driving industry, with Waymo aiming to prove Uber's use of stolen trade secrets.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Noble Group chairman Paul Brough has assured shareholders that the company's board and management are committed to completing a restructuring plan. The plan, which includes wiping out existing shareholders' equity, proposes halving debts of $3.5 billion by creditors taking on equity and new debt instruments. The restructuring follows three years of job cuts, asset sales, and massive write-downs. A group of investors, including the Securities Investors Association of Singapore, has expressed support for the plan, while Noble is disputing claims made by a civil engineering company, Huationg Global, and a supplier, Nutech Automation, over trademark and defamation issues.

site_title: Bond interest rates may determine market direction
summary: The stock market experienced a significant downturn, with major US indexes suffering their biggest weekly declines since January 2016, amid rising Treasury yields and disappointing earnings. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell by 665 points, and the price of bitcoin plummeted by as much as 20%. The cause was attributed to speculation on interest rates and inflation, with the Federal Reserve potentially raising rates more aggressively. Earnings season is expected to continue, but further moves in Treasury yields could jolt stocks.

site_title: Keppel Corporation buys back S$26.7m in share value
summary: Keppel Corporation purchased S$26.7 million in shares, primarily in January, amid a 0.7% decline in the Straits Times Index (STI) from January 26 to February 1. Other notable transactions include Sarine Technologies' acquisition by Axxion, Interra Resources' placement of 79 million shares, and BlackGold Natural Resources' reduction in stake following a married deal. Meanwhile, Low Keng Huat (Singapore) Limited increased its stake in LKHS, and LY Corporation debuted on Catalist with a S$19.7 million funding round.

site_title: China set to take lead in Asian golf
summary: China is poised to take the lead in Asian golf, with the country's top-ranked female player Feng Shanshan and talented male players like Li Haotong making significant strides in the sport. Despite being banned by Mao Zedong and discouraged by President Xi Jinping, Chinese golf is experiencing a resurgence, with the country boasting 358,000 core players and projected to reach 20 million by 2020. The PGA Tour Series China event is also resuming, offering significant prizes and recognition for Chinese golfers.

images.alt_text: China is often touted as the flagbearer for Asian golf; Li Haotong wrote his name in the history books and underlined his prodigious talent as he becomes the first Chinese male golfer to claim a spot in the world's top 50, and the country now boasts the world's No 1 ranked female player in Feng Shanshan (above).

China is often touted as the flagbearer for Asian golf; Li Haotong (above) wrote his name in the history books and underlined his prodigious talent as he becomes the first Chinese male golfer to claim a spot in the world's top 50, and the country now boasts the world's No 1 ranked female player in Feng Shanshan.

site_title: Explosive memo released as Trump escalates fight over Russia probe
summary: President Donald Trump released a disputed memo alleging US law enforcement agencies have a political bias against him, claiming the FBI's Russia probe is a product of bias. The memo, written by Republicans, accuses the FBI of concealing Democratic ties of a source used to justify surveillance on a former Trump campaign advisor. The FBI warned the memo is misleading and inaccurate, and Democrats said it mischaracterizes highly sensitive classified information. The memo's release deepens a breach between Trump and law enforcement officials, who are investigating potential obstruction of justice and collusion with Russia.

site_title: Singapore companies should seize potential across Asean
summary: Senior Minister of State for Trade & Industry and National Development Koh Poh Koon emphasized the "enormous potential" of Asean for Singapore companies, urging them to act sooner rather than later. Singapore is working on trade agreements and removing impediments to cross-border investment to facilitate the free flow of goods and services in the region. Asean is expected to continue growing at an average annual rate of 5.2% by 2020, with a projected US$3 trillion economy and population of over 600 million by then.

site_title: N Korea slams Trump's 'sinister' State of the Union address
summary: North Korea responded to US President Donald Trump's State of the Union address, calling it "screams of Trump terrified" by the country's power. Trump criticized the "cruel dictatorship" of Kim Jong-Un and his pursuit of atomic weapons, vowing to wage "maximum pressure" to derail the nuclear threat. In response, a North Korean spokesperson described Trump's comments as "arrogance, arbitrariness, and self-conceit", and accused him of revealing a "sinister intention" to harm the country. The exchange follows months of escalating rhetoric between the two nations.

site_title: EU says 'electroshock' tax plan for internet giants set for March
summary: The European Commission plans to unveil its "electroshock" tax plan for internet giants by the end of March, aiming to make them pay taxes in the countries where they earn profits. The current system allows companies like Google and Facebook to report income in low-tax nations, prompting them to choose countries like Ireland and Luxembourg. The proposed plan seeks to create a consensus and "electroshock" on taxing digital economy revenues, potentially leading to increased tax revenues for EU member states.

images.alt_text: EU Economic Affairs Commissioner Pierre Moscovici told France's Radio J that his proposals would "create a consensus and an electroshock" on taxing digital economy revenues.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report covers the tanker and dry bulk market for the week of February 4, 2018. Key findings include:

- Charterers maintained control of rates, with VLCCs languishing in the 40s for 270,000 tonnes to China.
- The Suezmax market saw rates fall 2.5 points to WS 50 for 130,000 tonnes to Europe.
- The Aframax market remained steady, with rates around WS 107.5/110 in the Mediterranean.
- The Panamax market saw rates decline, with the 55,000-tonne market fixed at WS 102.5.
- The Clean market improved, with rates gaining 10 points to WS 100 for 55,000 tonnes Middle East Gulf/Japan.
- The Capesize market was under pressure, with rates sharply lower, especially for transatlantic business.
- The Supramax market was uninspiring, with limited fresh period activity.
- The Handy market continued to fall, with negative sentiment evident, particularly for vessels open east coast South America and US Gulf.

site_title: In quest for growth, German toymakers keep it real
summary: German toymakers are shifting focus from licensing deals with Hollywood studios to traditional, real-world toys, bucking industry trends. Companies like Schleich and Steiff are seeing success with physical products, with Schleich's revenues climbing 9% in 2017 and Steiff's up 8%. Both companies plan to adapt to changing consumer habits by exploring film and digital partnerships, but are prioritizing their own brands for growth. This strategy is unique to Germany, where traditional toy manufacturers have a higher status than in other markets.

images.alt_text: Toymakers have to compete not just with each other, but also for the attention of children glued to tablets and smartphones. Hence, they are now pinning their hopes for growth on traditional, real-world toys with a bit of help from movie tie-ins.

site_title: Some en bloc projects running into technical road blocks
summary: En bloc projects in Singapore are facing technical roadblocks due to increased pressure on traffic infrastructure. Developers, such as Sim Lian Group, are building more units, putting strain on roads, and must obtain Planning Permission (PP) approval from the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) and comply with the Land Transport Authority's (LTA) road works proposal. This has led to delays and concerns among residents, who are worried about the impact on traffic demand. The government has mandated a Pre-Application Feasibility Study (PAFS) to assess traffic impact, which has affected tender processes, including the Pearlbank Apartments sale.

images.alt_text: The long-drawn collective sale process at Tampines Court shows that even after a buyer is found, the transaction can still be plagued with technical issues.

site_title: Digital flights to the future
summary: Digital transformation is revolutionizing the aviation industry, impacting flight efficiency, customer service, maintenance, and security. Connectivity is enabling the use of artificial intelligence, big data, cloud, mobility, and social media components, driving personalized experiences for passengers. Airlines can reap benefits from digital transformation, including enhanced customer service, increased revenues, and improved operational performance. Cybersecurity is also a key concern, but digital transformation can make air travel safer. Big data analytics will play a major role in the digital transformation of the aviation ecosystem, improving ground operations, airspace management, and customer understanding.

images.alt_text: SIA's chief executive officer has said that it is leveraging on digital platforms and technology to learn about customers' habits, preferences and travel patterns.

site_title: Merkel enters final stretch in coalition-building marathon
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel's conservatives are nearing a deal with their historic centre-left rivals, the Social Democratic Party (SPD), after four months of coalition talks. Key issues still need to be untangled, including labour law, healthcare reform, and housing policy, but a deal could be finalized by Sunday evening. Merkel's leadership is at stake, with a stable coalition or minority government crucial to her fourth term. The SPD's reluctance to form a government stems from a historic low vote share and fears of losing support, while Merkel faces grumbling among her troops about giving up ground to the far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD).

images.alt_text: Mrs Merkel arriving at the SPD headquarters on Sunday in Berlin. The German chancellor's struggles to form a government have had consequences abroad with some now looking to Paris and youthful President Emmanuel Macron of France for leadership rather than to Berlin.

site_title: We've reached peak smartphone. What is going to happen now?
summary: The smartphone market is experiencing a decline in upgrades, with global shipments slipping 0.1% in 2017 and US smartphone shipments growing just 1.6% in the same year. Americans are holding onto their phones for 25.3 months, on average, compared to 23.6 months in 2015. This shift is attributed to the increasing reliability and durability of smartphones, as well as the lack of significant new features. As a result, phone manufacturers are rethinking their business model, with Apple and Samsung exploring services and accessories to offset declining sales.

images.alt_text: On Thursday, Apple reported its first-ever holiday quarter decline in unit sales of iPhones. It was just a dip, from 78.3 million to 77.3 million phones.

site_title: Trump's weak dollar upends Asian growth calculus
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration has sent mixed signals about the end of the strong US dollar, contradicting long-standing American policy. The market believes in a weak dollar, which could harm Asia's exports and profits. The region's economies, including South Korea, Singapore, and Japan, are already feeling the effects, with shrinking profits and lower trade volumes. If the dollar weakens further, Asia's companies may face increased competition, making it harder for them to maintain growth. The US's weak-dollar gamble could lead to a confrontation over foreign exchange, with Asia's governments and central banks at risk of retaliation.

site_title: Glaxo, Reckitt are the only bidders for Pfizer's consumer unit: sources
summary: GlaxoSmithKline and Reckitt Benckiser are the only bidders for Pfizer's consumer unit, after rival companies such as Sanofi, Nestle, and Johnson & Johnson withdrew from the bidding process. Pfizer's consumer business, which includes brands like Advil and ChapStick, could fetch $15-20 billion. The company plans to open a data room for Glaxo and Reckitt to start due diligence before submitting final offers in the coming weeks. A sale would help Pfizer raise billions in cash for acquisitions and streamline operations.

site_title: Bitcoin ban expands across credit cards as JPMorgan, BofA recoil
summary: US credit-card issuers JPMorgan Chase and Bank of America are halting purchases of Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies due to associated credit risk. The move comes as Bitcoin's value has fallen below $8,000, amid regulatory threats, fear of price manipulation, and Facebook's ban on cryptocurrency ads. Other banks, such as Citigroup and Capital One, have already declined cryptocurrency transactions. The ban may exacerbate market pressures and make it more difficult for enthusiasts to buy into the market. The decision affects personal and business credit cards, but not debit cards.

site_title: US orders Wells Fargo to halt expansion over 'abuses'
summary: The US Federal Reserve ordered Wells Fargo to halt its expansion until it improves governance and controls, following "persistent misconduct" including the 2016 scandal of creating 3.5 million phony accounts without customer consent. Wells Fargo will replace four board members and submit an action plan within 60 days. The bank prioritized growth over effective risk management, leading to damaged credit scores and millions of dollars in unjustified fees for customers. Wells Fargo President and CEO Timothy Sloan aims to present a reform plan and seek third-party review by September 30.

site_title: High levels of cellphone radiation linked to tumours in rats: US study
summary: US government researchers have found that male rats exposed to high levels of cellphone radiation developed tumors in the tissues around their hearts, according to a draft report by the National Toxicology Programme. Female rats and mice did not develop tumors, but the findings raise new questions about exposure to radiofrequency radiation. However, scientists say the findings cannot be extrapolated to humans and that current safety limits on cellphone radiation are protective, and that the evidence for an association between cellphones and cancer is weak.

site_title: SPH brings festive cheer to seniors
summary: SPH staff visited the Lions Befrienders Senior Activity Centre in Singapore to distribute festive-themed bags filled with daily essentials to 60 seniors as part of the "SPH Cares with Bags of Love" initiative. The event also included games and lunch, with Lions Befrienders chairman William Loh Yoon Fatt expressing appreciation for the interaction between volunteers and seniors. This initiative is part of Lions Befrienders' efforts to provide friendship and care for seniors in Singapore.

site_title: US jobs engine gathers speed in January as wages rise
summary: US job creation accelerated in January, adding 200,000 net new positions, driven by gains in construction, retail, restaurants, and healthcare. The unemployment rate remained at a 17-year low of 4.1%, while average hourly earnings rose 0.3% to $26.74, a 2.9% gain from last year. This solid jobs report strengthens the case for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates in March, despite sparking a Wall Street sell-off due to concerns about rising rates and inflation.

site_title: Huationg Global sued by group of similarly-named companies
summary: Huationg Global, a civil engineering company, has been sued by a group of similarly-named but unrelated companies, alleging trademark invalidation and defamation. Huationg Global and its unit, Huationg Contractor, dispute the claims and plan to defend the allegations. The plaintiffs, Huationg Holdings and Huationg Inland Transport Services, are seeking damages for the alleged threats and defamation. The case is ongoing, with Huationg Global seeking legal advice.

site_title: Demand for shophouse units to remain strong in 2018: CBRE
summary: The demand for shophouse units in Singapore is expected to remain strong in 2018, driven by interest from ultra-high net worth individuals and property companies. Freehold shophouses offer net rental yields of 2-3%, while leasehold ones start from 3%. Transaction prices have increased, with more estate sales from long-term owners and investors seeking capital upside. Shophouses with good locations, strong tenants, and potential for future enhancement work are particularly in demand, making them a lucrative and future-proof investment option.

site_title: Key conference to give a bird's eye view of aviation's future
summary: The Singapore Airshow Aviation Leadership Summit (SAALS) will take place on February 4-5 at Pan Pacific Singapore, focusing on the future of aviation through technology and innovation. The biennial conference, now in its sixth edition, will bring together 300 top-level government and industry decision-makers from around the world to discuss the industry's transformation. Key speakers include Olumuyiwa Benard Aliu, Alexandre de Juniac, and Jeffrey Goh, and panels will explore topics such as next-generation aircraft technologies, the airline industry's future, and the impact of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs).

images.alt_text: Some of the aviation industry's leading figures who will speak at SAALS include Olumuyiwa Benard Aliu, president of the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO); Alexandre de Juniac, director-general of Iata (above) and Jeffrey Goh, chief executive of airline grouping Star Alliance.

site_title: Suspect arrested for petrol bomb thrown at Suu Kyi's Yangon villa
summary: Myanmar police have arrested Win Naing, a 48-year-old mentally ill man, for throwing a petrol bomb at Aung San Suu Kyi's Yangon villa, causing a fire that burned a water pipe. The attack occurred on Thursday when Suu Kyi was not home, and Naing confessed to the crime, citing being "cursed by magic". The incident has unnerved Suu Kyi's supporters, who have faced backlash from the international community over her handling of Rohingya Muslim abuses. Naing will face legal action despite being deemed to have mental health problems.

site_title: The business of getting fit
summary: Pure Fitness has expanded its presence in Singapore with the reopening of its gym on Orchard Road and the opening of a new 28,000 sq-ft gym at Ngee Ann City. The new facility features unique features such as an indoor cycling studio and an athletic turf. The company plans to open a new yoga studio at Suntec City, bringing its total number of facilities to seven in Singapore. Pure Fitness aims to continue its expansion, targeting the heartlands and other areas, but prioritizes finding the right location to meet its high standards.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: SingPost's Q3 net profit up, driven by broad growth, changes in US tax rates
summary: SingPost's Q3 net profit rose 37.2% to S$43 million, driven by broad growth in its postal, eCommerce, and property segments. Excluding exceptional items, underlying net profit grew 11.9% to S$35.2 million. Revenue increased 11.7% to S$412.8 million, with eCommerce-related activities contributing 60% to the growth. The company declared a dividend of 0.5 Singapore cent per ordinary share, similar to last year's.

site_title: MAS orders Nets to address cause of two-hour disruption
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has instructed Nets to investigate and address the cause of a two-hour disruption in its cashless services, believed to be its first outage in decades. The disruption occurred when a "connection module" failed, causing all forms of cashless services to be unavailable. Nets has assured that no personal data was compromised. The MAS will review the investigation report and take supervisory action if needed, amid concerns that e-payment systems need to be more resilient and have sufficient redundancies.

site_title: Apple overtakes Samsung in shrinking smartphone market: survey
summary: Apple surpassed Samsung as the largest smartphone producer in the fourth quarter, with 77.3 million iPhones sold, giving it a 19.2% market share. Despite a 1.3% decline in unit sales, Apple's lead over Samsung, which sold 74.1 million devices, increased due to Samsung's 4.4% decline in the quarter. Overall smartphone sales dropped 6.3% to 403.5 million units, with Huawei holding the number three position. The decline was attributed to consumers not upgrading to high-end flagship devices.

site_title: Oil falls on strong US dollar, stalling rally that opened 2018
summary: Oil prices fell on Friday as the US dollar surged following strong US jobs numbers, despite Opec's compliance with output cuts and rising global demand. US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude settled at $65.45 a barrel, down 35 cents, while Brent lost $1.07 to $68.58 a barrel. The decline narrowed the gap between WTI and Brent to its narrowest since August, boosting US exports. Oil prices have been influenced by the dollar's correlation with oil, with a correlation of -0.86 since the start of the year.

site_title: Indonesia to file case against US anti-subsidy duty on biodiesel
summary: Indonesia plans to file a case against the US Department of Commerce over anti-subsidy duties imposed on Indonesian biodiesel shipments, which range from 34.45% to 64.73%. The case will be filed at the US Court of International Trade by February 3. Indonesia is also planning to bring a complaint to the World Trade Organization, following a similar move by Argentina. The US Commerce Department set the duties in November following investigations into alleged subsidies for Indonesian and Argentine biodiesel imports.

images.alt_text: Indonesia plans to file a case against the US Department of Commerce at the US Court of International Trade over anti-subsidy duties imposed on Indonesian biodiesel shipments, a Trade Ministry official said on Friday.

site_title: US: Stocks dive amid rate hike fears; Dow -2.5%
summary: US stocks plummeted, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 2.5% to 25,520.96, its worst drop in over a year and a half. Disappointing earnings from big companies, including ExxonMobil and Chevron, and rising interest rates fueled the decline. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also fell, with the 10-year US Treasury yield reaching 2.85%. Analysts attribute the market's volatility to the rapid increase in bond yields and concerns about future Federal Reserve interest rate hikes.

site_title: Singapore still 2nd freest economy in the world; gap with top-ranked HK widens
summary: Singapore retained its position as the world's second freest economy, scoring 88.8 points on the 2018 Index of Economic Freedom. The city-state's score increased 0.2 points from last year, while Hong Kong's score improved by 0.4 points, widening the gap between the two cities to 1.4 points. The US think tank praised Singapore's open and corruption-free business environment, as well as its prudent policies and transparent legal framework. Hong Kong's score was boosted by improvements in government integrity and business freedom, but its property rights indicator declined.

site_title: Sentosa Cove penthouse up for auction in mortgagee sale
summary: A two-level penthouse in Sentosa Cove, valued at around S$7.64 million, will be auctioned off by Edmund Tie & Company on February 28. The property, with 2,939 sq ft of floor area, features unblocked views of the marina and private lift access. The sale is a mortgagee sale, with the unit potentially going for S$2 million less than its last transaction price. This is the first Sentosa Cove property to be put up for auction this year, following several mortgagee sales in the area last year.

images.alt_text: A two-level penthouse on the sixth storey of The Berth by the Cove is among the properties going under the hammer at Edmund Tie & Company's auction on Feb 28.

site_title: Japanese authorities raid crypto exchange Coincheck after hack; bitcoin plunges further
summary: Japanese authorities raided crypto exchange Coincheck after a $530 million hack, amid rising concerns about virtual currency security. The raid follows India's announcement to curb the use of cryptocurrencies, causing bitcoin to fall below $9,000. Coincheck's headquarters were searched by the Financial Services Agency, which had previously issued an administrative order. The firm plans to reimburse 260,000 customers with a 46.3 billion yen refund, at a rate of 88.549 yen per NEM.

site_title: The old school way to close that deal in private equity
summary: A study by researchers from the University of St Gallen and Oxford University found that attending the same university as the CEO of a portfolio company significantly increases a private equity fund's chances of winning a deal. The study analyzed over 1,500 US buyout funds and 2,500 portfolio companies, and found that when a CEO and a private equity fund manager attended the same university, the odds of winning the deal increased by 79%. This exclusive network link can provide an advantage in a competitive private equity environment, where multiple funds are vying for the same assets.

site_title: Apple posts record profit despite selling fewer iPhones
summary: Apple reported a record profit of US$20 billion in its holiday quarter, despite selling 77.3 million iPhones, lower than analyst expectations of 80-83 million. The company's revenue reached US$88.3 billion, driven by strong sales of the iPhone X and growth in its services business. Despite concerns about iPhone sales growth, Apple's guidance suggests it may be selling fewer phones than expected next quarter, but analysts believe the company's higher-cost phones and positive signs in China will help it emerge stronger.

site_title: Pacific Andes says talks with creditors, potential sponsors 'encouraging and productive'
summary: Pacific Andes, a seafood company, reported that discussions with creditors, bondholders, and potential plan sponsors are "encouraging and productive" for its restructuring process. The company's principal subsidiaries had combined unaudited turnover of HK$225m in the year ended Sept 28, 2017, with a significant drop in Ebitda and a loss of HK$42.6 million. The company's China Fishery Group in Peru had a successful fishing season, with a 17.7% increase in catch compared to the previous season. An independent review by RSM Corporate Advisory is nearing completion, with the final draft report expected to be submitted by Feb 15, 2018.

site_title: EDBI joins investors in US$500m funding for US biotech unicorn
summary: EDBI, the investment arm of the Singapore Economic Development Board, has joined a $500 million funding round for US biotech company Moderna Therapeutics. Other investors include Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, BB Biotech AG, and Sequoia Capital China. The funding will support Moderna's development pipeline of 19 candidates and expansion of its mRNA therapeutics and vaccines. With the new funding, Moderna now has nearly $1.4 billion in cash on its balance sheet.

site_title: Boxing: Mayweather drops another hint at MMA fight
summary: Floyd Mayweather hinted at a potential return to MMA, posting a picture of himself wearing mixed martial arts gloves and standing in a UFC cage on Twitter. The move comes after Mayweather's August boxing match with Conor McGregor, which generated 4.3 million pay-per-view buys. Mayweather's previous teasers follow his shadow boxing in a cage earlier this week. The "Billion Dollar Man" has a history of negotiating "comeback" fights for bigger paydays, and his perfect 50-0 record remains intact. Mayweather's intentions remain unclear, but the possibility of an MMA return has sparked excitement among fans.

site_title: US hiring accelerates; annual wage growth strongest since 2009
summary: US job growth surged in January, with non-farm payrolls jumping 200,000 jobs, the largest monthly gain in 8½ years. Average hourly earnings rose 0.3% to $26.74, boosting the year-on-year increase to 2.9%, the largest since June 2009. The unemployment rate remained at 4.1%, a 17-year low. Economists attribute job gains to buoyant domestic and global demand, but note that the labour market is near full employment, limiting further growth.

site_title: YouTube labels state-sponsored news as rules tighten
summary: YouTube has begun labeling news broadcasts that receive government funding, aiming to provide users with more information about the sources of news content. The feature, launched in the US, displays notices below videos uploaded by news broadcasters that receive government or public money, including links to Wikipedia for further information. This move is part of YouTube's efforts to tighten rules and enforce policies, with a goal of better surfacing authoritative news and protecting its community.

site_title: Spice Girls announce plans to work together again
summary: The Spice Girls announced plans to work together again, reuniting for the first time since 2012. The 1990s pop group, consisting of Victoria Beckham, Melanie Brown, Emma Bunton, Melanie Chisholm, and Geri Horner, gathered at Horner's house in London with their former manager Simon Fuller. They expressed interest in exploring new opportunities, including television projects, endorsement deals, and a compilation album, while reinforcing their message of feminine empowerment. The reunion follows previous failed attempts at a comeback in 2016 and marks the group's first gathering since the 2012 Olympics closing ceremony.

site_title: Understanding the different types of Reits
summary: This article examines the performance drivers of different types of Real Estate Investment Trusts (Reits), including Retail and Mall Reits, A-Grade Office and Commercial Reits, Industrial Reits, and Residential Reits. Key factors influencing each type include economic performance, tenant mix, location, and industry trends such as e-commerce and automation. Understanding these specific drivers can help investors make informed decisions and mitigate risks. The article concludes that a diversified portfolio and thorough analysis of market conditions are essential for successful Reit investing.

site_title: World manufacturing starts 2018 on strong note
summary: Manufacturing activity in major economies started 2018 on a strong note, with Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) figures reaching record highs. Singapore's PMI was at its highest since 2009, while the eurozone's manufacturing sector continued its expansion for the 55th month. In the US, manufacturing expansion was led by new orders and production, with PMI readings of 59.1 and 55.5. Asian countries, including Japan, Taiwan, and South Korea, also saw strong manufacturing growth, with some readings reaching four-year highs. However, Britain's manufacturing sector slowed down, with its PMI falling to a seven-month low.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng
A worker arranges steel bars at a factory in Beijing, China November 22, 2017.

site_title: City Harvest case, flash floods tabled for Parliament sitting
summary: Singapore's Home Affairs and Law Minister K. Shanmugam will address Parliament on Monday regarding the City Harvest court ruling, which upheld shorter jail terms for the six accused. The case involves City Harvest Church founder-pastor Kong Hee and five others accused of misusing millions in church funds. Meanwhile, Parliament will also discuss flash floods in Singapore, and several bills, including the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill and the Cybersecurity Bill, will be debated.

site_title: Pine Capital posts smaller Q3 loss; plans to raise funds
summary: Pine Capital Group reported a narrower Q3 loss of S$926,000, down from a year-ago loss of S$1.5 million. The company generated S$452,000 in revenue from a newly acquired subsidiary, Advance Capital Partners Asset Management. Pine has net current liabilities of S$1.9 million and is exploring fundraising options to strengthen its financial position. The company plans to grow its financial services sector to bolster performance. A fund-raising announcement will be made as needed.

site_title: Europe: Worst week in more than a year for stocks as risk appetite dries up
summary: European stocks suffered their worst weekly loss in over a year, falling 3.1% as investors lost appetite for risk and bond yields rose, leading to tighter monetary policy expectations. The pan-European STOXX 600 index declined 1.4% and Germany's DAX plummeted 1.7% for its biggest weekly fall in two years. Disappointing results from Deutsche Bank, record equity inflows, and a possible pullback in US stocks contributed to the decline, with analysts predicting a downturn ahead for stocks.

site_title: Foreign brands that misfire in China
summary: Unilever's deodorant, Rexona, failed to gain traction in China despite cultural and biological differences. The product, which is widely used in the West, was marketed with ads highlighting social embarrassment from body odor, but this message fell on deaf ears in China, where sweating is seen as a natural part of metabolism. China's low body odor issues are attributed to a genetic factor, with many East Asians having a gene that reduces the likelihood of strong human axillary odor. The product's failure was further compounded by a lack of understanding of Western humor and marketing strategies.

images.alt_text: Deodorants - a hard sell in China. Less than 10 per cent of China's population uses deodorant. To many Chinese, the traditional thinking is sweating is good because it helps people detox; perspiration is a natural part of metabolism that should not be blocked.

site_title: Weaker estimates cast shadow over Visa share price
summary: Visa Inc reported a better-than-expected quarterly profit of $2.52 billion, driven by a solid holiday shopping season, but shares fell 1.52% due to higher full-year expenses and slower revenue growth in the current quarter. Net income rose 21% to $1.07 per share, while operating expenses rose 12.8% to $1.54 billion. The company expects expenses to rise in the second quarter.

images.alt_text: Visa Inc's Q1 net income rose to US$2.52 billion while Mastercard's Q4 profit fell to US$227 million, including a one-time tax-related charge of US$981 million.

site_title: North Korea earned US$200m from banned exports, sends arms to Syria, Myanmar: UN report
summary: North Korea earned approximately $200 million in 2017 from banned exports, primarily coal, through false paperwork and exploitation of global supply chains, violating UN sanctions. The UN report also accused North Korea of supplying weapons to Syria and Myanmar, including ballistic missile systems and chemical weapons components. The report found evidence of ongoing sanctions breaches, including ship-to-ship transfers of petroleum products and involvement of multinational oil companies.

images.alt_text: North Korea violated United Nations sanctions to earn nearly US$200 million in 2017 from banned commodity exports, according to a confidential report by independent UN monitors, which also accused Pyongyang of supplying weapons to Syria and Myanmar.

site_title: Rags to riches tale ends sadly for Noble Group founder Richard Elman
summary: Richard Elman, founder of Noble Group Ltd, will see his 77-year-old stake in the company dwindle to 1.8% after a restructuring deal. Noble, once Asia's largest commodity trader, filed for bankruptcy and will be handed over to creditors. The company's debts, totaling over $1 billion, became unsustainable, and trading losses mounted due to allegations of accounting tricks. Elman's empire, built on borrowed cash and cheap credit, ultimately unraveled after a series of poor trading calls and declining commodity prices. The company's market value dropped from $10 billion to $263 million.

site_title: Aston Martin zooms off to China in race to make e-cars
summary: Aston Martin is seeking a joint venture in China to expand its electric vehicle (EV) business, following in the footsteps of other major automakers such as Volkswagen and Ford. The company plans to collaborate with a Chinese partner to share its lightweight materials and aerodynamic technologies, with talks underway with established carmakers and startups. China is poised to become a major market for EVs, with sales expected to top 700,000 units in 2017 and 1 million in 2018, and Aston Martin aims to tap into this growing market with a £600 million investment drive.

site_title: What's on the block in China's potential sale of the century?
summary: China's multinational conglomerates HNA Group, Dalian Wanda, and Anbang are downsizing due to a government crackdown on capital outflows to protect the yuan. HNA plans to sell US$16 billion in assets, Wanda is selling its last two overseas property developments, and Anbang is under pressure to sell its overseas assets after its chairman's detention. These companies, once known for their aggressive expansion, now face financial risks from China's mounting corporate debt. Their notable assets include stakes in Deutsche Bank, Hilton, CIT, and luxury properties worldwide.

site_title: Mercedes GLS: King of the jungle
summary: The Mercedes-Benz GLS 400 is a large, comfortable, and capable SUV that defies modern trends of prioritizing sports car-like performance over off-road capability. With a full load of seven people, the GLS can tackle rough terrain and still provide a smooth ride, thanks to its 333hp turbocharged V6 engine, light steering, and adjustable suspension. The GLS also boasts advanced off-road technology, including terrain modes and a centre-locking differential. While it has a high price tag and thirst for fuel, the GLS remains a top choice for those seeking a refined and capable SUV.

site_title: A tale of two women . . . or three
summary: A recent #MeToo movement has sparked a global debate on feminism, with European women defending the concept of "indulgent" male behavior, while American women criticize it as condoning harassment. The movement has also led to a reevaluation of the travel industry, where women are increasingly taking center stage. The article cites examples of powerful women, including Catherine Deneuve and Oprah Winfrey, who have spoken out against puritanical attitudes towards women's bodies and behavior. The author argues that while some men may cross boundaries, many are simply following their biological instincts, and that travel should be about "suspended disbelief" and "eyes wide open."

images.alt_text: Names have been named, people shamed, and others dragged to court. It is a subject that has grabbed headlines and hearts, bringing people together, and setting others apart as in the America-Europe divide over the meaning of feminism that has exposed a deeper attitudinal divergence.

site_title: MUFG's Q3 profit slides as overseas growth costs bite
summary: MUFG, Japan's largest lender, reported a 20% decline in Q3 net profit to 236.5 billion yen due to weak domestic lending and increased operating costs from expanding overseas. The bank's profits were the largest among Japan's top three banks, but smaller rivals outperformed. MUFG maintains its full-year net profit forecast of 950 billion yen, below analysts' estimates. The bank has been focusing on overseas growth, with recent agreements to buy stakes in Indonesian and Vietnamese banks.

site_title: Pacific Radiance's new restructuring terms leave noteholders still miffed
summary: Pacific Radiance has launched a consent solicitation exercise for a revised debt restructuring plan for its S$100 million 4.3% medium-term notes. The plan, which includes a 19 new share-for-every-S$5 conversion ratio, would leave noteholders with a 50% haircut and reduced protection as creditors. The company aims to address the maturity of the notes, due on August 29, and has proposed a debt-to-equity conversion. If noteholders do not approve, the firm may offer a "similar, better or worse" proposal.

site_title: Automatic for the people
summary: Audi's self-driving A8, certified for Level 3 autonomous driving, aims to free up an extra hour in daily commutes by allowing drivers to take their hands off the wheel. The vehicle features "pre-sense" technology, which monitors traffic conditions and initiates preventive measures to protect occupants in the event of an accident. Audi's parking system utilizes four cameras to display obstacles and provide a panoramic view, enabling the vehicle to steer itself into parking spots. The company plans to release the A8 with self-driving capabilities in H1 2018, subject to regulatory approvals, and has also developed plans for Level 4 and Level 5 autonomous vehicles.

images.alt_text: The virtual overhead view shown on the display gives the driver an overview of the overall parking situation, which can help position the car more precisely.

site_title: Reits
summary: Realty news includes reports on US mortgage rates rising after five weeks of decline, a Q3 condo launch wave testing demand in Singapore prime projects, and Manhattan rents reaching records. Additionally, Goldman Sachs acquired a hotel and retail asset in Seoul, UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high, and New World is selling China property assets. WeWork secured new tenants at 21 Collyer Quay in Singapore after its bankruptcy. These developments indicate a shift in market trends, with rising mortgage rates and increased demand for luxury properties.

site_title: May bags £9b in China deals, Xi promises to build on 'golden era'
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May concluded a three-trade mission in China with deals worth over £9.3 billion, solidifying the "golden era" in relations between the two countries. China pledged to upgrade its economic ties with Britain, while May emphasized the UK's desire to become a global trading nation after Brexit. The deals are expected to create over 2,500 jobs in the UK and secure market access for British financial services firms. China sees Britain as an important ally in promoting global openness, despite concerns about Brexit's impact on market access.

images.alt_text: From left: Philip May, husband of British Prime Minister Theresa May, Mrs May, President Xi Jinping and wife Peng Liyuan at the Diaoyutai State Guest House in Beijing,

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: ComfortDelGro Corp is scaling up its petrol station business to serve its growing fleet of hybrid taxis. OCBC Investment Research maintains a "hold" rating, expecting limited earnings lift until the business serves the private hire car fleet of Uber. AEM Holdings is acquiring Afore Oy, a Finnish MEMS test solutions provider, for S$12.3 million. CIMB Research upgrades AEM to "add" with a target price of S$6.62, citing the acquisition's accretive nature and strengthened management team.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Jumbo Group will establish a new branch office and restaurant in Xi'An, China, through a joint venture with Beijing Hualian Departmental Store. Ntegrator International secured S$17.2 million in contracts, including a US$2 million project in Myanmar. United Overseas Bank disposed of its 10.29% stake in Marco Polo Marine for S$12.68 million. The Association of Banks in Singapore raised the Fast and Secure Transfers system limit from S$50,000 to S$200,000.

site_title: An all-inclusive Chinese New Year gathering
summary: A halal-certified restaurant, The Dim Sum Place, offers an all-inclusive Chinese New Year gathering package in Singapore. The 7-course dinner package starts from S$298++ for 10 diners and features dishes such as Prosperity Fa Cai Yu Sheng and Crystal Shrimp Dumplings.
