Y Ventures has seen its shares double since the start of the year, with the company reporting a pre-tax profit of US$571,805 in the first half of 2017. The partnership is seen as a strong endorsement by R3, comprised of seasoned veterans in the consumer retail industry.

site_title: Trust in 'childhood friend' one factor behind Teos' investment in Marco Polo Marine
summary: The Teo family, founders of Super Group, has invested S$20 million in Marco Polo Marine through their private investment firm Apricot, taking a 19.28% stake in the company. The investment is part of a S$60 million rescue financing package, with Apricot contributing a third of the funds. The family views Marco Polo's CEO, Sean Lee, as a trusted partner and has taken a contrarian view on investing in the oil and gas sector, which they believe will co-exist with renewables. Apricot will take on a non-executive board seat, focusing on long-term investments and management team performance.

site_title: Shell's best profit in 3 years marred by surprise cash-flow drop
summary: Royal Dutch Shell posted its best profit in 3 years with an adjusted profit of US$4.3 billion last quarter, driven by improved exploration and production earnings of US$1.65 billion. However, refining and trading earnings fell short of expectations. The company's cash flow was the weakest since 2016, attributed to higher tax payments and increased cash requirements. Despite the mixed results, Shell's CEO expressed confidence in delivering strong returns and cash, citing a disciplined approach to maintain its market value as it aims to surpass Exxon Mobil Corp.

site_title: Janet Yellen seals success as market's therapist
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's final statement as chair marked a triumphant exit, as the Fed shifted its stance on inflation to a more modest assessment, warning of rising expectations. The statement offered a more measured view of the economy, contrasting with President Donald Trump's rosy picture. Yellen's steady approach, after taking over from Ben Bernanke in 2014, managed the transition from extraordinary to ordinary economic conditions, with the 10-year Treasury yield now near its highest level since the financial crisis. The Fed expects inflation to rise and stabilize around 2% in the medium term, signaling a potential increase in interest rates.

site_title: The future of insurance in BT Weekend
summary: A revolution is underway in the insurance industry, driven by the increasing use of big data to better price risk, influence customer behavior, and streamline claims processing. Insurers are leveraging data to create more personalized policies and improve efficiency. This shift towards data-driven insurance is expected to have a significant impact on the industry, transforming the way insurance is sold, claimed, and managed.

site_title: Datapulse told to alert SGX in advance to possible buys involving Ang Kong Meng
summary: Datapulse Technology has been required by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to notify it in advance of any possible acquisitions involving Ang Kong Meng, the vendor of Wayco Manufacturing, which Datapulse had agreed to acquire. The acquisition was proposed without due diligence and used a valuation provided by the vendor, who is also a known associate of Datapulse's new controlling shareholder, Ng Siew Hong. The SGX has deemed the requisition notice for extraordinary general meetings (EGMs) by a group led by Ng Bie Tjin invalid due to irregularities in the notice.

site_title: Jurong is now home to Mondelez's first global innovation hub in Asia
summary: Mondelez International, the world's second-largest confectionary company, has opened its first global innovation hub in Asia at its Singapore Technical Center (STC). The US$65 million facility in Jurong will focus on innovation and product development for iconic brands like Clorets, Halls, and Oreo biscuits. The hub will house up to 75 experts and work closely with Mondelez's manufacturing network across Asia-Pacific, Middle East, and Africa. The facility is part of Mondelez's global R&D investment and aims to improve speed, efficiency, and effectiveness in meeting consumer needs.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Technical Center will be home to up to 75 experts - scientists, developers, engineers, analytical chemists and other specialists - from all over the world.

site_title: ANA to expand budget airline business as Q3 profit shines
summary: ANA Holdings, Japan's largest airline by revenue, plans to expand its budget airline business into medium-length international flights. The airline aims to increase revenue to 2.45 trillion yen (S$29.5 billion) in 2022, with 50% growth in core international service. ANA plans to launch medium-haul flights of up to eight hours from Japan, starting from 2020, using smaller jets in the domestic market and new aircraft models, such as the Airbus A321LR.

site_title: Bitcoin's big wipeout erases US$44b of value in January
summary: Bitcoin experienced a significant one-month loss of US$44.2 billion in January, wiping out nearly 22% of its market value. The cryptocurrency's slide was attributed to a series of negative news, including a record heist and increased regulatory scrutiny. Analysts predict further decline to the US$5,000-US$6,000 range, with a potential recovery to US$10,000-US$15,000 in the future.

site_title: Trump tries for a reset on the political front
summary: US President Donald Trump delivered a State of the Union address, attempting to reset his image as a centrist dealmaker. The speech largely ignored contentious issues like healthcare, taxes, and abortion, instead focusing on general themes and populist ideas like immigration reform and infrastructure spending. While the speech may have lifted Trump's approval ratings temporarily, there are no concrete plans to enact these ideas, and his party's ideologues and the opposition party are unlikely to support them. The speech's effectiveness is uncertain, and Trump's ability to build bridges with Congress remains a challenge.

site_title: Step Up In Style
summary: New Balance has released two limited-edition Chinese New Year sneakers, the red 574 Sport and black 247, to mark the upcoming festive season. The shoes feature Fresh Foam midsole cushioning and have prices of S$169 each at New Balance Experience Outlets islandwide.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Upcoming Budget to continue efforts to help firms transform: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's upcoming Budget will focus on helping firms innovate and transform, Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong said. The government aims to build deep capabilities in firms and forge stronger partnerships. This is evident in the success story of Esco Group, a local life-science manufacturer that has transformed over the years with government schemes such as the Capability Development Grant. Wong praised Esco's innovation and transformation, saying it's a remarkable story of a Singaporean company seizing new opportunities. The Budget will continue to support such efforts.

site_title: Singapore Flora In Full Bloom
summary: Local artist Lucinda Law, a botany artist and founder of Within, has created a botanical plate showcasing Singapore's flora through an art-science perspective. Inspired by her course at London's Kew Gardens, Law aims to inspire others to appreciate nature and preserve biodiversity. Her work is part of BT Weekend's monthly colouring series, featuring heritage-themed drawings. Law hopes her art commissions and creative retreats will encourage people to be more sensitive to the need to protect plants and their cultural significance.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Singapore to develop small satellite capabilities
summary: Singapore plans to develop small satellite capabilities, aiming to be one of the first countries in the world to fly small satellites in formation. The initiative, led by the National University of Singapore and DSO National Laboratories, promises more comprehensive coverage and flexible usage at a lower cost. The global space industry is estimated to be worth US$330 billion, and Singapore's move is expected to build deep capabilities for advanced satellite applications. The country will support its burgeoning space technology sector through partnerships and an accelerator program for space startups.

images.alt_text: The Global Space and Technology Convention, now in its tenth year, is being held at Sheraton Towers Singapore.

site_title: Maximum of 6 unrelated tenants in a flat: HDB
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) in Singapore has announced changes to its rental policies, allowing owners of four-room or larger flats to rent to a maximum of six unrelated persons, down from nine. This change aims to minimize overcrowding issues and maintain a conducive living environment. The new policy also applies to commercial properties, reducing the number of occupants from eight to six. Flat owners and commercial property owners must now obtain approval before entering a tenancy agreement, with some exceptions for short-term rentals.

images.alt_text: All HDB flat owners, as well as all commercial property owners and tenants, will need to get approval before they begin any tenancy agreement.

site_title: SIA flip-flops again, this time on opt-out insurance for online booking
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has removed an online booking feature that automatically includes travel insurance unless travellers opt out. The airline initially introduced the feature to encourage customers to take up travel insurance, but faced complaints from customers who were unaware they were being charged. SIA has now amended the booking flow to offer travel insurance as an 'opt-in' feature, following criticism from the Consumers Association of Singapore. This is the second time SIA has been forced to change its policy in recent weeks, following its earlier backtracking on a credit card fee for Economy Lite tickets.

site_title: Prodigies Face Off
summary: The Singapore International Violin Competition 2018 is underway, featuring young violin talents competing for the top prize. The finals will take place on February 5 and 6, with the winner playing with the Singapore Symphony Orchestra on February 8. The competition has a history of launching successful careers, with the 2015 winner, Yu-Chien Tseng, signing with the Naxos music label.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Yu-Chien Tseng.

site_title: Stranger Flings
summary: Fashion's "ugly" phase, popularized by Gen-Z and designers like Vetements' Demna Gvasalia, is reemerging with trends like chunky sneakers, cargo denims, and monogram bags. While some items, like neon yellow windbreakers, are seen as stylish, others, such as trash bag-inspired dresses and fanny pouches, are deemed pretentious and unflattering. The trend's resurgence raises questions about the line between anti-fashion and ugly, with some arguing that it's a regression rather than a forward-thinking movement.

site_title: Keppel O&M CEO appointed to MPA board
summary: Keppel O&M CEO Chris Ong has been appointed to the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) board, joining 12 other members. SembCorp Marine president and CEO Wong Weng Sun is stepping down after nine years, with the MPA thanking him for his contributions. The board is chaired by Niam Chiang Meng, with notable members including Mediacorp's Walter Fernandez and BAE Systems' Ishak Ismail.

site_title: A quick-service approach to Unagi
summary: Uya, a new unagi restaurant in Singapore, offers a quick-service approach with minimal frills, focusing on grilled unagi rice topped with a sweet-savoury tare. Despite its efficient service, the restaurant's speedy pace undermines the authentic Japanese dining experience. The menu features a mix of unagi-related and conventional Japanese dishes, including a signature Hitsumabushi set with a secret recipe tare and good-quality eel. The unagi rice is a standout, with a good balance of sweet and savoury flavors. Overall, Uya is a promising restaurant that may not surpass its competitor, Man Man, but is a good alternative for those who prefer a quicker dining experience.

site_title: One-Stop Cleanfest
summary: Crate & Barrel's New Home Fair is a one-stop shop for spring cleaning needs, featuring 12 vendors offering services such as laundry, food delivery, home entertainment, and security systems. The fair will take place on Feb 3 from 10am-9pm at Crate&Barrel, Gateway@Emerald, with free admission. Additionally, attendees can schedule appointments with design consultants, participate in workshops on styling bookshelves and making the perfect bed, and receive advice on space planning and more.

site_title: WeWork plans Japan expansion, eyes Osaka, Yokohama, Fukuoka
summary: WeWork, a co-working space company backed by SoftBank Group, plans to expand its Japan operations to include Osaka, Yokohama, and Fukuoka. The company aims to open 10-12 offices in the Tokyo area this year, with its first location in Shibuya already open. WeWork's first Japan location, in Mori Building's Ark Hills complex, houses 886 desks and is fully booked. The company plans to open in Marunouchi Kitaguchi, Ginza Six, and Shimbashi in March and April, respectively, with SoftBank's founder Masayoshi Son investing US$4.4 billion in WeWork.

images.alt_text: SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son and his Vision Fund agreed to invest US$4.4 billion in WeWork to finance an aggressive global expansion plan that includes a US$500m project in China.

site_title: Dollar weakens after Fed bounce short-lived
summary: The US dollar weakened after the Federal Reserve hinted at rising inflation this year, despite leaving interest rates unchanged. The dollar rose briefly in Asian trading before falling back, reaching a three-year low of 88.438 earlier in the week. Analysts attribute the decline to stronger global economic growth and increased foreign investment in the eurozone, which has bolstered the euro and pressured the dollar. Despite US economic data due on Friday, many expect the dollar's decline to continue.

site_title: Amid high US valuations, tech and banks still a draw
summary: US fund managers see potential in tech firms, despite high valuations, citing structural trends like the Internet and artificial intelligence. Alibaba and Facebook are among the "strong buys" in their Global Technology Fund, with earnings growth expected. Meanwhile, US banks remain attractive due to rate hikes, with regional players offering better returns on capital and growth potential. Despite concerns over the business cycle, fund managers are optimistic, citing easing regulatory environments and low valuations.

images.alt_text: Mr Clark says tech firms remain firmly backed by long term, structural trends.
Ms Welch says loan growth can accelerate with a stronger economy and changes in tax laws.

site_title: Gillman Gets Goofy
summary: The inaugural DISINI Festival took place at Gillman Barracks in Singapore, showcasing large-scale public art installations. The festival featured wacky and humorous works, including a giant pink pineapple house, a half-human half-hare sculpture, and gibberish sculptures. Curated by Khai Hori, the event aimed to bring a lighthearted contrast to the surrounding galleries. Organized by Chan + Hori Contemporary and the National Arts Council, the festival also plans to take its concept overseas, commissioning international artists to create similar large-scale works.

A pineapple house by fashion collective MASH-UP.

Felipe Pantone's clashing motifs on Block 7 Lock Road.

site_title: New programme to help legal sector Go Global
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Law launched the "Lawyers Go Global" programme to support small to medium-sized law firms in exploring international markets. The programme includes overseas mission trips, training, and marketing campaigns, aiming to help firms tap into the growing demand for legal services in Asia. The initiative is part of Singapore's efforts to internationalise its legal sector, with a projected growth rate of 5.5% in the Asia-Pacific region between 2014 and 2019.

site_title: Pandora's Box
summary: The Women's Tennis Association (WTA) has announced that Shenzhen, China will host the WTA Finals from 2019 to 2028. Meanwhile, an interactive exhibition "Avatar: Discover Pandora" is currently running at the Great China International Exchange Square in Shenzhen until April 12, featuring a 12,000 sq. ft. immersive experience of the 2009 James Cameron movie.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
Avatar: Discover Pandora.

site_title: Japan's LNG imports hit 5-year high as cold bites
summary: Japan's liquefied natural gas (LNG) imports reached nearly 8.7 million tonnes in January, a 5-year high, driven by freezing weather and a cold snap that boosted power demand. The surge in imports is putting pressure on regional spot markets, with some utilities scrambling to secure cargo for the second half of February. However, demand is expected to fade with spring's arrival and as some nuclear reactors are set to restart, according to research analyst Boseok Jin.

site_title: Are we being held hostage to the stock market?
summary: The US stock market has reached record highs, with a 6% gain in the first 15 trading days of 2018, worth approximately $1.9 trillion. However, experts question whether this reflects the economy's underlying strength or runaway speculation. Stock valuations are considered "stretched" with a median price-earnings ratio of 24, compared to a 17-year average. Economists warn of a potential correction or crash, citing historical precedents of 13 full-fledged bear markets with declines exceeding 20%. The cause of the boom is debated, with some attributing it to tax cuts, regulatory policies, and new technologies, while others argue that financial innovations, such as index products, are driving the market.

site_title: White House seeking to slash renewable energy research: report
summary: The Trump administration is seeking a 72% cut in funding for clean energy and energy efficiency programs in the 2018 budget, according to a report by the Washington Post. The proposed cuts would reduce funding for the Energy Department's Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy from $2.04 billion to $575.5 million. The move aligns with the administration's focus on prioritizing fossil fuels and export, and could be met with resistance from Congress.

site_title: Fendi Expands
summary: Fendi has opened its first boutique in the Orchard Road belt with a dedicated menswear section, featuring ready-to-wear, leather goods, and accessories. The new store, located at ION Orchard, showcases a unique design by architect Cristina Celestino, including a mint green velvet armchair and a Roam Travertine marble table with a satin brass frame.

site_title: Go Nonya This CNY Season
summary: Chef Damian D'Silva presents his own Peranakan Tok Panjang at Folklore restaurant for Chinese New Year, featuring over 15 dishes including Peranakan Prawn Salad, Fish Maw Soup, and Babi Pongteh. The spread showcases traditional Peranakan flavors and dishes, available for dinner from Feb 15 to March 2 at S$68++ per adult and S$28++ per child.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: China's manufacturing performs well in Jan
summary: China's manufacturing sector began the year on a high note, with the Caixin/Markit PMI remaining stable at 51.1 in January, beating expectations. However, the government-backed survey showed a decline to an eight-month low, citing disruptions from pollution campaigns and potential base effects. Analysts expect growth to slow as Beijing regulates the financial sector and pursues structural reforms, potentially impacting the manufacturing industry.

site_title: Creating 'sweet' memories for the seniors
summary: A baking workshop was organized by Hong Leong Foundation for seniors aged 62-95 from Tai Pei Old People's Home and St Vincent's Home. 50 elderly participants prepared butter cookies and pineapple tarts under the guidance of pastry chef Jason Goh. The event aimed to boost their overall well-being through bonding over food and creating 'sweet' memories. As part of its annual charity event, Hong Leong Foundation made cash contributions of over S$453,000 to 3,778 recipients of the Ministry of Social and Family Development's ComCare Long-Term Assistance scheme.

Pastry chef Jason Goh teaching Hong Leong Foundation governors Kwek Eik Sheng (far left) and Ong Pang Boon (third from left), and Madam Chong Ah Inn, 80, from Tai Pei Old People's Home how to make strawberry butter cookies during the fun-and-bake workshop at Hong Leong Foundation's charity event.

site_title: Yingluck's 110m baht mansion seized
summary: Thailand's former prime minister Yingluck Shinawatra's 110 million baht (S$4.6 million) mansion in Bangkok has been seized as part of over 30 assets taken by the government to pay compensation for damages from her rice-pledging scheme. The mansion, valued at 110 million baht, is among assets frozen and liens claimed on by the government. Yingluck fled the country in August 2016 and was later sentenced to five years in jail for negligence. The government's Administrative Court rejected her request for an injunction, allowing the seizure of her assets.

site_title: OKH enters joint venture with Ping An unit
summary: OKH Global, a Singaporean property developer, has entered a joint venture with Ping An Industrial and Logistics to develop logistics and warehousing facilities in China. The partnership, inked in February 2018, aims to leverage Ping An's asset base and expertise. The joint venture company is expected to be set up by the end of the year. OKH Global will provide design, development, and leasing expertise, while Ping An will offer asset management, construction financing, and trade finance. The partnership focuses on cities in China's south and southwest.

site_title: Portrait Of Joni
summary: David Yaffe's biography "Reckless Daughter: A Portrait of Joni Mitchell" is a tribute to the influential singer-songwriter. Yaffe first discovered Mitchell's album "Blue" at 15 and has been a fan since. The book delves into Mitchell's life and career, as well as the genius behind iconic songs like "Both Sides Now" and "A Case Of You." Available at Kinokuniya for S$43.50 (hardcover).

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Reckless Daughter: A Portrait of Joni Mitchell by David Yaffe.

site_title: Some welcome muscle for comply-or-explain governance code
summary: Singapore's Code of Corporate Governance is set to be strengthened with a revised comply-or-explain regime, requiring listed companies to explicitly state deviations from the Code and justify their practices. The change aims to hold companies and directors accountable for not following the Code, addressing the current issue of boilerplate explanations for non-compliance. The revised regime will set a minimum standard against which issuers can be measured, and shareholders are urged to scrutinize their companies' practices and demand greater accountability from their boards.

site_title: China tycoon in talks to buy MassMutual's hotels
summary: Chinese real estate tycoon Cai Kui's family office, Junson Capital, is in talks to buy a US hotel portfolio from MassMutual for up to $800 million. The portfolio includes seven to eight boutique hotels and resort properties, with negotiations ongoing. This deal highlights Chinese investors' ability to acquire global real estate assets despite new restrictions. It follows $11.7 billion in announced hotel acquisitions by Asian companies in the past year, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Manulife Real Estate acquired the 14-storey office tower at 800 Collins Street in Melbourne, its first Australian commercial real estate acquisition. Hyflux's controlling shareholder Olivia Lum must make a general offer for the water treatment company's consumer business after a dividend in specie distribution. GuocoLand reported a 25% drop in net profit to S$43 million in the second quarter due to a divestment gain, while its revenue jumped 60% to S$370.6 million.

site_title: Mastercard profit slumps on one-time charge related to new tax law
summary: Mastercard reported a 76% drop in quarterly profit to $227 million, or 21 cents per share, due to a one-time charge of $981 million related to US tax law changes. This was below analysts' expectations of $1.12 per share. Despite a 21% increase in net revenue to $3.31 billion, the company's earnings fell short. The charge, which was a non-recurring item, affected Mastercard's quarterly performance.

site_title: India moves to stub out tobacco with Roman law doctrine
summary: India is pushing the Supreme Court to apply a Roman law doctrine, "res extra commercium," to strip tobacco companies of their right to trade, aiming to deter them from challenging new regulations. The doctrine, which classifies tobacco as "outside commerce," would give authorities more leeway to impose restrictions. If applied, it could pave the way for a ban on tobacco sales, a goal of the Indian government to curb tobacco consumption, which kills over 900,000 people annually.

site_title: GuocoLand's Q2 profit drops on absence of divestment gain from associate
summary: GuocoLand Limited reported a 25% drop in net profit to S$43 million in Q2 2018 due to a one-time divestment gain in the comparative period. Revenue jumped 60% to S$370.6 million, driven by stronger sales and progressive revenue recognition from Singapore residential projects. The company's share of profit from associates and joint ventures fell to S$9 million from S$44.8 million a year ago. For the first half, GuocoLand's net profit more than doubled to S$208.5 million, driven by higher revenue and share of profit from associates and joint ventures.

site_title: Takeda hikes outlook on cancer drug sales, Q3 profit jumps 60%
summary: Takeda Pharmaceutical Co Ltd reported a 60% increase in Q3 profit to 87.9 billion yen, exceeding analyst estimates. The company attributed the boost to strong sales of its cancer drug Velcade and digestive disease treatments, such as Entyvio and Takecab. Takeda's annual profit is expected to reach a six-year high, driven by its focus on cancer and disease treatments. The company's patent for Velcade has been upheld, allowing it exclusive rights to sell the drug until 2022.

site_title: India Budget boosts spending to drive economy
summary: India's government has announced a massive budget boost to drive the economy, with a focus on rural areas and projected economic growth above 8%. The proposed 14.34 trillion Indian rupees (S$296 billion) expenditure and revenue plan includes 14.34 trillion rupees for rural infrastructure spending and extra support for farmers. The budget aims to create jobs and entrepreneurs, and promote agriculture, organic farming, and fisheries. Economists generally welcomed the budget, but bond and share markets fell due to higher deficit targets and a new tax on long-term gains from stocks.

site_title: SGX requires Datapulse to inform possible acquisitions involving Ang Kong Meng in advance
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has required Datapulse Technology to inform it in advance of any possible acquisitions involving Ang Kong Meng, the vendor of Wayco Manufacturing, which Datapulse had agreed to acquire. Datapulse directors dispute the requisition notice, citing irregularities in the notice's validity. The group led by Ng Bie Tjin has requisitioned extraordinary general meetings to replace directors and deter diversification plans, but the SGX's requirement may hinder their efforts.

site_title: Like Pfizer, Roche sees US tax cut boosting 2018 profit
summary: Roche Holding AG expects a boost in 2018 profit due to US tax cuts for businesses, offsetting the impact of its significant transformation. Core earnings per share are projected to grow in the high single digits, driven by new medicines in cancer and emerging areas. Sales growth will slow this year, but the company is confident in its portfolio and recent launches to compensate. Roche's tax rate is expected to drop from 26.6% to the low 20s range, thanks to the US tax law changes.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on hawkish Fed, tepid earnings
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday due to a hawkish Federal Reserve and tepid earnings. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.37%, the S&P 500 lost 0.18%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.32%. The Fed raised its inflation outlook, contributing to the market's decline.

site_title: Bitcoin skids to two-month low after Facebook ad ban unnerves investors
summary: Bitcoin plummeted 11% to its two-month low of $9,022, its lowest since late November, due to a Facebook ad ban and growing regulatory concerns. The cryptocurrency's value has slid 26% in the past month, with other digital coins like Ripple and Bitcoin Cash also experiencing double-digit declines. The ban on cryptocurrency adverts and concerns over money laundering and speculation have unnerved investors, with some warning of a sector collapse.

site_title: Uptick in luxury watch sales in 2017
summary: Luxury watch sales in Switzerland saw a significant uptick in 2017, with global exports rising 2.7% to 19.9 billion Swiss francs. Shipments to key markets such as Singapore, Hong Kong, and China also rebounded, with increases of 8.5%, 6%, and 18.8% respectively. Industry analysts expect the recovery to continue into 2018, with growth projected at 5% for the year. Swiss watchmakers, including Swatch Group and Richemont Group, reported strong sales and profits in 2017, with Swatch Group's net income rising 27.3% to 755 million Swiss francs.

images.alt_text: The IWC booth at the Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie (SIHH) in Geneva. Exports of Switzerland's luxury watches to Singapore, like its watch shipments to the rest of the world, are picking up after two years of decline.

site_title: Markets see clear skies ahead amid summer breeze
summary: Markets are optimistic about the business cycle, with many analysts predicting it will continue for several years. Low inflation, high US consumer confidence, and emerging economies' early cycles are cited as factors supporting the recovery. While some signs of exuberance exist, such as high US consumer sentiment, analysts remain patient and expect the economy to "let the slack work itself out." The business cycle is expected to continue in the US, Europe, and Japan, with China's growth expected to slow but still outperforming expectations.

site_title: Trade deal with Britain must prevent unfair tax, labour competition - EU
summary: The European Union is seeking to prevent Britain from using low taxes, state subsidies, or lower environmental and labor standards to gain a competitive edge after Brexit. EU diplomats have proposed inserting a "non-regression clause" into the free trade agreement, which would require Britain to maintain a "level playing field" with the EU. The EU is also concerned about Britain's ability to subsidize export industries and has proposed treaty rules to limit this. To enforce the agreement, the EU and Britain would need to agree on dispute resolution mechanisms and sanctions, including potential blacklisting of Britain as a non-cooperative jurisdiction on tax matters.

site_title: Why the UK shouldn't go for a hasty Brexit
summary: The UK's hasty Brexit plan poses significant risks to its interests and is based on an irrational basis for deciding Britain's future. The two-year time limit for negotiating the UK's withdrawal from the EU is too short, and the proposed "transition period" may not be sufficient. An extension of the transition period under Article 50 by two or more years would be a more practical solution, allowing the UK to maintain access to the EU market and enjoy the benefits of EU membership. However, EU leaders are hesitant to offer such an extension, fearing it could be used as a bargaining tactic or to block EU reforms.

site_title: Uber plots expansion in Singapore and Japan despite talk of retreat
summary: Uber is planning to expand its operations in Japan and Singapore, despite recent speculation about a potential retreat from Asia. Head of Uber's business in the region, Brooks Entwistle, stated that Uber will continue to grow and compete in the markets, including against local players Grab in Singapore and Ola in India. Uber's CEO Dara Khosrowshahi emphasized the company's global scope and plans to remain aggressive in expansion, while SoftBank, Uber's largest shareholder, has expressed a desire for Uber to withdraw from certain Asian markets.

site_title: There's hope for change - only if everyone stands firm
summary: A powerful shift towards decency is unfolding in the US, driven by the #MeToo movement, reactions to mass killings, and activism at the ballot box. This "regime change cascade" phenomenon, where people take a stand and inspire others to do the same, may lead to transformative change. The author sees this as a hopeful moment, contrasting with the Alt-Right Spring of 2016-17, where white supremacists were emboldened. While there's no guarantee of success, the author believes a real uprising is underway, with the forces of decency gaining momentum and potentially leading to change.

site_title: Emerging Gulf State cyber security firm growing fast in size and revenue
summary: A UAE-based cybersecurity firm, Darkmatter, has rapidly expanded, tripling its workforce to 650 and generating hundreds of millions of dollars in revenue, largely from government contracts. The company, founded by Emirati entrepreneur Faisal al-Bannai, advises the UAE government on cybersecurity and provides defensive security tools. Its revenue has doubled annually, positioning it to compete with major companies like IBM and Lockheed Martin. Darkmatter's relationship with the UAE government is a commercial transaction, with the country seeking a local partner to build cybersecurity capabilities.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's household income inequality has fallen to an 18-year low, with a Gini coefficient of 0.452 last year. The South Korean won and Singapore dollar are experiencing downward pressure due to the worsening coronavirus outbreak in Asia. ANZ has cut Singapore's 2020 growth outlook to 0.4%, citing public consumption and fiscal support. Hongkong Land has acquired a prime plot in Shanghai's West Bund for 31 billion yuan. The Straits Times Index fell 0.5% as Budget euphoria waned.

images.alt_text: THE Gini coefficient, based on household income from work per household member, was 0.452 last year, lower than the 0.458 in 2018 and its lowest since 2001.

site_title: Fraud and graft in India and China weakening their economies: studies
summary: China's and India's failure to address corruption and fraud has weakened their economies. China's "shadow banking" system, comprising unregulated loans and wealth products, is a significant concern. India's non-performing loans are estimated at $147 billion, with banking fraud and corruption cases mounting. The Bank for International Settlements estimates that China's shadow banking assets total $8.5 trillion, accounting for 55% of the country's GDP. India's alleged debt fraud crisis is worsening, with potential losses rising to $2 billion. The governments of both countries are taking steps to clean up their financial systems, with China's National People's Congress meeting expected to address the issue.

site_title: WWII bomb defused in Hong Kong after thousands evacuated
summary: A WWII-era bomb was defused in Hong Kong's Wan Chai district after thousands were evacuated and roads were closed. The bomb, discovered on Wednesday, was the second found in the area within a week. Bomb disposal experts worked through the night, using a crane to lift the earth-covered bomb off the site after cutting a large hole to burn off explosive materials. The challenge was exacerbated by rain, a tricky location, and a fuse mechanism that was difficult to see. No injuries were reported, and the incident is the latest in a series of wartime bomb discoveries in the city.

site_title: Millennial traders flee boring banking to chase riches in crypto
summary: Millennial traders, disillusioned with the decline of the banking industry, are flocking to cryptocurrency markets, seeking the thrill and riches of the past. Notable examples include Arthur Hayes, co-founder of BitMEX, a cryptocurrency exchange that offers leveraged bets on digital currencies. Hayes and his peers, many of whom were former Deutsche Bank employees, are constructing marketplaces for virtual currencies with features similar to traditional finance. However, concerns about the lack of regulation, volatility, and potential for money laundering are mounting, with regulators cracking down on cryptocurrencies and financial institutions warning of the risks.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise at open
summary: Europe's major stock markets rose in opening trade on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index gaining 0.2%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 adding 0.4%, and Paris's CAC 40 climbing 0.5%. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, while US-EU trade talks were also in focus. Despite tariff uncertainty, the Singapore Stock Exchange Index (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks suffer fresh losses at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted over 1% at the opening on Thursday, extending losses from the previous two days. The Hang Seng Index fell 1.19%, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.75% and the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.60%. The losses followed a sell-off on Wall Street.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.4% up
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 13 points, or 0.4%, to 3,547.23 on Thursday, snapping a two-day losing streak. 2.8 billion shares worth S$1.7 billion were traded, with 222 gainers and 219 losers. Despite US tariff uncertainty and split Fed views, investors remained positive, driving the market higher.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: WeWork plans Japan expansion, eyes Osaka, Yokohama and Fukuoka
summary: WeWork Co, backed by SoftBank Group Corp, plans to expand its Japan operations to Osaka, Yokohama, and Fukuoka. The company aims to open 10-12 offices in the Tokyo area this year, starting with a location in Shibuya. WeWork's first co-working space in Japan opened in mid-February, housing 886 desks and is fully booked. The company plans to unveil more locations, including Marunouchi Kitaguchi and Ginza Six, with an aggressive expansion plan backed by a US$4.4 billion investment from SoftBank.

site_title: OKH Global to develop logistics and warehouse facilities in China with Ping An unit
summary: OKH Global, a Singaporean property developer, has signed a memorandum of understanding with Ping An Industrial and Logistics to develop logistics and warehouse facilities in China. The joint venture is expected to be set up by the second half of the year, leveraging Ping An's asset base and expertise. OKH Global will provide design, development, and asset management expertise, while Ping An will offer construction financing and trade finance. Cities in China's south and southwest have been identified for the projects, marking a strategic expansion into the Chinese market.

site_title: Sumitomo resumes output at Ambatovy nickel-cobalt project
summary: Sumitomo Corp has resumed production at the Ambatovy nickel-cobalt project in Madagascar, halted earlier due to cyclone damages. The operation is currently slow but plans to gradually ramp up output. The company will disclose its estimated nickel output for the January-March quarter on February 8.

site_title: Keppel O&M CEO, Mediacorp editor-in-chief join MPA board
summary: Keppel O&M CEO Chris Ong and Mediacorp editor-in-chief Walter Fernandez have been appointed to the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) board, replacing SembCorp Marine's Wong Weng Sun. The MPA's board now consists of 13 members, chaired by Niam Chiang Meng. The appointments were made as part of the MPA's efforts to refresh its leadership.

site_title: Factories start 2018 on solid footing
summary: Factories globally started 2018 on a strong note, with manufacturing activity in most countries reaching multi-year highs. The euro zone's booming manufacturing industry, particularly in Germany, Italy, France, and Spain, reinforced expectations of synchronized global expansion. However, Britain's manufacturing lost momentum, partly due to uncertainties over its path to leave the EU. Asia's strongest manufacturing readings came from tech exporters, driven by the robust semiconductor cycle, while China's factory growth appeared resilient despite crackdowns on air pollution and excessive financial risks.

site_title: Goldilocks says Noble's response "appears designed" to discredit its major shareholder
summary: NOBLE Group and major shareholder Goldilocks Investment Company are engaged in a dispute over restructuring and financial proposals. Noble claims Goldilocks demanded two board seats as a pre-condition, but Goldilocks says this is misleading. The Abu Dhabi-based fund, which owns 8.1% of Noble, believes Noble's response appears designed to discredit it and pit it against other shareholders and creditors. Goldilocks has requested clarification on Noble's financial situation and track record, and will provide further updates if necessary.

site_title: Motor racing: New Tesla-based electric series gets FIA approval
summary: A new electric production car series, the Electric GT Holdings (EPCS) championship, has received FIA approval. The series, featuring Tesla Model S P100D cars, will start in mid-2018 with 20 drivers competing in 60km day and dusk races. The car passed its official FIA crash test and will have a maximum of 585kW (778hp) of power. The championship will also include eKarting and eSports rounds, building on the success of Formula E, which is planning a production-based electric series later this year.

site_title: Ice, ice baby: Unilever posts rising 2017 profits
summary: Unilever posted 6.5 billion euros in 2017 profits, a 16.9% increase, driven by strong sales in Asia and organic product growth. The company, which rejected a Kraft Heinz takeover bid in 2017, achieved its savings target of 6 billion euros and aims to reach a targeted underlying operating margin of 20% by 2020. Unilever acquired several companies, including Betty Ice, and has vowed to prove its ability to deliver better profitability despite a restructuring plan and divestment of its margarine division.

site_title: Hong Kong retail sales rise in 2017, ending slump, as tourism picks up
summary: Hong Kong's retail sales rose 2.2% in 2017, ending a three-year slump, driven by increased tourist arrivals from mainland China and strong property and share prices. Retail sales reached HK$446.1 billion, with December being the 10th consecutive month of annual gains. Analysts expect continued growth in 2018, with forecasts ranging from 3-6% growth. The city's jobless rate dropped below 3% for the first time in nearly 20 years, supporting the retail sector's recovery.

site_title: EU makes bid to board blockchain bandwagon
summary: The European Union is launching a blockchain observatory and forum to explore the technology's broader uses beyond its original role in bitcoin markets. Consensys will work with EU officials to gather information, analyze trends, and find new applications. The EU aims to make financial markets more efficient, quicker, and energy-efficient, while also considering its use in other applications, such as digital health information. The initiative is part of the EU's efforts to coordinate research projects across the bloc and address concerns about the risks of monopolies and speculative bubbles.

site_title: AEM acquires MEMS tester Afore Oy; executes succession plan
summary: AEM Holdings, a Singapore-based semiconductor test handler, has acquired Finnish firm Afore Oy for 7.58 million euros (S$12.3 million). The deal aims to expand AEM's micro-electro mechanical system (MEMS) test solutions, valued at 10.6 times price to earnings. The acquisition is expected to take AEM a step closer to diversified growth, with the company forecasting a 6% share of the worldwide MEMS test handler market. AEM plans to close the deal by the end of February and has booked sales orders exceeding S$115 million for delivery in the first half of 2018.

site_title: Genting HK to sell back shares in Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings for total US$128.9m gain
summary: Genting Hong Kong Limited, a subsidiary of Genting Hong Kong Limited, is selling 19.5 million shares in Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings for US$128.9 million, resulting in a gain of approximately US$24.4 million. The shares are being sold to Morgan Stanley at US$56 apiece, with NCLH agreeing to repurchase the shares. The disposal will reduce Genting HK's stake in NCLH from 5.64% to 1.41%. Proceeds from the sale will be used as general working capital and capital expenditure for the group.

images.alt_text: Ann Williams

site_title: Ascendas Hospitality Trust posts 14% drop in Q3 DPS to 1.41 Singapore cents
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust reported a 14% drop in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.41 Singapore cents in Q3 2017, due to weaker performance in its Australia portfolio and translation losses. Net property income (NPI) fell 4.7% to S$25.2 million. Despite this, room revenue for the Australia portfolio remained healthy, with a 1.9% increase in revenue per available room (RevPAR). The trust manager remains optimistic about the Australia portfolio's long-term prospects.

site_title: Acromec signs MOU with Green Energy Resources to explore renewable energy opportunities
summary: Acromec, a CATALIST-listed engineering company, signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Green Energy Resources to explore opportunities in renewable energy. The agreement, valid for six months, covers cooperation on build-own-operate (BOO) energy projects and collaboration on renewable energy plants. Acromec will contribute expertise in controlled environments engineering, while Green Energy Resources will contribute expertise in green technologies. The MOU aims to create an additional stream of income for Acromec, capitalizing on its existing niche expertise in the renewable energy segment.

images.alt_text: CATALIST-listed engineering company Acromec announced that it has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Malaysian alternative energy specialist Green Energy Resources (GER) to explore opportunities in renewable energy.

site_title: Americans are finally returning to Macy's to shop for, yes, clothes
summary: Macy's reported a 1.4% sales growth in the most recent quarter, marking the first period of sales growth in over three years. The retailer attributed the increase to a renewed focus on apparel, leading to a 1.8% increase in fourth-quarter sales to $8.67 billion. Profits nearly tripled to $1.3 billion, or $4.31 a share, from $472 million, or $1.54 a share, a year earlier. This turnaround comes as Macy's faces increasing competition from Amazon and aims to revitalize its sales and customer base.

site_title: Carmaker PSA, Malaysia's Naza sign deal to produce PSA cars for Asia
summary: French carmaker PSA and Malaysian company Naza Corp have signed a deal to jointly produce PSA-branded cars for Malaysia and other Asian markets. The Malaysian plant, to be built in Gurun, Kedah, will have a capacity of 50,000 vehicles and produce Peugeot and Citroën models starting in 2018 and 2019, respectively. This deal is part of PSA's "Push to Pass" plan to boost sales by 10% by 2018 and 15% by 2021. The joint venture aims to develop a profitable business in the region.

site_title: UK house prices surged in Jan as few homes come to market
summary: UK house prices rose 0.6% in January, driven by a shortage of properties coming to market. This lifted the annual gain to 3.2%, the fastest since March. Despite slower economic growth and reduced consumer incomes, the market has shown resilience. Mortgage approvals fell to a three-year low, but the property market remains subdued, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors.

site_title: Hong Kong authorities on alert as ATM withdrawals surge
summary: Hong Kong authorities are on high alert as ATM withdrawals surge, with reports of mainland Chinese individuals using up to 50 cards at a time to withdraw hundreds of thousands of dollars. This comes as China has battled to curb capital outflows, with a new measure capping overseas withdrawals using domestic Chinese bank cards. The surge in withdrawals has raised concerns among monetary authorities, banks, and police.

site_title: EC World Reit's Q4 DPU rises to 1.5 S cents; to buy e-commerce logistics asset for S$31m
summary: EC World Reit reported a 3.6% increase in income available for distribution to S$11.8 million in Q4, resulting in a 1.5 Singapore cent DPU, despite a 17.6% drop in net property income and 16.4% decline in gross revenue. The company attributed the decline to accounting adjustments and a provision for impairment in other receivables. EC World will spend S$31 million to acquire a 100% equity interest in Wuqiao Zhonggong Merlot (Hubei) Logistics, which it believes will enhance its proposition as a specialised logistics Reit and grant it exposure to favourable macroeconomic fundamentals in Wuhan.

site_title: Spotify files US$1b IPO, eyeing streaming growth despite losses
summary: Spotify has filed a US$1 billion initial public offering, listing its shares on the New York Stock Exchange. Despite being deep in the red, the Swedish music streaming service expresses confidence in its soaring growth, driven by the streaming revolution it spearheaded. The IPO filing provides detailed financial information, marking the company's long-awaited listing.

site_title: Aussie shares end at over 3-week high; NZ also up
summary: Australian shares closed at a three-week high, rising 0.7% to 6,042.2, driven by a strong finish on Wall Street after the Federal Reserve eased concerns over its monetary policy stance. The 'Big Four' banks and retailers fueled gains, with Woolworths Group and Woodside Petroleum rising 2.1% and 1.8%, respectively. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 0.5%, marking a fourth consecutive session of gains, while QBE Insurance Group dropped 3% after reporting a US$1.25 billion annual loss.

site_title: Galapagos hosts nursery for new species of giant tortoise
summary: The Galapagos Islands have a nursery for a new species of giant tortoise, the eastern Santa Cruz tortoise (Chelondis donfaustoi), which was discovered in 2016. The nursery, located on Santa Cruz island, is part of the national park and is one of three centers breeding 12 species of unique giant tortoises. The tortoises were kept safe and raised in captivity after being determined to be a new species, native to the Galapagos Islands that inspired Charles Darwin's theory of evolution.

images.alt_text: Crowded under a rock in the Galapagos archipelago, the baby tortoises wait for the sun to go down to leave their shelter.

site_title: It pays to realise your full brand potential
summary: Asian companies are enhancing brand value across four dimensions: reputational, organisational, societal, and financial. Examples include Emirates Airlines, which built trust through service excellence and product quality, and Shinhan Bank of Korea, which restored trust and confidence with employees and customers after scandals. Singapore's SGInnovate also contributes to societal value by backing founders to tackle global challenges. These companies demonstrate the importance of realising brand potential to achieve financial value, with Emirates and Shinhan Bank experiencing significant growth and recognition.

images.alt_text: Emirates' success is not from clever marketing programmes and beguiling advertising. Rather, it has built trust over its corporate life through a conscientious investment in service excellence, product quality and commitment to follow through.

site_title: China's appetite for foreign agricultural land keeps growing
summary: China's increasing appetite for foreign agricultural land is driven by its massive population and food safety concerns. With 1.4 billion mouths to feed, China seeks to acquire arable land abroad, investing at least $94 billion since 2010. Private and state-owned Chinese enterprises have acquired 9 million hectares in developing countries, with recent focus on Australia, the US, and Europe. Notable deals include the purchase of a large ranch in Australia and US company Smithfield Foods, and the acquisition of New Zealand dairy farms. This trend highlights China's growing reliance on imported food.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.48 points to 1,853.51. Volume was 25.97 million lots worth RM9.47 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 81 to 56.

site_title: Singapore, Japan now ranked world's most powerful passports in global index
summary: Singapore and Japan have jointly taken the top spot as the world's most powerful passports, with visa-free access to 180 destinations. This surpasses Germany's passport, which offers visa-free access to 179 destinations. The rise in rankings comes after Uzbekistan lifted visa requirements for Singapore and Japan earlier this month, and other countries in Asia and the Middle East also followed suit. The Henley Passport Index attributes this shift to increased visa-policy activity in the Asian and Middle Eastern regions.

images.alt_text: Singapore's and Japan's rise up the rankings comes after Uzbekistan lifted visa requirements for citizens of both countries earlier this month.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2018 to continue efforts to help firms transform: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's Budget 2018 will focus on helping firms innovate and transform, with efforts to build deep capabilities in companies and forge stronger partnerships. Minister for National Development and Second Minister for Finance Lawrence Wong expressed support for corporate-level innovation and transformation, citing Esco Group's transformation and research and development efforts. The budget aims to facilitate more such innovation and transformation in the country.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: China drowns out critics of lifetime Xi presidency
summary: China's National People's Congress is set to endorse a constitutional amendment that scrapes term limits for President Xi Jinping, allowing him to rule for life. The move has sparked criticism on social media, with users defying censorship attempts and sharing dissenting comments. State media has defended the amendment, praising the Communist Party's leadership and claiming it will lead to "happier lives." The move is expected to be ratified next week, giving Xi a clear path to maintain power beyond 2023.

images.alt_text: China's propaganda machine kicked into overdrive Tuesday to defend the Communist Party's move to scrap term limits for President Xi Jinping as critics on social media again defied censorship attempts.

site_title: SGX requests Datapulse to appoint independent reviewer to audit company
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has requested Datapulse Technology to appoint an independent reviewer to audit the company's internal controls and corporate governance practices. The request comes after the company reshuffled its board of directors and diversified its business. Datapulse has until March 9 to comply. This move is part of the SGX's efforts to ensure the company's compliance with regulatory requirements.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares weaken as energy, finance stocks fall
summary: Hong Kong shares declined 0.75% at close, tracking Asian markets lower, with energy and finance stocks leading the drop. The Hang Seng index fell 245.18 points to 32,642.09. China's Shanghai Composite index also dropped 0.99%, while the CSI300 index fell 0.71%.

site_title: Judge halts construction of oil pipeline in Louisiana on eco concerns
summary: A US federal judge in Louisiana revoked a permit for the Bayou Bridge crude oil pipeline, halting its construction due to eco concerns. The decision was made following protests by local and environmental groups, who cited risks to the environment, health, and local economy. The pipeline route passes through the Atchafalaya Basin, a critical flood protection system and source of livelihood for commercial fishing. The judge's ruling requires the US Army Corps of Engineers to revisit its approval of the pipeline's construction.

site_title: India unveils healthcare for 500 million of its poorest
summary: India has unveiled a national healthcare scheme for 500 million of its poorest citizens, providing up to 500,000 rupees (S$10,291) a year for hospital cover. The initiative aims to increase public healthcare spending from 1% of GDP to 2.5% by 2025. This major giveaway is seen as a move to boost voter turnout ahead of the general election.

images.alt_text: India on Thursday announced a national healthcare scheme for half a billion of its poorest citizens in a major giveaway to voters in the final budget before a general election.

site_title: Shell's best profit in 3 years marred by surprise cash-flow drop
summary: Royal Dutch Shell Plc posted an adjusted profit of $4.3 billion in the last quarter, its highest since 2014, driven by improved exploration and production. However, cash flow was the weakest since 2016 due to higher tax payments and increased trading expenses. Despite the mixed results, Shell's CEO Ben Van Beurden expressed confidence in the company's ability to deliver strong returns and cash. The company's profit was boosted by the rise in Brent crude to a three-year high.

images.alt_text: The oil-price rally proved a double-edged sword for Royal Dutch Shell Plc, as improved exploration and production lifted profit to a three-year high while refining and trading fell short of expectations.

site_title: Oil drops on large inventory increase, profit taking
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday after US crude inventories rose by 3 million barrels, exceeding analyst expectations, and petrol stocks also increased. US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 2.17% to $61.64 a barrel and Brent crude futures dropped 2.7% to $64.73 a barrel. The market was also influenced by a stronger dollar and stock market declines. Despite rising US production, oil prices remain under pressure due to a larger-than-expected inventory increase and supply cuts by OPEC.

images.alt_text: Oil prices fell on Wednesday, after official data showed a larger-than-expected increase in US crude inventories and a surprise build in petrol stocks.

site_title: Turn up the gas: Japan LNG imports hit 5-year high as cold bites
summary: Japan's liquefied natural gas (LNG) imports surged to nearly 8.7 million tonnes in January, a 5-year high, due to freezing weather. This increase is putting pressure on regional spot markets, which reached three-year highs in the same month. China's drive to use gas for heating homes and factories has fueled the demand, while the global market is affected by US President Trump's tariff policies. As a result, LNG prices are expected to continue rising.

images.alt_text: Japanese imports of liquefied natural gas (LNG) hit their highest in at least five years in January, with shipments expected to continue at a brisk pace this month as freezing weather keeps its grip on the world's top buyer of the fuel.

site_title: Surviving the generations
summary: Swiss private bank Lombard Odier credits its long-term survival to independence, astute succession planning, and a focus on discretionary management. The bank, owned and run by seven managing partners, has maintained its independence by avoiding conflicts of interest and staying out of the transactional business. This approach has allowed it to differentiate itself and preserve its franchise. Lombard Odier has also invested in technology, which has enabled it to stay agile and nimble in the industry. The bank's long-term survival is also attributed to its ability to adapt to changing market conditions, including a focus on fixed income risks and a shift towards non-rated, creditworthy companies.

images.alt_text: "We're not forced by anyone to accept an idea. We're not forced to buy an investment vehicle, we're not asked by a general assembly of shareholders to perform better for the next quarter." - PATRICK ODIER.

site_title: Three taken to hospital after letter opened at Virginia military base
summary: Three people were taken to a hospital after a letter containing an unknown substance was opened at a US military base in Arlington, Virginia. Eleven people fell ill, and the incident is under investigation by the Naval Criminal Investigative Service and the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The Marine Corps stated that the building was screened and cleared after the letter was removed. The condition of the three hospitalized individuals is stable.

site_title: Consumer, property in play post-Budget
summary: The Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) fell 11.35 points, or 0.33%, to close at 3,476.53 after Budget announcements on a higher Goods and Services Tax (GST) and Buyers' Stamp Duty (BSD). Consumer stocks like Genting Singapore rose 3.2% due to a delayed GST hike, while Best World International and Hi-P International also saw gains. However, Thai Beverage slid 2.3% after missing expectations in its latest results. Semiconductor plays AEM and Micro-Mechanics remained hot, with Hi-P International reaching a historical high.

site_title: Major Xerox investor sues to block takeover by Fujifilm
summary: Major Xerox investor Darwin Deason is suing to block the company's planned takeover by Fujifilm, citing allegations of fraud. Deason, who controls 15.2% of Xerox shares, claims the deal is not in the best interest of the company or its shareholders. Xerox has denied the allegations, stating the deal is the best path to create value for the company and its shareholders. The planned deal would result in Fujifilm holding 50.1% of the joint venture, down from 75%. Xerox has stated it will "vigorously defend itself" against Deason's claims.

site_title: TMC Education announces new management and board
summary: TMC Education Corporation, a CATALIST-listed company, has announced new management and board of directors following the sale of its education subsidiary, TMC Academy, to its former controlling shareholders for S$6.32 million. The sale completes the disposal of TMC Academy, and the new management includes Koh Kian Soo as executive chairman and CEO, and Tan Chee Wee as executive director and COO. The company has also changed its sponsor and appointed new independent directors, effective May 1.

site_title: Qantas faces looming funding crunch to renew fleet: report
summary: Qantas faces a potential funding crunch when it's time to renew its fleet, with the average age of its planes being nearly 10 years, older than peers. The airline needs to increase investment, but has delayed spending, creating a "sizable funding task" from 2020. Qantas may have to reduce shareholder returns or tap equity markets, restricted by its own debt target and an Australian law limiting foreign ownership. The airline rejects the report, stating its current investment is adequate, but a credit analyst says a "step change" is needed.

images.alt_text: Qantas doesn't plan to increase capital expenditure this year or the next, creating a "sizable funding task" from 2020 onward, S&P said.

site_title: North Korea warms to South Korea after visit, pressure to be kept in place for now
summary: North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un expressed a desire to boost inter-Korean engagement after a high-level delegation visited South Korea, following a three-day visit by his younger sister Kim Yo Jong to the Pyeongchang Winter Olympics. The US and Japan have reiterated the need for maximum pressure and sanctions on North Korea, while South Korean President Moon Jae In has pushed for a diplomatic solution to the standoff over North Korea's nuclear and missile programmes. The US and South Korea have appeared to endorse deeper post-Olympics engagement, while Japan has stressed the importance of maintaining international pressure.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks edge up on weak yen
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.21% to 21,970.81, driven by a weak yen against the dollar. The broader Topix index lost 0.05%. This moderate market revival follows recent market sentiment.

site_title: Malaysian firm adds Islamic certification to cryptocurrency
summary: Malaysia-based firm HelloGold has received a Syariah-compliant certification for its gold-backed cryptocurrency, GOLDX, which is backed by physical gold stored in a Singapore vault. The certification, from Amanie Advisors, addresses transparency, certainty, and immediacy of transactions, key principles in Islamic financial contracts. HelloGold plans to launch its online gold platform in Thailand later this year, expanding its influence in Islamic finance markets in Southeast Asia.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks down as investors still cautious after rout
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.65% on Tuesday, closing at 21,244.68, due to late profit-taking and a strong yen. Despite two days of gains on Wall Street, investors remained cautious. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index lost 137.94 points. The decline follows a rally in Singapore stocks and comes as investors await GDP data.

site_title: S'pore firm making a difference differently
summary: A Singaporean marine civil engineering firm, HSL Constructor, is making a difference through its Corporate Citizen Foundation (CCF) and Swift Emergency Evaluation Deployment (SEED) initiatives. Established in 1994, the firm has contributed over $1 million to the CCF, which aims to improve the capacity and resilience of vulnerable communities in Asia. SEED, its first responders, has responded to several disasters, including super typhoons and earthquakes. HSL's efforts focus on sustainable livelihood and disaster management programs, and the company has collaborated with various organizations, including the Asean Centre for Humanitarian Assistance and Disaster Management.

images.alt_text: Mr Quek receiving a token of appreciation from PM Lee at the Berita Harian 60 Reminiscence by the River event. With them is Berita Harian editor Saat Abdul Rahman.

site_title: Deals for big planes in small supply at the Singapore Airshow
summary: At the Singapore Airshow, blockbuster commercial aircraft deals were missing in action, despite robust growth in passenger traffic. Analysts cite recent order boom for Boeing and Airbus, as well as last November's Dubai Airshow, as reasons for the tepid orders. Global passenger traffic is projected to expand at 6% this year, but the world's biggest plane-makers did not unveil any plane orders during the event.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Asian Pay Television Trust's Q4 profit falls 29% to S$11.5m
summary: Asian Pay Television Trust's Q4 profit fell 29% to S$11.5m due to higher income tax costs and a drop in net foreign exchange gain. Revenue increased 0.9% to S$84.7m, while earnings per unit dropped to 0.8 cents. The board reaffirmed distribution guidance for 2018 at 6.5 cents per unit, paid in quarterly instalments.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Lendingkart Technologies is seeking over $87 million in equity funding to expand its capabilities. Koh Brothers Group reported a 74% jump in fourth-quarter net profit despite a 21% plunge in revenue. NSL Engineering Holdings is looking to acquire a 30% stake in German engineering group Salzgitter Maschinenbau. Chip Eng Seng's fourth-quarter net profit shrank 2.4% due to lower other income and higher administrative expenses. Courts Asia reported a 28.7% drop in net profit due to lower credit sales in Malaysia.

site_title: South Korea police names Samsung chairman Lee as suspect for tax evasion
summary: South Korean police named Samsung Electronics Chairman Lee Kun Hee as a suspect in tax evasion allegations, citing bank accounts held in someone else's name worth 400 billion won (S$488.1 million). Lee, who has been hospitalized since a 2014 heart attack, has not commented on the matter. The allegations stem from his use of these accounts, leading to suspicions of tax evasion.

site_title: Coincheck theft exposes flaws in Japan's rules governing crypto coins
summary: Coincheck, a Japanese cryptocurrency exchange, suffered a $533 million theft in 2018, highlighting flaws in the country's rules governing crypto coins. Coincheck operated without regulatory approval, despite a 2014 Mt Gox hack that led to stricter regulations. The exchange was allowed to continue without oversight until its theft, sparking concerns about the effectiveness of Japan's regulatory framework. The incident raises questions about the need for stricter regulations in the cryptocurrency sector.

site_title: STI climbs back above 3,500 points
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) regained its 3,500-point mark, closing at 3,516.23, up 39.7 points or 1.1% on Wednesday. The rebound followed Hong Kong and Taiwan's gains, despite European stocks sliding and US yields increasing. Analysts attribute the STI's rise to banks' high single-digit loan growth forecasts and expected higher net interest margins.

site_title: With Easy Ride trial, Nissan takes new step towards being Uber competitor
summary: Nissan is taking steps to become an operator of autonomous transportation services with its Easy Ride trial, partnering with DeNA Co to test ride-hailing software in Japan. The service, set to launch in the early 2020s, will use Nissan's fleet of self-driving electric cars and aim to provide a concierge-like experience. This move aims to break into a segment dominated by Uber and other technology firms, as self-driving cars may curb vehicle ownership. Nissan's partnership marks a significant step towards the automaker's entry into the autonomous transportation market.

site_title: StarHub share price plunges after disappointing Q4 earnings
summary: StarHub's share price plummeted 10.14% to S$2.57 after releasing disappointing Q4 earnings, with net profit declining 74% year-over-year to S$47.1 million. Analysts attribute the decline to increased competition in the telecom industry, despite growth in the enterprise fixed services segment. A "sell" call has been reiterated by several analysts, citing concerns over the company's balance sheet and pricing pressure. The Bloomberg-compiled consensus target price now stands at S$2.44, with some analysts suggesting a "bear case" entry point below S$2.40.

images.alt_text: Annabeth Leow

site_title: Gamechangers in fintech
summary: Three Singapore-based fintech startups, M-Daq, CXA Group, and CCRManager, are making waves in the industry by addressing pressing concerns such as high forex spreads, escalating healthcare costs, and inefficient trade finance processes. M-Daq aims to reduce forex charges by 1-2%, while CXA Group targets healthcare costs for large employers, and CCRManager has created a platform for a secondary market for trade finance. Led by veterans in the finance business, these startups are partnering with large banks and insurers to improve processes and gain traction. With a focus on transparency and servant leadership, they are poised to emerge as Singapore's next big fintech players.
